original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully enlightened one

original: Dīghanikāye
analyzed: dīgha nikāye
translated: In the Dīgha Nikāya

original: Sīlakkhandhavaggaabhinavaṭīkā
translated: The New Commentary on the Chapter on Virtue

original: Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā
translated: The Introduction

original: Yo desetvāna saddhammaṃ, gambhīraṃ duddasaṃ varaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ desetvāna saddhammam gambhīram duddasam varam
translated: He who taught the true Dhamma, profound and excellent, difficult to see,

original: Dīghadassī ciraṃ kālaṃ, patiṭṭhāpesi sāsanaṃ.1.
analyzed: dīghadassī ciram kālam patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: The far-sighted one, for a long time, established the Dispensation.

original: Vineyyajjhāsaye chekaṃ, mahāmatiṃ mahādayaṃ;
analyzed: chekam mahāmatim mahā ādayam
translated: The one skilled in the disposition to be trained, of great wisdom, of great respect,

analyzed: natvāna tam sa sat dhamma gaṇam
translated: Having paid homage to him, together with the Dhamma and the Saṅgha, the vessel of respect.

original: Saṅgītittayamāruḷhā, dīghāgamavarassa yā;
analyzed: dīgha āgama varassa yā
translated: The one that is based on the three recitations, of the excellent Dīgha Āgama,

original: Saṃvaṇṇanā yā ca tassā, vaṇṇanā sādhuvaṇṇitā. 3.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā yā ca tassāḥ vaṇṇanā sādhu vaṇṇitā
translated: And the commentary on it, well-praised, the commentary.

original: Ācariyadhammapāla- ttherenevābhisaṅkhatā;
analyzed: ācariya dhammapāla ttherena iva abhisaṅkhatā
translated: Composed by the Elder Dhammapāla himself,

original: Sammā nipuṇagambhīra-duddasatthappakāsanā.4.
analyzed: sammā
translated: Clearly revealing the well-purified, profound, difficult-to-see Dhamma.

original: Kāmañca sā tathābhūtā, paramparābhatā pana;
analyzed: kāmam ca sā tathābhūtā paramparābhatā pana
translated: And although it is so, it is handed down by tradition,

original: Pāṭhato atthato cāpi, bahuppamādalekhanā.5.
analyzed: pāṭhataḥ atthataḥ ca api
translated: With many mistakes in the text, both in the recitation and the meaning.

original: Saṅkhepattā ca sotūhi, sammā ñātuṃ sudukkarā;
analyzed: ca sotūhi sammā ñātum su dukkarā
translated: And being brief, it is very difficult for listeners to understand correctly,

original: Tasmā sabrahmacārīnaṃ, yācanaṃ samanussaraṃ.6.
analyzed: tasmai sabrahmacārīnam yācanam
translated: Therefore, remembering the request of my fellow monks,

original: Yo’nekasetanāgindo, rājā nānāraṭṭhissaro;
analyzed: rājā nānā raṭṭhissaraḥ
translated: The king of many fears, the lord of various countries,

original: Sāsanasodhane daḷhaṃ, sadā ussāhamānaso.7.
analyzed: sāsana sodhane daḷham sadā
translated: And in the purification of the Dispensation, I was always full of zeal.

original: Taṃ nissāya “mamesopi, satthusāsanajotane;
analyzed: tam nissāya mama iso api satthu sāsana jotane
translated: And thinking: “If I can be of help, In the illumination of the Master’s Dispensation,

original: Appeva nāmupatthambho, bhaveyyā”ti vicintayaṃ.8.
analyzed: appā iva nāma upatthambhaḥ bhaveyyāti
translated: Even as a mere support,”

original: Vaṇṇanaṃ ārabhissāmi, sādhippāyamahāpayaṃ;
analyzed: vaṇṇanam ārabhissāmi sa adhippāya mahā payam
translated: I will undertake the commentary, With the great purpose in view,

original: Atthaṃ tamupanissāya, aññañcāpi yathārahaṃ.9.
analyzed: attham tam upanissāya aññam ca api
translated: And on the basis of that meaning, And also in other ways as is fitting.

original: Cakkābhivuḍḍhikāmānaṃ, dhīrānaṃ cittatosanaṃ;
analyzed: cakka abhivuḍḍhi kāmānam citta tosanam
translated: For the satisfaction of the minds Of the wise who desire to expand the wheel,

original: Sādhuvilāsiniṃ nāma, taṃ suṇātha samāhitāti. 10.
analyzed: sādhuvilāsinim nāma tam suṇātha samāhitā iti
translated: I will expound the commentary Called “The Delight in Good Exposition.” Listen with rapt attention.

original: Ganthārambhakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Introduction to the Text

original: Nānānayanipuṇagambhīravicitrasikkhattayasaṅgahassa buddhānubuddhasaṃvaṇṇitassa saddhāvahaguṇasampannassa
analyzed: nānā naya nipuṇa gambhīra vicitra sikkhattaya saṅgahassa buddha anubuddha saṃvaṇṇitassa saddhā vaha guṇa sampannassa
translated: The Buddha, who is endowed with the qualities that inspire faith, has been praised by the Buddhas of the past and future, and he has gathered the three trainings, which are profound, skillful, and varied.🔽This commentary, which illuminates the profound and difficult-to-understand meaning of the excellent Dīgha Nikāya,

original: dīghāgamavarassa gambhīraduranubodhatthadīpakaṃ saṃvaṇṇanamimaṃ karonto sakasamayasamayantaragahanajjhogāhanasamattho
analyzed: dīgha āgama varassa gambhīra duranubodha attha dīpakam saṃvaṇṇanam imam karontaḥ saka samaya samaya antara gahana ajjhogāhana samatthaḥ
translated: was composed by the great teacher, who is capable of penetrating the depths of his own time and other times,

original: mahāveyyākaraṇoyamācariyo saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmapayojanādividhānāni karonto
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇana ārambhe karonto
translated: when he was engaged in composing the commentary, and he set forth the purpose of paying homage to the Three Jewels and so on.

original: paṭhamaṃ tāva ratanattayapaṇāmaṃ kātuṃ “karuṇāsītalahadaya”ntiādimāha. Ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanārambhe
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva kātum ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: First of all, he says “Whose heart is cool with compassion” in order to make the homage to the Three Jewels. And here,🔽the teachers have elaborated in many ways on the purpose of making the homage at the beginning of the commentary.

original: ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇappayojanaṃ tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyā. Tathā hi vaṇṇayanti –
analyzed: tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyā tathā hi vaṇṇayanti
translated: They explain as follows:

original: “Saṃvaṇṇanārambhe satthari paṇāmakaraṇaṃ dhammassa svākkhātabhāvena satthari pasādajananatthaṃ,🔽satthu ca avitathadesanabhāvappakāsanena dhamme pasādajananatthaṃ. Tadubhayappasādā
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe satthari paṇāma karaṇam dhammassa svākkhāta bhāvena satthari pasāda janana attham  satthu ca avitatha desana bhāva pakāsanena dhamme pasāda janana attham tad ubhaya ppasādā
translated: “The purpose of making the homage to the Master at the beginning of the commentary is to generate confidence in the Master through the well-proclaimedness of the Dhamma,🔽and to generate confidence in the Dhamma through the demonstration of the Master’s untarnished teaching.

original: hi mahato atthassa siddhi hotī”ti.
analyzed: hi mahataḥ atthassa siddhi hoti iti
translated: For the success of great benefits comes through confidence in both of them.”

original: Atha vā “ratanattayapaṇāmavacanaṃ attano ratanattayappasādassa viññāpanatthaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: atha vā ratana ttaya paṇāma vacanam attanaḥ ratana ttaya ppasādassa viññāpana attham tam
translated: Or else: “The statement of homage to the Three Jewels is for the purpose of announcing one’s confidence in the Three Jewels,🔽which is for the purpose of pleasing the wise,🔽which is for the purpose of taking up the commentary,

original: pana viññūnaṃ cittārādhanatthaṃ, taṃ aṭṭhakathāya gāhaṇatthaṃ, taṃ sabbasampattinipphādanattha”nti.
analyzed: pana viññūnam citta ārādhana attham tam aṭṭhakathāya gāhaṇa attham tam sabba sampatti nipphādana attham ti
translated: which is for the purpose of producing all attainments.”

original: Atha vā “saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayavandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhavanissayavisuddhipaṭivedanatthaṃ,
analyzed: atha vā saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe ratana taya vandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhava nissaya visuddhi paṭivedana attham
translated: Or alternatively, the paying of homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the commentary is for the purpose of purifying the source of the Dhamma to be expounded,

original: taṃ pana dhammasaṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnaṃ bahumānuppādanatthaṃ, taṃ sammadeva tesaṃ uggahaṇadhāraṇādikkamaladdhabbāya
analyzed: tam pana dhamma saṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnam bahu māna uppādana attham tam sammat eva tesam uggahaṇa dhāraṇa ādi kama laddhabbāya
translated: and that is for the purpose of arousing respect in the wise for the Dhamma to be expounded, and that is for the purpose of producing the highest happiness by means of right practice, which is to be acquired by means of proper learning, memorization, etc.,

original: sammāpaṭipattiyā sabbahitasukhanipphādanattha”nti. Atha vā “maṅgalabhāvato, sabbakiriyāsu
analyzed: sammā paṭipattiyā sabba hita sukha nipphādana tthanti atha vā maṅgala bhāvataḥ sabba kiriyāsu
translated: Or alternatively, the paying of homage to the Three Jewels in the commentary is for the purpose of showing that it is a good omen, that it is the preliminary work in all undertakings,

original: pubbakiccabhāvato, paṇḍitehi samācaritabhāvato, āyatiṃ paresaṃ diṭṭhānugatiāpajjanato🔽ca saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ ratanattayapaṇāmakiriyā”ti. Atha vā “catugambhīrabhāvayuttaṃ dhammavinayaṃ🔽saṃvaṇṇetukāmassa mahāsamuddaṃ ogāhantassa viya paññāveyyattiyasamannāgatassāpi mahantaṃ
analyzed: pubba kicca bhāvataḥ paṇḍitehi samācarita bhāvataḥ āyatim paresam diṭṭha anugati āpajjanato  ca saṃvaṇṇanāyam atha vā catu gambhīra bhāva yuttam dhamma vinayam  saṃvaṇṇetu kāmassa mahā samuddam ogāhantassa viya paññā veyyattiya samannāgatassa api mahantam
translated: that it is the practice of the wise, and that it is the way to follow the example of others in the future.🔽Or alternatively, the paying of homage to the Three Jewels in the commentary is for the purpose of dispelling the great danger that might arise to one who, like one who has gone down to the great ocean, is endowed with the strength of wisdom,

original: bhayaṃ sambhavati, bhayakkhayāvahañcetaṃ ratanattayaguṇānussaraṇajanitaṃ paṇāmapūjāvidhānaṃ,
analyzed: bhayam sambhavati bhaya kkhaya āvaham ca itam rata nattaya guṇa anussaraṇa janitam paṇāma pūjā vidhānam
translated: and who wishes to expound the Dhamma and Discipline that is endowed with the four profundities.

original: tato ca saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ ratanattayapaṇāmakiriyā”ti. Atha vā “asattharipi satthābhinivesassa🔽lokassa yathābhūtaṃ satthari eva sammāsambuddhe satthusambhāvanatthaṃ, asatthari
analyzed: tato ca saṃvaṇṇanā idam atha vā sattha abhinivesassa  lokassa yathābhūtam satthari eva sammāsambuddhe satthu sambhāvana attham a satthari
translated: and then the paying of homage in the commendation is for the purpose of the homage to the Three Jewels.”

original: ca satthusambhāvanapariccajāpanatthaṃ, ‘tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammavinayaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā
analyzed: ca satthu sambhāvana pariccajāpana ttham tathāgata ppaveditam dhamma vinayam pariyāpuṇitvā
translated: Or alternatively, the paying of homage in the commendation is for the purpose of showing respect to the Teacher, the Fully Enlightened One, as he really is, in the case of the world that misapprehends a non-teacher as a teacher,

original: attano dahatī’ti ca vuttadosapariharaṇatthaṃ saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ paṇāmakiriyā”ti. Atha
analyzed: attanaḥ dahati iti ca vutta dosa pariharaṇa attham saṃvaṇṇanāyam paṇāma kiriyā ati atha
translated: and for the purpose of making it abandon the misapprehension of a non-teacher as a teacher, and for the purpose of avoiding the fault stated thus “He teaches what he has learnt from others” .

original: vā “buddhassa bhagavato paṇāmavidhānena sammāsambuddhabhāvādhigamāya buddhayānaṃ🔽paṭipajjantānaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ, saddhammassa ca paṇāmavidhānena paccekabuddhabhāvādhigamāya🔽paccekabuddhayānaṃ paṭipajjantānaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ, saṅghassa ca paṇāmavidhānena
analyzed: vā buddhassa bhagavataḥ paṇāma vidhānena sammāsambuddha bhāva adhigamāya buddha yānam  paṭipajjantānam ussāha janana attham saddhammassa ca paṇāma vidhānena paccekabuddha bhāva adhigamāya  paccekabuddha yānam paṭipajjantānam ussāha janana attham saṅghassa ca paṇāma vidhānena
translated: Or alternatively, the paying of homage in the commendation is for the purpose of arousing zeal in those who are practising the Buddhayāna for the purpose of attaining to the state of a Fully Enlightened One by the performance of homage to the Blessed One, the Buddha,🔽and for the purpose of arousing zeal in those who are practising the Paccekabuddhayāna for the purpose of attaining to the state of a Paccekabuddha by the performance of homage to the True Idea,

original: paramatthasaṅghabhāvādhigamāya sāvakayānaṃ paṭipajjantānaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: paramattha saṅgha bhāva adhigamāya sāvaka yānam paṭipajjantānam ussāha janana attham saṃvaṇṇanāyam
translated: and for the purpose of arousing zeal in those who are practising the Sāvakayāna for the purpose of attaining to the state of the Supreme Assembly by the performance of homage to the Community.

original: paṇāmakiriyā”ti. Atha vā “maṅgalādikāni satthāni anantarāyāni, ciraṭṭhitikāni, bahumatāni
analyzed: paṇāma kiriyā ti atha vā maṅgala ādikāni satthāni anantarāyāni cira ṭṭhitikāni bahu matāni
translated: and the making of homage.

original: ca bhavantīti evaṃladdhikānaṃ cittaparitosanatthaṃ saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ paṇāmakiriyā”ti.🔽Atha vā “sotujanānaṃ yathāvuttapaṇāmena anantarāyena uggahaṇadhāraṇādinipphādanatthaṃ
analyzed: ca bhavanti iti evaṃladdhikānam citta paritosana attham saṃvaṇṇanāyam paṇāma kiriyā ati  atha vā sotu janānam yathāvutta paṇāmena anantarāyena uggahaṇa dhāraṇa ādi nipphādana attham
translated: Or else, the making of homage in the commendation is for the purpose of gladdening the minds of those who have attained the state of being auspicious, etc., which are free from hindrance, long-lasting, and highly regarded.

original: saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ paṇāmakiriyā. Sotujanānuggahameva hi padhānaṃ katvā ācariyehi saṃvaṇṇanārambhe🔽thutipaṇāmaparidīpakāni vākyāni nikkhipīyanti, itarathā vināpi taṃ nikkhepaṃ kāyamanopaṇāmeneva
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā ayam paṇāma kiriyā sotu jana anuggaham eva hi padhānam katvā ācariyehi saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe  thuti paṇāma paridīpakāni vākyāni nikkhipīyanti itarathā vinā api tam nikkhepam kāya manaḥ upaṇāmena iva
translated: Or else, the making of homage in the commendation is for the purpose of producing the learning, retention, etc., of the people of the world by means of the homage as described above, which is free from hindrance.

original: yathādhippetappayojanasiddhito kimetena ganthagāravakaraṇenā”ti ca evamādinā. Mayaṃ
analyzed: yathā adhippeta payojana siddhitaḥ kim etena gantha gārava karaṇena ati ca evamādinā
translated: For when the teachers begin the commendation after making the people of the world their chief concern, they set down sentences that illustrate praise and homage, saying: “Otherwise, without even that setting down, the purpose as intended will be accomplished by the homage of body and mind alone. What is the use of this making of a burden of words?” and so on.

original: pana idhādhippetameva payojanaṃ dassayissāma, tasmā saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: pana idha adhippetam eva payojanam dassayissāma tasmai saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: But we shall show here the purpose as intended. Therefore the making of homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the commendation is

original: yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanatthanti veditabbaṃ. Idameva ca
analyzed: yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana atthanti veditabbam idam eva ca
translated: and the purpose is to be understood as the completion of the recitation without hindrance.

original: payojanaṃ ācariyena idhādhippetaṃ. Tathā hi vakkhati “iti me pasannamatino …pe… tassānubhāvenā”ti.
analyzed: payojanam ācariyena idha adhippetam tathā hi vakkhati iti me pasanna matino tassa anubhāvena ati
translated: This is the purpose that the teacher has in mind here. For he says: “When my mind is confident thus … by the power of that” .

original: Ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇañhi yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: rata natta ya paṇāma karaṇam hi yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana attham
translated: For the purpose of the completion of the recitation without hindrance is the making of the homage to the Three Jewels,

original: ratanattayapūjāya paññāpāṭavabhāvato, tāya ca paññāpāṭavaṃ rāgādimalavidhamanato. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: paññāpāṭava bhāvataḥ tāya ca paññāpāṭavam rāga ādi mala vidhamanataḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: because the homage to the Three Jewels is the means to the quickening of understanding, and the quickening of understanding is the means to the removal of the defilements of lust, etc. For this is said:

original: “Yasmiṃ mahānāma samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: yasmin mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ tathāgatam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye
translated: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple recollects the Tathāgata …🔽on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust,

original: rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam
translated: on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by hate, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by delusion,

original: cittaṃ hoti, ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hotī”tiādi.
analyzed: cittam hoti uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti itiādi
translated: on that occasion his mind is straight. ”

original: Tasmā ratanattayapūjāya vikkhālitamalāya paññāya pāṭavasiddhi. Atha vā ratanattayapūjāya paññāpadaṭṭhānasamādhihetuttā paññāpāṭavaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: tasmā ratanattaya pūjāya vikkhālita malāya paññāya atha vā ratanattaya pūjāya paññā padaṭṭhāna samādhi hetuttā paññāpāṭavam vuttam ha etam
translated: Or alternatively, the keenness of understanding is the cause of concentration, which is the footing for the understanding faculty, since this is said:

original: “Ujugatacitto kho pana mahānāma ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ,
analyzed: ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha vedam labhati dhamma vedam
translated: “Mahānāma, a noble disciple of steady mind obtains the meaning, obtains the Dhamma,

original: labhati dhammopasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati,
analyzed: labhati dhamma upasaṃhitam pāmojjam pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati
translated: obtains joy connected with the Dhamma. In one who is joyful, gladness is born. In one who is gladdened, the body is calmed.

original: passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedayati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyatī”ti.
analyzed: passaddha kāyaḥ sukham vedayati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati iti
translated: When the body is calmed, he feels pleasure. When he feels pleasure, his mind becomes concentrated” .

original: Samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhānabhāvo “samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti vuttoyeva.
analyzed: samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhāna bhāvo samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti vuttaḥ yeva
translated: And the footing for concentration is understanding, since it is said, “He who is concentrated understands” .

original: Tato evaṃ paṭubhūtāya paññāya khedamabhibhuyya paṭiññātaṃ saṃvaṇṇanaṃ samāpayissati.
analyzed: tatas evam paṭu bhūtāya paññāya khedam abhibhuyya paṭiññātam saṃvaṇṇanam samāpayissati
translated: So when understanding has become keen in this way, he will complete the description that he has undertaken, overcoming any fatigue.🔽That is why it was said above “because it is the cause for the keenness of understanding” .

original: Tena vuttaṃ “ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇañhi…pe… paññāpāṭavabhāvato”ti. Atha vā ratanattayapūjāya
analyzed: tena vuttam paññā pāṭava bhāvato ti atha vā ratanattaya pūjāya
translated: Or alternatively, the worship of the Three Gems is the cause of the keenness of understanding,

original: āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavaḍḍhanato anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ratanattayapaṇāmena
analyzed: āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vaḍḍhanataḥ anantarāyena parisamāpanam veditabbam
translated: and that it should be brought to fulfilment without hindrance through the increase of life, beauty, happiness, and strength.

original: hi āyuvaṇṇasukhabalāni vaḍḍhanti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: hi āyu vaṇṇa sukha balāni vaḍḍhanti vuttam ha etam
translated: For life, beauty, happiness, and strength increase through paying homage to the Triple Gem. It is said:🔽“For one who is of habit to pay homage,

original: “Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṃ vuḍḍhāpacāyino;
analyzed: abhivādana sīlissa niccam vuḍḍha apacāyinaḥ
translated: who always respects the elders,🔽four things increase:

original: Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ bala”nti. ;
analyzed: cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti āyu vaṇṇo sukham
translated: life, beauty, happiness, and strength.”

original: Tato āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavuddhiyā hotveva kāriyaniṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ “ratanattayapūjāya🔽āyu…pe… veditabba”nti. Atha vā ratanattayapūjāya paṭibhānāparihānāvahattā anantarāyena
analyzed: tatas āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vuddhiyā hotvā iva kāriya niṭṭhānam ti vuttam rata nattaya pūjāya  atha vā anantarāyena
translated: And since there is an increase of life, beauty, happiness, and strength, the fulfilment of one’s purpose is assured. Therefore it is said: “Through paying homage to the Triple Gem,🔽one’s purpose is assured. ”

original: parisamāpanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Aparihānāvahā hi ratanattayapūjā. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: parisamāpanam veditabbam a parihāna āvahā hi ratanattaya pūjā vuttam ha etam
translated: Or else, through paying homage to the Triple Gem, one’s inspiration and non-forgetfulness are assured, and one’s work is brought to fulfilment without hindrance. For paying homage to the Triple Gem is conducive to non-forgetfulness. It is said:

original: “Sattime bhikkhave, aparihānīyā dhammā, katame satta? Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā,
analyzed: sattime bhikkhave a parihānīyāḥ dhammāḥ katame satta satthu gāravatā dhamma gāravatā
translated: “Monks, there are seven things that lead to non-forgetting. What are the seven? Respect for the Teacher, respect for the Dhamma,

original: saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, kalyāṇamittatā, sovacassatā”ti tato
analyzed: saṅgha gāravatā sikkhā gāravatā samādhi gāravatā kalyāṇa mitta tā tatas
translated: respect for the Sangha, respect for the training, respect for concentration, having good friends, being easy to admonish.”

original: paṭibhānāparihānena hotveva yathāpaṭiññātaparisamāpananti vuttaṃ “ratanattaya…pe…🔽veditabba”nti. Atha vā pasādavatthūsu pūjāya puññātisayabhāvato anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ
analyzed: paṭibhāna a parihānena hotvā iva yathā paṭiññāta parisamāpanan ti vuttam  veditabban ti atha vā pasāda vatthūsu pūjāya puñña atisaya bhāvataḥ anantarāyena parisamāpanam
translated: and the completion of what has been undertaken without loss of inspiration.🔽Or else, the completion without hindrance of what has been undertaken should be understood as due to the abundance of merit in the act of worshipping the objects of faith.

original: veditabbaṃ. Puññātisayā hi pasādavatthūsu pūjā. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: veditabbam puñña atisayā hi pasāda vatthūsu pūjā vuttam ha etam
translated: For the act of worshipping the objects of faith is an abundance of merit. As it is said:

original: “Pūjārahe pūjayato, buddhe yadiva sāvake;
analyzed: pūjā rahe pūjayataḥ buddhe yat iva sāvake
translated: “When one who is worthy of worship, the Buddha and his disciples,

original: Papañcasamatikkante, tiṇṇasokapariddave.
analyzed: papañca sama tikkante tiṇṇa soka pariddave
translated: Has passed beyond all suffering, and crossed over sorrow and despair,

original: Te tādise pūjayato, nibbute akutobhaye;
analyzed: te tādise pūjayataḥ nibbute akutobhaye
translated: And one who worships such as they, who are extinguished and free from fear,

original: Na sakkā puññaṃ saṅkhātuṃ, imettamapi kenacī”ti. ;
analyzed: na sakkā puññam saṅkhātum kenaci iti
translated: No one can measure the merit of that act.”

original: Puññātisayo ca yathādhippetaparisamāpanupāyo. Yathāha –
analyzed: puñña atisayaḥ ca yathā adhippeta parisamāpan upāyaḥ yathā āha
translated: And an abundance of merit is the means for the completion of what has been undertaken as intended. As it is said:

original: “Esa devamanussānaṃ, sabbakāmadado nidhi;
analyzed: esa deva manussānam sabba kāma dadaḥ nidhi
translated: “This is the treasure of gods and men, the fulfiller of all wishes;

original: Yaṃ yadevābhipatthenti, sabbametena labbhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: yam yat eva abhipatthenti sabbam etena labbhati iti
translated: Whatever they aspire to, all that they obtain by this means.”

original: Upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hotveva kāriyaniṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ “pasādavatthūsu…pe… veditabba”nti.
analyzed: upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hotvā eva kāriya niṭṭhānan ti vuttam pasāda vatthu supe veditabbanti
translated: And for one who is practising by means of the means, the completion of what has been undertaken is bound to be successful. Thus it is said: “The completion of what has been undertaken should be understood as due to the abundance of merit in the act of worshipping the objects of faith.”

original: Evaṃ ratanattayapūjā niratisayapuññakkhettasambuddhiyā aparimeyyappabhāvo puññātisayoti
analyzed: evam ratanattaya pūjā niratisaya puñña kkhetta sambuddhiyāḥ aparimeyya ppabhāvo puññātisayaḥ ti
translated: So the worship of the Triple Gem is the cause of the arising of the immeasurable merit of the supreme field of merit, which is the Perfect Sambuddha.

original: bahuvidhantarāyepi lokasannivāse antarāyanibandhanasakalasaṃkilesaviddhaṃsanāya pahoti,
analyzed: bahuvidha antarāye pi loka sannivāse antarāya nibandhana sakala saṃkilesa vid haṃsanāya
translated: And it is able to destroy all defilements, which are the cause of obstacles, in the world, which is the abode of many kinds of obstacles,

original: bhayādiupaddavañca nivāreti. Tasmā suvuttaṃ “saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhaya ādi upaddavañca nivāreti tasmai su vuttam saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: and it wards off the dangers of fear, etc. That is why it was rightly said: “At the beginning of the commentary, the homage to the Triple Gem should be made

original: yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanatthanti veditabba”nti.
analyzed: yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana atthanti veditabbanti
translated: in order that the commentary may be completed without obstacle, in accordance with the promise.”

original: Evaṃ pana sapayojanaṃ ratanattayapaṇāmaṃ kattukāmo buddharatanamūlakattā sesaratanānaṃ
analyzed: evam pana sa payojanam kattu kāmaḥ buddha ratana mūla kattā
translated: But wishing to make the homage to the Triple Gem together with its purpose, he, since the other gems have the Buddha Gem as their basis,

original: paṭhamaṃ tassa paṇāmaṃ kātumāha – “karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ…pe… gativimutta”nti. Buddharatanamūlakāni
analyzed: paṭhamam tassa paṇāmam kātum āha buddha ratana mūlakāni
translated: first makes the homage to the Buddha Gem, saying: “I pay homage to the One whose heart is cool with compassion, etc.”

original: hi dhammasaṅgharatanāni, tesu ca dhammaratanamūlakaṃ saṅgharatanaṃ, tathābhāvo ca
analyzed: hi dhamma saṅgha ratanāni tesu ca dhamma ratana mūlakam saṅgha ratanam ca
translated: For the Dhamma and Sangha Gems have the Buddha Gem as their basis, and the Sangha Gem has the Dhamma Gem as its basis.

original: “puṇṇacando viya bhagavā, candakiraṇanikaro viya tena desito dhammo, candakiraṇasamuppāditapīṇito🔽loko viya saṅgho”ti evamādīhi aṭṭhakathāyamāgataupamāhi vibhāvetabbo. Atha vā sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: puṇṇa candaḥ viya bhagavā canda kiraṇa nikaraḥ viya tena desitaḥ dhammo canda kiraṇa samuppādita pīṇito  lokaḥ viya saṅghaḥ ti evamādīhi aṭṭhakathā ayam āgata aupamāhi vibhāvetabbaḥ atha vā sabba sattānam
translated: “The Blessed One is like the full moon, the Dhamma taught by him is like the moon’s rays, and the Saṅgha is like the world refreshed by the moon’s rays.”🔽Or else, the Saṅgha is to be understood as the field of merit for all beings,

original: aggoti katvā paṭhamaṃ buddho, tappabhavato, tadupadesitato ca tadanantaraṃ dhammo,🔽tassa dhammassa sādhāraṇato, tadāsevanato ca tadanantaraṃ saṅgho vutto. “Sabbasattānaṃ🔽vā hite viniyojakoti katvā paṭhamaṃ buddho, sabbasattahitattā tadanantaraṃ dhammo,
analyzed: aggaḥ iti katvā paṭhamam buddhaḥ tad pabhavataḥ tad upadesitataḥ ca tad anantaram dhammaḥ  tassa dhammassa sādhāraṇataḥ tad āsevanataḥ ca tad anantaram saṅghaḥ vuttaḥ sabba sattānam  vā hite viniyojakaḥ iti katvā paṭhamam buddhaḥ sabba satta hita ttā tad anantaram dhammaḥ
translated: “The Blessed One is like the full moon, the Dhamma he has taught is like the moon’s radiance, and the Saṅgha is like the world refreshed by the moon’s rays.” Or else, the Buddha is mentioned first as the “foremost of all beings,” the Dhamma next as the “best by far of all things,” and the Saṅgha last as the “best of all communities.”

original: hitādhigamāya paṭipanno adhigatahito cāti katvā tadanantaraṃ saṅgho vutto”ti aṭṭhakathāgatanayena
analyzed: hita adhigamāya paṭipannaḥ adhigata hito ca ati katvā tad anantaram saṅghaḥ vuttaḥ ti aṭṭhakathā gata nayena
translated: Or else, the Buddha is mentioned first as the “one who directs all beings to their welfare,” the Dhamma next as “the welfare of all beings,” and the Saṅgha last as “those who practice for the attainment of welfare and have attained it.”

original: anupubbatā veditabbā.
analyzed: anupubba tā veditabbā
translated: This is the method given in the commentaries.

original: Buddharatanapaṇāmañca karonto kevalapaṇāmato thomanāpubbaṅgamovasātisayoti “karuṇāsītalahadaya”ntiādipadehi
analyzed: buddha ratana paṇāmañca karontaḥ kevala paṇāmataḥ karuṇā sītalahadayanti ādi padehi
translated: When paying homage to the Buddha Jewel, one should do so with the utmost respect, with a sense of urgency, and with the thought that the Buddha is the foremost of all beings. The following verses should be recited:

original: thomanāpubbaṅgamataṃ dasseti. Thomanāpubbaṅgamena hi paṇāmena satthu guṇātisayayogo,
analyzed: thomanā pubbaṅgama tam dasseti thomanā pubbaṅgamena hi paṇāmena satthu guṇa atisaya yogaḥ
translated: He shows the pre-eminence of the praise. For the praise that is pre-eminent through praise is the means of yoking the Master’s special qualities,

original: tato cassa anuttaravandanīyabhāvo, tena ca attano paṇāmassa khettaṅgatabhāvo, tena
analyzed: tato ca assa anuttara vandanīya bhāvo tena ca attano paṇāmassa khettaṅgata bhāvo tena
translated: and then his state of being worthy of the highest worship, and then the state of being a field of merit of his own praise, and then

original: cassa khettaṅgatassa paṇāmassa yathādhippetanipphattihetubhāvo dassitoti. Thomanāpubbaṅgamatañca🔽dassento yassā saṃvaṇṇanaṃ kattukāmo, sā suttantadesanā karuṇāpaññāppadhānāyeva,
analyzed: cassa khettaṅgatassa paṇāmassa yathā adhippeta nipphatti hetu bhāvaḥ dassito ti thomanā pubbaṅgamatam ca  dassentaḥ yassā saṃvaṇṇanam kattu kāmo sā suttanta desanā karuṇā paññā appadhānāya iva
translated: the state of being the cause of the fulfilment of the wish of that praise that is a field of merit. So he shows the pre-eminence of the praise.

original: na vinayadesanā viya karuṇāppadhānā, nāpi abhidhammadesanā viya paññāppadhānāti tadubhayappadhānameva
analyzed: na vinaya desanā viya karuṇā appadhānā na api abhidhamma desanā viya paññā appadhānā ti tad ubhaya ppadhānam eva
translated: And in showing the pre-eminence of the praise he shows that the teaching of the Thread is pre-eminent in both lovingkindness and understanding, not only in lovingkindness as is the teaching of the Discipline, nor only in understanding as is the teaching of the Further Teaching.

original: thomanamārabhati. Esā hi ācariyassa pakati, yadidaṃ ārambhānurūpathomanā. Teneva
analyzed: thomanam ārabhati esā hi ācariyassa yat idam ārambha anurūpa thomanā tena iva
translated: So he begins the praise with the pre-eminence of both. For this is the teacher’s nature, namely, that the praise is in accordance with the beginning.

original: ca vinayadesanāya saṃvaṇṇanārambhe “yo kappakoṭīhipi…pe… mahākāruṇikassa tassā”ti
analyzed: ca vinaya desanāya saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe yaḥ mahā kāruṇikassa tassa ati
translated: And that is why, when he begins the praise of the teaching of the Discipline, he does so with the pre-eminence of lovingkindness thus: ‘He who for many millions of eons … of the Greatly Compassionate One’s’ ,

original: karuṇāppadhānaṃ, abhidhammadesanāya saṃvaṇṇanārambhe “karuṇā viya…pe… yathārucī”ti
analyzed: karuṇā ppadhānam abhidhamma desanāya saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe karuṇā viyape yathāruci iti
translated: and when he begins the praise of the teaching of the Further Teaching, he does so with the pre-eminence of understanding thus: ‘Lovingkindness … as he wishes’ .

original: paññāppadhānañca thomanamāraddhaṃ. Vinayadesanā hi āsayādinirapekkhakevalakaruṇāya🔽pākatikasattenāpi asotabbārahaṃ suṇanto, apucchitabbārahaṃ pucchanto, avattabbārahañca
analyzed: paññā appadhānam ca thomanam āraddham vinaya desanā hi āsaya ādi nirapekkha kevala karuṇāya  pākatika sattena api a sotabba āraham suṇantaḥ a pucchitabba āraham pucchantaḥ a vattabba āraham ca
translated: and the exertion of understanding is the teaching of the training precepts. For the teaching of the Vinaya is to be heard by one who is a normal person, who is without regard for his own comfort, and who is moved solely by compassion. He should hear what should be heard, ask what should be asked, and say what should be said.

original: vadanto sikkhāpadaṃ paññapesīti karuṇāppadhānā. Tathā hi ukkaṃsapariyantagatahirottappopi
analyzed: vadantaḥ sikkhāpadam paññapesi iti karuṇā appadhānā tathā hi ukkaṃsa pariyanta gata hira uttappaḥ api
translated: So the Blessed One, who was endowed with a sense of shame and fear of wrongdoing to the extent of the tip of a hair,

original: bhagavā lokiyasādhujanehipi pariharitabbāni “sikharaṇī, sambhinnā”tiādivacanāni,
analyzed: bhagavā pariharitabbāni sikharaṇī sambhinnā ati ādi vacanāni
translated: spoke in the midst of the great assembly words that should be avoided even by good people in the world, such as “Sikharaṇī, sambhinnā” ,

original: yathāparādhañca garahavacanāni mahākaruṇāsañcoditamānaso mahāparisamajjhe abhāsi,
analyzed: yathāparādham ca garaha vacanāni mahā karuṇā sañcodita mānasaḥ mahā parisamajjhe abhāsi
translated: and words of censure in accordance with the offence, his mind being urged on by his great compassion.

original: taṃtaṃsikkhāpadapaññatti kāraṇāpekkhāya ca verañjādīsu sārīrikaṃ khedamanubhosi.🔽Tasmā kiñcāpi bhūmantarapaccayākārasamayantarakathānaṃ viya vinayapaññattiyāpi samuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: taṃ taṃ sikkhāpada paññatti kāraṇa apekkhāya ca verañja ādīsu sārīrikam khedam anubhosi  tasmā kiñcā api bhūma antara paccaya ākāra samaya antara kathānam viya vinaya paññattiyā api samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: And he endured physical pain in Verañjā and other places, having regard for the reason for the promulgation of the various training precepts.

original: paññā anaññasādhāraṇatāya atisayakiccavatī, karuṇāya kiccaṃ pana tatopi adhikanti
analyzed: paññā anañña sādhāraṇa tāya atisaya kiccavatī karuṇāya kiccam pana tatas pi adhikanti
translated: Therefore, although the understanding that is the instigator of the promulgation of the Vinaya has a unique function in that it is not shared by others, as has the understanding that is the instigator of the exposition of the various planes, conditions, aspects, and occasions, nevertheless the function of compassion is greater than that.

original: vinayadesanāya karuṇāppadhānatā vuttā. Karuṇābyāpārādhikatāya hi desanāya karuṇāpadhānatā,
analyzed: vinaya desanāya karuṇā appadhāna tā vuttā karuṇā byāpāra adhikatāya hi desanāya karuṇā apadhāna tā
translated: The teaching of the Vinaya is said to have compassion as its ground because the teaching is concerned with the removal of suffering.

original: abhidhammadesanā pana kevalapaññāppadhānā paramatthadhammānaṃ yathāsabhāvapaṭivedhasamatthāya🔽paññāya tattha sātisayappavattito. Suttantadesanā pana karuṇāpaññāppadhānā tesaṃ
analyzed: abhidhamma desanā pana kevala paññā appadhānā paramattha dhammānam yathā sabhāva paṭivedha samatthāya  paññāya tattha sa atisaya ppavattito suttanta desanā pana karuṇā paññā appadhānā tesam
translated: The teaching of the Abhidhamma has only wisdom as its ground because it is concerned with the penetration of ultimate realities in their true nature.

original: tesaṃ sattānaṃ āsayānusayādhimutticaritādibhedaparicchindanasamatthāya paññāya sattesu🔽ca mahākaruṇāya tattha sātisayappavattito. Suttantadesanāya hi mahākaruṇāya samāpattibahulo🔽vineyyasantāne tadajjhāsayānulomena gambhīramatthapadaṃ patiṭṭhapesi. Tasmā ārambhānurūpaṃ
analyzed: tesam sattānam āsaya anusaya adhimutti carita ādi bheda paricchindana samatthāya paññāya sattesu  ca mahā karuṇāya tattha sa atisaya ppavattitaḥ suttanta desanāya hi mahā karuṇāya samāpatti bahulaḥ  vineyya santāne tad ajjhāsayā anulomena gambhīram attha padam patiṭṭhapesi tasmai ārambha anurūpam
translated: The teaching of the Suttas has both compassion and wisdom as its ground because it is concerned with the penetration of the various dispositions, latent tendencies, inclinations, and ethical natures of beings, and because it is concerned with the great compassion for beings.

original: karuṇāpaññāppadhānameva thomanaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ, ayamettha samudāyattho.
analyzed: karuṇā paññā appadhānam eva thomanam katan ti veditabbam ayam ettha samudāya ttho
translated: For in the teaching of the Suttas, the Buddha, who was rich in the attainment of great compassion, established the profound meaning in the mental continuities of those to be trained in accordance with their dispositions. Therefore the ground of the teaching should be understood as the compassion and wisdom that are appropriate to the undertaking. This is the meaning of the compound as a whole.

original: Ayaṃ pana avayavattho – kiratīti karuṇā, paradukkhaṃ vikkhipati paccayavekallakaraṇena
analyzed: ayam pana avayava tthaḥ kirati iti karuṇā para dukkham vikkhipati paccaya vekalla karaṇena
translated: The meaning of the component terms is as follows: Karuṇā is that which crushes kīrati suffering paraṃ dukkhaṃ, by removing its conditions.

original: apanetīti attho. Dukkhitesu vā kiriyati pasāriyatīti karuṇā. Atha vā kiṇātīti karuṇā,
analyzed: apaneti iti atthaḥ dukkhitesu vā kiriyati pasāriyati iti karuṇā atha vā kiṇāti iti karuṇā
translated: The meaning is that it takes away. Or alternatively, it is called compassion because it is produced and extended towards those who are suffering. Or alternatively, it is called compassion because it is the cutting of the suffering of others.

original: paradukkhe sati kāruṇikaṃ hiṃsati vibādhati, paradukkhaṃ vā vināsetīti attho. Paradukkhe🔽sati sādhūnaṃ kampanaṃ hadayakhedaṃ karotīti vā karuṇā. Atha vā kamiti sukhaṃ, taṃ🔽rundhatīti karuṇā. Esā hi paradukkhāpanayanakāmatālakkhaṇā attasukhanirapekkhatāya
analyzed: para dukkhe sati kāruṇikam hiṃsati vibādhati para dukkham vā vināseti iti atthaḥ para dukkhe  sati kampanam hadaya khedam karoti iti vā karuṇā atha vā kam iti sukham tam  rundhati iti karuṇā esā hi para dukkha apanayana kāma tā lakkhaṇā atta sukha nirapekkha tāya
translated: For the compassionate one cuts, that is, afflicts, the suffering of others, or he destroys the suffering of others, is the meaning.🔽Or alternatively, compassion is so called because it causes a trembling, a quaking of the heart of the good when they see the suffering of others.

original: kāruṇikānaṃ sukhaṃ rundhati vibandhatīti, sabbattha saddasatthānusārena padanipphatti
analyzed: kāruṇikānam sukham rundhati vibandhati iti sabbattha sadda sattha anusārena pada nipphatti
translated: Or alternatively, kam means pleasure; it is the cutting off of that, is compassion. For this has the characteristic of the desire to remove the suffering of others. It cuts off, obstructs, the pleasure of the compassionate ones, since they are indifferent to their own pleasure.🔽The derivation of the words should be understood in each instance according to the method given in the commentaries.

original: veditabbā. Uṇhābhitattehi sevīyatīti sītaṃ, uṇhābhisamanaṃ. Taṃ lāti gaṇhātīti sītalaṃ,
analyzed: veditabbā uṇha abhitattehi sevīyati iti sītam uṇha abhisamanam tam lāti gaṇhāti iti sītalam
translated: Cold is so called because it is sought for the purpose of removing heat, that is, the discomfort of heat. It is cool because it takes, that is, receives, that, that is, cold.🔽“I will split your heart with my sword” is said here with the chest in mind,

original: “cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmī”ti ettha uro “hadaya”nti vuttaṃ,🔽“vakkaṃ hadaya”nti ettha hadayavatthu, “hadayā hadayaṃ maññe aññāya tacchatī”ti ettha
analyzed: cittam vā te khipissāmi hadayam vā te phālessāmi iti ettha uraḥ hadayanti vuttam 🔽vakkam hadayanti ettha hadaya vatthu hadayā hadayam maññe aññāya tacchati iti ettha
translated: “The heart is the kidney” is said here with the heart-basis in mind,

original: cittaṃ, idhāpi cittameva abbhantaraṭṭhena hadayaṃ. Attano sabhāvaṃ vā haratīti hadayaṃ,
analyzed: cittam idha api cittam eva abbhantaraṭṭhena hadayam sabhāvam vā harati iti hadayam
translated: Or alternatively, it “carries off” its own individual essence, thus it is a heart ;🔽changing the ra to da.

original: ra-kārassa da-kāraṃ katvāti neruttikā. Karuṇāya sītalaṃ hadayamassāti karuṇāsītalahadayo,
analyzed: rakārassa dakāram katvā iti neruttikā karuṇāya sītalam hadayam assa ati karuṇā sītala hadayaḥ
translated: He has a heart that is cool with compassion, thus he is the one whose heart is cool with compassion ;

original: taṃ karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ.🔽Kāmañcettha paresaṃ hitopasaṃhārasukhādiaparihānijjhānasabhāvatāya, byāpādādīnaṃ
analyzed: tam karuṇā sītā lahadayam  kāmam ca itthā paresam hita upasaṃhāra sukha ādi a parihāni jhāna sabhāva tāya byāpāda ādīnam
translated: that heart that is cool with compassion.🔽Herein, it is true that loving- kindness and gladness are also causes for the heart’s coolness since they have respectively the nature of bestowing welfare on others, of bestowing pleasure on others, and of not wanting to take others’ lives away,

original: ujuvipaccanīkatāya ca sattasantānagatasantāpavicchedanākārappavattiyā mettāmuditānampi
analyzed: uju vipaccanīka tāya ca satta santāna gata santāpa vicchedana ākāra ppavattiyā
translated: and since they are the direct opposites of ill will, etc.,

original: cittasītalabhāvakāraṇatā upalabbhati, tathāpi paradukkhāpanayanākārappavattiyā parūpatāpāsahanarasā
analyzed: citta sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā upalabbhati tathā api para dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavattiyā parūpa tāpa āsahana rasā
translated: and since they occur with the mode of activity of removing the torment that exists in the continuity of the others’ mental body,

original: avihiṃsābhūtā karuṇāva visesena bhagavato cittassa cittapassaddhi viya sītibhāvanimittanti
analyzed: avihiṃsā bhūtā visesena bhagavato cittassa citta passaddhi viya sīti bhāva nimittanti
translated: nevertheless, it is only compassion that is the cause of the Blessed One’s heart’s coolness, as it were, in the way that bodily calm is the cause of the heart’s coolness in an ordinary person, because it occurs with the mode of activity of removing the torment that exists in the continuity of others’ mental bodies.🔽And it is because of this that it is said to be the cause of the heart’s coolness.

original: tassāyeva cittasītalabhāvakāraṇatā vuttā. Karuṇāmukhena vā mettāmuditānampi hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇatā
analyzed: citta sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā vuttā karuṇā mukhena vā hadaya sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā
translated: Or alternatively, it is only compassion that is the cause of the heart’s coolness in loving-kindness and gladness too,

original: vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi sabbattha niravasesattho upadisīyati, padhānasahacaraṇāvinābhāvādinayehipi
analyzed: vuttā iti daṭṭhabbam na hi sabbattha niravasesa atthaḥ upadisīyati padhāna sahacaraṇa avinābhāva ādi nayehi pi
translated: and it should be understood that the meaning is stated in this way. For the meaning is not taught in all instances in its entirety, but also by way of what is predominant, what is associated, what is inseparable,

original: yathālabbhamānaṃ gayhamānattā. Apicettha taṃsampayuttañāṇassa chaasādhāraṇañāṇapariyāpannatāya
analyzed: yathālabbhamānam gayhamāna ttā api ca ittha tad sampayutta ñāṇassa cha a sādhāraṇa ñāṇa pariyāpanna tāya
translated: and so on, because what is appropriate is accepted. Moreover, here, because the knowledge associated with it is included in the six kinds of knowledge not common to disciples,

original: asādhāraṇañāṇavisesanibandhanabhūtā sātisayaṃ, niravasesañca sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ viya
analyzed: asādhāraṇa ñāṇa visesa nibandhana bhūtā sa atisayam niravasesam ca sabbaññuta ññāṇam viya
translated: it is said to be the cause of the coolness of the heart, like the knowledge of omniscience, which is the basis for the distinction of the knowledge not common to disciples,

original: savisayabyāpitāya mahākaruṇābhāvamupagatā anaññasādhāraṇasātisayabhāvappattā karuṇāva
analyzed: sa visaya byāpitāya mahā karuṇā bhāvam upagatā anañña sādhāraṇa sa atisaya bhāva ppattā karuṇā vat
translated: and which has attained a special state of great compassion, which is pervaded by an object that is not shared by others, and which has attained a special state of greatness.

original: hadayasītalattahetubhāvena vuttā. Atha vā satipi mettāmuditānaṃ paresaṃ hitopasaṃhārasukhādiaparihānijjhānasabhāvatāya🔽sātisaye hadayasītalabhāvanibandhanatte sakalabuddhaguṇavisesakāraṇatāya tāsampi
analyzed: hadaya sīta latta hetu bhāvena vuttāḥ atha vā paresam hita upasaṃhāra sukha ādi a parihāni jhāna sabhāva tāya  sa atisaye hadaya sītala bhāva nibandhana tte sakala buddha guṇa visesa kāraṇatāya tāsam pi
translated: Or alternatively, although loving-kindness and compassion have the nature of the jhānas, which are the attainment of the happiness of bestowing welfare on others and the non-abandonment of others, respectively,🔽they are said to be the cause of the coolness of the heart, because they are the cause of all the special qualities of the Buddha, since they are the basis for the special state of coolness of the heart,

original: kāraṇanti karuṇāya eva hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇatā vuttā. Karuṇānidānā hi sabbepi buddhaguṇā.
analyzed: kāraṇam ti karuṇāyaḥ eva hadaya sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā vuttā karuṇā nidānāḥ hi sabbe api buddha guṇā
translated: which is greater than that of loving-kindness and compassion. For all the special qualities of the Buddha have compassion as their source.

original: Karuṇānubhāvanibbāpiyamānasaṃsāradukkhasantāpassa hi bhagavato paradukkhāpanayanakāmatāya
analyzed: karuṇā anubhāva nibbāpiyamāna saṃsāra dukkha santāpassa hi bhagavato para dukkha apanayana kāma tāya
translated: For the Blessed One’s mind, which is cooled by the influence of compassion, is not tormented by the suffering and misery of the round of rebirths.

original: anekānipi kappānamasaṅkhyeyyāni akilantarūpasseva niravasesabuddhakaradhammasambharaṇaniratassa
analyzed: anekāni api kappānam asaṅkhyeyyāni a kilanta rūpassa iva niravasesa buddha kara dhamma sambharaṇa niratassa
translated: And because of his desire to remove the suffering of others, he has no weariness even after countless eons in accumulating the requisites for Buddhahood, which are without remainder and difficult to traverse.

original: samadhigatadhammādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesupi sattasaṅghātasamupanītahadayūpatāpanimittesu
analyzed: samadhigata dhamma ādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesu pi satta saṅghāta samupanīta hadaya upatāpa nimittesu
translated: And when the signs of the torment of his heart by the heat of the mass of beings who are present in the vicinity of the Lord of the Dhamma who has entered into meditation,

original: na īsakampi cittasītibhāvassa aññathattamahosīti. Tīsu cettha vikappesu paṭhame vikappe🔽avisesabhūtā buddhabhūmigatā, dutiye tatheva mahākaruṇābhāvūpagatā, tatiye paṭhamābhinīhārato
analyzed: na īsakam pi citta sīti bhāvassa aññathattam ahosi iti tīsu ca ittha vikappesu paṭhame vikappe  avisesa bhūtāḥ buddha bhūmi gatāḥ dutiye tathā iva mahā karuṇā bhāvu upagatā tatiye paṭhama abhinīhārato
translated: his mind does not become even slightly disturbed or changed.

original: paṭṭhāya tīsupi avatthāsu pavattā bhagavato karuṇā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya tīsu pi avatthāsu pavattā bhagavataḥ karuṇā saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: In these three alternatives, in the first alternative, the compassion of the Blessed One, which is included in the stage of Buddhahood, is without distinction. In the second, it is included in the state of great compassion. In the third, it is included in the compassion of the Blessed One, which occurs in all three states, beginning from the first aspiration.

original: Pajānātīti paññā, yathāsabhāvaṃ pakārehi paṭivijjhatīti attho. Paññapetīti vā paññā,
analyzed: pajānāti iti paññā yathāsabhāvam pakārehi paṭivijjhati iti attho paññapeti iti vā paññā
translated: “He understands”: “paññā” means “he understands” . The meaning is: he penetrates by means of the aspects in accordance with reality. Or “paññā” means “he defines” .

original: taṃ tadatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ karotīti attho. Sāyeva ñeyyāvaraṇappahānato pakārehi dhammasabhāvajotanaṭṭhena
analyzed: tam tad attham pākaṭam karoti iti sāyā iva ñeyya āvaraṇa ppahānataḥ pakārehi dhamma sabhāva jotana ṭṭhena
translated: It is a light because it illuminates the real nature of states by means of the aspects of the four paths and fruits.

original: pajjototi paññāpajjoto. Paññavato hi ekapallaṅkenapi nisinnassa dasasahassilokadhātu
analyzed: pajjoto ti paññāpajjoto paññavataḥ hi eka pallaṅkena api nisinnassa dasa sahassi lokadhātu
translated: For when a man has understanding, even if he sits with his legs crossed only once in ten thousand world systems,

original: ekapajjotā hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā “cattārome bhikkhave, pajjotā. Katame cattāro?
analyzed: eka pajjotā hoti vuttam ha etam bhagavatā cattāro me bhikkhave pajjotā katame cattāro
translated: they are all lit up by his light. For this is said by the Blessed One: “Bhikkhus, there are these four lights. What four?

original: Candapajjoto, sūriyapajjoto, aggipajjoto, paññāpajjoto, ime kho bhikkhave, cattāro
analyzed: canda pajjotaḥ sūriya pajjotaḥ aggi pajjotaḥ paññā pajjotaḥ ime kho bhikkhave cattāro
translated: The light of the moon, the light of the sun, the light of fire, and the light of wisdom. These are the four lights.

original: pajjotā. Etadaggaṃ bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ pajjotānaṃ yadidaṃ paññāpajjoto”ti.
analyzed: pajjotāḥ etat aggam bhikkhave imesam catunnam pajjotānam yat idam paññāpajjotā ti
translated: But, bhikkhus, the foremost of these lights is the light of wisdom” .

original: Tena vihato visesena samugghāṭitoti paññāpajjotavihato, visesatā cettha upari āvi
analyzed: tena vihataḥ visesena samugghāṭito ti paññāpajja uta vihataḥ visesa tā ca ittha upari āvi
translated: It is a dispeller of the darkness of delusion because it dispels, that is, eradicates, the darkness of delusion by means of that light of wisdom. The distinction will be made clear later .

original: bhavissati. Muyhanti tena, sayaṃ vā muyhati, muyhanamattameva vā tanti moho, avijjā.
analyzed: bhavissati muyhanti tena sayam vā muyhati muyhana mattam eva vā mohaḥ avijjā
translated: Delusion is bewilderment, or one who is bewildered, or mere bewilderment. It is ignorance.

original: Sveva visayasabhāvapaṭicchādanato andhakārasarikkhatāya tamo viyāti mohatamo. Satipi
analyzed: su eva visaya sabhāva paṭicchādanato andhakāra sarikkha tāya tamaḥ viyāti moha tamaḥ
translated: It is the darkness of delusion because it is like darkness in that it conceals the real nature of its object.

original: tamasaddassa sadisakappanamantarena avijjāvācakatte mohasaddasannidhānena tabbisesakatāvettha
analyzed: tama saddassa sadisa kappanam antarena avijjā vācaka tte moha sadda sannidhānena tad visesaka tā avettha
translated: The word “darkness” is qualified by the word “delusion” as a synonym for ignorance, which is the opposite of the light of wisdom.

original: yuttāti sadisakappanā. Paññāpajjotavihato mohatamo yassāti paññāpajjotavihatamohatamo,
analyzed: yuttā ati sadisa kappanā paññā pajjota vihataḥ moha tamaḥ yassa ati paññā pajjota vihata moha tamo
translated: Thus the compound “darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom” is a bahubbīhi compound.

original: taṃ paññāpajjotavihatamohatamaṃ.🔽Nanu ca sabbesampi khīṇāsavānaṃ paññāpajjotena avijjandhakārahatatā sambhavati, atha
analyzed: tam paññāpajjota vihata mohatamam  nanu ca sabbesam pi khīṇāsavānam paññāpajjotena avijja andhakāra hata tā sambhavati atha
translated: The word “darkness” is a synonym for delusion.🔽But isn’t it true that the darkness of ignorance is dispelled by the light of wisdom in all those who have destroyed the taints? Then why is the Blessed One praised here by a special quality not shared by others?

original: kasmā aññasādhāraṇāvisesaguṇena bhagavato thomanā vuttāti? Savāsanappahānena anaññasādhāraṇavisesatāsambhavato.
analyzed: kasmai añña sādhāraṇa avisesa guṇena bhagavataḥ thomanā vuttā ati sa vāsanā pahānena anañña sādhāraṇa visesa tā sambhavato
translated: Because the destruction of the taints together with their residues is not shared by others.

original: Sabbesampi hi khīṇāsavānaṃ paññāpajjotahatāvijjandhakārattepi sati saddhādhimuttehi
analyzed: sabbesam pi hi khīṇāsavānam sati saddhā adhimuttehi
translated: For although all those who have destroyed the taints have dispelled the darkness of ignorance by the light of wisdom, still, just as in the case of those resolute in faith,

original: viya diṭṭhippattānaṃ sāvakapaccekabuddhehi sammāsambuddhānaṃ savāsanappahānena kilesappahānassa
analyzed: viya diṭṭhi ppattānam sāvaka paccekabuddhehi sammāsambuddhānam sa vāsanā ppahānena kilesa ppahānassa
translated: there is a difference between disciples, paccekabuddhas, and perfectly enlightened Buddhas who have attained to view in the destruction of the taints together with their residues.

original: viseso vijjatevāti. Atha vā paropadesamantarena attano santāne accantaṃ avijjandhakāravigamassa
analyzed: visesaḥ vijjate iva ati atha vā para upadesam antarena attano santāne accantam
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed One is praised here by a special quality not shared by others because of the complete destruction of the darkness of ignorance in his mental continuum without the help of another’s instruction.

original: nipphāditattā (nibbattitattā ma. ni. ṭī. 1.1), tattha ca sabbaññutāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa
analyzed: nipphādita ttā nibbattita ttā ma ni ṭī tattha ca sabbaññu tāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa
translated: Because it is produced in him, and because he has mastery over it by his omniscience,

original: samadhigatattā, parasantatiyañca dhammadesanātisayānubhāvena sammadeva tassa pavattitattā,
analyzed: samadhigata ttā para santatiyañca dhamma desanā atisaya anubhāvena sammat eva tassa pavattita ttā
translated: and because it occurs in him rightly by the power of his special ability to teach Dhamma in another’s continuity,

original: bhagavāyeva visesato paññāpajjotavihatamohatamabhāvena thometabboti. Imasmiñca atthavikappe🔽paññāpajjotapadena sasantānagatamohavidhamanā paṭivedhapaññā ceva parasantānagatamohavidhamanā
analyzed: bhagavāya iva visesataḥ imasmin ca attha vikappe  paññāpajjota padena sa santāna gata moha vidhamanā paṭivedha paññā ca iva para santāna gata moha vidhamanā
translated: the Blessed One is to be praised above all others by the light of his wisdom that dispels the darkness of delusion. And in this interpretation of the meaning,🔽the wisdom that is the light of the world is included by the general statement and by the method of the particular instance in the case of the dispelling of delusion in one’s own continuity and in the case of the dispelling of delusion in another’s continuity,

original: desanāpaññā ca sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesanayena vā saṅgahitā. Na tu purimasmiṃ atthavikappe
analyzed: desanā paññā ca sāmañña niddesena ekasesa nayena vā saṅgahitā na tu purimasmin attha vikappe
translated: respectively, as the wisdom of penetration and the wisdom of teaching, but not in the previous interpretation of the meaning,

original: viya paṭivedhapaññāyevāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: viya paṭivedha paññāya iva ati veditabbam
translated: where it is only the wisdom of penetration that is meant.

original: Aparo nayo – bhagavato ñāṇassa ñeyyapariyantikattā sakalañeyyadhammasabhāvāvabodhanasamatthena
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa ñeyya pariyantika ttā sakala ñeyya dhamma sabhāva avabodhana samatthena
translated: Another method: since the Blessed One’s knowledge is bounded by the knowable, it is capable of fathoming the individual essences of all knowable dhammas.

original: anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātena paññāpajjotena sakalañeyyadhammasabhāvacchādakamohatamassa
analyzed: anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātena paññā pajjotena sakala ñeyya dhamma sabhā vacchādaka moha tamassa
translated: So by the light of his wisdom, which is called “knowledge without obstruction,” the darkness of delusion that conceals the individual essences of all knowable dhammas is dispelled.

original: vihatattā anāvaraṇañāṇabhūtena anaññasādhāraṇapaññāpajjotavihatamohatamabhāvena bhagavato
analyzed: vihata ttā anāvaraṇa ñāṇa bhūtena anañña sādhāraṇa paññā pajjota vihata mohatama bhāvena bhagavato
translated: It should be understood as the Blessed One’s praise because it is the dispelling of the darkness of delusion by the light of his unique wisdom, which is the knowledge free from obstruction because of the absence of obstruction.

original: thomanā veditabbā. Imasmiṃ pana atthavikappe mohatamavidhamanante adhigatattā anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ🔽kāraṇūpacārena sakasantāne mohatamavidhamananti veditabbaṃ. Abhinīhārasampattiyā🔽savāsanappahānameva hi kilesānaṃ ñeyyāvaraṇappahānanti, parasantāne pana mohatamavidhamanassa
analyzed: thomanā veditabbā imasmin pana attha vikappe moha tama vidhamana nte adhigata ttā anāvaraṇa ñāṇam  kāraṇa upacārena saka santāne moha tama vidhamanan ti veditabbam abhinīhāra sampattiyā  sa vāsanā pahānam eva hi kilesānam ñeyya āvaraṇa ppahānam ti para santāne pana moha tama vidhamanassa
translated: In this interpretation, the knowledge free from obstruction should be understood as the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in his own mental continuum because of the attainment of the knowledge free from obstruction.

original: kāraṇabhāvato phalūpacārena anāvaraṇañāṇameva mohatamavidhamananti vuccati. Anāvaraṇañāṇanti🔽ca sabbaññutaññāṇameva, yena dhammadesanāpaccavekkhaṇāni karoti. Tadidañhi ñāṇadvayaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇa bhāvataḥ phala upacārena anāvaraṇa ñāṇam eva moha tama vidhamanam ti vuccati anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti  ca sabbaññu taññāṇam eva yena dhamma desanā paccavekkhaṇāni karoti tat idam hi ñāṇa dvayam
translated: For the complete abandoning of defilements together with their traces is the abandoning of the hindrance of the knowable. But the knowledge free from obstruction is called the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in the mental continuum of others because it is the cause of the dispelling of the darkness of delusion in others’ mental continua.🔽And the knowledge free from obstruction is the knowledge of omniscience, by means of which he performs the survey of the teaching of the Dhamma.

original: atthato ekameva. Anavasesasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatasammutidhammārammaṇatāya sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: atthataḥ ekam eva anavasesa saṅkhata asaṅkhata sammuti dhamma ārammaṇa tāya sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: For these two kinds of knowledge are in fact one and the same. The knowledge of omniscience has as its object all conditioned and unconditioned things, all dhammas, without exception, both as actualities and as terms of common usage.

original: tatthāvaraṇābhāvato nissaṅgacāramupādāya anāvaraṇañāṇanti, visayappavattimukhena
analyzed: tattha āvaraṇa abhāvataḥ nissaṅga cāram upādāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti visaya ppavatti mukhena
translated: “Because there is no obstruction, and because of the absence of clinging, the knowledge of the Blessed One is unobstructed. But in the sense of the occurrence of the object,

original: pana aññehi asādhāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ dvidhā katvā chaḷāsādhāraṇañāṇabhede vuttaṃ.🔽Kiṃ panettha kāraṇaṃ avijjāsamugghātoyeveko pahānasampattivasena bhagavato thomanāya
analyzed: pana aññehi asādhāraṇa bhāva dassana attham dvidhā katvā chaḷa asādhāraṇa ñāṇa bhede vuttam  kim pana ittha kāraṇam pahāna sampatti vasena bhagavataḥ thomanāya
translated: it is twofold in order to show that it is not shared by others. This is said in the exposition of the six kinds of knowledge not shared by disciples.

original: gayhati, na pana sātisayaṃ niravasesakilesappahānanti? Vuccate – tappahānavacaneneva
analyzed: gayhati na pana sa atisayam niravasesa kilesa ppahānan ti vuccate tad pahāna vacanena iva
translated: “But why is the destruction of ignorance alone mentioned as the Blessed One’s unique power of abandoning, and not the abandoning of all defilements without remainder? It is said:

original: hi tadekaṭṭhatāya sakalasaṃkilesasamugghātassa jotitabhāvato niravasesakilesappahānamettha
analyzed: hi tad ekaṭṭhatāya sakala saṃkilesa samugghātassa jotita bhāvataḥ niravasesa kilesa ppahānam ettha
translated: for by the statement of the abandoning of that , the abandoning of all defilements without remainder is implied, since the destruction of all defilement is indicated by the fact that it is included in the destruction of that .

original: gayhati. Na hi so saṃkileso atthi, yo niravasesāvijjāsamugghātanena na pahīyatīti.
analyzed: gayhati na hi so saṃkilesaḥ atthi yaḥ niravasesa avijjā samugghātanena na pahīyati iti
translated: For there is no defilement that is not abandoned by the destruction of ignorance without remainder.

original: Atha vā sakalakusaladhammuppattiyā, saṃsāranivattiyā ca vijjā viya niravasesākusaladhammuppattiyā,
analyzed: atha vā sakala kusala dhamma uppattiyā saṃsāra nivattiyā ca vijjā viya niravasesa akusala dhamma uppattiyā
translated: Or else, just as knowledge is the cause of the arising of all profitable things and of the cessation of the round of rebirths,

original: saṃsārappavattiyā ca avijjāyeva padhānakāraṇanti tabbighātavacaneneva sakalasaṃkilesasamugghātavacanasiddhito
analyzed: saṃsāra ppavattiyā ca avijjāya iva padhāna kāraṇan ti tad vighāta vacanena iva sakala saṃkilesa samugghāta vacana siddhitaḥ
translated: And since ignorance is the principal cause of the occurrence of the round of rebirths, the expression of its destruction implies the expression of the destruction of the defilements in their entirety.

original: soyeveko gayhatīti. Atha vā sakalasaṃkilesadhammānaṃ muddhabhūtattā avijjāya taṃ
analyzed: gayhati iti atha vā sakala saṃkilesa dhammānam muddha bhūta ttā avijjāya tam
translated: So it is only that which is stated. Or alternatively, since ignorance is the head of all defilements,

original: samugghātoyeveko gayhati. Yathāha –
analyzed: yathā āha
translated: its destruction is stated as the only one. As it is said:

original: “Avijjā muddhāti jānāhi, vijjā muddhādhipātinī;
analyzed: avijjā muddhā ati jānāhi vijjā muddhā adhipātinī
translated: “Know that ignorance is the head; Knowledge is what overcomes the head;

original: Saddhāsatisamādhīhi, chandavīriyena saṃyutā”ti. ;
analyzed: chanda vīriyena
translated: United with faith, mindfulness, concentration, And zeal and energy” .

original: Sanarāmaralokagarunti ettha pana paṭhamapakatiyā avibhāgena sattopi naroti vuccati,
analyzed: ettha pana paṭhama pakatiyā avibhāgena satto api naro ti vuccati
translated: The world of men and gods: here, although a being is called a “man” in the first sense of the word without distinction,

original: idha pana dutiyapakatiyā manujapurisoyeva, itarathā lokasaddassa avattabbatā siyā.
analyzed: idha pana dutiya pakatiyā itarathā loka saddassa avattabba tā siyā
translated: here in the second sense of the word only a human being is a man, otherwise the word “world” would be meaningless.

original: “Yathā hi paṭhamapakatibhūto satto itarāya pakatiyā seṭṭhaṭṭhena pure uccaṭṭhāne
analyzed: yathā hi paṭhama pakati bhūto sattaḥ itarāya pakatiyā seṭṭhaṭṭhena pure ucca ṭṭhāne
translated: “Just as a being who is in the first sense of the word a man is called a ‘man’ in the second sense of the word because he is the best in the second sense of the word, as he sits in a high place in the city,

original: seti pavattatīti purisoti vuccati, evaṃ jeṭṭhabhāvaṃ netīti naroti. Puttabhātubhūtopi
analyzed: sā iti pavattati iti puriso ti vuccati evam jeṭṭha bhāvam neti iti naro ti putta bhātu bhūtaḥ api
translated: so he is called a ‘man’ because he leads the world in the sense of the first-born. Even though he is a son or a brother,

original: hi puggalo mātujeṭṭhabhaginīnaṃ pituṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati, pageva bhattubhūto itarāsa”nti
analyzed: hi puggalaḥ mātu jeṭṭha bhaginīnam pitu ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati pagā iva
translated: A person stands in the place of a mother’s elder sister and of a father’s, and a fortiori of a wife’s and a husband’s.”🔽This is said in the commentary on the Discourse on the Simile of the Saw .

original: nāvāvimānavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Ekasesappakappanena puthuvacanantaviggahena vā narā,
analyzed: nāvā vimāna vaṇṇanāyam vuttam ekasesa pakappanena puthuvacana nta viggahena vā narā
translated: The word narā is used in the sense of many by the method of adding a suffix or by the method of adding a prefix.

original: maraṇaṃ maro, so natthi yesanti amarā, saha narehi, amarehi cāti sanarāmaro.Garati🔽uggacchati uggato pākaṭo bhavatīti garu, garasaddo hi uggame. Apica pāsāṇacchattaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam maro so natthi yesanti amarā saha narehi amarehi ca ati  uggacchati uggataḥ pākaṭaḥ bhavati iti garu gara saddaḥ hi uggame api ca pāsāṇa chattam
translated: The word maraṇa is derived from the root mar, to die. Those who do not have that are amarā . Together with men and gods they are sanarāmara .

original: viya bhāriyaṭṭhena “garū”ti vuccati.
analyzed: viya bhāriyaṭṭhena vuccati
translated: The word garu is derived from the root gar, to rise, to appear, to become manifest. Moreover, it is called garu in the sense of heavy, like a stone umbrella.

original: Mātāpitācariyesu, dujjare alahumhi ca;
analyzed: mātā pitā cariyesu dujjare a lahumhi ca
translated: In the case of mother, father, teacher, one difficult to repay, one who is not lazy,

original: Mahante cuggate ceva, nichekādikaresu ca;
analyzed: mahante cuggate ca iva nicheka ādi karesu ca
translated: one who is great, one who has risen, one who is low, and so on,

original: Tathā vaṇṇavisesesu, garusaddo pavattati.🔽Idha pana sabbalokācariye tathāgate. Keci pana “garu, gurūti ca dvidhā gahetvā bhāriyavācakatte
analyzed: tathā vaṇṇa visesesu garu saddo pavattati  idha pana sabba loka ācariye tathāgate keci pana ca dvidhā gahetvā bhāriya vācaka tte
translated: and in the case of different kinds of colour, the word garu is used.🔽But here it is used of the Tathāgata, the teacher of the whole world.

original: garusaddo, ācariyavācakatte tu gurusaddo”ti vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ. Pāḷivisaye
analyzed: garu saddaḥ ācariya vācaka tte tu guru saddo ti vadanti tam na gahetabbam pāḷi visaye
translated: Some, however, take it in two ways, as garu and gurū, and say that the word garu signifies heavy and the word gurū signifies teacher. But that should not be accepted.

original: hi sabbesampi yathāvuttānamatthānaṃ vācakatte garusaddoyevicchitabbo akārassa ākārabhāvena
analyzed: hi sabbesam pi vācaka tte akārassa ākāra bhāvena
translated: For the word “gāru” is to be understood as the vocative case of the word “garu” in the sense of “venerable” for all the above-mentioned meanings.

original: “gārava”nti taddhitantapadassa savuddhikassa dassanato. Sakkatabhāsāvisaye pana gurusaddoyevicchitabbo🔽ukārassa vuddhibhāvena aññathā taddhitantapadassa dassanatoti. Sanarāmaro ca so loko
analyzed: gāravanti taddhi tanta padassa savuddhikassa dassanato sakkata bhāsā visaye pana  ukārassa vuddhi bhāvena aññathā taddhi tanta padassa dassanato ti sa nara amaraḥ ca saḥ loko
translated: This is because the word “gāru” is shown as having a long vowel and a suffix. But the word “garu” is to be understood as the vocative case in the sense of “venerable” in the context of the Sakyan language.🔽This is because the word “garu” is shown without a long vowel and a suffix. The world of gods and men is “sanarāmaraloka.”

original: cāti sanarāmaraloko, tassa garūti tathā, taṃ sanarāmaralokagaruṃ. “Sanaramarūlokagaru”ntipi
analyzed: tassa tathā tam sa nara amara loka garum sa nara marū loka garuntipi
translated: “Tathā” means “in that way.” “Sanarāmaralokagaruṃ” means “venerable in the world of gods and men.”

original: paṭhanti, tadapi ariyāgāthattā vuttilakkhaṇato, atthato ca yuttameva. Atthato hi
analyzed: paṭhanti tat api ariyā gāthattā vutti lakkhaṇataḥ atthato ca yuttam eva atthataḥ hi
translated: Some read “sanaramarūlokagaruṃ,” which is also appropriate in terms of the characteristics of the meter and the meaning, because it is an ariya verse. For in terms of the meaning,

original: dīghāyukāpi samānā yathāparicchedaṃ maraṇasabhāvattā marūti devā vuccanti. Etena
analyzed: dīghāyukā api samānā yathāparicchedam devāḥ vuccanti etena
translated: even though they have a long life span, the gods are called “marū” because they have the nature of death within their allotted life span. By this,

original: devamanussānaṃ viya tadavasiṭṭhasattānampi yathārahaṃ guṇavisesāvahatāya bhagavato
analyzed: deva manussānam viya tad avasiṭṭha sattānam pi yathāraham guṇa visesa āvahatāya bhagavataḥ
translated: it is shown that the Blessed One is worthy of praise for the special qualities he possesses, as appropriate, not only for gods and humans but also for the remaining beings.

original: upakārakataṃ dasseti. Nanu cettha devamanussā padhānabhūtā, atha kasmā tesaṃ appadhānatā
analyzed: upakārakatam dasseti nanu ca ittha deva manussā padhāna bhūtāḥ atha kasmā tesam appadhāna tā
translated: He shows the helpfulness. But if gods and men are the principal matter here, then why is their being not principal

original: niddisīyatīti? Atthato padhānatāya gahetabbattā. Añño hi saddakkamo, añño atthakkamoti
analyzed: niddisīyati iti atthataḥ padhāna tāya gahetabba ttā aññaḥ hi sadda kkamaḥ aññaḥ attha kkamaḥ ti
translated: shown? —Because they are to be taken as principal in meaning. For the order of words is one thing, the order of meaning another.

original: saddakkamānusārena padhānāpadhānabhāvo na codetabbo. Edisesu hi samāsapadesu padhānampi
analyzed: sadda kkama anusārena padhāna apadhāna bhāvaḥ na codetabbaḥ edisesu hi samāsa padesu padhānam pi
translated: So the state of being principal or not principal should not be insisted on according to the order of words. For in such compound words as this, the principal

original: appadhānaṃ viya niddisīyati yathā taṃ “sarājikāya parisāyā”ti, tasmā sabbattha atthatova
analyzed: appadhānam viya niddisīyati yathā tam sa rājikāya parisāya ati tasmā sabbattha atthataḥ va
translated: is shown as if it were not principal, as in the phrase “with the royal retinue” . So the meaning should be sought in all cases

original: adhippāyo gavesitabbo, na byañjanamattena. Yathāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ gavesitabbaḥ na byañjana mattena yathā āhu porāṇā
translated: by the meaning and not by the letter. As the ancients said:

original: “Atthañhi nātho saraṇaṃ avoca,
analyzed: atthan hi nātho saraṇam avoca
translated: “The Lord has declared the meaning to be the refuge,

original: Na byañjanaṃ lokahito mahesi.
analyzed: na byañjanam loka hitaḥ mahā isi
translated: Not the letter, the Great Sage who benefits the world.

original: Tasmā akatvā ratimakkharesu,
analyzed: tasmai a katvā rati makkharesu
translated: So the wise man should not delight in the letter,

original: Atthe niveseyya matiṃ matimā”ti. ;
analyzed: atthe niveseyya matim matimā ati
translated: But should seek the meaning in the case of all of them.”

original: Kāmañcettha sattasaṅkhārabhājanavasena tividho loko, garubhāvassa pana adhippetattā
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha satta saṅkhāra bhājana vasena tividhaḥ lokaḥ garu bhāvassa pana adhippeta ttā
translated: Herein, although the world is threefold as the world of beings, the world of its physical support, and the world of the locality of the two,

original: garukaraṇasamatthasseva yujjanato sattalokavasena attho gahetabbo. So hi lokīyanti
analyzed: garu karaṇa samatthassa iva satta loka vasena atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ saḥ hi lokīyanti
translated: For the world is what is “lokiya” ,🔽and the word “loka” is said by those who know the words to be for the purpose of seeing.

original: ettha puññāpuññāni, tabbipāko cāti loko, dassanatthe ca lokasaddamicchanti saddavidū.
analyzed: ettha puñā apuññāni tad bipāko ca ati lokaḥ dassana atthe ca loka saddam icchanti sadda vidū
translated: And here the “gods” in the phrase “the world of gods” are the gods of the four divine abodes. Another method: the word “loka” is a collective term here,

original: Amaraggahaṇena cettha upapattidevā adhippetā. Aparo nayo – samūhattho ettha lokasaddo🔽samudāyavasena lokīyati paññāpīyatīti katvā. Saha narehīti sanarā, teyeva amarāti
analyzed: amara ggahaṇena ca ittha upapatti devāḥ adhippetāḥ aparaḥ nayaḥ samūha atthaḥ ettha loka saddo  samudāya vasena lokīyati paññāpīyati iti katvā saha narehi iti sa narā teyā iva amarāti
translated: for it is “lokiya” in the sense of “it is seen as a collection” .🔽“With men” is “with the human” . Those same gods are “the immortals” .

original: sanarāmarā, tesaṃ loko tathā, purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Amarasaddena cettha upapattidevā
analyzed: tesam tesam tathā purima nayena iva yojetabbam amara saddena ca ittha upapatti devā
translated: The world of them is “the world of the immortals” . It should be construed in the way already stated. And here the word “immortal” includes the gods of the pure abodes as well as the gods of the four divine abodes.

original: viya visuddhidevāpi saṅgayhanti. Tepi hi paramatthato maraṇābhāvato amarā. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: viya visuddhi devāḥ api te pi hi paramatthataḥ maraṇa abhāvataḥ amarāḥ imasmin
translated: For they are immortals too in the sense of being free from death.

original: pana atthavikappe narāmarānameva gahaṇaṃ ukkaṭṭhaniddesavasena yathā “satthā devamanussāna”nti.
analyzed: pana attha vikappe nara amarānam eva gahaṇam ukkaṭṭha niddesa vasena yathā satthā deva manussānam ti
translated: But in this interpretation only the gods of the four divine abodes and the human beings are included, as in the passage, “The Master, the Kinsman of the Sun, taught the Dhamma to the world with its gods, its Māras and its Brahmās, this generation with its recluses and brahmans, with its princes and its people” .

original: Tathā hi sabbānatthaparihānapubbaṅgamāya niravasesahitasukhavidhānatapparāya niratisayāya
analyzed: tathā hi sabba anattha parihāna pubbaṅgamāya niravasesa hita sukha vidhāna tad parāya niratisayāya
translated: For in this interpretation the gods of the pure abodes are not included, since they are not a condition for the arising of the path.

original: payogasampattiyā, sadevamanussāya pajāya accantamupakāritāya aparimitanirupamappabhāvaguṇasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: payoga sampattiyā sa deva manussāya pajāya accantam upakāritāya aparimita nirupama ppabhāva guṇa samaṅgi tāya
translated: and by the excellence of his application, he is the most helpful to the world with its deities, and he is endowed with the quality of having an immeasurable, incomparable, and sublime essence,

original: ca sabbasattuttamo bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ uttamamanaññasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ca sabba sattuttamaḥ bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam uttamam anañña sādhāraṇam
translated: and he is the most excellent of all beings. He is the object of veneration in immeasurable world systems for immeasurable beings, and he is not shared in common with any other.

original: gāravaṭṭhānanti. Kāmañca itthīnampi tathāupakārattā bhagavā garuyeva, padhānabhūtaṃ🔽pana lokaṃ dassetuṃ purisaliṅgena vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Neruttikā pana avisesanicchitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: gārava ṭṭhānanti kāmañca itthīnam pi padhāna bhūtam  pana lokam dassetum purisa liṅgena vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam neruttikā pana avisesa nicchita ṭṭhāne
translated: And although he is helpful in the same way to women, he is nevertheless venerated as the most excellent.🔽But he is described as having the male sex in order to show that he is the most excellent in the world.🔽But the Neruttikas wish to have it described in the same way in the place where the distinction is not intended, as in the passage, “Men, Nāgas, and Gandhabbas, having paid homage, departed.”

original: tathā niddiṭṭhamicchanti yathā “narā nāgā ca gandhabbā, abhivādetvāna pakkamu”nti. Tathā cāhu –
analyzed: tathā niddiṭṭham icchanti yathā narāḥ nāgā ca gandhabbāḥ abhivādetvāna pakkamunti tathā ca āhu
translated: And they say:🔽“By the sex of a neuter,

original: “Napuṃsakena liṅgena, saddodāhu pumena vā;
analyzed: napuṃsakena liṅgena pumena vā
translated: Or by the sound of a male,🔽It should be known that it is described,

original: Niddissatīti ñātabbamavisesavinicchite”ti.
analyzed: niddissati iti ñātabbam avisesa vinicchitā iti
translated: In the case of the undistinguished.”

original: Vandeti ettha pana –
analyzed: vanda iti ettha pana
translated: Herein, in the word vande,🔽The present participle, the fifth case,

original: Vattamānāya pañcamyaṃ, sattamyañca vibhattiyaṃ;
analyzed: vattamānāya pañcamyam sattamyam ca
translated: And the locative case,

original: Etesu tīsu ṭhānesu, vandesaddo pavattati.
analyzed: etesu tīsu ṭhānesu vande saddo pavattati
translated: These are the three places where the word vande occurs.

original: Idha pana vattamānāyaṃ aññāsamasambhavato. Tattha ca uttamapurisavasenattho gahetabbo
analyzed: idha pana vattamānā ayam aññāsama sambhavato tattha ca uttama purisa vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: But here, since the other is present, the meaning should be taken as “I pay homage to the Blessed One.”

original: “ahaṃ vandāmī”ti. Namanathutiyatthesu ca vandasaddamicchanti ācariyā, tena ca sugatapadaṃ,
analyzed: aham vandāmi iti namana thutiya tthesu ca vanda saddam icchanti ācariyā tena ca sugata padam
translated: The teachers say that the word vandā is to be construed with the words “I pay homage” in the sense of “praise” and “adoration.”

original: nāthapadaṃ vā ajjhāharitvā yojetabbaṃ. Sobhanaṃ gataṃ gamanaṃ etassāti sugato. Gamanañcettha
analyzed: nātha padam vā ajjhāharitvā yojetabbam sobhanam gatam gamanam etassa ati sugataḥ gamanam ca ittha
translated: The word sugata should be construed as follows: “gone well” .🔽Here “going” is twofold: bodily going and going by knowledge.

original: kāyagamanaṃ, ñāṇagamanañca, kāyagamanampi vineyyajanopasaṅkamanaṃ, pakatigamanañcāti
analyzed: kāya gamanam ñāṇa gamanañca kāya gamanam pi vineyya jana upasaṅkamanam pakati gamanam ca ati
translated: Bodily going is twofold: going to those to be trained and natural going.

original: dubbidhaṃ. Bhagavato hi vineyyajanopasaṅkamanaṃ ekantena tesaṃ hitasukhanipphādanato🔽sobhanaṃ, tathā lakkhaṇānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitarūpakāyatāya dutavilambitakhalitānukaḍḍhananippīḷanukkuṭika-kuṭilākulatādidosarahita-
analyzed: dubbidham bhagavataḥ hi vineyya jana upasaṅkamanam ekantena tesam hita sukha nipphādanato  sobhanam tathā lakkhaṇa anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita rūpa kāya tāya duta vilambita khalita anukaḍḍhana nippīḍa nukkuṭika kuṭila ākula tā ādi dosa rahita
