analyzed: vaṭṭati sadda matta paṭiniddesena atthassa avirodhanataḥ vagga sutta ādīnam nibbacanam paratas
translated: it is proper to indicate it as if it were turned around in the mind, either as a near expression or as a distant expression, because there is no contradiction in the meaning by the mere indication of the word. The explanation of the Vaggasutta and so on will be given later.

original: āvi bhavissati. Tayo vaggā yassāti tivaggo. Catuttiṃsa suttāni ettha saṅgayhanti,
analyzed: āvi bhavissati tayaḥ vaggāḥ yassa ati ti vaggo catuttiṃsa suttāni ettha saṅgayhanti
translated: It has three vaggas, thus it is Tivagga. Thirty-four suttas are included here,

original: tesaṃ vā saṅgaho gaṇanā etthāti catuttiṃsasuttasaṅgaho.
analyzed: tesam vā saṅgahaḥ gaṇanā ettha ati catuttiṃsa sutta saṅgaho
translated: or the collection, the reckoning, of them is here, thus it is Catuttiṃsasuttasaṅgaha.

original: Attano saṃvaṇṇanāya paṭhamasaṅgītiyaṃ nikkhittānukkameneva pavattabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ saṃvaṇṇanāya paṭhama saṅgītiyam nikkhitta anukkamena iva pavatta bhāvam dassetuṃ
translated: In order to show that it occurs in the same order as it was placed in the First Rehearsal by way of its own praise,

original: “tassa…pe… nidānamādī”ti vuttaṃ. Ādibhāvo hettha saṅgītikkameneva veditabbo. Kasmā
analyzed: nidānam ādi iti vuttam ādi bhāvaḥ ha ittha saṅgīti kkamena iva veditabbaḥ kasmā
translated: “The source, etc., of that is the beginning” is said. The beginning here should be understood by the method of the recitation.

original: pana catūsu āgamesu dīghāgamo paṭhamaṃ saṅgīto, tattha ca sīlakkhandhavaggo paṭhamaṃ🔽nikkhitto, tasmiñca brahmajālasuttaṃ, tatthāpi nidānanti? Nāyamanuyogo katthacipi🔽na pavattati sabbattheva vacanakkamamattaṃ paṭicca anuyuñjitabbato. Apica saddhāvahaguṇattā
analyzed: pana catūsu āgamesu dīgha āgamo paṭhamam saṅgītaḥ tattha ca sīla kkhandha vaggo paṭhamam  nikkhittaḥ tasmin ca brahmajāla suttam tattha api nidānam ti na ayam anuyogaḥ katthacipi  na pavattati sabbattha iva vacana kkama mattam paṭicca anuyuñjitabbataḥ api ca saddhā vaha guṇa ttā
translated: But why is the Long Collection recited first among the four collections, and why is the Chapter of the Monastic Code placed first in it,

original: dīghāgamova paṭhamaṃ saṅgīto. Saddhā hi kusaladhammānaṃ bījaṃ. Yathāha “saddhā bījaṃ🔽tapo vuṭṭhī”ti. Saddhāvahaguṇatā cassa heṭṭhā dassitāyeva. Kiñca bhiyyo – katipayasuttasaṅgahatāya
analyzed: dīgha āgamaḥ uva paṭhamam saṅgītaḥ saddhā hi kusala dhammānam bījam yathā āha saddhā bījam  tapaḥ vuṭṭhi iti saddhā vaha guṇa tā cassa heṭṭhā dassitāya iva kiñca bhiyyas katipaya sutta saṅgaha tāya
translated: and why is the Brahmajāla Sutta placed first in that, and why is the source placed first in that? This inquiry does not occur anywhere. It should be inquired into only in regard to the order of the words in all cases. Moreover, the Long Collection is recited first because it has the quality of arousing faith. Faith is the seed of wholesome qualities, as it is said, “Faith is the seed,

original: ceva appaparimāṇatāya ca uggahaṇadhāraṇādisukhato paṭhamaṃ saṅgīto. Tathā hesa catuttiṃsasuttasaṅgaho,
analyzed: ca iva appa parimāṇa tāya ca uggahaṇa dhāraṇa ādi sukhataḥ paṭhamam tathā ha esa catuttiṃsa sutta saṅgaho
translated: austerity is the rain” . The quality of arousing faith has already been shown above. Furthermore, it is recited first because it contains a few suttas and is of small extent, and is thus easy to learn, to remember, etc. For it contains forty-four suttas,

original: catusaṭṭhibhāṇavāraparimāṇo ca. Sīlakathābāhullato pana sīlakkhandhavaggo paṭhamaṃ🔽nikkhitto. Sīlañhi sāsanassa ādi sīlapatiṭṭhānattā sabbaguṇānaṃ. Tenevāha “tasmā🔽tiha tvaṃ bhikkhu ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu. Ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ?🔽Sīlañca suvisuddha”ntiādi. Sīlakkhandhakathābāhullato hi so “sīlakkhandhavaggo”ti
analyzed: catur aṭṭhi bhāṇa vāra parimāṇaḥ ca sīla kathā bāhullato pana sīlakkhandha vaggo paṭhamam  nikkhittaḥ sīlam hi sāsanassa ādi sīla patiṭṭhāna ttā sabba guṇānam tena iva āha tasmā  tiha tvam bhikkhu ādim eva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu kaḥ ca ādi kusalānam dhammānam  sīlam ca su visuddha ntiādi sīla kkhandha kathā bāhullataḥ hi saḥ sīla kkhandha vaggo ti
translated: and it is of the same extent as the four or six recitation sections. But the first section is called the “Chapter on Morality” because of the abundance of talk on morality. For morality is the beginning of the Dispensation because all special qualities are based on morality. That is why it is said: “Therefore, bhikkhu, purify first of all the beginning of wholesome states, which is faith. What is the beginning of wholesome states? It is virtue that is quite purified” . And the first section is called the “Chapter on Morality” because of the abundance of talk on the aggregate of morality.🔽

original: vutto. Diṭṭhiviniveṭhanakathābhāvato pana suttantapiṭakassa niravasesadiṭṭhivibhajanaṃ🔽brahmajālasuttaṃ paṭhamaṃ nikkhittanti veditabbaṃ. Tepiṭake hi buddhavacane brahmajālasadisaṃ🔽diṭṭhigatāni niggumbaṃ nijjaṭaṃ katvā vibhattasuttaṃ natthi. Nidānaṃ pana paṭhamasaṅgītiyaṃ🔽mahākassapattherena puṭṭhena āyasmatā ānandena desakālādinidassanatthaṃ paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: vuttaḥ diṭṭhi viniveṭhana kathā bhāvato pana suttanta piṭakassa niravasesa diṭṭhi vibhajanam 🔽brahmajāla suttam paṭhamam nikkhittanti veditabbam tepiṭake hi buddha vacane brahmajāla sadisam 🔽diṭṭhi gatāni niggumbam nijjaṭam katvā vibhatta suttam na atthi nidānam pana paṭhama saṅgītiyam 🔽mahākassapa therena puṭṭhena āyasmatā ānandena desa kāla ādi nidassana tham paṭhamam
translated: and it is of the length of four or six recitations. But the first chapter is called the Chapter on Morality because of the abundance of talk on morality there. For morality is the beginning of the Dispensation because all special qualities have morality as their foundation. That is why it is said: “Therefore, bhikkhu, purify first of all your own morality; when your morality is pure, purify understanding. What is the beginning of profitable things? Morality is the beginning of profitable things. Morality is the foundation of profitable things” . And that is why it is called the Chapter on Morality. But the Brahmajāla Sutta should be understood as the first sutta in the Sutta Piṭaka because it is the complete analysis of all views. For there is no sutta in the Buddha’s word that so thoroughly uproots and destroys the jungle of views as the Brahmajāla Sutta. The Nidāna Sutta was recited first at the First Council because it was asked for by the Elder Mahākassapa and was expounded by the venerable Ānanda in order to show the occasion, etc.,

original: nikkhittanti. Tenāha “brahmajālassāpī”tiādi. Tattha ca “āyasmatā”tiādinā desakaṃ
analyzed: nikkhittanti tena āha brahmajālassa api itiādi tattha ca āyasmatā iti ādinā desakam
translated: And here he specifies the teacher with the words ‘by the venerable’

original: niyameti, paṭhamasaṅgītikāleti pana kālanti, ayamattho upari āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: niyama iti paṭhama saṅgīti kāla iti pana kālanti ayam atthaḥ upari bhavissati
translated: and the time with the words ‘at the first council.’ But the meaning of this will become clear later.

original: Paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the first great recitation🔽Now, in connection with the words ‘at the time of the first great recitation,’

original: Idāni “paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikāle”ti vacanappasaṅgena taṃ paṭhamamahāsaṅgītiṃ dassento,
analyzed: idāni paṭhama mahāsaṅgīti kāla iti vacana ppasaṅgena tam paṭhama mahāsaṅgītim dassento
translated: showing that first great recitation,

original: yassaṃ vā paṭhamamahāsaṅgītiyaṃ nikkhittānukkamena saṃvaṇṇanaṃ kattukāmattā taṃ vibhāvento
analyzed: vā paṭhama mahā saṅgītiyam nikkhitta anukkamena saṃvaṇṇanam kattu kāma ttā tam vibhāvento
translated: he distinguishes it in order to comment on it in the same sequence in which it was placed at the first great recitation.

original: tassā tantiyā āruḷhāyapi idha vacane kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “paṭhamamahāsaṅgīti nāma cesā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tassā tantiyā vacane kāraṇam dassetum paṭhama mahāsaṅgī iti nāma ca isā ati ādim āha
translated: And in order to show the reason for the inclusion of this statement in that Thread, he said ‘This is called the first great recitation’ and so on.

original: Ettha hi kiñcāpi…pe… māruḷhāti etena nanu sā saṅgītikkhandhake tantimāruḷhā, kasmā
analyzed: ettha hi māruḷhā ati etena nanu sā saṅgīti kkhandhake tantim āruḷhā kasmā
translated: Herein, although it is included in the Thread in the Khandhakas of the Council,

original: idha puna vuttā, yadi ca vuttā assa niratthakatā, ganthagarutā ca siyāti codanālesaṃ
analyzed: idha puna vuttā yadi ca vuttā assa niratthaka tā gantha garu tā ca siyāti codana ālesam

original: Saddavidū pana “mo sivo candimā cevā”ti vuttaṃ sakkatabhāsānayaṃ gahetvā okārantampi
analyzed: sadda vidū pana mo sivo candimā ca eva ati vuttam sakkata bhāsā nayam gahetvā okāra antam pi
translated: But those who are skilled in the science of language, taking the word mo sivo candimā cevā , which is in the language of the Sakyans,

original: candimavācaka ma-saddamicchanti. Visākhāya yutto puṇṇamā yatthāti visākhāpuṇṇamo,🔽soyeva divaso tathā, tasmiṃ. Paccūsati timiraṃ vināsetīti paccūso, pati-pubbo usa-saddo
analyzed: ma saddam icchanti visākhāya yuttaḥ puṇṇamā yattha ati visākhāpuṇṇamaḥ  divasaḥ tathā tasmin paccūsati timiram vināseti iti paccūsaḥ patipubbaḥ usa saddo
translated: They want the letter ma to represent the moon. The full moon of the Visākhā constellation is the Visākhā full moon.🔽That very day is so, on that. The dawn breaks the darkness, thus it is dawn. The word usa is a🔽prefix and pubba is a suffix. It is said that the word neru is a prefix and the word tikā is a suffix. That very

original: rujāyanti hi neruttikā, soyeva samayoti rattiyā pacchimayāmapariyāpanno kālaviseso
analyzed: rujāyanti hi neruttikā so yā iva samayaḥ ti rattiyā pacchima yāma pariyāpanno kāla viseso
translated: time is called the last watch of the night, because it is included in the last watch of the night.

original: vuccati, tasmiṃ. Visākhāpuṇṇamadivase īdise rattiyā pacchimasamayeti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Upādīyate kammakilesehīti upādi, vipākakkhandhā, kaṭattā ca rūpaṃ. So pana upādi
analyzed: vuccati tasmin visākhā puṇṇama divase īdise rattiyā pacchima samaye iti vuttam hoti  upādīyate kamma kilesehi iti upādi vipāka kkhandhā kaṭattā ca rūpam saḥ pana upādi
translated: On that day, the full moon of the Visākhā constellation, on that kind of night, the last watch is what is said.

original: kilesābhisaṅkhāramāranimmathane anossaṭṭho, idha khandhamaccumāranimmathane ossaṭṭhona
analyzed: kilesa abhisaṅkhāra māra nimmathane an ussaṭṭhaḥ idha khandha maccu māra nimmathane ossaṭṭhaḥ na
translated: It is clung to by defilements of action, thus it is what is clung to. The resultants and the materiality that is the result of kamma are what is clung to. But that which is clung to is not outstanding in the overcoming of the defilements that are the instigators of kamma. Herein, it is outstanding in the overcoming of the aggregates that are the instigators of Mara.

original: sesito, tasmā natthi etissā upādisaṅkhāto seso, upādissa vā sesoti katvā “anupādisesā”ti
analyzed: tasmā natthi etissā upādi saṅkhātaḥ sesaḥ upādissa vā sesaḥ ti katvā anupādisesā ti
translated: Therefore it is called “without remainder” because there is no remainder of what is clung to in the form of the aggregates, or because there is a remainder of what is clung to.

original: vuccati. Nibbānadhātūti cettha nibbutimattaṃ adhippetaṃ, nibbānañca taṃ sabhāvadhāraṇato
analyzed: vuccati nibbāna dhātu uti ca ittha nibbutimattam adhippetam nibbānam ca tam sabhāva dhāraṇato
translated: Herein, the element of extinction is intended as mere extinction. And that extinction is the nature of the extinction of the aggregates.

original: dhātu cāti katvā. Nibbutiyā hi kāraṇapariyāyena asaṅkhatadhātu tathā vuccati. Itthambhūtalakkhaṇe🔽cāyaṃ karaṇaniddeso. Anupādisesatāsaṅkhātaṃ imaṃ pakāraṃ bhūtassa pattassa parinibbutassa
analyzed: dhātu ca ati katvā nibbutiyā hi kāraṇa pariyāyena asaṅkhata dhātu tathā vuccati ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe  ca ayam karaṇa niddesaḥ an upādisesa tā saṅkhātam imam pakāram bhūtassa pattassa parinibbutassa
translated: This is a locative construction in the sense of a state.🔽The Blessed One, who has become, who has attained, who has fully extinguished,

original: bhagavato lakkhaṇe nibbānadhātusaṅkhāte atthe tatiyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Nanu ca “anupādisesāyā”ti🔽nibbānadhātuyāva visesanaṃ hoti, na parinibbutassa bhagavato, atha kasmā taṃ bhagavā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ lakkhaṇe nibbāna dhātu saṅkhāte atthe tatiyā iti vuttam hoti nanu ca anupādisesāya ati  nibbāna dhātuyā ava visesanam hoti na parinibbutassa bhagavataḥ atha kasmā tam bhagavā
translated: has the state called the extinction element as his characteristic, is what is said.🔽But is not the word “without remainder” a distinguishing term for the extinction element, not for the Blessed One who has attained extinction? So how is it said that “the Blessed One has attained it”?

original: pattoti vuttoti? Nibbānadhātuyā sahacaraṇato. Taṃsahacaraṇena hi bhagavāpi anupādisesabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pattaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti nibbānadhātuyā sahacaraṇato tad sahacaraṇena hi bhagavā api anupādisesa bhāvam
translated: Because it is concurrent with the extinction element. For it is said that the Blessed One has attained the state of being without remainder because he has attained extinction concurrent with that.

original: pattoti vuccati. Atha vā anupādisesabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ imaṃ pakāraṃ pattāya nibbānadhātuyā
analyzed: patto ti vuccati atha vā anupādisesa bhāva saṅkhātam imam pakāram pattāya nibbānadhātuyā
translated: Or alternatively, it is proper to say that the extinction element, which has attained the state called “without remainder,”

original: lakkhaṇe sañjānanakiriyāya tatiyātipi vattuṃ yujjati. Anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyāti
analyzed: lakkhaṇe sañjānana kiriyāya tatiya atipi vattum yujjati an upādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā ati
translated: has the extinction element as its characteristic, in the sense of the act of causing to be known.🔽The extinction element without remainder:

original: ca anupādisesanibbānadhātu hutvāti attho. “Ūnapañcabandhanena pattenā”ti. Ettha hi
analyzed: ca anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu hutvā ati atthaḥ ūna pañca bandhanena pattena ati ettha hi
translated: and became the element of Nibbāna without residue of clinging.🔽“With a bowl with less than five mends”: here🔽they say that the meaning is “having become a bowl with less than five mends.”

original: ūnapañcabandhanapatto hutvāti atthaṃ vadanti. Apica nibbānadhātuyā anupādisesāya
analyzed: ūna pañca bandhana pattaḥ hutvā iti attham vadanti apica nibbānadhātuyā an upādisesāya
translated: Moreover, it is appropriate to say “having become the element of Nibbāna without residue of clinging, without residue of clinging.”

original: anupādisesā hutvā bhūtāyātipi yujjati. Vuttañhi udānaṭṭhakathāya nandasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽“upaḍḍhullikhitehi kesehīti itthambhūtalakkhaṇe karaṇavacanaṃ vippakatullikhitehi
analyzed: an upādisesāḥ hutvā bhūtāya atipi yujjati vuttam hi udāna ṭṭhakathāya nanda sutta vaṇṇanāyam  upaḍḍhullikhitehi kesehi iti ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe karaṇa vacanam vippa katullikhitehi
translated: For this is said in the Udāna Commentary in the commentary on the Nandasutta:🔽“With half-shaved hair”: the locative case is used in the sense of a characteristic, the meaning being “having been pointed out by hair that was half-shaved.”

original: kesehi upalakkhitāti attho”ti esanayo īdisesu. Dhātubhājanadivaseti jeṭṭhamāsassa🔽sukkapakkhapañcamīdivasaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, tañca na “sannipatitāna”nti etassa visesanaṃ,🔽“ussāhaṃ janesī”ti etassa pana visesanaṃ “dhātubhājanadivase bhikkhūnaṃ ussāhaṃ janesī”ti
analyzed: kesehi upalakkhitā ati atthaḥ ti esa nayo īdisesu dhātu bhājana divase iti jeṭṭha māsassa  sukka pakkha pañcamī divasam sandhāya vuttam tat ca na sannipatitānam ti etassa visesanam  ussāham janesi iti etassa pana visesanam dhātu bhājana divase bhikkhūnam ussāham janesi iti

original: ussāhajananassa kālavasena bhinnādhikaraṇavisesanabhāvato. Dhātubhājanadivasato hi

translated: is a specification of “assembled.” And this “inspired the bhikkhus”🔽is connected with “the bhikkhus” in “the elder of the Sangha.” But what is the size of that Sangha?

translated: are distinctive in the meaning of a sentence.🔽Let the general term be well known,

translated: as oil and the robe of the Sublime One.

analyzed: bhikkhu sata sahassa saddam añña pada antara abhāvena vākye viya apekkhitabba tthassa  gamaka ttā sattannam bhikkhu sata sahassānam ti hi etassa saṅgha sadde avayavībhāvena  sambandho tassa api sāmi bhāvena thera sadde ti sattannam bhikkhu sata sahassānam ti

analyzed: ca gaṇa pāmokkha bhikkhūya iva sandhāya vuttam tadā hi sannipatitāḥ bhikkhū ettakā ti  gaṇana patham atikkantā tathā hi veḷuva gāme vedanā vikkhambhanato paṭṭhāya nacirena iva
translated: For at that time the bhikkhus who had assembled were so numerous that they exceeded the count of seven hundred thousand.

analyzed: bhagavā parinibbāyissati iti sutvā tatas tatas āgatesu bhikkhūsu eka bhikkhu pi pakkantaḥ
translated: For when the bhikkhus heard that “before long the Blessed One will attain final Nibbāna,” they came from all directions to the Veḷuvana, and not a single bhikkhu left.

original: nāma natthi. Yathāhu –
analyzed: nāma natthi yathā āhu
translated: As it is said:

original: “Sattasatasahassāni, tesu pāmokkhabhikkhavo;
analyzed: satta sata sahassāni tesu pāmokkha bhikkhavaḥ
translated: “Seven hundred thousand bhikkhus, The chief bhikkhus in the Sangha,

analyzed: theraḥ mahākassapaḥ uva saṅgha ttheraḥ tadā ahū ti  āyasmā mahākassapaḥ anussarantaḥ maññamāno cintayantaḥ hutvā ussāham janesi anussarantaḥ
translated: The Elder Mahā Kassapa was the Elder of the Community then.

original: maññamāno cintayanto āyasmā mahākassapo ussāhaṃ janesīti vā sambandho. Mahantehi
analyzed: maññamānaḥ cintayantaḥ āyasmā mahākassapaḥ ussāham janesi iti vā sambandhaḥ mahantehi
translated: The Elder Mahā Kassapa generated zeal while recollecting, while conceiving, while reflecting. The Elder Mahā Kassapa generated zeal while recollecting, while conceiving, while reflecting.

original: sīlakkhandhādīhi samannāgatattā mahanto kassapoti mahākassapo. Apica “mahākassapo”ti
analyzed: sīla kkhandha ādīhi samannāgata ttā mahanto kassapo ti mahā kassapaḥ apica mahā kassapo ti
translated: The Elder Mahā Kassapa was great because he was endowed with great aggregates of virtue and so on. Moreover, he was called Mahā Kassapa

original: uruvelakassapo nadīkassapo gayākassapo kumārakassapoti ime khuddānukhuddake there
analyzed: uruvela kassapaḥ nadīkassapaḥ gayākassapaḥ kumārakassapaḥ ti ime khuddānukhuddake there
translated: in order to distinguish him from the lesser Elders named Kassapa, namely Uruvelakassapa, Nadīkassapa, Gayākassapa, and Titthiyakassapa.

original: upādāya vuccati. Kasmā panāyasmā mahākassapo ussāhaṃ janesīti anuyoge sati taṃ kāraṇaṃ🔽vibhāvento āha “sattāhaparinibbute”tiādi. Satta ahāni samāhaṭāni sattāhaṃ. Sattāhaṃ
analyzed: upādāya vuccati kasmai pana ayasmai mahākassapaḥ ussāham janesi iti anuyoge sati tam kāraṇam  vibhāventaḥ āha satta aha parinibbuta itiādi satta ahāni samāhaṭāni sattāham sattāham
translated: But why did the Elder Mahā Kassapa generate zeal? The reason is this:🔽When questioned, he said, “Seven days after the Blessed One had attained final Nibbāna,” etc. Seven days added together make seven days.

original: parinibbutassa assāti tathā yathā “acirapakkanto, māsajāto”ti, antatthaaññapadasamāsoyaṃ,
analyzed: parinibbutassa assa ati tathā yathā acira pakkantaḥ māsa jātaḥ ti anta ttha añña pada samāsaḥ yaṃ
translated: He was one whose final Nibbāna had taken place seven days before. Thus, just as one says “one who has gone away recently,” “one born a month ago,” this is a compound of the type called “having an internal base and a different meaning.”

original: tasmiṃ. Bhagavato parinibbānadivasato paṭṭhāya sattāhe vītivatteti vuttaṃ hoti, etassa
analyzed: tasmin bhagavataḥ parinibbāna divasataḥ paṭṭhāya sattāhe vītivattā iti vuttam hoti etassa
translated: In that, from the day of the Blessed One’s parinibbāna, after seven days had passed, is what is meant. This is the connection with the words “what was said”:

original: “vuttavacana”nti padena sambandho, tathā “subhaddena vuḍḍhapabbajitenā”ti etassapi.
analyzed: vutta vacanam ti padena sambandhaḥ tathā subhaddena vuḍḍha pabbajitena ati etassa api
translated: and likewise with the words “by Subhadda, who had gone forth in old age.”

original: Tattha subhaddoti tassa nāmamattaṃ, vuḍḍhakāle pana pabbajitattā “vuḍḍhapabbajitenā”ti
analyzed: tattha subhaddo ti tassa nāma mattam vuḍḍha kāle pana pabbajita ttā vuḍḍha pabbajitena ati
translated: Herein, Subhadda is his mere name. But because he had gone forth in old age, he is called “who had gone forth in old age.”

original: vuttaṃ, etena subhaddaparibbājakādīhi taṃ visesaṃ karoti. “Alaṃ āvuso”tiādinā tena🔽vuttavacanaṃ nidasseti. So hi sattāhaparinibbute bhagavati āyasmatā mahākassapattherena
analyzed: vuttam etena subhadda paribbājaka ādīhi tam visesam karoti alam āvuso ti ādinā tena  vutta vacanam nidasseti saḥ hi satta aha parinibbute bhagavati āyasmatā mahākassapa therena
translated: By this he makes a distinction between Subhadda the wanderer and others. “Enough, friend” and so on shows

original: saddhiṃ pāvāya kusināraṃ addhānamaggapaṭipannesu pañcamattesu bhikkhusatesu avītarāge🔽bhikkhū antarāmagge diṭṭhaājīvakassa santikā bhagavato parinibbānaṃ sutvā pattacīvarāni
analyzed: saddhim pāvāya kusināram addhāna magga paṭipannesu pañca mattesu bhikkhu satesu a vīta rāge  bhikkhū antarāmagge diṭṭha ājīvakassa santikā bhagavataḥ parinibbānam sutvā patta cīvarāni
translated: what was said by him. For when the Blessed One had been finally emancipated for seven days, the venerable Maha Kassapa the Elder was travelling along the road from Pava to Kusinara with five hundred bhikkhus,

original: chaḍḍetvā bāhā paggayhaṃ nānappakāraṃ paridevante disvā evamāha.
analyzed: chaḍḍetvā bāhā paggayham nānappakāram paridevante disvā evam āha
translated: and the bhikkhus who had not yet overcome their passions were throwing off their robes and bowls and stretching out their arms and lamenting in various ways on hearing from a certain Ajivaka they met on the way that the Blessed One had finally emancipated.🔽So Subhadda said this.

original: Kasmā pana so evamāhāti? Bhagavati āghātena. Ayaṃ kireso khandhake āgate ātumāvatthusmiṃ
analyzed: kasmā pana saḥ evam āha ati bhagavati āghātena ayam kiresaḥ khandhake āgate
translated: Why did he say this? Because of resentment against the Exalted One. This story is told in the Khandhaka.

original: nahāpitapubbako vuḍḍhapabbajito bhagavati kusinārato nikkhamitvā aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi
analyzed: nahāpita pubbakaḥ vuḍḍha pabbajitaḥ bhagavati kusinārataḥ nikkhamitvā aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: A certain man who had been a barber in the past, but who had gone forth when he was old, went with the Exalted One from Kusinārā to Ātumā, together with a company of one thousand two hundred and fifty monks.

original: saddhiṃ ātumaṃ gacchante “bhagavā āgacchatī”ti sutvā “āgatakāleyāgudānaṃ karissāmī”ti🔽sāmaṇerabhūmiyaṃ ṭhite dve putte etadavoca “bhagavā kira tātā ātumaṃ āgacchati mahatā🔽bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi, gacchatha tumhe tātā, khurabhaṇḍaṃ🔽ādāya nāḷiyā vā pasibbakena vā anugharakaṃ āhiṇḍatha, loṇampi telampi taṇḍulampi
analyzed: saddhim ātumam gacchante bhagavā āgacchati iti sutvā āgatakāleyāgudānam karissāmi iti  sāmaṇera bhūmiyam ṭhite dve putte etat avoca bhagavā kira tātā ātumam āgacchati mahatā  bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhu satehi gacchatha tumhe tātā khurabhaṇḍam  ādāya nāḷiyā vā pasibbakena vā anugharakam āhiṇḍatha loṇam pi telam pi taṇḍulam pi
translated: When he heard that the Exalted One was coming, he thought, “When he arrives, I will offer him rice gruel.”

original: khādanīyampi saṃharatha, bhagavato āgatassa yāgudānaṃ karissāmī”ti. Te tathā akaṃsu.
analyzed: khādanīyam pi saṃharatha bhagavataḥ āgatassa yāgu dānam karissāmi iti te tathā akaṃsu

analyzed: tathā hi tattha līna attha pakāsaniyam ācariya dhammapāla ttherena yāvat eva ati iminā samāna attham
translated: For in the explanation of the meaning of līna , the Elder Dhammapāla, the teacher, says: “As long as has the same meaning as for just as long as.

original: ‘yāvade’ti idaṃ pada”nti vuttaṃ. Potthakesu pana katthaci “yāvadevā”ti ayameva pāṭho
analyzed: yāvadā iti idam padam ti vuttam potthakesu pana katthaci yāvat eva iti ayam eva pāṭhaḥ
translated: This is the word for as long as” . But in some books the reading is “yāvadeva” .

original: dissati. Api ca yāvadeti yattakaṃ samāpattivihāraṃ viharituṃ ākaṅkhāmi, tattakaṃ🔽samāpattivihāraṃ viharāmīti samāpattiṭṭhāne, yattakaṃ abhiññāvohāraṃ voharituṃ ākaṅkhāmi,
analyzed: dissati api ca yāvat eti yattakam samāpatti vihāram viharitum ākaṅkhāmi tattakam  samāpatti vihāram viharāmi iti samāpatti ṭṭhāne yattakam abhiññā vohāram voharitum ākaṅkhāmi
translated: and I see. But I live as long as I want to live in the attainment-abode,🔽and I speak as long as I want to speak in the attainment-abode,🔽

original: tattakaṃ abhiññāvohāraṃ voharāmīti abhiññāṭhāne ca saha pāṭhasesena attho veditabbo.🔽Ācariyadhammapālattherenāpi tadevatthaṃ yathālābhanayena dassetuṃ “yattake samāpattivihāre,
analyzed: tattakam abhiññā vohāram voharāmi iti abhiññā ṭhāne ca saha pāṭha sesena atthaḥ veditabbo  ācariya dhammapāla ttherena api tat evattham yathā lābha nayena dassetum yattake samāpatti vihāre
translated: But as far as I wish is the meaning in the case of the bases of the attainments, namely, “I live as far as I wish in the life of the attainments,” and in the case of the bases of the kinds of direct-knowledge, namely, “I exercise the kinds of direct-knowledge as far as I wish.” The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance, together with the words “as far as I wish.”

original: abhiññāvohāre vā ākaṅkhanto vihārāmi ceva voharāmi ca, tathā kassapopīti attho”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Apare pana “yāvadeti ‘yaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ ākaṅkhāmi, taṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ upasampajja
analyzed: abhiññā vohāre vā ākaṅkhantaḥ vihārāmi ca iva voharāmi ca tathā kassapo pi iti attho ti  vuttam apare pana yāvat eti yam paṭhamajjhānam ākaṅkhāmi tam paṭhamajjhānam upasampajja
translated: And the teacher Dhammapāla has explained the meaning in the same way, saying: “I live and exercise the kinds of direct-knowledge as far as I wish in the life of the attainments and in the kinds of direct-knowledge.”

original: vihārāmī’tiādinā samāpattiṭṭhāne, iddhividhābhiññāṭhāne ca ajjhāharitassa ta-saddassa
analyzed: vihārāmi iti ādinā samāpatti ṭṭhāne iddhividha abhiññā ṭhāne ca ajjhāharitassa ta saddassa
translated: But others say that the meaning is this: “As far as I wish” is the meaning in the case of the bases of the attainments, namely, “I enter upon and dwell in the first jhāna as far as I wish,” and so on, and in the case of the bases of the kinds of direct-knowledge, namely, “I wield the supernormal power as far as I wish,” and so on.

original: kammavasena ‘yaṃ dibbasotaṃ ākaṅkhāmi, tena dibbasotena sadde suṇāmī’tiādinā sesābhiññāṭhāne
analyzed: kamma vasena yam dibba sotam ākaṅkhāmi tena dibba sotena sadde suṇāmi iti ādinā sesa abhiññā ṭhāne
translated: The word “as far as I wish” is to be construed with each of the kinds of direct-knowledge in the way beginning, “I hear the divine ear element sounds that are human and divine” .

original: karaṇavasena yojanā vattabbā”ti vadanti. Vivicceva kāmehīti ettha eva-saddo niyamattho,
analyzed: karaṇa vasena yojanā vattabbā ati vadanti vivicca iva kāmehi iti ettha eva saddaḥ niyama atthaḥ
translated: The word eva in the phrase vivicceva kāmehī is in the sense of restriction,

original: ubhayattha yojetabbo. Yamettha vattabbaṃ, tadupari āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: ubhayattha yojetabbaḥ yam ettha vattabbam tat upari bhavissati
translated: and it should be construed with both terms. What should be said here will be said later.

original: Navānupubbavihārachaḷabhiññāppabhedeti ettha navānupubbavihārā nāma anupaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: nava anupubba vihāra chaḍabhiññā appabhedā iti ettha nava anupubba vihārāḥ nāma anupaṭipāṭiyā
translated: The nine successive abidings and the six kinds of direct knowledge are called the “supramundane states” in the sense of being superior to the mundane.

original: samāpajjitabbattā evaṃsaññitā nirodhasamāpattiyā saha aṭṭha samāpattiyo. Chaḷabhiññā
analyzed: samāpajjitabba ttā evaṃsaññitā nirodha samāpattiyā saha aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ chaḍḍabhiññā
translated: The nine successive abidings are the eight attainments beginning with the first jhāna and including the attainment of cessation, which are so called because they are to be entered upon and dwelt in successively one after the other.

original: nāma āsavakkhayañāṇena saha pañcābhiññāyo. Katthaci potthake cettha ādisaddo dissati.
analyzed: nāma āsava kkhaya ñāṇena saha pañca abhiññāyo katthaci potthake ca ittha ādi saddo dissati
translated: The six kinds of direct knowledge are the five kinds of direct knowledge beginning with the divine eye together with knowledge of the destruction of cankers.🔽In some editions of the text the word ādi is found here.

original: So anadhippeto yathāvuttāya pāḷiyā gahetabbassa atthassa anavasesattā. Manussesu,🔽manussānaṃ vā uttaribhūtānaṃ, uttarīnaṃ vā manussānaṃ jhāyīnañceva ariyānañca dhammoti
analyzed: saḥ anadhippetaḥ yathā vuttāya pāḷiyā gahetabbassa atthassa an avasesa ttā manussesu  manussānam vā uttaribhūtānam uttarīnam vā manussānam jhāyīnam ca iva ariyānam ca dhammaḥ ti
translated: But that is not intended, since the meaning stated in the above passage is complete in itself.🔽The Dhamma of those who are superior to human beings, or the Dhamma of human beings that is superior, is the “supramundane Dhamma.”

original: uttarimanussadhammo, manussadhammā vā uttarīti uttarimanussadhammo. Dasa kusalakammapathā
analyzed: uttari manussa dhammo manussa dhammāḥ vā uttarī iti uttari manussa dhammo dasa kusala kammapathā
translated: The ten courses of wholesome kamma are the “mundane Dhamma.”

original: cettha vinā bhāvanāmanasikārena pakatiyāva manussehi nibbattetabbato, manussattabhāvāvahanato
analyzed: ca ittha vinā bhāvanā manasikārena pakatiyā va manussehi nibbattetabbataḥ manussa atta bhāva āvahanataḥ
translated: Herein, it is a human state since it can be produced by human beings without the need for development of understanding, and it is a human state since it leads to human rebirth.

original: ca manussadhammo nāma, tato uttari pana jhānādi uttarimanussadhammoti veditabbo.🔽Samasamaṭṭhapanenāti “ahaṃ yattakaṃ kālaṃ, yattake vā samāpattivihāre, yattakā abhiññāyo
analyzed: ca manussadhammo nāma tatas uttari pana jhāna ādi uttarimanussadhammo ti veditabbo  sama sama ṭhapanena ati aham yattakam kālam yattake vā samāpatti vihāre yattakā
translated: But what is beyond that is a superhuman state.

original: ca vaḷañjemi, tathā kassapopī”ti evaṃ samasamaṃ katvā ṭhapanena. Anekaṭṭhānesu ṭhapanaṃ,
analyzed: ca tathā kassapopī iti evam samasamam katvā ṭhapanena aneka ṭhānesu ṭhapanam
translated: By the same means of establishing: by establishing the same means of establishing, thinking, “For as long as I live the life of one attained to jhāna and direct-knowledge, and for as long as I live the life of one who has attained to this or that jhāna or direct-knowledge, so also will Kassapa.”🔽The establishment of the same means of establishing in many places,

original: kassacipi uttarimanussadhammassa asesabhāvena ekantasamaṭṭhapanaṃ vā sandhāya “samasamaṭṭhapanenā”ti
analyzed: kassaci pi uttari manussa dhammassa asesa bhāvena ekanta samaṭṭhapanam vā sandhāya sama samaṭṭhapanena ati
translated: or the establishment of the same means of establishing in the complete sense of the word as a superhuman state, is what is meant by “by the same means of establishing.”

original: vuttaṃ, idañca navānupubbavihārachaḷabhiññābhāvasāmaññena pasaṃsāmattanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam idam ca nava anupubba vihāra chaṭṭha abhiññā bhāva sāmaññena pasaṃsā mattan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: And this is said in praise of the fact that he was the same in respect of the nine successive abidings and the six kinds of direct-knowledge.

original: Na hi āyasmā mahākassapo bhagavā viya devasikaṃ catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasaṅkhyā
analyzed: na hi āyasmā mahākassapaḥ bhagavā viya devasikam catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhyā
translated: For the venerable Mahā Kassapa was not like the Blessed One, who,

original: samāpattiyo samāpajjati, yamakapāṭihāriyādivasena ca abhiññāyo vaḷañjetīti. Ettha
analyzed: samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjati yamaka pāṭihāriya ādi vasena ca ettha
translated: and he enters upon the attainments and wields the kinds of direct-knowledge, such as the Twin Marvels.

original: ca uttarimanussadhamme attanā samasamaṭṭhapanenā”ti idaṃ nidassanamattanti veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi –
analyzed: ca uttari manussa dhamme attanā sama sama ṭṭhapanena ati idam nidassanam atta nti veditabbam tathā hi
translated: And here the demonstration should be understood as follows:🔽“Advise the bhikkhus, Kassapa, instruct the bhikkhus, Kassapa, give the bhikkhus a discourse on the True Idea, Kassapa, either I should advise the bhikkhus, Kassapa, or you should.🔽Either I should instruct the bhikkhus, Kassapa, or you should.

original: “Ovada kassapa bhikkhū, karohi kassapa bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ, ahaṃ vā kassapa bhikkhū ovadeyyaṃ, tvaṃ vā. Ahaṃ vā kassapa bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ kareyyaṃ, tvaṃ vā”ti –
analyzed: ovada kassapa bhikkhū karohi kassapa bhikkhūnam dhammim katham aham vā kassapa bhikkhū ovadeyyam tvam vā aham vā kassapa bhikkhūnam dhammim katham kareyyam tvam vā ati
translated: Either I should give the bhikkhus a discourse on the True Idea, Kassapa, or you should” .

original: Evampi attanā samasamaṭṭhapanamakāsiyevāti.
analyzed: evam pi attanā
translated: So he did give advice that was equal to his own.🔽“Just as” : just as the “restraint of the body” was commended, so too the “restraint of the mind” was commended.

original: Tathāti rūpūpasaṃhāro yathā anuggahito, tathā pasaṃsitoti. Ākāse pāṇiṃ cāletvāti
analyzed: tathā ati rūpa upasaṃhāraḥ yathā anuggahito tathā pasaṃsito ti ākāse pāṇim cāletvā iti
translated: “Waving his hand in the air” :

original: bhagavatā attanoyeva pāṇiṃ ākāse cāletvā kulesu alaggacittatāya ceva karaṇabhūtāya
analyzed: bhagavatā attanoyā iva pāṇim ākāse cāletvā kulesu a lagga citta tāya ca iva karaṇa bhūtāya
translated: the Blessed One, having waved his hand in the air, commended the bhikkhu’s mind’s lack of attachment to families and his being a means of their welfare.

original: pasaṃsitoti sambandho. Alaggacittatāyāti vā ādhāre bhummaṃ, ākāse pāṇiṃ cāletvā kulūpakassa
analyzed: pasaṃsito ti sambandhaḥ a lagga citta tāya ati vā ādhāre bhummam ākāse pāṇim cāletvā kulūpakassa
translated: The construction is “lack of attachment to families” . Or alternatively, “lack of attachment to families” is locative absolute;

original: bhikkhuno alaggacittatāya kulesu alagganacittena bhavituṃ yuttatāya ceva maññeva
analyzed: bhikkhuno a lagga citta tāya kulesu a laggana cittena bhavitum yutta tāya ca iva
translated: Because of the monk’s lack of attachment to families, it is proper for him to be without attachment to families.

original: sakkhiṃ katvā pasaṃsitoti attho. Yathāha –
analyzed: sakkhim katvā pasaṃsito ti atthaḥ yathā āha
translated: Having made it possible for him to think, he praises him. As it is said:

original: “Atha kho bhagavā ākāse pāṇiṃ cālesi seyyathāpi bhikkhave, ayaṃ ākāse pāṇi na sajjati🔽na gayhati na bajjhati, evameva kho bhikkhave yassa kassaci bhikkhuno kulāni upasaṅkamato
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā ākāse pāṇim cālesi seyyathā api bhikkhave ayam ākāse pāṇi na sajjati  na gayhati na bajjhati evam eva kho bhikkhave yassa kassaci bhikkhunaḥ kulāni upasaṅkamataḥ
translated: “Then the Blessed One moved his hand in space as if it were not there. Just as, monks, this hand does not stick, does not cling, does not adhere to space,

original: kulesu cittaṃ na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati ‘labhantu lābhakāmā, puññakāmā karontu🔽puññānī’ti. Yathā sakena lābhena attamano hoti sumano, evaṃ paresaṃ lābhena attamano
analyzed: kulesu cittam na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati labhantu lābha kāmā puñña kāmā karontu  puññāni iti yathā sakena lābhena atta manaḥ hoti su mano evam paresam lābhena atta manaḥ
translated: so too, monks, when a monk approaches families, his mind does not stick, does not cling, does not adhere to families, thinking, ‘May those who desire gain gain it; may those who desire merit make merit;

original: hoti sumano. Evarūpo kho bhikkhave bhikkhu arahati kulāni upasaṅkamituṃ. Kassapassa
analyzed: hoti sumanaḥ evarūpaḥ kho bhikkhave bhikkhu arahati kulāni upasaṅkamitum kassapassa
translated: may those who desire to do what is good be glad.’ Just as he is pleased and glad with his own gain, so he is pleased and glad with the gain of others. A monk of this kind, monks, is fit to approach families.

original: bhikkhave kulāni upasaṅkamato kulesu cittaṃ na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati ‘labhantu
analyzed: bhikkhave kulāni upasaṅkamataḥ kulesu cittam na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati labhantu
translated: When Kassapa, monks, approaches families, his mind does not stick, does not cling, does not adhere to families, thinking, ‘May those who desire gain gain it;🔽may those who desire merit make merit; may those who desire to do what is good be glad.’

original: lābhakāmā, puññakāmā karontu puññānī’ti. Yathā sakena lābhena attamano hoti sumano,🔽evaṃ paresaṃ lābhena attamano hoti sumano”ti.🔽Tattha ākāse pāṇiṃ cālesīti nīle gaganantare yamakavijjukaṃ sañcālayamāno viya heṭṭhābhāge,
analyzed: lābha kāmā puñña kāmā karontu puññāni iti yathā sakena lābhena atta manaḥ hoti su mano  evam paresam lābhena atta manaḥ hoti su manoti  tattha ākāse pāṇim cālesi iti nīle gagana antare yamaka vijjukam sañcālayamāno viya heṭṭhābhāge
translated: “May they make merit for the sake of gain and for the sake of merit.” Just as he is pleased and delighted with his own gain,🔽so he is pleased and delighted with the gain of others.”🔽Herein, he waved his hand in the air: just as one might move a pair of lightning flashes in the blue sky, so he moved them in the lower part,

original: uparibhāge, ubhato ca passesu pāṇiṃ sañcālesi, idañca pana tepiṭake buddhavacane🔽asambhinnapadaṃ nāma. Attamanoti sakamano, na domanassena pacchinditvā gahitamano.🔽Sumanoti tuṭṭhamano, idāni yo hīnādhimuttiko micchāpaṭipanno evaṃ vadeyya “sammāsambuddho🔽‘alaggacittatāya ākāse cālitapāṇūpamā kulāni upasaṅkamathā’ti vadanto aṭṭhāne ṭhapeti,🔽asayhabhāraṃ āropeti, yaṃ na sakkā kātuṃ, taṃ kārehī”ti, tassa vādapathaṃ pacchinditvā
analyzed: upari bhāge ubhatas ca passesu pāṇim sañcālesi idam ca pana tepiṭake buddha vacane 🔽asambhinnapadam nāma atta mano ti sa kamanaḥ na domanassena pacchinditvā gahita mano 🔽su mano ti tuṭṭha mano idāni yaḥ hīna adhimuttikaḥ micchā paṭipannaḥ evam vadeyya sammāsambuddhaḥ 🔽a lagga citta tāya ākāse cālita pāṇu upamā kulāni upasaṅkamatha ati vadantaḥ aṭṭhāne ṭhapeti 🔽asayha bhāram āropeti yam na sakkā kātum tam kārehi iti tassa vāda patham pacchinditvā

original: “sakkā ca kho evaṃ kātuṃ, atthi evarūpo bhikkhū”ti āyasmantaṃ mahākassapattherameva
analyzed: sakkā ca kho evam kātum atthi evarūpaḥ bhikkhu iti āyasmantam mahākassapa theram eva
translated: “It is possible to do so, and there is such a bhikkhu,”

original: sakkhiṃ katvā dassento “kassapassa bhikkhave”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sakkhim katvā dassentaḥ kassapassa bhikkhave tiādim āha
translated: and he shows that it is the Elder Kassapa who is able to do so.

original: Aññampi pasaṃsanamāha “candopamapaṭipadāya cā”ti, candapaṭibhāgāya paṭipadāya ca karaṇabhūtāya pasaṃsito, tassaṃ vā ādhārabhūtāya maññeva sakkhiṃ katvā pasaṃsitoti attho. Yathāha –
analyzed: aññam pi pasaṃsanam āha canda upama paṭipadāya ca ati canda paṭibhāgāya paṭipadāya ca karaṇa bhūtāya pasaṃsitaḥ tassam vā ādhāra bhūtāya maññā iva sakkhim katvā pasaṃsito ti atthaḥ yathā āha
translated: He also praises the way of practice that is like the moon, saying “By the way of practice that is like the moon.” He is praised as one who has made the way of practice that is like the moon the means of his practice, or he is praised as one who has made the moon itself the means of his practice. As it is said:🔽“Bhikkhus, approach families as one who is like the moon:

original: “Candūpamā bhikkhave kulāni upasaṅkamatha apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ niccanavakā🔽kulesu appagabbhā. Seyyathāpi bhikkhave puriso jarudapānaṃ vā olokeyya pabbatavisamaṃ
analyzed: canda upamā bhikkhave kulāni upasaṅkamatha apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam nicca navakā  kulesu appagabbhā seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ jarut apānam vā olokeyya pabbata visamam
translated: with a body and mind that are aloof, ever new,🔽not over-familiar in families. Just as a man might look at a dried-up pond or a dried-up pool or a dried-up river,

original: vā nadīviduggaṃ vā apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ, evameva kho bhikkhave candūpamā
analyzed: vā nadī viduggam vā apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam evam eva kho bhikkhave canda upamā
translated: with a body and mind that are aloof, so too, bhikkhus, approach families as one who is like the moon:

original: kulāni upasaṅkamatha apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ niccanavakā kulesu appagabbhā.
analyzed: kulāni upasaṅkamatha apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam nicca navakāḥ kulesu appa gabbhāḥ
translated: with a body and mind that are aloof, ever new, not over-familiar in families.”

original: Kassapo bhikkhave candūpamo kulāni upasaṅkamati apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittaṃ
analyzed: kassapaḥ bhikkhave canda upamaḥ kulāni upasaṅkamati apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam
translated: Kassapa, like the moon, approaches families, with his body and mind withdrawn,

original: niccanavako kulesu appagabbho”ti.
analyzed: nicca navakaḥ kulesu appa gabbhaḥ ti
translated: always new to families, not familiar with them.

original: Tattha candūpamāti candasadisā hutvā. Kiṃ parimaṇḍalatāya sadisāti? No, apica kho
analyzed: tattha candu upamā ati canda sadisā hutvā kim parimaṇḍala tāya sadisā ati no api ca kho
translated: Herein, like the moon means like the moon. But is he similar to the moon in being round? No, rather

original: yathā cando gaganatalaṃ pakkhandamāno na kenaci saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā sinehaṃ vā ālayaṃ🔽vā nikantiṃ vā patthanaṃ vā pariyuṭṭhānaṃ vā karoti, na ca na hoti mahājanassa piyo
analyzed: yathā candaḥ gagana talam pakkhandamānaḥ na kenacid saddhim santhavam vā sineham vā ālayam  vā nikantim vā patthanam vā pariyuṭṭhānam vā karoti na ca na hoti mahājanassa piyaḥ
translated: just as the moon, when it has risen in the sky, does not make any contact, affection, attachment,

analyzed: manāpaḥ tumhe pi evam kenacid saddhim santhava ādīnam a karaṇena bahu janassa piyā manāpā  canda upamāḥ hutvā khattiya kula ādīni cattāri kulāni upasaṅkamatha ati atthaḥ api ca yathā
translated: bond, desire, or obsession with anyone, and yet it is dear and beloved to the multitude,🔽so you should approach the four families, namely, the aristocratic family, etc., like the moon, with your body and mind withdrawn, by not making any contact, etc., and so be dear and beloved to the multitude.🔽Moreover, just as the moon dispels darkness, spreads out its own beams,

original: cando andhakāraṃ vidhamati, ālokaṃ pharati, evaṃ kilesandhakāravidhamanena, ñāṇālokapharaṇena
analyzed: candaḥ andhakāram vidhamati ālokam pharati evam kilesa ndhakāra vidhamanena ñāṇa āloka pharaṇena
translated: so you should approach the four families like the moon, by dispelling the darkness of defilements and spreading out the beams of your knowledge.

original: ca candūpamā hutvāti evamādīhipi nayehi attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ca canda upamāḥ hutvā iti evamādīhi pi nayehi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning should be seen in this and other ways.

original: Apakasseva kāyaṃ, apakassa cittanti teneva santhavādīnamakaraṇena kāyañca cittañca
analyzed: apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittanti tena iva santhava ādīnam akaraṇena kāyam ca cittam ca
translated: “Having cast off body and mind”: having cast off, not taken up, not seized, body and mind,

original: apakassitvā, akaḍḍhitvā apanetvāti attho. Niccanavakāti niccaṃ navikāva, āgantukasadisā
analyzed: apakassitvā a kaḍḍhitvā apanetvā ati atthaḥ nicca navakā ti niccam navikā ava āgantuka sadisā

original: eva hutvāti attho. Āgantuko hi paṭipāṭiyā sampattagehaṃ pavisitvā sace naṃ gharasāmikā

translated: The meaning is: “having become like a newcomer.” For when a newcomer enters a house by turns, if the master of the house sees him,

original: disvā “amhākaṃ puttabhātaropi vippavāsagatā evaṃ vicariṃsū”ti anukampamānā nisīdāpetvā
analyzed: disvā amhākam putta bhātaraḥ api vippavāsa gatāḥ evam vicariṃsu iti anukampamānāḥ nisīdāpetvā

original: bhojenti, bhuttamattoyeva “tumhākaṃ bhājanaṃ gaṇhathā”ti uṭṭhāya pakkamati, na tehi🔽saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā karoti, kiccakaraṇīyāni vā saṃvidahati, evaṃ tumhepi paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: bhojenti bhutta matta uyā iva tumhākam bhājanam gaṇhatha ati uṭṭhāya pakkamati na tehi  saddhim santhavam vā karoti kicca karaṇīyāni vā saṃvidahati evam tumhe api paṭipāṭiyā
translated: As soon as he has eaten, he gets up and leaves, saying, “Take your bowl.” He does not engage in conversation with them, nor does he make any plans with them.

original: sampattagharaṃ pavisitvā yaṃ iriyāpathesu pasannā manussā denti, taṃ gahetvā pacchinnasanthavā
analyzed: sampatta gharam pavisitvā yam iriyāpathesu pasannāḥ manussāḥ denti tam gahetvā pacchinna santhavā
translated: In the same way, you should enter a house by turns, take what people who are pleased with your deportment give you, and then leave without engaging in conversation with them or making any plans with them.

original: tesaṃ kiccakaraṇīye abyāvaṭā hutvā nikkhamathāti dīpeti. Appagabbhāti na pagabbhā,
analyzed: tesam kicca karaṇīye a byāvaṭāḥ hutvā nikkhamatha ati dīpeti appagabbhā ati na pagabbhā

original: aṭṭhaṭṭhānena kāyapāgabbhiyena, catuṭṭhānena vacīpāgabbhiyena, anekaṭṭhānena manopāgabbhiyena
analyzed: aṭṭha ṭṭhānena kāya pāgabbhiyena catu ṭṭhānena vacī pāgabbhiyena aneka ṭṭhānena manaḥ pāgabbhiyena
translated: and by eight kinds of bodily crookedness, by four kinds of verbal crookedness, and by many kinds of mental crookedness.

original: ca virahitā kulāni upasaṅkamathāti attho.
analyzed: ca virahitā kulāni upasaṅkamatha ati attho
translated: The meaning is: “Go to families free from these.”

analyzed: nadiyāḥ viduggam chinna taṭa ṭṭhānam evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam jarut apāna ādayaḥ  viya hi cattāri kulāni olokana purisaḥ viya bhikkhu yathā pana an apakaṭṭha kāya citto
translated: a place on a river where the bank has collapsed. Just so: here is the correspondence of the similes:

original: tāni olokento puriso tattha patati, evaṃ arakkhitehi kāyādīhi kulāni upasaṅkamanto
analyzed: tāni olokento puriso tattha patati evam arakkhitehi kāya ādīhi kulāni upasaṅkamanto
translated: for the four kinds of families are like the old well, etc., the bhikkhu is like the man who looks into them, but just as the man who looks into them without steadying himself falls in,

original: bhikkhu kulesu bajjhati, tato nānappakāraṃ sīlapādabhañjanādikaṃ anatthaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: bhikkhu kulesu bajjhati tatas nānappakāram sīla pāda bhañjana ādikam anattham pāpuṇāti
translated: so the bhikkhu who visits families without guarding his body, etc., is ruined in families, and then he suffers various kinds of misfortune such as the breaking of his virtue, etc.

original: Yathā pana apakaṭṭhakāyacitto puriso tattha na patati, evaṃ rakkhiteneva kāyena,
analyzed: yathā pana apakaṭṭha kāya cittaḥ puriso tattha na patati evam rakkhitena iva kāyena
translated: But just as the man who steadies himself does not fall in, so the bhikkhu who visits families with his body guarded, etc.,

analyzed: rakkhitāya vācāya rakkhitehi cittehi su upaṭṭhitāya satiyā apakaṭṭha kāya cittaḥ hutvā

analyzed: kulāni upasaṅkamantaḥ bhikkhu kulesu na bajjhati athassa sīla saddhā samādhi paññā saṅkhātāni

analyzed: pāda hattha kucchi sīsāni na bhañjanti rāga kaṇṭaka ādayaḥ na vijjhanti sukhitaḥ yenakāmam
translated: his hands called body and mind, his head called mindfulness, are not broken. The thorns of lust, etc., do not pierce him. He goes happily wherever he wants,

original: agatapubbaṃ nibbānadisaṃ gacchati, evarūpo ayaṃ mahākassapoti hīnādhimuttikassa micchāpaṭipannassa
analyzed: agata pubbam nibbāna disam gacchati evarūpaḥ ayam mahākassapaḥ ti hīna adhimuttikassa micchā paṭipannassa

original: vādapathapacchindanatthaṃ mahākassapattheraṃ eva sakkhiṃ katvā dassento “kassapo
analyzed: vāda patha pacchindana attham mahākassapa theram eva sakkhim katvā dassento kassapaḥ
translated: He spoke, making the Elder Kassapa himself the example, saying: “Kassapa, bhikkhus. ”

original: bhikkhave”tiādimāhāti. Evampettha atthamicchantialaggacittatāsaṅkhātāya candopamapaṭipadāya
analyzed: bhikkhave tiādim āha ati evam pa ittha attham icchanti a lagga citta tā saṅkhātāya canda upama paṭipadāya

original: karaṇabhūtāya pasaṃsito, tassaṃ vā ādhārabhūtāya maññeva sakkhiṃ katvā pasaṃsitoti,

original: evaṃ sati ceva-saddo, ca-saddo ca na payujjitabbo dvinnaṃ padānaṃ tulyādhikaraṇattā,

original: ayameva attho pāṭho ca yuttataro viya dissati parinibbānasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ “ākāse pāṇiṃ
analyzed: ayam eva attho pāṭho ca yuttataraḥ viya dissati parinibbāna sutta vaṇṇanāyam ākāse pāṇim
translated: and this meaning and this reading seem more appropriate. In the commentary to the Parinibbana Sutta, “in the sky,🔽

original: Tassa kimaññaṃ āṇaṇyaṃ bhavissati, aññatra dhammavinayasaṅgāyanāti adhippāyo. Tattha🔽tassāti yaṃ-saddassa kāraṇanidassane “tasmā”ti ajjhāharitvā tassa meti attho, kiriyāparāmasane
analyzed: tassa kimaññam āṇaṇyam bhavissati aññatra dhamma vinaya saṅgāyanā ti adhippāyaḥ tattha  tassa iti kāraṇa nidassane tasmā iti ajjhāharitvā tassa mā iti atthaḥ kiriyā parāmasane
translated: The intention is this: “What other freedom from debt could there be for him, apart from the recitation of the Dhamma and the Discipline?”

analyzed: dissati evam sati kiriyā parāmasane tassa ati aparam padam ajjhāharitabbam na atthi  yassa ati aṇaṇaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ āṇaṇyam dhamma vinaya saṅgāyanam ṭhapetvā aññam kim
translated: If that is so, then in the sense of a verbal noun, another word must be supplied, such as “tassā.”🔽“He who has no debt” is ananata; the state of that is ananata. Apart from the recitation of the Dhamma and the Discipline, what other freedom from debt could there be for him? There could not be any.

original: nāma tassa iṇavirahitattaṃ bhavissati, na bhavissati evāti attho. “Nanu maṃ bhagavā”tiādinā
analyzed: nāma tassa iṇa virahita ttam bhavissati na bhavissati eva ati atthaḥ nanu mama bhagavā iti ādinā

analyzed: vuttam eva attham upamā vasena vibhāveti saka kavaca aissariya an uppadānena ti ettha kavacaḥ

analyzed: pana abhiññā samāpatti nidassanena ati daṭṭhabbam kula vaṃsa patiṭṭhāpakam ti kula vaṃsassa  kula paveṇiyā patiṭṭhāpakam mā iti padassa nicca sa apekkha ttā saddhamma vaṃsa patiṭṭhāpakaḥ ti
translated: “The establishment of the family lineage” : the establishment of the family lineage,🔽of the family tradition. The compound “saddhammavaṃsappatiṭṭhāpako me”

analyzed: samāsaḥ idam vuttam hoti sattu saṅgha nimmaddanena attanaḥ kula vaṃsa ppatiṭṭhāpana attham
translated: is made by the addition of the word “me” , which expresses the idea of permanence. This is what is said: “Just as a king, for the purpose of establishing his own family lineage by the destruction of the seven assemblies,

analyzed: saka kavaca aissariya an uppadānena kula vaṃsa patiṭṭhāpakam puttam rājā viya bhagavā api
translated: bestows his own armour and sovereignty,

original: maṃ dīghadassī “saddhammavaṃsappatiṭṭhāpako me ayaṃ bhavissatī”ti mantvā sāsanapaccatthikagaṇanimmaddanena
analyzed: mam dīghadassī saddhamma vaṃsa patiṭṭhāpakaḥ me ayam bhavissati iti mantvā sāsana paccatthika gaṇa nimmaddanena
translated: so the Blessed One, seeing that I was far-sighted, thinking ‘This will be the establishment of the lineage of the True Dhamma for me,’ by the destruction of the multitude of adversaries to the Dispensation,

analyzed: saddhamma vaṃsa patiṭṭhāpana attham cīvara dāna sama samaṭṭhapana saṅkhātena iminā asādhāraṇa anuggahena
translated: and he favoured him with this special favour called the establishing of the robe-offering immediately after the establishing of the True Dhamma,

original: anuggahesi nanu, imāya ca uḷārāya pasaṃsāya pasaṃsi nanūti. Iti cintayantoti ettha
analyzed: anuggahesi nanu imāya ca uḷārāya pasaṃsāya pasaṃsi nanu uti iti cintayanto ti ettha
translated: and he praised him with this high praise, did he not? “ Contemplating thus: here

original: itisaddena “antaradhāpeyyuṃ, saṅgāyeyyaṃ, kimaññaṃ āṇaṇyaṃ bhavissatī”ti vacanapubbaṅgamaṃ,
analyzed: iti saddena antaradhāpeyyum saṅgāyeyyam kimaññam āṇaṇyam bhavissati iti vacana pubbaṅgamam
translated: the word thus indicates the three sentences beginning with “they would disappear, they would recite, what other freedom would there be?”

original: “ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjatī”tiādi vākyattayaṃ nidasseti.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati itiādi vākyattayam nidasseti
translated: or “it is possible that this might happen,” etc.

original: Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ saṅgītikkhandhakapāḷiyā sādhento āha “yathāhā”tiādi. Tattha🔽yathāhāti kiṃ āha, mayā vuttassa atthassa sādhakaṃ kiṃ āhāti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathā vā🔽yena pakārena mayā vuttaṃ, tathā tena pakārena pāḷiyampi āhāti attho. Yathā vā yaṃ
analyzed: idāni saṅgīti kkhandhaka pāḷiyā sādhentaḥ āha yathā āha atiādi tattha  yathā āha ati kim āha mayā vuttassa atthassa sādhakam kim āha ati vuttam hoti yathā vā  yena pakārena mayā vuttam tathā tena pakārena pāḷiyam pi āha ati atthaḥ yathā vā yaṃ
translated: Now, in order to establish the meaning stated thus, he said “Yathāhā” , etc. Herein🔽yathāhā means what did he say? He said what establishes the meaning stated by me, is what is meant. Or else🔽yathā means in what way. In the way stated by me, in that way the text also says, is the meaning. Or else

original: vacanaṃ pāḷiyaṃ āha, tathā tena vacanena mayā vuttavacanaṃ saṃsandati ceva sameti
analyzed: vacanam pāḷiyam āha tathā tena vacanena mayā vutta vacanam saṃsandati ca iva sameti
translated: yathā means as. In the way the text says, in that way my statement agrees with and fits in with🔽the statement in the text.

original: ca yathā taṃ gaṅgodakena yamunodakantipi vattabbo pāḷiyā sādhanatthaṃ udāharitabhāvassa
analyzed: ca yathā tam gaṅgā udakena yamunā udakam ti pi vattabbaḥ pāḷiyā sādhana ttham udāharita bhāvassa
translated: and it can be said of it as of the water of the Ganges and the water of the Yamunā that it is “to be demonstrated by the texts” .🔽because it is known by direct experience, and because the word “known” is used in the expression of the meaning.

original: paccakkhato viññāyamānattā, viññāyamānatthassa ca saddassa payoge kāmācārattā. Adhippāyavibhāvanatthā
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ viññāyamāna ttā viññāyamāna atthassa ca saddassa payoge kāma ācāra ttā adhippāya vibhāvana tthā

analyzed: hi attha yojanā yathā vā yena pakārena dhamma vinaya saṅgāyana ttham bhikkhūnam ussāham
translated: Or else, the meaning is that the text is also in the same way as the method by which the monks were inspired to the purpose of the recitation of the Dhamma and Discipline.

original: janesi, tathā tena pakārena pāḷiyampi āhāti attho. Evamīdisesu.
analyzed: tathā tena pakārena pāḷiyam pi āha ati attho evamīdisesu
translated: In such passages as this.

original: Ekamidāhanti ettha idanti nipātamattaṃ. Ekaṃ samayanti ca bhummatthe upayogavacanaṃ,
analyzed: ettha idanti nipāta mattam ekam ca bhumma tthe upayoga vacanam
translated: In the passage “Ekamidāha” , the word idā is merely a particle. The expression “ekam-idāha” is a locution in the sense of a time,

original: ekasmiṃ samayeti attho. Pāvāyāti pāvānagarato, tattha piṇḍāya caritvā “kusināraṃ
analyzed: ekasmin samaye iti pāvāya ati pāvā nagarataḥ tattha piṇḍāya caritvā kusināram
translated: the meaning being “at one time.” Pāvāya means from the town of Pāvā. The meaning is that he was travelling on the highway, having gone for alms in that place and thinking “I will go to Kusināra.”

original: gamissāmī”ti addhānamaggappaṭipannoti vuttaṃ hoti. Addhānamaggoti ca dīghamaggo vuccati,
analyzed: gamissāmi iti addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ ti vuttam hoti addhāna maggaḥ iti ca dīgha maggaḥ vuccati
translated: And the expression “addhānamaggappaṭipanno” is said of one who is travelling on the highway. The word addhāna is said to mean a long road,

original: dīghapariyāyo hettha addhānasaddo. Mahatāti guṇamahattenapi saṅkhyāmahattenapi mahatā.
analyzed: dīgha pariyāyaḥ ha ittha addhāna saddaḥ mahatā ati guṇa mahat tena api saṅkhyā mahat tena api mahatā
translated: the word addhāna in this case has the meaning of a long period. Mahatā means great by reason of the greatness of its special qualities and by reason of the greatness of its number.

original: “Pañcamattehī”tiādinā saṅkhyāmahattaṃ dasseti, mattasaddo ca pamāṇavacano “bhojane🔽mattaññutā”tiādīsu viya. “Dhammavinayasaṅgāyanatthaṃ ussāhaṃ janesī”ti etassatthassa🔽sādhanatthaṃ āhatā “atha kho”tiādikā pāḷi yathāvuttamatthaṃ na sādheti. Na hettha🔽ussāhajananappakāro āgatoti codanaṃ pariharitumāha “sabbaṃ subhaddakaṇḍaṃ vitthārato
analyzed: pañca mattehi iti ādinā saṅkhyā mahattam dasseti matta saddo ca pamāṇa vacanaḥ bhojane  mattaññu tā ti ādīsu viya dhamma vinaya saṅgāyana attham ussāham janesi iti  sādhana attham āhatā atha kho ti ādikā pāḷi yathāvuttam attham na sādheti na ha ittha  ussāha janana ppakāraḥ āgataḥ iti codanam pariharitum āha sabbam subhadda kaṇḍam vitthārato
translated: “Five hundred” shows the greatness of number. The word “measure” is a synonym for “quantity,” as in “moderation in eating” . The text beginning with “then” is quoted to prove the meaning “they made an effort for the purpose of reciting the Dhamma and Discipline,” but it does not prove the said meaning. For the method of making an effort is not mentioned there. To avoid this objection he says: “The entire Subhaddaka- sutta should be quoted in full” .🔽

original: veditabba”nti. Evampesā codanā tadavatthāyevāti vuttaṃ “tato paraṃ āhā”tiādi. Apica🔽yathāvuttatthasādhikā pāḷi mahatarāti ganthagarutāpariharaṇatthaṃ majjhe peyyālamukhena🔽ādiantameva pāḷiṃ dassento “sabbaṃ subhaddakaṇḍaṃ vitthārato veditabba”nti āha. Tena🔽hi “atha khvāhaṃ āvuso maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdī”ti vuttapāḷito
analyzed: veditabbam ti evam pi isā codanā tad avatthāya iva ati vuttam tatas param āha atiādi apica 🔽yathā vutta ttha sādhikā majjhe peyyāla mukhena 🔽ādi antam eva pāḷim dassentaḥ sabbam subhadda kaṇḍam vitthārataḥ veditabban ti āha tena 🔽hi atha khvā aham āvuso maggā okkamma aññatarasmin rukkha mūle nisīdi iti vutta pāḷito
translated: “Of the five hundred” shows the greatness of number. The word “measure” is a synonym for “quantity,” as in “moderation in eating” . The text beginning with “Then” is cited to prove the meaning “he generated enthusiasm for the purpose of reciting the Dhamma and Discipline,” but it does not prove the stated meaning. For the method of generating enthusiasm is not given here. To avoid the charge, he says, “The entire Subhaddaka- sutta should be understood in detail.” Thus this charge is answered right there. Therefore it is said, “After that, he says” . Furthermore, the text that proves the stated meaning is greater . To avoid the charge of the heaviness of the text, he shows the beginning and end of the text by the method of a refrain in the middle, and says, “The entire Subhaddaka-sutta should be understood in detail.” Therefore, from the text stated thus: “Then, venerable friends, having left the road, I sat down at the root of a tree,”

original: paṭṭhāya “yaṃ na icchissāma, na taṃ karissāmā”ti vuttapāḷipariyosānaṃ subhaddakaṇḍaṃ dasseti.🔽“Tato para”ntiādinā pana tadavasesaṃ “handa mayaṃ āvuso”tiādikaṃ ussāhajananappakāradassanapāḷiṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya yam naḥ icchissāma na tam karissāma ati vutta pāḷi pariyosānam subhadda kaṇḍam dasseti  tatas para nti ādinā pana tad avasesam handa mayam āvuso ti ādikam ussāha janana ppakāra dassana pāḷim
translated: and the Subhadda Khandhaka, which ends with the words, “We will not do what we do not like” .🔽“After that” and so on shows the words of the text that begin “Come, friends, let us recite the True Idea and the Discipline” , which is the way of arousing enthusiasm.

original: Tasmā tato paraṃ āhāti ettha subhaddakaṇḍato paraṃ ussāhajananappakāradassanavacanamāhāti
analyzed: tasmai tatas param āha ati ettha subhadda kaṇḍataḥ param ussāha janana ppakāra dassana vacanam āha ati
translated: So the meaning here should be understood as follows: “After that, he said, after the Subhadda Khandhaka, he said the words that begin ‘Come, friends, let us recite the True Idea and the Discipline’ , which is the way of arousing enthusiasm.”

original: attho veditabbo. Mahāgaṇṭhipadepi hi soyevattho vutto. Ācariyasāriputtattherenāpi
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ mahāgaṇṭhi pade pi hi vuttaḥ ācariya sāriputta therena api
translated: For that is the meaning stated in the Mahā-Gaṇṭhi Commentary too. And it is intended in the same way by the teacher Sāriputta Thera.

original: tatheva adhippeto. Ācariyadhammapālattherena pana “tato paranti tato bhikkhūnaṃ ussāhajananato
analyzed: tathā iva adhippetaḥ ācariya dhammapāla ttherena pana tato paranti tatas bhikkhūnam ussāha jananato
translated: But the teacher Dhammapāla Thera has said that “after that” is after the bhikkhus’ arousing of enthusiasm.

original: parato”ti vuttaṃ, tadetaṃ vicāretabbaṃ heṭṭhā ussāhajananappakārassa pāḷiyaṃ avuttattā.
analyzed: paratas ti vuttam tat etam vicāretabbam heṭṭhā ussāha janana ppakārassa pāḷiyam a vutta ttā
translated: That should be examined, since the way of arousing enthusiasm is not stated in the text below.

original: Ayameva hi ussāhajananappakāro yadidaṃ “handa mayaṃ āvuso dhammañca vinayañca saṅgāyeyyāma,
analyzed: ayam eva hi ussāha janana ppakāraḥ yat idam handa mayam āvuso dhammañca vinayañca saṅgāyeyyāma
translated: For this is the way of arousing enthusiasm, namely, “Come, friends, let us recite the True Idea and the Discipline,

original: pure adhammo dippatī”tiādi. Yadi pana subhaddakaṇḍameva ussāhajananahetubhūtassa
analyzed: pure adhammaḥ dippati itiādi yadi pana subhadda kaṇḍam eva ussāha janana hetu bhūtassa
translated: and the Dhamma is obscured. ”

original: subhaddena vuttavacanassa pakāsanattā ussāhajanananti vadeyya, natthevettha vicāretabbatāti.
analyzed: subhaddena vutta vacanassa pakāsana ttā ussāha janananti vadeyya natthā iva ittha vicāretabba tā ti
translated: If, however, he were to say that the Subhadda Khandhaka is the “arousing of energy” because it reveals the words spoken by Subhadda, which are the cause for arousing energy, then there is no need to examine it.

original: Pure adhammo dippatīti ettha adhammo nāma dasakusalakammapathapaṭipakkhabhūto adhammo.
analyzed: pure adhammo dippati iti ettha adhammo nāma dasa kusala kammapatha paṭipakkha bhūto adhammo
translated: As regards the words “The Dhamma is obscured,” the “Dhamma” is the Dhamma that is the opposite of the ten courses of unwholesome kamma.

original: Dhammavinayasaṅgāyanatthaṃ ussāhajananappasaṅgattā vā tadasaṅgāyanahetuko dosagaṇopi
analyzed: dhamma vinaya saṅgāyana attham ussāha janana ppasaṅga ttā vā tad asaṅgāyana hetukaḥ dosa gaṇaḥ api
translated: Or else, since it is connected with the arousing of energy for the purpose of reciting the Dhamma and Discipline, the multitude of faults that are the cause for the non-recitation of the Dhamma and Discipline

original: sambhavati, “adhammavādino balavanto honti, dhammavādino dubbalā hontī”ti vuttattā
analyzed: sambhavati adhamma vādinaḥ balavantaḥ honti dhamma vādinaḥ dubbalāḥ honti iti vutta ttā
translated: are also possible, for it is said: “The proponents of the Dhamma are weak, the proponents of the Dhamma are few.”

original: sīlavipattiādihetuko pāpicchatādidosagaṇo adhammotipi vadanti. Pure dippatīti api
analyzed: sīla vipatti ādi hetuko vadanti pure api
translated: Therefore they say that the multitude of faults such as evil desires, etc., that are the cause for the failure in virtue, etc., is also the “Dhamma.”🔽As regards the words “The Dhamma is obscured,” the word pure is in the sense of doubt.

original: nāma dippati. Saṃsayatthe hi pure-saddo. Atha vā yāva adhammo dhammaṃ paṭibāhituṃ
analyzed: nāma dippati saṃsaya tthe hi pure saddaḥ atha vā yāva adhammaḥ dhammam paṭibāhitum
translated: Or else, the meaning is: “As long as the Dhamma is able to ward off the Dhamma, then it is obscured.”

original: samattho hoti, tato puretaramevāti attho. Āsanne hi anadhippete ayaṃ pure-saddo.
analyzed: samatthaḥ hoti tatas puretaram eva ati atthaḥ āsanne hi an adhippete ayam pure saddaḥ
translated: For the word pure is used in the sense of nearness when there is no over- powering.

analyzed: dippati iti pure sadda yogena hi anāgata tthe ayam vattamāna payogaḥ yathā
translated: He will shine: he will shine, for the future is expressed by the present tense here by the method of the “pure” word,

original: “purā vassati devo”ti. Tathā hi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: purā vassati devaḥ ti tathā hi vuttam
translated: as in the passage, “Before the rain falls” . For this is said:🔽“In the future, in the past,

original: “Anāgate sannicchaye, tathātīte ciratane;
analyzed: anāgate sannicchaye tathā atīte ciratane
translated: And in the past that is long ago,🔽The word ‘before’ is used by poets

original: Kāladvayepi kavīhi, puresaddo payujjate”ti. ;
analyzed: kāla dvaye pi kavīhi puresaddaḥ payujjata iti
translated: In both the two times, past and future.”🔽“Before, as long as, and in the past,

analyzed: purā iyau apurā yoge niccam vā karahi kadā
translated: Always do, or when,🔽Is said, what is obtained even?

original: Lacchāyamapi kiṃ vutte, vattamānā bhavissatī”ti ca.🔽Keci panettha evaṃ vaṇṇayanti – pureti pacchā anāgate, yathā addhānaṃ gacchantassa🔽gantabbamaggo “pure”ti vuccati, tathā idhāpi maggagamananayena anāgatakālo “pure”ti🔽vuccatīti. analyzed: lacchā ayam api kim vutte vattamānā bhavissati iti ca  keci pana ittha evam vaṇṇayanti purā iti pacchā anāgate yathā addhānam gacchantassa  gantabba maggaḥ purā iti vuccati tathā idha api magga gamana nayena anāgata kālaḥ purā iti  vuccati iti evam sati tad kāla apekkhāya ca ittha vattamāna payogo sambhavati dhammo paṭibāhiyyati iti
translated: The present will be.”

original: etthāpi pure-saddena yojetvā vuttanayena attho veditabbo, tathā dhammopi adhammaviparītavasena,
analyzed: ettha api pure saddena yojetvā vutta nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ tathā dhammaḥ api adhamma viparīta vasena
translated: But some explain it as follows: “In the past” is after, in the future. Just as the road to be gone along by one who is going a journey is called “in the past,” so here the future time is called “in the past” by the method of going along a road. That being so, the present tense is possible here in the expectation of that time. The Dhamma will be rejected: here too the meaning should be understood according to the method stated by the word “in the past.” So too, the Dhamma, in the sense of the opposite of non-Dhamma,

original: ito parampi eseva nayo. Avinayoti pahānavinayasaṃvaravinayānaṃ paṭipakkhabhūto avinayo.🔽Vinayavādino dubbalā hontīti evaṃ iti-saddena pāṭho, so “tato paraṃ āhā”ti ettha
analyzed: itas param pi esa iva nayaḥ avinayo ti pahāna vinaya saṃvara vinayānam paṭipakkha bhūto avinayo  vinaya vādinaḥ dubbalāḥ honti iti evam iti saddena pāṭho so tato param āha ati ettha
translated: The same method applies in the rest. ‘Not the discipline’: the opposite of the discipline of abandoning and the discipline of restraint.

translated: ‘The reciters of the discipline were weak’: the reading is thus, with the word iti after the first iti. It should be construed with the word āha in the next sentence.

original: Tena hīti uyyojanatthe nipāto. Uccinane uyyojentā hi mahākassapattheraṃ evamāhaṃsu
analyzed: tena hi iti uyyojana atthe nipātaḥ uccinane uyyojentā hi mahākassapa theram evam āhaṃsu
translated: ‘Then’: the particle hi is for emphasis. For the elders were urging Mahākassapa to do this:

analyzed: bhikkhū uccinatu iti saṅgītiyāḥ anurūpe bhikkhū uccinitvā upadhāretvā gaṇhātu iti atthaḥ

analyzed: sakala pe pariggahesi iti etena sukkha vipassaka khīṇāsava pariyantānam yathāvutta puggalānam
translated: ‘The entire canon … he grasped’: by this he shows that although those people mentioned, namely, the dry-insight meditator and the one whose cankers are destroyed, have the attainment of learning and the attainment of development,

analyzed: sati pi āgama adhigama sambhave saha paṭisambhidāhi pana tevijja ādi guṇa yuttānam āgama adhigama sampattiyā

analyzed: ukkaṃsa gata ttā saṅgītiyāḥ bahu upakāra tam dasseti sakalam sutta geyya ādikam navaṅgam
translated: The entire nine-part canon consisting of the Discourses, Mixed Prose and Verse, etc.,

analyzed: ettha etassa ati vā sakala nava aṅgam satthu bhagavato sāsanam satthu sāsanam sāsīyati  etena ati katvā tat eva satthu sāsananti sakala navaṅga satthu sāsanam nava vā sutta geyya ādīni
translated: Herein, the word etassa is either the whole of the nine-factored, or the Master’s Dispensation, which is called the Master’s Dispensation because it is taught by the Master.🔽That is the whole of the nine-factored Master’s Dispensation. analyzed: aṅgāni ettha etassa ati vā navaṅgam tam eva satthu sāsanam tat ca sakalam eva na

analyzed: tathā attha kāmena pariyāpuṇitabbā sikkhitabbā diṭṭhadhammika ādi purisa attham vā nipphādetum  pariyattā samatthā ati tīṇi piṭakāni sakala navaṅga satthu sāsana saṅkhātā
translated: So it is. It should be learnt and trained in by one who desires welfare.🔽It is called the “tradition” because it is capable of producing the welfare of men, etc., in the here-and-now. The three Piṭakas,🔽which are called the whole of the nine-factored Master’s Dispensation, are the tradition.

original: pariyatti, taṃ dhārentīti tathā, tādiseti attho. Puthujjana…pe… sukkhavipassakakhīṇāsavabhikkhūti ettha –

translated: They bear that, is what is meant. The word puthujjana is analysed thus:

analyzed: duve puthujjanāḥ vuttāḥ buddhena adicca bandhunā
translated: “Two kinds of ordinary men Are mentioned by the Kinsman of the Sun,

analyzed: andhaḥ puthujjanaḥ ekaḥ kalyāṇa ekaḥ puthujjano ti
translated: One kind of ordinary man is blind, The other kind of ordinary man is good” .

original: Vuttesu kalyāṇaputhujjanāva adhippetā saddantarasannidhānenapi atthavisesassa viññātabbattā.
analyzed: vuttesu kalyāṇa puthujjanā ava adhippetā sadda antara sannidhānena api attha visesassa viññātabba ttā
translated: The good ordinary men are intended here, because a special meaning is to be understood by the proximity of another word.

analyzed: samatha bhāvanā sineha abhāvena sukkhā lūkhā asi niddhā vipassanā etesanti sukkha vipassakā
translated: They are “dry” because of the absence of the affection of the development of serenity, and “insight workers” because of their insight which is “rough” and “unlubricated” .🔽They are “those whose cankers are destroyed” because they are so by the same method.

original: teyeva khīṇāsavāti tathā. “Bhikkhū”ti pana sabbattha yojetabbaṃ. Vuttañhi –

translated: But “monks” should be construed here in all cases, for it is said:

original: “Yañcatthavato saddekasesato vāpi suyyate;
analyzed: vā api
translated: “Whatever is heard by one who is complete in the meaning and the letter

analyzed: tam sambajjhate paccekam yathālābham kadācipi iti
translated: Should be analyzed by him separately, according to the meaning, at any time.”

original: Tipiṭakasabbapariyattippabhedadhareti ettha tiṇṇaṃ piṭakānaṃ samāhāro tipiṭakaṃ,
analyzed: ti piṭaka sabba pariyatti pabheda dharā iti ettha tiṇṇam piṭakānam samāhāraḥ ti piṭakam
translated: “Who bears in mind the divisions of the entire scriptures of the three baskets”: the three baskets are the collection of the three Piṭakas.

original: taṃsaṅkhātaṃ navaṅgādivasena anekabhedabhinnaṃ sabbaṃ pariyattippabhedaṃ dhārentīti🔽tathā, tādise. Anu anu taṃ samaṅginaṃ bhāveti vaḍḍhetīti anubhāvo, soyeva ānubhāvo,
analyzed: tad saṅkhātam navaṅga ādi vasena aneka bheda bhinnam sabbam pariyat tippa bhedam dhārenti iti  tathā tādise anu anu tam samaṅginam bhāveti vaḍḍheti iti anubhāvaḥ
translated: He bears in mind all the divisions of the scriptures, which are classed in the nine divisions of the scriptures, etc.🔽He is “of great influence” because he has “great power” . original: pabhāvo, mahanto ānubhāvo yesaṃ te mahānubhāvā. “Etadaggaṃ bhikkhave”ti bhagavatā
analyzed: pabhāvaḥ mahantaḥ ānubhāvaḥ yesam te mahā anubhāvāḥ etat aggam bhikkhava iti bhagavatā
translated: “This is the highest service, monks,” said the Blessed One,

original: vuttavacanamupādāya pavattattā “etadagga”nti padaṃ anukaraṇajanāmaṃ nāma yathā “yevāpanaka”nti,
analyzed: vutta vacanam upādāya pavatta ttā etat aggam iti padam anukaraṇa ja nāmam nāma yathā yevāpanakam ti
translated: The words “this foremost” are a repetition of the words of the question, just as “yeva-pana-ka” is a repetition of the words of the question in the passage “Ye bhikkhave bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, te je bhikkhave bhikkhū yeva-pana-ka samāpattiparibhāvitā” .

original: tabbasena vuttaṭṭhānantaramidha etadaggaṃ, tamāropiteti attho. Etadaggaṃ eso bhikkhu
analyzed: tad basena vutta ṭṭhāna ntaram idha etad aggam tam āropitā iti atthaḥ etad aggam esaḥ bhikkhu
translated: The meaning is: “after the words ‘this foremost’ had been uttered here, he superimposed it.” Or the meaning can be taken as: “after the words ‘this foremost bhikkhu’ had been superimposed.”🔽Even though it is not superimposed, it is still “picked out” because it possesses the remaining special qualities.

original: aggoti vā āropitepi vaṭṭati. Tadanāropitāpi avasesaguṇasampannattā uccinitā tattha
analyzed: vā āropite pi vaṭṭati tad anāropitā api avasesa guṇa sampanna ttā uccinitā tattha

original: santīti dassetuṃ “yebhuyyenā”ti vuttaṃ. Tisso vijjā tevijjā, tā ādi yesaṃ chaḷabhiññādīnanti
analyzed: santi iti dassetum yebhuyyena iti vuttam tissaḥ vijjā tevijjā tā ādi yesam chaṭṭha abhiññā ādīnam ti

translated: “You are wandering about like one who destroys crops, like one who destroys families. Your following is breaking up, your new supporters are falling away. This young man does not know the right amount.”

translated: Herein, like one who destroys crops means you are wandering about as if destroying crops. Like one who destroys families means you are wandering about as if destroying families. Your new supporters are falling away means, reverend Ānanda, your supporters are falling away, the majority of your new supporters, the novices and young bhikkhus of one and two years’ standing, are falling away. This young man does not know the right amount means this young man does not know his own measure. He is reproaching the elder: I will not be released from the young man’s talk.
