analyzed: paññatta ttā pañattiyo ti vuccanti paññattiyam ca khandha saddo dissati dāru kkhandho
translated: and the rules of training called the rules and the training rules. For these are called “aggregates” because they are laid down by the Blessed One,

original: aggikkhandho, udakakkhandho”tiādīsu viya. Apica bhāgarāsaṭṭhatāpi yujjatiyeva tāsaṃ
analyzed: aggi kkhandhaḥ udaka kkhandhaḥ ti ādīsu api ca bhāga rāsaṭṭha tā api tāsam
translated: just as “a log-raft,” “a log-raft of kindling,” “a log-raft of grass” are called “log-rafts” because they are made of logs.🔽And they are called “aggregates” because they are divided up by aggregates, just as “a log-raft,” “a log-raft of kindling,” “a log-raft of grass” are called “log-rafts” because they are divided up by logs.

original: paññattīnaṃ bhāgato, rāsito ca vibhattattā, taṃ pana vinayapiṭakaṃ bhāṇakehi rakkhitaṃ
analyzed: paññattīnam bhāgataḥ rāsito ca vibhatta ttā tam pana vinaya piṭakam bhāṇakehi rakkhitam
translated: But that Vinaya Piṭaka is guarded by the reciters

original: gopitaṃ saṅgahāruḷhanayeneva cirakālaṃ anassamānaṃ hutvā patiṭṭhahissatīti āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: gopitam saṅgaha āruḷha nayena iva cira kālam anassamānam hutvā patiṭṭhahissati iti āyasmantam
translated: and it will be preserved for a long time without loss by being committed to writing in the way beginning “Thus I have heard” .

original: upālittheraṃ paṭicchāpesuṃ “āvuso imaṃ tuyhaṃ nissitake vācehī”ti.🔽Dhammaṃ saṅgāyitukāmoti suttantābhidhammasaṅgītiṃ kattukāmo “dhammo ca vinayo ca
analyzed: upālittheram paṭicchāpesuṃ āvuso imam tuyham nissitake vācehi iti  dhammam saṅgāyitu kāmo iti suttanta abhidhamma saṅgītim kattu kāmaḥ dhammo ca vinayaḥ ca
translated: They entrusted it to the venerable Upāli, saying, “Friend, recite this as your own responsibility.”

original: desito paññatto”tiādīsu viya pārisesanayena dhammasaddassa suttantābhidhammesveva
analyzed: desito paññatto ti ādīsu viya pārisesa nayena dhamma saddassa suttanta abhidhammesu eva
translated: “He wished to recite the Dhamma”: he wished to recite the Sutta and Abhidhamma Piṭakas. For the word “Dhamma” occurs in the sense of the Sutta and Abhidhamma Piṭakas in such passages as “The Dhamma and Discipline promulgated by the Blessed One is well expounded” .

original: pavattanato. Ayamattho upari āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: pavattanataḥ ayam atthaḥ upari bhavissati
translated: The meaning of this will be made clear later.

original: Saṅghaṃ ñāpesīti ettha heṭṭhā vuttanayena attho veditabbo. Kataraṃ āvuso piṭakanti
analyzed: saṅgham ñāpesi iti ettha heṭṭhā vutta nayena attho veditabbo kataram āvuso piṭakanti
translated: “He announced to the Community”: the meaning should be understood here in the way already given .🔽“Which Piṭaka, friend?”: which of the two Piṭakas, the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma,

original: vinayāvasesesu dvīsu piṭakesu kataraṃ piṭakaṃ. Vinayābhidhammānampi khuddakasaṅgītipariyāpannattā
analyzed: vinaya avasesesu dvīsu piṭakesu kataram piṭakam vinaya abhidhammānam pi khuddaka saṅgīti pariyāpanna ttā
translated: For the Khuddaka Saṅgaṇī is included in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.🔽Therefore it is said, “In the Sutta Piṭaka there are four recitations” .

original: tamantarena vuttaṃ “suttantapiṭake catasso saṅgītiyo”ti. Saṅgītiyoti ca saṅgāyanakāle
analyzed: tam antarena vuttam suttanta piṭake catasso saṅgītiyo ti saṅgītiyo ti ca saṅgāyana kāle
translated: “Recitation” is the recitation at the time of the rehearsal.

original: dīghādivasena visuṃ visuṃ niyametvā saṅgayhamānattā nikāyāva vuccanti. Tenāha “dīghasaṅgīti”ntiādi.🔽Suttāneva sampiṇḍetvā vaggakaraṇavasena tayo vaggā, nāññānīti dassetuṃ “catuttiṃsa🔽suttāni tayo vaggā”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmā catuttisaṃ suttāni tayo vaggā honti, suttāni
analyzed: dīgha ādi vasena visum visum niyametvā vuccanti tena āha dīgha saṅgīti ntiādi  suttāni eva sampiṇḍetvā vagga karaṇa vasena tayaḥ vaggāḥ na aññāni iti dassetum catuttiṃsa  suttāni tayaḥ vaggā iti vuttam tasmā catuttisam suttāni tayaḥ vaggāḥ honti suttāni
translated: They are called “collections” because they are collected by being limited to the long, etc., respectively. Hence he said “The Long Collection,” etc.

original: vā catuttiṃsa, tesaṃ vaggakaraṇavasena tayo vaggā, tesu tīsu vaggesūti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā catuttiṃsa tesam vagga karaṇa vasena tayaḥ vaggā tesu tīsu vaggesu iti yojetabbam
translated: The three sections are made by collecting the discourses together and then dividing them into three sections. To show this he said “The thirty-four discourses are the three sections.” Therefore the thirty-four discourses are the three sections, or the discourses are thirty-four, and by dividing them into three sections there are three sections. In these three sections, thus should it be construed.

original: “Brahmajālasuttaṃ nāma atthi, taṃ paṭhamaṃ saṅgāyāmā”ti vutte kasmāti codanāsambhavato
analyzed: brahmajāla suttam nāma atthi tam paṭhamam saṅgāyāma ati vutte kasmā iti codanā sambhavato
translated: When it is said “There is a discourse called the Brahmajāla, which they collected first,” since it is possible to ask why,

original: “tividhasīlālaṅkata”ntiādimāha. Hetugabbhāni hi etāni. Cūḷamajjhimamahāsīlavasena
analyzed: tividha sīla alaṅkata nti ādim āha hetu gabbhāni hi etāni cūḷa majjhima mahā sīla vasena
translated: he said “Adorned with the threefold virtue,” etc. For these are the womb of the cause.

original: tividhassāpi sīlassa pakāsanattā tena alaṅkataṃ vibhūsitaṃ tathā nānāvidhe micchājīvabhūte
analyzed: tividhassa api sīlassa tena alaṅkatam vibhūsitam tathā nānāvidhe micchājīva bhūte
translated: Since it reveals the threefold virtue, it is adorned with it, embellished by it. So too, it destroys the various kinds of wrong livelihood, such as scheming and hinting, etc.

original: kuhanalapanādayo viddhaṃsetīti nānāvidhamicchājīvakuhanalapanādividdhaṃsanaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: kuhana lapana ādayaḥ viddhaṃseti iti nānāvidham icchājīva kuhana lapana ādi viddhaṃsanam
translated: Thus it is the destroyer of the various kinds of wrong livelihood, scheming, hinting, etc. Herein,

original: kuhanāti kuhāyanā, paccayapaṭisevanasāmantajappanairiyāpathasannissitasaṅkhātena
analyzed: kuhanā ati kuhāyanā paccaya paṭisevana sāmanta jappana eriyāpatha sannissita saṅkhātena
translated: “Deceit” is the deceiving of others by means of the three kinds of scheming: scheming about requisites, scheming about service, and scheming about gains.

original: tividhena vatthunā vimhāpanāti attho. Lapanāti vihāraṃ āgate manusse disvā “kimatthāya🔽bhonto āgatā, kiṃ bhikkhū nimantetuṃ. Yadi evaṃ gacchatha, ahaṃ pacchato bhikkhū
analyzed: tividhena vatthunā vimhāpanā ati atthaḥ lapanā ati vihāram āgate manusse disvā kimatthāya  bhontaḥ āgatā kim bhikkhū nimantetum yadi evam gacchatha aham pacchatas bhikkhū
translated: The meaning is: the deceiving of others by means of these three kinds of scheming. “Flattery” is the speaking of words such as these to people who come to the monastery: “Why have you come, sirs?

original: gahetvā āgacchāmī”ti evamādinā bhāsanā. Ādisaddena pupphadānādayo, nemittikatādayo
analyzed: gahetvā āgacchāmi iti evamādinā bhāsanā ādi saddena puppha dāna ādayaḥ nemittika tā ādayaḥ
translated: Are you going to invite the bhikkhus? If so, go along and I will come later and join you.” And so on. The word “etc.” includes the giving of flowers, etc., and the giving of hints, etc.

original: ca saṅgaṇhāti. Apicettha micchājīvasaddena kuhanalapanāhi sesaṃ anesanaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: ca saṅgaṇhāti api ca ittha micchājīva saddena kuhana lapanāhi sesam anesanam gaṇhāti
translated: Moreover, by the word “wrong livelihood” the other kinds of wrong search are included.

original: Ādisaddena pana tadavasesaṃ mahicchatādikaṃ dussilyanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo
analyzed: ādi saddena pana tad avasesam mahicchata ādikam daṭṭhabbam dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: But by the word “etc.,” the other kinds of unskillfulness such as great desires, etc., should be understood.

original: eva paliveṭhanaṭṭhena jālasarikkhatāya jālaṃ, tassa viniveṭhanaṃ apaliveṭhakaraṇaṃ tathā.
analyzed: eva paliveṭhana aṭṭhena jāla sa rikkha tāya jālam tassa viniveṭhanam a paliveṭha karaṇam tathā
translated: The sixty-two views are a “net” because they resemble a net in the sense that they entangle. The “entanglement” is the entangling of beings.

original: Antarā ca bhante rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandanti ettha antarāsaddo vivare “apicāyaṃ
analyzed: antarā ca bhante rājagaham antarā ca na āḷandanti ettha antarāsaddaḥ vivare apica ayam
translated: “Between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā” : the word “between” means “in the interval between.”

original: bhikkhave tapodādvinnaṃ mahānirayānaṃ antarikāya āgacchatī”tiādīsu viya. Tasmā rājagahassa
analyzed: bhikkhave tapodā dvinnam mahānirayānam antarikāya āgacchati itiādīsu viya tasmā rājagahassa
translated: and so on. Therefore the meaning should be seen as “between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā.”

original: ca nāḷandassa ca vivareti attho daṭṭhabbo. Antarāsaddena pana yuttattā upayogavacanaṃ🔽kataṃ. Īdisesu ṭhānesu akkharacintakā “antarā gāmañca nadiñca yātī”ti evaṃ ekameva
analyzed: ca nāḷandassa ca vivarā iti attho daṭṭhabbo antarā saddena pana yutta ttā upayoga vacanam  īdisesu ṭhānesu akkhara cintakāḥ antarā gāmam ca nadim ca yāti iti evam ekam eva
translated: But because of the word antarā, the word upayoga is used.

original: antarāsaddaṃ payujjanti, so dutiyapadenapi yojetabbo hoti. Ayojiyamāne hi upayogavacanaṃ
analyzed: antarāsaddam payujjanti saḥ dutiya padena api yojetabbaḥ hoti a yojiyamāne hi upayoga vacanam
translated: In such places, those who think in terms of syllables use the word antarā only once, as in “He goes between the village and the river.” But it should be construed with the second word as well.

original: na pāpuṇāti sāmivacanassa pasaṅge antarāsaddayogena upayogavacanassa icchitattā.
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti sāmi vacanassa pasaṅge antarāsadda yogena upayoga vacanassa icchita ttā
translated: For if it is not construed, the word upayoga does not apply, because it is intended that the word upayoga be construed with the word antarā in the sense of a preposition, as in “in the vicinity of the master.”

original: Tattha rañño kīḷanatthaṃ paṭibhānacittavicitraagāramakaṃsu, taṃ “rājāgāraka”nti vuccati,
analyzed: tattha raññaḥ kīḷana ttham tam rājāgārakanti vuccati
translated: There, the clever people built a house of various kinds of reflections for the king’s amusement. That is called “the royal house.”

original: tasmiṃ. Ambalaṭṭhikāti rañño uyyānaṃ. Tassa kira dvārasamīpe taruṇo ambarukkho atthi,
analyzed: tasmim ambalaṭṭhikā ati raññaḥ uyyānam tassa kira dvāra samīpe taruṇaḥ amba rukkho atthi
translated: Ambalaṭṭhikā is the king’s pleasure park. It seems that near its gate there was a young mango tree,

original: taṃ “ambalaṭṭhikā”ti vadanti, tassa samīpe pavattattā uyyānampi “ambalaṭṭhikā” tveva
analyzed: tam ambalaṭṭhikā ti vadanti tassa samīpe pavatta ttā uyyānam pi ambalaṭṭhikā tu eva
translated: and they call it “Ambalaṭṭhikā.” Because it occurred near that, the pleasure park is also called “Ambalaṭṭhikā.”

original: saṅkhyaṃ gataṃ yathā “varuṇanagara”nti, tasmā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ nāma uyyāne rājāgāraketi🔽attho. Aviññāyamānassa hi viññāpanatthaṃ etaṃ ādhāradvayaṃ vuttaṃ rājāgārametassāti
analyzed: saṅkhyam gatam yathā tasmai ambalaṭṭhikā ayam nāma uyyāne rāja āgārakā iti  atthaḥ a viññāyamānassa hi viññāpana attham etam ādhāra dvayam vuttam rāja āgāram etassa ati
translated: and it is reckoned as such, like the city of Varuṇa. So the meaning is: in the royal pleasaunce called the Mango Grove.

original: vā rājāgārakaṃ, uyyānaṃ, rājāgāravati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ nāma uyyāneti attho. Bhinnaliṅgampi
analyzed: vā rājāgārakam uyyānam rājāgāravati ambalaṭṭhikāyam nāma uyyāna iti atthaḥ bhinna liṅgam pi
translated: For the two bases are stated in order to make known what is not known. The meaning is: in the royal pleasaunce called the Mango Grove, which has a royal palace.

original: hi visesanapadamatthī”ti keci vadanti, evaṃ sati rājāgāraṃ ādhāro na siyā. “Rājāgāraketi🔽evaṃnāmake uyyāne abhiramanārahaṃ kira rājāgārampi. Tattha, yassa vasenetaṃ evaṃ🔽nāmaṃ labhatī”ti vajirabuddhitthero. Evaṃ sati “ambalaṭṭhikāya”nti āsannataruṇambarukkhena
analyzed: hi visesana padam atthi iti keci vadanti evam sati rājāgāram ādhāraḥ na siyā rājāgāraka iti  evaṃnāmake uyyāne abhiramana araham kira rāja āgāram pi tattha yassa evam  nāmam labhati iti vajira buddhi ttheraḥ evam sati ambalaṭṭhikāyanti āsanna taruṇa amba rukkhena
translated: Some say that the word “called” is used because the name is not known. But if that were so, the royal pleasaunce would not be the base.🔽The Elder Vajirabuddhi says that the royal pleasaunce is worthy of a king’s enjoyment, and it is called by that name because the king had his dwelling there.🔽If that is so, then the meaning comes to be that the royal pleasaunce is specified by the nearby young mango tree and is called the Mango Grove by the name of the royal pleasaunce.

original: visesetvā “rājāgārake”ti uyyānameva nāmavasena vuttanti attho āpajjati, tathā ca
analyzed: visesetvā rāja āgāraka iti uyyānam eva nāma vasena vuttanti atthaḥ āpajjati tathā ca
translated: And in that case,

original: vuttadosova siyā. Suppiyañca paribbājakanti suppiyaṃ nāma sañcayassa antevāsiṃ channaparibbājakañca.
analyzed: vutta dosaḥ uva siyā suppiyam ca paribbājakanti suppiyam nāma sañcayassa antevāsim channa paribbājakañca
translated: The wanderer Suppiya: the wanderer Suppiya, a pupil of Sañcaya, and the wanderer Channa.

original: Brahmadattañca māṇavanti ettha taruṇo “māṇavo”ti vutto “ambaṭṭho māṇavo, aṅgako māṇavo”tiādīsu
analyzed: brahmadattam ca māṇavanti ettha taruṇaḥ māṇavaḥ iti vuttaḥ ambaṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ aṅgakaḥ māṇavaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: The brahmin student Brahmadatta: here the word “student” is used for a young man, as in such passages as “the young man Ambattha,” “the young man Aṅgaka,”

original: viya, tasmā brahmadattaṃ nāma taruṇapurisañca ārabbhāti attho. Vaṇṇāvaṇṇeti pasaṃsāya🔽ceva garahāya ca. Atha vā guṇo vaṇṇo, aguṇo avaṇṇo, tesaṃ bhāsanaṃ uttarapadalopena
analyzed: tasmai brahmadattam nāma taruṇa purisam ca ārabbha ati atthaḥ vaṇṇa avaṇṇā iti pasaṃsāya  ca iva garahāya ca atha vā guṇaḥ vaṇṇo aguṇaḥ avaṇṇo tesam bhāsanam uttara pada lopena
translated: etc. Therefore the meaning is: with reference to a young man named Brahmadatta.🔽Praise and blame: praise and blame.

original: tathā vuttaṃ yathā “rūpabhavo rūpa”nti.
analyzed: tathā vuttam yathā rūpa bhavaḥ
translated: Or else: a virtue is a praise, a vice is a blame. The speaking of them is stated in the way beginning “form existence is form” by the elision of the second term🔽in the compound.

original: “Tato para”ntiādimhi ayaṃ vacanakkamo – sāmaññaphalaṃ panāvuso ānanda kattha bhāsitanti?
analyzed: tato para nti ādimhi ayam vacana kkamaḥ sāmañña phalam pana āvuso ānanda kattha bhāsitanti
translated: “After that”: in this passage the sequence of the words is this: “But, friend Ānanda, where was the Fruits of the Life of One Who Has had a Part in What is Unexcelled spoken?”

original: Rājagahe bhante jīvakambavaneti. Kena saddhinti? Ajātasattunā vedehiputtena saddhinti.
analyzed: rājagahe bhante jīvakambavana iti kena saddhinti ajātasattunā vedehiputtena saddhinti
translated: “At Rājagaha, venerable sir, in the Jīvaka Mango Grove.” “With whom?” “With Ajātasattu, the son of the Videhi lady.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ sāmaññaphalassa nidānampi pucchi,
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahākassapaḥ āyasmantam ānandam sāmañña phalassa nidānam pi pucchi
translated: Then the venerable Kassapa the Great asked the venerable Ānanda about the source of the Fruits of the Life of One Who Has had a Part in What is Unexcelled,

original: puggalampi pucchīti. Ettha hi “kaṃ ārabbhā”ti avatvā “kena saddhi”nti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: puggalam pi pucchi iti ettha hi kam ārabbha ati avatvā kena saddhinti vattabbam
translated: and a person.” For here, instead of “concerning whom,” he should have said “with whom.”

original: Kasmāti ce? Na bhagavatā eva etaṃ suttaṃ bhāsitaṃ, raññāpi “yathā nu kho imāni puthusippāyatanānī”tiādinā🔽kiñci kiñci vuttamatthi, tasmā evameva vattabbanti. Imināva nayena sabbattha “kaṃ
analyzed: kasmā iti ce na bhagavatā eva etam suttam bhāsitam raññā api yathā nu kho imāni puthu sippa āyatanāni iti ādinā  kiñci kiñci vuttam atthi tasmai evam eva vattabbanti iminā ava nayena sabbattha kaṃ
translated: Why? Because this Thread was not spoken by the Blessed One alone, but also by the King, who said something or other beginning with “How is it that these various crafts” ,

original: ārabbhā”ti vā “kena saddhi”nti vā yathārahaṃ vatvā saṅgītimakāsīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tantinti
analyzed: ārabbha ati vā kena saddhinti vā yathāraham vatvā saṅgītim akāsi iti daṭṭhabbam tantinti
translated: and so he should have said it thus. In this way, it should be seen that he made the Recital by saying “concerning whom” or “with whom” as appropriate in each instance. The Thread is

original: suttavaggasamudāyavasena vavatthitaṃ pāḷiṃ. Evañca katvā “tivaggasaṅgahaṃ catuttiṃsasuttapaṭimaṇḍita”nti🔽vacanaṃ upapannaṃ hoti. Pariharathāti uggahaṇavācanādivasena dhāretha. Tato anantaraṃ
analyzed: sutta vagga samudāya vasena vavatthitam pāḷim evam ca katvā ti vagga saṅgaham catuttiṃsa sutta paṭimaṇḍitan ti  vacanam upapannam hoti pariharatha ati uggahaṇa vācana ādi vasena dhāretha tatas anantaram
translated: the text delimited by the collection of the Thread-collection. And when it is done in this way, the words “Gathered in three sections, adorned with forty-three Threads”

original: saṅgāyitvāti sambandho.
analyzed: saṅgāyi tvā iti
translated: are appropriate. “Bear it in mind” : learn it by heart by the method of recitation, etc. The construction is “after that, having recited it together” .

original: “Dhammasaṅgaho cā”tiādinā samāso. Evaṃ saṃvaṇṇitaṃ porāṇakehīti attho. Etena “mahādhammahadayena,
analyzed: dhamma saṅgaho ca ati ādinā samāsaḥ evam saṃvaṇṇitam porāṇakehi iti atthaḥ etena mahā dhamma hadayena
translated: “The Dhamma-collection” , etc., is a compound. The meaning is: “so praised by the Ancients”. By this he shows that he has the Dhamma-collection in its entirety. “With the great heart of the Dhamma” ,

original: mahādhātukathāya vā saddhiṃ sattappakaraṇaṃ abhidhammapiṭakaṃ nāmā”ti vuttaṃ vitaṇḍavādimataṃ
analyzed: mahā dhātu kathāya vā saddhim satta pakaraṇam abhidhammapiṭakam nāma ati vuttam vitaṇḍa vādi matam
translated: Or else the seven books together with the Great Category are called the Abhidhamma Piṭaka” .

original: paṭikkhipitvā “kathāvatthunāva saddhi”nti vuttaṃ samānavādimataṃ dasseti. Saṇhañāṇassa,
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā kathā vatthunā eva saddhin ti vuttam samānavādi matam dasseti saṇha ñāṇassa
translated: He shows the opinion of the Samānāvādas by saying “together with the Kathāvatthu” after rejecting the opinion of the Vitaṇḍavādins.

original: saṇhañāṇavantānaṃ vā visayabhāvato sukhumañāṇagocaraṃ.🔽Cūḷaniddesamahāniddesavasena duvidhopi niddeso. Jātakādike khuddakanikāyapariyāpanne,
analyzed: saṇha ñāṇavantānam vā visaya bhāvataḥ sukhuma ñāṇa gocaram  cūḷaniddesa mahāniddesa vasena duvidhaḥ api niddesaḥ jātaka ādike khuddaka nikāya pariyāpanne
translated: It is the province of subtle knowledge, that is, of knowledge that is subtle because it is the province of one of delicate knowledge or of those who have delicate knowledge.🔽The exposition is of two kinds, brief and detailed.

original: yebhuyyena ca dhammaniddesabhūte tādise abhidhammapiṭakeva saṅgaṇhituṃ yuttaṃ, na
analyzed: yebhuyyena ca dhamma niddesa bhūte tādise abhidhamma piṭakā iva saṅgaṇhitum yuttam na
translated: It is proper to include it in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, which is mostly a commentary on the Dhamma and which is included in the Khuddhaka Nikāya as the Niddesa, Jātaka, etc.,

original: pana dīghanikāyādippakāre suttantapiṭake, nāpi paññattiniddesabhūte vinayapiṭaketi
analyzed: pana dīgha nikāya ādi ppakāre suttanta piṭake na api paññatti niddesa bhūte vinaya piṭakā iti
translated: but not in the Sutta Piṭaka as the Dīgha, Majjhima, etc., nor in the Vinaya Piṭaka, which is an exposition of the rules of training.🔽Therefore the Dīgha reciters say that the Jātaka, etc., are included in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.

original: dīghabhāṇakā jātakādīnaṃ abhidhammapiṭake saṅgahaṃ vadanti. Cariyāpiṭakabuddhavaṃsānañcettha
analyzed: dīgha bhāṇakāḥ jātaka ādīnam abhidhamma piṭake saṅgaham vadanti cariyā piṭaka buddha vaṃsānam ca ittha
translated: Herein, the Cariyā Piṭaka and the Buddhavamsa are not included because they are Jātaka and history respectively,

original: aggahaṇaṃ jātakagatikattā, nettipeṭakopadesādīnañca niddesapaṭisambhidāmaggagatikattā.
analyzed: aggahaṇam jātaka gatika ttā netti peṭaka upadesa ādīnam ca niddesa paṭisambhidā magga gatika ttā
translated: and the Netti and the Peṭaka are not included because they are a guide and a commentary respectively.

original: Majjhimabhāṇakā pana aṭṭhuppattivasena desitānaṃ jātakādīnaṃ yathānulomadesanābhāvato🔽tādise suttantapiṭake saṅgaho yutto, na pana sabhāvadhammaniddesabhūte yathādhammasāsane
analyzed: pana aṭṭhuppatti vasena desitānam jātaka ādīnam yathā anuloma desanā bhāvato  tādise suttanta piṭake saṅgahaḥ yuttaḥ na pana sabhāva dhamma niddesa bhūte yathā dhamma sāsane
translated: But the Majjhima reciters say that the Jātakas, etc., are taught by way of the origin stories of the eight assemblies, and that they are therefore included in the Sutta Piṭaka, which is a teaching in accordance with the way things are,

original: abhidhammapiṭake, nāpi paññattiniddesabhūte yathāparādhasāsane vinayapiṭaketi jātakādīnaṃ
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭake na api paññatti niddesa bhūte yathā aparādha sāsane vinaya piṭakā iti jātaka ādīnam
translated: but not in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, which is a teaching of the individual essences of dhammas, nor in the Vinaya Piṭaka, which is a teaching of the way in which offences are incurred.

original: suttantapiṭakapariyāpannataṃ vadanti. Yuttamettha vicāretvā gahetabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ nimittapayojanakāladesakārakakaraṇappakārehi paṭhamaṃ saṅgītiṃ dassetvā idāni
analyzed: vadanti yuttam ettha vicāretvā gahetabbam  evam nimitta payojana kāla desa kāraka karaṇa ppakārehi paṭhamam saṅgītim dassetvā idāni
translated: This is a matter to be considered and accepted with judgment.

original: tattha vavatthāpitesu dhammavinayesu nānappakārakosallatthaṃ ekavidhādibhedaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: tattha vavatthāpitesu dhamma vinayesu ekavidha ādi bhedam dassetuṃ
translated: Having thus shown the first council by way of its occasion, purpose, time, place, presidents, and proceedings, the author now says “Evametaṃ,” etc., in order to show the various divisions of the Dhamma and Vinaya by way of the one-division, etc., for the purpose of skill in the various aspects of the Dhamma and Vinaya.

original: “evameta”ntiādimāha. Tattha “eva”nti iminā etasaddena parāmasitabbaṃ yathāvuttasaṅgītippakāraṃ
analyzed: evam etat tiādim āha tattha evam ti iminā eta saddena parāmasitabbam yathā vutta saṅgīti pakāram
translated: Herein, by the word “eva” he points out the method of the council referred to by the word “etaṃ.”🔽The rest is clear.

original: nidasseti. “Yañhī”tiādi vitthāro. Anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhinti anāvaraṇañāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nidassa iti yat hi itiādi vitthāraḥ anuttaram sammāsambodhin ti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam
translated: The supreme perfect enlightenment is the basis for unobstructed knowledge.

original: maggañāṇaṃ, maggañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ. Etthantareti abhisambujjhanassa,
analyzed: magga ñāṇam magga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam ca anāvaraṇa ñāṇam etthantare ti abhisambujjhanassa
translated: Path knowledge and the unobstructed knowledge that has the path as its object. ‘In between’: in the interval between the discovery of the path and the final Nibbāna.

original: parinibbāyanassa ca vivare. Tadetaṃ pañcacattālīsa vassānīti kālavasena niyameti.
analyzed: parinibbāyanassa ca vivare tat etam pañcacattālīsa vassāni iti kāla vasena
translated: ‘For fifty years’: he defines it in terms of time.🔽‘Looking back’: he says this referring to the states that occurred in the way beginning with the utterance of the Udāna.

original: Paccavekkhantena vāti udānādivasena pavattadhammaṃ sandhāyāha. Yaṃ vacanaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: paccavekkhantena vā ti udāna ādi vasena pavatta dhammam sandhāya āha yam vacanam vuttam
translated: The meaning of the words is this: ‘What utterance was spoken?

original: sabbaṃ tanti sambandho. Kiṃ panetanti āha “vimuttirasamevā”ti, na tadaññarasanti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Vimuccitthāti vimutti, rasitabbaṃ assādetabbanti rasaṃ, vimuttisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: sabbam tat ti sambandhaḥ kim pana itanti āha vimutti rasam eva ati na tat añña rasa nti  vuttam hoti vimuccittha ati vimutti rasitabbam assādetabbam ti rasam vimutti saṅkhātam
translated: What is the connection between them? What is the meaning of the words?’🔽‘The meaning of the words is this’: he answers, ‘The meaning of the words is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse, “The supreme state of peace” ’.

original: rasametassāti vimuttirasaṃ, arahattaphalassādanti attho. Ayaṃ ācariyasāriputtattherassa🔽mati. Ācariyadhammapālatthero pana taṃ kecivādaṃ katvā imamatthamāha “vimuccati vimuccitthāti
analyzed: rasam etassa ati vimutti rasam arahatta phalassa ādanti atthaḥ ayam ācariya sāriputta therassa  mati ācariya dhammapāla ttheraḥ pana tam keci vādam katvā imam attham āha vimuccati vimuccittha iti
translated: ‘The supreme state of peace’: the supreme state of Nibbāna. ‘The meaning of the words is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse’: the meaning of the words of the verse is the same as the meaning of the words of the utterance.🔽‘What is the meaning of the words of the verse?’ ‘The meaning of the words of the verse is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse, “The supreme state of peace” ’.

original: vimutti, yathārahaṃ maggo phalañca. Rasanti guṇo, sampattikiccaṃ vā, vuttanayena
analyzed: vimutti yathāraham maggo phalam ca guṇo sampatti kiccam vā vutta nayena
translated: ‘The supreme state of peace’: the supreme state of Nibbāna. ‘The meaning of the words of the verse is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse’: the meaning of the words of the verse is the same as the meaning of the words of the utterance.🔽‘What is the meaning of the words of the utterance?’ ‘The meaning of the words of the utterance is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse, “The supreme state of peace” ’.🔽‘The supreme state of peace’: the supreme state of Nibbāna. ‘The meaning of the words of the utterance is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse’: the meaning of the words of the utterance is the same as the meaning of the words of the verse.

original: samāso. Vimuttānisaṃsaṃ, vimuttisampattikaṃ vā maggaphalanipphādanato, vimuttikiccaṃ🔽vā kilesānamaccantavimuttisampādanatoti attho”ti. Aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “attharasassādīsu🔽attharaso nāma cattāri sāmaññaphalāni, dhammaraso nāma cattāro maggā, vimuttiraso
analyzed: samāsaḥ vimutta anisaṃsam vimutti sampattikam vā magga phala nipphādanataḥ vimutti kiccam  vā atthaḥ ti aṅguttara ṭṭhakathā ayam pana attha rasassa ādīsu  attha rasaḥ nāma cattāri sāmañña phalāni dhamma rasaḥ nāma cattāro maggāḥ vimutti rasaḥ
translated: and the compound is a copulative one. Or the function of the path is the function of liberation because it produces the attainment of the path and fruition, or because it brings about the complete liberation of defilements.

original: nāma amatanibbāna”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Kiñcāpi avisesena sabbampi buddhavacanaṃ kilesavinayanena vinayo, yathānusiṭṭhaṃ🔽paṭipajjamāne apāyapatanādito dhāraṇena dhammo ca hoti, tathāpi idhādhippeteyeva🔽dhammavinaye vatticchāvasena sarūpato niddhāretuṃ “tattha vinayapiṭaka”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: nāma amata nibbānan ti vuttam  kiñcā api avisesena sabbam pi buddha vacanam kilesa vinayanena vinayaḥ yathānusiṭṭham  paṭipajjamāne apāya patana āditaḥ dhāraṇena dhammo ca hoti tathā api idha adhippeteya iva eva  dhamma vinaye vatti icchā vasena sarūpataḥ niddhāretum tattha vinaya piṭakan ti ādim āha
translated: In the Commentary on the Aṅguttara Nikāya it is said: “The meaning juice is the four fruits of asceticism; the Dhamma juice is the four paths; the liberation juice is the deathless Nibbāna.”🔽Although all the Buddha’s word is discipline in the sense of training in the destruction of defilements, and is the Dhamma in the sense of holding one who practices in accordance with the training from falling into states of woe, etc., nevertheless, in order to extract the discipline and the Dhamma here in their specific senses as the two principal parts of the threefold division of the Buddha’s word, he says, “Herein, the Vinaya Piṭaka,” etc.

original: Avasesaṃ buddhavacanaṃ dhammo khandhādivasena sabhāvadhammadesanābāhullato. Atha
analyzed: avasesam buddha vacanam dhammaḥ khandha ādi vasena sa bhāva dhamma desanā bāhullataḥ atha
translated: The rest of the Buddha’s word is the Dhamma in the sense of natural law, because it is abundant in teaching the nature of things such as the aggregates, etc.

original: vā yadipi vinayo ca dhammoyeva pariyattiyādibhāvato, tathāpi vinayasaddasannidhāne
analyzed: vā yadi pi vinayaḥ ca tathā api vinaya sadda sannidhāne
translated: although the Discipline is Dhamma in the sense of what should be learned, etc., nevertheless, when the word Discipline is used in proximity to the word Dhamma,

original: bhinnādhikaraṇabhāvena payutto dhammasaddo vinayatanti viparītaṃ tantimeva dīpeti🔽yathā “puññañāṇasambhārā, gobalībadda”nti. Payogavasena taṃ dassentena “tenevāhā”tiādi
analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇa bhāvena payuttaḥ dhamma saddaḥ vinaya tanti viparītam tantim eva dīpeti  yathā puññañāṇa sambhārāḥ go balī baddanti payoga vasena tam dassentena tena iva āha atiādi
translated: the word Dhamma is used in the sense of the first part of the scriptures, and so it shows the opposite of that,

original: vuttaṃ. Yena vinaya…pe… dhammo, teneva tesaṃ tathābhāvaṃ saṅgītikkhandhake āhāti attho.
analyzed: vuttam yena dhammo tena iva tesam tathābhāvam saṅgīti khandhake āha ati attho
translated: just as in the passage, “The accumulation of merit and of wisdom, the yoke-bearer’s fetter” . In showing that by means of the application, it is said, “Therefore he said” . By means of that by which the Discipline … is Dhamma, therefore he said that they are so in the Saṅgīti- sutta.

original: “Anekajātisaṃsāra”nti ayaṃ gāthā bhagavatā attano sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ arahattappattiṃ🔽paccavekkhantena ekūnavīsatimassa paccavekkhaṇañāṇassa anantaraṃ bhāsitā, tasmā “paṭhamabuddhavacana”nti
analyzed: aneka jāti saṃsāram ti ayam gāthā bhagavatā attano sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhānam arahatta ppattim  paccavekkhantena ekūnavīsatimassa paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa anantaram bhāsitā tasmai paṭhama buddha vacanam ti
translated: This verse, “Wandering through the many a birth,” was spoken by the Blessed One when he was reflecting on his own attainment of the state of omniscience and of arahatship,

original: vuttā. Idaṃ kira sabbabuddhehi avijahitaṃ udānaṃ. Ayamassa saṅkhepattho – ahaṃ imassa
analyzed: vuttā idam kira sabba buddhehi a vijahitam udānam ayam assa saṅkhepa atthaḥ aham imassa
translated: and it was spoken immediately after the knowledge of reviewing of nineteen times. Therefore it is called “the first utterance of the Buddha.” This is the inspired utterance that is not abandoned by any Buddha. This is the condensed meaning of it: I,

original: attabhāvasaṅkhātassa gehassa kārakaṃ taṇhāvaḍḍhakiṃ gavesanto yena ñāṇena taṃ daṭṭhuṃ
analyzed: atta bhāva saṅkhātassa gehassa kārakam taṇhā vaḍḍhakim gavesantaḥ yena ñāṇena tam daṭṭhum
translated: Searching for the builder of the house called the self, the increaser of craving, by means of the knowledge by which he could see it,

original: sakkā, tassa bodhiñāṇassatthāya dīpaṅkarapādamūle katābhinīhāro ettakaṃ kālaṃ anekajātisaṃsāraṃ
analyzed: sakkā tassa bodhiñāṇassa atthāya dīpaṅkara pāda mūle kata abhinīhāraḥ ettakam kālam aneka jāti saṃsāram
translated: for the sake of the knowledge of enlightenment, he made his aspiration at the feet of Dīpaṅkara. For so long a time, through the round of births,

original: anekajātisatasahassasaṅkhyaṃ saṃsāravaṭṭaṃ anibbisaṃ anibbisanto taṃ ñāṇaṃ avindanto
analyzed: aneka jāti sata sahassa saṅkhyam saṃsāra vaṭṭam a nibbisam a nibbisantaḥ tam ñāṇam a vindantaḥ
translated: which is reckoned in many hundreds of thousands of births, through the round of rebirths, without finding a resting place, without finding that knowledge,

original: alabhantoyeva sandhāvissaṃ saṃsariṃ. Yasmā jarābyādhimaraṇamissatāya jāti nāmesā
analyzed: a labhantoyā iva sandhāvissam saṃsarim yasmai jarā byādhi maraṇa missatāya jāti nāma esā
translated: without obtaining it, he wandered and transmigrated. Because birth, which is mixed with old age, sickness and death,

original: punappunaṃ upagantuṃ dukkhā, na ca sā tasmiṃ adiṭṭhe nivattati, tasmā taṃ gavesanto
analyzed: punappunam upagantum dukkhā na ca sā tasmin a diṭṭhe nivattati tasmā tam gavesanto
translated: is difficult to approach again and again, and it does not turn back from that which is not seen, therefore, searching for it,

original: sandhāvissanti attho. Idāni bho attabhāvasaṅkhātassa gehassa kāraka taṇhāvaḍḍhaki🔽tvaṃ mayā sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ paṭivijjhantena diṭṭho asi. Puna imaṃ attabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: sandhāvissanti attho idāni bho atta bhāva saṅkhātassa gehassa kāraka taṇhā vaḍḍhaki  tvam mayā sabbaññuta ññāṇam paṭivijjhantena diṭṭhaḥ asi puna imam atta bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: he wandered. Now, O builder of the house called the self, the increaser of craving,

original: mama gehaṃ na kāhasi na karissasi. Tava sabbā avasesakilesa phāsukā mayā bhaggā bhañjitā.
analyzed: mama geham na na karissasi tava sabbā avasesa kilesa phāsukā mayā bhaggā bhañjitā
translated: you have been seen by me! You will not build this house, called the self, again. All your remaining defilements, O builder, are now broken and destroyed by me.

original: Imassa tayā katassa attabhāvasaṅkhātassa gehassa kūṭaṃ avijjāsaṅkhātaṃ kaṇṇikamaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: imassa tayā katassa atta bhāva saṅkhātassa gehassa kūṭam avijjā saṅkhātam kaṇṇika maṇḍalam
translated: The corner of the house called the self, which you have built,🔽has been demolished, destroyed, by the rafter called ignorance.

original: visaṅkhataṃ viddhaṃsitaṃ. Idāni mama cittaṃ visaṅkhāraṃ nibbānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena
analyzed: visaṅkhatam viddhaṃsitam idāni mama cittam visaṅkhāram nibbānam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: Now my mind has gone to the destruction of conditions, to Nibbāna, by making it its object,

original: gataṃ anupaviṭṭhaṃ. Ahañca taṇhānaṃ khaya saṅkhātaṃ arahattamaggaṃ, arahattaphalaṃ🔽vā ajjhagā adhigato pattosmīti. Gaṇṭhipadesu pana visaṅkhāragataṃ cittameva taṇhānaṃ
analyzed: gatam anupaviṭṭham aham ca taṇhānam khaya saṅkhātam arahatta maggam arahatta phalam  vā ajjhagāḥ adhigataḥ patto smi iti gaṇṭhi padesu pana visaṅkhāra gatam cittam eva
translated: and has entered into it and become settled in it. And I have attained the destruction of the taints, which is called the path of arahatship, or the fruit of arahatship.🔽But in the stanzas the meaning is stated thus: “The mind has gone to the destruction of conditions, which is called the path of arahatship, or the fruit of arahatship.”

original: khayasaṅkhātaṃ arahattamaggaṃ, arahattaphalaṃ vā ajjhagā adhigatanti attho vutto.🔽“Sandhāvissa”nti ettha ca “gāthāyamatītatthe imissa”nti neruttikā. “Taṃkālavacanicchāyamatītepi
analyzed: khaya saṅkhātam arahatta maggam arahatta phalam vā ajjhagā adhigatanti atthaḥ vutto  ettha ca gāthāyam atīta atthe neruttikā
translated: “Wandering on” : here some say that the word “wandering” is in the past tense in the stanza, but the word “wandering” in the commentary is in the present tense.🔽But others say that the word “wandering” in the stanza is in the present tense, and that the word “wandering” in the commentary is in the past tense.

original: bhavissantī”ti keci. Punappunanti abhiṇhatthe nipāto. Pātabbā rakkhitabbāti phāsu
analyzed: bhavissanti iti keci punappunanti abhiṇha atthe nipātaḥ pātabbā rakkhitabbā ati phāsu
translated: “Again and again” : the prefix “punar” has the meaning of “repeatedly.” “To be drunk” : to be drunk with the intoxication of gain, fame, etc., and to be protected from it.

original: pa-kārassa pha-kāraṃ katvā, phusitabbāti vā phāsu, sāyeva phāsukā. Ajjhagāti ca “ajjataniyamāttamiṃ
analyzed: pakārassa phakāram katvā phusitabbā ati vā phāsu sāyā iva phāsukā ajjhagāti ca
translated: and the letter pa is made into the letter pha, and it is to be touched, thus it is at-ease, and that at-ease is at-ease-ness. And as to the word ajjhagā, they say: “From today onwards, either this or that.”

original: vā aṃ vā”ti vadanti. Yadi pana cittameva kattā, tadā parokkhāyeva. Antojappanavasena
analyzed: vā aṃ vā ati vadanti yadi pana cittam eva kattā tadā parokkhāya iva antar jappana vasena
translated: But if the doer is the mind, then it is only a private affair.🔽It is said that the Blessed One spoke the two verses beginning, “For many a birth have I wandered in cyclic existence,”

original: kira bhagavā “anekajātisaṃsāra”nti gāthādvayamāha, tasmā esā manasā pavattitadhammānamādi.
analyzed: kira bhagavā aneka jāti saṃsāranti gāthā dvayam āha tasmai esā manasā
translated: with reference to the occurrence of the states in the mind.

original: “Yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā”ti ayaṃ pana vācāya pavattitadhammānanti vadanti.
analyzed: yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā ati ayam pana vācāya pavattita dhammānanti vadanti
translated: “When the ideas appear” , they say, refers to the occurrence of the states in speech.

original: Kecīti khandhakabhāṇakā. Paṭhamaṃ vutto pana dhammapadabhāṇakānaṃ vādo. Yadā…pe…
analyzed: keci iti khandhaka bhāṇakā paṭhamam vuttaḥ pana dhamma pada bhāṇakānam vādaḥ
translated: “Some” : the Section-by-Section Reciters. But the first statement is that of the Discourse-in-Brief Reciters.

original: dhammāti ettha nidassanattho, ādyattho ca iti-saddo luttaniddiṭṭho. Nidassanena hi
analyzed: dhammā ti ettha nidassana atthaḥ ādi atthaḥ ca iti saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ nidassanena hi
translated: “When the ideas appear” , etc.: here the word iti has the sense of demonstration and the sense of beginning. It is demonstrated thus.

original: mariyādavacanena vinā padatthavipallāsakārināva attho paripuṇṇo na hoti. Tattha ādyatthameva
analyzed: mariyāda vacanena vinā attho paripuṇṇaḥ na hoti tattha ādi attham eva
translated: The meaning is not complete without the word iti, which is a respectful form of address and which reverses the order of the words.

original: iti-saddaṃ gahetvā iti-saddo ādiattho, “tena ātāpino…pe… sahetudhamma’ntiādigāthāttayaṃ
analyzed: iti saddam gahetvā iti saddaḥ ādi attho tena
translated: The teacher Sāriputta has said that the word iti is a word for “beginning” and that it includes the three verses beginning “Then, being ardent … he saw the Dhamma by himself” .

original: saṅgaṇhātī”ti ācariyasāriputtattherena vuttaṃ. Khandhaketi mahāvagge. Udānagāthanti
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti iti ācariya sāriputta therena vuttam khandhake ti mahā vagge udāna gāthan ti
translated: The “section” is in the Great Chapter. The “quotation from the Udāna” is

original: jātiyā ekavacanaṃ, tatthāpi vā paṭhamagāthameva gahetvā vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: jātiyāḥ ekavacanam tattha api vā paṭhama gātham eva gahetvā vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: the singular form “birth” . Here, too, it should be understood that only the first verse is meant.

original: Ettha ca khandhakabhāṇakā evaṃ vadanti “dhammapadabhāṇakānaṃ gāthā manasāva desitattā

original: me suta”ntiādīni vadati. Evaṃ pana vattabbaṃ siyā “ekamidāhaṃ bhante samayaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ🔽viharāmi jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme”tiādi. analyzed: me suta nti ādīni vadati evam pana vattabbam siyā ekam idā aham bhante samayam sāvatthiyam 🔽viharāmi jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāma itiādi tasmai dutiya tatiya saṅgīti kārakehi 🔽evam me suta nti ādinā subha suttam saṅgītim āropitam viya dissati atha ācariya dhammapāla ttherassa 🔽evam adhippāyaḥ siyā ānanda ttherena iva vuttam pi subha suttam paṭhama saṅgītim āropetvā
translated: It was said by the Elder Dhammapāla, teacher of teachers. But the Subha Sutta is given thus: “Thus have I heard. At one time the venerable Ānanda was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Wood, at Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery, soon after the Blessed One had attained to Parinibbāna” . Herein, the words “Thus have I heard” are not appropriate for the venerable Ānanda to say himself at the first rehearsal. For the venerable Ānanda did not himself teach the Subha Sutta and then say “Thus have I heard.” But it might be said that he should have said “At one time, venerable sirs, I was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Wood, at Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery” and so on. So it seems that the Subha Sutta was rehearsed by the makers of the second and third rehearsals with the words “Thus have I heard” and so on. Then it may be that the teacher of teachers, the Elder Dhammapāla, had this intention: “The Subha Sutta was taught by the venerable Ānanda himself, but it was rehearsed at the first rehearsal with the words ‘Thus have I heard’ and so on.

translated: and when the Elder Kassapa the Great and the others wanted to set up the Thread, they set it up with the words ‘Thus have I heard’ and so on, in the way stated in the other suttas.” If that were so, it would be right.🔽Or alternatively, although the venerable Ananda himself taught the Subha Sutta,🔽he taught it in the way taught by the Blessed One in the case of the Fruits of the Life of a Householder and so on.

original: vutto. “Itī”ti yathāvuttaṃ buddhavacanaṃ nidassetvā “ida”nti taṃ parāmasati. Iti-saddo
analyzed: vuttaḥ iti iti yathā vuttam buddha vacanam nidassetvā idam ti tam parāmasati iti saddaḥ
translated: Having indicated the word of the Buddha stated thus, he refers to it with the demonstrative pronoun “this.” The word iti

original: vā idamatthe, idanti vacanasiliṭṭhatāmattaṃ, iti idanti vā pariyāyadvayaṃ idamattheyeva
analyzed: vā idam atthe idanti vacana siliṭṭha tā mattam iti idanti vā pariyāya dvayam
translated: is in the sense of “thus.” The word idam is merely the grammatical form of the demonstrative pronoun. The word iti idam is a pair of synonyms in the sense of “this.”

original: vattati “idānetarahi vijjatī”tiādīsu viya. Esa nayo īdisesu. Brahmajālādīni catuttiṃsa
analyzed: vattati idānetarahi vijjati iti ādīsu viyaḥ esa nayaḥ īdisesu brahmajāla ādīni catuttiṃsa
translated: as in the case of the words idānetarahi vijjatīti, etc. The same method applies in the case of the other terms.

original: suttāni saṅgayhanti ettha, etena vā, tesaṃ vā saṅgaho gaṇanā etassāti brahmajālādicatuttiṃsasuttasaṅgaho.
analyzed: suttāni saṅgayhanti ettha etena vā tesam vā saṅgahaḥ gaṇanā etassa ati brahmajāla ādi catuttiṃsa sutta saṅgahaḥ
translated: The thirty-four suttas beginning with the Brahmajāla are collected here, or they are collected by this, or their collection is reckoned as this, thus it is the collection of the thirty-four suttas beginning with the Brahmajāla.🔽The same method applies in the case of the other terms.

original: Evamitaresupi. Heṭṭhā vuttesu dīghabhāṇakamajjhimabhāṇakānaṃ vādesu majjhimabhāṇakānaññeva
analyzed: evam itaresu pi heṭṭhā vuttesu dīgha bhāṇaka majjhima bhāṇakānam vādesu
translated: Among the views of the Dīghabhāṇakas and Majjhimabhāṇakas mentioned above, the view of the Majjhimabhāṇakas

original: vādassa yuttatarattā khuddakapāṭhādayopi suttantapiṭakeyeva saṅgahetvā dassento “khuddaka…pe…🔽suttantapiṭakaṃ nāmā”ti āha. Tattha “suṇātha bhāvitattānaṃ, gāthā atthūpanāyikāti
analyzed: vādassa yuttatara ttā khuddaka pāṭha ādayaḥ api suttanta piṭake iya iva saṅgahetvā dassento  suttantapiṭakam nāma ati āha tattha suṇātha bhāvita ttānam gāthā atthu upanāyikā ti
translated: is more appropriate, since the Khuddaka- pāṭha, etc., are also included in the Suttapiṭaka. Showing this, he said: “The Khuddaka …

original: vuttattā “theragāthā therīgāthā”ti ca pāṭho yutto.🔽Evaṃ sarūpato piṭakattayaṃ niyametvā idāni nibbacanaṃ dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ttā thera gāthā therī gāthā iti ca pāṭhaḥ yuttaḥ  evam sarūpataḥ piṭaka ttayam niyametvā idāni nibbacanam dassetum tattha atiādi vuttaṃ
translated: is called the Suttapiṭaka.” Herein, the reading theragāthā therīgāthā is appropriate because of the words: “Listen to the verses of the elders and the verses of the elderesses, which are the means of understanding the meaning.”🔽Having thus determined the three Piṭakas by their individual characteristics, he now said “Tattha” , etc., in order to show the derivation of the terms.

original: Tatthāti tesu tibbidhesu piṭakesu. Vividhavisesanayattāti vividhanayattā, visesanayattā
analyzed: tattha ati tesu tibbidhesu piṭakesu vividha visesa nayattā ati vividha naya ttā visesa nayattā
translated: Therein, among the three Piṭakas, by the various methods, by the various distinctions,

original: ca. Vinayanatoti vinayanabhāvato, bhāvappadhānaniddesoyaṃ, bhāvalopo vā, itarathā
analyzed: ca vinayanataḥ ti vinayana bhāvataḥ bhāva ppadhāna niddesaḥ yam bhāva lopaḥ vā itarathā
translated: As to discipline: as to the state of being a discipline. This is a description of the state of being a discipline, or the state of being a discipline has been elided. Otherwise

original: dabbameva padhānaṃ siyā, tathā ca sati vinayanatāguṇasamaṅginā vinayadabbeneva hetubhūtena
analyzed: dabbam eva padhānam siyā tathā ca sati vinayana tā guṇa samaṅginā vinaya dabbena iva hetu bhūtena
translated: it would be a mere discipline. And if that were so, then it would be discipline only because of the mere fact of being a discipline, which is the cause,

original: vinayoti akkhāto, na pana vinayanatāguṇenāti anadhippetatthappasaṅgo bhaveyya. Ayaṃ
analyzed: vinayaḥ ti akkhātaḥ na pana vinayana tā guṇena ati an adhippeta ttha ppasaṅgaḥ bhaveyya ayam
translated: and it would not be called “discipline” because of the quality of being a discipline. And in that case the meaning intended would not be included. This

original: nayo edisesu. Vinīyate vā vinayanaṃ, tatoti attho. Ayaṃ vinayoti atthapaññattibhūto🔽saññīsaṅkhāto ayaṃ tanti vinayo. Vinayoti akkhātoti saddapaññattibhūto saññāsaṅkhāto
analyzed: edisesu vinīyate vā vinayanam tato ti atthaḥ ayam vinayo ti attha paññatti bhūto  saññī saṅkhātaḥ ayam tanti vinayaḥ vinayo ti akkhāto ti sadda paññatti bhūto saññā saṅkhāto
translated: is the method in such cases. Or alternatively, discipline is that by which one is disciplined. The meaning is: because of that. This is the discipline🔽that is the basis for the description of the meaning. It is called “discipline”🔽because of the quality of being a discipline. It is called “discipline” because of the description of the sound. For the description of the meaning is the

original: vinayo nāmāti kathito. Atthapaññattiyā hi nāmapaññattivibhāvanaṃ nibbacananti.
analyzed: vinayaḥ nāma ati kathito attha paññattiyā hi nāma paññatti vibhāvanam nibbacanan ti
translated: analysis of the description of the name.

original: Idāni imissā gāthāya atthaṃ vibhāvento āha “vividhā hī”tiādi. “Vividhā ettha nayā,
analyzed: idāni imissā gāthāya attham vibhāventaḥ āha vividhā hi itiādi vividhāḥ ettha nayā
translated: Now, in order to explain the meaning of this stanza, he said “Herein, the methods are various,” etc. “Herein, the methods are various,

original: tasmā vividhanayattā vinayoti akkhāto”tiādinā yojetabbaṃ. Vividhattaṃ sarūpato dasseti
analyzed: tasmā vividha naya ttā vinayo ti akkhāto ti ādinā yojetabbam vividha ttam sarūpataḥ dasseti
translated: therefore it is called ‘discipline’ because of the various methods.” This should be construed thus. He shows the variousness by the way of the nature of the various methods.

original: “pañcavidhā”tiādinā, tathā visesattampi “daḷhīkammā”tiādinā. Lokavajjesu sikkhāpadesu
analyzed: pañcavidhā ti ādinā tathā daḷhīkamma ati ādinā loka vajjesu sikkhāpadesu
translated: “Fivefold” and so on, and also the distinction “Firmly done” and so on. In the training precepts concerning social impropriety

original: daḷhīkammapayojanā, paṇṇattivajjesu sithilakaraṇapayojanā. Saññamavelaṃ abhibhavitvā
analyzed: daḷhī kamma payojanā paṇṇatti vajjesu sithila karaṇa payojanā saññama velam abhibhavitvā
translated: the purpose is to do them firmly, and in those concerning the rules of the Patimokkha the purpose is to do them loosely. Conduct that occurs

original: pavatto ācāro ajjhācāro, vītikkamo, kāye, vācāya ca pavatto so, tassa nisedhanaṃ
analyzed: pavattaḥ ācāraḥ ajjhācāraḥ vītikkamo kāye vācāya ca pavattaḥ saḥ tassa nisedhanam
translated: overpowering the sense of moderation is “excessive.” The prohibition of that

original: tathā, tena tathānisedhanameva pariyāyena kāyavācāvinayanaṃ nāmāti dasseti. “Tasmā”ti🔽vatvā tassānekadhā parāmasanamāha “vividhanayattā”tiādi. Yathāvuttā ca gāthā īdisassa🔽nibbacanassa pakāsanatthaṃ vuttāti dassetuṃ “tenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tenāti vividhanayattādihetunā
analyzed: tathā tena tathā nisedhanam eva pariyāyena kāya vācā vinayanam nāma ati dasseti tasmā iti  vatvā tassa anekadhā parāmasanam āha vividha nayattā atiādi yathā vuttā ca gāthā īdisassa  nibbacanassa pakāsana attham vuttā iti dassetum tena atiādi vuttam tena ati vividha naya tta ādi hetunā
translated: is “restraint.” Thus he shows that the restraint of body and speech is called “restraint” in the sense of prohibiting that conduct in that way. “Therefore”🔽he says that it is to be taken in many ways. “Because of the variety of methods” and so on. And he says “Therefore” and so on in order to show the explanation of the verse stated in this way. They say that “therefore” means

original: karaṇabhūtenāti vadanti. Apica “vividhā hī”tiādivākyassa yathāvuttassa guṇaṃ dassento
analyzed: karaṇa bhūtena ati vadanti apica vividhāḥ hi itiādi vākyassa yathā vuttassa guṇam dassento
translated: by the reason consisting of the variety of methods and so on, which is the instrument. Moreover, they say that the connection is this: showing the virtue of the statement beginning “Because of the variety of methods”

original: “tenā”tiādimāhātipi sambandhaṃ vadanti. Evaṃ sati tenāti vividhanayattādinā hetubhūtenāti
analyzed: sambandham vadanti evam sati tena ati vividha nayat tā ādinā hetu bhūtena ati
translated: he says “therefore” and so on. If this is so, “therefore” means by the reason consisting of the variety of methods and so on.

original: attho. Atha vā yathāvuttavacanameva sandhāya porāṇehi ayaṃ gāthā vuttāti saṃsandetuṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ atha vā yathā vutta vacanam eva sandhāya porāṇehi ayam gāthā vuttā iti saṃsandetum
translated: Or else, they say, the verse was spoken by the Ancients in order to resolve the doubt as to whether the words spoken are the meaning or not.

original: “tenā”tiādi vuttantipi vadanti, dutiyanaye viya “tenā”ti padassa attho. Etanti gāthāvacanaṃ.
analyzed: tena atiādi vuttam ti pi vadanti dutiya naye viya tena ati padassa atthaḥ etan ti gāthā vacanam
translated: “Therefore” is said in order to show the meaning of the word “therefore” as in the second method. “That” is the words of the verse.

original: Etassāti vinayasaddassa, “vacanatthā”ti padena sambandho. “Vacanassa attho”ti hi
analyzed: etassa ati vinaya saddassa vacana tthā ati padena sambandhaḥ vacanassa attho ti hi
translated: “Of that” is of the word “discipline.” The connection is with the word “meaning.”🔽Even though it is said in the connection “the meaning of the words,”

original: sambandhe vuttepi tassa vacanasāmaññato visesaṃ dassetuṃ “etassā”ti puna vuttaṃ.🔽Neruttikā pana samāsataddhitesu siddhesu sāmaññattā, nāmasaddattā ca edisesu saddantarena
analyzed: sambandhe vutte api tassa vacana sāmaññataḥ visesam dassetum etassa ati puna vuttam  neruttikā pana samāsa taddhitesu siddhesu sāmaññattā nāma saddattā ca edisesu saddantarena
translated: it is said again “of that” in order to show the difference by the similarity of the words.

original: visesitabhāvaṃ icchanti.
analyzed: visesita bhāvam icchanti
translated: But the grammarians want the distinction to be made by another word in such cases because of the established meaning of the compound and the similarity of the name.

original: “Atthāna”nti padaṃ “sūcanato…pe… suttāṇā”ti padehi yathārahaṃ kammasambandhavasena
analyzed: padam sūcana tope padehi yathāraham kamma sambandha vasena
translated: The word “meaning” should be connected by the method of the relation of action in the appropriate way with the words “because of the indication” … “of the suttas.”

original: yojetabbaṃ. Tamatthaṃ vivarati “tañhī”tiādinā. Attatthaparatthādibhede attheti yo
analyzed: yojetabbam tam attham vivarati tat hi itiādinā atta ttha para ttha ādi bhede attha iti yaḥ
translated: He explains the meaning of that with “That is to say, in the matter of the meaning,” etc. The meaning is of the kind beginning with one’s own benefit and another’s benefit.

original: taṃ suttaṃ sajjhāyati, suṇāti, vāceti, cinteti, deseti ca, suttena saṅgahito sīlādiattho
analyzed: tam suttam sajjhāyati suṇāti vācā iti cinteti deseti ca suttena saṅgahitaḥ sīla ādi attho
translated: He recites that Thread, hears it, recites it for others, reflects on it, and teaches it. The meaning of virtue, etc., included in the Thread

original: tassapi hoti, tena parassa sādhetabbato parassapīti tadubhayaṃ taṃ suttaṃ sūceti
analyzed: tassa api hoti tena parassa sādhetabbataḥ parassa api iti tat ubhayam tam suttam sūceti
translated: is his too, and it is that of others too, because it has to be accomplished by others. So that Thread shows both

original: dīpeti, tathā diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthe lokiyalokuttaratthe cāti evamādibhede🔽atthe ādi-saddena saṅgaṇhāti. Atthasaddo cāyaṃ hitapariyāyo, na bhāsitatthavacano.
analyzed: dīpeti tathā diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika tthe lokiya lokuttara tthe ca ati evamādi bhede  atthe ādi saddena saṅgaṇhāti attha saddaḥ ca ayam hita pariyāyaḥ na bhāsita attha vacanaḥ
translated: that meaning and the meaning of the future life in this very life, and the meaning of the mundane and the supramundane. So it includes in the word “meaning”🔽such kinds of meaning as this. And the word “meaning” is a synonym for welfare, not a synonym for the meaning of what is said.

original: Yadi siyā, suttaṃ attanopi bhāsitatthaṃ sūceti, parassapīti ayamanadhippetattho vutto
analyzed: yadi siyā suttam attanaḥ api bhāsita attham sūceti parassa api iti ayam anadhippeta tthaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: If it were, then the Thread would show the meaning of what is said by oneself and by others, and so the meaning “of others” would not be stated as not intended.🔽For the meaning that is revealed by the Thread is that of the Thread that reveals it,

original: siyā. Suttena hi yo attho pakāsito, so tasseva pakāsakassa suttassa hoti, tasmā na🔽tena parattho sūcito, tena sūcetabbassa paratthassa nivattetabbassa abhāvā attatthaggahaṇañca
analyzed: siyā suttena hi yaḥ atthaḥ pakāsito so tassa iva pakāsakassa suttassa hoti tasmā na  tena para atthaḥ sūcito tena sūcetabbassa para atthassa nivattetabbassa abhāvāḥ atta ttha gahaṇañca
translated: and so it is not🔽that of others. And the words “of oneself” should not be taken because there is no need to reveal the meaning of what is to be revealed, namely, the meaning of what is said by oneself. And the words “beginning” should not be taken

original: na kattabbaṃ. Attatthaparatthavinimuttassa bhāsitatthassa abhāvā ādiggahaṇañca na
analyzed: na kattabbam atta attha para attha vinimuttassa bhāsita tthassa abhāvā ādi ggahaṇam ca na
translated: because there is no meaning of what is said that is not included in the meaning of what is for one’s own benefit and in the meaning of what is for the benefit of others.

original: kattabbaṃ, tasmā yathāvuttassa hitapariyāyassa atthassa sutte asambhavato suttādhārassa🔽puggalassa vasena attatthaparatthā vuttā.
analyzed: kattabbam tasmai yathāvuttassa hita pariyāyassa atthassa sutte asambhavataḥ sutta ādhārassa  puggalassa vasena atta attha para tthā vuttā
translated: So since the meaning of the expression “advantage” as stated is not found in the texts, the four kinds of advantage, namely, one’s own advantage, etc., are stated here in terms of the person who is the support for the texts.

original: Atha vā suttaṃ anapekkhitvā ye attatthādayo atthappabhedā “na ha’ññadattha’tthi pasaṃsalābhā”ti
analyzed: atha vā suttam an apekkhitvā ye atta ttha ādayaḥ attha ppabhedāḥ na pasaṃsa lābhā ti
translated: Or alternatively, without regard to the texts, the four kinds of advantage, namely, one’s own advantage, etc., are stated here in terms of the different kinds of meaning mentioned in the explanation of the words “There is no advantage in praise, no disadvantage in blame” .

original: etassa padassa niddese vuttā “attattho, parattho, ubhayattho, diṭṭhadhammiko attho,🔽samparāyiko attho, uttāno attho, gambhīro attho, gūḷho attho, paṭicchanno attho,
analyzed: etassa padassa niddese vuttā atta tthaḥ para tthaḥ ubhaya tthaḥ diṭṭhadhammikaḥ attho  samparāyikaḥ attho uttānaḥ attho gambhīraḥ attho gūḍhaḥ attho paṭicchannaḥ attho
translated: The four kinds of advantage are one’s own advantage, another’s advantage, the advantage of both, the advantage visible here and now,

original: neyyo attho, nīto attho, anavajjo attho, nikkileso attho, vodāno attho, paramattho”ti,
analyzed: neyyaḥ atthaḥ nītaḥ atthaḥ anavajjaḥ atthaḥ nikkilesaḥ atthaḥ vodānaḥ attho paramattho ti
translated: the advantage in the life to come, the advantage of the essentials of existence, the advantage of the immaterial, the advantage of the supramundane, the advantage of the conditioned, and the advantage of the unconditioned.

original: te atthappabhede sūcetīti attho gahetabbo. Kiñcāpi hi suttanirapekkhaṃ attatthādayo
analyzed: te attha ppabhede sūceti iti atthaḥ gahetabbo kiñcā api hi sutta nirapekkham atta ttha ādayaḥ
translated: The four kinds of disadvantage are the opposite of these. The four kinds of benefit are the opposite of the four kinds of disadvantage.🔽The four kinds of harm are the opposite of the four kinds of advantage. The four kinds of non-harm are the opposite of the four kinds of harm.🔽The four kinds of blame are the opposite of the four kinds of non-harm. The four kinds of non-blame are the opposite of the four kinds of blame.🔽The four kinds of fault are the opposite of the four kinds of non-blame. The four kinds of non-fault are the opposite of the four kinds of fault.🔽The four kinds of danger are the opposite of the four kinds of non-fault. The four kinds of safety are the opposite of the four kinds of danger.🔽The four kinds of defilement are the opposite of the four kinds of safety. The four kinds of purification are the opposite of the four kinds of defilement.🔽The four kinds of corruption are the opposite of the four kinds of purification. The four kinds of non-corruption are the opposite of the four kinds of corruption.

original: vuttā suttatthabhāvena aniddiṭṭhattā, tesu pana ekopi atthappabhedo suttena dīpetabbataṃ
analyzed: vuttā sutta attha bhāvena aniddiṭṭha ttā tesu pana ekaḥ api attha ppabhedaḥ suttena dīpetabba tam
translated: The four kinds of non-transgression are the opposite of the four kinds of transgression. The four kinds of non-affliction are the opposite of the four kinds of affliction.🔽The four kinds of cleansing are the opposite of the four kinds of affliction. The four kinds of non-distress are the opposite of the four kinds of distress.🔽The four kinds of non-fever are the opposite of the four kinds of fever. The four kinds of non-bondage

original: nātivattatīti. Imasmiñca atthavikappe atthasaddo bhāsitatthapariyāyopi hoti. Ettha
analyzed: na ativattati iti imasmin ca attha vikappe attha saddo bhāsita ttha pariyāyaḥ api hoti ettha
translated: And in this interpretation of the meaning the word “meaning” is a synonym for “what is said.”🔽For here the first five kinds of meaning are synonyms for “welfare,”

original: hi purimakā pañca atthappabhedā hitapariyāyā, tato pare cha bhāsitatthappabhedā,
analyzed: hi purimakā pañca attha pabhedā hita pariyāyā tato pare cha bhāsita ttha pabhedā
translated: the next six are synonyms for “what is said,”

original: pacchimakā cattāro ubhayasabhāvā. Tattha suviññeyyatāya vibhāvena anagādhabhāvo uttāno.
analyzed: cattāro ubhaya sabhāvā tattha su viññeyya tāya vibhāvena anagādha bhāvaḥ uttānaḥ
translated: and the last four are a combination of both. Herein, what is obvious is evident by reason of its being easy to know.🔽What is deep is not evident by reason of its being hard to fathom.

original: Duradhigamatāya vibhāvena agādhabhāvo gambhīro. Avivaṭo gūḷho. Mūludakādayo viya
analyzed: duradhigama tāya vibhāvena agādha bhāvaḥ gambhīraḥ a vivaṭaḥ gūḍhaḥ mūla udaka ādayaḥ
translated: What is obscure is hidden.🔽What is concealed is covered up by dust, etc., or by the arrangement of the letters,

original: paṃsunā akkharasannivesādinā tirohito paṭicchanno. Niddhāretvā ñāpetabbo neyyo. Yathārutavasena🔽veditabbo nīto. Anavajjanikkilesavodānā pariyāyavasena vuttā, kusalavipākakiriyādhammavasena
analyzed: paṃsunā akkhara sannivesa ādinā tirohitaḥ paṭicchannaḥ niddhāretvā ñāpetabbaḥ neyyaḥ yathāruta vasena  veditabbaḥ nītaḥ anavajja nikkilesa vodānā pariyāya vasena vuttā kusala vipāka kiriyā dhamma vasena
translated: and so on. What is to be inferred is to be made known by inference.🔽What is to be arrived at is to be known by the method of agreement.🔽What is free from taint is stated by way of the absence of the taint of blame.🔽Or they can be taken respectively as profitable, resultant, and inoperative states.

original: vā yathākkamaṃ yojetabbā. Paramattho nibbānaṃ, dhammānaṃ aviparītasabhāvo eva vā.
analyzed: vā yathākkamam yojetabbā param atthaḥ nibbānam dhammānam aviparīta sabhāvaḥ eva vā
translated: The ultimate meaning is Nibbāna, or the unperverted individual essence of states.🔽Or alternatively, “He himself has few wishes” is for his own welfare;

original: Atha vā “attanā ca appiccho hotī”ti attatthaṃ, “appicchakathañca paresaṃ kattā hotī”ti
analyzed: atha vā attanā ca appicchaḥ hoti iti attattham appicchakatham ca paresam kattā hoti iti
translated: “he is one who speaks to others about having few wishes” is for the welfare of others;

original: paratthaṃ sūceti. Evaṃ “attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, parañca pāṇātipātā🔽veramaṇiyā samādapetī”tiādisuttāni yojetabbāni. Apare pana “yathāsabhāvaṃ bhāsitaṃ🔽attatthaṃ, pūraṇakassapādīnamaññatitthiyānaṃ samayabhūtaṃ paratthaṃ sūceti, suttena🔽vā saṅgahitaṃ attatthaṃ, suttānulomabhūtaṃ paratthaṃ, suttantanayabhūtaṃ vā attatthaṃ,
analyzed: parattham sūcaya iti evam attanā ca pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti param ca pāṇa atipātā  veramaṇiyā samādapeti iti ādi suttāni yojetabbāni apare pana yathāsabhāvam bhāsitam  atta ttham pūraṇa kassapa ādīnam añña titthiyānam samaya bhūtam parattham sūceti suttena  vā saṅgahitam attattham sutta anuloma bhūtam parattham suttanta naya bhūtam vā attattham
translated: and the other’s meaning is that it points to the other’s welfare. So too with the other suttas beginning, “He himself abstains from the destruction of life … and he instigates others to abstain from the destruction of life” . But others say that the meaning for oneself is that it is spoken in accordance with actuality,🔽and the meaning for the other is that it points to the welfare of the other, as in the case of the doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa and the other sectarian teachers. The meaning for oneself is that it is included in the discourses,🔽and the meaning for the other is that it is in conformity with the discourses, or that it is in the tradition of the discourses,

original: vinayābhidhammanayabhūtaṃ paratthaṃ sūcetī”tipi vadanti. Vinayābhidhammehi ca visesetvā🔽suttasaddassa attho vattabbo, tasmā veneyyajjhāsayavasappavattāya desanāya sātisayaṃ🔽attahitaparahitādīni pakāsitāni honti tappadhānabhāvato, na pana āṇādhammasabhāva-vasappavattāyāti🔽idameva “atthānaṃ sūcanato sutta”nti vuttaṃ. Sūca-saddassa cettha rasso. “Evañca
analyzed: vinaya abhidhamma naya bhūtam parattham vadanti vinaya abhidhammehi ca visesetvā 🔽sutta saddassa atthaḥ vattabbaḥ tasmā veneyya ajjhāsaya vasa ppavattāya desanāya sa atisayam 🔽atta hita para hita ādīni pakāsitāni honti tad padhāna bhāvataḥ na pana āṇā dhamma sabhāva vasa ppavattāya ati 🔽idam eva atthānam sūcanato suttan ti vuttam sūca saddassa ca ittha rassaḥ evam ca
translated: It indicates the benefit for oneself. Likewise the other Threads should be applied in the same way, that is to say, “He is himself abstaining from killing breathing things, and he instigates others to abstain from killing breathing things” , and so on. But others say that what is spoken of according to its individual essence is the benefit for oneself, and what is the occasion for others is indicated as the benefit for others, as in the case of the wanderers of other sects such as Purana Kassapa, etc., and that what is included in the Thread is the benefit for oneself, and what is the occasion for others is indicated as the benefit for others, as in the case of the Thread called “The Great Way of the Factors of Making for Emancipation” , and what is the Thread’s way is the benefit for oneself, and what is the Discipline and the Further-Norm’s way is indicated as the benefit for others. But the meaning of the word “ Thread” should be stated by distinguishing it from the Discipline and the Further-Norm. Therefore what is taught in the teaching that occurs according to the inclination of the disciples is the benefit for oneself and the benefit for others, etc., in excess, since it is the state of their practice, but it does not occur as the state of the nature of a command. So it is this that is called “ Thread” since it indicates the benefit. And here the word “ Thread” has a short vowel .

original: katvā ‘ettakaṃ tassa bhagavato suttāgataṃ suttapariyāpanna’nti ca sakavāde pañca
analyzed: katvā ettakam tassa bhagavato sutta āgatam sutta pariyāpannanti ca saka vāde pañca
translated: and having done so, he would say: ‘This much is spoken by the Blessed One, this much is included in the discourses,’ and he would make a division in his own doctrine,

original: suttasatānī’ti ca evamādīsu suttasaddo upacaritoti gahetabbo”ti ācariyasāriputtattherena
analyzed: sutta satāni iti ca evamādīsu sutta saddo upacarito ti gahetabbaḥ ti ācariya sāriputta ttherena
translated: and in his own doctrine he has stated that there are five hundred suttas, and so on. So the word sutta should be taken here as a conventional term.”

original: vuttaṃ. Aññe pana yathāvuttasadiseneva nibbacanena suttasaddassa vinayābhidhammānampi vācakattaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: vuttam aññe pana yathā vutta sadisena iva nibbacanena sutta saddassa vinaya abhidhammānam pi vācaka ttam vadanti
translated: But others say that the word sutta signifies the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma as well by the same method of derivation as that given above.

original: Sutte ca āṇādhammasabhāvo veneyyajjhāsayamanuvattati, na vinayābhidhammesu viya veneyyajjhāsayo
analyzed: sutte ca āṇā dhamma sabhāvaḥ veneyya ajjhāsayam anuvattati na vinaya abhidhammesu viya veneyya ajjhāsayaḥ
translated: And in the case of the sutta the nature of the thing enjoined conforms to the inclination of the disciples, but in the case of the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma the inclination of the disciples conforms to the nature of the thing enjoined.

original: āṇādhammasabhāve, tasmā veneyyānaṃ ekantahitapaṭilābhasaṃvattanikā suttantadesanāti
analyzed: āṇā dhamma sabhāve tasmā veneyyānam ekanta hita paṭilābha saṃvattanikā suttanta desanā ti
translated: Therefore the teaching of the sutta-collection is conducive to the attainment of the highest welfare of disciples.

original: āha “suvuttā cettha atthā”tiādi. “Ekantahitapaṭilābhasaṃvattanikā suttantadesanā”ti
analyzed: āha su vuttā ca ittha attha atiādi ekanta hita paṭilābha saṃvattanikā suttanta desanā ti
translated: That is why he said, “The meaning is well proclaimed here” , and so on.🔽And this is said too: “The teaching of the sutta-collection is conducive to the attainment of the highest welfare of disciples.”

original: idampi veneyyānaṃ hitasampādane suttantadesanāya tapparabhāvameva sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam pi veneyyānam hita sampādane suttanta desanāya tad para bhāvam eva sandhāya vuttam
translated: This is said with reference to the fact that the teaching of the sutta-collection is the means for accomplishing the welfare of disciples.

original: Tapparabhāvo ca veneyyajjhāsayānulomato daṭṭhabbo. Tenevāha “veneyyajjhāsayānulomena🔽vuttattā”ti. Etena ca hetunā nanu vinayābhidhammāpi suvuttā, atha kasmā idameva evaṃ
analyzed: tad para bhāvo ca veneyya ajjhāsayā anulomataḥ daṭṭhabbo tena iva āha veneyya ajjhāsayā anulomena  vutta ttā iti etena ca hetunā nanu vinaya abhidhammā api su vuttā atha kasmai idam eva evam
translated: And the latter part should be regarded as in conformity with the dispositions of those susceptible of teaching. That is why it is said, “Because it is spoken in conformity with the dispositions of those susceptible of teaching.”

original: vuttanti anuyogaṃ pariharati.
analyzed: vutta nti anuyogam pariharati
translated: And by this reason he answers the question, “But surely the Vinaya and the Abhidhamma are well spoken too. So why is it said that only this is well spoken?”

original: Anupubbasikkhādivasena kālantarena atthābhinipphattiṃ dassetuṃ “sassamiva phala”nti
analyzed: anupubba sikkhā ādi vasena kāla antarena attha abhinipphattim dassetum sassam iva phalanti
translated: The words “like a crop, its fruit” are said to show that the meaning is accomplished in time by gradual training, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā sassaṃ nāma vapanaropanādikkhaṇeyeva phalaṃ na pasavati,🔽anupubbajagganādivasena kālantareneva pasavati, tathā idampi savanadhāraṇādikkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: vuttam idam vuttam hoti yathā sassam nāma vapana ropana ādi kkhaṇeya iva phalam na pasavati  anupubba jaggana ādi vasena kāla antarena iva pasavati tathā idam pi savana dhāraṇā ādi kkhaṇeya iva
translated: For a crop does not produce its fruit at the very time of sowing and planting, etc.,🔽but it produces it only in time by gradual tending, etc., so too this Dhamma does not produce its meaning at the very time of hearing and memorizing it,

original: atthe na pasavati, anupubbasikkhādivasena kālantareneva pasavatīti. Pasavatīti ca
analyzed: atthe na pasavati anupubba sikkhā ādi vasena kāla antarena iva pasavati iti pasavati iti ca
translated: but it produces it only in time by gradual training, etc. “It produces” is said

original: phalati, abhinipphādetīti attho. Abhinipphādanameva hi phalanaṃ. Upāyasamaṅgīnaññeva
analyzed: phalati abhinipphādeti iti atthaḥ abhinipphādanam eva hi phalanam
translated: because it ripens, the meaning of which is that it is accomplished. For ripening is the same as accomplishment.

original: atthābhinipphattiṃ dassento “dhenu viya khīra”nti āha. Ayamettha adhippāyo – yathā
analyzed: attha abhinipphattim dassentaḥ dhenu viya khīran ti āha ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ yathā
translated: He said “milk from a cow” in order to show the attainment of the benefit. The intention here is this:

original: dhenu nāma kāle jātavacchā thanaṃ gahetvā duhataṃ upāyavantānameva khīraṃ paggharāpeti,
analyzed: dhenu nāma kāle jātavacchā thanam gahetvā duhatam upāyavantānam eva khīram
translated: Just as a cow, when her calf is born and she has been milked by those who know how to milk her, lets her milk flow for them,

original: na akāle ajātavacchā. Kālepi vā visāṇādikaṃ gahetvā duhataṃ anupāyavantānaṃ, tathā🔽idampi nissaraṇādinā savanadhāraṇādīni kurutaṃ upāyavantānameva sīlādiatthe paggharāpeti,
analyzed: na akāle kāle pi vā visāṇa ādikam tathā  idam pi nissaraṇa ādinā savana dhāraṇa ādīni kurutam upāyavantānam eva sīla ādi atthe
translated: but not when her calf is not yet born, or even when it is born, if she is milked by those who do not know how to milk her;

original: na alagaddūpamāya savanadhāraṇādīni kurutaṃ anupāyavantānanti. Yadipi “sūdatī”ti🔽etassa gharati siñcatīti attho, tathāpi sakammikadhātuttā paggharāpetīti kāritavasena
analyzed: savana dhāraṇa ādīni kurutam savana dhāraṇa ādīni kurutam sūdati iti  etassa gharati siñcati iti atthaḥ tathā api sa kammika dhātuttā paggharāpeti iti kārita vasena
translated: so too this Dhamma lets the benefit of virtue, etc., flow for those who listen to it, bear it in mind, etc., and who are equipped with the means, but not for those who do not listen to it, bear it in mind, etc., and are not equipped with the means, though they be clever like the eel.

original: attho vutto yathā “taratī”ti etassa nipātetīti attho”ti. “Suttāṇā”ti etassa atthamāha
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ yathā tarati iti etassa nipāteti iti attho ti etassa attham āha
translated: Although the meaning of the word “sūdati” is “it makes flow,” nevertheless the meaning is stated here in terms of the action of letting flow, as in the expression “tarati” , which means “it makes to cross over.”

original: “suṭṭhu ca ne tāyatī”ti. Neti atthe.
analyzed: suṭṭhu ca ne tāyati iti neti atthe
translated: He explains the meaning of the word “suttāṇā” as “suṭṭhu ca ne tāyati” . The word “ne” has the meaning of “atthe.”

original: Suttasabhāganti suttasadisaṃ. Tabbhāvaṃ dasseti “yathā hī”tiādinā. Tacchakānaṃ suttanti
analyzed: sutta sabhāgam ti sutta sadisam tad bhāvam dasseti yathā hi itiādinā tad śakānam sutta nti
translated: The “assembly of suttas” is like a sutta. He shows its nature with “For just as,” etc. The “straightened thread” of the weavers is

original: vaḍḍhakīnaṃ kāḷasuttaṃ. Pamāṇaṃ hoti tadanusārena tacchanato. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti –
analyzed: vaḍḍhakīnam kāḷasuttam pamāṇam hoti tad anusārena tad śanataḥ idam vuttam hoti
translated: the black thread. It is a measure because it is straightened by following it. This is what is said:

original: yathā kāḷasuttaṃ pasāretvā saññāṇe kate gahetabbaṃ, vissajjetabbañca paññāyati, tasmā🔽taṃ tacchakānaṃ pamāṇaṃ hoti, evaṃ vivādesu uppannesu sutte ānītamatte “idaṃ gahetabbaṃ,
analyzed: yathā kāḷa suttam pasāretvā saññāṇe kate gahetabbam vissajjetabbam ca paññāyati tasmā  tat tat śakānam pamāṇam hoti evam vivādesu uppannesu sutte ānīta matte idam gahetabbam
translated: just as the black thread, when stretched out, is seen to be the means of taking up and letting go of the warp,

original: idaṃ vissajjetabba”nti pākaṭattā vivādo vūpasammati, tasmā etaṃ viññūnaṃ pamāṇanti.
analyzed: idam vissajjetabbam ti pākaṭa ttā vivādaḥ vūpasammati tasmai etam viññūnam pamāṇam ti
translated: so too, when a dispute has arisen, as soon as a sutta is brought up, it becomes clear what is to be taken up and what is to be let go of, and so the dispute is settled. Therefore this is a measure for the wise.

original: Idāni aññathāpi suttasabhāgataṃ vibhāvento “yathā cā”tiādimāha. Suttenāti pupphāvutena
analyzed: idāni aññathā api sutta sabhā gatam vibhāventaḥ yathā ca atiādim āha suttena ati puppha āvutena
translated: Now, in order to show the similarity to a sutta in another way, he says “And just as,” etc. By a sutta means by a thread of flowers,
