translated: For in the Abhidhamma the three kinds of clear knowledge, the six kinds of direct-knowledge, and the four analytical knowledges are mentioned.🔽But the analytical knowledges are mentioned in the Suttas too.

original: aññattha pabhedavacanābhāvaṃ, tattheva ca sammā vibhattabhāvaṃ dīpetukāmo heṭṭhā
analyzed: aññattha pabheda vacana abhāvam tattha iva ca sammā vibhatta bhāvam dīpetu kāmaḥ heṭṭhā
translated: wishing to point out that there is no explanation of the divisions elsewhere, and that they are properly explained there, he said:🔽🔽

original: vuttanayena avadhāraṇamakatvā “tatthevā”ti parivattetvā avadhāraṇaṃ ṭhapeti. “Abhidhamme🔽pana tisso vijjā, cha abhiññā, catasso ca paṭisambhidā aññe ca sammappadhānādayo🔽guṇavisesā vibhattā. Kiñcāpi vibhattā, visesato pana paññājātikattā catassova paṭisambhidā
analyzed: vutta nayena avadhāraṇam a katvā tattha eva ati parivattetvā avadhāraṇam ṭhapeti abhidhamme  pana tissaḥ vijjā cha abhiññā catasso ca paṭisambhidāḥ aññe ca sammappadhāna ādayo  guṇa visesāḥ vibhattā kiñcā api vibhattā visesato pana paññā jātika ttā catasso uva paṭisambhidā
translated: The Elder Vajirabuddhi says that the intention is to show that there is no division elsewhere and that the division is correct here itself, and so, without making the specification as in the previous case, he makes the specification by reversing the order thus: ‘Herein only.’

original: pāpuṇātīti dassanatthaṃ ‘tāsañca tatthevā’ti avadhāraṇavipallāso kato”ti vajirabuddhitthero.

original: “Eva”ntiādi nigamanaṃ.🔽Sukho samphasso etesanti sukhasamphassāni, anuññātāniyeva tādisāni attharaṇapāvuraṇādīni,

original: tesaṃ phassasāmaññato sukho vā samphasso tathā, anuññāto so yesanti anuññātasukhasamphassāni,

original: “Cattārome bhikkhave, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ. Katame cattāro? Attahitāya🔽paṭipanno no parahitāya, parahitāya paṭipanno no attahitāya, nevattahitāya paṭipanno

translated: “Monks, there are these four people to be found existing in the world. Which four? There is the person who practices for his/her own benefit but not for the benefit of others; for the benefit of others but not for his/her own benefit; neither for his/her own benefit nor for the benefit of others;

original: no parahitāya, attahitāya ceva paṭipanno parahitāya ca…pe… ime kho bhikkhave…pe… lokasmi”nti –

translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four kinds of persons to be found existing in the world. What four? These are the four kinds of persons to be found existing in the world” .🔽Thus he shows the text of the Sutta called the “Discourse on the Identification of the Four Persons” .

original: Atthānulomikattaṃ vibhāvetumāha “kasmā”tiādi. Guṇopacārena, taddhitavasena vā dīgha-saddena🔽dīghappamāṇāni suttāniyeva gahitāni, nikāyasaddo ca ruḷhivasena samūhanivāsatthesu🔽vattatīti dasseti “dīghappamāṇāna”ntiādinā. Saṅketasiddhattā vacanīyavācakānaṃ payogato
analyzed: vibhāvetum āha kasmā itiādi guṇa upacārena taddhita vasena vā dīgha saddena  dīgha ppamāṇāni suttāniyā iva gahitāni nikāya saddaḥ ca ruḷhi vasena samūha nivāsa atthesu  vattati iti dasseti dīgha ppamāṇa ananti ādinā saṅketa siddha ttā vacanīya vācakānam payogataḥ
translated: The word “long” is used in the sense of a quality or in the derivative sense of “long in extent.”🔽And the word “collection” is used in the sense of a heap or a dwelling place by natural development.🔽He shows this with the words “long in extent” and so on.🔽Since the relation between the word and its meaning is well known, he makes it known in the sense of that with the words “I do not say” and so on.

original: tadatthesu tassa saṅketasiddhataṃ ñāpento “nāha”ntiādimāha. Ekanikāyampīti ekasamūhampi.

original: Evaṃ cittanti evaṃ vicittaṃ. Yathayidanti yathā ime tiracchānagatā pāṇā. Poṇikā,

original: Etthāti nikāyasaddassa samūhanivāsānaṃ vācakabhāve. analyzed: ettha ati nikāya saddassa samūha nivāsānam vācaka bhāve sādhakāni iti adhippetassa atthassa  sādhanataḥ udāharaṇāni vuccanti samānītāni iti pāṭha sesena ca itassa sambandhaḥ sakkhīni  vā yathā vutta nayena sādhakāni yam hi niddhāretvā adhippeta ttham sādhenti tam sakkhi iti  vadanti tathā hi manorathapūraṇiyam vuttam pañcagaru jātakam pana sakkhibhāva tthāya
translated: ‘Here’ means in the case of the word ‘collection’ as denoting a group or a dwelling-place. ‘Proofs’ are called ‘examples’ because they prove the meaning intended. ‘They are the same’ is the connection with the word ‘mind’ by a different reading. Accordingly it is said in the Manorathapūraṇī: ‘But the Pañcagaru Jātaka is for the purpose of being a witness’ .🔽

original: āharitvā kathetabba”nti sāsanatoti sāsanapayogato, sāsane vā. Lokatoti lokiyapayogato,🔽loke vā. Idaṃ pana piṭakattaye na vijjati, tasmā evaṃ vuttanti vadanti. analyzed: āharitvā kathetabbanti sāsanato ti sāsana payogato sāsane vā lokato ti lokiya payogato 🔽loke vā idam pana piṭaka ttaye na vijjati tasmai evam vuttam iti vadanti ettha ca 🔽paṭhamam udāharaṇam sāsanataḥ sādhaka vacanam dutiyam lokato ti daṭṭhabbam 🔽mūla pariyāya vagga ādi vasena pañcadasa vagga saṅgahāni aḍḍhena dutiyam diyaḍḍham tat eva
translated: ‘Here’ means in the case of the word ‘collection’ as denoting a collection and a dwelling-place. ‘Proofs’ are called ‘examples’ because they prove the meaning intended. ‘The same’ is the connection with the word ‘mind’ by a different reading. Or else the ‘witnesses’ are the proofs in the way stated. For they call that ‘a witness’ by which they prove the meaning intended. Accordingly it is said in the Manorathapūraṇī: ‘But the Pañcagaru Jātaka should be told by bringing it in for the purpose of being a witness’ . ‘From the Dispensation’: from the use of the Dispensation, or in the Dispensation. ‘From the world’: from the use of the world, or in the world. But this is not found in the three Baskets, and that is why it is said thus. And here the first example should be regarded as a statement that proves from the Dispensation, and the second as proving from the world. They are included in the fifteen-group division according to the first section, the ‘Root-Enumeration’ , etc.

original: sataṃ, ekasataṃ, paññāsa ca suttānīti vuttaṃ hoti. Yatthāti yasmiṃ nikāye. Pañcadasavaggapariggahoti

analyzed: padam pada samudāye ca vākyam vākya samudāye suttam sutta samudāye vaggo ti samaññā  evam vagga samudāye saṃyutta samaññā devatāya pucchitena kathita sutta vagga ādīnam saṃyutta ttā

And by that it is known that “in all cases

analyzed: suttaṅgam siyā maṅgala sutta ādīnam suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ na siyā gāthā bhāvataḥ dhamma pada ādīnam  viya geyyaṅga saṅgahaḥ vā siyā sagāthaka ttā sagāthā vaggassa viya tathā ubhatas vibhaṅga ādīsu
translated: But if it were a sutta part in some way or other, then the Mangala Sutta, etc., would not be included in the sutta part because they are without verses, like the Dhammapada, etc.,🔽or they would be included in the geyya part because they have verses, like the Sagāthāvagga.🔽So too, in the two Vibhaṅgas, etc., there is the expression “the section with verses” .

analyzed: sa nimittā niruḍha ttā sahatā aññena na aññatas

analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmā mahākaccāyanaḥ nettiyam āha navavidha suttanta pariyeṭṭhī iti tattha  hi sutta ādi vasena navaṅgassa sāsanassa pariyeṭṭhi pariyesanā attha vicāraṇā navavidha

The deities had asked the Buddha who had been created by the Blessed One to question himself.🔽Thus here

original: suttanipāte āgatānaṃ maṅgalasuttādīnaṃ suttaṅgasaṅgaho dassito, tattheva āgatānaṃ
analyzed: sutta nipāte āgatānam maṅgala sutta ādīnam suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ dassito tattha iva āgatānam
translated: The Collection of Stanzas has been shown to be a collection of sutta-type discourses, such as the Mangala Sutta, etc., which are found in the Collection of Stanzas.🔽And it will show that the Collection of Stanzas is also a collection of the gāthā-type discourses, such as the Asuttanāma, etc., which are found in the same collection.

original: asuttanāmikānaṃ suddhikagāthānaṃ gāthaṅgasaṅgahañca dassayissati, evaṃ sati suttanipātaṭṭhakathārambhe –
analyzed: a sutta nāmikānam suddhika gāthānam gāthaṅga saṅgaham ca dassayissati evam sati sutta nipāta ṭṭhakathā ārambhe
translated: If this is so, then why does the Commentary on the Collection of Stanzas begin with the following question:🔽“Why is it called the Collection of Stanzas,

original: “Gāthāsatasamākiṇṇo, geyyabyākaraṇaṅkito;
analyzed: gāthā sata samākiṇṇaḥ
translated: Which is filled with a hundred stanzas,

original: Kasmā suttanipātoti, saṅkhamesa gatoti ce”ti. ; –
analyzed: kasmā sutta nipāto ti saṅkhamesa gato ti ca iti
translated: And marked with geyya and veyyākaraṇa?”

original: Sakalassāpi suttanipātassa geyyaveyyākaraṇaṅgasaṅgaho kasmā coditoti? Nāyaṃ virodho.
analyzed: sakalassa api sutta nipātassa geyya veyyākaraṇa aṅga saṅgaho kasmā coditaḥ iti na ayam virodhaḥ
translated: Why is it asked why the Collection of Stanzas is a collection of geyya and veyyākaraṇa? There is no contradiction here.

original: Kevalañhi tattha codakena sagāthakattaṃ, katthaci pucchāvissajjanattañca gahetvā🔽codanāmattaṃ kataṃ, aññathā suttanipāte niggāthakassa suttasseva abhāvato veyyākaraṇaṅgasaṅgaho
analyzed: kevalam hi tattha ca udakena sagāthaka ttam katthaci pucchā vissajjana ttam ca gahetvā  codanā mattam katam aññathā sutta nipāte niggāthakassa suttassa iva abhāvataḥ veyyākaraṇa aṅga saṅgaho
translated: For the questioner has merely asked the question in order to point out that some of the discourses in the Collection of Stanzas are in verse and some are in prose.🔽Otherwise, since there is no discourse in the Collection of Stanzas that is not in verse or prose, the questioner might not have asked why the Collection of Stanzas is a collection of geyya and veyyākaraṇa.

original: na codetabbo siyā, tasmā codakassa vacanametaṃ appamāṇanti idha, aññāsu ca vinayaṭṭhakathādīsu
analyzed: na codetabbaḥ siyā tasmā codakassa vacanam etam appamāṇam ti idha aññāsu ca vinaya ṭṭhakathā ādīsu
translated: Therefore the questioner’s statement should be taken as a mere question. In other places, such as the Commentary on the Vinaya,

original: vuttanayeneva tassa suttaṅgagāthaṅgasaṅgaho dassitoti. Suttanti cuṇṇiyasuttaṃ. Visesenāti🔽rāsibhāvena ṭhitaṃ sandhāyāha. Sagāthāvaggo geyyanti sambandho.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva tassa suttaṅga gāthaṅga saṅgahaḥ dassito ti suttam ti cuṇṇiya suttam visesena ati  rāsi bhāvena ṭhitam sandhāya āha sa gāthā vaggaḥ geyyan ti sambandhaḥ
translated: he says this referring to what is classed in groups. The construction is: “The chapter with verses is the chanting.”

original: “Aṭṭhahi aṅgehi asaṅgahitaṃ nāma paṭisambhidādī”ti tīsupi kira gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhahi aṅgehi asaṅgahitam nāma paṭisambhidā ādi iti tīsu pi kira gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam
translated: “What is not included in the eight limbs is the Discrimination of Persuits, etc.” is said in the three Commentaries.

original: Apare pana paṭisambhidāmaggassa geyyaveyyākaraṇaṅgadvayasaṅgahaṃ vadanti. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: apare pana paṭisambhidā maggassa geyya veyyākaraṇa aṅga dvaya saṅgaham vadanti vuttam ha etam
translated: But others say that the Discrimination of Persuits and the Path are included in the two limbs of chanting and recitation. For this is said in the commentary on that:

original: tadaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “navasu satthusāsanaṅgesu yathāsambhavaṃ geyyaveyyākaraṇaṅgadvayasaṅgahita”nti,
analyzed: tad aṭṭhakathā ayam navasu satthu sāsana aṅgesu yathāsambhavam geyya veyyākaraṇa aṅga dvaya saṅgahitanti
translated: “In the nine limbs of the Master’s Dispensation they are included in the two limbs of chanting and recitation as appropriate.”

original: etthāpi geyyaṅgasaṅgahitabhāvo vuttanayena vīmaṃsitabbo. No suttanāmikāti asuttanāmikā
analyzed: ettha api geyyaṅga saṅgahita bhāvaḥ vutta nayena vīmaṃsitabbaḥ no sutta nāmikā ati a sutta nāmikā
translated: Herein, the inclusion in the Verse-limb should be investigated in the same way as above. “Not called a sutta” : not given the name of a sutta.

original: saṅgītikāle suttasamaññāya apaññātā. “Suddhikagāthā nāma vatthugāthā”ti tīsupi kira
analyzed: saṅgīti kāle sutta samaññāya apaññātā suddhikagāthā nāma vatthu gāthā ati tīsupi kira
translated: at the time of the rehearsal of the True Idea it was not given the name of a sutta. “A pure verse is a verse about a situation” is said in the three Commentaries.

original: gaṇṭhipadesu vuttaṃ, vatthugāthāti ca pārāyanavaggassa nidānamāropentena āyasmatā
analyzed: gaṇṭhi padesu vuttam vatthu gāthā ati ca pārāyana vaggassa nidānam āropentena āyasmatā
translated: And “a verse about a situation” is the introduction to the Pārāyana chapter composed by the venerable Mahā-Kaccāna, who was skilled in the nine-factored introduction.

original: ānandattherena saṅgītikāle vuttā chappaññāsa gāthāyo, nālakasuttassa nidānamāropentena
analyzed: ānanda therena saṅgīti kāle vuttā chappaññāsa gāthāyaḥ nālaka suttassa nidānam āropentena
translated: The fifty-six verses spoken by the Elder Ananda at the time of the rehearsal of the Dhamma are called the “Nalakasutta” because they are introduced by the story of Nalakas.

original: teneva tadā vuttā vīsatimattā gāthāyo ca vuccanti. Suttanipātaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “parinibbute
analyzed: tena iva tadā vuttāḥ vīsati mattāḥ gāthāyaḥ ca vuccanti sutta nipāta ṭṭhakathā ayam pana parinibbute
translated: The twenty verses spoken by the Elder Ananda at that time are also called the “Nalakasutta.” But in the commentary to the Suttanipata it is said:

original: bhagavati saṅgītiṃ karontenāyasmatā mahākassapena tameva moneyyapaṭipadaṃ puṭṭho
analyzed: bhagavati saṅgītim karontena ayasmatā mahākassapena tam eva moneyya paṭipadam puṭṭhaḥ
translated: “When the Blessed One had attained final Nibbana, the venerable Maha Kassapa, who was rehearsing the Dhamma, asked the venerable Ananda about the way of practice that was the forerunner of the supernormal powers.

original: āyasmā ānando yena, yadā ca samādapito nālakatthero bhagavantaṃ pucchi, taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ yena yadā ca samādapitaḥ nālaka ttheraḥ bhagavantam pucchi tam sabbam
translated: The venerable Ananda replied, ‘Venerable sir, when the Elder Nalakaputta asked the Blessed One about the way of practice that was the forerunner of the supernormal powers, the Blessed One answered him thus.’

original: pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetukāmo ‘ānandajāte’tiādikā vīsati vatthugāthāyo vatvā vissajjesi,
analyzed: pākaṭam katvā dassetu kāmaḥ ānanda jāta iti ādikāḥ vīsati vatthu gāthāyaḥ vatvā vissajjesi
translated: Desiring to show all this clearly, he recited the twenty verses beginning with the words ‘When Ananda was born’ and then concluded.🔽All this is called the ‘Nalakasutta.’ ”

original: taṃ sabbampi ‘nālakasutta”nti vuccatī”ti āgatattā nālakasuttassa vatthugāthāyo nālakasuttaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: tat sabbam pi nālaka suttanti vuccati iti āgata ttā nālaka suttassa vatthu gāthāyaḥ nālaka sutta ggahaṇena iva
translated: Since the verses of the story of the Nalakasutta are included in the Nalakasutta itself,

original: gahitāti pārāyanavaggassa vatthugāthāyo idha suddhikagāthāti gahetabbaṃ. Tattheva
analyzed: gahitā ti pārāyana vaggassa vatthu gāthāyaḥ idha suddhika gāthā ti gahetabbam tattha eva
translated: the verses of the story of the Parayana should be taken as the “pure verses” here.🔽And in the Parayana itself there are the twenty-six questions of the brahmin students Ajita and so forth,

original: ca pārāyanavagge ajitamāṇavakādīnaṃ soḷasannaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pucchāgāthā, bhagavato
analyzed: ca pārāyana vagge ajita māṇavaka ādīnam brāhmaṇānam pucchāgāthāḥ bhagavato
translated: and the Blessed One’s answers to them.

original: vissajjanagāthā ca pāḷiyaṃ suttanāmena avatvā ‘ajitamāṇavakapucchā, tissametteyyamāṇavakapucchā”tiādinā
analyzed: vissajjana gāthā ca pāḷiyam sutta nāmena avatvā ajita māṇavaka pucchā tissa metteyya māṇavaka pucchā ati ādinā
translated: And the verses of the answer are called in the text not by the name of a sutta but by the names of the questioners, namely, “The Questions of Ajita the wanderer” and “The Questions of Tissa the son of Mettagāma” .

original: āgatattā, cuṇṇiyaganthe hi asammissattā ca “no suttanāmikā suddhikagāthā nāmā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: āgata ttā cuṇṇiya ganthe hi a sammissa ttā ca no sutta nāmikā suddhikagāthā nāma ati vattum vaṭṭati
translated: And in the Collection of Five Hundred Verses they are called “pure verses not named after a sutta” because they are unmixed.

original: “Somanassañāṇamayikagāthāpaṭisaṃyuttā”ti etena udānaṭṭhena udānanti anvatthasaññataṃ
analyzed: somanassa ñāṇa mayika gāthā paṭisaṃyuttā ti etena udāna aṭṭhena udānanti anvattha saññatam
translated: “The verses are connected with the knowledge of gladness” shows that it is called an udāna because it has the characteristic of being a cry of joy.🔽What is this udāna? It is an exclamation arisen by the impact of gladness.

original: dasseti kimidaṃ udānaṃ nāma? Pītivegasamuṭṭhāpito udāhāro. Yathā hi yaṃ telādi minitabbavatthu🔽mānaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, vissanditvā gacchati, taṃ “avasesako”ti vuccati. Yañca
analyzed: dassa iti kim idam udānam nāma pīti vega samuṭṭhāpitaḥ udāhāraḥ yathā hi yam tela ādi minitabba vatthu  mānam gahetum na sakkoti vissanditvā gacchati tam avasesakaḥ ti vuccati yat ca
translated: For just as a thing to be measured, such as oil or water,🔽that cannot be measured and overflows is called “excess,”

original: jalaṃ taḷākaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, ajjhottharitvā gacchati, taṃ “mahogho’ti vuccati,
analyzed: jalam taḷākam gahetum na sakkoti ajjhottharitvā gacchati tam mahogho ti vuccati
translated: and water in a tank that cannot be contained and overflows is called a “flood,”

original: evameva yaṃ pītivegasamuṭṭhāpitaṃ vitakkavipphāraṃ antohadayaṃ sandhāretuṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: evam eva yam pīti vega samuṭṭhāpitam vitakka vipphāram antar hadayam sandhāretum na sakkoti
translated: so too, this is an overflow of the impact of gladness, a flood of the impact of gladness, a cry of joy arisen by the impact of gladness, which cannot be contained by the heart’s core and so overflows from the mouth as an exclamation.

original: so adhiko hutvā anto asaṇṭhahitvā bahi vacīdvārena nikkhanto paṭiggāhakanirapekkho
analyzed: saḥ adhikaḥ hutvā antar a saṇṭhahitvā bahi vacī dvārena nikkhantaḥ paṭiggāhaka nirapekkhaḥ
translated: and it is said that “udāna is a special utterance that, having arisen in the mind, does not remain there but, overflowing, comes out through the door of the mouth without regard for a recipient.”

original: udāhāraviseso “udāna”nti vuccati “uda mode kīḷāyañcā”ti hi akkharacintakā vadanti,
analyzed: udāhāra visesaḥ udānanti vuccati uda mode kīḷāyan ca ati hi akkhara cintakāḥ vadanti
translated: The etymologists say that the word udāna is derived from the verb udāneti, “to rejoice, to play.”

original: idañca yebhuyyena vuttaṃ dhammasaṃvegavasena uditassāpi “sace bhāyatha dukkhassā”tiādiudānassa
analyzed: idam ca yebhuyyena vuttam dhamma saṃvega vasena uditassa api sace bhāyatha dukkhassa ati ādi udānassa
translated: And this is so in the majority of cases, for the udāna “If you fear suffering” is uttered out of a sense of urgency about the Dhamma,

original: udānapāḷiyaṃ āgatattā, tathā“gāthāpaṭisaṃyuttā”ti idampi yebhuyyeneva “atthi bhikkhave,🔽tadāyatanaṃ, yattha neva pathavī, na āpo”tiādikassa cuṇṇiyavākyavasena uditassāpi🔽tattha āgatattā. Nanu ca udānaṃ nāma pītisomanassasamuṭṭāpito, dhammasaṃvegasamuṭṭhāpito
analyzed: udāna pāḷiyam āgata ttā tathāgāthā paṭisaṃyuttā ti idam pi yebhuyyena iva atthi bhikkhave  tad āyatanam yattha na iva pathavī na āpo ti ādikassa cuṇṇiya vākya vasena uditassa api  tattha āgata ttā nanu ca udānam nāma pīti somanassa samuṭṭāpitaḥ dhamma saṃvega samuṭṭhāpito
translated: and it is included in the Udāna collection. Likewise, the verse “There is, bhikkhus, that base” is uttered in the form of a verse,🔽and it is included in the Udāna collection.

original: vā dhammapaṭiggāhakanirapekkho gāthābandhavasena, cuṇṇiyavākyavasena ca pavatto udāhāro,
analyzed: vā dhamma paṭiggāhaka nirapekkhaḥ gāthābandha vasena cuṇṇiya vākya vasena ca pavattaḥ udāhāraḥ
translated: But is not udāna a special utterance arisen either from joy and happiness or from a sense of urgency about the Dhamma, uttered in the form of a verse or a prose statement without regard for a recipient of the Dhamma?

original: tathā ceva sabbattha āgataṃ, idha kasmā “bhikkhave”ti āmantanaṃ vuttanti? Tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: tathā ca iva sabbattha āgatam idha kasmai bhikkhave ti āmantanam vuttanti tesam bhikkhūnam
translated: And is it not so in all the instances cited? Why then is the word bhikkhave used here as an address?

original: saññāpanatthaṃ eva, na paṭiggāhakakaraṇatthaṃ. Nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttañhi bhagavā dhammaṃ🔽desetvā nibbānaguṇānussaraṇena uppannapītisomanassena udānaṃ udānento “ayaṃ nibbānadhammo🔽kathamapaccayo upalabbhatī”ti tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ cetoparivitakkamaññāya tesaṃ tamatthaṃ🔽ñāpetukāmena “tadāyatana”nti vuttaṃ, na pana ekantato te paṭiggāhake katvāti veditabbanti.🔽Tayidaṃ sabbaññubuddhabhāsitaṃ paccekabuddhabhāsitaṃ sāvakabhāsitanti tibbidhaṃ hoti. analyzed: gāthā bhagavatā bodhi mūle udāna vasena pavattitā aneka sata sahassānam sammāsambuddhānam
translated: The verse was uttered by the Blessed One at the foot of the Bodhi Tree in the form of a spontaneous utterance (udāna). It is the spontaneous utterance of many hundreds of thousands of Perfectly Enlightened Ones.

original: udānabhūtā ca, tā aparabhāge dhammabhaṇḍāgārikassa bhagavatā desitattā dhammasaṅgāhakehi
analyzed: udāna bhūtā ca tāḥ aparabhāge dhammabhaṇḍāgārikassa bhagavatā desita ttā dhamma saṅgāhakehi
translated: Later, because it was taught by the Blessed One to the treasurer of the Dhamma,

original: udānapāḷiyaṃ saṅgahaṃ anāropetvā dhammapade saṅgahitā, yañca “aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño
analyzed: udāna pāḷiyam saṅgaham an āropetvā dhamma pade saṅgahitā yat ca aññā asi vata bho koṇḍañño
translated: it was not included in the Udāna section by the compilers of the Dhamma, but was included in the Dhammapada. The words of the spontaneous utterance “Koṇḍañña has understood!

original: aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño”ti udānavacanaṃ dasasahassilokadhātuyā devamanussānaṃ pavedanasamatthanigghosavipphāraṃ
analyzed: aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño ti udāna vacanam dasa sahassi lokadhātuyā deva manussānam pavedana samattha nigghosa vipphāram
translated: Koṇḍañña has understood!” uttered by the Blessed One, which had the power to announce to the devas and humans in the ten thousand world-element,

original: bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ, tadapi paṭhamabodhiyaṃ sabbesaṃ eva bhikkhūnaṃ sammāpaṭipattipaccavekkhaṇahetukaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā bhāsitam tat api paṭhama bodhiyam sabbesam eva bhikkhūnam sammā paṭipatti paccavekkhaṇa hetukam
translated: were spoken by the Blessed One at the first assembly of monks, as a result of his reflection on the correct practice of all the monks.🔽Just as the words “The monks have served me well, at one time” and so forth,

original: “ārādhayiṃsu vata maṃ bhikkhū ekaṃ samaya”ntiādivacanaṃ viya dhammacakkappavattanasuttantadesanāpariyosāne
analyzed: ārādhayiṃsu vata mama bhikkhū ekam samaya nti ādi vacanam viya dhamma cakka ppavattana suttanta desanā pariyosāne
translated: were spoken by the Blessed One at the conclusion of the teaching of the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta,

original: attanāpi adhigatadhammekadesassa yathādesitassa ariyamaggassa sabbapaṭhamaṃ sāvakesu
analyzed: attanā api adhigata dhamma ekadesassa yathā desitassa ariya maggassa sabba paṭhamam sāvakesu
translated: so too, the Blessed One spoke this verse in order to show the first disciples the path of the noble ones, which he had attained and taught.

original: therena adhigatattā attano parissamassa saphalabhāvapaccavekkhaṇahetutaṃ pītisomanassajanitaṃ🔽udāhāramattaṃ, na pana “yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā”tiādivacanaṃ viya pavattiyā,
analyzed: therena adhigata ttā attano parissamassa sa phala bhāva paccavekkhaṇa hetutam pīti somanassa janitam  udāhāra mattam na pana yadā have pātubhavanti dhamma ati ādi vacanam viya pavattiyā
translated: The Elder recited it because he had attained it. It is a mere utterance, born of the joy and gladness of his reflection on the success of his own struggle.🔽But it is not a declaration of the occurrence or the cessation of anything, as is the text beginning, “When ideas become manifest to the contemplation” .

original: nivattiyā vā pakāsananti dhammasaṅgāhakehi udānapāḷiyaṃ na saṅgītanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nivattiyā vā pakāsananti dhamma saṅgāhakehi udāna pāḷiyam na saṅgītanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: So it should be regarded as not included in the Collection of Threads by those who compile the Collection of Threads.

original: Udānapāḷiyaṃ pana aṭṭhasu vaggesu dasa dasa katvā asītiyeva suttantā saṅgītā. Tathā
analyzed: udānapāḷiyam pana aṭṭhasu vaggesu dasa dasa katvā asītiyā iva suttantā saṅgītā tathā
translated: But in the Collection of Threads itself eighty threads are compiled, ten in each of the eight sections.

original: hi tadaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ –
analyzed: hi tat aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam
translated: For this is said in the commentary on it:🔽“Eighty threads in all,

original: “Asītiyeva suttantā, vaggā aṭṭha samāsato”ti..
analyzed: asītiyā iva suttantāḥ vaggāḥ aṭṭha samāsato ti
translated: In eight sections, in brief” .

original: Idha pana “dveasīti suttantā”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ udānapāḷiyā na sameti, tasmā “asīti suttantā”ti
analyzed: idha pana dve asi iti suttantā ati vuttam tam udāna pāḷiyā na sameti tasmai asi iti suttantā ati
translated: But here it is said, “two hundred and eighty threads,” which does not agree with the Collection of Threads. So the reading should be “eighty threads.”

original: pāṭhena bhavitabbaṃ. Apica na kevalaṃ idheva, atha kho aññāsupi vinayābhidhammaṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: pāṭhena bhavitabbam apica na kevalam idha iva atha kho aññāsu pi vinaya abhidhamma ṭṭhakathāsu
translated: Moreover, not only here, but also in the Vinaya and Abhidhamma commentaries,

original: tathāyeva vuttattā “appakaṃ pana ūnamadhikaṃ vā gaṇanūpagaṃ na hotī”ti pariyāyena
analyzed: tathāya iva vutta ttā appakam pana ūnam adhikam vā gaṇana upagam na hoti iti pariyāyena
translated: it is said in the same way. So it is in a sense not counted as a small or extra number.

original: anekaṃsena vuttaṃ siyā. Yathā vā tathā vā anumānena gaṇanameva hi tattha tattha ūnādhikasaṅkhyā,
analyzed: anekaṃsena vuttam siyā yathā vā tathā vā anumānena gaṇanam eva hi tattha tattha ūna adhika saṅkhyā
translated: and it is said in many ways. Or else, they say, the number of the words is less or more according to the way in which they are counted by inference.

original: itarathā tāyeva na siyuntipi vadanti, pacchā pamādalekhavacanaṃ vā etaṃ.
analyzed: itarathā vadanti pacchā pamāda lekha vacanam vai etam
translated: Otherwise it would not be so. Or else, this is a statement of the measure of the words afterwards.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatātiādinayappavattāti ettha ādisaddena “vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā,
analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā ati ādi naya ppavattā ti ettha ādi saddena vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: As to the words “This was said by the Blessed One,” etc., the word “etc.” includes the collection of twelve hundred and fifty suttas stated in the form of single, double, triple, and quadruple sets,

original: vuttamarahatāti me sutaṃ. Ekadhammaṃ bhikkhave, pajahatha, ahaṃ vo pāṭibhogo anāgāmitāya.
analyzed: vuttam arahatā ati me sutam eka dhammam bhikkhave pajahatha aham vaḥ pāṭibhogaḥ anāgāmi tāya
translated: beginning thus: “Bhikkhus, abandon one thing and I guarantee you non-return.

original: Katamaṃ ekadhammaṃ? Lobhaṃ bhikkhave, ekadhammaṃ pajahatha, ahaṃ vo pāṭibhogo anāgāmitāyā”ti🔽evamādinā ekadukatikacatukkanipātavasena vuttaṃ dvādasuttarasatasuttasamūhaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Tathā hi itivuttakapāḷiyameva udānagāthāhi dvādasuttarasatasuttāni gaṇetvā saṅgītāni,
analyzed: katamam eka dhammam lobham bhikkhave eka dhammam pajahatha aham vaḥ pāṭibhogaḥ anāgāmi tāya ati  evamādinā eka duka tika catukka nipāta vasena vuttam dvādaśa uttara sata sutta samūham saṅgaṇhāti  tathā hi itivuttaka pāḷiyam eva udāna gāthāhi dvādaśa uttara sata suttāni gaṇetvā saṅgītāni
translated: What one thing? Greed. Bhikkhus, abandon greed and I guarantee you non-return” .🔽For the hundred and fifty suttas of the twelve hundred and fifty are counted and included in the Udana verses in the Itivuttaka itself,

original: tadaṭṭhakathāyampi tathāyeva vuttaṃ. Tasmā “dvādasuttarasatasuttantā” icceva pāṭhena
analyzed: tat aṭṭhakathā ayam pi tathāyā iva vuttam tasmā dvādaśa uttara sata suttantāḥ icca iva pāṭhena
translated: and the commentary on that text states it in the same way. Therefore the reading should be “twelve hundred and fifty suttas” .

original: bhavitabbaṃ, yathāvuttanayena vā anekaṃsato vuttantipi vattuṃ sakkā, tathāpi īdise
analyzed: bhavitabbam yathā vutta nayena vā anekaṃsatas vutta nti pi vattum sakkā tathā api īdise
translated: Or else it can be said that it is of many kinds in the way already stated.

original: ṭhāne pamāṇaṃ dassentena yāthāvatova niyametvā dassetabbanti “dasuttarasatasuttantā”ti
analyzed: ṭhāne pamāṇam dassentena yāthāvatā iva niyametvā dassetabbanti
translated: Nevertheless, when a measure is being given in such a place, it should be given by defining it exactly. So they say that the words “one hundred and ten suttas”

original: idaṃ pacchā pamādalekhamevāti gahetabbanti vadanti. Iti evaṃ bhagavatā vuttaṃ itivuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam pacchā pamāda lekham eva ati gahetabbanti vadanti iti evam bhagavatā vuttam itivuttam
translated: are a later addition, a scribal error. Thus it is said by the Blessed One, thus it is said:

original: Itivuttanti saṅgītaṃ itivuttakaṃ. Ruḷhināmaṃ vā etaṃ yathā “yevāpanakaṃ, natumhākavaggo”ti,
analyzed: itivuttam ti saṅgītam itivuttakam ruḷhi nāmam vā etam yathā yevāpanakam
translated: Thus it is said. It is recited as “Thus it was said.” It is called “The Collection of Thus-Said Judgments” .

original: vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā, vuttamarahatāti me sutanti nidānavacanena saṅgītaṃ yathāvuttasuttasamūhaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā ati me sutam iti nidāna vacanena saṅgītam yathā vutta sutta samūham
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, heard by me, thus it is recited: thus the collection of the above-mentioned suttas is recited by means of the words of the nidana.

original: Jātaṃ bhūtaṃ purāvutthaṃ bhagavato pubbacaritaṃ kāyati katheti pakāseti etenāti jātakaṃ,
analyzed: jātam bhūtam purāvuttham bhagavataḥ pubba caritam kāyati katheti pakāseti etena ati jātakam
translated: The Jataka is that by which the Blessed One’s former conduct, which was born, which came to be, which was formerly told, is made known, is made to appear.

original: taṃ pana imānīti dassetuṃ “apaṇṇakajātakādīnī”tiādimāha. Tattha “paññāsādhikāni pañcajātakasatānī”ti
analyzed: tam pana imāni iti dassetum apaṇṇaka jātaka ādīni iti ādim āha tattha paññāsādhikāni pañca jātaka satāni iti
translated: But in order to show that it is this, he says “The Jataka beginning with the Apaṇṇaka,” etc. Herein, “five hundred and fifty Jatakas”

original: idaṃ appakaṃ pana ūnamadhikaṃ vā gaṇanūpagaṃ na hotīti katvā anekaṃsena, vohārasukhatāmattena
analyzed: idam appakam pana ūnam adhikam vā na hoti iti katvā aneka aṃsena vohāra sukha tā mattena
translated: But since this is a small number, and it is not possible to count it as less or more, it is said in the plural, for the sake of convenience of expression.

original: ca vuttaṃ. Ekaṃsato hi sattacattālīsādhikāniyeva yathāvuttagaṇanato tīhi ūnattā.
analyzed: ca vuttam ekaṃsataḥ hi yathā vutta gaṇanataḥ tīhi ūna ttā
translated: For in the strict sense there are only forty-seven hundred, since the number given falls short of the stated total by three.

original: Tathā hi ekanipāte paññāsasataṃ, dukanipāte sataṃ, tikanipāte paññāsa, tathā catukkanipāte,
analyzed: tathā hi eka nipāte paññāsa satam duka nipāte satam tika nipāte paññāsa tathā catukka nipāte
translated: For in the Ekakanipāta there are five hundred and fifty; in the Dukanipāta there are one hundred; in the Tikanipāta there are fifty; likewise in the Catukkanipāta;

original: pañcakanipāte pañcavīsa, chakkanipāte vīsa, sattanipāte ekavīsa, aṭṭhanipāte dasa,
analyzed: pañcaka nipāte pañcavīsa chakka nipāte vīsa satta nipāte ekavīsa aṭṭha nipāte dasa
translated: in the Pañcakanipāta there are twenty-five; in the Chakkanipāta there are twenty; in the Sattakanipāta there are twenty-one; in the Aṭṭhakanipāta there are ten;

original: navanipāte dvādasa, dasanipāte soḷasa, ekādasanipāte nava, dvādasanipāte dasa, tathā
analyzed: nava nipāte dvādasa dasa nipāte soḷasaḥ ekādasa nipāte nava dvādasa nipāte dasa tathā
translated: in the Navakanipāta there are twelve; in the Dasa- nipāta there are sixteen; in the Ekādasakanipāta there are nine; in the Dvādasakanipāta there are ten; likewise

original: terasanipāte, pakiṇṇakanipāte terasa, vīsatinipāte cuddasa, tiṃsanipāte dasa, cattālīsanipāte
analyzed: terasa nipāte pakiṇṇaka nipāte terasa vīsati nipāte cuddasa tiṃsa nipāte dasa cattālīsa nipāte
translated: in the Terasanipāta; in the Pakiṇṇakanipāta there are thirteen; in the Vīsatinipāta there are fourteen; in the Tiṁsanipāta there are ten; in the Cattālīsanipāta

original: pañca, paṇṇāsanipāte tīṇi, saṭṭhinipāte dve, tathā sattatinipāte, asītinipāte pañca,
analyzed: pañca paṇṇāsa nipāte tīṇi saṭṭhi nipāte dve tathā sattati nipāte asīti nipāte pañca
translated: there are five; in the Paṇṇāsanipāta there are three; in the Saṭṭhinipāta there are two; likewise in the Sattatinipāta; in the Asītinipāta there are five;

original: mahānipāte dasāti sattacattālīsādhikāneva pañca jātakasatāni saṅgītānīti.
analyzed: mahānipāte pañca jātaka satāni saṅgītāni iti
translated: in the Mahānipāta there are ten. Thus the total is only forty-seven hundred jātakas.

original: Abbhuto dhammo sabhāvo vutto yatthāti abbhutadhammaṃ, taṃ panidanti āha “cattārome”tiādi. Ādisaddena cettha –
analyzed: abbhutaḥ dhammaḥ sabhāvaḥ vuttaḥ yattha ati abbhuta dhammam tam āha cattāro mā itiādi ādi saddena ca ittha
translated: And here the word “etc.” includes the following:

original: “Cattārome bhikkhave, acchariyā abbhutā dhammā ānande. Katame cattāro? Sace bhikkhave,
analyzed: cattāro me bhikkhave acchariyāḥ abbhutāḥ dhammāḥ ānande katame cattāro sace bhikkhave
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four wonderful and marvellous things about Ananda. What four?

original: bhikkhuparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanenapi sā attamanā hoti. Tatra
analyzed: bhikkhu parisā ānandam dassanāya upasaṅkamati dassanena api sā attamanā hoti tatra
translated: If, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu-assembly goes to see Ananda, it is satisfied with just seeing him.

original: ce ānando, dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti, atittāva bhikkhave bhikkhuparisā
analyzed: ce ānandaḥ dhammam bhāsati bhāsitena api sā attamanā hoti atittā ava bhikkhave bhikkhu parisā
translated: If, having seen him, it hears dhamma from him, it is satisfied with hearing dhamma from him. The bhikkhu-assembly is never satisfied with seeing and hearing dhamma from Ananda.

original: hoti, atha ānando tuṇhī bhavati. Sace bhikkhave, bhikkhunīparisā…pe… upāsakaparisā…pe…
analyzed: hoti atha ānandaḥ tuṇhī bhavati sace bhikkhave bhikkhunī parisāpe upāsaka parisāpe
translated: If, bhikkhus, a bhikkhunī-assembly … a male lay-follower’s assembly … a female lay-follower’s assembly goes to see Ananda, it is satisfied with just seeing him.🔽If, having seen him, it hears dhamma from him, it is satisfied with hearing dhamma from him. The female lay-follower’s assembly is never satisfied with seeing and hearing dhamma from Ananda.

original: upāsikā – parisā…pe… tuṇhī bhavati. Ime kho bhikkhave…pe… ānande”ti –
analyzed: upāsikā parisāpe tuṇhī bhavati ime kho bhikkhave pe ānandeti
translated: These are the four wonderful and marvellous things about Ananda” .

original: Evamādinayappavattaṃ tattha tattha bhāsitaṃ sabbampi acchariyabbhutadhammapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ suttantaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: evamādi naya ppavattam tattha tattha bhāsitam sabbam api acchariya bbhuta dhamma paṭisaṃyuttam suttantam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: All the suttas in the various places that occur in this way and that deal with the wonderful and marvellous Dhamma are included here.

original: Cūḷavedallādīsu visākhena nāma upāsakena puṭṭhāya dhammadinnāya nāma bhikkhuniyā
analyzed: cūḷa vedalla ādīsu visākhena nāma upāsakena puṭṭhāya dhammadinnāya nāma bhikkhuniyā
translated: In the Cūḷavedalla and so on, the nun Dhammadinnā was asked by a lay devotee named Visākha,

original: bhāsitaṃ suttaṃ cūḷavedallaṃ nāma. Mahākoṭṭhikattherena pucchitena āyasmatā sāriputtattherena
analyzed: bhāsitam suttam cūḷavedallam nāma mahākoṭṭhika ttherena pucchitena āyasmatā sāriputta ttherena
translated: and what she said is called the Cūḷavedalla. The elder Mahā Koṭṭhita asked the venerable Sāriputta,

original: bhāsitaṃ mahāvedallaṃ nāma. Sammādiṭṭhisuttampi bhikkhūhi puṭṭhena teneva bhāsitaṃ,
analyzed: bhāsitam mahāvedallam nāma sammādiṭṭhi suttam pi bhikkhūhi puṭṭhena tena iva bhāsitam
translated: and what he said is called the Mahāvedalla. The Sammādiṭṭhi Sutta was also asked by bhikkhus and was spoken by him.

original: etāni majjhimanikāyapariyāpannāni. Sakkapañhaṃ pana sakkena puṭṭho bhagavā abhāsi,🔽taṃ dīghanikāyapariyāpannaṃ. Mahāpuṇṇamasuttaṃ pana tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇamāya
analyzed: etāni majjhima nikāya pariyāpannāni sakka pañham pana sakkena puṭṭhaḥ bhagavā abhāsi  tam dīgha nikāya pariyāpannam mahāpuṇṇama suttam pana tad ahuposathe pannarase puṇṇamāya
translated: These are included in the Majjhima Nikāya. The Sakkapañha was spoken by the Blessed One when asked by Sakka,🔽and it is included in the Dīgha Nikāya. The Mahāpuṇṇamāsa Sutta was spoken by the Blessed One when asked on the full-moon day of the Uposatha by a certain bhikkhu,

original: rattiyā aññatarena bhikkhunā puṭṭhena bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ, taṃ majjhimanikāyapariyāpannaṃ.
analyzed: rattiyā aññatarena bhikkhunā puṭṭhena bhagavatā bhāsitam tat majjhima nikāya pariyāpannam
translated: and it is included in the Majjhima Nikāya.

original: Evamādayo sabbepi tattha tatthāgatā vedañca tuṭṭhiñca laddhā laddhā pucchitasuttantā
analyzed: evamādayo sabbe pi tattha tatthāgatāḥ vedam ca tuṭṭhim ca laddhā laddhā pucchita suttantā
translated: In this way, all the suttas asked and answered here and there, having attained knowledge and confidence,

original: “vedalla”nti veditabbaṃ. Vedanti ñāṇaṃ. Tuṭṭhinti yathābhāsitadhammadesanaṃ viditvā
analyzed: vedallanti veditabbam vedanti ñāṇam tuṭṭhinti yathā bhāsita dhamma desanam viditvā
translated: should be understood as “vedalla.” “Ved” means knowledge. “Tuṭṭhi” means confidence.

original: “sādhu ayye sādhāvuso”tiādinā abbhanumodanavasappavattaṃ pītisomanassaṃ. Laddhā laddhāti
analyzed: sādhu ayye sādhu avuso ti ādinā pīti somanassam laddhā laddhā iti
translated: “Excellent, Lady, excellent, friend,” etc., is the happiness and gladness that arise with the approval of the recitation. “Having gained, having gained” means

original: labhitvā labhitvā, punappunaṃ labhitvāti vuttaṃ hoti, etena vedasaddo ñāṇe, somanasse
analyzed: labhitvā labhitvā punappunam labhitvā iti vuttam hoti etena veda saddaḥ ñāṇe somanasse
translated: having received, having received, having received again and again. By this he shows that the word “veda” occurs in the sense of knowledge and in the sense of happiness

original: ca ekasesanayena, sāmaññaniddesena vā pavattati, vedamhi nissitaṃ tassa labhāpanavasenāti
analyzed: ca eka sesa nayena sāmañña niddesena vā pavattati vedamhi nissitam tassa labhāpana vasena ati
translated: and gladness, either by the method of a part for the whole or by the method of the cause being substituted for the result, and that it is based on the Vedas because of the gaining of the Vedas.

original: vedallanti ca dasseti.
analyzed: ca dassa iti
translated: Thus he shows that “vedalla” means “having gained the Vedas.”

original: Evaṃ aṅgavasena sakalampi buddhavacanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni dhammakkhandhavasena vibhajitukāmo
analyzed: evam aṅga vasena sakalam pi buddha vacanam vibhajitvā idāni dhammakkhandha vasena vibhajitu kāmaḥ
translated: Having thus divided the entire word of the Buddha by way of its component parts, the Master now wishes to divide it by way of the baskets of the Teaching.

original: “katha”ntiādimāha. Tattha dhammakkhandhavasenāti dhammarāsivasena. “Dvāsītī”ti ayaṃ
analyzed: katham ti ādim āha tattha dhamma kkhandha vasena ati dhamma rāsi vasena ayaṃ
translated: Therefore he says, “How many are the baskets of the Teaching?” etc. Herein, by way of the baskets of the Teaching means by way of the three baskets of the Teaching. “There are eighty-two” means

original: gāthā vuttatthāva. Evaṃ paridīpitadhammakkhandhavasenāti gopakamoggallānena nāma
analyzed: evam paridīpita dhamma kkhandha vasena ati gopakamoggallānena nāma
translated: the meaning of this verse is already explained. Thus by way of the baskets of the Teaching that have been demonstrated means that the Elder Mahā Kassapa,

original: brāhmaṇena puṭṭhena gopakamoggallānasutte attano guṇappakāsanatthaṃ vā theragāthāyaṃ

analyzed: gāthāyaḥ vuccamānassa hi vuttassa vā atthassa vippakiṇṇa bhāvena pavattitum a datvā  uddham dānam rakkhaṇam udānam saṅgaha vacanan ti attho sīla kkhandha vagga mūla pariyāya vagga ādi vasena
translated: The verses. For when the meaning of what is being said or has been said occurs in a scattered way,🔽the compilers of the Dhamma, not allowing it to occur in a scattered way, collected it together and recited it, and that is why it is called an uddāna. The meaning is a collection of words. The “Compendium of Vaggas” is the placing by the compilers of the Dhamma in the following way, namely, by way of the Vaggas beginning with the Sīlakkhandha Vagga, the Mūlapariyāya Vagga, and so on.

original: vaggasaṅgaho. Vaggoti hi dhammasaṅgāhakeheva katā suttasamudāyassa samaññā. Uttarimanussapeyyālanīlapeyyālādivasena
analyzed: vagga saṅgahaḥ vaggaḥ ti hi dhamma saṅgāhakehi iva katā sutta samudāyassa samaññā uttari manussa peyyāla nīla peyyāla ādi vasena
translated: For “vagga” is a name for a collection of suttas made by the compilers of the Dhamma. The “Compendium of Suttas” is the placing by the compilers of the Dhamma in the following way, namely, by way of the suttas beginning with the Uttaramanussadhamma Sutta, the Nīla Sutta, and so on.

original: peyyālasaṅgaho. Pātuṃ rakkhituṃ, vitthārituṃ vā alanti hi peyyālaṃ, saṅkhipitvā dassanavacanaṃ.
analyzed: peyyāla saṅgahaḥ pātum rakkhitum vitthāritum vā alanti hi peyyālam saṅkhipitvā dassana vacanam
translated: The summary of the peyyālas is this. The peyyāla is a contraction of the words “to protect, to guard, to extend.”

original: Aṅguttaranikāyādīsu nipātasaṅgaho, gāthaṅgādivasena nipātanaṃ. Samudāyakaraṇañhi
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya ādīsu nipāta saṅgahaḥ gāthaṅga ādi vasena nipātanam samudāya karaṇam hi
translated: The summary of the nipātas in the Aṅguttara Nikāya, etc., is this. The nipāta is a collection of suttas arranged according to the number of factors, etc.

original: nipāto. Devatāsaṃyuttādivasena saṃyuttasaṅgaho. Vaggasamudāye eva dhammasaṅgāhakehi🔽katā saṃyuttasamaññā. Mūlapaṇṇāsakādivasena paṇṇāsasaṅgaho, paññāsa paññāsa suttāni
analyzed: nipātaḥ devatā saṃyutta ādi vasena saṃyutta saṅgahaḥ vagga samudāye eva dhamma saṅgāhakehi  katā saṃyutta samaññā mūla paṇṇāsaka ādi vasena paṇṇāsa saṅgaho paññāsa paññāsa suttāni
translated: For the nipāta is a collection of suttas. The summary of the saṃyuttas is this. The saṃyutta is a collection of suttas connected by a common topic, such as the deities, etc.🔽The saṃyutta is so called because the suttas are collected together by the compilers of the canon under a single heading. The summary of the paṇṇāsas is this. The paṇṇāsa is a collection of fifty suttas.🔽The paṇṇāsa is so called because it is a collection of fifty suttas. The word “etc.” includes the summaries of the vaggas, etc.

original: gaṇetvā saṅgahoti vuttaṃ hoti. Ādisaddena tassaṃ tassaṃ pāḷiyaṃ dissamānaṃ saṅgītikārakavacanaṃ
analyzed: gaṇetvā saṅgahaḥ ti vuttam hoti ādi saddena tassam tassam pāḷiyam dissamānam saṅgīti kāraka vacanam
translated: The summary of the udānas is this. The udāna is a collection of the Buddha’s inspired utterances.🔽The summary of the avadānas is this. The avadāna is a collection of the Buddha’s discourses on the results of kamma.🔽The summary of the jātakas is this. The jātaka is a collection of the Buddha’s discourses on his own previous births.🔽The summary of the vedallas is this. The vedalla is a collection of discourses on the various aspects of the Dhamma.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Udānasaṅgaha…pe… paṇṇāsasaṅgahādīhi anekavidhaṃ tathā. Sattahi māsehīti🔽kiriyāpavagge tatiyā “ekāheneva bārāṇasiṃ pāyāsi. Navahi māsehi vihāraṃ niṭṭhāpesī”tiādīsu
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti udāna saṅgaha pe paṇṇāsa saṅgaha ādīhi anekavidham tathā sattahi māsehi iti  kiriyā pavagge tatiyā eka ahena iva bārāṇasim pāyāsi navahi māsehi vihāram niṭṭhāpesi itiādīsu
translated: The summary of the vaṇṇas is this. The vaṇṇa is a collection of discourses on the various aspects of the Dhamma.

original: viya. Kiriyāya āsuṃ pariniṭṭhāpanañhi kiriyāpavaggo.
analyzed: viya kiriyāya āsum pariniṭṭhāpanam hi kiriyā pavaggo
translated: The summary of the kirayas is this. The kiraya is a collection of discourses on the various aspects of the Dhamma.

original: Tadā anekacchariyapātubhāvadassanena sādhūnaṃ pasādajananatthamāha “saṅgītipariyosāne🔽cassā”tiādi. Assa buddhavacanassa saṅgītipariyosāne sañjātappamodā viya, sādhukāraṃ
analyzed: tadā sādhūnam pasāda janana attham āha saṅgīti pariyosāne  cassa ati ādi assa buddha vacanassa saṅgīti pariyosāne sañjāta ppamodā viya sādhukāram
translated: Then, in order to generate confidence in the good people by showing the manifestation of many psychic powers, he said “At the conclusion of the recitation of the Dhamma,” etc.🔽At the conclusion of the recitation of the Buddha’s word, the Elder Mahinda was delighted and glad, just like the Elder Ānanda, who was delighted and glad at the conclusion of the recitation of the Dhamma by the Elder Mahākassapa.

original: dadamānā viya ca saṅkampi…pe… pāturahesunti sambandho. Viyāti hi ubhayattha yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: dadamānā viya ca saṅkampipe pāturahesunti sambandhaḥ viya iti hi ubhayattha yojetabbam
translated: Then, in order to generate confidence in the good people by showing the manifestation of many psychic powers, he said “At the conclusion of the recitation of the Dhamma,” etc. At the conclusion of the recitation of the Buddha’s word, the earth shook, as if it were filled with joy and delight, as if it were applauding. The construction is: “It shook, etc., and manifested itself.” The word “as if” should be construed with both clauses.

original: Pavattane, pavattanāya vā samatthaṃ pavattanasamatthaṃ. Udakapariyantanti pathavīsandhārakaudakapariyosānaṃ
analyzed: pavattane pavattanāya vā samattham pavattana samattham udaka pariyantanti pathavī sandhāraka odaka pariyosānam
translated: Capable of shaking, or capable of being shaken, is “shakable.” As far as the water that supports the earth, is “to the edge of the water.”

original: katvā, saha tena udakena, taṃ vā udakaṃ āhaccāti vuttaṃ hoti, tena ekadesakampanaṃ🔽nivāreti. Saṅkampīti uddhaṃ uddhaṃ gacchantī suṭṭhu kampi. Sampakampīti uddhamadho
analyzed: katvā saha tena udakena tam vā udakam āhacca ati vuttam hoti tena eka desa kampanam  nivāreti saṅkampīti uddham uddham gacchantī suṭṭhu kampi sampakampīti uddham adhas
translated: With that water, or that water, is what is meant by “together with.” This excludes the shaking of a part of the earth.

original: ca gacchantī sammā pakārena kampi. Sampavedhīti catūsu disāsu gacchantī suṭṭhu bhiyyo
analyzed: ca gacchantī sammā pakārena kampi sampavedhi iti catūsu disāsu gacchantī suṭṭhu bhiyyas
translated: It shook, moving up and down, is “it shook well.” It shook all around, moving up and down and sideways, is “it shook all around well.” It shook thoroughly, moving in the four directions, is “it shook thoroughly.”

original: pavedhi. Evaṃ etena padattayena chappakāraṃ pathavīcalanaṃ dasseti. Atha vā puratthimato,🔽pacchimato ca unnamanaonamanavasena saṅkampi. Uttarato, dakkhiṇato ca unnamanaonamanavasena
analyzed: evam etena padattayena cha pakāram pathavī calanam dasseti atha vā puratthimatas  pacchimatas ca unnamana onamana vasena saṅkampi uttaratas dakkhiṇatas ca unnamana onamana vasena
translated: and it shook. Thus he shows the quaking in six ways by means of these three terms. Or alternatively, it quivered by rising and sinking in the east and west,🔽it trembled by rising and sinking in the north and south,

original: sampakampi. Majjhimato, pariyantato ca unnamanaonamanavasena sampavedhi. Evampi chappakāraṃ

analyzed: puratthimatas unnamati pacchimatas onamati pacchimatas unnamati puratthimatas onamati  uttaratas unnamati dakkhiṇatas onamati dakkhiṇatas unnamati uttaratas onamati majjhimataḥ
translated: “It rose in the east and sank in the west, it rose in the west and sank in the east,

analyzed: ayam paṭhama mahāsaṅgī iti nāma ati sambandho  evam paṭhama mahāsaṅgī iti dassetvā yadattham sā idha dassitā idāni tam nidānam nigamana vasena

original: ekasesavasena padapadaviggahāpi padavibhāgasaddena vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Padaviggahato
analyzed: ekasesa vasena pada pada viggahā api pada vibhāga saddena vuttā iti daṭṭhabbam pada viggahato
translated: But the analysis of the words and the analysis of the words should be regarded as stated by the word analysis of the words by the method of single and multiple occurrence.

original: pana “bhikkhūnaṃ saṅgho”tiādinā upari saṃvaṇṇanaṃ karissati, tathā padatthānuyogaparihārehipi.
analyzed: pana bhikkhūnam saṅgha uti ādinā upari saṃvaṇṇanam karissati tathā padattha anuyoga parihārehi pi
translated: But the commentary above will be given by way of the analysis of the words beginning with “the Community of bhikkhus” and so on, and likewise by way of the avoidance of the application of the word-meaning.

original: Evanti ettha luttaniddiṭṭhaiti-saddo ādiattho antarāsadda ca saddādīnampi saṅgahitattā,🔽nayaggahaṇena vā te gahitā. Tenāha “metiādīni nāmapadānī”ti. Itarathā hi antarāsaddaṃ
analyzed: evam ti ettha ādi atthaḥ ca sadda ādīnam pi saṅgahita ttā  vā te gahitā tena āha mā iti ādīni nāma padāni iti itarathā hi
translated: Herein, the word eva, which is a demonstrative pronoun, has the meaning of “beginning with,” and the word and so on includes sounds and so on.🔽Or they are included by the word nay. Therefore he says “meti and so on are nominal bases.” For otherwise the state of being a prefix would have to be stated for the word and so on,

original: ca saddādīnampi nipātabhāvo vattabbo siyā. Metiādīnīti ettha pana ādi-saddena yāva
analyzed: ca sadda ādīnam pi nipāta bhāvaḥ vattabbaḥ siyā mā iti ādīni iti ettha pana ādi saddena yāva
translated: which is a demonstrative pronoun. Meti and so on. Herein, by the word and so on as far as

original: paṭisaddo, tāva tadavasiṭṭhāyeva saddā saṅgahitā. Paṭīti upasaggapadaṃ patisaddassa kāriyabhāvato.
analyzed: paṭi saddaḥ tāva tad avasiṭṭhāya iva saddā saṅgahitā paṭi iti upasagga padam pati saddassa kāriya bhāvato
translated: the word paṭi is included. Paṭi is a prefix word because it has the function of a prefix.

original: Idāni atthuddhārakkamena padatthato saṃvaṇṇanaṃ karonto “atthato panā”tiādimāha. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne sotūnaṃ saṃvaṇṇanānayakosallatthaṃ saṃvaṇṇanāppakārā vattabbā. Kathaṃ?
analyzed: idāni attha uddhāra kkamena padatthato saṃvaṇṇanam karontaḥ atthataḥ pana ati ādim āha imasmin pana ṭhāne sotūnam saṃvaṇṇanā anaya kosalla attham saṃvaṇṇanā appakārā vattabbā katham
translated: The commentary is said to be threefold:

original: Ekanāḷikā kathā ca, caturassā tathāpi ca;🔽Nisinnavattikā ceva, tidhā saṃvaṇṇanaṃ vade.🔽Tattha pāḷiṃ vatvā ekekapadassa atthakathanaṃ ekāya nāḷiyā minitasadisattā, ekekaṃ
analyzed: eka nāḷikā kathā ca catur assā tathā api ca  nisinnavattikā ca iva tidhā saṃvaṇṇanam vade  tattha pāḷim vatvā ekeka padassa attha kathanam ekāya nāḷiyā ekekam
translated: The commentary by way of one reed, and likewise by way of four corners,🔽And by way of the sitting mat.🔽Herein, the commentary by way of one reed is so called because the explanation of the meaning of each word is like a reed cut from one end,

original: vā padaṃ nāḷaṃ mūlaṃ, ekamekaṃ padaṃ vā nāḷikā atthaniggamanamaggo etissāti katvā🔽ekanāḷikā nāma. Paṭipakkhaṃ dassetvā, paṭipakkhassa ca upamaṃ dassetvā, sapakkhaṃ
analyzed: vā padam nāḷam mūlam ekam ekam padam vā nāḷikā attha niggamana maggaḥ etissa ati katvā  ekanāḷikā nāma paṭipakkham dassetvā paṭipakkhassa ca upamam dassetvā sa pakkham
translated: or because each word is a reed, a root, and each word is a passage for the meaning to come out, thus it is called by way of one reed.

original: dassetvā, sapakkhassa ca upamaṃ dassetvā, kathanaṃ catūhi bhāgehi vuttattā, cattāro
analyzed: dassetvā sa pakkhassa ca upamam dassetvā kathanam catūhi bhāgehi vutta ttā cattāro
translated: The commentary by way of four corners is so called because the explanation is made by way of the four parts, namely, by showing the opposite, by showing the simile for the opposite, by showing the like,

original: vā rassā sallakkhaṇūpāyā etissāti katvā caturassā nāma, visabhāgadhammavaseneva pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: vā rassā sallakkhaṇa upāyā etissa ati katvā caturassā nāma visabhāga dhamma vasena iva pariyosānam
translated: and by showing the simile for the like, or because the four corners, the means of discerning, are stated, thus it is called by way of four corners.🔽The commentary by way of the sitting mat is so called because the explanation is made by way of the conclusion by means of the method of the dissimilar dhamma.

original: gantvā puna sabhāgadhammavaseneva pariyosānagamanaṃ nisīdāpetvā patiṭṭhāpetvā āvattanayuttattā,
analyzed: gantvā puna sabhāga dhamma vasena iva pariyosāna gamanam nisīdāpetvā patiṭṭhāpetvā āvattana yutta ttā
translated: and after going he makes them sit down again in order to conclude in the same way as before, and he establishes them, and he does so because it is proper to do so,

original: niyamato vā nisinnassa āraddhassa vatto saṃvatto etissāti katvā nisinnavattikā nāma,🔽yathāraddhassa atthassa visuṃ visuṃ pariyosānāpi niyuttāti vuttaṃ hoti, sodāharaṇā
analyzed: niyamataḥ vā nisinnassa āraddhassa vatto saṃvatto etissa ati katvā nisinnavattikā nāma  yathā āraddhassa atthassa visum visum pariyosānā api niyuttā ati vuttam hoti sa udāharaṇā
translated: or else because the duty that has been begun by one who is sitting is a duty that is being done, and that is why it is called the duty while sitting,

original: pana kathā aṅguttaraṭṭhakathāya taṭṭīkāyaṃ ekādasanipāte gopālakasuttavaṇṇanāto gahetabbā.
analyzed: pana kathā aṅguttara ṭṭhakathāya tad ṭīkāyam ekādasa nipāte gopālaka sutta vaṇṇanāto gahetabbā
translated: and what is meant is that the conclusion of the meaning begun is proper to each section. The story with the simile can be understood from the commentary on the Ekādasanipāta in the Commentary on the Minor Books, in the commentary on the Gopālaka Sutta.

original: Bhedakathā tatvakathā, pariyāyakathāpi ca;
analyzed: bheda kathā tatva kathā pariyāya kathā api ca
translated: The analysis, the explanation, And the synonyms as well,

original: Iti atthakkame vidvā, tidhā saṃvaṇṇanaṃ vade.🔽Tattha pakatiādivicāraṇā bhedakathā yathā “bujjhatīti buddho”tiādi. Sarūpavicāraṇā🔽tatvakathā yathā “buddhoti yo so bhagavā sayambhū anācariyako”tiādi. Vevacanavicāraṇā
analyzed: iti atthakkame vidvā tidhā saṃvaṇṇanam vade  tattha pakati ādi vicāraṇā bheda kathā yathā bujjhati iti buddhaḥ iti ādi sarūpa vicāraṇā  tatva kathā yathā buddha iti saḥ bhagavā sayambhu vevacana vicāraṇā
translated: Thus, when the meaning is divided, The wise man should state the commentary in three ways.🔽Herein, the analysis is the consideration of the ordinary meaning, etc., as in the case of the word “awakened” in the word “Buddha.”🔽The explanation is the consideration of the meaning as it really is, as in the case of the word “Buddha” in the passage beginning, “The one who is called ‘Buddha,’ he is the Blessed One, the Self-Awakened One, the One Without a Peer” .

original: pariyāyakathā yathā “buddho bhagavā sabbaññū lokanāyako”tiādi.
analyzed: pariyāya kathā yathā buddhaḥ bhagavā sabbaññū loka nāyakaḥ iti ādi
translated: The synonyms are the consideration of the various synonyms, as in the case of the word “Buddha” in the passage beginning, “Buddha, Blessed One, Omniscient One, Leader of the World” .

original: Payojanañca piṇḍattho, anusandhi ca codanā;
analyzed: payojanam ca anusandhi ca codanā
translated: The purpose, the summary, the sequence, the questioning,

original: Parihāro ca sabbattha, pañcadhā vaṇṇanaṃ vade.🔽Tattha payojanaṃ nāma desanāphalaṃ, taṃ pana sutamayañāṇādi. Piṇḍattho nāma vippakiṇṇassa🔽atthassa suvijānanatthaṃ sampiṇḍetvā kathanaṃ. Anusandhi nāma pucchānusandhādi. Codanā
analyzed: parihāro ca sabbattha pañcadhā vaṇṇanam vade  tattha payojanam nāma desanā phalam tam pana suta maya ñāṇa ādi piṇḍatthaḥ nāma vippakiṇṇassa  atthassa su vijānana attham sampiṇḍetvā kathanam anusandhi nāma puccha anusandhā ādi codanā
translated: The reply, and everywhere the explanation: these are the fivefold explanation.🔽Herein, the purpose is the fruit of the teaching, which is knowledge consisting in what is heard, etc. The summary is the telling in brief for the purpose of easy memorizing of the meaning that is scattered through the various parts of the text. The sequence is the order. The questioning is the asking of questions. The reply is the answering of the questions.

original: nāma yathāvuttassa vacanassa virodhikathanaṃ. Parihāro nāma tassa avirodhikathanaṃ.
analyzed: nāma yathāvuttassa vacanassa virodhi kathanam parihāraḥ nāma tassa avirodhi kathanam
translated: The explanation is the answering of the questions.

original: Ummugghāto padañceva, padattho padaviggaho;
analyzed: ummugghātaḥ padañca iva padatthaḥ padaviggahaḥ
translated: The source, the word, the meaning, the analysis of the word,

original: Cālanā paccupaṭṭhānaṃ, chadhā saṃvaṇṇanaṃ vade. ;
analyzed: cālanā paccupaṭṭhānam chadhā saṃvaṇṇanam vade
translated: The questioning, the reply, the explanation: these are the sixfold explanation.

original: Tattha ajjhattikādinidānaṃ ummugghāto. “Evamida”nti nānāvidhena padavisesatākathanaṃ🔽padaṃ, saddatthādhippāyatthādi padattho. Anekadhā nibbacanaṃ padaviggaho. Cālanā
analyzed: tattha ajjhattika ādi nidānam ummugghātaḥ evam idam ti nānāvidhena pada visesa tā kathanam  padam saddattha adhippāya ttha ādi padatthaḥ anekadhā nibbacanam pada viggahaḥ cālanā
translated: Herein, the source is the source in oneself, etc., “Thus this was said” . The word is the telling in various ways of the different kinds of words,

original: nāma codanā. Paccupaṭṭhānaṃ parihāro.
analyzed: nāma codanā paccupaṭṭhānam parihāro
translated: The meaning is the meaning of the word, the meaning of the expression, etc. The analysis of the word is the analysis into many kinds. The questioning is the questioning. The reply is the answering of the questions.

original: Samuṭṭhānaṃ padattho ca, bhāvānuvādavidhayo;
analyzed: samuṭṭhānam ca bhāva anuvāda vidhayaḥ
translated: The source, the meaning, the word, the mode of being, the mode of expression,

original: Virodho parihāro ca, nigamananti aṭṭhadhā.
analyzed: virodho parihāro ca nigamanan ti aṭṭhadhā
translated: Contradiction, reply, and conclusion: thus the commentary is eightfold.

original: Tattha samuṭṭhānanti ajjhattikādinidānaṃ. Padatthoti adhippetānadhippetādivasena
analyzed: tattha samuṭṭhānam ti ajjhattika ādi nidānam padattho ti adhippeta anadhippeta ādi vasena
translated: Herein, origin is the source, which is internal, etc.,🔽The meaning of a word is manifold, according as it is intended or not intended, etc.,

original: anekadhā padassa attho. Bhāvoti adhippāyo. Anuvādavidhayoti paṭhamavacanaṃ vidhi,
analyzed: anekadhā padassa atthaḥ bhāvaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ anuvāda vidhayaḥ ti paṭhama vacanam vidhi
translated: The intention is the purport. The injunction and the reiteration are as follows:

original: tadāvikaraṇavasena pacchā vacanaṃ anuvādo, visesanavisesyānaṃ vā vidhānuvāda samaññā.
analyzed: pacchā vacanam anuvādaḥ vā vidhā anuvāda samaññā
translated: The first statement is the injunction, and the subsequent statement is the reiteration, which is a mode of the injunction, or else the injunction and the reiteration are the names for the specific and the general.

original: Virodhoti atthanicchayanatthaṃ codanā. Parihāroti tassā sodhanā. Nigamananti anusandhiyā anurūpaṃ appanā.
analyzed: virodhaḥ ti attha nicchaya nattham codanā parihāro ti tassā sodhanā nigamanam ti anusandhiyā anurūpam appanā
translated: Contradiction is the challenge for the purpose of showing the meaning to be unintended. Reply is the clearing up of that. Conclusion is the application in conformity with the connection.

original: Ādito tassa nidānaṃ, vattabbaṃ tappayojanaṃ;
analyzed: āditas tassa nidānam vattabbam tad payojanam
translated: The source should be stated at the beginning,

original: Piṇḍattho ceva padattho, sambandho adhippāyako;
analyzed: piṇḍa attho ca iva pada attho sambandhaḥ adhippāyako
translated: The purpose, the word meaning, the connection, the purport,

original: Codanā sodhanā ceti, aṭṭhadhā vaṇṇanaṃ vade.
analyzed: codanā sodhanā ca iti aṭṭhadhā vaṇṇanam vade
translated: The challenge, and the reply: thus the commentary is said to be eightfold.

original: Tattha sambandho nāma pubbāparasambandho, yo “anusandhī”ti vuccati. Sesā vuttatthāva, evamādinā tattha tatthāgate saṃvaṇṇanāppakāre ñatvā sabbattha yathārahaṃ vicetabbāti.🔽Evamanekatthappabhedatā payogatova ñātabbāti tabbasena taṃ samatthetuṃ “tathā hesā”tiādi
analyzed: tattha sambandhaḥ nāma pubba apara sambandhaḥ yaḥ anusandhi iti vuccati sesāḥ evamādinā tattha tatthāgate saṃvaṇṇanā appakāre ñatvā sabbattha yathāraham vicetabbā ati  evam aneka attha ppabheda tā payogataḥ va ñātabbā ati tad basena tam samatthetum tathā ha isā atiādi
translated: Herein, the connection is the connection of what precedes and follows, which is called “sequence.” The rest is as already stated. So when he has understood the method of commentating in each instance beginning with this, he should investigate in each instance as is fitting.

original: vuttaṃ. Atha vā ayaṃ saddo imassatthassa vācakoti saṅketavavatthitāyeva saddā taṃ🔽tadatthassa vācakā, saṅketo ca nāma payogavasena siddhoti dassetumpi idaṃ vuttanti
analyzed: vuttam atha vā ayam saddo imassa atthassa vācakaḥ iti saṅketa vavatthitāya iva saddā tam  tad atthassa vācakā saṅketo ca nāma payoga vasena siddho ti dassetum pi idam vuttan ti
translated: So the various meanings are to be understood as to phrasing too. In order to demonstrate that, this is said beginning with “For this is how it is said” . Or else, the words “This word is a name for this meaning” are established by convention. The words are🔽the announcers of that and that meaning. And the convention is established by the use. In order to show this, this is said. So it should be regarded.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evamīdisesu. Nanu ca –🔽“Yathāpi puppharāsimhā, kayirā mālāguṇe bahū;
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam evam īdisesu nanu ca  yathā api mālā guṇe
translated: In such passages as this,

original: Evaṃ jātena maccena, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ bahu”nti. ;
analyzed: evam jātena maccena kattabbam kusalam bahunti
translated: “As from a flower’s parts a skilled man makes A garland, so the wise man, born into this world, Should make a garland of this life’s flowers” ,

original: Ettha evaṃ-saddena upamākārasseva vuttattā ākāratthoyeva evaṃ-saddo siyāti? Na, visesasabbhāvato.
analyzed: ettha evaṃsaddena upamā ākārassa iva vuttattā ākāra atthaḥ yā iva evaṃsaddaḥ siyā iti na visesa sabbhāvato
translated: is the word eva used in the sense of manner because the word eva is said to be a manner of speaking? No, because of the difference.

original: “Evaṃ byā kho”tiādīsu hi ākāramattavācakoyeva ākāratthoti adhippeto, na pana ākāravisesavācako.
analyzed: evam khaḥ iti ādīsu hi ākāra matta vācakaḥ yā iva ākāra atthaḥ ti adhippetaḥ na pana ākāra visesa vācakaḥ
translated: In the passage “Evaṃ byā kho” , etc., the word evaṃ is intended to convey the mere mode , not the particular mode .

original: Ettha hi kiñcāpi puppharāsisadisato manussūpapatti sappurisūpanissaya saddhammasavana
analyzed: ettha hi kiñcā api puppha rāsi sadisataḥ manussu upapatti sappurisu upanissaya saddhamma savana
translated: Here, although the rebirth of a human being is like a heap of flowers, the dependence on a good person, the hearing of the true Dhamma,

original: yonisomanasikārabhogasampattiādidānādipuññakiriyāhetusamudāyato sobhāsugandhatādiguṇayogena
analyzed: yoni so manasikāra bhoga sampatti ādi dāna ādi puñña kiriyā hetu samudāyataḥ sobhā sugandha tā ādi guṇa yogena
translated: the attainment of the requisites of wise attention and enjoyment, etc., the collection of causes such as the performance of meritorious deeds such as giving, etc., the possession of such qualities as beauty, fragrance, etc.,

original: mālāguṇasadisiyo bahukā puññakiriyā maritabbasabhāvatāya maccena sattena kattabbāti
analyzed: mālā guṇa sadisiyaḥ bahukā puñña kiriyāḥ maritabba sabhāva tāya maccena sattena kattabbā ati
translated: the many meritorious deeds which are like the qualities of a garland, should be done by a person who is about to die,

original: atthassa jotitattā puppharāsimālāguṇāva upamā nāma upamīyati etāyāti katvā, tesaṃ🔽upamākāro ca yathāsaddena aniyamato jotito, tasmā “evaṃ-saddo niyamato upamākāranigamanattho”ti
analyzed: atthassa jotita ttā upamā nāma upamīyati katvā tesam  upamā ākāraḥ ca yathā saddena aniyamataḥ jotitaḥ tasmai evaṃsaddaḥ niyamataḥ upamā kāra nigamana ttho ti
translated: because the meaning is illuminated, like a heap of flowers and the qualities of a garland, it is called a simile, because it is compared by this .🔽And the mode of the simile is indicated by the word yathā in an unrestricted way. Therefore it is proper to say: “The word evaṃ is the meaning of the conclusion of the mode of the simile in a restricted way.”

original: vattuṃ yuttaṃ, tathāpi so upamākāro niyamiyamāno atthato upamāva hoti nissayabhūtaṃ
analyzed: vattum yuttam tathā api saḥ upamā kāraḥ niyamiyamānaḥ atthataḥ upamā ava hoti nissaya bhūtam
translated: However, when that mode of the simile is restricted, it becomes a simile in meaning, which is the basis.

original: tamantarena nissitabhūtassa upamākārassa alabbhamānattāti adhippāyenāha “upamāyaṃ
analyzed: tam antarena nissita bhūtassa upamā kārassa a labbha māna ttā ati adhippāyena āha upamā ayam
translated: and the simile is not found in the sense of a simile that is dependent on that. It is with this intention that he says ‘in the simile’ .

original: āgato”ti. Atha vā upamīyanaṃ sadisīkaraṇanti katvā puppharāsimālāguṇehi sadisabhāvasaṅkhāto🔽upamākāroyeva upamā nāma. “Saddhammattaṃ siyopamā”ti hi vuttaṃ, tasmā ākāramattavācakova
analyzed: āgataḥ iti atha vā upamīyanam sadisīkaraṇam ti katvā puppha rāsi mālā guṇehi sadisa bhāva saṅkhātaḥ  upamā ākāroyā iva upamā nāma saddhamma ttam siyā upamā iti hi vuttam tasmai ākāra matta vācakaḥ uva
translated: Or alternatively, since a simile is a making similar , the simile itself, called ‘the mode of similarity’, which is the state of being similar to the flower-bed, garland, and creeper,🔽is called ‘simile’. For it is said, ‘A simile is a mode of similarity’ . So the word evaṃ is a mere mode-word,

original: ākārattho evaṃ-saddo. Upamāsaṅkhātaākāravisesavācako pana upamātthoyevāti vuttaṃ “upamāyaṃ āgato”ti.
analyzed: ākāra atthaḥ evaṃsaddaḥ upamā saṅkhāta ākāra visesa vācakaḥ pana upamā tthaḥ yeva ati vuttam upamāyam āgataḥ ti
translated: and the meaning of the word evaṃ is a mode only. But the word upamā is a word that signifies a mode called ‘simile’. That is why he says ‘in the simile’ .

original: Tathā “evaṃ iminā ākārena abhikkamitabba”ntiādinā upadisiyamānāya samaṇasāruppāya
analyzed: tathā evam iminā ākārena abhikkamitabba nti ādinā upadisiyamānāya samaṇa sāruppāya
translated: Similarly, when the mode of the right way of life is being taught thus, ‘In this way the going forth should be gone forth to’ ,

original: ākappasampattiyā upadisanākāropi atthato upadesoyevāti āha “evaṃ…pe… upadese”ti.
analyzed: ākappa sampattiyāḥ upadisana ākāraḥ api atthataḥ upadesaḥ yā iva ati āha upadese iti
translated: the mode of teaching is also, in fact, the teaching. That is why he says ‘in the teaching’ .

original: Evametanti ettha pana bhagavatā yathāvuttamatthaṃ aviparītato jānantehi kataṃ tattha
analyzed: evam etat ti ettha pana bhagavatā yathā vuttam attham aviparītataḥ jānantehi katam tattha
translated: As to the words in this way: when those who know the meaning stated thus by the Blessed One do it without perverting it,

original: saṃvijjamānaguṇānaṃ pakārehi haṃsanaṃ udaggatākaraṇaṃ sampahaṃsanaṃ. Tattha sampahaṃsanākāropi🔽atthato sampahaṃsanamevāti vuttaṃ “sampahaṃsaneti. Evameva panāyanti ettha ca dosavibhāvanena
analyzed: saṃvijjamāna guṇānam pakārehi haṃsanam udaggatā karaṇam sampahaṃsanam tattha sampahaṃsana ākāraḥ api  atthato sampahaṃsanam evā ti vuttam sampahaṃsana iti evam eva pana āyanti ettha ca dosa vibhāvanena
translated: The act of extolling is the act of praising.🔽The act of extolling is the act of praising.

translated: “So it is, Lord,” means “good, Lord,” “well, Lord.” Herein, “good” is a term for what is proper.

original: savanamanasikāre sanniyojitehi bhikkhūhi tattha attano ṭhitabhāvassa paṭijānanameva🔽vacanasampaṭiggaho, tadākāropi atthato vacanasampaṭiggahoyeva nāma, tenāha “vacanasampaṭiggahe”ti.

translated: The grammarians say that the word viya is a substitute for the words va and kāra, and that it is formed by the addition of ya to the compound va-kāra.

translated: As to the words “wonderful,” etc., they say that “wonderful” is so because it removes opposition, because it removes defilements such as lust.

original: vadanti. Bhagavato pana paṭipakkhā rāgādayo na santi, ye haritabbā bodhimūleyeva
analyzed: vadanti bhagavataḥ pana paṭipakkhāḥ rāga ādayaḥ na santi ye haritabbāḥ bodhi mūleya iva
translated: But the Blessed One has no opposition, namely, lust, etc., to be removed, since he has abandoned all defilements together with their traces at the root of the Bodhi Tree.

original: savāsanasakalasaṃkilesānaṃ pahīnattā. Puthujjanānampi ca vigatūpakkilese aṭṭhaguṇasamannāgate
analyzed: sa vāsana sakala saṃkilesānam pahīna ttā puthujjanānam pi ca vigata upakkilese aṭṭha guṇa samannāgate
translated: And it is wonderful in the sense of being endowed with the eight noble qualities, which are free from the ten imperfections.

original: citte hatapaṭipakkhe satiyeva iddhividhaṃ pavattati, tasmā puthujjanesu pavattavohārenapi🔽na sakkā idha “pāṭihāriya”nti vattuṃ, sace pana mahākāruṇikassa bhagavato veneyyagatāva🔽kilesā paṭipakkhā saṃsārapaṅkanimuggassa sattanikāyassa samuddharitukāmato, tasmā
analyzed: citte hata paṭipakkhe satiyā iva iddhividham pavattati tasmā puthujjanesu pavatta vohārena api  na sakkāḥ idha vattum sace pana mahā kāruṇikassa bhagavataḥ  kilesā paṭipakkhā saṃsāra paṅka nimuggassa satta nikāyassa samuddharitu kāmataḥ tasmā
translated: And the various kinds of supernormal power occur only when there is the destruction of the opposite qualities in the mind. So it cannot be called a “miracle” in the ordinary sense of the word, which occurs in ordinary men.🔽But if the Blessed One, the Greatly Compassionate One, is called “miraculous” because he removes the opposite qualities in the form of defilements in those who are his disciples, because he is desirous of rescuing the multitude of beings who are sunk in the mud of the round of rebirths,

original: tesaṃ veneyyagatakilesasaṅkhātānaṃ paṭipakkhānaṃ haraṇato pāṭihāriyanti vuttaṃ assa,
analyzed: tesam veneyya gata kilesa saṅkhātānam paṭipakkhānam haraṇataḥ pāṭihāriyanti vuttam assa
translated: then it is proper to call him “miraculous” because he removes the opposite qualities in the form of defilements in those who are his disciples.

original: evaṃ sati yuttametaṃ.
analyzed: evam sati yuttam etam
translated: And that being so, it is proper to call him “miraculous.”

original: Atha vā bhagavato sāsanassa paṭipakkhā titthiyā, tesaṃ titthiyabhūtānaṃ paṭipakkhānaṃ🔽haraṇato pāṭihāriyantipi yujjati. Kāmañcettha titthiyā haritabbā nāssu, tesaṃ pana
analyzed: atha vā bhagavataḥ sāsanassa paṭipakkhāḥ titthiyāḥ tesam titthiya bhūtānam paṭipakkhānam  haraṇataḥ yujjati kāmam ca ittha titthiyāḥ haritabbāḥ na assu tesam pana
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed One’s opponents are the sectarians, and he is called “miraculous” because he removes the opponents in the form of sectarians.🔽But although the sectarians need not be removed, still the teaching of the view in their disciples and the teaching of the miracle of supernormal power, etc.,

original: santānagatadiṭṭhiharaṇavasena diṭṭhippakāsane asamatthatākāraṇena ca iddhiādesanānusāsanīsaṅkhātehi
analyzed: santāna gata diṭṭhi haraṇa vasena diṭṭhi ppakāsane asamattha tā kāraṇena ca iddhi ādesanā anusāsanī saṅkhātehi
translated: are called “miraculous” because they are the cause of the removal of the view in their disciples and because they are the cause of the incapacity of the sectarians to teach a doctrine of such a kind.

original: tīhipi pāṭihāriyehi te haritā apanītā nāma honti. Paṭīti vā ayaṃ saddo “pacchā”ti
analyzed: tīhi pi pāṭihāriyehi te haritāḥ apanītāḥ nāma honti vā ayam saddo
translated: They are called “removed” by the three kinds of miracle. The word “miracle” is a name for the fourth jhāna.🔽It is a name for the fourth jhāna because it is the state of being “miraculously” ,

original: etassa atthaṃ bodheti “tasmiṃ paṭipaviṭṭhamhi, añño āgañchi brāhmaṇo”tiādīsu viya,
analyzed: etassa attham bodheti tasmin paṭipaviṭṭhamhi aññaḥ āgañchi brāhmaṇa uti ādīsu viya
translated: like the words “after” and “before” in such passages as “When he had entered there, another brahmin came” .

original: tasmā samāhite citte vigatūpaklese katakiccena pacchā haritabbaṃ pavattetabbanti
analyzed: tasmā samāhite citte vigata upaklese kata kiccena pacchā haritabbam pavattetabbam ti
translated: So when the mind is concentrated without defilements, having done the task, it is “miraculously” removed and made to occur again.

original: paṭihāriyaṃ, tadeva dīghavasena, sakatthavuttipaccayavasena vā pāṭihāriyaṃ, attano
analyzed: paṭihāriyam tat eva dīgha vasena sa katthavutti paccaya vasena vā pāṭihāriyam attano
translated: That is a miracle. It is a miracle in the sense of being “miraculously” removed and made to occur again after being removed, or in the sense of being a state of “miraculous” occurrence.

original: vā upaklesesu catutthajjhānamaggehi haritesu pacchā tadaññesaṃ haraṇaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ🔽vuttanayena. Iddhiādesanānusāsaniyo hi vigatūpaklesena, katakiccena ca sattahitatthaṃ
analyzed: vā upaklesesu catuttha jhāna maggehi haritesu pacchā tad aññesam haraṇam pāṭihāriyam  vutta nayena iddhi ādesanā anusāsaniyaḥ hi vigata upaklesena kata kiccena ca satta hita attham
translated: Or alternatively, when the defilements that are its own are removed by the path of the fourth jhāna, it is “miraculously” removed and made to occur again afterwards.🔽It is a miracle in the sense of being “miraculously” removed and made to occur again in the way already described.🔽For the demonstration of psychic power, the reading of minds, and the giving of advice are to be made to occur again for the benefit of others by one who is without defilements and has done the task.

original: puna pavattetabbā, hatesu ca attano upaklesesu parasattānaṃ upaklesaharaṇāni ca hontīti
analyzed: puna pavattetabbā hatesu ca attanaḥ upaklesesu para sattānam upaklesa haraṇāni ca honti iti
translated: And when the defilements that are his own are removed, they are also the removal of the defilements of other beings.

original: tadubhayampi nibbacanaṃ yujjati.
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi nibbacanam yujjati
translated: So the description of both is appropriate.

original: Apica yathāvuttehi nibbacanehi iddhiādesanānusāsanīsaṅkhāto samudāyo paṭihāriyaṃ
analyzed: apica yathā vuttehi nibbacanehi iddhi ādesanā anusāsanī saṅkhātaḥ samudāyaḥ
translated: Moreover, the collection called “the demonstration of psychic power, the reading of minds, and the giving of advice” is a miracle in the sense of the description already given.

original: nāma. Ekekaṃ pana tasmiṃ bhavaṃ “pāṭihāriya”nti vuccati visesatthajotakapaccayantarena
analyzed: nāma ekekam pana tasmim bhavam pāṭihāriyanti vuccati visesa attha jotaka paccaya antarena
translated: But each of these is called a “miracle” because it is a cause for showing a special meaning by a special arrangement of sounds.

original: saddaracanāvisesasambhavato, paṭihāriyaṃ vā catutthajjhānaṃ, maggo ca paṭipakkhaharaṇato,
analyzed: sadda racanā visesa sambhavataḥ paṭihāriyam vā catuttha jhānam maggo ca paṭipakkha haraṇato
translated: Or alternatively, the fourth jhāna is a miracle because it removes opposition, and the path is a miracle because it removes opposition;

original: tattha jātaṃ, tasmiṃ vā nimittabhūte, tato vā āgatanti pāṭihāriyaṃ. Vicitrā hi taddhitavutti.
analyzed: tattha jātam tasmin vā nimitta bhūte tatas vā pāṭihāriyam vicitrā hi tad hita vutti
translated: and what is born there, or what is the sign of that, or what comes from that, is a miracle. For the usage of the verbal suffix is various.

original: Tassa pana iddhiādesanānusāsanībhedena, visayabhedena ca bahuvidhassa bhagavato desanāya
analyzed: tassa pana iddhi ādesanā anusāsanī bhedena visaya bhedena ca bahuvidhassa bhagavataḥ desanāya
translated: But since the Blessed One’s teaching is of many kinds, being divided into exhortation, instruction, and so on, and into the three Piṭakas,

original: labbhamānattā “vividhapāṭihāriyanti vuttaṃ. Bhagavā hi kadāci iddhivasenāpi desanaṃ🔽karoti nimmitabuddhena saha pucchāvissajjanādīsu, kadāci ādesanāvasenāpi āmagandhabrāhmaṇassa
analyzed: labbha māna ttā vividha pāṭihāriyanti vuttam bhagavā hi kadāci iddhi vasena api desanam  karoti nimmita buddhena saha pucchā vissajjana ādīsu kadāci ādesanā vasena api āmagandha brāhmaṇassa
translated: it is said to be “of various miracles.” For the Blessed One sometimes teaches by means of supernormal power, as in the case of the questions and answers with the created Buddha,🔽sometimes by means of exhortation, as in the case of the teaching of the Dhamma to the brahmin Aggikabhāradvāja,

original: dhammadesanādīsu, yebhuyyena pana anusāsaniyā. Anusāsanīpāṭihāriyañhi buddhānaṃ satataṃ
analyzed: dhamma desanā ādīsu yebhuyyena pana anusāsaniyā anusāsanī pāṭihāriyam hi buddhānam satatam
translated: and sometimes by means of instruction. For the miracle of instruction is always present to the Buddhas.

original: dhammadesanā. Iti taṃtaṃdesanākārena anekavidhapāṭihāriyatā desanāya labbhati. Ayamattho🔽upari ekādasamassa kevaṭṭasuttassa vaṇṇanāya āvi bhavissati. Atha vā tassa vividhassāpi
analyzed: dhamma desanā iti taṃ taṃ desanā ākārena anekavidha pāṭihāriya tā desanāya labbhati ayam attho  upari ekādasamassa kevaṭṭa suttassa vaṇṇanāya bhavissati atha vā tassa vividhassa api
translated: The Teaching is of many kinds of wonders by way of the various kinds of teaching. This meaning will become clear above in the commentary on the eleventh sutta, the Kevatta Sutta. Or else, although that variety is manifold,🔽

original: pāṭihāriyassa bhagavato desanāya saṃsūcanato “vividhapāṭihāriya”nti vuttaṃ, anekavidhapāṭihāriyadassananti attho.
