translated: “Not only the Blessed One, but also others.” And here, because of possessing such qualities,🔽

original: bhavituṃ yuttopi esa parinibbuto evāti pakaraṇānurūpamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “eva”ntiādi🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Āsā patthanā kena janetabbā, na janetabbā evāti attho. “Ahaṃ
analyzed: bhavitum yuttaḥ api esa parinibbutaḥ evā ti pakaraṇa anurūpam attham dassetum eva ntiādi  vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam āsā patthanā kena janetabbā na janetabbā eva ati atthaḥ aham
translated: “Not only the Blessed One, but also others.” And here the meaning in accordance with the text should be regarded as stated thus: “Because he possesses such and such special qualities, he is fit to be one who has not attained final Nibbāna, and yet he is one who has attained final Nibbāna.” The words “eva” , etc., are stated in order to show this meaning.

original: ciraṃ jīviṃ, ciraṃ jīvāmi, ciraṃ jīvissāmi, sukhaṃ jīviṃ, sukhaṃ jīvāmi, sukhaṃ jīvissāmī”ti
analyzed: ciram jīvim ciram jīvāmi ciram jīvissāmi sukham jīvim sukham jīvāmi sukham jīvissāmi iti
translated: The hope, the wish, by whom should it be generated? The meaning is, it should not be generated. “I have lived long, I am living long, I shall live long; I have lived happily, I am living happily, I shall live happily” —

original: majjanavasena uppanno māno jīvitamado nāma, tena matto pamatto tathā. Saṃvejetīti
analyzed: majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ jīvita madaḥ nāma tena mattaḥ pamattaḥ tathā saṃvejeti iti
translated: the conceit that arises by way of immersion is called intoxication with life. Intoxicated with that, heedless, he does not become anxious.

original: saṃvegaṃ janeti, tatoyeva assa janassa saddhamme ussāhaṃ janeti. Saṃvejanañhi ussāhahetu
analyzed: saṃvegam janeti tatas yā iva assa janassa saddhamme ussāham janeti saṃvejanam hi ussāha hetu
translated: “Anxious” means generating anxiety. From that, too, he generates enthusiasm for the true Dhamma in the people. For anxiety is the cause of enthusiasm,

original: “saṃviggo yoniso padahatī”ti vacanato.
analyzed: saṃviggaḥ yonisaḥ padahati iti vacanataḥ
translated: since it is said: “One who is anxious investigates with wisdom” .

original: Desanāsampattiṃ niddisati vakkhamānassa sakalasuttassa “eva”nti nidassanato. Sāvakasampattinti
analyzed: desanā sampattim niddisati vakkhamānassa sakala suttassa evam ti nidassanataḥ sāvaka sampattim ti
translated: He shows the excellence of the teaching, since the entire sutta is indicated by the word “eva” . The excellence of the disciple is shown by the words “the bhikkhu who has aroused energy.”

original: suṇantapuggalasampattiṃ niddisati paṭisambhidāppattena pañcasu ṭhānesu bhagavatā
analyzed: suṇanta puggala sampattim niddisati paṭisambhidā appattena pañcasu ṭhānesu bhagavatā
translated: He shows the excellence of the hearer in the words “heard by me” . The Blessed One has placed him at the head of those who have penetrated the analytical knowledges,

original: etadagge ṭhapitena, pañcasu ca kosallesu āyasmatā dhammasenāpatinā pasaṃsitena mayā
analyzed: etad agge ṭhapitena pañcasu ca kosallesu āyasmatā dhammasenāpatinā pasaṃsitena mayā
translated: and he has been praised by the venerable Dhamma-sena-pati in the five hundred Paṇḍita verses:🔽“What was heard by me, a great disciple,

original: mahāsāvakena sutaṃ, tañca kho sayameva sutaṃ na anussutaṃ, na ca paramparābhatanti🔽atthassa dīpanato. Kālasampattiṃ niddisati bhagavātisadasannidhāne payuttassa samayasaddassa
analyzed: mahāsāvakena sutam tat ca kho sayam eva sutam na anussutam na ca  atthassa dīpanataḥ kāla sampattim niddisati bhagavā ati sada sannidhāne payuttassa samaya saddassa
translated: is not what was heard by another, nor what was heard by hearsay, but what was heard by myself.”🔽He shows the excellence of the time in the words “heard by me” . The word “time” , which is used in the sense of “opportunity” ,

original: buddhuppāda-paṭimaṇḍita-samaya-bhāva-dīpanato. Buddhuppādaparamā hi kālasampadā. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: buddhuppāda paṭimaṇḍita samaya bhāva dīpanataḥ buddhuppāda paramā hi kāla sampadā tena itam vuccati
translated: shows that the time was made fruitful by the arising of the Buddha. For the excellence of the time is at its height when the Buddha has arisen. Therefore it is said:

original: “Kappakasāyakaliyuge, buddhuppādo aho mahacchariyaṃ;
analyzed: kappa kasāya kali yuge buddhuppādaḥ aho mahat śariyam
translated: “In the age of strife, the arising of the Buddha is a great gain;

original: Hutavahamajjhe jātaṃ, samuditamakarandamaravinda”nti. ;
analyzed: hutavaha majjhe jātam samudita makarandam aravindanti
translated: Born in the midst of the sacrifice of the oblation, the honey-sweet lotus has blossomed.”

original: Tassāyamattho – kappasaṅkhātakālasañcayassa lekhanavasena pavatte kaliyugasaṅkhāte
analyzed: tassa ayam atthaḥ kappa saṅkhāta kāla sañcayassa lekhana vasena pavatte kali yuga saṅkhāte
translated: The meaning is this: In the age called “the age of strife” , which occurs by way of the writing down of the age called “the age of accumulation” ,

original: sakarājasammate vassādisamūhe jāto buddhuppādakhaṇasaṅkhāto dinasamūho andhassa pabbatārohanamiva🔽kadāci pavattanaṭṭhena, accharaṃ paharituṃ yuttaṭṭhena ca mahacchariyaṃ hoti. Kimiva
analyzed: saka rāja sammate vassa ādi samūhe jātaḥ buddhuppāda khaṇa saṅkhātaḥ dina samūhaḥ andhassa pabbata ārohanam iva  kadāci pavattana ṭṭhena accharam paharitum yutta ṭṭhena ca mahat śariyam hoti kim iva
translated: The time of the Buddha’s appearance, called the “occasion,” is like the time of the blind man’s climbing the mountain.🔽It is “great” in the sense of occurring only occasionally and in the sense of being worthy of being struck with palms in applause.

original: jātanti ce? Hutavahasaṅkhātassa pāvakassa majjhe sammā uditamadhumantaṃ aravindasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: jātanti ce hutavaha saṅkhātassa pāvakassa majjhe sammā udita madhumantam aravinda saṅkhātam
translated: “What is it like?” It is like a lotus called “aravinda” which is well-risen and full of honey in the middle of the fire called “hutavaha” .

original: vārijamiva jātanti. Desakasampattiṃ niddisati guṇavisiṭṭhasattuttamagāravādhivacanato.🔽Evaṃ padachakkassa padānukkamena nānappakārato atthavaṇṇanaṃ katvā idāni “antarā🔽ca rājagaha”ntiādīnaṃ padānamatthavaṇṇanaṃ karonto “antarā cā”tiādimāha. Antarā ca
analyzed: vāri jam iva desaka sampattim niddisati guṇa visiṭṭha sattu ttama gārava adhivacanato  evam pada chakkassa pada anukkamena nānā pakārataḥ attha vaṇṇanam katvā idāni antarā  ca rājagahanti ādīnam padānam attha vaṇṇanam karontaḥ antarā ca ati ādim āha antarā ca
translated: The speaker’s excellence is shown by the word “uttama,” which means “excellent,” and by the word “agaru,” which means “great respect.”🔽Having thus explained the meaning of the words in various ways according to the sequence of the words in the stanza, he now explains the meaning of the words “antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandā” , etc., by saying “antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandā” , etc. The word “antarā” is seen to be used in the sense of “between”

original: rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandanti ettha samabhiniviṭṭho antarā-saddo dissati sāmaññavacanīyatthamapekkhitvā
analyzed: rājagaham antarā ca na āḷandanti ettha samabhiniviṭṭhaḥ antarā saddaḥ dissati sāmaññavacanīya ttham apekkhitvā
translated: in the expression “antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandā” .

original: pakaraṇādisāmatthiyādigatatthamantarenāti attho. Evaṃ panassa nānatthabhāvo payogato
analyzed: pakaraṇa ādi sāmatthiya ādi gata ttham antarena ati atthaḥ evam panassa nānattha bhāvaḥ payogato
translated: the meaning of the words in the text, etc., and the meaning of the words in the commentary, etc.🔽The meaning of the words in the text, etc., and the meaning of the words in the commentary, etc., are different in application.

original: avagamīyatīti dasseti “tadantara”ntiādinā. Tattha tadantaranti taṃ kāraṇaṃ. Mañca
analyzed: avagamīyati iti tad antaranti ādinā tattha tad antaranti tam kāraṇam
translated: the meaning of the words is dependent on the meaning of the expression, etc. He shows how its diversity is understood by usage: “Tadantara” , etc. Herein, tadantara means that reason.

original: tañca mantenti, kimantaraṃ kiṃ kāraṇanti attho. Vijjantarikāyāti vijjuniccharaṇakkhaṇe.🔽Dhovantī itthī addasāti sambandho. Antaratoti hadaye. Kopāti cittakālussiyakaraṇato
analyzed: tat ca mantenti kim antaram kim kāraṇam ti atthaḥ vijjantarikāya ati vijju niccharaṇa khaṇe  dhovantī itthī addasā ati sambandhaḥ antarataḥ ti hadaye kopā ti
translated: Or they chant it, what is the reason? What is the meaning? Vijjantarikāya means at the moment of the flash of lightning.🔽The connection is: “The woman was washing, she saw” . Antarato means in the heart. Kopā means anger.

original: cittapakopā rāgādayo. Antarā vosānanti ārambhanipphattīnaṃ vemajjhe pariyosānaṃ āpādi.
analyzed: citta pakopāḥ rāga ādayaḥ antarā vosānanti ārambha nipphattīnam vemajjhe pariyosānam āpādi
translated: The defilements such as lust are the disturbance of the mind because they cause the mind to be disturbed. Vosāna means the end.

original: Apicāti tathāpi, evaṃ pabhavasampannepīti attho. Dvinnaṃ mahānirayānanti lohakumbhīniraye
analyzed: api ca iti tathā api evam lohakumbhīniraye
translated: Apicā means although thus, although it has such an origin, the meaning is. Dvinnaṃ mahānirayānanti means in the two great hells.🔽He says this referring to the hell of the iron cauldron. Antarikāya means in between.

original: sandhāyāha. Antarikāyāti antarena. Rājagahanagaraṃ kira āvijjhitvā mahāpetaloko.
analyzed: sandhāya āha antarikāya iti antarena rājagaha nagaram kira āvijjhitvā
translated: It is said that the great river of embers crossed the city of Rājagaha.

original: Tattha dvinnaṃ mahālohakumbhīnirayānaṃ antarena ayaṃ tapodā nadī āgacchati, tasmā
analyzed: tattha dvinnam mahālohakumbhīnirayānam antarena ayam tapodā nadī āgacchati tasmai
translated: There, between the two great hells of the iron cauldrons, this river Tapodā comes.

original: sā kuthitā sandatīti. Svāyamidha vivare pavattati tadaññesamasambhavato. Ettha ca🔽“tadantaraṃ ko jāneyya, etesaṃ antarā kappā, gaṇanāto asaṅkhiyā, antarantarā kathaṃ
analyzed: sā kuthitā sandati iti vivare pavattati ettha ca  tad antaram kaḥ jāneyya etesam antarā kappāḥ gaṇanātaḥ asaṅkhiyāḥ antar antarā katham
translated: and it is split and cleaved.

original: opātetī”tiādīsu viya kāraṇavemajjhesu vattamānā antarāsaddāyeva udāharitabbā siyuṃ,
analyzed: opāteti itiādīsu viya kāraṇa vemajjhesu vattamānāḥ antarāsaddāya iva udāharitabbā siyum
translated: Herein, the word “interval” should be cited as occurring in the middle of a reason in such passages as “Who could know the intervals between these eons, which are incalculable by reckoning” ,

original: na pana cittakhaṇavivaresu vattamānā antarikaantarasaddā. Antarāsaddassa hi ayamatthuddhāroti.
analyzed: na pana citta khaṇa vivaresu vattamānā antarika antara saddā antarāsaddassa hi ayam attha uddhāraḥ ti
translated: and not as the word “interval” occurring in the intervals of the moments of consciousness. For this is the meaning of the word “interval.”

original: Ayaṃ panetthādhippāyo siyā – yesu atthesu antarikasaddo, antarasaddo ca pavattati,
analyzed: ayam pana itthā adhippāyaḥ siyā yesu atthesu antarika saddaḥ antara saddo ca pavattati
translated: But the intention here may be this: the word “interval” occurs in the same sense as the words “between” and “interval” do in the passages cited.

original: tesu antarāsaddopīti samānatthattā antarāsaddatthe vattamāno antarikasaddo, antarasaddo,
analyzed: tesu antarāsaddaḥ api iti samāna atthattā antarāsadda atthe vattamānaḥ antarika saddo antara saddaḥ
translated: So the word “between” is cited as occurring in the sense of the word “interval” because of the sameness of meaning.

original: ca udāhaṭoti. Atha vā antarāsaddoyeva “yassantarato”ti ettha gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ
analyzed: ca udāhaṭaḥ iti atha vā ettha gāthā bandha sukha ttham
translated: Or alternatively, the word “interval” itself is stated in the verse in the abbreviated form “yassantarato” for the sake of ease in the metrical arrangement.

original: rassaṃ katvā vutto –
analyzed: rassam katvā vuttaḥ
translated: For it is said:

original: “Yassantarato na santi kopā,
analyzed: yaḥ santarataḥ na santi kopā
translated: “In whom there is no anger at all,

original: Itibhavābhavatañca vītivatto;
analyzed: itibhava abhavatan ca vītivatto
translated: Who has passed beyond the becoming of this world and the becoming of the other world,

original: Taṃ vigatabhayaṃ sukhiṃ asokaṃ,
analyzed: tam vigata bhayam sukhim a sokam
translated: He is free from fear, happy, and griefless,

original: Devā nānubhavanti dassanāyā”ti. ; –
analyzed: devāḥ na anubhavanti dassanāya ati
translated: The gods do not get to see him.”

original: Hi ayaṃ udāne bhaddiyasutte gāthā. Soyeva ika-saddena sakatthapavattena padaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: hi ayam udāne bhaddiya sutte gāthā soyā iva ika saddena sa kattha pavattena padam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: This is the verse in the Bhaddiya Sutta of the Udana. It is the same verse, but the word is extended by the word ika, which has the meaning of “like,”

original: “antarikāyā”ti ca vutto, tasmā udāharaṇodāharitabbānamettha virodhābhāvo veditabboti.
analyzed: antarikāya iti ca vuttaḥ tasmai udāharaṇa udāharitabbānam ettha virodha abhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: and is said to be “in the middle.” Therefore, the absence of contradiction between the example and the exemplification should be understood here.

original: Kimatthaṃ atthavisesaniyamo katoti āha “tasmā”tiādi. Nanu cettha upayogavacanameva,
analyzed: kimattham attha visesa niyamaḥ kato ti āha tasmā itiādi nanu ca ittha upayoga vacanam eva
translated: Why is the restriction to a particular meaning made? He says “therefore,” etc. But isn’t the expression of use alone here?

original: atha kasmā sambandhīyattho vutto, sambandhīyatthe vā kasmā upayogavacanaṃ katanti
analyzed: atha kasmai sambandhīya tthaḥ vuttaḥ sambandhīya tthe vā kasmai upayoga vacanam
translated: Then why is the meaning of the related word stated? Or why is the expression of use made in the meaning of the related word?

original: anuyogasambhavato taṃ pariharituṃ “antarāsaddena panā”tiādi vuttaṃ, tena sambandhīyatthe
analyzed: anuyoga sambhavataḥ tam pariharitum antarā saddena pana atiādi vuttam tena sambandhīya tthe
translated: Because the objection is possible, in order to answer it, “But by the middle word,” etc. is said. Therefore, in the meaning of the related word,

original: sāmivacanappasaṅge saddantarayogena laddhamidaṃ upayogavacananti dasseti, na kevalaṃ
analyzed: sāmi vacana ppasaṅge sadda antara yogena laddham idam upayoga vacanan ti dasseti na kevalam
translated: the expression of use is obtained by the connection of the word with the meaning of the master. This is shown. Not only

original: sāsaneva, lokepi evamevidaṃ laddhanti dassento “īdisesu cā”tiādimāha. Visesayogatādassanamukhena
analyzed: sāsanā iva loke pi evam eva idam laddhanti dassentaḥ īdisesu ca ati ādim āha visesa yoga tā dassana mukhena
translated: in the Dispensation, but also in the world, it is obtained in this way. Showing this, he says “in such cases,” etc. By the method of showing the connection with the particular,

original: hi ayamatthopi dassito. Ekenapi antarā-saddena yuttattā dve upayogavacanāni kātabbāni.
analyzed: hi ayam atthaḥ api dassitaḥ ekena api antarāsaddena yutta ttā dve upayogavacanāni kātabbāni
translated: for this meaning is also shown. Because it is connected with the word ‘and’ it is necessary to make two usages.🔽But if there are two connections, what is the point? Because the meaning is accomplished.

original: Dvīhi pana yoge kā kathāti atthassa sijjhanato. Akkharaṃ cintenti liṅgavibhattiyādīhīti
analyzed: dvīhi pana yoge kā kathā iti atthassa sijjhanataḥ akkharam cintenti liṅga vibhattiyā ādīhi iti
translated: They think of the letters, the genders, the case-endings, etc.

original: akkharacintakā, saddavidū. Akkhara-saddena cettha tammūlakāni padādīnipi gahetabbāni.
analyzed: akkhara cintakā sadda vidū akkhara saddena ca ittha tad mūlakāni pada ādīni pi gahetabbāni
translated: They are ‘thinkers of letters’, ‘experts in language’. And here the words ‘letters’ and ‘words’ should be taken as including the roots of those words.

original: Yadipi saddato ekameva yujjanti, atthato pana so dvikkhattuṃ yojetabbo ekassāpi padassa
analyzed: yadi api saddataḥ ekam eva yujjanti atthataḥ pana saḥ dvi kkhattum yojetabbaḥ ekassa api padassa
translated: Although they are connected in one way from the point of view of the words, from the point of view of the meaning they should be connected in two ways,

original: āvuttiyādinayena anekadhā sampajjanatoti dasseti “dutiyapadenapī”tiādinā. Ko pana
analyzed: āvuttiyā ādi nayena anekadhā sampajjanato ti dassa iti dutiya padena pi iti ādinā kaḥ pana
translated: because even one word can be used in many ways by the method of repetition, etc. He shows this with the words ‘and also with the second word’. But what is the

original: doso ayojiteti āha “ayojiyamāne upayogavacanaṃ na pāpuṇātī”ti. Dutiyapadaṃ na pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: dosaḥ a yojitā iti āha upayoga vacanam na pāpuṇāti iti dutiya padam na pāpuṇāti iti
translated: fault if they are not connected? He says ‘if they are not connected, the usage is not complete’. The meaning is that the second word is not complete.

original: attho saddantarayogavasā saddeyeva sāmivacanappasaṅge upayogavibhattiyā icchitattā.
analyzed: attho sadda antara yoga vasā sāmi vacana ppasaṅge upayoga vibhattiyāḥ icchita ttā
translated: Because the case-ending is desired in the word itself when there is a connection with another word, in the case of the word ‘master’.

original: Saddādhikāro hi vibhattipayogo.
analyzed: hi vibhatti payogaḥ
translated: For the usage of the case-ending is in the word.

original: Addhāna-saddo dīghapariyāyoti āha “dīghamagga”nti. Kittāvatā pana so dīgho nāma tadatthabhūtoti
analyzed: addhāna saddaḥ dīgha pariyāyaḥ ti āha dīgha maggam ti kittāvatā pana saḥ dīghaḥ nāma tad attha bhūto ti
translated: The word “distance” has a long meaning, thus he said “long road.” But how far is it that is the meaning of “distance”?

original: codanamapaneti “addhānagamanasamayassa hī”tiādinā. Addhānagamanasamayassa vibhaṅgeti
analyzed: codanam apanā iti addhāna gamana samayassa hi itiādinā addhāna gamana samayassa vibhaṅga iti
translated: He answers that by “the time of going on a journey,” etc. The time of going on a journey is analyzed

original: gaṇabhojanasikkhāpadādīsu addhānagamanasamayasaddassa padabhājanīyabhūte vibhaṅge.
analyzed: gaṇa bhojana sikkhāpada ādīsu addhāna gamana samaya saddassa pada bhājanīya bhūte vibhaṅge
translated: in the analysis of the expression “time of going on a journey” in the Vibhanga section of the training rule on eating in a group, etc.

original: Aḍḍhayojanampi addhānamaggo, pageva taduttari. Aḍḍhameva yojanassa aḍḍhayojanaṃ,
analyzed: aḍḍha yojanam pi addhāna maggaḥ pagā iva tad uttari aḍḍham eva yojanassa aḍḍha yojanam
translated: A road a distance of even half a yojana is a long road, let alone more than that. Half of a yojana is half a yojana,

original: dvigāvutamattaṃ. Idha pana catugāvutappamāṇaṃ yojanameva, tasmā “addhānamaggapaṭipanno”ti vadatīti adhippāyo.🔽Mahantasaddo uttamattho, bahvattho ca idhādhippetoti āha “mahatā”tiādi. Guṇamahattenāti
analyzed: dviga avuta mattam idha pana catuga avuta ppamāṇam yojanam eva tasmai addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ ti vadati iti adhippāyaḥ  mahanta saddo uttama atthaḥ bahu atthaḥ ca idha adhippetaḥ iti āha mahatā atiādi guṇa mahattena ati
translated: just two gavutas. But here the intention is that a yojana is just four gavutas, thus he says “one who is traveling on a long road.”🔽The word “great” is intended here in the sense of “excellent” and in the sense of “many,” thus he said “great” and so on. By the greatness of his qualities

original: appicchatādiguṇamahantabhāvena. Saṅkhyāmahattenāti gaṇanamahantabhāvena. Tadevatthaṃ
analyzed: appicchatā ādi guṇa mahanta bhāvena saṅkhyā mahattena ati gaṇana mahanta bhāvena tat evattham
translated: means by the greatness of his qualities such as fewness of wishes. By the greatness of their number means by the greatness of their quantity. That very meaning

original: samattheti “so hī”tiādinā. So bhikkhusaṅghoti idha āgato tadā parivārabhūto bhikkhusaṅgho.
analyzed: samatthā iti saḥ hi itiādinā saḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti idha āgataḥ tadā parivāra bhūtaḥ bhikkhu saṅgho
translated: “He” is the one who is spoken of in the verse. “The Community of Bhikkhus” is the Community of Bhikkhus that had come there to wait upon him.

original: Mahāti uttamo. Vākyepi hi tamicchanti payogavasā. Appicchatāti nillobhatā saddo cettha
analyzed: mahā ati uttamaḥ vākye pi hi tam icchanti payoga vasāḥ ca ittha
translated: “Great” means “supreme.” For the word is used in the sense of “application” . “Fewness of wishes” is the state of being without greed. The word here

original: sāvaseso, attho pana niravaseso. Na hi “appalobhatāti abhitthavitumarahatī”ti aṭṭhakathāsu🔽vuttaṃ. Majjhimāgamaṭīkākāro pana ācariyadhammapālatthero evamāha “appasaddassa parittapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: sa avasesaḥ attho pana niravasesaḥ na hi appalobha tā ati abhitthavitum arahati iti aṭṭhakathāsu  vuttam majjhima āgama ṭīkākāraḥ pana ācariya dhammapāla ttheraḥ evam āha appa saddassa paritta pariyāyam

original: manasi katvā ‘byañjanaṃ sāvasesaṃ viyā’ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Appasaddo panettha
analyzed: manasi katvā byañjanam sa avasesam viya ati aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam appasaddo pana ittha
translated: But the teacher Dhammapāla, the author of the Majjhima commentary, says as follows: “The expression ‘of fewness of wishes’ is used in the commentary as though it had a remainder, with reference to the brief passage on fewness of wishes. But here

analyzed: abhāva atthaḥ tipi sakkā viññātum itiādīsu viyāti
translated: the word ‘fewness of wishes’ can be understood to have the meaning of ‘absence’ as in such passages as ‘I understand that I have few wishes’ .”

original: mahāti gaṇanāyapi bahu ahosi, “bhikkhusaṅgho”ti padāvatthikantavacanavasena saṃvaṇṇetabbapadassa
analyzed: mahā ati bahu ahosi bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti padāvatthika anta vacana vasena saṃvaṇṇetabba padassa
translated: “Great” means “numerous.” “The Community of Bhikkhus” is a word that is to be analysed as follows:

original: chedanamiva hotīti tadaparāmasitvā “tena bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti puna vākyāvatthikantavacanavasena
analyzed: chedanam iva hoti iti tat a parāmasitvā tena bhikkhu saṅghena ati puna vākya āvatthika anta vacana vasena

original: saṃvaṇṇetabbapadena sadisīkaraṇaṃ. Esā hi saṃvaṇṇanakānaṃ pakati, yadidaṃ vibhattiyānapekkhāvasena
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇetabba padena sadisīkaraṇam esā hi saṃvaṇṇanakānam pakati yat idam vibhattiyā an apekkhā vasena
translated: The word “together” is a synonym for the word “with” . This is the nature of synonyms, namely, that

original: yathārahaṃ saṃvaṇṇetabbapadatthaṃ saṃvaṇṇetvā puna tattha vijjamānavibhattivasena🔽parivattetvā nikkhipananti. Diṭṭhisīlasāmaññena saṃhatattā saṅghoti imamatthaṃ vibhāvento
analyzed: yathāraham saṃvaṇṇetabba padattham saṃvaṇṇetvā puna tattha vijjamāna vibhatti vasena  parivattetvā nikkhipananti diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena saṃhata ttā saṅghaḥ ti imam attham vibhāvento
translated: without regard to case- endings they are used in the sense of the word to be synonymised, in whatever way is appropriate. Having thus synonymised, he again🔽reverses the case-ending that is there and puts it in the right place.🔽The meaning of the word “Order” is that it is a collection of monks who are alike in view and in moral habit. In order to show this meaning he said “by the group of monks who are alike in view and in moral habit”.

original: āha “diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṅghātena samaṇagaṇenā”ti. Ettha pana “yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā
analyzed: āha diṭṭhi sīla sāmañña saṅghātena samaṇa gaṇena ati ettha pana yā ayam diṭṭhi ariyā
translated: Herein, the view referred to is that described thus “That view that is noble,

original: niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato
analyzed: niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkha kkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ
translated: leading out , leading to the cessation of suffering, to the destruction of suffering, that is the view that a monk should live by” .🔽The moral habit is that described thus “Those moral habits that are unbroken, untorn, unblotched,

original: viharatī”ti evaṃ vuttāya diṭṭhiyā. “Yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni
analyzed: viharati iti evam vuttāya diṭṭhiyā yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni
translated: unmottled,

original: akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpesu
analyzed: a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni a parāmaṭṭhāni samādhi saṃvattanikāni tathārūpesu
translated: They are not to be despised, are honoured by the wise, are unattached, and lead to concentration.🔽He lives in conformity with the concord of virtue thus described.

original: sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharatī”ti evaṃ vuttānañca sīlānaṃ sāmaññena saṅghāto saṅghaṭito🔽sametoti diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṅghāto, samaṇagaṇo, diṭṭhisīlasāmaññena saṃhatoti vuttaṃ
analyzed: sīlesu sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati iti evam vuttānam ca sīlānam sāmaññena saṅghātaḥ saṅghaṭitaḥ  sameto ti diṭṭhi sīla sāmañña saṅghātaḥ samaṇa gaṇaḥ diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena saṃhato ti vuttam
translated: And the concord of virtue is the concord of virtue and view.🔽The concord of virtue and view is the concord of virtue and view in a group, a collection, a multitude, a concourse, of ascetics.🔽The concord of virtue and view is the concord of virtue and view in a group, a collection, a multitude, a concourse, of ascetics.

original: hoti. “Diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṅghāṭasaṅkhātenā” tipi pāṭho. Tathā saṅkhātena katitenāti🔽attho. Tathā hi diṭṭhisīlādīnaṃ niyatasabhāvattā sotāpannāpi aññamaññaṃ diṭṭhisīlasāmaññena
analyzed: hoti diṭṭhi sīla sāmañña saṅghāṭa saṅkhātena tipi tathā saṅkhātena katitena ati  atthaḥ tathā hi diṭṭhi sīla ādīnam niyata sabhāva ttā sā utāpannā api aññam aññam diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena
translated: The meaning is that it is described, called, by the name “concord of virtue and view in a group, a collection, a multitude, a concourse, of ascetics.”🔽For stream-enterers, too, are concordant in virtue and view, and still more so are once-returners, etc., because of the fixedness of their individual natures in virtue and view.

original: saṃhatā, pageva sakadāgāmiādayo, tathā ca vuttaṃ “niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti, “aṭṭhānametaṃ
analyzed: saṃhatā pagā iva sakadāgāmi ādayo tathā ca vuttam niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ ti aṭṭhānam etam
translated: And this is said: “This is impossible, there is no way this can be, that a person possessed of right view could deprive a living being of life” ,

original: bhikkhave, anavakāso, yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo sañciccapāṇaṃ jīvitā voropeyya,
analyzed: bhikkhave anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalo sañcicca pāṇam jīvitā voropeyya
translated: “It is impossible, bhikkhus, it cannot happen that a person possessed of right view could deprive a living being of life …

original: netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti ca ādi. Ariyapuggalassa hi yattha katthaci dūre ṭhitāpi attano
analyzed: na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti ca ādi ariya puggalassa hi yattha katthaci dūre ṭhitā api attanaḥ
translated: This is impossible” , and so on. For wherever an ariyan person is, whether far away or nearby,

analyzed: guṇa sāmaggiyā saṃhata tāya iva tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ viharati tathārūpesu
translated: and the unity of the qualities is the unity of the group itself. But because of the words, “He lives with a unity of view with such a view,

analyzed: sīlesu sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati iti vacanato pana puthujjanānam pi diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena
translated: he lives with a unity of virtue with such virtue,” the unity of the group of ordinary men is also obtained by the unity of view and virtue.

original: saṃhatabhāvo labbhatiyeva. Saddhiṃ-saddo ekatoti atthe nipāto. Pañca…pe… mattānīti
analyzed: saṃhata bhāvaḥ ekato ti atthe nipātaḥ pañcape mattāni iti
translated: The word “together” means “together with.” The compound “five … measure”

original: pañca-saddena mattasaddaṃ saṅkhipitvā bāhiratthasamāso vutto. Etesanti bhikkhusatānaṃ.
analyzed: pañca saddena matta saddam saṅkhipitvā bāhirattha samāsaḥ vuttaḥ etesan ti bhikkhu satānam
translated: is a bahubbīhi compound in which the word “measure” is abbreviated by the word “five.” “These” refers to the hundred bhikkhus.

original: Puna pañca mattā pamāṇāti byāso, nikāralopo cettha napuṃsakaliṅgattā.
analyzed: punar pañca mattā byāsaḥ nikāra lopaḥ ca ittha napuṃsaka liṅga ttā
translated: “Five … measure” is the analysis. The omission of the particle is because of the neuter gender.

original: Suppiyoti tassa nāmameva, na guṇādi. Na kevalaṃ bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ bhagavāyeva,
analyzed: suppiyaḥ ti tassa nāmam eva na guṇa ādi na kevalam bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim bhagavāya iva
translated: “Suppiya” is just his name, not his qualities, etc. Not only did the Blessed One go together with the Community of Bhikkhus,

original: atha kho suppiyopi paribbājako brahmadattena māṇavena saddhinti puggalaṃ sampiṇḍeti,
analyzed: atha kho suppiyaḥ api paribbājakaḥ brahmadattena māṇavena saddhinti puggalam sampiṇḍeti
translated: but also the wanderer Suppiya together with the brahmin student Brahmadatta. The individual is included in the group,

original: tañca kho maggapaṭipannasabhāgatāya eva, na sīlācārādisabhāgatāyāti vuttaṃ “pi-kāro”tiādi.
analyzed: tat ca kho magga paṭipanna sabhā gatāya eva na sīla ācāra ādi sabhā gatāya ati vuttam pikāra utiādi
translated: and that is only because of the similarity of the path being followed, not because of the similarity of virtue, conduct, etc. Therefore it is said “the word ‘and’ … ”

original: Sukhuccāraṇavasena pubbāparapadānaṃ sambandhamattakarabhāvaṃ sandhāya “padasandhikaro”ti
analyzed: sukha uccāraṇa vasena pubba apara padānam sambandha matta kara bhāvam sandhāya pada sandhi karoti
translated: The word “connector” is said with reference to the mere connection of the preceding and succeeding words by their being uttered together,

original: vuttaṃ, na pana sarabyañjanādisandhibhāvaṃ, tenāha “byañjanasiliṭṭhatāvasena vutto”ti,🔽etena padapūraṇamattanti dasseti. Apica avadhāraṇatthopi kho-saddo yutto “assosi
analyzed: vuttam na pana sara byañjana ādi sandhi bhāvam tena āha byañjana siliṭṭha tā vasena vuttaḥ iti  etena pada pūraṇam atta nti dasseti apica avadhāraṇa atthaḥ api kho saddaḥ yuttaḥ
translated: but not with reference to the connection of the syllables, etc., by their being uttered together. Therefore it is said, “It is said by way of the arrangement of the syllables.”

original: kho verañjo brāhmaṇo”tiādīsu viya, tena addhānamaggapaṭipanno ahosiyeva, nāssa maggapaṭipattiyā🔽koci antarāyo ahosīti ayamattho dīpito hoti. Sañjayassāti rājagahavāsino sañjayanāmassa🔽paribbājakassa, yassa santike paṭhamaṃ upatissakolitāpi pabbajiṃsu channaparibbājakova,
analyzed: kho verañjaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ti ādīsu viya tena addhāna magga paṭipanno na assa magga paṭipattiyā  koci antarāyaḥ ahosi iti ayam atthaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti sañjayassa ati rājagaha vāsinaḥ sañjaya nāmassa  paribbājakassa yassa santike paṭhamam upatissakolitā api pabbajiṃsu channa paribbājakaḥ uva
translated: By this he shows that it is merely a filling out of the verse. Moreover, the word kho is appropriate also in the sense of restriction, as in the passage, “The brahmin Verañjā heard” (M.i,18),🔽and so the meaning indicated is that he was travelling on the road all the time, and that there was no obstacle to his travelling on the road.🔽To Sañjaya: to the wanderer named Sañjaya who lived in Rājagaha, in whose presence Upatissa and Kolita first went forth as wanderers, and not as the naked ascetic.

original: na acelakaparibbājako. “Yadā, tadā”ti ca etena samakālameva addhānamaggapaṭipannataṃ
analyzed: na acelaka paribbājakaḥ yadā tadā ati ca etena sama kālam eva addhāna magga paṭipanna tam
translated: “When, then”: by this he shows that he was travelling on the road at the same time as the wanderer.

original: dasseti. Atītakālattho pāḷiyaṃ hotisaddo yogavibhāgena, taṃkālāpekkhāya vā evaṃ vuttaṃ, tadā hotīti attho.
analyzed: dasseti atīta kāla atthaḥ pāḷiyam hoti saddaḥ yogavibhāgena tad kāla apekkhāya vā evam vuttam tadā hoti iti attho
translated: and shows. The word “is” in the text is in the past tense, but it is said thus by analysis of the compound or else with reference to the time of the occurrence of the action.

original: Anteti samīpe. Vasatīti vattapaṭivattādikaraṇavasena sabbiriyāpathasādhāraṇavacanaṃ,
analyzed: anta iti samīpe vasati iti vatta paṭivatta ādi karaṇa vasena sat viriyāpatha sādhāraṇa vacanam
translated: “In the end” means “in the vicinity.” “Lives” is a word common to all postures by way of the performance of the functions of going forwards, going backwards, and so on.

original: avacaratīti vuttaṃ hoti, tenevāha “samīpacāro santikāvacaro sisso”ti. Coditā devadūtehīti🔽daharakumāro jarājiṇṇasatto gilāno kammakāraṇā, kammakāraṇikā vā matasattoti imehi
analyzed: avacarati iti vuttam hoti tena iva āha samīpa cāraḥ santika avacaraḥ sissaḥ ti coditā deva dūtehi iti  dahara kumāraḥ jarā jiṇṇa sattaḥ gilānaḥ kamma kāraṇā kamma kāraṇikā vā matasatto ti imehi
translated: “Moves about” is what is meant. Therefore it is said: “The pupil is one who moves about in the vicinity, who moves about nearby.” “Being admonished by the messengers of the gods” means🔽being admonished, being exhorted, and being caused to arouse urgency by these five messengers of the gods, namely, a young man, an old man, a sick man, a dead man, and a deva.

original: pañcahi devadūtehi coditā ovaditā saṃvegaṃ uppāditā samānāpi. Te hi devā viya dūtā,
analyzed: pañcahi deva dūtehi coditā ovaditā saṃvegam uppāditā samānā api te hi devāḥ viya dūtā
translated: For these are messengers like the gods,

original: visuddhidevānaṃ vā dūtāti devadūtā. Hīnakāyūpagāti apāyakāyamupagatā. Narasaṅkhātā
analyzed: visuddhi devānam vā dūtā ati deva dūtā hīna kāyūpagā ati apāya kāyam upagatā nara saṅkhātā
translated: or they are messengers of the pure gods, thus they are “messengers of the gods.” “Has gone to a lower rebirth” means has gone to a rebirth in the unhappy destinations.🔽The connection is this: “Those called men who have gone to a lower rebirth are young men.”

original: te māṇavāti sambandho. Sāmaññavasena cettha satto “māṇavo”ti vutto, itare pana visesavasena.
analyzed: te māṇavā ti sambandhaḥ sāmañña vasena ca ittha satto māṇavo ti vutto itare pana visesa vasena
translated: Herein, a being is called a “young man” in the sense of generality, but the others are in the sense of particularities.

original: Pakaraṇādhigato hesa atthuddhāroti. Katakammehīti katacorakammehi. Taruṇoti soḷasavassato
analyzed: pakaraṇa adhigataḥ ha isa atthuddhāro ti kata kammehi iti kata cora kammehi taruṇaḥ ti soḷasa vassataḥ
translated: He is one who has grasped the meaning from the text. “Those who have committed a crime” means those who have committed a crime of thieves. “Young” means from sixteen years of age

original: paṭṭhāya pattavīsativasso, udānaṭṭhakathāyañhi “sattā jātadivasato paṭṭhāya yāva
analyzed: paṭṭhāya patta vīsati vassaḥ sattāḥ jāta divasato paṭṭhāya yāva
translated: up to twenty years of age, for in the Udana Commentary it is said: “From the day of their birth

original: pañcadasavassakā, tāva ‘kumārakā, bālā’ti ca vuccanti. Tato paraṃ vīsativassāni ‘yuvāno”’ti
analyzed: pañcadasa vassakā tāva kumārakā bālā ati ca vuccanti tato param vīsati vassāni yuvāno ti
translated: up to fifteen years of age, they are called ‘boys’ and ‘fools.’ After that, up to twenty years of age, they are called ‘young men.’

original: vuttaṃ. Taruṇo, māṇavo, yuvāti ca atthato ekaṃ, lokiyā pana “dvādasavassato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: vuttam taruṇaḥ māṇavaḥ yuvā ti ca atthataḥ ekam lokiyā pana dvādasa vassato paṭṭhāya
translated: “Young,” “student,” and “youth” are the same in meaning, but worldly people say: “From twelve years of age

original: yāva jaramappatto, tāva taruṇo”tipi vadanti.
analyzed: tāva vadanti
translated: up to the age of old age, they are called ‘young.’“

original: Tesu vā dvīsu janesūti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ. Yo vā “ekaṃ samaya”nti pubbe adhigato
analyzed: tesu vā dvīsu janesu iti niddhāraṇe bhummam yaḥ vā ekam samayam ti pubbe adhigataḥ
translated: Among these two people, the locative case is used for specification. Or the time that was previously grasped as “at one time”

original: kālo, tassa paṭiniddeso tatrāti yañhi samayaṃ bhagavā antarā rājagahañca nāḷandañca
analyzed: kālo tassa paṭiniddesaḥ tatra ati yat hi samayam bhagavā antarā rājagaham ca nāḍandam ca
translated: is the indication of that. For at the time when the Blessed One was traveling on the road between Rajagaha and Nalanda,

original: addhānamaggapaṭipanno, tasmiṃyeva samaye suppiyopi taṃ addhānamaggaṃ paṭipanno avaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ tasmin yeva samaye suppiyaḥ api tam addhāna maggam paṭipannaḥ avaṇṇam
translated: at that very time Suppiya was also traveling on that road, speaking in dispraise of the ascetic Gotama.

original: bhāsati, brahmadatto ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti. Nipātamattanti ettha mattasaddena visesatthābhāvato
analyzed: bhāsati brahmadatto ca vaṇṇam bhāsati iti ettha matta saddena visesa ttha abhāvato
translated: and Brahmadatta praises him. The mere end of a line: here the word mere shows that there is no special meaning,

analyzed: dasseti madhupiṇḍika pariyāyo ti madhupiṇḍika desanā nāma iti naṃ suttantam
translated: that it is a mere filling out of the line. The Madhupiṇḍika story: the teaching called the Madhupiṇḍika Sutta,

original: dhārehi, rājaññāti pāyāsirājaññanāmakaṃ rājānamālapati. Pariyāyati parivattatīti🔽pariyāyo, vāro. Pariyāyeti desetabbamatthaṃ paṭipādetīti pariyāyo, desanā. Pariyāyati🔽attano phalaṃ paṭiggahetvā pavattatīti pariyāyo, kāraṇaṃ. Anekasaddeneva anekavidhenāti
analyzed: dhārehi rājañña ati pāyāsi rājañña nāmakam rājānam ālapati pariyāyati parivattati iti  pariyāyaḥ vāro pariyāyeti desetabbam attham paṭipādeti iti pariyāyaḥ desanā pariyāyati  attanaḥ phalam paṭiggahetvā pavattati iti pariyāyaḥ kāraṇam aneka saddena iva anekavidhena ati
translated: remember it thus. The son of a wealthy man: he addresses the prince named Pāyāsi. A story is a succession, a turn,🔽a story is a teaching, since it causes the meaning to be taught to be turned over, i.e. to be turned over in one’s mind. A story is a reason,🔽since it turns over, i.e. occurs after having accepted its own fruit. The meaning of “in many ways” is understood by the many words,

original: attho viññāyati adhippāyamattenāti āha “anekavidhenā”ti. Kāraṇañcettha kāraṇapatirūpakameva,
analyzed: atthaḥ viññāyati adhippāya mattena ati āha anekavidhena ati kāraṇam ca ittha kāraṇa patirūpakam eva
translated: but the intention is simply “in many ways,” he says. And here the reason is a mere semblance of a reason,

original: na ekaṃsakāraṇaṃ avaṇṇakāraṇassa abhūtattā, tasmā kāraṇenāti kāraṇapatirūpakenāti
analyzed: na avaṇṇa kāraṇassa abhūta ttā tasmā kāraṇena ati kāraṇa patirūpakena ati
translated: not a real reason, since there was no reason for the dispraise. Therefore the meaning of “for a reason” is “for a mere semblance of a reason.”

original: attho. Tathā hi vakkhati “akāraṇameva ‘kāraṇa’nti vatvā”ti. Jātivasenidaṃ bahvatthe
analyzed: atthaḥ tathā hi vakkhati akāraṇam eva kāraṇanti vatvā ati jāti vasena idam bahu atthe
translated: For he says: “having stated a mere semblance of a reason as a reason.” This is a word of many meanings

original: ekavacananti dasseti “bahūhī”tiādinā.
analyzed: ekavacanam iti bahūhi itiādinā
translated: “In the singular” shows that the word “many” is in the singular.

original: “Avaṇṇavirahitassa asamānavaṇṇasamannāgatassapī”ti vakkhamānakāraṇassa akāraṇabhāvahetudassanatthaṃ
analyzed: avaṇṇa virahitassa asamāna vaṇṇa samannāgatassa api iti vakkhamāna kāraṇassa akāraṇa bhāva hetu dassana tham
translated: “Even though he is free from dispraise and possesses praise that is unequalled” is said in order to show that the reason for saying that is not a reason.🔽The meaning is: “Even though he is free from hatred and possesses unequalled qualities.”

original: vuttaṃ, dosavirahitassapi asadisaguṇasamannāgatassāpīti attho. Buddhassa bhagavato🔽avaṇṇaṃ dosaṃ nindanti sambandho. “Yaṃ loke”tiādinā arasarūpanibbhogaakiriyavādaucchedavādajegucchīvenayikatapassīapagabbhabhāvānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam dosa virahitassa api asadisa guṇa samannāgatassa api iti atthaḥ buddhassa bhagavato  avaṇṇam dosam nindanti sambandhaḥ yam loka iti ādinā
translated: The connection is: “Dispraise, hatred, and blame of the Blessed One, the Buddha.”🔽“The taste of the world” and so on shows the reason for the following: the absence of taste, the absence of form, the absence of enjoyment, the absence of action, the absence of annihilation, the absence of impurity, the absence of discipline, the absence of views, and the absence of a womb.

original: kāraṇapatirūpakaṃ dasseti. Tasmāti hi etaṃ “arasarūpo…pe… apagabbho”ti imehi padehi🔽sambandhitabbaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – lokasammato abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalīkammasāmīcikammaāsanābhinimantanasaṅkhāto
analyzed: kāraṇa patirūpakam dasseti tasmā ati hi etam imehi padehi  sambandhitabbam idam vuttam hoti loka sammataḥ abhivādana paccuṭṭhāna añjalīkamma sāmīcikamma āsana abhinimantana saṅkhātaḥ
translated: Therefore, this should be connected with the words “the absence of taste … the absence of a womb.”

original: sāmaggīraso samaṇassa gotamassa natthi, tasmā so sāmaggīrasasaṅkhātena rasena asampannasabhāvo,
analyzed: sāmaggī raso samaṇassa gotamassa na atthi tasmā saḥ sāmaggī rasa saṅkhātena rasena a sampanna sabhāvaḥ

original: tena sāmaggīrasasaṅkhātena paribhogena asamannāgato. Tassa akattabbatāvādo, ucchijjitabbatāvādo🔽ca, taṃ sabbaṃ gūthaṃ viya maṇḍanajātiyo puriso jegucchī. analyzed: tena sāmaggī rasa saṅkhātena paribhogena asamannāgataḥ tassa a kattabba tā vādaḥ ucchijjitabba tā vādaḥ  ca tam sabbam gūtham viya maṇḍana jātiyaḥ purisaḥ jegucchī tassa vināsakaḥ saḥ uva tad akaraṇataḥ  vinetabbaḥ tad akaraṇena vayaḥ vuḍḍhe tāpeti tad ācāra virahita tāya vā kapaṇa purisaḥ tad akaraṇena  deva loka gabbhataḥ apagataḥ tad akaraṇataḥ vā saḥ hīna gabbhaḥ ca ati evam tat eva abhivādana ādi akaraṇam
translated: He is not provided with the enjoyment called “unanimity” . The teaching of his not doing what should be done and the teaching of his being worthy to be dismissed🔽are all like dung. He should be trained in that non-doing of it.🔽By his non-doing of it he is emaciated with old age or he is a poor man because he is devoid of that conduct. By his non-doing of it🔽he has fallen away from the womb of the world of the gods, or he is of low-born womb because of his non-doing of it. Thus that very non-doing of the duties of saluting, etc.,🔽🔽

original: arasarūpatādīnaṃ kāraṇapatirūpakaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Natthi…pe… viseso”ti etassa pana

translated: He is not provided with the enjoyment consisting in the concordance of the three, and so on. The teaching that it should not be done and the teaching that it should be destroyed are like the dung. The man of the kind described as “adorned” is disgusted with it. He should be trained in the destruction of that by not doing it. By not doing it he is scorched in the aging of life or he is a poor man in the absence of that conduct. By not doing it he is deprived of the womb of the deva world. Or he is of low birth by not doing it. Thus the very same non-doing of the duties of saluting, and so on, should be regarded as a simile for the cause of the absence of taste, and so on. “There is no distinction, etc.” The following should be cited as similes for the cause of this:

analyzed: uttari manussadhamma uva takka pariyāhatam ti kappanā mattena samantataḥ āharitam vitakkena

original: vā parighaṭitaṃ. Vīmaṃsānucaritanti vīmaṃsanāya punappunaṃ parimajjitaṃ. Sayampaṭibhānanti🔽sayameva attano vibhūtaṃ, tādisaṃ dhammanti sambandho. Akāraṇanti ayuttaṃ anupapattiṃ.

original: Kāraṇapade cetaṃ visesanaṃ. Na hi arasarūpatādayo dosā bhagavati saṃvijjanti, dhammasaṅghesu

original: ca durakkhātaduppaṭipannādayo akāraṇanti vā yuttikāraṇarahitaṃ attanā paṭiññāmattaṃ.🔽Pakatikammapadañcetaṃ. Imasmiñca atthe kāraṇaṃ vatvāti ettha kāraṇaṃ ivāti iva-saddattho
analyzed: ca durakkhāta duppaṭipanna ādayaḥ akāraṇam ti vā yutti kāraṇa rahitam attanā paṭiññāmattam  pakati kamma padam ca itam imasmin ca atthe kāraṇam vatvā ati ettha kāraṇam iva ati iva sadda atthaḥ
translated: Or it is a mere assertion of his own, devoid of reason, for it is not reasonable that such faults should be found in the Dhamma and the discipline.🔽This is a word of natural denotation. And in this sense the word “reason” should be construed as a simile, as if it were the word “like,” because a semblance of a reason is intended.

original: rūpakanayena yojetabbo patirūpakakāraṇassa adhippetattā. Tathā tathāti jātivuḍḍhānamanabhivādanādinā

original: tena tena ākārena. Vaṇṇasaddassa guṇapasaṃsāsu pavattanato yathākkamaṃ “avaṇṇaṃ dosaṃ ninda”nti vuttaṃ.

analyzed: niyyāniko tatas vā niyyānam nissaraṇam tattha niyuttaḥ ti niyyānikaḥ vaṭṭataḥ vā niyyāti iti

translated: the ya is made ka and the i is made ra,🔽for the grammarians say that the word anīya is a verbal noun formed from the verb abhidhāyaka “to say” . But the escape from it is not so.🔽It is the way that leads to the non-stilling of suffering in the round of rebirths,
