original: kho panā”tiādimāha. Halāhalanti taṅkhaṇaññeva māraṇakaṃ visaṃ. Hanatīti hi halo na-kārassa🔽la-kāraṃ katvā, halānampi viseso halo halāhalo majjhedīghavasena, etena ca aññe aṭṭhavidhe
analyzed: kho pana ati ādim āha halāhalanti māraṇakam visam hanati iti hi ha laḥ nakārassa  lakāram katvā halānam pi visesaḥ halaḥ halāhalaḥ majjhe dīgha vasena etena ca aññe aṭṭhavidhe
translated: Halāhala is a poison that kills at the very moment it is eaten. “Halo” means “it kills” . The “na” of “na” has been changed to “la” .

original: vise nivatteti. Vuttañca –
analyzed: vise nivattā iti vuttam ca
translated: Halāhala is a special kind of poison, a compound of the first and last syllables of “halā” and “hala” . By this he rejects the other eight kinds of poison. It is said:

original: “Pume paṇḍe ca kākola, kāḷakūṭahalāhalā;
analyzed: pume paṇḍe ca kākola kāḷakūṭa halāhalā
translated: “Pume, paṇḍe, and kākola, kāḷakūṭa, halāhala;

original: Sarotthikosuṅkike yo, brahmaputto padīpano;
analyzed: yaḥ brahma putto padīpano
translated: Sarotthikosuṅkike, yo, brahmaputto, padīpano;

original: Dārado vacchanābho ca, visabhedā ime navā”ti.
analyzed: dāradaḥ ca visabhedāḥ ime navāti
translated: Dārado, vacchanābho, these are the nine kinds of poison.”

original: Kharodakanti caṇḍasotodakaṃ. “Khārodaka”ntipi pāṭho, atiloṇatāya tittodakanti attho.
analyzed: khara udakanti caṇḍa sota udakam khāra udakam tipi pāṭhaḥ ati loṇa tāya tittodakam ti attho
translated: Kharodaka is water with a strong current. The reading is also “khārodaka” . The meaning is: water that is bitter because of its excessive saltiness.

original: Narakapapātanti corapapātaṃ. Māṇavakāti attānameva ovadituṃ ālapati “samayopi kho
analyzed: cora papātam attānam eva ovaditum ālapati
translated: Narakapapāta is a robber’s precipice. Māṇavaka is an address to himself in order to admonish himself: “Even a wise man, a learned brahmin,

original: te bhaddāli appaṭividdhoahosī”tiādīsu viya. “Kammassakā”ti kammameva attasantakabhāvaṃ
analyzed: te bhaddāli appaṭividdho ahosi itiādīsu viya kammassakā ati kammam eva atta santaka bhāvam
translated: “You have not understood it, Bhaddāli” , etc. “Kamma-owners” : having stated that kamma is the self’s own,

original: vatvā tadeva vivarati “attano kammānurūpameva gatiṃ gacchantī”tiādinā. Yonisoti upāyena🔽ñāyena. Ummujjitvāti ācariyo viya ayoniso ariyūpavāde animmujjanto yoniso ariyūpavādato
analyzed: vatvā tat eva vivarati kamma anurūpam eva gatim gacchanti itiādinā upāyena  ñāyena ummujjitvā ati ācariyaḥ a nimmujjantaḥ
translated: he explains it thus: “They go to the destination according to their own kamma” , etc. “Reasonably” : by means of the right

original: ummujjitvā, uddhaṃ hutvāti attho. Maddamānoti maddanto bhindanto. Ekaṃsakāraṇameva🔽idha kāraṇanti dassetukāmena “sammā”ti vuttaṃ. “Yathā ta”ntiādinā tassa samāraddhabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ummujjitvā uddham hutvā iti attho maddamānaḥ iti maddantaḥ bhindantaḥ ekaṃsa kāraṇam eva  idha kāraṇanti dassetu kāmena sammā iti vuttam yathā tanti ādinā tassa samāraddha bhāvam
translated: means, by the right method. “Having emerged” : not emerging from the noble admonishments in the wrong way like a teacher, but having emerged from the noble admonishments in the right way; the meaning is: having risen up. “Boasting” : boasting, bragging.

original: dasseti, nti ca nipātamattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā añño paṇḍitasabhāvo jāti ācāravasena
analyzed: dassa iti nti ca nipāta mattam idam vuttam hoti yathā añño paṇḍita sabhāvaḥ ācāra vasena
translated: The reason is stated here by the word “rightly” with the intention of showing that the reason is the only reason. “As does another” , etc., shows the state of his being engaged in it. “Nti” is merely a particle. This is what is said: Just as another person, a wise man, a gentleman by birth and conduct,

original: kulaputto anekapariyāyena tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitumārabhati, tathā ayampi
analyzed: kula puttaḥ aneka pariyāyena tiṇṇam ratanānam vaṇṇam bhāsitum ārabhati tathā ayam pi
translated: begins to speak in many ways in praise of the Three Jewels, so this

original: āraddho, tañca kho api nāmāyamācariyo ettakenāpi ratanattayāvaṇṇabhāsato orameyyāti.
analyzed: āraddhaḥ tat ca kho api nāma ayam ācariyaḥ ettakena api
translated: one is engaged in it too. And it is possible that this teacher will emerge from speaking in praise of the Three Jewels even with this much.

original: Sapparājavaṇṇanti ahirājavaṇṇaṃ. Vaṇṇapokkharatāyāti vaṇṇasundaratāya, vaṇṇasarīrena
analyzed: sapparāja vaṇṇam ti ahirāja vaṇṇam vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya ati vaṇṇa sundara tāya vaṇṇa sarīrena
translated: “With the colour of a king’s horse” means with the colour of a royal horse. “In the matter of the excellence of colour” means in the matter of the beauty of colour, in the matter of the body’s colour.

original: vā. Vārijaṃ kamalaṃ na paharāmi na bhañjāmi, ārā dūratova upasiṅghāmīti attho. Athāti
analyzed: vā vāri jam kamalam na paharāmi na bhañjāmi ārā dūratas va upasiṅghāmi iti atthaḥ atha ati
translated: Sapparājavaṇṇanti ahirājavaṇṇaṃ: ‘I do not touch the water-born lotus, I do not break it, I only smell it from afar,’ is the meaning. Athāti

original: evaṃ santepi. Gandhatthenoti gandhacoro. Saññūḷhāti ganthitā bandhitā. Gahapatīti
analyzed: evam sante pi gandhatthena uti gandha coraḥ saññūḍhā ati ganthitā bandhitā gahapati iti
translated: evaṃ santepi. Gandhatthena: ‘I am a thief of scent,’ Saññūḷhāti ganthitā bandhitā. Gahapatīti

original: upāligahapatiṃ nāṭaputtassa ālapanaṃ. Ettha ca vaṇṇitabbo “ayamīdiso”ti pakāsetabboti
analyzed: upāli gahapatim nāṭa puttassa ālapanam ettha ca vaṇṇitabbaḥ ayam īdiso ti pakāsetabbaḥ ti
translated: upāligahapatiṃ nāṭaputtassa ālapanaṃ. Ettha ca vaṇṇitabbo “ayamīdiso”ti pakāsetabboti

original: vaṇṇo, saṇṭhānaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati asaṅkarato vavatthāpīyatīti vaṇṇo, jāti. Vaṇṇeti vikāramāpajjamānaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ saṇṭhānam vaṇṇīyati asaṅkarataḥ vavatthāpīyati iti vaṇṇaḥ jāti vaṇṇeti vikāram āpajjamānam
translated: vaṇṇo, saṇṭhānaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati asaṅkarato vavatthāpīyatīti vaṇṇo, jāti. Vaṇṇeti vikāramāpajjamānaṃ

original: hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti vaṇṇo, rūpāyatanaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati phalametena yathāsabhāvato
analyzed: hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti iti vaṇṇaḥ rūpa āyatanam phalam etena yathā sabhāvataḥ
translated: hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti vaṇṇo, rūpāyatanaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati phalametena yathāsabhāvato

original: vibhāvīyatīti vaṇṇo, kāraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati appamahantādivasena pamīyatīti vaṇṇo, pamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: vibhāvīyati iti vaṇṇo kāraṇam appamahanta ādi vasena pamīyati iti vaṇṇo pamāṇam
translated: vibhāvīyatīti vaṇṇo, kāraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati appamahantādivasena pamīyatīti vaṇṇo, pamāṇaṃ.

original: Vaṇṇīyati pasaṃsīyatīti vaṇṇo, guṇo. Vaṇṇanaṃ guṇasaṃkittanaṃ vaṇṇo, pasaṃsā. Evaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇīyati pasaṃsīyati iti vaṇṇaḥ guṇaḥ vaṇṇanam guṇa saṃkittanam vaṇṇaḥ pasaṃsā evam
translated: Vaṇṇīyati pasaṃsīyatīti vaṇṇo, guṇo. Vaṇṇanaṃ guṇasaṃkittanaṃ vaṇṇo, pasaṃsā. Evaṃ

original: tattha tattha vaṇṇasaddassuppatti veditabbā. Ādisaddena jātarūpapuḷinakkharādayo🔽saṅgaṇhāti. “Idha guṇopi pasaṃsāpī”ti vuttameva samattheti “ayaṃ kirā”tiādinā. Kirāti
analyzed: tattha tattha veditabbā ādi saddena jātarūpa puḷi nakkhara ādayaḥ  saṅgaṇhāti idha guṇaḥ api pasaṃsā api iti vuttam eva samatthā iti ayam kirāti ādinā kirāti
translated: The arising of the colour and sound should be understood in each case. The word “etc.” includes molten gold, chalk, etc.🔽“Herein, the praise is also a quality” is what is said. The word “kirā” is used in the sense of “it is said” or simply to fill out the line.

original: cettha anussavanatthe, padapūraṇamatte vā. Guṇūpasañhitanti guṇopasaññutaṃ. “Guṇūpasañhitaṃ
analyzed: ca ittha anussavana atthe pada pūraṇa matte vā guṇa upasañhitanti guṇa upasaññutam guṇa upasañhitam
translated: “Endowed with qualities” means endowed with praise. But one who says “praise endowed with qualities”

original: pasaṃsa”nti pana vadanto pasaṃsāya eva guṇabhāsanaṃ siddhaṃ tassā tadavinābhāvato,
analyzed: pasaṃsanti pana vadantaḥ pasaṃsāyaḥ eva guṇa bhāsanam siddham tassā tad avinābhāvato
translated: has already established the speaking of qualities as praise, since praise is inseparable from them.

original: tasmā idamatthadvayaṃ yujjatīti dasseti.
analyzed: tasmai idam attha dvayam yujjati iti dasseti
translated: Therefore he shows that these two meanings are appropriate.

original: Kathaṃ bhāsatīti āha “tatthā”tiādi. Eko ca so puggalo cāti ekapuggalo. Kenaṭṭhena
analyzed: katham bhāsati iti āha tattha atiādi ekaḥ ca so puggalo ca ati eka puggalo kenaṭṭhena
translated: How does he speak? He says “tatthā” and so on. He is one and a man, thus he is a single man. In what sense is he a single man?

original: ekapuggalo? Asadisaṭṭhena, guṇavisiṭṭhaṭṭhena, asamasamaṭṭhena ca. So hi paṭhamābhinīhārakāle
analyzed: eka puggalaḥ asadisa ṭṭhena guṇa visiṭṭha ṭṭhena asamasama ṭṭhena ca so hi paṭhama abhinīhāra kāle
translated: In the sense of being incomparable, distinguished by qualities, and unequaled. For at the time of the first aspiration

original: dasannaṃ pāramīnaṃ paṭipāṭiyā āvajjanaṃ ādiṃ katvā bodhisambhārasambharaṇaguṇehi
analyzed: dasannam pāramīnam paṭipāṭiyā āvajjanam ādim katvā bodhi sambhāra sambharaṇa guṇehi
translated: he began by adverting to the ten perfections in order, and by the qualities of accumulating the requisites for enlightenment

original: ceva buddhaguṇehi ca sesamahājanena asadiso. Ye cassa guṇā, tepi aññasattānaṃ guṇehi
analyzed: ca iva buddha guṇehi ca sesa mahājanena asadisaḥ ye ca assa guṇā te api añña sattānam guṇehi
translated: and in the qualities of a Buddha, he is incomparable to the multitude of men. And his qualities are distinguished from the qualities of other beings,

original: visiṭṭhā, purimakā ca sammāsambuddhā sabbasattehi asamā, tehi pana ayameveko rūpakāyanāmakāyehi
analyzed: visiṭṭhā purimakā ca sammāsambuddhā sabba sattehi asamā tehi pana ayam eva ekaḥ rūpa kāya nāma kāyehi
translated: and the former Perfectly Awakened Ones are unequalled by all beings, but he is equal to them in the two bodies called the form body and the mind body.

original: samo. Loketi sattaloke. “Uppajjamāno uppajjatī”ti pana idaṃ ubhayampi vippakatavacanameva
analyzed: samaḥ loke iti satta loke uppajjamānaḥ uppajjati iti pana idam ubhayam pi vippakata vacanam eva
translated: In the world means in the world of beings. “Arising, he arises” is a double verbal expression.

original: uppādakiriyāya vattamānakālikattā. Uppajjamāno bahujanahitāya uppajjati, na aññena
analyzed: uppāda kiriyāya vattamāna kālika ttā uppajjamānaḥ bahu jana hitāya uppajjati na aññena
translated: This is because the action of arising is in the present tense. “Arising, he arises for the welfare of the multitude” means he arises not for any other reason

original: kāraṇenāti evaṃ panettha attho veditabbo. Lakkhaṇe hesa māna-saddo, evarūpañcettha
analyzed: kāraṇena ati evam pana ittha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ lakkhaṇe ha isa māna saddo evarūpaṃ ca ittha
translated: but for the welfare of the multitude. This is how the meaning should be understood here. The word “name” here is in the sense of a characteristic,

original: lakkhaṇaṃ na sakkā aññena saddalakkhaṇena paṭibāhituṃ. Apica uppajjamāno nāma, uppajjati
analyzed: lakkhaṇam na sakkā aññena sadda lakkhaṇena paṭibāhitum apica uppajjamānaḥ nāma uppajjati
translated: and such a characteristic cannot be excluded by any other characteristic of a name. Moreover, the distinction here should be understood as follows: “arising” is the arising,

original: nāma, uppanno nāmāti ayamettha bhedo veditabbo. Esa hi dīpaṅkarapādamūlato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: nāma uppannaḥ nāma ati ayam ettha bhedaḥ veditabbo esa hi dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “he arises” is the arisen. This is how the distinction should be understood here. For this is the case from the time of the Great Being’s descent into the womb of the mother

original: yāva anāgāmiphalaṃ, tāva uppajjamāno nāma, arahattamaggakkhaṇe uppajjati nāma, arahattaphalakkhaṇe
analyzed: yāva anāgāmi phalam tāva uppajjamānaḥ nāma arahatta magga kkhaṇe uppajjati nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe
translated: and it is called “arisen” at the moment of the fruition of Arahantship.

original: uppanno nāma. Buddhānañhi sāvakānaṃ viya na paṭipāṭiyā iddhividhañāṇādīni uppajjanti,🔽saheva pana arahattamaggena sakalopi sabbaññuguṇarāsi āgatova nāma hoti, tasmā nibbattasabbakiccattā
analyzed: uppannaḥ nāma buddhānam hi sāvakānam viya na paṭipāṭiyā iddhividha ñāṇa ādīni uppajjanti  saha iva pana arahatta maggena sakalaḥ api sabbaññu guṇa rāsi āgataḥ va nāma hoti tasmā nibbatta sabba kicca ttā
translated: For the Buddhas do not, like disciples, acquire the kinds of supernormal power, knowledge of others’ minds, etc., in succession;

original: arahattaphalakkhaṇe uppanno nāma, tadanibbattattā tadaññakkhaṇe yathārahaṃ “uppajjamāno
analyzed: arahatta phala kkhaṇe uppannaḥ nāma tad anibbatta ttā tad añña kkhaṇe yathāraham uppajjamānaḥ
translated: but with the mere path of Arahantship they have arrived at the whole mass of the qualities of omniscience, and so it is said that they have “arisen” at the moment of the fruition of Arahantship because all that has to be done has been done.🔽And because it has not arisen in the other moments it is said, as appropriate, that it “is arising” and “arises.”

original: uppajjati” cceva vuccati. Imasmimpi sutte arahattaphalakkhaṇaṃyeva sandhāya “uppajjatī”ti
analyzed: uppajjati cca iva vuccati imasmim pi sutte arahatta pha lakkhaṇam yā iva sandhāya uppajjati iti
translated: And here too in this sutta the word “arises” is said with reference to the moment of the fruition of Arahantship.

original: vuttaṃ. Atītakālikassāpi vattamānapayogassa katthaci diṭṭhattā uppanno hotīti ayañhettha
analyzed: vuttam atīta kālikassa api vattamāna payogassa katthaci diṭṭhattā uppannaḥ hoti iti ayam ha ittha
translated: And the meaning here is that it has arisen because it is seen in some places as a present usage even though it is past.

original: attho. Evaṃ sati “uppajjamāno”ti cettha māna-saddo sāmatthiyattho. Yāvatā sāmatthiyena
analyzed: atthaḥ evam sati uppajjamānaḥ iti ca ittha māna saddaḥ sāmatthiya tthaḥ yāvatā sāmatthiyena
translated: So in this case the word “arising” has the meaning of potentiality.

original: mahābodhisattānaṃ carimabhave uppatti icchitabbā, tāvatā sāmatthiyena bodhisambhārabhūtena
analyzed: mahā bodhisattānam carima bhave uppatti icchitabbā tāvatā sāmatthiyena bodhi sambhāra bhūtena
translated: The appearance of a great Bodhisatta in his last birth should be accepted as the first of the three appearances.

original: paripuṇṇena samannāgato hutvāti attho. Tathāsāmatthiyayogena hi uppajjamāno nāmāti.
analyzed: paripuṇṇena samannāgataḥ hutvā iti attho tathā sāmatthiya yogena hi uppajjamānaḥ nāma ati
translated: The meaning is that he is endowed with the perfection of the requisites of enlightenment in the sense of being fit for the appearance of the three appearances.

original: Sabbasattehi asamo, asamehi purimabuddheheva samo majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇa nikkhaṃ viya🔽nibbisiṭṭho, “ekapuggalo”ti cetassa visesanaṃ. Ālayasaṅkhātaṃ taṇhaṃ samugghāteti
analyzed: sabba sattehi asamaḥ asamehi purima buddhehi iva samaḥ majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇa nikkham viya  eka puggalaḥ ti cetassa visesanam ālaya saṅkhātam taṇham samugghāte ti
translated: He is unequalled by all beings, and equal to the unequaled former Buddhas, like a piece of gold from the Jambu River.🔽He is called “the one person” as a distinguishing term for the Buddha. He uproots craving called “clinging”

original: samucchindatīti ālayasamugghāto. Vaṭṭaṃ upacchindatīti vaṭṭupacchedo.
analyzed: samucchindati iti ālaya samugghātaḥ vaṭṭam upacchindati iti vaṭṭupacchedaḥ
translated: and cuts off the round of rebirths.

original: Pahontenāti sakkontena. “Pañcanikāye”ti vatvāpi anekāvayavattā tesaṃ na ettakena
analyzed: pahontena ati sakkontena pañca nikāya iti vatvā api aneka avayava ttā tesam na ettakena
translated: “He is able” means he is capable. Although it is said “in the five Nikayas,” they have many parts, and it is not

original: sabbathā pariyādānanti “navaṅgaṃ satthusāsanaṃ caturāsīti dhammakkhandhasahassānī”ti
analyzed: sabbathā pariyādānam ti navaṅgam satthu sāsanam catur asīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti
translated: possible to know them all by heart.🔽The meaning is that he is able to know them all by heart. “The shore beyond” is the place of no return. It should not be said that the Buddha and the others are immeasurable in appearance,

original: vuttaṃ. Atitthenāti anotaraṇaṭṭhānena. Na vattabbo aparimāṇavaṇṇattā buddhādīnaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam atitthena ati anotaraṇa ṭhānena na vattabbaḥ aparimāṇa vaṇṇa ttā buddha ādīnam
translated: because of the fact that they are immeasurable in appearance.

original: niravasesānañca tesaṃ idha pakāsanena pāḷisaṃvaṇṇanāya eva sampajjanato, cittasampahaṃsanakammaṭṭhānasampajjanavasena
analyzed: niravasesānam ca tesam idha pakāsanena pāḷi saṃvaṇṇanāya eva sampajjanataḥ citta sampahaṃsana kammaṭṭhāna sampajjana vasena
translated: and because they are all included in the explanation of the text by the demonstration here, and because the demonstration of the meditation subject for encouraging the mind is fruitful.🔽The “firmness” should be understood as demonstrated in every way.

original: ca saphalattā. Thāmo veditabbo sabbathāmena pakāsitattā. Kiṃ pana so tathā ogāhetvā
analyzed: ca saphala ttā thāmaḥ veditabbaḥ sabba thāmena pakāsita ttā kim pana saḥ tathā ogāhetvā
translated: But why does he speak thus after not having gone to the Brahma-world?🔽“Brahmadatta, however, …”🔽Repeated hearing is “recollection” .

original: bhāsatīti āha. “Brahmadatto panā”tiādi. Anukkamena punappunaṃ vā savanaṃ anussavo,
analyzed: bhāsati iti āha brahmadattaḥ pana atiādi anukkamena punappunam vā savanam anussavaḥ
translated: Successive hearing is “tradition” .

original: paramparasavanaṃ. Ādi-saddena ākāraparivitakkadiṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyo saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: parampara savanam ādi saddena ākāra parivitakka diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantiyaḥ saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The word “etc.” includes the “consideration of reasons,” “consideration of particulars,” “acceptance of views after pondering views,” and “acceptance of views after pondering views.”

original: Tattha “sundaramidaṃ kāraṇa”nti evaṃ sayameva kāraṇaparivitakkanaṃ ākāraparivitakko.🔽Attano diṭṭhiyā nijjhāyitvā khamanaṃ ruccanaṃ diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantīti aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: tattha sundaram idam kāraṇam ti evam sayam eva kāraṇa parivitakkanam ākāra parivitakko  attanaḥ diṭṭhiyā nijjhāyitvā khamanam ruccanam diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhanti iti aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: Herein, the “consideration of reasons” is the personal consideration of reasons in this way: “This reason is good.”🔽Acceptance, approval, of one’s own view after pondering it is “acceptance of views after pondering views,” it is said in the commentaries.

original: vuttaṃ, tehiyeva sambandhitenāti attho. Matta-saddo hettha visesanivattiattho, tena
analyzed: vuttam tehiyā iva sambandhitena ati atthaḥ matta saddaḥ ha ittha visesa nivatti atthaḥ tena
translated: The meaning is that they are connected with those . The word “just” here has the meaning of limitation. By that he shows that the “consideration of reasons” and the rest are not the only causes for the arising of views.

original: yathāvuttaṃ kāraṇaṃ nivatteti. Attano thāmenāti attano ñāṇabaleneva, na pana buddhādīnaṃ🔽guṇānurūpanti adhippāyo. Asaṅkhyeyyāparimeyyappabhedā hi buddhādīnaṃ guṇā. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: yathā vuttam kāraṇam nivatteti attanaḥ thāmena ati attanaḥ ñāṇa balena iva na pana buddha ādīnam  guṇa anurūpam ti adhippāyaḥ asaṅkhyeyya aparimeyya ppabhedāḥ hi buddha ādīnam guṇāḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: He rejects the reason stated. By his own strength: by his own strength of knowledge, not by the strength of the Buddha, etc.

original: “Buddhopi buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇaṃ,🔽Kappampi ce aññamabhāsamāno;
analyzed: buddhaḥ api buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇam  kappam pi ce aññam a bhāsamāno
translated: The meaning is that he does not have the ability to extol the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., in accordance with their excellence. For the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., are of an incalculable and immeasurable variety. As it is said:

original: Khīyetha kappo ciradīghamantare,
analyzed: khīyetha cira dīgham antare
translated: “Even if for an eon or the remainder of an eon🔽The Buddha were to extol the Buddha,🔽The eon would end before his praise,

original: Vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassā”ti. ;
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa ati
translated: But the Tathāgata’s qualities would not.”

original: Idhāpi vakkhati “appamattakaṃ kho paneta”ntiādi.
analyzed: idha api vakkhati appamattakam kho pana itantiādi
translated: Here too he says: “But this is a very minor matter” , etc.

original: Iti-saddo nidassanattho vuttappakāraṃ nidasseti. Ha-kāro nipātamattanti āha “evaṃ
analyzed: iti saddaḥ nidassana atthaḥ vutta ppakāram nidasseti hakāraḥ nipāta mattam ti āha evam
translated: The word iti has the sense of indication; it indicates the aforementioned matter. The syllable ha is merely a particle. Therefore he says: “Thus, bhikkhus” .

original: te”ti. Aññamaññassā”ti idaṃ ruḷhipadaṃ “eko ekāyā”ti padaṃ viyāti dassento “aññoaññassā”ti
analyzed: te iti aññam aññassa ati idam ruḷhi padam ekaḥ ekāya ati padam viyā ti dassento añño aññassa ati
translated: The expression aññamaññassa is a conventional expression, like the expression eko ekāyāti. Showing this, he explains with the conventional expression añño aññassāti.

original: ruḷhipadeneva vivarati. “Ujumevā”ti sāvadhāraṇasamāsataṃ vatvā tena nivattetabbatthaṃ
analyzed: ruḷhi padena iva vivarati ujum evā iti sāvadhāraṇa samāsatam vatvā tena
translated: Having stated the determinative compound ujupaṭipannānaṃ, he rejects the meaning that would be excluded by that compound.

original: āha “īsakampi apariharitvā”ti, thokatarampi avirajjhitvāti attho. Kathanti āha “ācariyena
analyzed: āha īsakampi a pariharitvā ti thokataram pi a virajjhitvā ti attho kathanti āha ācariyena
translated: He said, “Without even a little restraint” : without even a little non-attachment. “How?” He said, “The teacher” , etc.

original: hī”tiādi. Pubbe ekavāramiva avaṇṇavaṇṇabhāsane niddiṭṭhepi “ujuvipaccanīkavādā”ti🔽vuttattā anekavārameva te evaṃ bhāsantīti veditabbanti dassetuṃ “puna itaro avaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: hi itiādi pubbe eka vāram iva avaṇṇa vaṇṇa bhāsane niddiṭṭhe pi uju vipaccanīka vādā ti  vutta ttā aneka vāram eva te evam bhāsanti iti veditabban ti dassetum puna itaraḥ avaṇṇam
translated: Although the teaching of dispraise and praise was shown as if it were a single round, still, since it is said, “The opposite of the right way,”🔽it should be understood that they spoke thus many times. In order to show this, it is said, “Then the other one dispraised” ,

original: itaro vaṇṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Tena hi visaddassa vividhatthataṃ samattheti. Sāraphalaketi
analyzed: itaraḥ vaṇṇam ti vuttam tena hi visaddassa samatthā iti sāra phalakā iti
translated: “The other one praised” . Thereby he shows the various meanings of the word visada .🔽On a slab of heartwood : on a slab of the best wood, or on a slab of the best wood.

original: sāradāruphalake, uttamaphalake vā. Visarukkhaāṇinti visadārumayapaṭāṇiṃ. Iriyāpathānubandhanena
analyzed: sāra dāru phalake uttama phalake vā visa rukkha āṇim ti visa dāru maya paṭa āṇim iriyāpatha anubandhanena
translated: With boards of clear wood : with boards made of clear wood.🔽They are followers by way of conduct,

original: anubandhā honti, na sammāpaṭipattianubandhanena.
analyzed: anubandhāḥ honti na sammāpaṭipatti anubandhanena
translated: not by way of right practice.

original: Sīsānulokinoti sīsena anulokino, sīsaṃ ukkhipitvā maggānukkamena olokayamānāti attho.
analyzed: sīsa anulokinaḥ ti sīsena anulokinaḥ sīsam ukkhipitvā magga anukkamena olokayamānā ti attho
translated: Looking with the head : looking with the head, looking along the path with the head raised, is the meaning.

original: Tasmiṃ kāleti yamhi saṃvacchare, utumhi, māse, pakkhe vā bhagavā taṃ addhānamaggaṃ
analyzed: tasmin kāle iti yamhi saṃvacchare utumhi māse pakkhe vā bhagavā tam addhānamaggam
translated: In that year, season, month, or fortnight, the Blessed One went along that road.

original: paṭipanno, tasmiṃ kāle. Tena hi aniyamato saṃvaccharautumāsaḍḍhamāsāva niddisitā
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ tasmin kāle tena hi aniyamataḥ niddisitā
translated: and he was travelling at that time.

original: “taṃ divasa”nti divasassa visuṃ niddiṭṭhattā, muhuttādīnañca divasapariyāpannato.🔽“Taṃ addhānaṃ paṭipanno”ti cettha ādhāravacanametaṃ. Teneva hi kiriyāvicchedadassanavasena
analyzed: tam divasanti divasassa visum niddiṭṭha ttā muhutta ādīnam ca divasa pariyāpannato  tam addhānam paṭipannaḥ ti ca itthā ādhāra vacanam etam tena iva hi kiriyā viccheda dassana vasena
translated: “On that day” is mentioned separately from the time, and the moment, etc., are included in the day.🔽“He was travelling on that road” is a locative expression.

original: “rājagahe piṇḍāya caratī”ti saha pubbakālakiriyāhi vattamānaniddeso kato, itarathā
analyzed: rāja gahe piṇḍāya carati iti saha pubba kāla kiriyāhi vattamāna niddeso kataḥ itarathā
translated: For this reason, the present tense is used in the phrase “he was walking for alms in Rājagaha” in order to show the continuity of the action. Otherwise,

original: tasmiṃ kāle rājagahe piṇḍāya carati, taṃ addhānamaggañca paṭipannoti anadhippetattho
analyzed: tasmin kāle rājagahe piṇḍāya carati tam addhāna maggam ca paṭipannaḥ ti
translated: “he was walking for alms in Rājagaha at that time, and he was travelling on that road” would be meaningless.

original: āpajjeyya. Na hi asamānavisayā kiriyā ekādhārā sambhavanti, yā cettha adhippetā addhānapaṭipajjanakiriyā,
analyzed: āpajjeyya na hi asamāna visayā kiriyā eka ādhārā sambhavanti yā ca ittha adhippetā addhāna paṭipajjana kiriyā
translated: For actions with different objects cannot have the same basis. And the action of travelling on the road, which is referred to here,

original: sā ca aniyamitā na yuttāti. Rājagahaparivattakesūti rājagahaṃ parivattetvā ṭhitesu.
analyzed: sā ca aniyamitā na yuttā ati rāja gaha parivattakesu iti rāja gaham parivattetvā ṭhitesu
translated: is not definite. It is not proper to say that the action of walking for alms in Rājagaha is the same as the action of travelling on the road.🔽“Those who were turning back from Rājagaha” means those who had turned back from Rājagaha and were staying there.

original: “Aññatarasmi”nti iminā tesu bhagavato anibaddhavāsaṃ dasseti. Soti evaṃ rājagahe
analyzed: aññatarasmin ti iminā tesu bhagavataḥ anibaddha vāsam dasseti saḥ iti evam rājagahe
translated: “On a certain road” shows that the Exalted One did not have a fixed residence among them.

original: vasamāno so bhagavā. Piṇḍāya caraṇenapi hi tattha paṭibaddhabhāvavacanato sannivāsattameva
analyzed: vasamānaḥ saḥ bhagavā piṇḍāya caraṇena api hi tattha paṭibaddha bhāva vacanato
translated: because of the fact that he was bound to that place for alms. But if he were to be disrespectful, saying, “The Blessed One was walking for alms,” he would incur the meaning stated in the following passage:

original: dasseti. Yadi pana “piṇḍāya caramāno so bhagavā”ti paccāmaseyya, yathāvuttova anadhippetattho🔽āpajjeyyāti. Taṃ divasanti yaṃ divasaṃ addhānamaggaṃ paṭipanno, taṃ divasa. Taṃ addhānaṃ
analyzed: dassa iti yadi pana piṇḍāya caramānaḥ saḥ bhagavā iti yathā vuttaḥ iva an adhippeta tthaḥ  āpajjeyya iti tam divasanti yam divasam addhāna maggam paṭipannaḥ tam divasa tam addhānam
translated: “If a bhikkhu should speak thus: ‘The Blessed One was walking for alms and said this …’ he should be told: ‘Do not misrepresent the Blessed One. For it is not right to misrepresent the Blessed One. The Blessed One would not say this.🔽On that occasion: on the occasion of his going on the journey. He was going on that journey: this is a way of speaking of complete connection.🔽After he had eaten his meal: after he had eaten the alms food.🔽When he had finished his meal: when he had finished eating the alms food.

original: paṭipannoti ettha accantasaṃyogavacanametaṃ. Bhattabhuñjanato pacchā pacchābhattaṃ,🔽tasmiṃ pacchābhattasamaye. Piṇḍapātapaṭikkantoti yattha piṇḍapātatthāya caritvā bhuñjanti,
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ ti ettha bhatta bhuñjanataḥ pacchā pacchābhattam  tasmin pacchābhatta samaye piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto ti yattha piṇḍapāta tthāya caritvā bhuñjanti
translated: After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.

original: tato apakkanto. Taṃ addhānaṃ paṭipannoti “nāḷandāyaṃ veneyyānaṃ vividhahitasukhanipphattiṃ
analyzed: tatas a pakkantaḥ tam addhānam paṭipanno ti nāḷandāyam veneyyānam vividha hita sukha nipphattim
translated: After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.

original: ākaṅkhamāno imissā aṭṭhuppattiyā tividhasīlālaṅkataṃ nānāvidhakuhanalapanādimicchājīvaviddhaṃsanaṃ
analyzed: ākaṅkhamānaḥ imissā aṭṭhuppattiyā tividha sīla alaṅkatam nānāvidha kuhana lapana ādim icchājīva viddhaṃsanam
translated: After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal is when he had finished eating.🔽After he had eaten his meal is after the meal; when he had finished his meal

original: dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhijālaviniveṭhanaṃ dasasahassilokadhātupakampanaṃ brahmajālasuttaṃ desessāmī”ti
analyzed: dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi jāla viniveṭhanam dasa sahassi lokadhātu upakampanam brahmajāla suttam desessāmi iti
translated: I will teach the Brahmajāla Sutta, which will tear to shreds the net of the sixty-two views, shake the ten-thousandfold world system, and make the devas shout for joy.”

original: taṃ yathāvuttaṃ dīghamaggaṃ paṭipanno, idaṃ pana kāraṇaṃ pakaraṇatova pākaṭanti na
analyzed: tam yathāvuttam dīgha maggam paṭipannaḥ idam pana kāraṇam pakaraṇataḥ iva pākaṭanti na
translated: He was traveling the route described above, but since the reason for his journey is clear from the text itself,

original: vuttaṃ. Ettāvatā “kasmā pana bhagavā taṃ addhānaṃ paṭipanno”ti codanā visodhitā hoti.
analyzed: vuttam ettāvatā kasmā pana bhagavā tam addhānam paṭipannaḥ ti codanā visodhitā hoti
translated: it is not mentioned here. So far the question “But why did the Blessed One undertake the journey?” has been answered.

original: Idāni itarampi codanaṃ visodhituṃ “suppiyopī”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmiṃ kāle, taṃ divasaṃ🔽anubandhoti ca vuttanayena sambandho. Pāto asitabboti pātarāso, so bhutto yenāti🔽bhuttapātarāso. Iccevāti evameva manasi sannidhāya, na pana “bhagavantaṃ, bhikkhusaṅghañca🔽piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhissāmī”ti. Tena vuttaṃ “bhagavato taṃ maggaṃ paṭipannabhāvaṃ
analyzed: idāni itaram pi codanam visodhitum suppiyaḥ api iti vuttam tasmin kāle tam divasam  anubandhaḥ ti ca vutta nayena sambandho pātaḥ asitabbaḥ ti pāta rāsaḥ saḥ bhuttaḥ yena ati  bhutta pāta rāsaḥ iccā iva ati evam eva manasi sannidhāya na pana bhagavantam bhikkhu saṅghañca  piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhissāmi iti tena vuttam bhagavataḥ tam maggam paṭipanna bhāvam
translated: Now, in order to answer the other question, “Suppiya too,” is said. At that time, on that day,🔽the connection is made in the way stated. Pātarāso is derived from asitabbo in the morning. He who has eaten that is bhuttapātarāso. Icceva means “having thus brought to mind,” not “I will follow behind the Blessed One and the community of monks.”

original: ajānantovā”ti, tathā ajānanto eva hutvā anubandhoti attho. Na hi so bhagavantaṃ daṭṭhumeva
analyzed: tathā a jānantaḥ eva hutvā anubandho ti atthaḥ na hi so bhagavantam daṭṭhum eva
translated: Therefore it is said, “without knowing that the Blessed One had undertaken the journey,” the meaning is that he followed without knowing that. For he did not follow in order to see the Blessed One,

original: icchati, tenāha “sace pana jāneyya, nānubandheyyā”ti. Ettāvatā “kasmā ca suppiyo
analyzed: icchati tena āha sace pana jāneyya na anubandheyya ati ettāvatā kasmā ca suppiyaḥ
translated: If he had wished to, he would not have followed him.🔽So far the question “Why did he follow Suppiya?” has been answered.

original: anubandho”ti codanā visodhitā hoti. “So”tiādinā aparampi codanaṃ visodheti. Kadāci
analyzed: codanā visodhitā hi iti sā uti ādinā aparam pi codanam kadācid
translated: With the words “He” he answers another question.

original: pana bhagavā aññataraveseneva gacchati aṅgulimāladamanapakkusātiabhiggamanādīsu,
analyzed: pana bhagavā aññatara vesena iva gacchati aṅguli māla damana pakkusāti abhiggamana ādīsu
translated: Sometimes the Blessed One goes by some other means, as in the taming of Angulimala, in the visit to the sick lay devotee,

original: kadāci buddhasiriyā, idhāpi īdisāya buddhasiriyāti dassetuṃ “buddhasiriyā sobhamāna”ntiādi
analyzed: kadāci buddha siriyā idha api īdisāya buddha siriyā ati dassetum buddha siriyā sobhamāna nti ādi
translated: and so on. Sometimes he goes by the splendor of a Buddha, as here.

original: vuttaṃ. Sirīti cettha sarīrasobhaggādisampatti, tadeva upamāvasena dasseti “rattakambalaparikkhittamivā”tiādinā.
analyzed: vuttam sirī iti ca ittha sarīra sobhagga ādi sampatti tat eva upamā vasena dasseti ratta kambala parikkhittam iva ati ādinā
translated: “Splendor” is the excellence of bodily beauty, etc. He illustrates that with a simile in the words “as if surrounded by a red blanket.”🔽“He went” means he moved, as in the word “walk” .

original: Gacchatīti jaṅgamo yathā “caṅkamo”ti. Cañcalamāno gacchanto giri, tādisassa kanakagirino
analyzed: gacchati iti jaṅgamaḥ yathā caṅkamo ti cañcalamānaḥ gacchantaḥ tādisassa kanakagirino
translated: A mountain that moves, goes, is like that.

original: sikharamivāti attho.
analyzed: sikharam iva ati attho
translated: The meaning is: the peak of a golden mountain.🔽“It is said that” and so on is a description of it. Since it is not given in the text,

original: “Tasmiṃ kirā”tiādi tabbivaraṇaṃ, pāḷiyaṃ adassitattā, porāṇaṭṭhakathāyañca anāgatattā
analyzed: tasmin kirāti ādi tad vivaraṇam pāḷiyam a dassita ttā porāṇa aṭṭhakathāyam ca anāgata ttā
translated: and since it is not found in the old commentaries,

original: anussavasiddhā ayaṃ kathāti dassetuṃ “kirā”ti vuttanti vadanti, tathā vā hotu aññathā
analyzed: anussava siddhā ayam kathā iti dassetum kira ati vuttan ti vadanti tathā vā hotu aññathā
translated: In order to show that this is a matter established by tradition, “it is said” is stated, they say. Let it be so in that way or otherwise.

original: vā, attanā adiṭṭhaṃ, asutaṃ, amutañca anussavamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nīlapītalohitodātamañjiṭṭhapabhassaravasena
analyzed: vā attanā a diṭṭham a sutam a mutam ca anussavam eva ati daṭṭhabbam nīla pīta lohita udāta mañjiṭṭha pabhassara vasena
translated: “Kirā” is said to show that this is a tradition handed down by word of mouth. Let it be so in that way or in another way. It should be understood that what is not seen, heard, or sensed by oneself is only a tradition.

original: chabbaṇṇā. Samantāti samantato dasahi disāhi. Asītihatthappamāṇeti tesaṃ rasmīnaṃ🔽pakatiyā pavattiṭṭhānavasena vuttaṃ, tasmā samantato, upari ca paccekaṃ asītihatthamatte
analyzed: chabbaṇṇā samantā ati samantataḥ dasahi disāhi asīti hattha ppamāṇā iti tesam rasmīnam  pakatiyā pavatti ṭṭhāna vasena vuttam tasmā samantataḥ upari ca paccekam asīti hattha matte
translated: It is six-hued by virtue of its blue, yellow, red, white, crimson, and clear colors.🔽“All around” means all around in the ten directions. “Eighty leagues” is said by way of the natural range of the rays. Therefore it should be understood that all around and above, in a region of eighty leagues each, the rays naturally become dense.

original: padese pakatiyāva ghanībhūtā rasmiyo tiṭṭhantīti daṭṭhabbaṃ, vinayaṭīkāyaṃ pana “tāyeva
analyzed: padese pakatiyā ava ghanībhūtāḥ rasmiyaḥ tiṭṭhanti iti daṭṭhabbam vinayaṭīkāyam pana tāya iva
translated: But in the Vinaya Commentary it is said:

original: byāmappabhā nāma. Yato chabbaṇṇā rasmiyo taḷākato mātikā viya dasasu disāsu dhāvanti,
analyzed: byāmappabhāḥ nāma yatas chabbaṇṇāḥ rasmiyaḥ taḷākataḥ mātikāḥ viya dasasu disāsu dhāvanti
translated: “That is called the ‘effulgence of the fathom.’ From that the six-hued rays run in the ten directions like the veins in a leaf.🔽Since it appears as if it were a fathom long, it is called the ‘effulgence of the fathom.’ ”

original: sā yasmā byāmamattā viya khāyati, tasmā byāmappabhāti vuccatī”ti vuttaṃ, saṅgītisuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: sā yasmā byāma mattā viya khāyati tasmā byāmappabhā ati vuccati iti vuttam saṅgīti sutta vaṇṇanāyam
translated: In the commentary to the Saṅgīti Sutta it is said:

original: pana vakkhati “puratthimakāyato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ🔽gaṇhāti. Pacchimakāyato. Dakkhiṇahatthato. Vāmahatthato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā🔽asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Upari kesantato paṭṭhāya sabbakesāvaṭṭehi moragīvavaṇṇā
analyzed: pana vakkhati puratthima kāyataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattham ṭhānam  gaṇhāti pacchima kāyataḥ dakkhiṇa hatthataḥ vāma hatthataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā  asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti upari kesantataḥ paṭṭhāya sabba kesāvaṭṭehi moragī vavaṇṇā
translated: but he says: “A golden-coloured radiance arises from the front part of his body and extends for eighty cubits.🔽A golden-coloured radiance arises from the back part of his body and extends for eighty cubits. A golden-coloured radiance arises from the right hand and extends for eighty cubits. A golden-coloured radiance arises from the left hand and extends for eighty cubits.

original: rasmi uṭṭhahitvā gaganatale asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Heṭṭhā pādatalehi pavāḷavaṇṇā🔽rasmi uṭṭhahitvā ghanapathaviyaṃ asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Evaṃ samantā asītihatthamattaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā gagana tale asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti heṭṭhā pāda talehi pavāḷa vaṇṇā  rasmi uṭṭhahitvā ghana pathaviyam asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti evam samantā asīti hattha mattam
translated: A peacock-coloured radiance arises from all the curls of hair on the head and extends for eighty cubits in the sky.

original: ṭhānaṃ chabbaṇṇā buddharasmiyo vijjotamānā vipphandamānā vidhāvantī”ti keci pana
analyzed: ṭhānam chabbaṇṇāḥ buddha rasmiyaḥ vijjotamānāḥ vipphandamānāḥ vidhāvanti iti keci pana
translated: A coral-coloured radiance arises from the soles of the feet and extends for eighty cubits in the solid earth. Thus the eighty cubits all around are suffused, flooded, and drenched with the six-coloured Buddha-rays, which spread, expand, and extend.”

original: aññathāpi parikappanāmattena vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ tathā aññattha anāgatattā,
analyzed: aññathā api parikappanā mattena vadanti tat na gahetabbam tathā aññattha anāgata ttā
translated: But others say otherwise, merely by way of conjecture, and that should not be accepted, because it is not found elsewhere in the texts,

original: ayuttattā ca. Tāsaṃ pana buddharasmīnaṃ tadā aniggūhitabhāvadassanatthaṃ “tasmiṃ
analyzed: ayutta tā ca tāsam pana buddha rasmīnam tadā a niggūhita bhāva dassana attham tasmin

original: kira samaye”ti vuttaṃ. Pakkusātiabhiggamanādīsu viya hi tadā tāsaṃ niggūhane kiñci
analyzed: kira samaya iti vuttam pakkusāti abhiggamana ādīsu viya hi tadā tāsam niggūhane kiñci
translated: “At the time, it seems, they were not crying out.” For there was no reason for them to cry out, as there was in the case of the approach of the elephant, etc.

original: kāraṇaṃ natthi. Ādhāvantīti abhimukhaṃ disaṃ dhāvanti. Vidhāvantīti vividhā hutvā vidisaṃ dhāvanti.
analyzed: kāraṇam na atthi ādhāvanti iti abhimukham disam dhāvanti vidhāvanti iti vividhāḥ hutvā vidisam dhāvanti
translated: “They ran hither and thither”: they ran in all directions. “They ran in all directions”: they ran in all directions in various ways.

original: paññāyamānākāraviseso. Kuṭilaṃ aciraṭṭhāyittā virūpaṃ hutvā javati dhāvatīti vijju,
analyzed: paññāyamāna ākāra viseso kuṭilam virūpam hutvā javati dhāvati iti vijju
translated: and the difference in the mode of appearance is the difference in the mode of manifestation. The lightning is crooked, and it flashes and runs, having become distorted,

original: sāyeva latā taṃsadisabhāvenāti tathā, vāyuvegato valāhakaghaṭṭaneneva jātarasmi.
analyzed: sāyā iva latā taṃsadisa bhāvena ati tathā vāyu vegataḥ valāhaka ghaṭṭanena iva jātaḥ asmi
translated: and that creeper is like it in that respect, and so it is called “like lightning,” like the flame of a firebrand whirled around by the force of the wind.

original: Tāyati avijahanavasena ākāsaṃ pāletīti tārā, gaṇasaddo paccekaṃ yojetabbo. Tassa
analyzed: tāyati avijahana vasena ākāsam pāleti iti tārā gaṇa saddo paccekam yojetabbo tassa
translated: It shines, and it spreads out, pervading the sky without leaving any gaps, and so it is called “star,” and the word “group” should be construed with each of the three.

original: pabhā tathā. Vipphuritaviccharitamivāti ābhāya vividhaṃ pharamānaṃ, vijjotayamānaṃ
analyzed: pabhā tathā vipphurita viccharitam iva ati ābhāya vividham pharamānam vijjotayamānam
translated: Its light is like that.🔽It is as if it were scattered and diffused, and so it is called “constellation,” and the word “group” should be construed with each of the three.

original: viya ca. Vanassa antaraṃ vivaraṃ vanantaraṃ, bhagavatā pattapattavanappadesanti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Asītiyā anubyañjanehi tambanakhatādīhi anurañjitaṃ tathā. Kamalaṃ padumapuṇḍarīkāni,
analyzed: viya ca vanassa antaram vivaram vanantaram bhagavatā patta patta vana ppadesan ti vuttam hoti  anubyañjanehi tamba nakha tā ādīhi anurañjitam tathā kamalam paduma puṇḍarīkāni
translated: The interior of the forest is the space between the trees, and so it is called “forest interior.” The word “forest” is used here for the place where the trees are scattered.🔽It is adorned with the eighty minor characteristics such as the bronze-coloured nails, and so it is called “adorned.” The lotus is of five kinds: the white lotus, the blue lotus, the red lotus, the white water lily, and the white lotus.🔽The rest is the blue, the red, and the white water lily, and the white lotus.

original: avasesaṃ nīlarattasetabhedaṃ saroruhaṃ uppalaṃ, iti pañcavidhā paṅkajajāti pariggahitā🔽hoti. Vikasitaṃ phullitaṃ tadubhayaṃ yassa sarassa tathā. Sabbena pakārena parito
analyzed: avasesam nīla ratta seta bhedam saroruham uppalam iti pañcavidhā paṅkaja jāti pariggahitā 🔽hoti vikasitam phullitam tat ubhayam yassa sarassa tathā sabbena pakārena paritas
translated: The lake is fully blossomed, and it is fully spread out, and so it is called “blossomed.”

original: samantato phullati vikasatīti sabbapāliphullaṃ a-kārassa ā-kāraṃ, ra-kārassa ca la-kāraṃ
analyzed: samantataḥ phullati vikasati iti sabba pāli phullam akārassa ākāram rakārassa ca lakāram
translated: It is all-blossomed because it is all-blossomed and expanded. The letter a becomes ā, and the letter ra becomes la.

original: katvā yathā “pālibhaddo”ti, tārānaṃ marīci pabhā, tāya vikasitaṃ vijjotitaṃ tathā.
analyzed: katvā yathā marīci pabhā vikasitam vijjotitam tathā
translated: It is like the word pālibhaddā. The light of the stars is their radiance. It is expanded and illuminated by that.

original: Byāmappabhāya parikkhepo parimaṇḍalo, tena vilāsinī sobhinī tathā. Mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni
analyzed: byāma ppabhāya parikkhepo parimaṇḍalo tena vilāsinī sobhinī tathā mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni
translated: The enclosure of the light of the sky is circular. Therefore, it is a beauty, a splendor. The characteristics of a great man

original: aññamaññapaṭibaddhattā mālākāreneva ṭhitānīti vuttaṃ “dvattiṃsavaralakkhaṇamālā”ti.🔽Dvattiṃsacandādīnaṃ mālā kenaci ganthetvā paṭipāṭiyā ca ṭhapitāti na vattabbā “yadi
analyzed: añña mañña paṭibaddha ttā mālākārena iva ṭhitāni iti vuttam dvattiṃsa vara lakkhaṇa mālā ati  dvattiṃsa canda ādīnam mālā kenaci ganthetvā paṭipāṭiyā ca ṭhapitā ati na vattabbā yadi
translated: are said to be arranged in the form of a garland because they are mutually connected.🔽It cannot be said that a garland of thirty-two moons, etc., is arranged and placed in a row,

original: siyā”ti parikappanāmattena hi “ganthetvā ṭhapitadvattiṃsacandamālāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: siyā iti parikappanā mattena hi ganthetvā ṭhapita dvat tiṃsa canda mālāya itiādi vuttam
translated: because if it were so, it would be a mere supposition. Therefore, “a garland of thirty-two moons, etc., arranged and placed” is said by way of supposition.🔽This is a suppositional simile,

original: Parikappopamā hesā, lokepi ca dissati.
analyzed: parikappa upamā ha esā loke pi ca dissati
translated: and it is seen in the world too.

original: “Mayeva mukhasobhāsse, tyalaminduvikatthanā;
analyzed: mayā iva ti alam indu vikatthanā
translated: “These moon-like faces are ornaments for me alone,

original: Yatombujepi sātthīti, parikappopamā aya”nti.
analyzed: yatas ambuje pi sā atthi iti parikappa upamāḥ ayanti
translated: because they are useful even in a lotus flower. This is a suppositional simile.”

original: Dvattiṃsacandamālāya siriṃ attano siriyā abhibhavantī ivāti sambandho. Esa nayo sesesupi.🔽Evaṃ bhagavato tadā sobhaṃ dassetvā idāni bhikkhusaṅghassāpi sobhaṃ dassento “tañca
analyzed: dvattiṃsa canda mālāya sirim siriyā abhibhavantī iva ati sambandhaḥ esa nayaḥ sesesu pi  evam bhagavato tadā sobham dassetvā idāni bhikkhu saṅghassa api sobham dassento tat ca
translated: The construction is: “She, with her own beauty, as if surpassing the beauty of the thirty-two-threaded garland.” The same method applies to the rest.

original: panā”tiādimāha. Catubbidhāya appicchatāya appicchā. Dvādasahi santosehi santuṭṭhā.
analyzed: pana ati ādim āha catubbidhāya appicchatāya appicchā dvādasahi santosehi santuṭṭhā
translated: Having thus shown the beauty of the Exalted One, he now shows the beauty of the community of bhikkhus, saying “And that community of bhikkhus,” etc. They are “content” with the twelve kinds of contentment.

original: Tividhena vivekena pavivittā. Rājarājamahāmattādīhi asaṃsaṭṭhā. Duppaṭipattikānaṃ
analyzed: tividhena vivekena pavivittāḥ rāja rāja mahāmatta ādīhi asaṃsaṭṭhāḥ duppaṭipattikānam
translated: They are “secluded” by the threefold seclusion. They are “not socializing” with kings, royal ministers, etc. They are “rebukers” of those who practice badly.

original: codakā. Pāpe akusale garahino paresaṃ hitapaṭipattiyā vattāro. Paresañca vacanakkhamā.🔽Vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ nāma paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ. “Tesa”ntiādinā tadabhisambandhena bhagavato🔽sobhaṃ dasseti. Rattapadumānaṃ saṇḍo samūho vanaṃ, tassa majjhe gatā tathā. “Rattaṃ
analyzed: codakā pāpe akusale garahino paresam hita paṭipattiyāḥ vattāro paresam ca vacana kkhamā  vimutti ñāṇa dassanam nāma paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam tesan ti ādinā tad abhisambandhena bhagavataḥ  sobham dasseti ratta padumānam saṇḍaḥ samūhaḥ vanam tassa majjhe gatā tathā rattam
translated: They are “condemners” of evil, unwholesome things, and they are “advisers” in the practice of what is beneficial to others. They are “patient” with the speech of others.🔽“Knowledge and vision” is the knowledge of reviewing. With the words “And that community of bhikkhus,” etc., he shows the beauty of the Exalted One in connection with that . A “grove” is a collection, an assemblage of red lotuses. They are “gone to the middle” of that grove. “Red”

original: padumaṃ, setaṃ puṇḍarīka”nti pattaniyamamantarena tathā vuttaṃ, pattaniyamena pana
analyzed: padumam setam puṇḍarīkanti patta niyamam antarena tathā vuttam patta niyamena pana
translated: means “red lotus,” “white” means “white lotus.” This is said with reference to the distinction of the petals. With reference to the distinction of the petals, however,

original: satapattaṃ padumaṃ, ūnakasatapattaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ. Pavāḷaṃ viddumo, tena katāya vedikāya
analyzed: sata pattam padumam ūnaka sata pattam puṇḍarīkam pavāḷam tena katāya vedikāya
translated: The lotus has a hundred petals, the white lotus has less than a hundred petals. The coral tree is the viddhu.

original: parikkhitto viya. Migapakkhīnampīti pi-saddo, api-saddo vā sambhāvanāyaṃ, tenāha
analyzed: parikkhittaḥ viya miga pakkhīnam pi iti pi saddaḥ a pi saddaḥ vā sambhāvanā ayam tena āha
translated: It is as if surrounded by a balustrade made of that. The word ‘and’ in the phrase ‘deer and birds’ is a copulative conjunction, or it is a particle indicating a reason,

original: “pageva devamanussāna”nti. Mahātherāti mahāsāvake sandhāyāha. Surañjitabhāvena īsakaṃ
analyzed: pagā iva deva manussānam ti mahā therā ti mahā sāvake sandhāya āha su rañjita bhāvena īsakam
translated: hence he said ‘how much more so gods and men’. ‘Great elder’: he said this referring to the great disciples. Because of the colour of the gold it was a little

original: kaṇhavaṇṇatāya meghavaṇṇaṃ. Ekaṃsaṃ karitvāti ekaṃsapārupanavasena vāmaṃse karitvā.
analyzed: kaṇha vaṇṇa tāya megha vaṇṇam eka aṃsam karitvā iti eka aṃsa pārupana vasena vāma aṃse karitvā
translated: like the colour of a cloud. ‘Having placed it on one shoulder’: having placed it on the left shoulder in the manner of wearing it on one shoulder.

original: Kattarassa jiṇṇassa ālambano daṇḍo kattaradaṇḍo, bāhullavasenāyaṃ samaññā. Suvammaṃ
analyzed: kattarassa jiṇṇassa ālambanaḥ daṇḍo kattara daṇḍaḥ bāhulla vasena ayam samaññā su vammam
translated: A staff is a support for one who is old and worn out, a staff for the worn out. This is a common name for it. Gold

original: nāma sobhaṇuracchado, tena vammitā sannaddhāti suvammavammitā, idaṃ tesaṃ paṃsukūladhāraṇanidassanaṃ.
analyzed: nāma tena vammitā sannaddhā ati su vamma vammitā idam tesam paṃsukūla dhāraṇa nidassanam
translated: is a beautiful ornament, they are wrapped in it, covered with it, thus they are wrapped in gold. This shows how they wore their rag-robes.

original: Yesaṃ kucchigataṃ sabbampi tiṇapalāsādi gandhajātameva hoti, te gandhahatthino nāma,
analyzed: yesam kucchi gatam sabbam pi tiṇa palāsa ādi gandha jātam eva hoti te gandhahatthinaḥ nāma
translated: Those in whose bellies all the grass, leaves, etc., become fragrant are called fragrant-wind elephants,

original: ye “hemavatā”tipi vuccanti, tesampi therānaṃ sīlādiguṇagandhatāya taṃsadisatā. Antojaṭābahijaṭāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: ye hemavatā ati pi vuccanti tesam pi therānam sīla ādi guṇa gandha tāya antar jaṭā bahi jaṭā saṅkhātāya
translated: They are also called “Himalayan” because of the fragrance of their virtue, etc., like that mountain.

original: taṇhājaṭāya vijaṭitabhāvato vijaṭitajaṭā. Taṇhābandhanāya chinnattā chinnabandhanā.
analyzed: taṇhā jaṭāya vijaṭita bhāvataḥ vijaṭita jaṭā taṇhā bandhanāya chinnattā chinna bandhanā
translated: He is called “hair-matted” because he has disentangled the tangle of craving, which is called “inner hair-matting” and “outer hair-matting” . He is called “unfettered” because he has cut the fetter of craving.🔽“He” , etc., shows the virtues of the Blessed One as stated above.

original: “So”tiādi yathāvuttavacanassa guṇadassanaṃ. Anubuddhehīti buddhānamanubuddhehi. Tepi
analyzed: so ti ādi yathā vutta vacanassa guṇa dassanam anubuddhehi iti buddhānam anubuddhehi te pi
translated: “By those who have awakened after him” : by those who have awakened after the Buddhas.

original: hi ekadesena bhagavatā paṭividdhapaṭibhāgeneva cattāri saccāni bujjhanti. Pattaparivāritanti
analyzed: hi ekadesena bhagavatā paṭividdha paṭibhāgena iva cattāri saccāni bujjhanti patta parivāritanti
translated: For they awaken to the Four Noble Truths by the same method of penetration as the Blessed One.🔽“Surrounded by a wreath of flowers” : surrounded by a wreath of flower petals.

original: pupphadalena parivāritaṃ. Kaṃ vuccati kamalādi, tasmiṃ sarati virājatīti kesaraṃ,
analyzed: puppha dalena parivāritam kam vuccati kamala ādi tasmin sarati virājati iti kesaram
translated: A lotus is called a “kamala” . It “shines” in it, thus it is a “kesara” .🔽A “kiñjalkha” is a flower bud.

original: kiñjakkho. Kaṇṇe karīyatīti kaṇṇikā. Kaṇṇālaṅkāro, taṃsadisaṇṭhānatāya kaṇṇikā, bījakoso.
analyzed: kiñjakkhaḥ kaṇṇe karīyati iti kaṇṇikā kaṇṇālaṅkāraḥ taṃsa disaṇṭhāna tāya kaṇṇikā bīja kosaḥ
translated: A “kaṇṇikā” is a flower ornament. It is called a “kaṇṇikā” because it is worn in the ear, and it is a flower bud.

original: Channaṃ haṃsakulānaṃ seṭṭho dhataraṭṭho haṃsarājā viya, hārito nāma mahābrahmā viya.
analyzed: channam haṃsa kulānam seṭṭhaḥ dhataraṭṭhaḥ haṃsa rājā viya hāritaḥ nāma mahā brahmā
translated: Like the king of geese, Dhataraṭṭha, the best of the six kinds of geese; like the great brahmā named Hārita.

original: Evaṃ gacchantaṃ bhagavantaṃ, bhikkhū ca disvā attano parisaṃ olokesīti sambandho.
analyzed: evam gacchantam bhagavantam bhikkhū ca disvā attano parisam olokesi iti sambandho
translated: And seeing the Blessed One going thus and the bhikkhus, he looked at his own retinue.

original: Kājadaṇḍaketi kājasaṅkhāte bhārāvahadaṇḍake, kājasmiṃ vā bhāralaggitadaṇḍake. Khuddakaṃ
analyzed: kāja daṇḍaka iti kāja saṅkhāte bhāra āvaha daṇḍake kājasmin vā bhāra laggita daṇḍake khuddakam
translated: With a staff of bamboo: with a staff of bamboo called a “burden-bearer,” or with a staff of bamboo with a burden-bearing load.

original: pīṭhaṃ pīṭhakaṃ. Mūle, agge ca tidhā kato daṇḍo tidaṇḍo. Morahatthako morapiñchaṃ.
analyzed: pīṭham pīṭhakam mūle agge ca tidhā kataḥ daṇḍaḥ tidaṇḍaḥ morahatthakaḥ morapiñcham
translated: A small seat is a seatlet. A staff with three sections at the base and the top is a three-sectioned staff. A peacock’s foot is a peacock’s tail-feather.

original: Khuddakaṃ pasibbaṃ pasibbakaṃ. Kuṇḍikā kamaṇḍalu. Sā hi kaṃ udakaṃ udeti pasaveti,
analyzed: khuddakam pasibbam pasibbakam kuṇḍikā kamaṇḍalu sā hi kam udakam udeti pasaveti
translated: A small basket is a basketlet. A water-pot is a water-pot. For it is a water-pot in the sense of “it brings up water” ,

original: rakkhatīti vā kuṇḍikā niruttinayena. Gahitaṃ omakato lujjitaṃ, vividhaṃ lujjitañca
analyzed: rakkhati iti vā kuṇḍikā nirutti nayena gahitam omakataḥ lujjitam vividham lujjitam ca
translated: or in the sense of “it protects water” . What is taken and falls off is varied and fallen off.

original: pīṭhaka…pe… kuṇḍikādianekaparikkhārasaṅkhātaṃ bhāraṃ bharati vahatīti gahita…pe…
analyzed: kuṇḍikā ādi aneka parikkhāra saṅkhātam bhāram bharati vahati iti
translated: A seatlet … a water-pot … a burden consisting of many requisites such as a water-pot is borne, is carried, by him, thus it is taken …

original: bhārabharitā. Itīti nidassanattho. Evanti idamattho. Evaṃ idaṃ vacanamādi yassa vacanassa
analyzed: bhāra bharitāḥ iti iti nidassana atthaḥ evam ti idam atthaḥ evam idam vacanam ādi yassa vacanassa
translated: a burden-bearer. Thus is in the sense of pointing out. Thus is in the sense of this. Thus this speech, etc., is

original: tathā, tadeva niratthakaṃ vacanaṃ yassāti evamādiniratthakavacanā. Mukhaṃ etassa
analyzed: tathā tat eva niratthakam vacanam yassa ati evamādi niratthaka vacanā mukham etassa
translated: such speech as that. That is just meaningless speech.🔽The face of that

original: atthīti mukharā, sabbepi mukhavantā eva, ayaṃ pana pharusābhilāpamukhavatī, tasmā
analyzed: atthi iti mukharā sabbe pi mukhavantaḥ eva ayam pana pharusa abhilāpa mukhavatī tasmā
translated: “There is” : they are talkers. All of them are talkers, but this one is a talker of harsh speech. Therefore

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ. Nindāyañhi ayaṃ rapaccayo. Mukhena vā amanāpaṃ kammaṃ rāti gaṇhātīti
analyzed: evam vuttam nindā ayan hi ayam rapat cayaḥ mukhena vā amanāpam kammam rāti gaṇhāti iti
translated: it is said thus. For this is the condition for censure. Or, she is a talker because she delights in, takes up, harsh speech by way of mouth.

original: mukharā. Vividhā kiṇṇā vācā yassāti vikiṇṇavācā. Tassāti suppiyassa paribbājakassa.
analyzed: mukharā vividhā kiṇṇā vācā yassa ati vikiṇṇa vācā tassa ati suppiyassa paribbājakassa
translated: She is one of confused speech because she has various confused words. “To him” : to the wanderer Suppiya.

original: Nti yathāvuttappakāraṃ parisaṃ.
analyzed: nti yathāvutta pakāram
translated: “To that assembly” : to the assembly of that kind as described.

original: Idānīti tassa tathārūpāya parisāya dassanakkhaṇe. Panāti arucisaṃsūcanattho, tathāpīti🔽attho. Lābha…pe… hāniyā ceva hetubhūtāya. Kathaṃ hānīti āha “aññatitthiyānañhī”tiādi.
analyzed: idāni iti tassa tathārūpāya parisāya dassana kkhaṇe pana ati aruci saṃsūcana atthaḥ tathā api iti  atthaḥ lābha pe hāniyā ca iva hetu bhūtāya katham hāni iti āha añña titthiya anañhi itiādi
translated: “Now” : at the moment of seeing such an assembly. “But” : the meaning is “although” ; the meaning of “but” is to indicate displeasure.🔽Gain … loss : the cause of loss. How is there loss? “For the other sectarians” , etc.🔽“Without glory” : without glory, without fame. This meaning should be illustrated by the stories of the peacock, etc.

original: Nissirīkatanti nisobhataṃ, ayamattho morajātakādīhipi dīpetabbo. “Upatissakolitānañcā”tiādinā
analyzed: nissirīkatam ti ayam atthaḥ mora jātaka ādīhi pi dīpetabbaḥ
translated: “And the disciples of the teacher Upatissa” , etc.

original: pakkhahānitāya vitthāro. Āyasmato sāriputtassa, mahāmoggallānassa ca bhagavato santike
analyzed: pakkha hāni tāya vitthāraḥ āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa mahāmoggallānassa ca bhagavato santike
translated: is the elaboration of the loss of the faction. To the venerable Sāriputta and the venerable Mahāmoggallāna,

original: pabbajjaṃ sandhāya “tesu pana pakkantesū”ti vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ pabbajitakāleyeva aḍḍhateyyasataṃ
analyzed: pabbajjam sandhāya tesu pana pakkantesu iti vuttam tesam pabbajita kāleya iva aḍḍhateyya satam
translated: “Among them” refers to the going forth. At the time of their going forth, the assembly of wanderers numbered two hundred and fifty.

original: paribbājakaparisā pabbaji, tato parampi tadanupabbajitā paribbājakaparisā aparimāṇāti
analyzed: paribbājaka parisā pabbaji tatas param pi tad anupabbajitā paribbājaka parisā aparimāṇā ati
translated: The rest of the assembly of wanderers who had not gone forth was immeasurable.

original: dasseti “sāpi tesaṃ parisā bhinnā”ti iminā. Yāya kāyaci hi paribbājakaparisāya pabbajitāya
analyzed: dasseti sā api tesam parisā bhinnā ati iminā yāya kāyaci hi paribbājaka parisāya pabbajitāya
translated: This is shown by the words “that assembly of theirs was also split up.” For when any assembly of wanderers goes forth,

original: tassa parisā bhinnāyeva nāma samānagaṇattāti tathā vuttaṃ. “Imehī”tiādinā lābhapakkhahāniṃ
analyzed: tassa parisā bhinnāya iva nāma samāna gaṇa ttā ti tathā vuttam imehi itiādinā lābha pakkha hānim
translated: that assembly is called “split up” because it is no longer a single group. Thus it is said. By the words “and they lost their gains and fame,” he shows the loss of gains and fame by way of a conclusion.

original: nigamanavasena dasseti. Usūyasaṅkhātassa visassa uggāro uggilanaṃ usūyavisuggāro,🔽taṃ. Ettha ca “yasmā panesā”tiādināva “kasmā ca so ratanattayassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī”ti🔽codanaṃ visodheti, “sace”tiādikaṃ pana sabbampi tapparivāravacanamevāti tehipi sā
analyzed: nigamana vasena dasseti usūya saṅkhātassa visassa uggāraḥ uggilanam usūya visuggāraḥ  tam ettha ca yasmā kasmā ca saḥ ratanattayassa avaṇṇam bhāsati iti  codanam visodheti sacā iti ādikam pana sabbam pi tad parivāra vacanam evā ati tehi pi sā
translated: The vomiting of the poison called envy is the vomiting of envy.🔽Here, by the words “But because of this,” etc., he clears up the question “Why did he speak dispraise of the Triple Gem?” The rest, beginning with the words “If,” etc., is all merely a statement of his retinue.

original: visodhitāyeva nāma. Bhagavato virodhānunayābhāvavīmaṃsanatthaṃ ete avaṇṇaṃ vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: visodhitāya iva nāma bhagavataḥ virodha anunaya abhāva vīmaṃsana attham ete avaṇṇam vaṇṇam
translated: Therefore, by them too, it is cleared up. In order to test whether the Blessed One was free from hostility and affection, they spoke dispraise and praise of him.

original: bhāsanti. “Mārena anvāviṭṭhā evaṃ bhāsantī”ti ca keci vadanti, tadayuttameva aṭṭhakathāya🔽ujuvipaccanīkattā. Pākaṭoyevāyamatthoti.
analyzed: bhāsanti mārena anvāviṭṭhāḥ evam bhāsanti iti ca keci vadanti tat ayuttam eva aṭṭhakathāya  uju vipaccanīka ttā
translated: Some say that they speak thus being possessed by Mara. But that is not right, because it is contrary to the Commentary.🔽The meaning is quite clear.

original: 2. Yasmā atthaṅgato sūriyo, tasmā akālo dāni gantunti sambandho.
analyzed: yasmai atthaṅgataḥ sūriyo tasmai akālaḥ dāni gantunti sambandho
translated: The construction is: “Since the sun has set, it is now the wrong time to go.”

original: Ambalaṭṭhikāti sāmīpikavohāro yathā “varuṇanagaraṃ, godāgāmo”ti āha “tassa kirā”tiādi.
analyzed: ambalaṭṭhikā ati sāmīpika vohāraḥ yathā varuṇa nagaram godāgāmaḥ ti āha tassa kirāti ādi
translated: “Ambalaṭṭhikā” is a possessive compound, like “Varuṇas city” and “the village of Godhā.”

original: Taruṇapariyāyo laṭṭhikā-saddo rukkhavisaye yathā “mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā beluvalaṭṭhikāya🔽mūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdī”tiādīsūti dasseti” “taruṇambarukkho”ti iminā. Keci pana “ambalaṭṭhikā
analyzed: taruṇa pariyāyaḥ laṭṭhikā saddaḥ rukkha visaye yathā mahā vanam ajjhogāhetvā beluva laṭṭhikāya  mūle divāvihāram nisīdi itiādīsu uti dasseti taruṇa amba rukkho ti iminā keci pana amba laṭṭhikā
translated: The word “ambalaṭṭhikā” in the sense of a young tree is found in the expression “having entered the Great Wood, he sat down at the foot of a beluva sapling for the day’s abiding” .🔽This is shown by the words “a young mango tree.”

original: nāma vuttanayena eko gāmo”ti vadanti, tesaṃ mate ambalaṭṭhikāyanti samīpatthe bhummavacanaṃ.🔽Chāyūdakasampannanti chāyāya ceva udakena ca sampannaṃ. Mañjusāti peḷā. Paṭibhānacittavicittanti
analyzed: nāma vutta nayena ekaḥ gāmaḥ ti vadanti tesam mate ambalaṭṭhikāyanti samīpa atthe bhumma vacanam 🔽chāyūdaka sampannanti chāyāya ca iva udakena ca sampannam mañjusāti peḷā paṭibhāna citta vicittanti
translated: But some say that “ambalaṭṭhikā” is a village in the sense stated above. In their opinion the locative ending in “ambalaṭṭhikāya” has the meaning of vicinity.

original: itthipurisasaññogādinā paṭibhānacittena vicittaṃ, etena rañño agāraṃ, tadeva rājāgārakanti
analyzed: itthi purisa saññoga ādinā paṭibhāna cittena vicittam etena raññaḥ agāram tat eva rāja āgārakan ti
translated: and the king’s palace is variegated with the mind’s consciousness of the perception of a woman and a man, etc., and so on.

original: dasseti. Rājāgārakaṃ nāma vessavaṇamahārājassa devāyatananti eke.
analyzed: dasseti rājāgārakam nāma vessavaṇa mahā rājassa devāyatanan ti eke
translated: Some say that the king’s palace is the shrine of the Great King Vessavana.

original: Bahuparissayoti bahupaddavo. Kehīti vuttaṃ “core’hipī”tiādi. Handāti vacanavossaggatthe
analyzed: bahu parissayo ti bahu paddavaḥ kehi iti vuttam corehi pi itiādi handa ati vacana vossagga atthe
translated: “With many dangers” : with many perils. “By thieves” is said in the verse. “Handa” is an indeclinable expressing the giving up of speech.

original: nipāto, tadānubhāvato nipparissayatthāya idāni upagantvā sve gamissāmīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: nipātaḥ tadā anubhāvataḥ nipparissaya tthāya idāni upagantvā sve gamissāmi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is: “Having come now for the sake of being without danger by his power, I will go tomorrow.”

original: “Saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavenā” ticceva sīhaḷaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ, tañca
analyzed: saddhim antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena ticca iva sīhaḷaṭṭhakathāyam vuttam tat ca
translated: “Together with his pupil, the brahman student Brahmadatta” is said only in the Sinhalese Commentary.

original: kho pāḷiāruḷhavaseneva, na pana tadā suppiyassa parisāya abhāvatoti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: kho pāḷi āruḷha vasena iva na pana tadā suppiyassa parisāya abhāvato ti imam attham dassetuṃ
translated: But that is according to the text only, not because there was no assembly of Suppiya then. In order to show this meaning,

analyzed: saddhim attano parisāya iti idha vuttam kasmā pana ittha
translated: “together with his own assembly” is said here. But why is only Brahmadatta mentioned in the text,

analyzed: na pana tad avasesā suppiyassa parisā ati desanā anadhīna bhāvena payojana abhāvataḥ yathā
translated: and not the rest of Suppiya’s assembly? Because of the absence of purpose due to the absence of dependence on the teaching.

analyzed: evam aññam pi edisam payojana abhāvato saṅgīti kārakehi na saṅgītan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: This is the way to regard any other such passage as not included in the Collection because it has no purpose.

original: Keci pana “pāḷiyaṃ vutta”nti ādhāraṃ vatvā ‘tadetaṃ na sīhaḷaṭṭhakathānayadassanaṃ,🔽pāḷiyaṃ vuttabhāvadassanamevā’ti” vadanti, taṃ na yujjati. Pāḷiāruḷhavaseneva pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: keci pana pāḷiyam vuttanti ādhāram vatvā tat etam na sīhaḷaṭṭhakathā naya dassanam  pāḷiyam vutta bhāva dassanam evā ti vadanti tam na yujjati pāḷi āruḷha vasena iva pāḷiyam
translated: But some say that the meaning of the passage “in the texts” is not that it is seen in the Sihala Atthakathā,🔽but that it is seen in the texts, that is, in the scriptures. That is incorrect. For the meaning intended is included in the scriptures themselves,

original: vuttanti adhippetatthassa āpajjanato. Tasmā yathāvuttanayeneva attho gahetabboti.
analyzed: vuttam ti adhippeta tthassa āpajjanataḥ tasmā yathā vutta nayena iva atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ iti
translated: so that it is called “in the texts” because it is found in the scriptures.

analyzed: vuttanti vā amhehi pi idha vattabbanti attho evam hi tadā parisāya vijjamāna bhāva dassana ttham
translated: “Or else the meaning is this: ‘It is said’ means ‘it should be said by us here.’ For it is said in this way in order to show that it existed in the assembly even though it was not known to others.

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ, pāḷiyamāruḷhavasena pana aññathāpi idha vattabbanti adhippāyo yutto”ti vadanti.
analyzed: evam vuttam pāḷiyam āruḷha vasena pana aññathā api idha vattabbanti adhippāyaḥ yutto ti vadanti
translated: But the intention is that it should be said here in some other way too, according to what is found in the scriptures.”

original: Idāni “tatrāpi suda”ntiādipāḷiyā sambandhaṃ dassetuṃ “evaṃ vāsaṃ upagato panā”tiādi
analyzed: idāni tatra api su danti ādi pāḷiyā sambandham dassetum evam vāsam upagataḥ pana ati ādi
translated: Now, in order to show the connection with the passage beginning, “There too, ‘well’” , it is said: “But when he has thus taken up residence” ,

analyzed: vuttam parivāretvā nisinnaḥ hoti iti sambandho kucchitam kattabbanti kukatam tassa
translated: and the construction is: “he sits down surrounded.” “What is badly done” is what is done wrongly,

translated: “Fidgeting” is the state of fidgeting, the act of fidgeting, the meaning being that of moving this way and that. Fidgeting of the hand is

analyzed: tathā sā hi iti ādinā tathābhūta tāya kāraṇam dasseti nivātā iti vāta virahita ṭṭhāne  yathā vutta dosa abhāvena niccalā tam tādisam sobham vippalapanti iti sati vossagga vasena
translated: “And so” and what follows shows the reason for that state. “In a place free from wind” is in a place free from wind.

original: vividhā lapanti. Nillālitajivhāti ito cito ca nikkhantajivhā. Kākacchamānāti kākānaṃ🔽saddasadisaṃ saddaṃ kurumānā. Gharugharupassāsinoti gharugharuiti saddaṃ janetvā
analyzed: vividhāḥ lapanti nillālita jivhā ati itas citas ca nikkhanta jivhā kākacchamānā ati kākānam  sadda sadisam saddam kurumānāḥ gharu gharu passāsino ti gharu gharu iti saddam janetvā
translated: It is “motionless” because it is free from the faults stated. “That beauty” is such beauty. “Chattering” is talking in various ways by way of the loss of mindfulness. “With their tongues lolling” is with their tongues coming out this way and that. “Cawing” is making a sound like the

original: passasantā. Issāvasenāti yathāvuttehi dvīhi kāraṇehi usūyanavasena. “Sabbaṃ vattabba”nti
analyzed: passasantā issā vasena ati yathā vuttehi dvīhi kāraṇehi usūyana vasena sabbam vattabbanti
translated: cawing of crows. “Breathing noisily” is breathing out with a sound of “ghara-ghara.” “Out of envy” is by way of the two reasons stated. “All should be said”

original: iminā “ādipeyyālanayoya”nti dasseti.
analyzed: iminā dasseti
translated: shows that this is the method of the initial recitation.

original: 3. Sammā pahonti taṃ taṃ kammanti sampahulā, bahavo, tenāha “bahukāna”nti. Sabbantimena
analyzed: sammā pahonti tam tam kammanti sampahulāḥ bahavaḥ tena āha bahu kānanti
translated: “They are mixed up because they are capable of this and that action,” that is, they are many. Therefore it is said, “many.” “All”

analyzed: paricchedena catu vagga saṅghena iva vinaya kammassa kattabbattā vinaya pariyāyena atiādi
translated: “By the method of the Monastic Law” is said because the legal procedure of the Monastic Law must be done by a sangha of at least four monks by means of a resolution.

original: vuttaṃ. Tayo janāti cesa upalakkhaṇaniddeso dvinnampi sampahulattā. Tattha tattha
analyzed: vuttam tayaḥ ca isaḥ upalakkhaṇa niddeso dvinnam pi sampahula ttā tattha tattha
translated: “Three people” is a specification by way of a distinguishing mark, because two is a small gathering and🔽because it is stated in the same way in the various passages.

original: tathāyevāgatattā “suttantapariyāyenā”tiādimāha. Taṃ taṃ pāḷiyā āgatavohāravasena
analyzed: suttanta pariyāyena ati ādim āha tam tam pāḷiyā āgata vohāra vasena
translated: “By the method of the discourses” is said because of the usage stated in the various texts.

original: hi ayaṃ bhedo. Tayo janā tayo eva nāma, tato paṭṭhāya uttari catupañcajanādikā sampahulāti🔽attho. Tatoti cāyaṃ mariyādāvadhi. Maṇḍalamāḷoti anekatthapavattā samaññā, idha pana
analyzed: hi ayam bhedo eva nāma tatas paṭṭhāya uttari catu pañca jana ādikā  attho tatoti ca ayam mariyādā avadhi maṇḍalamāḷo ti aneka attha pavattā samaññā idha pana
translated: This is the distinction. Three people are just three people. From then on, four, five, and more are a large gathering.🔽This is the meaning.🔽“From then on” is the limit. “A circular building” is a common name used in many places. But here

original: īdisāya evāti niyamento āha “katthacī”tiādi. Kaṇṇikā vuccati kūṭaṃ. Haṃsavaṭṭakacchannenāti
analyzed: īdisāya eva ati niyamentaḥ āha katthaci itiādi kaṇṇikā vuccati kūṭam haṃsa vaṭṭaka channena ati
translated: the author specifies it as being like this, saying “in such and such a place”. A “corner” is called a “peak”. “With a roof like a swan’s outstretched wings”

original: haṃsamaṇḍalākārachannena. Tadeva channaṃ aññattha “supaṇṇavaṅkacchadana”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: haṃsa maṇḍala ākāra channena tat eva channam aññattha su paṇṇa vaṅka chadanam ti vuttam

original: parivāretvā, parimaṇḍalākārena thambhapantiṃ katvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Upaṭṭhānasālā nāma
analyzed: parivāretvā parimaṇḍala ākārena thambha pantim katvā iti vuttam hoti upaṭṭhānasālā nāma
translated: and they surrounded it, making a circular enclosure, is what is meant. The rest-house is
