analyzed: upaṭṭhāna mattam karonti na nisīdanam
translated: the hall for paying respect. Where they do the mere act of paying respect, not sitting for one night or two nights, etc.,

original: idha pana tathā katā nisīdanasālāyevāti dasseti “idha panā”tiādinā. Teneva pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: idha pana tathā katā nisīdana sālāya iva ati dassa iti idha pana ati ādinā tena iva pāḷiyam
translated: but here he shows that it is a sitting hall made in that way, with “Here, however, it is a sitting hall.” Therefore in the text

original: “sannipatitāna” ntveva avatvā “sannisinnāna”ntipi vuttaṃ. Mānitabboti māḷo, mīyati
analyzed: sannipatitāna ntu eva avatvā sannisinnāna nti pi vuttam mānitabbaḥ uti māḷaḥ mīyati
translated: it is said “sitting together” instead of “having come together.”

original: pamīyatīti vā māḷo. Maṇḍalākārena paṭicchanno māḷoti maṇḍalamāḷo, anekakoṇavanto
analyzed: pamīyati iti vā māḷaḥ maṇḍala ākārena paṭicchannaḥ māḷo ti maṇḍalamāḷaḥ aneka koṇavantaḥ
translated: The word māḷa is derived from the verb māyati , to be honoured, or from the verb mīyati , to be destroyed. A māḷa is a building enclosed in a circular form. A maṇḍalamāḷa is a special resting place with many corners.

original: paṭissayaviseso. “Sannisinnāna”nti nisajjanavasena vuttaṃ, nisajjanavasena vā “sannisinnāna”nti🔽saṃvaṇṇetabbapadamajjhāharitvā sambandho. Iminā nisīdanairiyāpathaṃ, kāyasāmaggīvasena
analyzed: paṭissaya visesaḥ sannisinnānam ti nisajjana vasena vuttam nisajjana vasena vā sannisinnānam ti  saṃvaṇṇetabba padam ajjhāharitvā sambandhaḥ iminā nisīdana eriyā patham kāya sāmaggī vasena
translated: “Sitting together” is said with reference to sitting. Or “sitting together” is said with reference to sitting.

original: ca samodhānaṃ sandhāya padadvayametaṃ vuttanti dasseti. Saṅkhiyā vuccati kathā sammā
analyzed: ca samodhānam sandhāya pada dvayam etam vuttanti dasseti saṅkhiyā vuccati kathā sammā
translated: The connection is made by omitting the word to be praised. By this he shows that these two terms are said with reference to the posture of sitting and to the concord of body and mind.🔽Conversation is said to be talk.

original: khiyanato kathanato. Kathādhammoti kathāsabhāvo, upaparikkhā vidhīti keci.
analyzed: khiyanataḥ kathanataḥ kathā dhammo ti kathā sabhāvaḥ upaparikkhā vidhi iti keci
translated: and by way of the ‘talk’ and by way of the ‘discussion’. ‘Talk about the Dhamma’ means the nature of the talk, some say it is the method of investigation.

original: “Acchariya”ntiādi tassa rūpadassananti āha “katamo pana so”tiādi. Soti kathādhammo.
analyzed: tassa rūpa dassananti āha katamaḥ pana saḥ tiādi saḥ ti kathā dhammo
translated: ‘Wonderful’ and so on is the seeing of that, therefore it is said: “But what is that?” and so on. ‘That’ means the talk about the Dhamma.

original: “Nīyatīti nayo, attho, saddasatthaṃ anugato nayo saddanayo”ti ācariyadhammapālattherena
analyzed: nīyati iti nayaḥ attho sadda sattham anugataḥ nayaḥ sadda nayo ti ācariya dhammapāla ttherena
translated: “The method is that which leads, the meaning, the method that follows the sound and the letter,” was said by the teacher Dhammapāla.

original: vuttaṃ. Nīyati attho etenāti vā nayo, upāyo, saddasatthe āgato nayo atthagahaṇūpāyo
analyzed: vuttam nīyati atthaḥ etena ati vā nayaḥ upāyaḥ sadda satthe āgataḥ nayaḥ attha gahaṇa upāyaḥ
translated: Or it is the method because the meaning is led by it, the method is the means, the method that has come into the sound and the letter is the means of grasping the meaning,

original: saddanayo. Tattha hi anabhiṇhavuttike acchariya-saddo icchito ruḷhivasena. Tenevāha
analyzed: tattha hi an abhiṇhavuttike acchariya saddaḥ icchitaḥ ruḷhi vasena tena iva āha
translated: the method of the sound. For in that (method) the wonderful sound is intended for one who does not use it often, by way of the natural law. Therefore it is said:

original: “andhassa pabbatārohaṇaṃ viyā”tiādi. Tassa hi tadārohaṇaṃ na niccaṃ, kadāciyeva siyā,
analyzed: andhassa pabbata ārohaṇam viya atiādi tassa hi tad ārohaṇam na niccam kadāci iva iva siyā
translated: “Like the blind man’s climbing the mountain,” and so on. For his climbing that (mountain) is not constant, it may only be sometimes,

original: evamidampi. Accharāyoggaṃ acchariyaṃ niruttinayena yoggasaddassa lopato, taddhitavasena
analyzed: evam idam pi accharāyoggam acchariyam nirutti nayena yogga saddassa lopataḥ taddhita vasena
translated: so it is like this. The wonderful is a compound of the wonderful and the difficult, by way of the method of etymology the word ‘difficult’ is omitted, or by way of the affix

original: vā ṇiyapaccayassa vicitravuttito, so pana porāṇaṭṭhakathāyameva āgatattā “aṭṭhakathānayo”ti
analyzed: vā ṇiya paccayassa vicitra vuttitaḥ saḥ pana porāṇa ṭṭhakathā ayam eva āgata ttā aṭṭhakathā anayā iti
translated: the condition ‘ṇiya’ has a varied usage. But because that (method) has come into the old commentary it is called “the method of the commentary,”

original: vutto. Pubbe abhūtanti abhūtapubbaṃ, etena na bhūtaṃ abhūtanti nibbacanaṃ, bhūta-saddassa
analyzed: vuttaḥ pubbe abhūtanti abhūta pubbam etena na bhūtam abhūtanti nibbacanam bhūta saddassa
translated: . Formerly there was: there was formerly, by this he shows the explanation: “not what was there was not” . And he shows the meaning of the past tense in the word bhūta .

original: ca atītatthaṃ dasseti. Yāvañcidanti sandhivasena niggahitāgamoti āha “yāva ca ida”nti,🔽etassa ca “suppaṭividitā”ti etena sambandho. Yāva cayattakaṃ idaṃ ayaṃ nānādhimuttikatā
analyzed: ca atīta attham dasseti sandhi vasena āha ca  etassa ca suppaṭividitā ti etena sambandhaḥ yāva cayattakam idam ayam nānā adhimuttika tā
translated: As far as: the ending is elided by sandhi, thus he says “as far as this” .

original: suppaṭividitā, taṃ “ettakamevā”ti na sakkā amhehi paṭivijjhituṃ, akkhātuñcāti sapāṭhasesattho.
analyzed: su paṭividitā tam ettakam evā ti na sakkā amhehi paṭivijjhitum akkhātum ca ati sa pāṭha sesa tthaḥ
translated: And the connection of this with “well penetrated” is this: as far as this is the case, this diversity of views is well penetrated by us, it is not possible for us to penetrate it any further, and to declare it. The meaning is: with the remainder of the text.

original: Tenevāha “tena suppaṭividitatāya appameyyataṃ dassetī”ti.
analyzed: tena iva āha tena suppaṭividita tāya appameyya tam dasseti iti
translated: Therefore he says: “by that well penetration he shows the immeasurableness” .

original: “Bhagavatā”tiādīhi padehi samānādhikaraṇabhāvena vuttattā tenāti ettha ta-saddo sakatthapaṭiniddeso,
analyzed: bhagavatā ati ādīhi padehi samāna adhikaraṇa bhāvena vutta ttā tena ati ettha ta saddo saka attha paṭiniddesaḥ
translated: Since the words “by the Blessed One” are stated in the same case, the word ta in the expression tena is a demonstrative pronoun referring to the same thing.

original: tasmā yena abhisambuddhabhāvena bhagavā pakato samāno supākaṭo nāma hoti, tadabhisambuddhabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tasmai yena abhisambuddha bhāvena bhagavā pakataḥ samānaḥ supākaṭaḥ nāma hoti tad abhisambuddha bhāvam
translated: Therefore, by the state of enlightenment by which the Blessed One, being cooked, became well cooked, and was called well cooked, he shows that state of enlightenment

original: saddhiṃ āgamanapaṭipadāya tassa atthabhāvena dassento “yo so”tiādimāha. Na hettha
analyzed: saddhim āgamana paṭipadāya tassa attha bhāvena dassentaḥ yaḥ saḥ ti ādim āha na ha ittha
translated: together with the way of coming, by the meaning of that, saying “that which” . Here

original: so pubbe vutto atthi, yo attho tehi therehi ta-saddena parāmasitabbo bhaveyya. Tasmā
analyzed: saḥ pubbe vuttaḥ atthi yaḥ attho tehi therehi ta saddena parāmasitabbaḥ bhaveyya tasmā
translated: and there is a meaning that was previously stated which should be taken up by those Elders with the word ‘ta.’ Therefore

original: yathāvuttaguṇasaṅkhātaṃ sakatthaṃyevesa padhānabhāvena parāmasatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Anuttaraṃ🔽sammāsambodhinti aggamaggañāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ, anāvaraṇañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca🔽aggamaggañāṇaṃ. Tadubhayañhi sammā aviparītaṃ sayameva bujjhati, sammā vā pasaṭṭhā🔽sundaraṃ bujjhatīti sammāsambodhi. Sā pana buddhānaṃ sabbaguṇasampattiṃ deti abhiseko
analyzed: yathā vutta guṇa saṅkhātam padhāna bhāvena parāmasati iti daṭṭhabbam anuttaram  sammāsambodhim ti aggamagga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam anāvaraṇa ñāṇam anāvaraṇa ñāṇa padaṭṭhānañca  agga magga ñāṇam tat ubhayam hi sammā aviparītam sayam eva bujjhati sammā vā pasaṭṭhā  sundaram bujjhati iti sammāsambodhi sā pana buddhānam sabba guṇa sampattim deti abhisekaḥ
translated: it should be regarded as taking up its own meaning, which is called the aforesaid characteristic, as the principal thing.

original: viya rañño sabbalokissariyabhāvaṃ, tasmā “anuttarā sammāsambodhī”ti vuccati. Abhisambuddhoti
analyzed: viya rañño sabba loka issariya bhāvam tasmai anuttarā sammāsambodhī iti vuccati abhisambuddhā ti
translated: The supreme perfect enlightenment: knowledge without obstruction, which has the knowledge of the path of the highest fruit as its basis, and the knowledge of the path of the highest fruit, which has knowledge without obstruction as its basis. For both of these are perfectly, i.e. non-erroneously, enlightened by oneself, or they perfectly, i.e. beautifully, enlighten the one who is rightly inclined. Thus it is called perfect enlightenment. But this gives the Blessed One the perfection of all the special qualities of a Buddha, just as the anointing gives a king the lordship over all the people. Therefore it is called the supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: abbhaññāsi paṭivijjhi, tena tādisena bhagavatāti attho. Satipi ñāṇadassanānaṃ idha
analyzed: paṭivijjhi tena tādisena bhagavatā ati atthaḥ sati pi ñāṇa dassanānam idha
translated: Enlightened: penetrated, broke through. The meaning is: the Blessed One was such. Although here knowledge and insight are synonyms for wisdom,

original: paññāvevacanabhāve tena tena visesena nesaṃ visayavisesappavattiṃ dassento “tesaṃ
analyzed: paññā vevacana bhāve tena tena visesena nesam visaya visesa ppavattim dassento tesam
translated: showing their occurrence with a particular object by means of a particular distinction, he said: “of those

original: tesaṃ sattāna”ntiādimāha. Ettha hi paṭhamamatthaṃ asādhāraṇañāṇavasena dasseti. Āsayānusayañāṇena🔽jānatā sabbaññutānāvaraṇañāṇehi passatāti attho.
analyzed: tesam sattānam ti ādim āha ettha hi paṭhamam attham asādhāraṇa ñāṇa vasena dasseti āsaya anusaya ñāṇena  jānatā sabbaññu tā anāvaraṇa ñāṇehi passatā iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he knows with the knowledge of the way to penetrate to the deathless and he sees with the knowledge of the way to penetrate to the deathless and with the unobstructed knowledge that is omniscience.🔽In the second case he shows it by means of the three kinds of clear-vision.

original: Dutiyaṃ vijjattayavasena. Pubbenivāsādīhīti pubbenivāsāsavakkhayañāṇehi. Tatiyaṃ🔽abhiññānāvaraṇañāṇavasena. Abhiññāpariyāpannepi “tīhi vijjāhī”ti tāsaṃ rāsibhedadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam vijjattaya vasena pubbenivāsa ādīhi iti pubbenivāsa āsava kkhaya ñāṇehi tatiyam  abhiñāna āvaraṇa ñāṇa vasena abhiññā pariyāpanne pi tīhi vijjāhi iti tāsam rāsi bheda dassana ttham
translated: In the third case he shows it by means of the knowledge that is the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision and the knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of the all-seeing knowledge called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.

original: vuttaṃ. Anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātena samantacakkhunā passatāti attho. Catutthaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇamaṃsacakkhuvasena.
analyzed: vuttam anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātena samanta cakkhunā passatā ti attho catuttham sabbaññuta ññāṇa maṃsa cakkhu vasena
translated: The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.

original: Paññāyāti sabbaññutaññāṇena. Kuṭṭassa bhittiyā tiro paraṃ, anto vā, tadādīsu gatāni.🔽Ativisuddhenāti ativiya visuddhena pañcavaṇṇasamannāgatena sunīlapāsādikaakkhilomasamalaṅkatena
analyzed: paññāyāti sabbaññuta ññāṇena kuṭṭassa bhittiyā tiras param antar vā tad ādīsu gatāni 🔽ati visuddhena ati visuddhena pañca vaṇṇa samannāgatena su nīla pāsādika akkhiloma samalaṅkatena
translated: The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omniscience called “knowledge that is the surmounting of the direct-knowledge of the three kinds of clear-vision.” In the fourth case he shows it by means of the eye of flesh and the eye of omniscience.🔽The meaning is that he sees with the eye of omnis

original: rattiñceva divā ca samantā yojanaṃ passantena maṃsacakkhunā. Pañcamaṃ paṭivedhadesanāñāṇavasena.
analyzed: rattim ca iva divā ca samantā yojanam passantena maṃsacakkhunā pañcamam paṭivedha desanā ñāṇa vasena
translated: and by means of the knowledge of the description of penetration, he sees a league all round by day and by night with his physical eyes.

original: “Attahitasādhikāyā”ti ekaṃsato vuttaṃ, pariyāyato panesā parahitasādhikāpi hoti.
analyzed: atta hita sādhikāya iti ekaṃsataḥ vuttam pariyāyataḥ pana esā para hita sādhikā api hoti
translated: “For the sake of his own welfare” is said in one respect, but in another respect it is also for the sake of others’ welfare.

original: Tāya hi dhammasabhāvapaṭicchādakakilesasamugghātāya desanāñāṇādi sambhavati. Paṭivedhapaññāyāti
analyzed: tāya hi dhamma sabhāva paṭicchādaka kilesa samugghātāya desanā ñāṇa ādi sambhavati paṭivedha paññāya ati
translated: For by it the defilements that conceal the true nature of dhammas are removed, and so the knowledge of the description, etc., becomes possible.

original: ariyamaggapaññāya. Vipassanāsahagato samādhi padaṭṭhānaṃ āsannakāraṇametissāti samādhipadaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: ariya magga paññāya vipassanā sahagataḥ samādhi padaṭṭhānam āsanna kāraṇam etissa ati samādhi padaṭṭhānā
translated: By means of the understanding of penetration: by means of the understanding of the noble path. Concentration is the proximate cause of insight, and so it is called the footing for it.

original: tāya. Desanāpaññāyāti desanākiccanipphādakena sabbaññutaññāṇena. Arīnanti kilesārīnaṃ,🔽pañcamārānaṃ vā, sāsanapaccatthikānaṃ vā aññatitthiyānaṃ. Tesaṃ hananaṃ pāṭihāriyehi
analyzed: tāya desanā paññāya ati desanā kicca nipphādakena sabbaññuta ññāṇena arīnanti kilesa arīnam  pañca mārānam vā sāsana paccatthikānam vā añña titthiyānam tesam hananam pāṭihāriyehi
translated: By means of the understanding of the description: by means of the knowledge of omniscience that accomplishes the task of description.🔽The enemies: the enemies that are defilements, or the five enemies, or the sectarians who are adversaries of the Dispensation. The slaying of them is the overawing of them by miracles, the making of them incapable of reply, and the ignoring of them.

original: abhibhavanaṃ appaṭibhānatākaraṇaṃ, ajjhupekkhanañca majjhimapaṇṇāsake pañcamavagge
analyzed: abhibhavanam appaṭibhāna tā karaṇam ajjhupekkhanam ca majjhima paṇṇāsake pañcama vagge
translated: And the ignoring of them is treated in the fifth chapter of the middle section of the Majjhima Nikāya.

original: saṅgītaṃ caṅkīsuttañcettha nidassanaṃ, etena arayo hatā anenāti niruttinayena padasiddhimāha.
analyzed: saṅgītam caṅkīsuttam ca ittha nidassanam etena arayaḥ hatāḥ anena ati nirutti nayena pada siddhim āha
translated: The Sutta on the Chanting together is the example here. By the method of derivation he shows the derivation of the word.

original: Ato nāvacanassa tābyappadeso mahāvisayenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Apica arayo hanatīti antasaddena🔽padasiddhi, ikārassa ca akāro. Paccayādīnaṃ sampadānabhūtānaṃ, tesaṃ vā paṭiggahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: a tassa na a vacanassa tābi appadesaḥ mahā visayena ati daṭṭhabbam apica arayaḥ hanati iti anta saddena  pada siddhi ikārassa ca akāraḥ paccaya ādīnam sampadāna bhūtānam tesam vā paṭiggahaṇam
translated: So the word “tāva” should be regarded as a particle indicating limitation of meaning.🔽And by the word “han” he shows the derivation of the word “araya” as “one who destroys enemies” and the change of the vowel of the syllable “i” to “a”.

original: paṭiggahituṃ vā arahatīti arahanti dasseti “paccayādīnañca arahattā”ti iminā. Sammāti🔽aviparītaṃ. Sāmañcāti sayameva, aparaneyyo hutvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kathaṃ panettha “sabbadhammāna”nti🔽ayaṃ viseso labbhatīti? Sāmaññajotanāya visese avaṭṭhānato, visesatthinā ca visesassa
analyzed: paṭiggahitum vā arahati iti arahanti dasseti paccaya ādīnam ca arahattā ati iminā sammā ti  aviparītam sāmañcā ati sayam eva aparaneyyaḥ hutvā iti vuttam hoti katham pana ittha sabba dhammānam ti  ayam visesaḥ labbhati iti sāmañña jotanāya visese avaṭṭhānataḥ visesatthinā ca visesassa
translated: And by the words “because of his worthiness to receive” he shows the derivation of the word “arahant” as “one worthy to receive requisites” and so on, which are the conditions for the arising of the noble states, or as “one worthy to receive” those noble states themselves.🔽“Rightly” means without distortion. “By himself” means by himself alone, without depending on another.🔽But how is the distinction “of all ideas” to be understood here?

original: anupayojetabbato yajjevaṃ “dhammāna”nti visesovānupayojito siyā, kasmā sabbadhammānanti
analyzed: anupayojetabbataḥ yat jevam dhammānan ti visesaḥ uvā anupayojitaḥ siyā kasmā sabba dhammānan ti
translated: Because the general principle is not restricted to the distinction, and because the distinction cannot be made by one who is not concerned with the distinction, just as the distinction “of ideas” cannot be made by one not concerned with it, why is it said “of all ideas”

original: ayamattho anupayojīyatīti? Ekadesassa aggahaṇato. Padesaggahaṇe hi asati gahetabbassa
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ ekadesassa a gahaṇato padesa ggahaṇe hi asati gahetabbassa
translated: Does this meaning not serve a purpose? Because of the non-inclusion of one part. For if there were no inclusion of a part,

original: nippadesatā viññāyati yathā “dikkhito na dadātī”ti, esa nayo īdisesu.
analyzed: nippadesa tā viññāyati yathā dikkhitaḥ na dadāti iti esa nayaḥ īdisesu
translated: the non-partness of what is to be included would be known, just as in “One seen in the direction does not give.” This is the method in such cases.

original: Idāni ca catūhi padehi catuvesārajjavasena attanā adhippetataraṃ chaṭṭhamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: idāni ca catūhi padehi catu vesārajja vasena attanā adhippetataram chaṭṭham attham dassetuṃ
translated: And now, in order to show by means of four terms the sixth meaning intended by himself by way of the four grounds for self-confidence,

original: “antarāyikadhamme vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tathā hi tadeva nigamanaṃ karoti “eva”ntiādinā.🔽Tattha antarāyakaradhammañāṇena jānatā, niyyānikadhammañāṇena passatā, āsavakkhayañāṇena
analyzed: antarāyika dhamme vā itiādi vuttam tathā hi tat eva nigamanam karoti evam iti ādinā  tattha antarāya kara dhamma ñāṇena jānatā niyyānika dhamma ñāṇena passatā āsava kkhaya ñāṇena
translated: “or in the case of things that are obstacles,” etc., is said. Thus he makes the conclusion with “thus” , etc.

original: arahatā, sabbaññutaññāṇena sammāsambuddhenaāti yathākkamaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Anatthacaraṇena🔽kilesā eva arayoti kilesārayo, tesaṃ kilesārīnaṃ. Etthāha – yassa ñāṇassa vasena
analyzed: arahatā sabbaññu ta ññāṇena sammāsambuddhena ā ti yathākkamam yojetabbam anattha caraṇena  kilesāḥ eva arayo ti kilesa arayo tesam kilesa arīnam ettha āha yassa ñāṇassa vasena
translated: Herein, he who knows by means of the knowledge of the things that are obstacles, he who sees by means of the knowledge of the things that are emancipations, he who is a Worthy One by means of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers, he who is a Fully Enlightened One by means of the knowledge of omniscience—thus it should be construed in due sequence. By the doing of what is unprofitable

original: sammā sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā bhagavā sammāsambuddho nāma jāto, kiṃ panidaṃ
analyzed: sammā sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā bhagavā sammāsambuddhaḥ nāma jātaḥ kim panidam
translated: the defilements themselves are enemies, thus they are defilement-enemies. Herein, it may be asked: By means of what knowledge is it that the Blessed One is called “Fully Enlightened” because he has enlightened himself fully and rightly about all things? But what is this knowledge?

original: ñāṇaṃ sabbadhammānaṃ bujjhanavasena pavattamānaṃ sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati,
analyzed: ñāṇam sabba dhammānam bujjhana vasena pavattamānam sakiṃyeva sabbasmin visaye pavattati
translated: Knowledge, occurring as the act of knowing all things, does one penetrate all its objective fields at once,

original: udāhu kamenāti. Kiñcettha – yadi tāva sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati, evaṃ
analyzed: udāhu kamena ati kiñca ittha yadi tāva sa kiṃyā iva sabbasmin visaye pavattati evam
translated: or does one do so by parts? What is the point here? If it is at once, then

original: sati atītānāgatapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhādibhedabhinnānaṃ saṅkhatadhammānaṃ, asaṅkhatasammutidhammānañca
analyzed: sati atīta anāgata paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddhā ādi bheda bhinnānam saṅkhata dhammānam asaṅkhata sammuti dhammānam ca
translated: in that case, since it occurs thus, there would be no apprehension of the distinction of formed things classed as past, future, and present, internal and external, and so on, and of the conventional things classed as unformed and conventional,

original: ekajjhaṃ upaṭṭhāne dūrato cittapaṭaṃ pekkhantassa viya paṭibhāgenāvabodho na siyā,🔽tathā ca sati “sabbe dhammā anattā”ti vipassantānaṃ anattākārena viya sabbe dhammā
analyzed: ekajjham upaṭṭhāne dūratas citta paṭam pekkhantassa viya paṭibhāgena avabodhaḥ na siyā  tathā ca sati sabbe dhammā anattā ati vipassantānam anatta ākārena viya sabbe dhammā
translated: as there would be if one were looking at a painted canvas from a distance.🔽And if that were so, then all things would be the objective field of the Blessed One’s knowledge in the same way as they are of those who see them as non-self by insight into non-self.

original: anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇavisayā hontīti āpajjati. Yepi “sabbañeyyadhammānaṃ🔽ṭhitilakkhaṇavisayaṃ vikapparahitaṃ sabbakālaṃ buddhānaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattati, tena te
analyzed: anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇa visayāḥ honti iti āpajjati ye pi sabba ñeyya dhammānam  ṭhiti lakkhaṇa visayam vikappa rahitam sabbakālam buddhānam ñāṇam pavattati tena te
translated: And those who say that the Blessed One’s knowledge occurs at all times without making anything its object, like the space in a gabled room,🔽and that it is only the knowledge of disciples that occurs with a made object, like the space in a waterpot,🔽and that therefore the Blessed One is omniscient in the sense that he is able to know all things, but not in the sense that he knows all things at a single time,

original: ‘sabbavidū’ti vuccanti. Evañca katvā –🔽‘Gacchaṃ samāhito nāgo, ṭhito nāgo samāhito;
analyzed: vuccanti evam ca katvā 🔽gaccham samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ ṭhitaḥ nāgaḥ samāhitaḥ
translated: and that consequently the Blessed One’s knowledge is not all-seeing,

original: Seyyaṃ samāhito nāgo, nisinnopi samāhito’ti. ; –
analyzed: sā iyyam samāhitaḥ nāgaḥ nisinnaḥ api samāhita uti
translated: “The elephant in trance, the elephant in trance when sitting” .

original: Idampi sabbadā ñāṇappavattidīpakaṃ aṅguttarāgame nāgopamasuttavacanaṃ suvuttaṃ nāma🔽hotī”ti vadanti, tesampi vāde vuttadosā nātivatti. Ṭhitilakkhaṇārammaṇatāya ca atītānāgatadhammānaṃ
analyzed: idam api sabbadā ñāṇa ppavatti dīpakam aṅguttara āgame nāgopama sutta vacanam su vuttam nāma  hoti iti vadanti tesam pi vāde vutta dosā na ativatti ṭhiti lakkhaṇa ārammaṇa tāya ca atīta anāgata dhammānam
translated: This too is well said, they say, in the Anguttara Nikāya in the text of the Elephant Simile .🔽But in their doctrine the aforesaid objections are not overcome. And because the object of the Blessed One’s knowledge is the three characteristics of impermanence, etc., of present states only, his knowledge must have only a limited field,

original: tadabhāvato ekadesavisayameva bhagavato ñāṇaṃ siyā, tasmā sakiññeva sabbasmiṃ visaye
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ eka desa visayam eva bhagavataḥ ñāṇam siyā tasmā sa kiññā iva sabbasmin visaye
translated: since past and future states do not exist. Therefore it is not proper to say that his knowledge extends to the whole field.

original: ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti na yujjati. Atha kamena sabbasmimpi visaye ñāṇaṃ pavattati, evampi🔽na yujjati. Na hi jātibhūmisabhāvādivasena, disādesakālādivasena ca anekabhedabhinne
analyzed: ñāṇam pavattati iti na yujjati atha kamena sabbasmim pi visaye ñāṇam pavattati evam pi  na yujjati na hi jāti bhūmi sabhāva ādi vasena disā desa kāla ādi vasena ca aneka bheda bhinne
translated: If it is claimed that his knowledge extends to the whole field by degrees, that is not proper either.

original: ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesapaṭivedho sambhavati apariyantabhāvato ñeyyassa.
analyzed: ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesa paṭivedho sambhavati a pariyanta bhāvataḥ ñeyyassa
translated: For when the knowable, which is differentiated in many ways by way of species, plane, nature, etc., and by way of direction, location, time, etc., is apprehended by degrees, it is not possible to penetrate it without remainder, because the knowable is infinite.

original: Ye pana “atthassa avisaṃvādanato ñeyyassa ekadesaṃ paccakkhaṃ katvā sesepi evanti
analyzed: ye pana atthassa avisaṃvādanato ñeyyassa eka desam paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti
translated: But those who say that the Blessed One’s knowledge extends to the whole field by degrees, claiming that it is like the knowledge of a person who, having seen one part of a field, infers the rest in the same way, on the grounds that the Blessed One’s knowledge is not contradicted in regard to the meaning of what is seen,

original: adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū nāma bhagavā jāto, tañca ñāṇaṃ na anumānikaṃ
analyzed: adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū nāma bhagavā jātaḥ tat ca ñāṇam na anumānikam
translated: and by determining it after resolving upon it, the Blessed One became one who knows all. And that knowledge is not inferential.

original: nāma saṃsayābhāvato. Saṃsayānubaddhañhi ñāṇaṃ loke anumānika”nti vadanti, tesampi🔽taṃ na yuttameva. Sabbassa hi appaccakkhabhāve atthāvisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa ekadesaṃ
analyzed: nāma saṃsaya abhāvataḥ saṃsaya anubaddham hi ñāṇam loke anumānikam ti vadanti tesam pi  tat na yuttam eva sabbassa hi appaccakkha bhāve attha avisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa eka desam
translated: because there is no doubt. For they say in the world that knowledge is inferential when it is accompanied by doubt.

original: paccakkhaṃ katvā sesepi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanasseva asambhavato tathā asakkuṇeyyattā
analyzed: paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanassa iva asambhavataḥ tathā a sakkuṇeyya ttā
translated: But that is not right. For if all were beyond his direct knowledge, then it would be impossible for him to determine the rest after resolving upon it by making one part of the knowable directly known by the non-deceptive act of seeing,🔽because it would be impossible for him to do so.

original: ca. Yañhi sesaṃ, tadapaccakkhameva, atha tampi paccakkhaṃ, tassa sesabhāvo eva na
analyzed: ca yat hi sesam tat apaccakkham eva atha tam pi paccakkham tassa sesa bhāvaḥ eva na
translated: For what remains beyond his direct knowledge is not so, and if that too were directly known, then it would not be the rest,🔽because the knowable is infinite. It is impossible to determine it thus.

original: siyā, apariyantabhāvato ñeyyassa tathāvavatthitumeva na sakkāti? Sabbametaṃ akāraṇaṃ.🔽Kasmā? Avisayavicāraṇabhāvato. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā “buddhānaṃ bhikkhave, buddhavisayo
analyzed: siyā apariyanta bhāvataḥ ñeyyassa tathā avavatthitum eva na sakkāti sabbam etam akāraṇam  kasmai avisaya vicāraṇa bhāvataḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā buddhānam bhikkhave buddha visayaḥ
translated: All this is no reason.

original: acinteyyo na cintetabbo, yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti idaṃ panettha
analyzed: a cinteyyaḥ na cintetabbaḥ yam cintentaḥ ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati idam pana ittha
translated: Why? Because it is not a field for speculation. For this is said by the Blessed One: “The Buddhas’ knowledge of the Buddhas’ range, bhikkhus, is inconceivable, it causes no terror, it is not a field for speculation” .

original: sanniṭṭhānaṃ – yaṃ kiñci bhagavatā ñātuṃ icchitaṃ, sakalamekadeso vā, tattha tattha
analyzed: sanniṭṭhānam yam kiñci bhagavatā ñātum icchitam sakalam eka desaḥ vā tattha tattha
translated: Resolution: whatever the Blessed One wishes to know, whether the whole or a part, here or there,

original: appaṭihatavuttitāya paccakkhato ñāṇaṃ pavattati niccasamādhānañca vikkhepābhāvato,
analyzed: appaṭihata vutti tāya paccakkhataḥ ñāṇam pavattati nicca samādhānam ca vikkhepa abhāvato
translated: Resolution is the knowledge that occurs in the Blessed One, unobstructedly and with no effort, about anything he wishes to know, either in its totality or in part. And it is always resolved, because he is never distracted.

original: ñātuṃ icchitassa ca sakalassa avisayabhāve tassa ākaṅkhāpaṭibaddhavuttitā na siyā,🔽ekanteneva sā icchitabbā, sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavato āvajjanapaṭibaddhā ākaṅkhāpaṭibaddhā
analyzed: ñātum icchitassa ca sakalassa avisaya bhāve tassa ākaṅkhā paṭibaddha vutti tā na siyā  ekantena iva sā icchitabbā sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavataḥ āvajjana paṭibaddhāḥ ākaṅkhā paṭibaddhā
translated: And if the totality of what is to be known were not his province, his knowledge would not occur in dependence on his wish.

original: manasikārapaṭibaddhā cittuppādapaṭibaddhāti vacanato. Atītānāgatavisayampi bhagavato
analyzed: manasikāra paṭibaddhā cittuppāda paṭibaddhā ati vacanataḥ atīta anāgata visayam pi bhagavato
translated: It must be admitted that all states are bound up with the Blessed One’s adverting, bound up with his wish, bound up with his attention, bound up with his thought.

original: ñāṇaṃ anumānāgamatakkagahaṇavirahitattā paccakkhameva.
analyzed: ñāṇam anumāna āgama takka gahaṇa virahita ttā paccakkham eva
translated: And the Blessed One’s knowledge of the past and future occurs as direct-knowledge, not as inference or hearsay.

original: Nanu ca etasmimpi pakkhe yadā sakalaṃ ñātuṃ icchitaṃ, tadā sakiṃyeva sakalavisayatāya
analyzed: nanu ca etasmin pi pakkhe yadā sakalam ñātum icchitam tadā sakala visaya tāya
translated: But is it not so that in this case too, when he wishes to know the totality, then since his knowledge has a totality of objects,🔽it would occur in the Blessed One without distinguishing the individual dhammas, and so the objection remains?

original: anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇaṃ pavatteyyāti vuttadosā nātivattiyevāti? Na, tassa
analyzed: anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇam pavatteyya iti vutta dosā na ativattiyā iva ati na tassa
translated: No. Because

original: visodhitattā. Visodhito hi so buddhavisayo acinteyyoti. Aññathā pacurajanañāṇasamānavuttitāya
analyzed: visodhita ttā visodhitaḥ hi so buddha visayaḥ acinteyyaḥ ti aññathā pacura jana ñāṇa samāna vutti tāya
translated: because it is purified. For that is purified, being the Buddha’s province, and so it is inconceivable. Otherwise,

original: buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ ñāṇassa acinteyyatā na siyā, tasmā sakaladhammārammaṇampi
analyzed: buddhānam bhagavantānam ñāṇassa acinteyya tā na siyā tasmā sakala dhamma ārammaṇam pi
translated: if it were to occur in the same way as the cognizance of ordinary people, then the cognizance of the Blessed Buddhas would not be inconceivable. So although it has all ideas as its object,

original: taṃ ekadhammārammaṇaṃ viya suvavatthāpiteyeva te dhamme katvā pavattatīti idamettha
analyzed: tam eka dhamma ārammaṇam viya te dhamme katvā pavattati iti idam ettha
translated: it occurs as though it had a single idea as its object by making those ideas well defined. This is what is inconceivable here.

original: acinteyyaṃ, “yāvatakaṃ neyyaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakaṃ neyyaṃ.
analyzed: acinteyyam yāvatakam neyyam tāvatakam ñāṇam yāvatakam ñāṇam tāvatakam neyyam
translated: “As far as there is the knowable, there is knowledge. As far as there is knowledge, there is the knowable.

original: Neyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ neyyaṃ. Neyyaṃ atikkamitvā ñāṇaṃ nappavattati,
analyzed: neyya pariyantikam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam neyyam neyyam atikkamitvā ñāṇam na ppavattati
translated: The knowable is the limit of knowledge, knowledge is the limit of the knowable. Knowledge does not occur exceeding the knowable,

original: ñāṇaṃ atikkamitvā neyyapatho natthi. Aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyino te dhammā, yathā🔽dvinnaṃ samuggapaṭalānaṃ sammā phusitānaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ samuggapaṭalaṃ uparimaṃ nātivattati,
analyzed: ñāṇam atikkamitvā na iyya pathaḥ natthi aññamañña pariyanta ṭṭhāyinaḥ te dhammā yathā  dvinnam samugga paṭalānam sammā phusitānam heṭṭhimam samugga paṭalam uparimam na ativattati
translated: the path of the knowable does not exist exceeding knowledge. Those ideas are the limit of each other, just as🔽two sets of touching finger-webs are the limit of each other.🔽Just as the lower set of touching finger-webs does not exceed the upper set,

original: uparimaṃ samuggapaṭalaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ nātivattati. Aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyino, evameva
analyzed: uparimam samugga paṭalam heṭṭhimam na ativattati aññamañña pariyanta ṭṭhāyinaḥ evam eva
translated: and the upper set does not exceed the lower set, so too🔽those ideas are the limit of each other.

original: buddhassa bhagavato neyyañca ñāṇañca aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyino…pe… te dhammā”ti
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ na iyyam ca ñāṇañca aññamañña pariyanta ṭṭhāyinā upe te dhammā ti
translated: The knowledge of the Buddha and the knowledge of the disciples are mutually inclusive. … These ideas are the same.

original: evamekajjhaṃ, visuṃ, sakiṃ, kamena vā icchānurūpaṃ pavattassa tassa ñāṇassa vasena
analyzed: evam ekajjham visum sakim kamena vā icchā anurūpam pavattassa tassa ñāṇassa vasena
translated: Thus, in accordance with the knowledge that occurs according to one’s wish, either collectively, separately, singly, or in sequence,

original: sammā sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā bhagavā sammāsambuddho nāma jātoti.
analyzed: sammā sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā bhagavā sammāsambuddhaḥ nāma jātaḥ ti
translated: the Blessed One is called the Perfectly Enlightened One because he is the one who has fully and rightly awakened to all dhammas.

original: Ayaṃ panettha aṭṭhakathāmuttako nayo – ṭhānāṭhānādīni chabbisayāni chahi ñāṇehi jānatā,
analyzed: ayam pana ittha aṭṭhakathā muttakaḥ nayaḥ ṭhāna aṭhāna ādīni cha bisayāni chahi ñāṇehi jānatā
translated: The following method of explanation is given in the commentaries: The Blessed One is the one who knows the six bases of contact, such as the eye and forms, etc.,

original: yathākammūpage satte cutūpapātadibbacakkhuñāṇehi passatā, savāsanānamāsavānaṃ āsavakkhayañāṇena🔽khīṇattā arahatā, jhānādidhamme saṃkilesavodānavasena sāmaṃyeva aviparītāvabodhato
analyzed: yathā kamma upage satte cutu upapāta dibba cakkhu ñāṇehi passatā sava āsanānam āsavānam āsava kkhaya ñāṇena  khīṇa ttā arahatā jhāna ādi dhamme saṃkilesa vodāna vasena sāmaṃyā iva a viparīta avabodhato
translated: the one who sees the passing away and arising of beings according to their kamma by means of the knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings and the divine eye,🔽the one who has destroyed the taints together with their residues by means of the knowledge of the destruction of the taints,🔽the one who has fully and rightly awakened to the dhammas such as the jhānas, etc., by means of the knowledge of the dhammas, which is the knowledge of the dhammas in their corrupted and purified states,

original: sammāsambuddhena, evaṃ dasabalañāṇavasena catūhākārehi thomitena. Apica tīsu kālesu
analyzed: sammāsambuddhena evam dasa bala ñāṇa vasena catur hākārehi thomitena api ca tīsu kālesu
translated: the one who has fully and rightly awakened to the dhammas by means of the knowledge of the ten powers.🔽Moreover, the Blessed One is the one who knows because his knowledge is unobstructed with regard to the three periods of time,

original: appaṭihatañāṇatāya jānatā, tiṇṇampi kammānaṃ ñāṇānuparivattito nisammakāritāya passatā,
analyzed: a paṭihata ñāṇa tāya jānatā tiṇṇam pi kammānam ñāṇa anuparivattitaḥ nisamma kāri tāya passatā
translated: the one who sees because his knowledge is accompanied by the knowledge of the three times,

original: davādīnaṃ channamabhāvasādhikāya pahānasampadāya arahatā, chandādīnaṃ channamahānihetubhūtāya
analyzed: dava ādīnam channam abhāva sādhikāya pahāna sampadāya arahatā chanda ādīnam channam a hāni hetu bhūtāya
translated: The Blessed One has abandoned the four taints by the perfection of abandoning, which is the non-existence of the four taints;🔽and he has omniscience, which is the non-exhaustion of the four confidences, which are the great causes for the non-existence of the four taints.

original: aparikkhayapaṭibhānasādhikāya sabbaññutāya sammāsambuddhena, evaṃ aṭṭhārasāveṇikabuddhadhammavasena🔽catūhākārehi thomitenāti evamādinā tesaṃ tesaṃ ñāṇadassanapahānabodhanatthehi saṅgahitānaṃ
analyzed: a parikkhaya paṭibhāna sādhikāya sabbaññu tāya sammāsambuddhena evam aṭṭhārasa āveṇika buddha dhamma vasena  catūhākārehi thomitena ati evamādinā tesam tesam ñāṇa dassana pahāna bodhana atthehi saṅgahitānam
translated: Thus, by way of the eighteen unique qualities of a Buddha,

original: buddhaguṇānaṃ vasena yojanā kātabbāti.
analyzed: buddha guṇānam vasena yojanā kātabbā ati
translated: he is “lauded in four ways.” “In this way” and so forth refer to the way in which the qualities of the Buddha are to be understood by way of the knowledge, insight, abandoning, and awakening that are included in the four ways of lauding.

original: Catuvesārajjaṃ sandhāya “catūhākārehī”ti vuttaṃ. “Thomitenā”ti etena imesaṃ “bhagavatā”ti
analyzed: catu vesārajjam sandhāya catūhākārehi iti vuttam thomitena ati etena imesam bhagavatā ati
translated: The four kinds of fearlessness are referred to by the words “in four ways.” By the words “lauded” he shows that the word “Blessed One” is a qualification.

original: padassa visesanataṃ dasseti. Yadipi hīnapaṇītabhedena duvidhāva adhimutti pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: padassa visesana tam dasseti yadi pi hīna paṇīta bhedena
translated: Although the inclinations are said in the text to be of two kinds, namely, inferior and superior,

original: vuttā, pavattiākāravasena pana anekabhedabhinnāvāti āha “nānādhimuttikatā”ti. Sā
analyzed: vuttā pavatti ākāra vasena pana aneka bheda bhinna āvā iti āha nānā adhimuttika tā iti sā
translated: they are of many kinds according to the modes of their occurrence. Thus he says “the variety of inclinations.”

original: pana adhimutti ajjhāsayadhātuyeva, tadapi tathā tathā dassanaṃ, khamanaṃ, rocanañcāti
analyzed: pana adhimutti tat api tathā tathā dassanam khamanam rocanam ca ati
translated: But this inclination is the element of intention, and that is the seeing, the enduring, and the delighting in this or that way.

original: atthaṃ viññāpeti “nānajjhāsayatā”ti iminā. Tathā hi vakkhati “nānādhimuttikatā nānajjhāsayatā🔽nānādiṭṭhikatā nānakkhantitā nānārucitā”ti. “Yāvañcida”nti etassa “suppaṭividitā”ti
analyzed: attham viññāpeti nānā ajjhāsaya tā ti iminā tathā hi vakkhati nānā adhimuttika tā nānā ajjhāsaya tā  nānādiṭṭhika tā nānā khanti tā nānāruci tā ati etassa suppaṭividitā ati
translated: He indicates the meaning of “different dispositions” by “different persuasions”. For he says: “Different persuasions, different dispositions,🔽different views, different preferences, different likings” . The connection of “as well” with “well penetrated” is this:

original: iminā sambandho. Tattha ca idanti padapūraṇamattaṃ, “nānādhimuttikatā”ti etena vā🔽padena samānādhikaraṇaṃ, tassattho pana pākaṭoyevāti āha “yāva ca suṭṭhu paṭividitā”ti.🔽“Yā ca aya”ntiādinā dhātusaṃyuttapāḷiṃ dassento tadeva saṃyuttaṃ manasi karitvā tesaṃ🔽avaṇṇavaṇṇabhāsanena saddhiṃ ghaṭetvā therānamayaṃ saṅkhiyadhammo udapādīti dasseti.🔽Ato assa bhagavato dhātusaṃyuttadesanānayena tāsaṃ suppaṭividitabhāvaṃ samatthanavasena
analyzed: iminā sambandhaḥ tattha ca idam ti etena vā  padena samāna adhikaraṇam tassa atthaḥ pana pākaṭaḥ yā iva iti āha yāva ca suṭṭhu paṭividitā ti  yā ca ayanti ādinā dhātu saṃyutta pāḷim dassento tat eva saṃyuttam manasi karitvā tesam  avaṇṇa vaṇṇa bhāsanena saddhim ghaṭetvā saṅkhiya dhammo udapādi iti dasseti  atas assa bhagavataḥ dhātu saṃyutta desanā nayena tāsam suppaṭividita bhāvam samatthana vasena
translated: “As well” is a mere filler-up of a gap, or it is in apposition with “different persuasions” by the word “different persuasions” . But the meaning of this is evident, so he said “well penetrated” .

original: dassetuṃ “ayaṃ hī”tiādimāhāti attho daṭṭhabbo. Suppaṭividitabhāvasamatthanañhi “ayaṃ
