original: cettha sabbaññutaññāṇameva adhippetaṃ, na dasabalañāṇanti āha “sabbaññutaññāṇenā”ti.
analyzed: ca ittha sabbaññu taññāṇam eva adhippetam na dasa bala ñāṇan ti āha sabbaññu taññāṇena ati
translated: Herein, the diversity of the way of entry is the diversity of the way of entry into the four noble truths. The diversity of the way of seeing is the diversity of the way of seeing the four noble truths. The diversity of the way of discernment

original: Evaṃ ācariyadhammapālattherena vuttaṃ, abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ, dasabalasuttaṭṭhakathāsu ca evamāgataṃ.
analyzed: evam ācariya dhammapāla therena vuttam abhidhamma ṭṭhakathāyam dasabala sutta ṭṭhakathāsu ca evam āgatam
translated: This is how it is stated by the Elder Dhammapāla, the teacher, in the Abhidhamma Commentary and in the Commentaries on the Dasabala Sutta.

original: Paravādī panāha “dasabalañāṇaṃ nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ natthi, sabbaññutaññāṇassevāyaṃ pabhedo”ti,
analyzed: paravādī pana āha dasa bala ñāṇam nāma pāṭiyekkam natthi sabbaññuta ññāṇassa iva ayam pabhedaḥ ti
translated: But the opponent says: “There is no such thing as the knowledge of the ten powers. It is a mere subdivision of the knowledge of omniscience.”

original: taṃ tathā na daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aññameva hi dasabalañāṇaṃ, aññaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ. Dasabalañāṇañhi
analyzed: tat tathā na daṭṭhabbam aññam eva hi dasa bala ñāṇam aññam sabbaññuta ññāṇam dasa bala ñāṇam hi
translated: That should not be regarded as correct. For the knowledge of the ten powers is one thing and the knowledge of omniscience is another.

original: sakakiccameva jānāti, sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana tampi tato avasesampi jānāti. Dasabalañāṇesu
analyzed: saka kiccam eva jānāti sabbaññuta ññāṇam pana tam pi tatas avasesam pi jānāti dasa bala ñāṇesu
translated: The knowledge of the ten powers knows only the respective functions of the powers. But the knowledge of omniscience knows that and also everything else.

original: hi paṭhamaṃ kāraṇākāraṇameva jānāti, dutiyaṃ kammantaravipākantarameva, tatiyaṃ kammaparicchedameva,🔽catutthaṃ dhātunānattakāraṇameva, pañcamaṃ sattānamajjhāsayādhimuttimeva, chaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: hi paṭhamam kāraṇa akāraṇam eva jānāti dutiyam kamma antara vipāka antaram eva tatiyam kamma paricchedam eva  catuttham dhātu nānatta kāraṇam eva pañcamam chaṭṭham
translated: For the first power knows only the possible and the impossible. The second knows only the results of action and the times when they are experienced. The third knows only the range of kamma.

original: indriyānaṃ tikkhamudubhāvameva, sattamaṃ jhānādīhi saddhiṃ tesaṃ saṃkilesādimeva,
analyzed: indriyānam tikkha mudu bhāvam eva sattamam jhāna ādīhi saddhim tesam saṃkilesa ādim eva
translated: The fourth knows only the diversity of elements. The fifth knows only the dispositions and inclinations of beings. The sixth knows only the keenness and dullness of faculties. The seventh knows only the defilement, etc., of jhānas, etc.

original: aṭṭhamaṃ pubbenivutthakkhandhasantatimeva, navamaṃ sattānaṃ cutipaṭisandhimeva, dasamaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhamam pubbenivuttha kkhandha santatim eva navamam sattānam cuti paṭisandhim eva dasamam
translated: The eighth is the continuity of aggregates in a previous birth. The ninth is the passing away and reappearing of beings. The tenth is the

original: saccaparicchedameva, sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana etehi jānitabbañca tato uttariñca jānāti,
analyzed: sacca paricchedam eva sabbaññuta ññāṇam pana etehi jānitabbam ca tatas uttariñca jānāti
translated: truths. But the knowledge of omniscience knows these and more besides.

original: etesaṃ pana kiccaṃ na sabbaṃ karoti. Tañhi jhānaṃ hutvā appetuṃ na sakkoti, iddhi🔽hutvā vikubbituṃ na sakkoti, maggo hutvā kilese khepetuṃ na sakkoti. Apica paravādī🔽evaṃ pucchitabbo “dasabalañāṇaṃ nāma etaṃ savitakkasavicāraṃ avitakkavicāramattaṃ🔽avitakkaavicāraṃ, kāmāvacaraṃ rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacaraṃ, lokiyaṃ lokuttara”nti. Jānanto
analyzed: etesam pana kiccam na sabbam karoti tat hi jhānam hutvā appetum na sakkoti iddhi  hutvā vikubbitum na sakkoti maggaḥ hutvā kilese khepetum na sakkoti apica paravādī  evam pucchitabbaḥ dasa bala ñāṇam nāma etam sa vitakka sa vicāram a vitakka vicāra mattam  a vitakka a vicāram kāmāvacaram rūpāvacaram arūpāvacaram lokiyam lokuttaram jānantaḥ
translated: But it does not perform all the functions of these knowledges. For it cannot, as the knowledge of the attainment of cessation does, attain Nibbāna;

original: paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni “savitakkasavicārānī”ti vakkhati, tato parāni dve “avitakkaavicārānī”ti
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇāni sa vitakka sa vicārāni iti vakkhati tatas parāni dve avitakka avicārāni iti
translated: nor can it, as the knowledge of supernormal power does, perform the kinds of psychic power; nor can it, as the knowledge of the destruction of the taints does, destroy the defilements. Moreover, an opponent should be questioned thus: “Is the knowledge of the ten powers with applied thought and sustained thought, without applied thought but with sustained thought only, without applied thought and without sustained thought? Is it in the sense sphere, in the fine-material sphere, in the immaterial sphere? Is it mundane, is it supramundane?” If he knows, he will say that seven of the knowledges are with applied thought and sustained thought, and the next two are without applied thought but with sustained thought only,

original: vakkhati, āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ “siyā savitakkasavicāraṃ, siyā avitakkavicāramattaṃ, siyā
analyzed: vakkhati āsava kkhaya ñāṇam siyā sa vitakka sa vicāram siyā a vitakka vicāra mattam siyā
translated: and the knowledge of the destruction of the taints is either without applied thought and sustained thought or without applied thought but with sustained thought only.🔽The knowledge of omniscience is without applied thought and sustained thought.

original: avitakkaavicāra”nti vakkhati, tathā paṭipāṭiyā satta kāmāvacarāni, tato paraṃ dve
analyzed: avitakka avicāranti vakkhati tathā paṭipāṭiyā satta kāmāvacarāni tato param dve
translated: and he says, “without thinking and exploring,” and in the same way he says the seven of the sense sphere in the reverse order, and after that the two

original: rūpāvacarāni, avasāne ekaṃ “lokuttara’nti vakkhati, sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana savitakkasavicārameva,
analyzed: rūpāvacarāni avasāne ekam lokuttaranti vakkhati sabbaññuta ññāṇam pana sa vitakka sa vicāram eva
translated: of the fine-material sphere, and finally he says “supramundane.” But the knowledge of omniscience is only with thinking and exploring,

original: kāmāvacarameva, lokiyamevāti. Iti aññadeva dasabalañāṇaṃ, aññaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇanti,
analyzed: kāmāvacaram eva lokiyam eva ati iti aññat eva dasa bala ñāṇam aññam sabbaññuta ññāṇam ti
translated: only of the sense sphere, and only mundane. So the knowledge of the ten powers is one thing and the knowledge of omniscience is another.

original: tasmā pañcamabalañāṇasaṅkhātena nānādhimuttikatāñāṇena ca sabbaññutaññāṇena ca viditāti
analyzed: tasmā pañcama bala ñāṇa saṅkhātena nānā adhimuttika tā ñāṇena ca sabbaññu taññāṇena ca viditā ati
translated: Therefore the meaning should be understood as follows: “He knows with the knowledge of omniscience called the knowledge of the many and varied elements and with the knowledge called the fifth power, the knowledge of the many and varied elements.”

original: attho veditabbo. Ca-kāropi hi potthakesu dissati. Sāti yathāvuttā nānādhimuttikatā.🔽“Dvepi nāmā”tiādinā yathāvuttasuttassatthaṃ saṅkhepena dassetvā “imesu cāpī”tiādinā
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ cakāraḥ api hi potthakesu dissati sā ati yathā vuttā nānā adhimuttika tā  dve api nāma atiādinā saṅkhepena dassetvā imesu ca api itiādinā
translated: For the word “and” is also found in the texts. The “many and varied elements” are as already stated.🔽Having shown in brief the meaning of the sutta stated in the way beginning, “Two ideas, bhikkhus,” with the words, “Two ideas, bhikkhus,” etc., he now makes it clear that the limited idea is related to that.

original: tassa saṅkhiyadhammassa tadabhisambandhataṃ āvi karoti. Iti ha meti ettha evaṃsaddatthe
analyzed: tassa saṅkhiya dhammassa tad abhisambandha tam āvi karoti iti ha mā iti ettha evaṃsaddatthe
translated: The words iti hētaṃ are analyzed as follows: iti is a particle in the sense of “thus”;

original: iti-saddo, ha-kāro nipātamattaṃ, āgamo vā. Sandhivasena ikāralopo, akārādeso vāti
analyzed: iti saddaḥ hakāraḥ nipāta mattam āgamaḥ vā sandhi vasena ikāra lopaḥ akāra ādesaḥ vā ati
translated: ha is a mere particle or an adverb; the vowel i has been dropped by sandhi; and the a is a vowel indicator.

original: dasseti “evaṃ ime”ti iminā.
analyzed: dassa iti evam imā iti iminā
translated: “He shows them thus” with the words “He shows them thus.”

original: 4. “Viditvā”ti ettha pakatiyatthabhūtā vijānanakiriyā sāmaññena abhedavatīpi samānā
analyzed: viditvā ti ettha samānā
translated: As to “knowing,” the act of knowing, which is the true nature of the ordinary act of knowing, is undifferentiated in the sense of being the same in all its instances,

original: taṃtaṃkaraṇayogyatāya anekappabhedāti dassetuṃ “bhagavā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vatthūnīti
analyzed: tad tad karaṇa yogyatāya aneka ppabhedā iti dassetum bhagavā hi itiādi vuttam vatthūni iti
translated: but it is shown that it has many differentiations according to the suitability of the various kinds of object.

original: gharavatthūni. “Sabbaññutaññāṇena disvā aññāsī”ti ca vohāravacanamattametaṃ. Na hi
analyzed: ghara vatthūni sabbaññuta ññāṇena disvā ca vohāra vacanam attam etam na hi
translated: “The objects” are the objects of the house. And the words “He knew by seeing with the knowledge of omniscience” are merely a way of speaking.

original: tena dassanato aññaṃ jānanaṃ nāma natthi. Tadidaṃ ñāṇaṃ āvajjanapaṭibaddhaṃ ākaṅkhāpaṭibaddhaṃ🔽manasikārapaṭibaddhaṃ cittuppādapaṭibaddhaṃ hutvā pavattati. Kiṃ nāma karonto bhagavā
analyzed: tena dassanataḥ aññam jānanam nāma na atthi tat idam ñāṇam āvajjana paṭibaddham ākaṅkhā paṭibaddham  manasikāra paṭibaddham cittuppāda paṭibaddham hutvā pavattati kim nāma karontaḥ bhagavā
translated: For there is no knowing apart from seeing with that knowledge.🔽This knowledge occurs bound up with adverting, bound up with desire to know, bound up with attention, bound up with consciousness.

original: tena ñāṇena āvajjanādipaṭibaddhena aññāsīti sotūnamatthassa suviññāpanatthaṃ parammukhā
analyzed: tena ñāṇena āvajjana ādi paṭibaddhena aññāsi iti sotūnam atthassa su viññāpana attham parammukhā
translated: What was the Blessed One doing when he knew by means of that knowledge bound up with adverting, etc.?

original: viya codanaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti “kiṃ karonto aññāsī”ti iminā, pacchimayāmakiccaṃ karonto
analyzed: viya codanam samuṭṭhāpeti kim karontaḥ aññāsi iti iminā pacchima yāma kiccam karontaḥ
translated: In order to make the meaning clear to the listeners, he raises the question as if to another, as though to stimulate them, with the words “What was he doing when he knew?”🔽Doing what as his last watch duty,

original: taṃ ñāṇaṃ āvajjanādipaṭibaddhaṃ hutvā tena tathā aññāsīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sāmaññasmiṃ
analyzed: tam ñāṇam āvajjana ādi paṭibaddham hutvā tena tathā aññāsi iti vuttam hoti sāmaññasmin
translated: The knowledge is bound up with adverting, etc., and so it is said that he knows thus by means of that.🔽The distinction made in the case of the state of a recluse is meaningful.

original: sati visesavacanaṃ sātthakaṃ siyāti anuyogenāha “kiccañcanāmeta”ntiādi. Arahattamaggena
analyzed: sati visesa vacanam sātthakam siyā ti anuyogena āha kiccan canām etat tiādi arahatta maggena
translated: The word “function” is used in the sense of “cause” .

original: samugghātaṃ kataṃ tassa samuṭṭhāpakakilesasamugghāṭanena, yato “natthi abyāvaṭamano”ti
analyzed: samugghātam katam tassa samuṭṭhāpaka kilesa samugghāṭanena yatas natthi
translated: The function of the path of arahatship is the abandoning of the defilements that cause the arising of the taints.

original: aṭṭhārasasu buddhadhammesu vuccati. Niratthako cittasamudācāro natthīti hettha attho.🔽Evampi vuttānuyogo tadavatthoyevāti codanamapaneti “taṃ pañcavidha”ntiādinā. Tattha🔽purimakiccadvayaṃ divasabhāgavasena, itarattayaṃ rattibhāgavasena gahetabbaṃ tathāyeva vakkhamānattā.🔽“Upaṭṭhākānuggahaṇatthaṃ, sarīraphāsukatthañcā”ti etena anekakappasamupacitapuññasambhārajanitaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhārasasu buddha dhammesu vuccati niratthako citta samudācāro natthi iti ha ittha attho 🔽evam pi vutta anuyogaḥ codanam apaneti tam pañcavidha nti ādinā 🔽purima kicca dvayam divasa bhāga vasena ratti bhāga vasena gahetabbam tathāya iva vakkhamāna ttā 🔽upaṭṭhāka anuggahaṇa attham sarīra phāsuka ttham ca ati etena aneka kappa samupacita puñña sambhāra janitam
translated: The meaning is that there is no mental activity that is without purpose.

original: bhagavato mukhavaraṃ duggandhādidosaṃ nāma natthi, tadubhayatthameva pana mukhadhovanādīni🔽karotīti dasseti. Sabbopi hi buddhānaṃ kāyo bāhirabbhantarehi malehi anupakkiliṭṭho
analyzed: bhagavataḥ mukha varam duggandha ādi dosam nāma natthi tad ubhayattham eva pana mukha dhovana ādīni  karoti iti dasseti sabbaḥ api hi buddhānam kāyaḥ bāhira bbhantarehi malehi an upakkiliṭṭhaḥ
translated: There is no such thing as a bad smell or any other defect in the Blessed One’s mouth. He does this only to show that he is like others in having to wash his mouth after eating. For the bodies of the Buddhas are not defiled by any external or internal impurity.

original: sudhotamaṇi viya hoti. Vivittāsaneti phalasamāpattīnamanurūpe vivekānubrūhanāsane.🔽Vītināmetvāti phalasamāpattīhi vītināmanaṃ vuttaṃ, tampi na vivekaninnatāya, paresañca
analyzed: viya hoti vivitta āsanā iti phala samāpattīnam anurūpe viveka anubrūhana āsane  vītināmetvā iti phala samāpattīhi vītināmanam vuttam tat pi na viveka ninnatāya paresam ca
translated: The Blessed One’s face has no such faults as bad smell, etc., but he does the mouth-washing, etc., in order to show that he shares the two kinds of blessing with others. For the whole body of the Enlightened Ones is uncontaminated by any external or internal dirt, like a gem of pure water. In a secluded abode: in an abode that is conducive to the development of the seclusion that is a prerequisite for the attainment of the fruitions.

original: diṭṭhānugati āpajjanatthaṃ. Surattadupaṭṭaṃ antaravāsakaṃ vihāranivāsanaparivattanavasena
analyzed: diṭṭha anugati āpajjana attham surat tad upaṭṭam antaravāsakam vihāra nivāsana parivattana vasena
translated: Having spent: this is said with reference to the spending of time in the attainment of the fruitions. That too is not because of his leaning towards seclusion, but in order to conform with the world and to make others attain the goal. Having put on the inner robe, covering both shoulders evenly,

original: nivāsetvā vijjulatāsadisaṃ kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā meghavaṇṇaṃ sugatacīvaraṃ pārupitvā🔽selamayapattaṃ ādāyāti adhippāyo. Tathāyeva hi tattha tattha vutto. “Kadāci ekako”tiādi
analyzed: nivāsetvā vijju latā sadisam kāya bandhanam bandhitvā megha vaṇṇam sugata cīvaram pārupitvā  sela maya pattam ādāya ati adhippāyaḥ tathāya iva hi tattha tattha vuttaḥ kadāci ekakaḥ iti ādi
translated: having fastened the waistband, which is like a flash of lightning, having put on the well-sewn outer robe, which is the color of rain clouds,

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ vineyyānaṃ vinayanānukūlaṃ bhagavato upasaṅkamanadassanaṃ. Gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ
analyzed: tesam tesam vineyyānam vinayana anukūlam bhagavato upasaṅkamana dassanam gāmam vā nigamam
translated: having taken the bowl made of stone, this is the intention. For it is said in this way in the various places. Sometimes alone: this is the Blessed One’s going to and sitting in the place of the disciples in order to show them, in a manner suitable for the training of each one, the seeing of him. To a village or town or city,

original: vāti ettha vā-saddo vikappanattho, tena nagarampi vikappeti. Yathāruci vattamānehi
analyzed: vā ti ettha vā saddaḥ vikappana atthaḥ tena nagaram pi vikappeti yathāruci vattamānehi
translated: The word ‘vā’ here has the sense of ‘vikappa’ (alternative). Therefore he enters the city after making it an alternative. As he wishes

original: anekehi pāṭihāriyehi pavisatīti sambandho.🔽“Seyyathida”ntiādinā pacchimapakkhaṃ vitthāreti. Seyyathidanti ca taṃ katamanti atthe
analyzed: anekehi pāṭihāriyehi pavisati iti sambandhaḥ  seyyathidanti ādinā pacchima pakkham vitthāreti ca tam katamanti atthe
translated: the connection is that he enters with many wonders.

original: nipāto, idaṃ vā sappāṭihīrapavisanaṃ katamantipi vaṭṭati. Mudugatavātāti mudubhūtā,🔽mudubhāvena vā gatā vātā. Udakaphusitānīti udakabindūni. Muñcantāti osiñcantā. Reṇuṃ🔽vūpasametvāti rajaṃ sannisīdāpetvā upari vitānaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhanti caṇḍa-vātātapa-himapātādi-haraṇena
analyzed: nipātaḥ idam vā vaṭṭati mudu gata vātā ati mudu bhūtā  mudu bhāvena vā gatāḥ vātāḥ udaka phusitāni iti udaka bindūni muñcantā ati osiñcantā reṇum  rajam sannisīda apetvā upari vitānam hutvā tiṭṭhanti caṇḍa vāta ātapa hima pāta ādi haraṇena
translated: “Seyyathīdaṃ” etc. he explains the latter part. And the word ‘seyyathīdaṃ’ is a nipāta in the sense of ‘taṃ katam’ (that is done). Or this ‘entering with wonders’ is also allowable as ‘taṃ katam’. The winds are ‘mudugatā’ (gone softly),🔽they are ‘mudubhūtā’ (become soft), or they have ‘gone’ (gata) with ‘softness’ (mudutā). ‘Udakaphusitāni’ are water drops. ‘Muñcanti’ means they are trickling. ‘Reṇuṃ vūpasametvā’ means after making the dust settle down. They stand above like a canopy,

original: vitānakiccanipphādakattā, tato tato himavantādīsu pupphūpagarukkhato upasaṃharitvāti
analyzed: vitāna kicca nipphādaka ttā tatas tatas himavanta ādīsu puppha upaga rukkhataḥ upasaṃharitvā iti
translated: because they perform the function of a canopy by removing strong winds, heat, cold, rain, etc. Therefore, after collecting them from here and there from flowering trees in the Himalayas, etc.

original: atthassa viññāyamānattā tathā na vuttaṃ. Samabhāgakaraṇamattena onamanti, unnamanti
analyzed: atthassa viññāyamāna ttā tathā na vuttam sama bhāga karaṇa mattena onamanti unnamanti
translated: because the meaning is understood, it is not said in that way. They bend down and rise up by the mere act of sharing equally.

original: ca, tatoyeva pādanikkhepasamaye samāva bhūmi hoti. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ sakkharakathalakaṇṭakasaṅkukalalādiapagamanassāpi
analyzed: ca tatoyā iva pāda nikkhepa samaye hoti nidassana mattam ca itam sakkhara kathala kaṇṭaka saṅku kalala ādi apagamanassa api
translated: and the ground becomes level with the mere placing of the foot. But this is merely an indication, for it is possible that stones, potsherds, thorns, stumps, and so on, may not disappear.

original: sambhavato, tañca suppatiṭṭhitapādatālakkhaṇassa nissandaphalaṃ, na iddhinimmānaṃ.🔽Padumapupphāni vāti ettha vā-saddo vikappanattho, tena “yadi yathāvuttanayena samā
analyzed: sambhavataḥ tat ca su patiṭṭhita pāda tā lakkhaṇassa nissanda phalam na iddhi nimmānam  paduma pupphāni vā ti ettha vā saddaḥ vikappana atthaḥ tena yadi yathā vutta nayena samā
translated: And that is the fruit of the outcome of the characteristic of the well-placed foot, not of the supernormal power of creation.

original: bhūmi hoti, evaṃ sati tāni na paṭiggaṇhanti, tathā pana asatiyeva paṭiggaṇhantī”ti
analyzed: evam sati tāni na paṭiggaṇhanti tathā pana asatiyā iva paṭiggaṇhanti iti
translated: ‘The lotuses open’ : the word vā is in the sense of vikappa . Thus he shows that if the ground becomes level in the way described, then the lotuses do not open, but if it does not become level, then they open.🔽He shows that the Blessed One proceeds according to his pleasure.

original: bhagavato yathāruci pavattanaṃ dasseti. Sabbadāva bhagavato gamanaṃ paṭhamaṃ dakkhiṇapāduddharaṇasaṅkhātānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitanti🔽āha “ṭhapitamatte dakkhiṇapāde”ti. Buddhānaṃ sabbadakkhiṇatāya tathā vuttanti ācariyadhammapālatthero,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ yathāruci pavattanam dasseti sabbadāva bhagavataḥ gamanam paṭhamam dakkhiṇa pāda uddharaṇa saṅkhāta anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitanti  āha ṭhapita matte dakkhiṇa pāde ti buddhānam sabba dakkhiṇa tāya tathā vuttan ti ācariya dhammapāla ttheraḥ
translated: Always the Blessed One’s going is adorned with the secondary characteristics beginning with the lifting of the right foot first.🔽Therefore it is said, ‘When the right foot is lifted.’ The Elder Acariya Dhammapāla and the Elder Acariya Sāriputta say that it is so described because of the Blessed One’s rightness in all things.

original: ācariyasāriputtatthero ca vadati, sabbesaṃ uttamatāya evaṃ vuttanti attho. Evaṃ sati
analyzed: ācariya sāriputta thero ca vadati sabbesam uttama tāya evam vuttanti atthaḥ evam sati
translated: The meaning is that it is so described because of his being foremost in all things.

original: uttamapurisānaṃ tathāpakatitāyāti āpajjati. Ṭhapitamatte nikkhamitvā dhāvantīti sambandho.
analyzed: uttama purisānam āpajjati ṭhapita matte nikkhamitvā dhāvanti iti sambandhaḥ
translated: and so it is with the great men. The construction is: “having gone out running immediately after the sound was uttered.”

original: Idañca yāvadeva vineyyajanavinayanatthaṃ satthu pāṭihāriyanti tesaṃ dassanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: idam ca yāvat eva vineyya jana vinayana attham satthu pāṭihāriyanti tesam dassana ṭṭhānam
translated: And this is a miracle of the Master for the purpose of training those who need training.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. “Chabbaṇṇarasmiyo”ti vatvāpi “suvaṇṇarasapiñjarāni viyā”ti vacanaṃ🔽bhagavato sarīre pītābhāya yebhuyyatāyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Rasa-saddo cettha udakapariyāyo,
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam chabbaṇṇa rasmiyā iti vatvā api suvaṇṇa rasa piñjarāni viyā iti vacanam  bhagavato sarīre pīta ābhāya yebhuyyatāya ati daṭṭhabbam rasa saddo ca ittha udaka pariyāyo
translated: Although it is said that “six-coloured rays,” the statement that “they were like golden rays”🔽should be understood to mean that the Master’s body was mostly of a golden colour. The word “rasa” here is a synonym for “water,”

original: piñjara-saddo hemavaṇṇapariyāyo, suvaṇṇajaladhārā viya suvaṇṇavaṇṇānīti attho”ti
analyzed: piñjara saddo hema vaṇṇa pariyāyaḥ suvaṇṇa jala dhārāḥ viya suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāni iti atthaḥ ti
translated: and the word “piñjara” is a synonym for “golden colour.” The meaning is that they were like golden streams.

original: sāratthadīpaniyaṃ vuttaṃ. Pāsādakūṭāgārādīni tesu tesu gāmanigamādīsu saṃvijjamānāni
analyzed: sāratthadīpaniyam vuttam pāsāda kūṭāgāra ādīni tesu tesu gāma nigama ādīsu saṃvijjamānāni
translated: This is stated in the commentary, the Sārattha-Dīpanī. The palaces, the upper chambers, etc., which are found in the various villages, towns, etc.,

original: alaṅkarontiyo hutvā.
analyzed: alaṅkarontiyaḥ hutvā
translated: are like ornaments.

original: “Tathā”tiādinā sayameva dhammatāvasena tesaṃ saddakaraṇaṃ dasseti. Tadā kāyaṃ upagacchantīti
analyzed: tathā ti ādinā sayam eva dhamma tā vasena tesam sadda karaṇam dasseti tadā kāyam upagacchanti iti
translated: With the words “And so on,” he shows that the sound was produced by them by the natural law. The sound went to the body

original: kāyūpagāni, na yattha katthaci ṭhitāni. “Antaravīthi”nti iminā bhagavato piṇḍāya🔽gamanānurūpavīthiṃ dasseti. Na hi bhagavā loluppacārapiṇḍacāriko viya yattha katthaci🔽gacchati. Ye paṭhamaṃ gatā, ye vā tadanucchavikaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dātuṃ samatthā, te bhagavatopi🔽pattaṃ gaṇhantīti veditabbaṃ. Paṭimānentīti patissamānasā pūjenti, bhagavantaṃ vā🔽paṭimānāpenti paṭimānantaṃ karonti. Vohāramattañcetaṃ, bhagavato pana apaṭimānanā🔽nāma natthi. Cittasantānānīti atīte, etarahi ca pavattacittasantānāni. Yathā keci
analyzed: kāya upagāni na yattha katthaci ṭhitāni iminā bhagavataḥ piṇḍāya  gamana anurūpa vīthim dasseti na hi bhagavā loluppa cāra piṇḍacārikaḥ viya yattha katthaci  gacchati ye paṭhamam gatāḥ ye vā tad anucchavikam piṇḍapātam dātum samatthā te bhagavataḥ api  pattam gaṇhanti iti veditabbam paṭimānenti iti pūjenti bhagavantam vā  paṭimānāpenti paṭimānantam karonti bhagavato pana a paṭimānanā  nāma natthi citta santānāni iti atīte etarahi ca pavatta citta santānāni yathā keci
translated: They are not placed here and there. “In the middle of the street” shows the street in which the Blessed One went for alms. For the Blessed One does not go anywhere at all like one who goes for alms by way of greed. It should be understood that those who went first or who were able to give alms in a manner suitable to the Blessed One took the Blessed One’s bowl. “They honored” means they worshipped with a mind of reverence, or they made the Blessed One an object of reverence. But this is merely a figure of speech, for there is no one who does not honor the Blessed One. “The currents of their minds” means the currents of their minds that occurred in the past and are occurring at present.

original: arahatte patiṭṭhahanti, tathā dhammaṃ desetīti sambandho. Keci pabbajitvāti ca arahattasamāpannānaṃ🔽pabbajjāsaṅkhepagatadassanatthaṃ, na pana gihīnaṃ arahattasamāpannatāpaṭikkhepanatthaṃ.
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhahanti tathā dhammam deseti iti sambandhaḥ keci pabbajitvā iti ca arahatta samāpannānam 🔽pabbajjā saṅkhepa gata dassana attham na pana gihīnam arahatta samāpanna tā paṭikkhepana attham
translated: They are not standing here and there, but are attached to the body. By the words “in the middle of the street” he shows the street suitable for the Blessed One’s alms round. For the Blessed One does not go here and there like one who goes about for the sake of gain. It should be understood that those who have gone first or who are able to give alms in a manner suitable to the Blessed One take his bowl. “They honor” means they worship with a mind of respect. Or they honor the Blessed One, they make him an object of respect. But this is merely a figure of speech, for there is no one who does not honor the Blessed One. “The continuity of their minds” means the continuity of their minds occurring in the past and in the present. The construction is: he teaches the Dhamma in such a way that some establish themselves in arahatship. “Some go forth” is said in order to show that those who attain arahatship are included among those who have gone forth, but not in order to exclude householders from attaining arahatship.

original: Ayañhi arahattappattānaṃ gihīnaṃ sabhāvo, yā tadaheva pabbajjā vā, kālaṃ kiriyāvāti.
analyzed: ayam hi arahatta pattānam gihīnam sabhāvaḥ yā tadahā iva pabbajjā vā kālam kiriyā vā ati
translated: For this is the nature of the lay followers who have reached Arahantship, either to go forth on that very day or to attain final Nibbāna.

original: Tathā hi vuttaṃ āyasmatā nāgasenattherena “visamaṃ mahārāja, gihiliṅgaṃ, visame liṅge
analyzed: tathā hi vuttam āyasmatā nāgasena ttherena visamam mahā rāja gihi liṅgam visame liṅge
translated: For this is said by the venerable elder Nāgasena: “The lay follower’s state is an uneven one, sire,

original: liṅgadubbalatāya arahattaṃ patto gihī tasmiṃyeva divase pabbajati vā parinibbāyati
analyzed: liṅga dubbala tāya arahattam pattaḥ gihī tasmiṃ yeva divase pabbajati vā parinibbāyati
translated: and because of the weakness of the lay follower’s state, sire, the lay follower who has reached Arahantship goes forth on that very day or attains final Nibbāna.

original: vā neso mahārāja, doso arahattassa, gihiliṅgasseveso doso yadidaṃ liṅgadubbalatā”ti
analyzed: vā na isaḥ mahā rāja dosaḥ arahattassa gihi liṅgassa iva īsaḥ dosaḥ yat idam liṅga dubbala tā ati
translated: This, sire, is not a defect in Arahantship, but a defect in the lay follower’s state, namely, the weakness of the lay follower’s state.”

original: sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ. Ettha ca sappāṭihīrappavesanasambandheneva mahājanānuggahaṇaṃ dassitaṃ,🔽appāṭihīrappavesanena ca pana “te sunivatthā supārutā”tiādivacanaṃ yathārahaṃ sambandhitvā
analyzed: sabbam vattabbam ettha ca sappāṭihīra pavesana sambandhena iva mahājana anuggahaṇam dassitam  ca pana te sunivatthā supāruta ati ādi vacanam yathāraham
translated: All this should be quoted. And here the helping of the multitude is shown by the entry with the Great Miracle,

original: mahājanānuggahaṇaṃ atthato vibhāvetabbaṃ hoti. Tampi hi purebhattakiccamevāti. Upaṭṭhānasālā
analyzed: mahājana anuggahaṇam atthataḥ vibhāvetabbam hoti tam pi hi purebhatta kiccam eva ati upaṭṭhāna sālā
translated: and by the entry without the Great Miracle the help given to the multitude should be made clear in meaning by connecting it with the words “They were well clothed and well attended upon” , etc., in the appropriate way. For that was done before breakfast.

original: cettha maṇḍalamāḷo. Tattha gantvā maṇḍalamāḷeti idha pāṭho likhito. “Gandhamaṇḍalamāḷe”tipi🔽manorathapūraṇiyā dissati, taṭṭīkāyañca “catujjātiyagandhena paribhaṇḍe maṇḍalamāḷe”ti
analyzed: tattha gantvā maṇḍalamāḷa iti pāṭhaḥ likhitaḥ gandha maṇḍalamāḷa iti pi  manorathapūraṇiyā dissati tad ṭīkāyan ca catur jātiya gandhena paribhaṇḍe maṇḍalam āḷeti
translated: Here the word ‘maṇḍalamāḷa’ is written in the text as ‘maṇḍalamāḷe’. “In the Perfumed Chamber” is also seen. In the sub-commentary it is said: “In the Perfumed Chamber which is surrounded by the four kinds of perfumes.”🔽🔽

original: vuttaṃ. Gandhakuṭiṃ pavisatīti ca pavisanakiriyāsambandhatāya, tassamīpatāya ca vuttaṃ,🔽tasmā pavisituṃ gacchatīti attho daṭṭhabbo, na pana anto tiṭṭhatīti. Evañhi “atha
analyzed: vuttam gandhakuṭim pavisati iti ca pavisana kiriyā sambandha tāya tad samīpa tāya ca vuttam  tasmā pavisitum gacchati iti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo na pana antar tiṭṭhati iti evam hi atha
translated: Here the word ‘palace’ is used. The reading ‘having gone there to the palace’ is written here. ‘In the fragrant palace’ is seen in the Manorathapūraṇī. And in the sub-commentary it is said: ‘In the palace which is surrounded by the four kinds of fragrant substances.’ ‘Enters the fragrant chamber’ is said because of the connection with the action of entering and because of its nearness.

original: kho bhagavā”tiādivacanaṃ sūpapannaṃ hoti.🔽Atha khoti evaṃ gandhakuṭiṃ pavisituṃ gamanakāle. Upaṭṭhāneti samīpapadese. “Pāde🔽pakkhāletvā pādapīṭhe ṭhatvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ovadatī”ti ettha pāde pakkhālentova pādapīṭhe
analyzed: kho bhagavān ati ādi vacanam su upapannam  atha kho iti evam gandhakuṭim pavisitum gamana kāle upaṭṭhāna iti samīpa padese pāde  pakkhāletvā pāda pīṭhe ṭhatvā bhikkhu saṅgham ovadati iti ettha pāde pakkhālentaḥ uva pāda pīṭhe
translated: Therefore the meaning should be seen as ‘he goes to enter,’ not that he stands inside. For in this way the statement ‘then the Fortunate One’ and so on becomes well-founded.

original: tiṭṭhanto ovadatīti veditabbaṃ. Etadatthaṃyeva hi bhikkhūnaṃ bhattakiccapariyosānaṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhantaḥ ovadati iti veditabbam etad attham yeva hi bhikkhūnam bhatta kicca pariyosānam
translated: Then: at the time of going to enter the fragrant chamber. Upaṭṭhāneti is a locative case. ‘Having washed his feet, standing on the foot-stool, he instructed the Community of monks’ here it should be understood that having washed his feet he stood on the foot-stool and instructed. For this is the meaning: the monks’ meal-time was finished,

original: āgamayamāno nisīdi. Dullabhā sampattīti satipi manussattapaṭilābhe patirūpadesavāsaindriyāvekallasaddhāpaṭilābhādayo
analyzed: āgamayamānaḥ nisīdi dullabhā sampatti iti manus satta paṭilābhe pati rūpa desa vāsa indriya avekalla saddhā paṭilābha ādayaḥ
translated: and sat down. The words “rare to obtain” mean that even though the human state is easy to obtain, the qualities called “accomplishments” — such as living in a suitable place, having intact faculties, and the acquisition of faith — are rare.

original: sampattisaṅkhātā guṇā dullabhāti attho. Potthakesu pana “dullabhā saddhāsampattī”ti🔽pāṭho dissati, so ayuttova. Tatthāti tasmiṃ pādapīṭhe ṭhatvā ovadanakāle, tesu vā
analyzed: sampatti saṅkhātāḥ guṇāḥ dullabhā ti potthakesu pana dullabhā saddhā sampatti iti  pāṭhaḥ dissati saḥ ayuttaḥ iva tattha ati tasmim pāda pīṭhe ṭhatvā ovadana kāle tesu vā
translated: But in the manuscripts the reading is “dullabhā saddhāsampattī” , which is inappropriate.

original: bhikkhūsu, rattiyā vasanaṃ ṭhānaṃ rattiṭṭhānaṃ, tathā divāṭhānaṃ. “Kecī”tiādi tabbivaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhūsu rattiyāḥ vasanam ṭhānam rattiṭṭhānam tathā divāṭhānam keci itiādi tad bivaraṇam
translated: “There” means in the place where he was standing on the footstool and giving the exhortation, or among the bhikkhus. The place where they slept at night is the night quarters, and the place where they slept by day is the day quarters. “Some” and so on are the reasons for the search.

original: Cātumahārājikabhavananti cātumahārājikadevaloke suññavimānāni sandhāya vuttaṃ. Esa🔽nayo tāvatiṃsabhavanādīsupi. Tato bhagavā gandhakuṭiṃ pavisitvā pacchābhattaṃ tayo
analyzed: cātumahārājika bhavanan ti cātumahārājika deva loke suñña vimānāni sandhāya vuttam esa  tatas bhagavā gandhakuṭim pavisitvā pacchābhattam
translated: The “abode of the Four Great Kings” is said with reference to the empty palaces in the realm of the Four Great Kings.

original: bhāge katvā paṭhamabhāge sace ākaṅkhati, dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti, sace
analyzed: bhāge katvā paṭhama bhāge sace ākaṅkhati dakkhiṇena passena sīha seyyam kappeti sace
translated: The same method applies to the abode of the Thirty-three and so on. Then the Blessed One entered the Fragrant Cell and, having eaten his meal, divided the night into three parts. In the first part, if he so desired, he would lie down on his right side in the lion’s posture,

original: nākaṅkhati, buddhāciṇṇaṃ phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati, atha yathākālaparicchedaṃ tato
analyzed: na ākaṅkhati buddha āciṇṇam phala samāpattim samāpajjati atha yathākāla paricchedam tatas
translated: He does not wish to do so, but enters upon the attainment of fruition as a Buddha-practice. Then, after emerging from it at the time he has decided upon,

original: vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyabhāge pacchimayāmassa tatiyakoṭṭhāse viya lokaṃ voloketi veneyyānaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhahitvā dutiya bhāge pacchima yāmassa tatiya koṭṭhāse viya lokam voloketi veneyyānam
translated: in the second part of the night, in the last watch, as it were, he surveys the world. He does so in order to see whether there are any to be trained who have reached the time to be trained.

original: ñāṇaparipākaṃ passituṃ, tenāha “sace ākaṅkhatī”tiādi. Sīhaseyyantiādīnamattho heṭṭhā
analyzed: ñāṇa paripākam passitum tena āha sace ākaṅkhati itiādi sīha seyyanti ādīnam atthaḥ heṭṭhā
translated: That is why he says, “If he wishes” and so on. The meaning of “lion-pose” and so on has been given already.🔽We shall comment only on the words that are not clear.

original: vuttova. Yañhi apubbaṃ padaṃ anuttānaṃ, tadeva vaṇṇayissāma. Sammā assāsitabboti
analyzed: vuttaḥ iva yat hi apubbam padam anuttānam tat eva vaṇṇayissāma sammā assāsitabbaḥ ti
translated: “To be exhorted” : to be encouraged by being taken hold of.🔽“Such a body” : one that is so.

original: gāhāpanavasena upatthambhitabboti samassāsito. Tādiso kāyo yassāti tathā. Dhammassavanatthaṃ
analyzed: gāhāpana vasena upatthambhitabbaḥ ti samassāsito tādisaḥ kāyaḥ yassa ati tathā dhamma ssavana attham
translated: “The assembly gathers” : the assembly of those who have gathered together for the purpose of hearing the Dhamma.

original: sannipatati. Tassā parisāya cittācāraṃ ñatvā katabhāvaṃ sandhāyāha “sampattaparisāyaanurūpena
analyzed: sannipatati tassā parisāya citta ācāram ñatvā kata bhāvam sandhāya āha sampatta parisāya anurūpena
translated: Having known the mental behavior of that assembly, he says, “With a miracle that is appropriate to the assembly that has gathered,” referring to the fact that he has done what should be done.

original: pāṭihāriyenā”ti. Yattha dhammaṃ saha bhāsanti, sā dhammasabhā nāma. Kālayuttanti
analyzed: pāṭihāriyena ati yattha dhammam saha bhāsanti sā dhammasabhā nāma kāla yuttan ti
translated: “Where they speak the Dhamma together” is called a Dhamma assembly.

original: “imissā velāya imassa evaṃ vattabba”nti taṃtaṃkālānurūpaṃ. Samayayuttanti tasseva
analyzed: imissā velāya imassa evam vattabbanti tat tat kāla anurūpam samaya yuttam ti tassa iva
translated: “In accordance with the occasion” : in accordance with the time, thinking, “At this time this should be said.”🔽“In accordance with the rule” : in accordance with the rule of the Dhamma.

original: vevacanaṃ, aṭṭhuppattianurūpaṃ vā samayayuttaṃ. Atha vā samayayuttanti hetudāharaṇehi
analyzed: vevacanam aṭṭhuppatti anurūpam vā samaya yuttam atha vā samaya yuttam ti hetu dāharaṇehi
translated: or it is a synonym for it, or it is suitable to the occasion in the sense of being in conformity with the origin of the eight meditative attainments.🔽Or else, “suitable to the occasion” means suitable to the cause and the example.

original: yuttaṃ. Kālena sāpadesañhi bhagavā dhammaṃ deseti. Kālaṃ viditvā parisaṃ uyyojeti,
analyzed: yuttam kālena sa apadesam hi bhagavā dhammam deseti kālam viditvā parisam uyyojeti
translated: For the Exalted One teaches the Dhamma at the appropriate time. Knowing the time, he dismisses the assembly.

original: na yāva samandhakārā dhammaṃ desetīti adhippāyo. “Samayaṃ viditvā parisaṃ uyyojesī”tipi
analyzed: na yāva samandhakārā dhammam deseti iti adhippāyaḥ samayam viditvā parisam uyyojesi iti pi
translated: The intention is that he does not teach the Dhamma until the darkness has fallen. “Having known the time, he dismisses the assembly” is a reading found in some places.

original: katthaci pariyāyavacanapāṭho dissati, so pacchā pamādalikhito.
analyzed: katthaci pariyāya vacana pāṭhaḥ dissati saḥ pacchā pamāda likhitaḥ
translated: This is a later interpolation due to negligence.

original: Gattānīti kāyoyeva anekāvayavattā vutto. “Utuṃ gaṇhāpetī”ti iminā utugaṇhāpanatthameva
analyzed: gattāni iti kāyaḥ yā iva aneka avayavattā vuttaḥ utum gaṇhāpeti iti iminā utu gaṇhāpana attham eva
translated: “The one with the veins” is so called because the body has many parts. By the words “he had the weather taken” he shows that the sprinkling was done only for the purpose of taking the weather,

original: osiñcanaṃ, na pana malavikkhālanatthanti dasseti. Na hi bhagavato kāye rajojallaṃ
analyzed: osiñcanam na pana mala vikkhālana atthanti dasseti na hi bhagavataḥ kāye rajojallam
translated: and not for the purpose of washing away dirt, for dust and dirt do not soil the Exalted One’s body.

original: upalimpatīti. Catujjātikena gandhena paribhāvitā kuṭī gandhakuṭī. Tassā pariveṇaṃ
analyzed: upalimpati iti catur jātikena gandhena paribhāvitā kuṭī gandha kuṭī tassā pariveṇam
translated: The fragrant chamber is perfumed with the four noble fragrances. The courtyard is also like that.

original: tathā. Phalasamāpattīhi muhuttaṃ paṭisallīno. Tato tatoti attano attano rattiṭṭhānadivāṭhānato,
analyzed: tathā phala samāpattīhi muhuttam paṭisallīno tatas tatas ti attanaḥ attanaḥ ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭhānato
translated: He was secluded for a moment by the attainment of the fruit. “From here and there” means from his own night quarters and day quarters.

original: upagantvā, samīpe vā ṭhānaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ, bhajanaṃ sevananti attho. Tatthāti tasmiṃ
analyzed: upagantvā samīpe vā ṭhānam upaṭṭhānam bhajanam sevananti attho tattha ati tasmin
translated: and having approached, a place near to them is a resort, the meaning is, a service. Therein

original: nisīdanaṭṭhāne, purimayāme vā, tesu vā bhikkhūsu.🔽Pañhākathanādivasena adhippāyaṃ sampādento “dasasahassilokadhātū”ti evaṃ avatvā tassā
analyzed: nisīdana ṭṭhāne purima yāme vā tesu vā bhikkhūsu  pañhā kathana ādi vasena adhippāyam sampādentaḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātū ti evam avatvā tassā
translated: Having approached, or a place near to it is a resort. The meaning is: she served. Therein means in that place for sitting down, or in the first watch of the night, or in those bhikkhus.

original: anekāvayavasaṅgahaṇatthaṃ “sakaladasasahassilokadhātū”ti vuttaṃ. Purebhattapacchābhattapurimayāmesu
analyzed: aneka avayava saṅgahaṇa attham sakala dasa sahassi lokadhātu iti vuttam purebhatta pacchābhatta purima yāmesu
translated: Satisfying her intention by means of answering questions, etc., she said “the entire ten-thousandfold world-element” instead of “the ten-thousandfold world-element” in order to include its many components.

original: manussaparisābāhullato okāsaṃ alabhitvā idāni majjhimayāmeyeva okāsaṃ labhamānā,
analyzed: manussa parisā bāhullataḥ okāsam a labhitvā idāni okāsam labhamānā
translated: In the morning, after the meal, and in the first watch of the night, she did not get an opportunity because of the great number of human assemblies. Now, getting an opportunity only in the middle watch,

original: bhagavatā vā katokāsatāya okāsaṃ labhamānāti adhippāyo. Kīdisaṃ pana pucchantīti
analyzed: bhagavatā vā kata ukāsa tāya okāsam labhamānā ati adhippāyaḥ kīdisam pana pucchanti iti
translated: she got an opportunity because of the opportunity given by the Blessed One. This is the intention. But what kind of question did she ask?

original: āha “yathābhisaṅkhataṃ antamaso caturakkharampī”ti. Yathābhisaṅkhatanti abhisaṅkhatānurūpaṃ,
analyzed: āha yathā abhisaṅkhatam antamasaḥ iti yathā abhisaṅkhatanti abhisaṅkhata anurūpam
translated: He said: “as it was conceived, even if it were only four lines.” As it was conceived means according to the conception,

original: tadanatikkamma vā, etena yathā tathā attano paṭibhānānurūpaṃ pucchantīti dasseti.
analyzed: tat an atikkamma vā etena yathā tathā attanaḥ paṭibhāna anurūpam pucchanti iti dasseti
translated: without exceeding it. By this he shows that she asked according to her own inspiration, in whatever way.

original: Pacchābhattakālassa tīsu bhāgesu paṭhamabhāge sīhaseyyākappanaṃ ekantaṃ na hotīti
analyzed: pacchābhatta kālassa tīsu bhāgesu paṭhama bhāge sīha seyyā kappanam ekantam na hoti iti
translated: The lying down in the lion’s posture is not exclusively in the first of the three divisions of the night after the time for eating in the evening,

original: āha “purebhattato paṭṭhāya nisajjāya pīḷitassa sarīrassā”ti. Teneva hi pubbe “sace
analyzed: āha purebhattataḥ paṭṭhāya nisajjāya pīḷitassa sarīrassa ati tena iva hi pubbe sace
translated: so it is said, “When the body is tired by sitting in the earlier part of the night.” For it is shown that the lying down in the lion’s posture is not fixed by the words, “If he is so wishing” .

original: ākaṅkhatī”ti tadā sīhaseyyākappanassa anibaddhatā vibhāvitā. Kilāsubhāvo kilamatho.
analyzed: ākaṅkhati iti tadā sīha seyyā kappanassa anibaddha tā vibhāvitā kilāsu bhāvaḥ kilamatho
translated: Fatigue is weariness.

original: Sarīrassa kilāsubhāvamocanatthaṃ caṅkamena vītināmeti sīhaseyyaṃ kappetīti sambandho.
analyzed: sarīrassa kilāsu bhāva mocana attham caṅkamena vītināmeti sīhaseyyam kappeti iti sambandho
translated: The construction is: “In order to remove the fatigue of the body he spends the time by pacing up and down and then he lies down in the lion’s posture.”

original: Buddhacakkhunāti āsayānusayaindriyaparopariyattañāṇasaṅkhātena pañcamachaṭṭhabalabhūtena🔽buddhacakkhunā. Tena hi lokavolokanabāhullatāya taṃ “buddhacakkhū”ti vuccati, idañca
analyzed: buddha cakkhunā ti āsaya anusaya aindriya para upari yatta ñāṇa saṅkhātena pañcama chaṭṭha bala bhūtena  buddha cakkhunā tena hi loka volokana bāhulla tāya tam buddha cakkhu iti vuccati idam ca
translated: With the eye of a Buddha: with the eye of a Buddha consisting in the knowledge of the fifth and sixth powers, that is to say, the knowledge of the disposition of other beings’ faculties and the knowledge of the defilement and cleansing of the paths.

original: pacchimayāme bhagavato bahulaṃ āciṇṇavasena vuttaṃ. Appekadā avasiṭṭhabalañāṇehi,
analyzed: pacchima yāme bhagavataḥ bahulam āciṇṇa vasena vuttam appekadā avasiṭṭha bala ñāṇehi
translated: For that is called the “eye of a Buddha” because of the abundance of looking at the world with it. And this is said because the Blessed One usually did it in the last watch of the night. Sometimes he did it with the knowledge of remaining strength and with the knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇeneva ca bhagavā tamatthaṃ sādheti.
analyzed: sabbaññu tad ññāṇena iva ca bhagavā tam attham sādheti
translated: The Blessed One establishes that matter with the knowledge of omniscience.

original: “Pacchimayāmakiccaṃ karonto aññāsī”ti pubbe vuttamatthaṃ samatthento “tasmiṃ pana🔽divase”tiādimāha. Buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ yattha katthaci vasantānaṃ idaṃ pañcavidhaṃ🔽kiccaṃ avijahitameva hoti sabbakālaṃ suppatiṭṭhitasatisampajaññattā, tasmā tadahepi
analyzed: pacchima yāma kiccam karontaḥ aññāsi iti pubbe vutta mattham samatthento tasmim pana  divasa iti ādim āha buddhānam bhagavantānam yattha katthacid idam pañcavidham  kiccam a vijahitam eva hoti sabbakālam su patiṭṭhita sati sampajañña ttā tasmā tad ahe pi
translated: “He knew while performing the last watch of the night” — the meaning of this statement made previously is being restated by the words “On that day, etc.”🔽Wherever the Blessed Buddhas reside, these five duties are never neglected by them at any time, because their mindfulness and clear comprehension are well-established. Therefore, on that day too,🔽

original: tadavijahanabhāvadassanatthaṃ idha pañcavidhakiccapayojananti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Caṅkamanti
analyzed: tad avijahana bhāva dassana attham idha pañcavidha kicca payojananti daṭṭhabbam caṅkamanti
translated: “He knew while performing the last watch of the night” — the meaning of this statement was already explained above. The meaning of the phrase “on that occasion” is as follows: Wherever the Blessed One, the Exalted One, resides, these five watches of the night are never neglected by him, for his mindfulness and clear comprehension are well established at all times. Therefore, in order to show that on that day also he did not neglect them, it should be understood that the five watches of the night are mentioned here as the purpose of the discourse. He walked up and down.

original: tattha caṅkamanānurūpaṭṭhānaṃ. Caṅkamamāno aññāsīti yojetabbaṃ. Pubbe vutte atthadvaye
analyzed: tattha caṅkamana anurūpa ṭṭhānam caṅkamamāno aññāsi iti yojetabbam pubbe vutte attha dvaye
translated: The place for walking up and down is there. He knew while walking up and down.

original: pacchimatthaññeva gahetvā “sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ ārabbhā”ti vuttaṃ. Purimattho hi pakaraṇādhigatattā suviññeyyoti.
analyzed: gahetvā sabbaññuta ññāṇam ārabbha iti vuttam purimatthaḥ hi pakaraṇa adhigata ttā su viññeyyaḥ ti
translated: The meaning of the last watch of the night should be understood as stated in the commentary on the passage “He knew while performing the last watch of the night.”

original: “Atha kho bhagavā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ imaṃ saṅkhiyadhammaṃ viditvā yena maṇḍalamāḷo,
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tesam bhikkhūnam imam saṅkhiya dhammam viditvā yena maṇḍala māḷaḥ
translated: “Then the Blessed One, having understood the significance of this, on that occasion recited this verse:

original: tenupasaṅkamī”ti ayaṃ sāvasesapāṭho, tasmā etaṃ viditvā, evaṃ cintetvā ca upasaṅkamīti
analyzed: tena upasaṅkami iti ayam tasmai etam viditvā evam cintetvā ca upasaṅkami iti
translated: “I will approach him” is the reading with a remainder. Therefore, in order to show that the meaning should be understood thus: “Having understood this, having thought thus, he approached,”

original: attho veditabboti dassetuṃ “ñatvā ca panassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha assa etadahosīti
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti dassetum ñatvā ca pana assa atiādi vuttam tattha assa etat ahosi iti
translated: it is said: “Having understood this, he thought: ‘I will approach him.’ ” Herein, this occurred to him means

original: assa bhagavato etaṃ parivitakkanaṃ, eso vā cetaso parivitakko ahosi, liṅgavipallāsoyaṃ
analyzed: assa bhagavataḥ etam parivitakkanam esaḥ vā cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ ahosi liṅga vipallāsaḥ ayam
translated: this occurred to the Blessed One as a thought, or this was the thought in his mind. This is a case of inversion of the normal word-order,

original: “etadagga”ntiādīsu viya. Sabbaññutaññāṇakiccaṃ na sabbathā pākaṭaṃ. Nirantaranti
analyzed: etat agga nti ādīsu viya sabbaññu taññāṇa kiccam na sabbathā pākaṭam nirantaram ti
translated: like the expression “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ …pe… sekkhāgamana” . The function of the knowledge of omniscience is not evident in all instances. Without a break means

original: anupubbārocanavasena nibbivaraṃ, yathābhāsitassa vā ārocanavasena nibbisesaṃ. Bhāvanapuṃsakañcetaṃ.🔽Taṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvāti taṃ yathārocitaṃ vacanaṃ imassa suttassa uppattikāraṇaṃ🔽katvā, imassa vā suttassa desanāya uppannaṃ kāraṇaṃ katvātipi attho. Attha-saddo
analyzed: anupubba ārocana vasena nibbivaram yathā bhāsitassa vā ārocana vasena nibbisesam bhāva napuṃsakam ca itam  tam aṭṭhuppattim katvā ati tam yathārocitam vacanam imassa suttassa uppatti kāraṇam  katvā imassa vā suttassa desanāya uppannam kāraṇam katvā atipi atthaḥ attha saddaḥ
translated: without a sequence, or without a remainder, in the sense of the proclamation of what has been spoken. The word bhāvanā is masculine.🔽Having made that the origin of the sutta means having made that statement as it was proclaimed the reason for the arising of this sutta,🔽or having made the reason for the teaching of this sutta. The word attha

original: cettha kāraṇe, tena imassa suttassa aṭṭhuppattikaṃ nikkhepaṃ dasseti. Dvāsaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: ca ittha kāraṇe tena imassa suttassa aṭṭhuppattikam nikkhepam dasseti dvāsaṭṭhiyā
translated: here means “reason.” Therefore he shows that the introduction of this sutta is its origin. The sixty-two

original: ṭhānesūti dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigataṭṭhānesu. Appaṭivattiyanti samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā
analyzed: ṭhānesu iti dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata ṭṭhānesu appaṭivattiyanti samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā
translated: In the sense of the sixty-two views.🔽Not to be turned back by anyone in the world, by a recluse or a brahmin,

original: devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ anivattiyaṃ. Sīhanādaṃ nadantoti
analyzed: devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenacid vā lokasmin anivattiyam sīha nādam nadanto ti
translated: by a god, a Mara or a Brahma.🔽Roaring his lion’s roar:

original: seṭṭhanādasaṅkhātaṃ abhītanādaṃ nadanto. Yaṃ pana lokiyā vadanti –
analyzed: seṭṭha nāda saṅkhātam abhīta nādam nadantaḥ yam pana lokiyāḥ vadanti
translated: The lion’s roar is a fearless roar. But what the worldlings say,

original: “Uttarasmiṃ pade byagghapuṅgavosabhakuñjarā;
analyzed: uttarasmin pade byaggha puṅgava usabha kuñjarā
translated: “In the northern countries the lion, the bull, the elephant,

original: Sīhasaddūlanāgādyā, pume seṭṭhatthagocarā”ti.
analyzed: sīha saddūla nāga ādyā pume seṭṭhattha gocarā ti
translated: The lion, the tiger, the dragon, etc., are the best of males,”

original: Taṃ yebhuyyavasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sīhanādasadisaṃ vā nādaṃ nadanto. Ayamattho sīhanādasuttena
analyzed: tam yebhuyya vasena ati daṭṭhabbam sīha nāda sadisam vā nādam nadantaḥ ayam attho sīha nāda suttena
translated: should be understood as being so only in the main. Or else, he is roaring a roar similar to the lion’s roar. This meaning should be illustrated by the Sīhanāda Sutta.

original: dīpetabbo. Yathā vā kesaro migarājā sahanato, hananato, ca “sīho”ti vuccati, evaṃ
analyzed: dīpetabbaḥ yathā vā kesaraḥ miga rājā sahanataḥ hananataḥ ca sīhaḥ ti vuccati evam
translated: Or just as the kīsa flower is called “lion” because it is similar to the lion in color and shape,

original: tathāgatopi lokadhammānaṃ sahanato, parappavādānaṃ hananato ca “sīho”ti vuccati.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ api loka dhammānam sahanato para ppavādānam hananato ca sīhaḥ ti vuccati
translated: so too the Tathāgata is called “lion” because he is similar to the lion in that he endures and destroys.

original: Tasmā sīhassa tathāgatassa nādaṃ nadantotipi attho daṭṭhabbo. Yathā hi sīho sīhabalena
analyzed: tasmā sīhassa tathāgatassa nādam nadantaḥ iti pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo yathā hi sīhaḥ sīha balena
translated: Therefore the meaning “roaring the lion’s roar of the Tathāgata” should be understood. For just as the lion,

original: samannāgato sabbattha visārado vigatalomahaṃso sīhanādaṃ nadati, evaṃ tathāgatasīhopi🔽tathāgatabalehi samannāgato aṭṭhasu parisāsu visārado vigatalomahaṃso “ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā”tiādinā
analyzed: samannāgataḥ sabbattha visāradaḥ vigata loma haṃsaḥ sīha nādam nadati evam tathāgata sīhaḥ pi  tathāgata balehi samannāgataḥ aṭṭhasu parisāsu visāradaḥ vigata lomahaṃsaḥ ime diṭṭhiṭṭhāna ati ādinā
translated: He is endowed with all the powers, is confident in all circumstances, and roars his lion’s roar without fear or trembling. So too the Tathāgata,

original: nayena nānāvidhadesanāvilāsasampannaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “sīhoti
analyzed: nayena nānāvidha desanā vilāsa sampannam sīha nādam nadati yam sandhāya vuttam sīhaḥ ti
translated: endowed with the Tathāgata’s powers, is confident in all circumstances, and roars his lion’s roar without fear or trembling, displaying his various kinds of knowledge in the eight assemblies, saying: “These are the standpoints for views.”

original: kho bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa. Yaṃ kho bhikkhave,
analyzed: kho bhikkhave tathāgatassa itam adhivacanam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa yam kho bhikkhave
translated: It is with reference to this that it is said: “Bhikkhus, the Tathāgata is a lion, a supreme bull, a great Nāga.

original: tathāgato parisāya dhammaṃ deseti, idamassa hoti sīhanādasmi”nti. “Ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā”tiādikā🔽hi idha vakkhamānadesanāyeva sīhanādo. Tesaṃ “vedanāpaccayā taṇhā”tiādinā vakkhamānanayena
analyzed: tathāgataḥ parisāya dhammam deseti idam assa hoti sīha nādasmin ti ime diṭṭhiṭṭhāna ati ādikā  hi idha vakkhamāna desanāyā iva sīha nādaḥ tesam vedanā paccayā taṇhā āti ādinā vakkhamāna nayena
translated: When the Tathāgata teaches the Dhamma to the assembly, this is his lion’s roar.”🔽The teaching given here beginning with the words “These are the standpoints for views” is itself the lion’s roar. The combination of the teaching with the principle of conditionality, which will be given in the passage beginning “With feeling as condition, craving” , should also be understood as the lion’s roar.

original: paccayākārassa samodhānampi veditabbaṃ. Sineruṃ…pe… viya cāti upamādvayena brahmajāladesanāya
analyzed: paccaya ākārassa samodhānam pi veditabbam sineruṃpe viya ca ati upamā dvayena brahma jāla desanāya
translated: And like Sineru, etc.—by the two similes.

original: anaññasādhāraṇattā sudukkarataṃ dasseti. Suvaṇṇakūṭenāti suvaṇṇamayapaharaṇopakaraṇavisesena.
analyzed: anañña sādhāraṇa ttā su dukkara tam dasseti suvaṇṇa kūṭena ati suvaṇṇa maya paharaṇa upakaraṇa visesena
translated: He shows the difficulty of attainment by the fact that it is not shared by others. ‘With a golden pinnacle’: with a special golden ornament on the top.

original: Ratananikūṭena viya agāraṃ arahattanikūṭena brahmajālasuttantaṃ niṭṭhapento, nikūṭenāti
analyzed: ratana nikūṭena viya agāram arahatta nikūṭena brahmajāla suttantam niṭṭhapentaḥ nikūṭena ati
translated: ‘With the pinnacle of Arahantship’ as though with a pinnacle of jewels. He concludes the Brahmajāla Sutta with the word ‘pinnacle’ .

original: ca niṭṭhānagatena accuggatakūṭenāti attho. Idañca arahattaphalapariyosānattā sabbaguṇānaṃ🔽tadeva sabbesaṃ uttaritaranti vuttaṃ. Purimo pana me-saddo desanāpekkhoti parinibbutassāpi
analyzed: ca niṭṭhāna gatena accuggata kūṭena ati attho idam ca arahatta phala pariyosāna ttā sabba guṇānam  tat eva sabbesam uttaritaran ti vuttam purimaḥ pana me saddo desanā apekkho ti parinibbutassa api
translated: ‘Pinnacle’ means ‘having reached the top’. And this is said because all the special qualities culminate in the fruit of Arahantship.

original: me sā desanā aparabhāge pañcavassasahassānīti attho yutto. Savanauggahaṇadhāraṇavācanādivasena

original: paricayaṃ karonte, tathā ca paṭipanne nibbānaṃ sampāpikā bhavissatīti adhippāyo.

original: aññāyeva, tehi ca asammissattā visuṃ ekāyevāti adhippāyaṃ dassetuṃ “aññā, ekā”ti
analyzed: aññāya iva tehi ca a sammissa ttā visum ekāya iva ati adhippāyam dassetuṃ aññā ekā ti
translated: because it is the middle of those, and it is “separate” because it is not mixed up with them. The intention is to show that it is “another” and “separate.”

original: ca vuttaṃ. Pakārena karaṇaṃ pakato, tato vigatā, vigataṃ vā pakataṃ yassāti vippakatā,
analyzed: ca vuttam pakārena karaṇam pakataḥ tatas vigatā vigatam vā pakatam yassa ati vippakatā
translated: and it is said. The state of being cooked is cooking; that which is free from that is free from cooking.

original: apariniṭṭhitā. Sikhanti pariyosānaṃ. Ayaṃ pana tadabhisambandhavasena uttari kathetukamyatāpucchā,
analyzed: a pariniṭṭhitā sikhanti pariyosānam ayam pana tad abhisambandha vasena uttari kathetu kamya tā pucchā
translated: It is not completed. The end is the conclusion. But this is a question asked with a desire to speak further in connection with that.

original: taṃ sandhāyāha “nāha”ntiādi. Kathābhaṅgatthanti kathāya bhañjanatthaṃ. Atthato āpannattā
analyzed: tam sandhāya āha na aham iti ādi kathā bhaṅga ttham ti kathāya bhañjana ttham atthataḥ āpanna ttā
translated: With reference to that he said “No” and so on. For the sake of breaking off the discussion: for the purpose of breaking off the discussion. Because the meaning is included,

original: sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavāreti. Aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā kathā
analyzed: sabbaññu pavāraṇam pavāreti aniyyānika ttā saggamokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtā kathā
translated: he invites the all-knowing one to speak. Because it is not the way to heaven or to deliverance, the discussion is animal-like.

original: tiracchānakathā. Tiracchānabhūtāti ca tirokaraṇabhūtā, vibandhanabhūtāti attho. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: tiracchāna kathā tiracchāna bhūtā ati ca tirokaraṇa bhūtā vibandhana bhūtā ati atthaḥ ādi saddena
translated: It is animal-like discussion. And animal-like means concealing, obstructing, is the meaning. By the word “and so on”

original: cettha coramahāmattasenābhayakathādikaṃ anekavihitaṃ niratthakakathaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: ca ittha cora mahāmatta senā bhaya kathā ādikam aneka vihitam niratthaka katham saṅgaṇhāti
translated: here he includes in the animal-like discussion many kinds of pointless discussion such as talk about thieves, ministers, armies, dangers, and so on.

original: Ayaṃ kathā evāti antogadhāvadhāraṇataṃ, aññatthāpohanaṃ vā sandhāya cetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ayam kathā eva iti aññattha apohanam vā sandhāya ca itam vuttam
translated: This discussion is just that: this is said with reference to the inclusion of the discussion within the definition, or to the exclusion of other meanings.

original: Athāti tassā avippakatakāleyeva. “Taṃ no”tiādinā atthato āpannamāha. Esa nayo īdisesu.
analyzed: atha ati tassāḥ a vippakata kāleya iva tam no ti ādinā atthataḥ āpannam āha esa nayaḥ īdisesu
translated: “Then” means at the time when they were not yet dispersed. “That is our loss” is the meaning of the words “taṃ no” . The same method applies to the other words.

original: Nanu ca tehi bhikkhūhi sā kathā “iti ha me”tiādinā yathādhippāyaṃ niṭṭhāpitāyevāti?
analyzed: nanu ca tehi bhikkhūhi sā kathā iti ha mā iti ādinā yathā adhippāyam niṭṭhāpitāya eva ati
translated: But was not that discussion concluded by those bhikkhus in the way they intended with the words “Thus have I heard” ?

original: Na niṭṭhāpitā bhagavato upasaṅkamanena upacchinnattā. Yadi hi bhagavā tasmiṃ khaṇe
analyzed: na niṭṭhāpitā bhagavataḥ upasaṅkamanena upacchinna ttā yadi hi bhagavā tasmin khaṇe
translated: It was not concluded, because it was interrupted by the arrival of the Exalted One. For if the Exalted One had not arrived at that time,

original: na upasaṅkameyya, bhiyyopi tappaṭibaddhāyeva tathā pavatteyyuṃ, bhagavato upasaṅkamanena
analyzed: na upasaṅkameyya bhiyyas pi tad paṭibaddhāya iva tathā pavatteyyum bhagavataḥ upasaṅkamanena
translated: they would have continued to talk about the same thing even more, but because of the arrival of the Exalted One,

original: pana na pavattesuṃ, tenevāha “ayaṃ no…pe… anuppatto”ti.🔽Idāni nidānassa, nidānavaṇṇanāya vā pariniṭṭhitabhāvaṃ dassento tassa bhagavato vacanassānukūlabhāvampi
analyzed: pana na pavattesum tena iva āha ayam nope anuppatto ti  idāni nidānassa nidāna vaṇṇanāya vā pariniṭṭhita bhāvam dassento tassa bhagavataḥ vacanassa anukūla bhāvam pi
translated: they did not continue to talk about it. Therefore the Exalted One said, “This talk of yours has come to this … has arrived at this.”

original: samatthetuṃ “ettāvatā”tiādimāha. Ettāvatāti hi ettakena “evaṃ me suta”ntiādivacanakkamena
analyzed: samatthetum ettāvatā atiādim āha ettāvatā ati hi ettakena evam me suta nti ādi vacana kkamena
translated: Now, in order to show that the introduction and the commentary on the introduction are finished, and also to establish the suitability of the words of the Exalted One, the commentator says “ettāvatā” . “Ettāvatā” means “in this way” with the words “evaṃ me suta” ,

original: yaṃ nidānaṃ bhāsitanti vā ettakena “tattha evanti nipātapada”ntiādivacanakkamena
analyzed: yam nidānam bhāsitanti vā ettakena tattha evanti nipāta pada nti ādi vacana kkamena
translated: or “in this much” with the words “tattha evanti nipātapada” .

original: atthavaṇṇanā samattāti vā dvidhā attho daṭṭhabbo. “Kamala…pe… salilāyā”tiādinā pana
analyzed: attha vaṇṇanā samattā ati vā dvidhā attho daṭṭhabbo kamalape salilāya ati ādinā pana
translated: or else the meaning should be regarded as twofold, as commentary and as meaning.🔽But by the words “In the lotus-pool, etc.,” he shows that the words of the Exalted One are in conformity with the nidana.

original: tassa nidānassa bhagavato vacanassānukūlabhāvaṃ dīpeti. Tattha kamalakuvalayujjalavimalasādhurasasalilāyāti🔽kamalasaṅkhātehi padumapuṇḍarīkasetuppalarattuppalehi ceva kuvalayasaṅkhātena nīluppalena🔽ca ujjalavimalasādhurasasalilavatiyā. Nimmalasilātalaracanavilāsasobhitaratanasopānanti
analyzed: tassa nidānassa bhagavataḥ vacanassa anukūla bhāvam dīpeti tattha kamala kuvalaya ujjala vimala sādhu rasa salilāyāti  kamala saṅkhātehi paduma puṇḍarīka setuppala rattuppalehi ca iva kuvalaya saṅkhātena nīluppalena  ca ujjala vimala sādhu rasa salilavatiyā nimmala silā tala racana vilāsa sobhita ratana sopānanti
translated: Herein, in the lotus-pool, etc., means in the lotus-pool which is endowed with clear, pure, beautiful, excellent water.🔽In the lotus-pool which is endowed with clear, pure, beautiful, excellent water, and with the blue lotus called kuvalaya,🔽and with the water lily called paduma, puṇḍarīka, setu, and uppala, and with the red water lily called paduma, puṇḍarīka, setu, and uppala.

original: nimmalena silātalena racanāya vilāsena līlāya sobhitaratanasopānavantaṃ, nimmalasilātalena🔽vā racanavilāsena, susaṅkhatakiriyāsobhena ca sobhitaratanasopānaṃ, vilāsasobhitasaddehi
analyzed: nimmalena silā talena racanāya vilāsena līlāya sobhita ratana sopānavantam nimmala silā talena  vā racana vilāsena ca sobhita ratana sopānam vilāsa sobhita saddehi
translated: With the jewel stairways which are beautiful with the play of the designs in the clear stone slabs, means with the jewel stairways which are beautiful with the play of the designs in the clear stone slabs.🔽Or else, with the jewel stairways which are beautiful with the play of the designs in the clear stone slabs, which are beautiful with the excellence of the well-arranged work.

original: vā ativiya sobhitabhāvo vutto. Vippakiṇṇamuttātalasadisavālukācuṇṇapaṇḍarabhūmibhāganti
analyzed: vā ati viya sobhita bhāvaḥ vutto vippakiṇṇa muttā tala sadisa vālukā cuṇṇa paṇḍara bhūmi bhāgam ti
translated: Or else, the beauty of the play is stated as the beauty of the very beautiful sound of the words which are beautiful with the play of the designs in the clear stone slabs.🔽With the ground which is white like a scattered bed of pearls, with the sand-dust, etc.,

original: vividhena pakiṇṇāya muttāya talasadisānaṃ vālukānaṃ cuṇṇehi paṇḍaravaṇṇabhūmibhāgavantaṃ.

translated: and surrounded. As if wishing to touch the sky, the path of the stars, with its lofty height,🔽the connection is with the word ‘open’ . ‘With an open assembly of revelry’ means with a multitude of revelry.🔽With ivory🔽and with a multitude of the radiance of gems,🔽it is resplendent with beauty. analyzed: samujjala sobhā sampannam suvaṇṇa valaya nupura ādi saṅghaṭṭana sadda sammissita kathita hasita
translated: it is resplendent with beauty. With ivory🔽and with a multitude of the

original: madhurassaragehajanavicaritassāti suvaṇṇamayaniyurapādakaṭakādīnaṃ aññamaññaṃ saṅghaṭṭanena
analyzed: madhurassara geha jana vicaritassa ati suvaṇṇa maya niyura pāda kaṭaka ādīnam aññam aññam saṅghaṭṭanena
translated: and frequented by sweet-voiced birds,🔽and by the tinkling of golden and silver anklets, etc.,

original: janitasaddehi sammissitakathitasarahasitasarasaṅkhātena madhurassarena sampannānaṃ🔽gehanivāsīnaṃ naranārīnaṃ vicaritaṭṭhānabhūtassa. Uḷārissariyavibhavasobhitassāti
analyzed: janita saddehi sammissita kathita sara hasita sara saṅkhātena madhurassarena sampannānam  geha nivāsīnam nara nārīnam vicarita ṭṭhāna bhūtassa uḷāri ssariya vibhava sobhitassa ati
translated: And frequented by men and women of sweet voices, etc. : frequented by men and women living in the palace, who are endowed with sweet voices, sweet laughter, and sweet conversation, which are produced by the mutual contact of golden and silver anklets, bracelets, etc.,

original: uḷāratāsampannajanaissariyasampannajanavibhavasampannajanehi, tannivāsīnaṃ vā naranārīnaṃ🔽uttamādhipaccabhogehi sobhitassa. Suvaṇṇarajatamaṇimuttāpavāḷādijutivissaravijjotitasuppatiṭṭhitavisāla
analyzed: uḷāra tā sampanna jana aissariya sampanna jana vibhava sampanna janehi tad nivāsīnam vā  uttama adhi pacca bhogehi sobhitassa
translated: And resplendent with great wealth and noble possessions: resplendent with people endowed with great beauty, with people endowed with noble possessions, or with the best possessions of men and women living there,

original: dvārabāhanti suvaṇṇarajatanānāmaṇimuttāpavāḷādīnaṃ jutīhi pabhassaravijjotitasuppatiṭṭhitavitthatadvārabāhaṃ.
analyzed: dvāra bāhanti suvaṇṇa rajata nānā maṇi muttā pavāḷa ādīnam jutīhi pabhassara vijjotita suppatiṭṭhita vitthata dvāra bāham
translated: And with its wide doors and architraves well established and illuminated by the radiance of the light of gold, silver, gems, pearls, cat’s eyes, etc.

original: Tividhasīlādidassanavasena buddhassa guṇānubhāvaṃ sammā sūcetīti buddhaguṇānubhāvasaṃsūcakaṃ,
analyzed: tividha sīla ādi dassana vasena buddhassa guṇa anubhāvam sammā sūceti iti buddha guṇa anubhāva saṃsūcakam
translated: It is called “indicating the power of the Buddha’s virtues” because it correctly indicates the power of the Buddha’s virtues by showing the threefold virtue, etc.

original: tassa. Kālo ca deso ca desako ca vatthu ca parisā ca, tāsaṃ apadesena nidassanena paṭimaṇḍitaṃ tathā.🔽Kimatthaṃ panettha dhammavinayasaṅgahe kariyamāne nidānavacanaṃ vuttaṃ, nanu bhagavatā
analyzed: tassa kālo ca deso ca desako ca vatthu ca parisā ca tāsam apadesena nidassanena paṭimaṇḍitam tathā  kimattham pana ittha dhamma vinaya saṅgahe kariyamāne nidāna vacanam vuttam nanu bhagavatā
translated: and the time, the place, the teacher, the subject, and the assembly, and the discourse is adorned with the description of these.🔽But why is the statement of the occasion made in the recitation of the Dhamma and Discipline? Should not the recitation be confined to the words actually spoken by the Blessed One?

original: bhāsitavacanasseva saṅgaho kātabboti? Vuccate – desanāya ṭhitiasammosasaddheyyabhāvasampādanatthaṃ.🔽Kāladesadesakavatthuparisāpadesehi upanibandhitvā ṭhapitā hi desanā ciraṭṭhitikā
analyzed: bhāsita vacanassa iva saṅgahaḥ kātabbaḥ iti vuccate desanāya ṭhiti asammosa saddheyya bhāva sampādana attham  kāla desa desaka vatthu parisā apadesehi upanibandhitvā ṭhapitā hi desanā cira ṭṭhitikā
translated: It is said that the statement of the occasion is made in order to ensure the teaching’s permanence, its freedom from corruption, and its credibility.🔽For a teaching that is established by being connected with a time, a place, a teacher, a subject, and an assembly will endure long.

original: hoti, asammosadhammā, saddheyyā ca desakālavatthuhetunimittehi upanibandho viya vohāravinicchayo,
analyzed: hoti asammosa dhammā saddheyyā ca desa kāla vatthu hetu nimittehi upanibandhaḥ viya vohāra vinicchayo
translated: It will not be subject to corruption, just as legal procedure is credible when it is connected with a place, a time, a teacher, a subject, and a reason.

original: teneva cāyasmatā mahākassapena “brahmajālaṃ āvuso ānanda kattha bhāsita”ntiādinā🔽desādipucchāsu katāsu tāsaṃ vissajjanaṃ karontena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena āyasmatā ānandattherena
analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmatā mahākassapena brahma jālam āvuso ānanda kattha bhāsita nti ādinā 🔽desa ādi pucchāsu katāsu tāsam vissajjanam karontena dhammabhaṇḍa āgārikena āyasmatā ānanda ttherena
translated: That is why, when the venerable Mahākassapa asked the venerable Ānanda, the venerable Ānanda, the treasurer of the Dhamma,

original: nidānaṃ bhāsitanti tadevidhāpi vuttaṃ “kāladesadesakavatthuparisāpadesapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ nidāna”nti.🔽Apica satthusampattipakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacanaṃ. Tathāgatassa hi bhagavato pubba-racanā-numānāgama-takkābhāvato🔽sammāsambuddhattasiddhi. Sammāsambuddhabhāvena hissa puretaraṃ racanāya, “evampi🔽nāma bhaveyyā”ti anumānassa, āgamantaraṃ nissāya parivitakkassa ca abhāvo sabbattha
analyzed: nidānam bhāsitan ti tadevidhā api vuttam kāla desa desaka vatthu parisā apadesa paṭimaṇḍitam nidānan ti  apica satthu sampatti pakāsana attham nidāna vacanam tathāgatassa hi bhagavataḥ pubba racanā anumāna āgama takka abhāvato  sammāsambuddha tta siddhi sammāsambuddha bhāvena hi ssa puretaram racanāya evam pi  nāma bhaveyya ati anumānassa āgama antaram nissāya parivitakkassa ca abhāvo sabbattha
translated: and the source is said to be the occasion. It is also said: “The source is adorned with the time, the place, the district, the persons, the occasion, and the setting. ”🔽Moreover, the source is stated in order to proclaim the excellence of the Teacher. For the Exalted One, the Tathāgata, is a Perfectly Enlightened One, because he has no need for the prior arrangement of his teaching, for inference, or for scriptural tradition.

original: appaṭihatañāṇacāratāya ekappamāṇattā ñeyyadhammesu. Tathā ācariyamuṭṭhidhammamacchariyasāsanasāvakānurodhabhāvato
analyzed: a paṭihata ñāṇa cāra tāya eka ppamāṇa ttā ñeyya dhammesu tathā ācariya muṭṭhi dhamma macchariya sāsana sāvaka anurodha bhāvato
translated: For the Perfectly Enlightened One has no need for prior arrangement, saying, “Thus may it be in the future”; nor for inference, which is the investigation of a matter by one’s own mind, depending on another scriptural tradition; nor for scriptural tradition, which is the investigation of a matter by one’s own mind, depending on another scriptural tradition. He is the one and only measure in all matters to be known, because his knowledge extends everywhere without obstruction.🔽And he is one whose cankers are destroyed, because he has no need for a teacher, for the Dhamma, for stinginess, for disciples, or for compliance with the world.

original: khīṇāsavattasiddhi. Khīṇāsavatāya hi ācariyamuṭṭhiādīnamabhāvo, visuddhā ca parānuggahappavatti.
analyzed: khīṇāsavatta siddhi khīṇāsavatāya hi ācariya muṭṭhi ādīnam abhāvaḥ visuddhā ca para anuggaha ppavatti
translated: For one whose cankers are destroyed has no need for a teacher, etc., and his pure activity is directed only toward helping others.

original: Iti desakasaṃkilesabhūtānaṃ diṭṭhisīlasampattidūsakānaṃ avijjātaṇhānaṃ abhāvasaṃsūcakehi,
analyzed: iti desaka saṃkilesa bhūtānam diṭṭhi sīla sampatti dūsakānam avijjā taṇhānam abhāva saṃsūcakehi
translated: Thus the source is stated in order to proclaim the excellence of the Teacher, in order to show the non-existence of ignorance and craving, which are the defilements of the place, and which defile the excellence of view and morality.

original: ñāṇappahānasampadābhibyañjanakehi ca sambuddhavisuddhabhāvehi purimavesārajjadvayasiddhi.
analyzed: ñāṇa ppahāna sampadā abhibyañjanakehi ca sambuddha visuddha bhāvehi
translated: and the success in the two kinds of confidence mentioned first is due to the qualities of being fully enlightened and being purified in the Dispensation.

original: Tatoyeva ca antarāyikaniyyānikesu sammohābhāvasiddhito pacchimavesārajjadvayasiddhīti
analyzed: ca antarāyika niyyānikesu sammoha abhāva siddhito pacchima vesārajja dvaya siddhi iti
translated: And the success in the two kinds of confidence mentioned last is due to the absence of confusion about the hindrances and the way to deliverance.

original: bhagavato catuvesārajjasamannāgamo, attahitaparahitapaṭipatti ca nidānavacanena pakāsitā🔽hoti sampattaparisāya ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānena dhammadesanādīpanato,🔽“jānatā passatā”tiādivacanato ca, tena vuttaṃ “satthusampattipakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacana”nti.
analyzed: bhagavato catu vesārajja samannāgamaḥ atta hita para hita paṭipatti ca nidāna vacanena pakāsitā  hoti sampatta parisāya ajjhāsayā anurūpam ṭhāna uppattika paṭibhānena dhamma desanā dīpanato  jānatā passatā iti ādi vacanato ca tena vuttam satthu sampatti pakāsana ttham nidāna vacanan ti
translated: So the Blessed One’s possession of the four kinds of confidence and his practice of what is beneficial to himself and others are revealed by the words “Thus have I heard.”🔽And the teaching of the Dhamma by the Blessed One with his own incomparable voice, beginning with the words “Bhikkhus, those bhikkhus alone are deserving of gifts, …” is revealed by the words “Thus have I heard.”🔽And the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma with his own incomparable voice is revealed by the words “Thus have I heard” because it is revealed by the words “Bhikkhus, those bhikkhus alone are deserving of gifts, …” which are uttered by the Blessed One with his own incomparable voice in conformity with the dispositions of the audience present.

original: Apica sāsanasampattipakāsanatthaṃ nidānavacanaṃ. Ñāṇakaruṇāpariggahitasabbakiriyassa
