analyzed: bodhisattā macchere dosa dassāvinaḥ sīla pe asaṃvarepe nekkhamma pe kāmesupe
translated: in negligence… renunciation… in sensual pleasures…

original: yathābhūtañāṇa…pe… vicikicchāya.…Pe… vīriya …pe… kosajje…pe… khanti…pe… akkhantiyaṃ…pe…
analyzed: vicikicchāyape vīriya pe kosajjepe khanti pe akkhantiyaṃpe
translated: and the knowledge of things as they are, … and doubt, … and energy, … and idleness, … and patience, … and impatience, …

original: sacca…pe… visaṃvādane…pe… adhiṭṭhāna…pe… anadhiṭṭhāne…pe… mettā…pe… byāpāde…pe… upekkhā…pe…
analyzed: sacca pe visaṃvāda nepe adhiṭṭhāna pe anadhiṭṭhāna pe mettā pe byāpāda pe upekkhā pe
translated: and truth, … and deception, … and resolution, … and lack of resolution, … and loving kindness, … and ill will, … and equanimity, …

original: sukhadukkhesu ādīnavadassāvino”ti.🔽Etesu hi maccheraasaṃvarakāmavicikicchākosajjaakkhantivisaṃvādanaanadhiṭṭhāna- byāpādasukhadukkhasaṅkhātesu🔽ādīnavadassanapubbaṅgamā dānādininnacittatāsaṅkhātā dānajjhāsayatādayo dānādipāramīnaṃ
analyzed: sukha dukkhesu ādīnava dassāvino ti  etesu hi macchera asaṃvara kāma vicikicchā kosajja akkhanti visaṃvādana anadhiṭṭhāna byāpāda sukha dukkha saṅkhātesu  ādīnava dassana pubbaṅgamāḥ dāna ādi ninna citta tā saṅkhātāḥ dāna ajjhāsaya tā ādayaḥ dāna ādi pāramīnam
translated: and the seeing of danger in the slightest fault.”🔽For the giving of gifts, etc., has as its condition the state of mind bent on giving, etc., which is preceded by the seeing of danger in the respective faults, namely,🔽stinginess, failure to control the sense faculties, acquisitiveness, uncertainty, laziness, impatience, deception, lack of resolution, ill will, and delight in pleasure and pain.

original: nibbattiyā paccayo. Tathā apariccāgapariccāgādīsu yathākkamaṃ ādīnavānisaṃsapaccavekkhaṇampi
analyzed: nibbattiyā paccayaḥ tathā apariccāga pariccāga ādīsu yathākkamam ādīnava anisaṃsa paccavekkhaṇam pi
translated: And the reviewing of danger in the respective faults and the reviewing of the benefits of the opposite qualities

original: dānādipāramīnaṃ paccayo hoti.
analyzed: dāna ādi pāramīnam paccayaḥ hoti
translated: are also conditions for the pāramīs.🔽Here is the method of reviewing:

original: Tatrāyaṃ paccavekkhaṇāvidhi – khettavatthuhiraññasuvaṇṇagomahiṃ sadāsīdāsaputtadārādipariggahabyāsattacittānaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam paccavekkhaṇā vidhi khetta vatthu hirañña suvaṇṇa go mahim sa dāsī dāsa putta dāra ādi pariggaha byāsatta cittānam
translated: Those whose minds are attached to the ownership of fields, land, gold, silver, cattle, sheep, slaves, men and women servants, sons, daughters, wives, and so on, and who are not free from desire for them,

original: sattānaṃ khettādīnaṃ vatthukāmabhāvena bahupatthanīyabhāvato, rājacorādisādhāraṇabhāvato,
analyzed: sattānam khetta ādīnam vatthu kāma bhāvena bahu patthanīya bhāvataḥ rāja cora ādi sādhāraṇa bhāvataḥ
translated: because they are much sought after by beings as objects of sensual pleasure, because they are shared with kings, thieves, etc.,

original: vivādādhiṭṭhānato, sapattakaraṇato, nissārato, paṭilābhaparipālanesu paraviheṭhanahetubhāvato,🔽vināsanimittañcasokādianekavihitabyasanāvahato tadāsattinidānañca maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitacittānaṃ
analyzed: vivāda adhiṭṭhānataḥ sa patta karaṇataḥ nissārataḥ paṭilābha paripālanesu para viheṭhana hetu bhāvataḥ  vināsa nimittam ca soka ādi aneka vihita byasana avahato tad āsatti nidānam ca
translated: because they are the basis for disputes, because they cause enmity, because they are perishable, because they are the cause for others’ violence in the search for and guarding of acquisitions,🔽and because they are the cause for the many kinds of misfortune beginning with sorrow that arise when they are lost, and because they are the cause for rebirth in states of woe for those whose minds are obsessed by the stain of miserliness.

original: apāyūpapattihetubhāvatoti evaṃ vividhavipulānatthāvahāni pariggahitavatthūni nāma,
analyzed: apāyu upapatti hetu bhāvataḥ ti evam vividha vipula anattha āvahāni pariggahita vatthūni nāma
translated: Thus they are the source of manifold and extensive misfortune. The things to be given up are the objects to be relinquished.

original: tesaṃ pariccāgoyeveko sotthibhāvoti pariccāge appamādo karaṇīyo.🔽Apica “yācako yācamāno attano guyhassa ācikkhanato mayhaṃ vissāsiko”ti ca “pahāya
analyzed: tesam sotthi bhāvo ti pariccāge appamādaḥ karaṇīyo  apica yācakaḥ yācamānaḥ attanaḥ guyhassa ācikkhanataḥ mayham vissāsikā uti ca pahāya
translated: The relinquishing of them is the only way to safety. Therefore one should be diligent in relinquishing.🔽Moreover, the giver is a confessor in that, by asking for something, the beggar reveals his own secret.

original: gamanīyaṃ attano santakaṃ gahetvā paralokaṃ yāhītiupadisanato mayhaṃ upadesako”ti
analyzed: gamanīyam santakam gahetvā para lokam yāhi iti upadisanataḥ mayham upadesakaḥ ti
translated: He is an adviser in that, by telling him “Go and take what is yours and go to the other world,” he advises the giver.

original: ca “āditte viya agāre maraṇagginā āditte loke tato mayhaṃ santakassa apaharaṇato
analyzed: ca āditte viya agāre maraṇagginā āditte loke tatas mayham santakassa apaharaṇato
translated: He is a remover of the burden in that, when the world is burning with the fire of death, he removes the burden belonging to the giver.

original: apavāhakasahāyo”ti ca “apavāhitassa cassa ajjhāpananikkhepaṭṭhānabhūto”ti ca “dānasaṅkhāte🔽kalyāṇakammasmiṃ sahāyabhāvato, sabbasampattīnaṃ aggabhūtāya paramadullabhāya buddhabhūmiyā
analyzed: apavāhaka sahāyaḥ ti ca apavāhitassa ca ssa ajjhāpana nikkhepa ṭṭhāna bhūto ti ca dāna saṅkhāte  kalyāṇa kammasmim sahāya bhāvato sabba sampattīnam agga bhūtāya parama dullabhāya buddha bhūmiyā
translated: and “a companion in the removal of the defilements” and “the basis for the laying hold of and the casting out of the defilements” and “a companion in the good deed called giving”🔽and “a companion in the attainment of the supreme and most difficult to attain state of Buddhahood, which is the highest of all attainments,”

original: sampattihetubhāvato ca paramo kalyāṇamitto”ti ca paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: sampatti hetu bhāvataḥ ca paramaḥ kalyāṇa mitto ti ca paccavekkhitabbam
translated: and “a companion in the removal of the defilements” and “a basis for the laying hold of and the casting out of the defilements” and “a companion in the good deed called giving” and “a supreme good friend in the obtaining of all kinds of excellence and in the cause of the excellence of the supreme state of Buddhahood, which is extremely hard to find” .

original: Tathā “uḷāre kammani anenāhaṃ sambhāvito, tasmā sā sambhāvanā avitathā kātabbā”ti🔽ca “ekantabheditāya jīvitassa āyācitenāpi mayā dātabbaṃ, pageva yācitenā”ti ca “uḷārajjhāsayehi
analyzed: tathā uḷāre kammani anena aham sambhāvito tasmā sā sambhāvanā a vitathā kātabbā ati  ca ekanta bheditāya jīvitassa āyācitena api mayā dātabbam pagā iva yācitena ati ca
translated: He should review the beggar thus: “I have been honoured by him with this great deed. I must not disappoint his expectations.”🔽“Even if he does not ask, I must give, because of the rarity of the opportunity afforded by the appearance of a beggar.”🔽“Even if I have to search for him, I must give, because he has come to me by the power of my own merit.”

original: gavesitvāpi dātabbo, [dātabbato ] sayamevāgato mama puññenā”ti ca “yācakassa dānāpadesena
analyzed: gavesitvā api dātabbaḥ dātabbataḥ sayam eva āgataḥ mama puññena ati ca yācakassa dāna apadesena
translated: “It is a favour to me that he asks me for a gift.”

original: mayhamevāyamanuggaho”ti ca “ahaṃ viya ayaṃ sabbopi loko mayā anuggahetabbo”ti ca
analyzed: mayham eva ayam anuggahaḥ iti ca aham viya ayam sabbaḥ api lokaḥ mayā anuggahetabbaḥ iti ca
translated: “Just as I should be helped, so should all the world be helped by me.”

original: “asati yācake kathaṃ mayhaṃ dānapāramī pūreyyā”ti ca “yācakānamevatthāya mayā sabbopi
analyzed: asati yācake katham mayham dāna pāramī pūreyya ati ca yācakānam eva atthāya mayā
translated: “If there were no beggars, how could I fulfil the perfection of giving?” “It is for the sake of beggars that I have taken on myself the burden of maintaining all the world.

original: pariggahetabbo”ti ca “ayācitvāpi maṃ mama santakaṃ yācakā kadā sayameva gaṇheyyu”nti
analyzed: pariggahetabbaḥ uti ca a yācitvā api mam mama santakam yācakā kadā sayam eva gaṇheyyunti
translated: and “When will they take it themselves without my having to give it?”🔽and “How can I be dear and agreeable to those who ask?”

original: ca “kathamahaṃ yācakānaṃ piyo cassaṃ manāpo”ti ca “kathaṃ vā te mayhaṃ piyā cassu🔽manāpā”ti ca “kathaṃ vāhaṃ dadamāno datvāpi ca attamano assaṃ pamudito pītisomanassajāto”ti
analyzed: ca katham aham yācakānam piyaḥ cassam manāpaḥ iti ca katham vā te mayham piyā cassu  manāpā ati ca katham vā aham dadamānaḥ da tvā api ca atta manaḥ assam pamuditaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ ti
translated: and “How can they be dear and agreeable to me?”🔽and “How can I be glad and elated and full of rapture and joy when I am giving a gift?”🔽and “How can I be a giver and have a reputation for giving?”

original: ca “kathaṃ vā me yācakā bhaveyyuṃ, uḷāro ca dānajjhāsayo”ti ca “kathaṃ vāhamayācito
analyzed: ca katham vā me yācakāḥ bhaveyyuṃ uḷāraḥ ca ca katham vā aham a yācitaḥ
translated: and “How can I give to those who ask, discerning the proper time for giving?”

original: eva yācakānaṃ hadayamaññāya dadeyya”nti “sati dhane, yācake ca apariccāgo mahatī
analyzed: eva yācakānam hadayam aññāya dadeyyanti sati dhane yācake ca a pariccāgaḥ mahatī
translated: and “If I have wealth and those who ask are present, it is a great loss to me if I do not give,”

original: mayhaṃ vañcanā”ti ca “kathamahaṃ attano aṅgāni, jīvitañcāpi pariccajeyya”nti ca cāganinnatā upaṭṭhapetabbā.🔽Apica “attho nāmāyaṃ nirapekkhaṃ dāyakamanugacchati yathā taṃ nirapekkhaṃ khepakaṃ
analyzed: mayham vañcanā ati ca katham aham attanaḥ aṅgāni jīvitam ca api pariccajeyyan ti ca cāga ninna tā upaṭṭhapetabbā  apica atthaḥ nāma ayam nirapekkham dāyakam anugacchati yathā tam nirapekkham khepakam
translated: and “How can I give even my own limbs and my life?”🔽Moreover, he should arouse his mind thus: “Wealth goes to the man who has no concern for it, as a stray ox goes to the man whose ox is lost” .

original: kiṭako”ti atthe nirapekkhatāya cittaṃ uppādetabbaṃ. Yācamāno pana yadi piyapuggalo
analyzed: kiṭakā uti atthe nirapekkha tāya cittam uppādetabbam yācamānaḥ pana yadi piya puggalo
translated: He should arouse his mind thus: “Wealth goes to the man who has no concern for it, as a stray ox goes to the man whose ox is lost” .🔽If the person who asks is a dear person,

original: hoti “piyo maṃ yācatī”ti somanassaṃ uppādetabbaṃ. Atha udāsīnapuggalo hoti “ayaṃ
analyzed: hoti piyaḥ mama yācati iti somanassam uppādetabbam atha udāsīna puggalaḥ hoti ayam
translated: “He is dear to me and asks me,” he should arouse gladness. If the person is neutral,

original: maṃ yācamāno addhā iminā pariccāgena mitto hotī”ti somanassaṃ uppādetabbaṃ. Dadanto
analyzed: mam yācamānaḥ addhā iminā pariccāgena mittaḥ hoti iti somanassam uppādetabbam dadantaḥ
translated: “This person who asks me will certainly become a friend through this giving,” he should arouse gladness.

original: hi yācakānaṃ piyo hotīti. Atha pana verīpuggalo yācati, “paccatthiko maṃ yācati,
analyzed: hi yācakānam piyaḥ hoti iti atha pana verī puggalaḥ yācati paccatthikaḥ mam yācati
translated: For the giver is dear to those who ask. But if the enemy asks, “An enemy asks me,”

original: ayaṃ maṃ yācamāno addhā iminā pariccāgena verīpi piyo mitto hotī”ti visesato somanassaṃ🔽uppādetabbaṃ. Evaṃ piyapuggale viya majjhattaverīpuggalesupi mettāpubbaṅgamaṃ karuṇaṃ
analyzed: ayam mama yācamānaḥ addhā iminā pariccāgena piyaḥ mittaḥ hoti iti visesato somanassam  uppādetabbam evam piya puggale viya majjhatta verī puggalesu pi mettā pubbaṅgamam karuṇam
translated: “This person who asks me will certainly become a dear friend through this giving even though he is an enemy,” he should arouse gladness especially.

original: upaṭṭhapetvāva dātabbaṃ.
analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā ava dātabbam
translated: So he should give, arousing compassion headed by loving-kindness, as if towards a dear person, towards a neutral person and towards an enemy.

original: Sace panassa cirakālaṃ paribhāvitattā lobhassa deyyadhammavisayā lobhadhammā uppajjeyyuṃ,
analyzed: sace pana assa cira kālam paribhāvita ttā lobhassa deyya dhamma visayāḥ lobha dhammāḥ uppajjeyyuṃ
translated: But if greed-to-give-up-after-rousing-pity-headed-by-loving-kindness-towards-all-breathing-things-as-if-towards-an-only-child-

original: tena bodhisattapaṭiññena iti paṭisañcikkhitabbaṃ “nanu tayā sappurisa sambodhāya
analyzed: tena bodhisatta paṭiññena iti paṭisañcikkhitabbam nanu tayā sappurisa sambodhāya
translated: should arise in him, then that one who has acknowledged himself to be a Bodhisatta should reflect thus: “Have you not acknowledged yourself to be a Bodhisatta,

original: abhinīhāraṃ karontena sabbasattānamupakārāya ayaṃ kāyo nissaṭṭho, tappariccāgamayañca
analyzed: abhinīhāram karontena sabba sattānam upakārāya ayam kāyaḥ nissaṭṭhaḥ tad pariccāga mayaṃ ca
translated: The merit from that relinquishment,

original: puññaṃ, tattha nāma te bāhirepi vatthusmiṃ abhisaṅgappavatti hatthisinānasadisī hoti,
analyzed: puññam tattha nāma te bāhire pi vatthusmiṃ abhisaṅga ppavatti hatthi sināna sadisī hoti
translated: even in regard to external things, the occurrence of attachment is like the bathing of an elephant.🔽Therefore, you should not arouse attachment anywhere.

original: tasmā tayā na katthaci abhisaṅgo uppādetabbo. Seyyathāpi nāma mahato bhesajjarukkhassa🔽tiṭṭhato mūlaṃ mūlatthikā haranti, papaṭikaṃ, tacaṃ, khandhaṃ, viṭapaṃ, sākhaṃ, palāsaṃ,
analyzed: tasmā tayā na katthaci abhisaṅgaḥ uppādetabbaḥ seyyathā api nāma mahataḥ bhesajja rukkhassa  tiṭṭhataḥ mūlam mūlatthikāḥ haranti papaṭikam tacam khandham viṭapam sākham palāsam
translated: Suppose there is a great medicinal tree🔽standing, and those who need roots take the roots, those who need bark take the bark, those who need trunk take the trunk, those who need branches take the branches, those who need foliage take the foliage, those who need flowers take the flowers, those who need fruit take the fruit,

original: pupphaṃ, phalaṃ phalatthikā haranti, na tassa rukkhassa ‘mayhaṃ santakaṃ ete harantī’ti
analyzed: puppham phalam phalatthikāḥ haranti na tassa rukkhassa mayham santakam ete haranti iti
translated: it does not occur to that tree ‘They are taking my belongings’

original: vitakkasamudācāro hoti, evameva sabbalokahitāya ussukkamāpajjantena mayā mahādukkhe
analyzed: vitakka samudācāraḥ hoti evam eva sabbaloka hitāya ussukkam āpajjantena mayā mahā dukkhe
translated: or ‘They are not taking my belongings’, in the same way, by me who has undertaken to strive for the welfare of the whole world, in great suffering,

original: akataññuke niccāsucimhi kāye paresaṃ upakārāya viniyujjamāne aṇumattopi micchāvitakko
analyzed: akataññuke nicca asucimhi kāye paresam upakārāya viniyujjamāne aṇumattaḥ api micchāvitakko
translated: in a body that is ungrateful, always impure, when being applied for the benefit of others, even the slightest wrong thought

original: na uppādetabbo. Ko vā ettha viseso ajjhattikabāhiresu mahābhūtesu ekantabhedanavikiraṇaviddhaṃsanadhammesu.
analyzed: na uppādetabbaḥ kaḥ vā ettha visesaḥ ajjhattika bāhiresu mahābhūtesu ekanta bhedana vikiraṇa viddhaṃsana dhammesu
translated: What difference is there between the internal and external great primaries, which are all of the nature of destruction, dissolution, and disintegration?

original: Kevalaṃ pana sammohavijambhitametaṃ, yadidaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti
analyzed: kevalam pana sammoha vijambhitam etam yat idam etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati
translated: It is only a delusion and a joke to insist: ‘This is mine, this am I, this is my self.’

original: abhiniveso, tasmā bāhiresu mahābhūtesu viya ajjhattikesupi karacaraṇanayanādīsu,
analyzed: abhinivesaḥ tasmā bāhiresu mahābhūtesu ajjhattikesu pi kara caraṇa nayana ādīsu
translated: Therefore, like the external great primaries, one should be indifferent to the internal eye, ear, nose, etc.,

original: maṃsādīsu ca anapekkhena hutvā ‘taṃ tadatthikā harantū’ti nissaṭṭhacittena bhavitabba”nti.
analyzed: maṃsa ādīsu ca anapekkhena hutvā tam tad atthikāḥ harantu uti nissaṭṭha cittena bhavitabbanti
translated: and to the flesh, etc., and should give them away, thinking: ‘Whoever needs them, let them take them.’

original: Evaṃ paṭisañcikkhato cassa sambodhāya pahitattassa kāyajīvitesu nirapekkhassa appakasireneva
analyzed: evam paṭisañcikkhataḥ cassa sambodhāya pahita ttassa kāya jīvitesu nirapekkhassa appa kasirena iva
translated: As he reflects thus, his mind is bent on enlightenment, he is indifferent to his body and life, and🔽his bodily, verbal, and mental actions become very pure with little difficulty.

original: kāyavacīmanokammāni suvisuddhāni honti, so visuddhakāyavacīmanokammanto visuddhājīvo🔽ñāyapaṭipattiyaṃ ṭhito āyāpāyupāyakosallasamannāgamena bhiyyoso mattāya deyyadhammapariccāgena,
analyzed: kāya vacī manaḥ kammāni su visuddhāni honti saḥ visuddha kāya vacī manaḥ kammantaḥ visuddha ājīvaḥ 🔽ñāya paṭipattiyam ṭhitaḥ āya apāyu pāya kosalla samannāgamena bhiyyosaḥ mattāya deyya dhamma pariccāgena
translated: With his bodily, verbal, and mental actions thus purified,🔽he is of pure livelihood.

original: abhayadānasaddhammadānehi ca sabbasatte anuggaṇhituṃ samattho hoti, ayaṃ tāva dānapāramiyaṃ paccavekkhaṇānayo.
analyzed: abhaya dāna saddhamma dānehi ca sabba satte anuggaṇhitum samatthaḥ hoti ayam tāva dāna pāramiyam paccavekkhaṇa anayaḥ
translated: and by the gift of fearlessness and the gift of the Dhamma he is able to help all beings. This is the method of reviewing the perfection of giving.

original: Sīlapāramiyaṃ pana evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ – “idañhi sīlaṃ nāma gaṅgodakādīhi visodhetuṃ
analyzed: sīla pāramiyam pana evam paccavekkhitabbam idam hi sīlam nāma gaṅgā udaka ādīhi visodhetum
translated: The perfection of virtue should be reviewed as follows: “This virtue is the water for washing off the stains of defilements that cannot be washed off with the water of the Ganges, etc.;

original: asakkuṇeyyassa dosamalassa vikkhālanajalaṃ, haricandanādīhi vinetuṃ asakkuṇeyyassa
analyzed: asakkuṇeyyassa dosa malassa vikkhālana jalam haricandana ādīhi vinetum asakkuṇeyyassa
translated: it is the training in the taming of the lust, etc., that cannot be tamed by the use of yellow sandalwood, etc.;

original: rāgādipariḷāhassa vinayanaṃ, muttāhāramakuṭakuṇḍalādīhi pacurajanālaṅkārehi asādhāraṇo
analyzed: rāga ādi pariḷāhassa vinayanam mutta āhāra makuṭa kuṇḍala ādīhi pacura jana alaṅkārehi asādhāraṇaḥ
translated: it is the special ornament of the good that is not shared by ordinary people, such as strings of pearls, tiaras, and earrings;

original: sādhūnamalaṅkāraviseso, sabbadisāvāyanako atikittimo [sabbadisāvāyanato akittimo
analyzed: sādhūnam alaṅkāra visesaḥ sabba disāvāyanakaḥ atikittimaḥ sabba disāvāyanataḥ akittimaḥ
translated: it is the fragrance that is suitable for all times and all places, the fame that spreads in all directions;

original: ] sabbakālānurūpo ca surabhigandho, khattiyamahāsālādīhi, devatāhi ca vandanīyādibhāvāvahanato
analyzed: sabba kāla anurūpo ca surabhi gandho khattiya mahā sāla ādīhi devatāhi ca vandanīya ādi bhāva āvahanato
translated: it is the supreme spell for enthralling others, the stairway for ascending to the heavenly worlds of the gods of the four divine kings, etc.;

original: paramo vasīkaraṇamanto, cātumahārājikādidevalokārohaṇasopānapanti, jhānābhiññānaṃ
analyzed: paramaḥ jhāna abhiññānam
translated: it is the foundation for the jhānas and the direct knowledges,

original: adhigamūpāyo, nibbānamahānagarassa sampāpakamaggo, sāvakabodhipaccekabodhisammāsambodhīnaṃ
analyzed: adhigama upāyaḥ nibbāna mahā nagarassa sampāpaka maggaḥ sāvaka bodhi pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhīnam
translated: It is the means to the attainment of the goal, the path that leads to the city of Nibbāna, the foundation for the enlightenment of disciples, the enlightenment of paccekabuddhas, and the supreme enlightenment.

original: patiṭṭhānabhūmi, yaṃ yaṃ vā panicchitaṃ patthitaṃ, tassa tassa samijjhanūpāyabhāvato🔽cintāmaṇikapparukkhādike ca atiseti. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā “ijjhati bhikkhave, sīlavato🔽cetopaṇidhi visuddhattā”ti. Aparampi vuttaṃ “ākaṅkheyya ce bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna bhūmi yam yam vā panicchitam patthitam tassa tassa samijjhana upāya bhāvato  cintāmaṇi kappa rukkha ādike ca vuttam ha etam bhagavatā ijjhati bhikkhave sīlavataḥ  cetaḥ upaṇidhi visuddha ttā ti aparam pi vuttam ākaṅkheyya ce bhikkhave bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnam
translated: It is the means to the fulfilment of whatever is wished for and desired.

original: piyo ca assaṃ manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cāti, sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī”tiādi.
analyzed: piyaḥ ca manāpaḥ ca garu ca bhāvanīyaḥ ca ati sīlesu evassa paripūra kārī itiādi
translated: It surpasses the wish-fulfilling gem, the heavenly wish-granting tree, etc. For the Exalted One has said: “Bhikkhus, the heart’s wish of one who is virtuous succeeds, because of his purity” . And again: “Bhikkhus, if a bhikkhu should wish: ‘May I be dear and agreeable to my companions in the holy life, respected and esteemed by them,’ let him perfect the virtues” .

original: Tathā “avippaṭisāratthāni kho ānanda kusalāni sīlānī”ti, “pañcime gahapatayo, ānisaṃsā🔽sīlavato sīlasampadāyā”tiādisuttānañca vasena sīlaguṇā paccavekkhitabbā. Tathā aggikkhandhopamasuttādīnaṃ
analyzed: tathā a vippaṭisāra atthāni kho ānanda kusalāni sīlāni iti pañcime gahapatayaḥ ānisaṃsā  sīlavataḥ sīla sampadāya ati ādi suttānam ca vasena sīla guṇā paccavekkhitabbā tathā aggi kkhandha upama sutta ādīnam
translated: And again: “Ānanda, wholesome virtues are for the sake of non-remorse” . And again: “Householders, there are these five advantages for the virtuous in perfecting the virtues” .

original: vasena sīlavirahe ādīnavā.
analyzed: vasena sīla virahe ādīnavā
translated: In this way the qualities of virtue should be reviewed according to the suttas. And the dangers in the absence of virtue should be reviewed according to the suttas such as the “Simile of the Heartwood” .

original: Apica pītisomanassanimittato, attānuvādaparānuvādadaṇḍaduggatibhayābhāvato, viññūhi
analyzed: apica pīti somanassa nimittataḥ atta anuvāda para anuvāda daṇḍa duggati bhaya abhāvataḥ viññūhi
translated: Furthermore, it is the sign of rapture and joy, and it is the absence of self-reproach, of the reproach of others, of punishment, and of the fear of unhappy states of becoming.

original: pāsaṃsabhāvato, avippaṭisārahetuto, paramasotthiṭṭhānato, kulasāpateyyādhipateyyajīvitarūpaṭṭhānabandhumittasampattīnaṃ🔽atisayanato ca sīlaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ. Sīlavato hi attano sīlasampadāhetu mahantaṃ
analyzed: pāsaṃsa bhāvataḥ a vippaṭisāra hetutaḥ parama sotthi ṭhānataḥ kula sāpateyya ādhipateyya jīvita rūpa ṭṭhāna bandhu mitta sampattīnam  ati sayanataḥ ca sīlam paccavekkhitabbam sīlavataḥ hi attanaḥ sīla sampadā hetu mahantam
translated: Furthermore, virtue should be reviewed as the source of happiness and joy, as the absence of self-reproach and fear of others, as the praise of the wise, as the cause of non-remorse, as the supreme security, and as the basis for the attainment of the most excellent states of the future life.

original: pītisomanassaṃ uppajjati “kataṃ vata mayā kusalaṃ, kataṃ kalyāṇaṃ, kataṃ bhīruttāṇa”nti.🔽Tathā sīlavato attā na upavadati, na ca pare viññū, daṇḍaduggatibhayānañca sambhavoyeva
analyzed: pīti somanassam uppajjati katam vata mayā kusalam katam kalyāṇam katam bhīruttāṇanti  tathā sīlavataḥ attā na upavadati na ca pare viññū daṇḍa duggati bhayānam ca
translated: For when a man possesses virtue, he experiences a great happiness and joy on account of his virtuousness. He thinks: “I have done what is wholesome, I have done what is good, I have done what is skillful.”

original: natthi, “sīlavā purisapuggalo kalyāṇadhammo”ti viññūnaṃ pāsaṃso ca hoti. Tathā sīlavato
analyzed: natthi sīlavā purisa puggalo kalyāṇa dhammo ti viññūnam pāsaṃsaḥ ca hoti tathā sīlavataḥ
translated: Thus he does not reproach himself, nor are others, who are discerning, likely to reproach him. He has no fear of self or others, of punishment or of the nether worlds. He is praised by the wise as a virtuous person of good character.

original: yvāyaṃ “kataṃ vata mayā pāpaṃ, kataṃ luddaṃ, kataṃ kibbisa”nti dussīlassa vippaṭisāro
analyzed: yvā ayam katam vata mayā pāpam katam luddam katam kibbisanti dussīlassa vippaṭisāraḥ
translated: And he has no remorse, as does the unvirtuous person who thinks: “I have done evil, I have done what is vile, I have done what is wrong.”

original: uppajjati, so na hoti. Sīlañca nāmetaṃ appamādādhiṭṭhānato, bhogabyasanādiparihāramukhena🔽mahato atthassa sādhanato, maṅgalabhāvato, paramaṃ sotthiṭṭhānaṃ. Nihīnajaccopi sīlavā
analyzed: uppajjati so na hoti sīlam ca nāma etam appamāda adhiṭṭhānataḥ bhoga byasana ādi parihāra mukhena  mahataḥ atthassa sādhanataḥ maṅgala bhāvataḥ paramam sotthi ṭṭhānam sīlavā
translated: and it does not arise when it should. And this virtue is the supreme resort for safety because it accomplishes great benefits by way of avoiding loss of wealth, etc., and because it is a good omen.

original: khattiyamahāsālādīnaṃ pūjanīyo hotīti kulasampattiṃ atiseti sīlasampadā, “taṃ kiṃ
analyzed: khattiya mahāsāla ādīnam pūjanīyaḥ hoti iti kula sampattim atiseti sīla sampadā tam kim
translated: Even a man of low birth who is virtuous is worthy of honor from great wealthy khattiyas, etc., so the excellence of virtue surpasses the excellence of birth.

original: maññasi mahārāja, idha te assa dāso kammakaro”tiādi vakkhamānasāmaññasuttavacanañcettha🔽sādhakaṃ, corādīhi asādhāraṇato, paralokānugamanato, mahapphalabhāvato, samathādiguṇādhiṭṭhānato🔽ca bāhiradhanaṃ sāpateyyaṃ atiseti sīlaṃ. Paramassa cittissariyassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato
analyzed: maññasi mahā rāja idha te assa dāso kamma karoti ādi vakkhamāna sāmañña sutta vacanam ca ittha  sādhakam cora ādīhi asādhāraṇataḥ para loka anugamanataḥ mahat phala bhāvataḥ samatha ādi guṇa adhiṭṭhānato  ca bāhira dhanam sāpateyyam atiseti sīlam paramassa cittissariyassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato
translated: The Sāmaññaphala Sutta passage beginning, “What do you think, great king? Suppose there were a slave, a bondservant born in the house” ,🔽confirms this. Virtue surpasses external wealth because it is not shared with thieves, etc., because it accompanies one even when one goes to the other world, because it has great fruit, and because it is the basis for the qualities of peace, etc.🔽Virtue surpasses the sovereignty of khattiyas, etc., because it is the basis for the highest human sovereignty.

original: khattiyādīnamissariyaṃ atiseti sīlaṃ. Sīlanimittañhi taṃtaṃsattanikāyesu sattānamissariyaṃ,
analyzed: atiseti sīlam sīla nimittam hi tad tad satta nikāyesu sattānamissariyam
translated: For sovereignty among the various kinds of beings in the various orders of beings is due to virtue.

original: vassasatādidīghappamāṇato ca jīvitato ekāhampi sīlavato jīvitassa visiṭṭhatāvacanato,
analyzed: vassa sata ādi dīgha ppamāṇataḥ ca jīvitataḥ eka aham pi sīlavataḥ jīvitassa visiṭṭha tā vacanato
translated: and in comparison with life, which is measured in years, etc., the life of the virtuous is distinguished by its length, even if it is only a single day.

original: satipi jīvite sikkhānikkhipanassa maraṇatāvacanato ca sīlaṃ jīvitato visiṭṭhataraṃ.
analyzed: sati api jīvite sikkhā nikkhipanassa maraṇa tā vacanato ca sīlam jīvitataḥ visiṭṭhataram
translated: And even though the life of one who has broken the training may be long, it is as if he were dead. So virtue is more distinguished than life.

original: Verīnampi manuññabhāvāvahanato, jarārogavipattīhi anabhibhavanīyato ca rūpasampattiṃ🔽atiseti sīlaṃ. Pāsādahammiyādiṭṭhānappabhede rājayuvarājasenāpatiādiṭhānavisese ca
analyzed: manuñña bhāva āvahanataḥ jarā roga vipattīhi ca rūpa sampattim  atisā iti sīlam pāsāda hammiya ādi ṭhāna ppabhede rāja yuvarāja senāpati ādi ṭhāna visese ca
translated: It surpasses beauty because it causes even enemies to feel affection and because it cannot be destroyed by the misfortunes of ageing and sickness.🔽It surpasses the happiness of sovereignty because it is the basis for the distinction of the happiness of the various kinds of sovereignty, such as that of a world-ruling monarch, etc.,

original: sukhavisesādhiṭṭhānabhāvato atiseti sīlaṃ. Sabhāvasiniddhe santikāvacarepi bandhujane,🔽mittajane ca ekantahitasampādanato, paralokānugamanato ca atiseti sīlaṃ. “Na taṃ
analyzed: sukha visesa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ atiseti sīlam santika avacare pi bandhu jane  mitta jane ca ekanta hita sampādanataḥ para loka anugamanataḥ ca atiseti sīlam na tam
translated: and because it is the basis for the distinction of the happiness of the various kinds of positions of trust, such as that of a king, a prince, a general, etc.🔽It surpasses the happiness of kinsmen because it brings about the highest welfare and because it follows one even into the next world. The words “Neither father nor mother” , etc., are the proof here.

original: mātā pitā kayirā”tiādi vacanañcettha sādhakaṃ. Tathā hatthiassarathapattibalakāyehi,
analyzed: mātā pitā kayi rāti ādi vacanam ca ittha sādhakam tathā hatthi assa ratha patti balakāyehi
translated: And it surpasses the happiness of wealth because it is independent of the protection of armies, etc.,

original: mantāgadasotthānapayogehi ca durārakkhānamanāthānaṃ attādhīnato, anaparādhīnato,
analyzed: ca durārakkhānam anāthānam atta adhīnataḥ anapara adhīnataḥ
translated: and of the efforts of counsel, treasure, and so on, and because it is not dependent on others, being dependent on oneself.

original: mahāvisayato ca ārakkhabhāvena sīlameva visiṭṭhataraṃ. Tenevāha “dhammo have rakkhati🔽dhammacāri”ntiādi. Evamanekaguṇasamannāgataṃ sīlanti paccavekkhantassa aparipuṇṇā
analyzed: mahā visayato ca ārakkha bhāvena sīlam eva visiṭṭhataram tena iva āha dhammaḥ have rakkhati  dhammacārin tiādi evam aneka guṇa samannāgatam sīlanti paccavekkhantassa aparipuṇṇā
translated: And it is more distinguished than the other two because it is the means of guarding the other two. Hence it is said: “Dhamma guards the one who lives by dhamma” .

original: ceva sīlasampadā pāripūriṃ gacchati, aparisuddhā ca pārisuddhiṃ.
analyzed: ca iva sīla sampadā pāripūrim gacchati a parisuddhā ca pārisuddhim
translated: Thus, when a man reflects on virtue as endowed with these many special qualities, his own virtue will be perfected if it is not already so, and if it is already perfected it will become purified.

original: Sace panassa dīgharattaṃ paricayena sīlapaṭipakkhadhammā dosādayo antarantarā uppajjeyyuṃ,
analyzed: sace pana assa dīgharattam paricayena sīla paṭipakkha dhammāḥ dosa ādayo antarantarāḥ uppajjeyyuṃ
translated: But if, because of long habituation, hatred and the other hindrances to virtue arise in him from time to time,

original: tena bodhisattapaṭiññena evaṃ paṭisañcikkhitabbaṃ “nanu tayā bodhāya paṇidhānaṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: tena bodhisatta paṭiññena evam paṭisañcikkhitabbam nanu tayā bodhāya paṇidhānam katam
translated: then he, as one who has taken upon himself the name of a Bodhisatta, should reflect thus: “Have you not made your aspiration for enlightenment?

original: sīlavekallena ca na sakkā na ca sukarā lokiyāpi sampattiyo pāpuṇituṃ, pageva lokuttarā”ti.
analyzed: sīla vekallena ca na sakkāḥ na ca sukarāḥ lokiyāḥ api sampattiyaḥ pāpuṇitum pagā iva lokuttarā ti
translated: And it is not possible to attain even mundane perfections, much less supramundane ones, with virtue impaired.”

original: Sabbasampattīnamaggabhūtāya sammāsambodhiyā adhiṭṭhānabhūtena sīlena paramukkaṃsagatena
analyzed: sabba sampattīnam agga bhūtāya sammāsambodhiyā adhiṭṭhāna bhūtena sīlena param ukkaṃsa gatena
translated: Virtue is the foundation for the right aspiration for the supreme enlightenment, which is the path to all perfections.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, tasmā “kikīva aṇḍa”ntiādinā vuttanayena sammadeva sīlaṃ rakkhantena
analyzed: bhavitabbam tasmā sammad eva sīlam rakkhantena
translated: Therefore, guarding virtue well, as is done by the hen who sits on her eggs,

original: suṭṭhu tayā pesalena bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: suṭṭhu tayā pesalena bhavitabbam
translated: You must be pure in your conduct.

original: Apica tayā dhammadesanāya yānattaye sattānamavatāraṇaparipācanāni kātabbāni, sīlavekallassa
analyzed: apica tayā dhamma desanāya yānattaye sattānam avatāraṇa paripācanāni kātabbāni sīla vekallassa
translated: Moreover, you must be able to lead and develop beings by teaching the Dhamma to them.

original: ca vacanaṃ na paccetabbaṃ hoti, asappāyāhāravicārassa viya vejjassa tikicchanaṃ,🔽tasmā “kathāhaṃ saddheyyo hutvā sattānamavatāraṇaparipācanāni kareyya”nti sabhāvaparisuddhasīlena
analyzed: ca vacanam na paccetabbam hoti asappāya āhāra vicārassa viya vejjassa tikicchanam  tasmai kathā aham saddheyyaḥ hutvā sattānam avatāraṇa paripācanāni kareyyanti sabhāva parisuddha sīlena
translated: But if your virtue is defective, your words will not be accepted, just as a doctor’s treatment is of no avail if he does not follow a proper diet.🔽Therefore you must be pure in virtue, thinking: “How can I be trusted to lead and develop beings?”

original: bhavitabbaṃ. Kiñca jhānādiguṇavisesayogena me sattānamupakārakaraṇasamatthatā, paññāpāramīādiparipūraṇañca🔽jhānādayo guṇā ca sīlapārisuddhiṃ vinā na sambhavantīti sammadeva sīlaṃ sodhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhavitabbam kiñca jhāna ādi guṇa visesa yogena me sattānam upakāra karaṇa samattha tā paññāpāramī ādi paripūraṇañca  jhāna ādayaḥ guṇā ca sīla pārisuddhim vinā na sambhavanti iti sammat eva sīlam sodhetabbam
translated: And you must purify your virtue well, thinking: “Only by possessing the special qualities of jhāna, etc., can I be of service to beings and fulfill the perfection of wisdom, etc.🔽But these qualities cannot be achieved without pure virtue.”🔽Similarly, you should purify your virtue well, thinking: “Home life is a state of turmoil, a path to bondage,” etc.,

original: Tathā “sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho”tiādinā gharāvāse, “aṭṭhikaṅkalūpamā kāmā”tiādinā
analyzed: tathā sambādhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ rajas pathā iti ādinā ghara āvāse aṭṭhi kaṅkalūpamā kāmā ati ādinā
translated: “Sensual pleasures are like a skeleton,” etc.,

original: “mātāpi puttena vivadatī”tiādinā ca kāmesu, “seyyathāpi puriso iṇaṃ ādāya kammante
analyzed: mātā api puttena vivadati iti ādinā ca kāmesu sā iyyathā api purisaḥ iṇam ādāya kammante
translated: “Even a mother will argue with her son,” etc., and “Just as a man who has borrowed a lamp

original: payojeyyā”tiādinā kāmacchandādīsu ādīnavadassanapubbaṅgamā, vuttavipariyāyena “abbhokāso🔽pabbajjā”tiādinā pabbajjādīsu ānisaṃsāpaṭisaṅkhāvasena nekkhammapāramiyaṃ paccavekkhaṇā
analyzed: payojeyya iti ādinā kāmacchanda ādīsu ādīnava dassana pubbaṅgamā vutta vipariyāyena abbhokāsaḥ  pabbajja āti ādinā pabbajja ādīsu ānisaṃsā paṭisaṅkhā vasena nekkhamma pāramiyam paccavekkhaṇā
translated: and so on.

original: kātabbā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana dukkhakkhandhaāsivisopamasuttādi vasena veditabbo.🔽Tathā “paññāya vinā dānādayo dhammā na visujjhanti, yathāsakaṃ byāpārasamatthā ca
analyzed: kātabbāḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana dukkhakkhandha āsi visopama sutta ādi vasena veditabbo  tathā paññāya vinā dāna ādayaḥ dhammāḥ na visujjhanti yathāsakam byāpāra samatthā ca
translated: The reflection should be undertaken in this way, by way of the contemplation of the advantages of renunciation, etc., in the opposite sense to the way in which the disadvantages of sensual desire, etc., are stated in the passage beginning: “Sensual pleasures have less and less satisfaction, and the pain increases more and more” , and so on. This is the brief treatment here; the detailed treatment should be understood as it is given in the Discourse on the Mass of Fire .🔽And the special qualities of wisdom should be borne in mind thus: “Without wisdom, the other factors of stream-entry, such as giving, are not purified, and they are not effective in their functions.

original: na hontī”ti paññāya guṇā manasi kātabbā. Yatheva hi jīvitena vinā sarīrayantaṃ na🔽sobhati, na ca attano kiriyāsu paṭipattisamatthaṃ hoti. Yathā ca cakkhādīni indriyāni
analyzed: na honti iti paññāya guṇāḥ manasi kātabbāḥ yathā iva hi jīvitena vinā sarīrayantam na  sobhati na ca attanaḥ kiriyāsu paṭipatti samattham hoti yathā ca cakkha ādīni indriyāni
translated: For just as the body, without life, is unsightly and incapable of action,

original: viññāṇena vinā yathāsakaṃ visayesu kiccaṃ kātuṃ nappahonti, evaṃ saddhādīni indriyāni
analyzed: viññāṇena vinā yathāsakam visayesu kiccam kātum na ppahonti evam saddhā ādīni indriyāni
translated: and just as the sense faculties, without consciousness, are incapable of exercising their respective functions with regard to their objects,🔽so too, without wisdom, the other factors of stream-entry are incapable of exercising their respective functions.”

original: paññāya vinā sakakiccapaṭipattiyamasamatthānīti pariccāgādipaṭipattiyaṃ paññā padhānakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: paññāya vinā saka kicca paṭipattiyam asamatthāni iti pariccāga ādi paṭipattiyam paññā padhāna kāraṇam
translated: and without wisdom they are incapable of undertaking their own duties. So wisdom is the principal cause for the undertaking of the practice of giving and so on.

original: Ummīlitapaññācakkhukā hi mahāsattā bodhisattā attano aṅgapaccaṅgānipi datvā anattukkaṃsakā,
analyzed: ummīlita paññā cakkhukāḥ hi mahāsattāḥ bodhisattāḥ attanaḥ aṅga paccaṅgāni pi da tvā anattukkaṃsakā
translated: For the Great Beings, the Bodhisattvas, who have opened the eye of wisdom, give even their own limbs and organs without boasting and without despising others,

original: aparavambhakā ca honti, bhesajjarukkhā viya vikapparahitā kālattayepi somanassajātā.
analyzed: ca honti bhesajja rukkhāḥ viya vikappa rahitā kāla ttaye pi somanassa jātā
translated: like medicinal herbs, free from discrimination, and they are joyful in the three times.

original: Paññāvasena hi upāyakosallayogato pariccāgo parahitapavattiyā dānapāramibhāvaṃ upeti.
analyzed: paññā vasena hi upāya kosalla yogataḥ pariccāgaḥ para hita pavattiyā dānapārami bhāvam upeti
translated: For it is through wisdom that giving, by being combined with skill in means, attains the state of the perfection of giving, which is the occurrence of benefit for others.

original: Attatthañhi dānaṃ muddhasadisaṃ [vuddhisadisaṃ ] hoti.
analyzed: attattham hi dānam muddha sadisam vuddhi sadisam hoti
translated: For giving is like a fool’s muddi muddi , if it is only for one’s own benefit.

original: Tathā paññāya abhāvena taṇhādisaṃkilesāviyogato sīlassa visuddhiyeva na sambhavati,
analyzed: tathā paññāya abhāvena taṇhā ādi saṃkilesa aviyogato sīlassa visuddhiyā iva na sambhavati
translated: And likewise, without wisdom, the purification of virtue is not possible, since it is not dissociated from defilements such as craving,

original: kuto sabbaññuguṇādhiṭṭhānabhāvo. Paññavā eva ca gharāvāse kāmaguṇesu saṃsāre ca ādīnavaṃ,
analyzed: kutas sabbaññu guṇa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvo paññavā eva ca ghara āvāse kāma guṇesu saṃsāre ca ādīnavam
translated: how much less the state of being the basis for the special qualities of omniscience. And only one who is wise, after properly discerning the danger in the household life and in sense pleasures,

original: pabbajjāya jhānasamāpattiyaṃ nibbāne ca ānisaṃsaṃ suṭṭhu sallakkhento pabbajitvā
analyzed: pabbajjāya jhāna samāpattiyam nibbāne ca ānisaṃsam suṭṭhu sallakkhento pabbajitvā
translated: and the benefit in going forth and in the attainment of jhāna and nibbāna, goes forth from the household life,

original: jhānasamāpattiyo nibbattetvā nibbānaninno, pare ca tattha patiṭṭhapeti.🔽Vīriyañca paññārahitaṃ yathicchitamatthaṃ na sādheti durārambhabhāvato. Anārambhoyeva
analyzed: jhāna samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā nibbāna ninno pare ca tattha patiṭṭhapeti  vīriyam ca paññā rahitam yathā icchitam attham na sādheti durārambha bhāvataḥ
translated: and he himself attains the jhānas and reaches Nibbāna, and he establishes others in them.🔽And energy, when devoid of wisdom, does not accomplish its desired purpose, because it is hard to get started.

original: hi durārambhato seyyo, paññāsahitena pana vīriyena na kiñci duradhigamaṃ upāyapaṭipattito.
analyzed: hi durārambhato seyyo paññā sahitena pana vīriyena na kiñci duradhigamam upāya paṭipattito
translated: For it is better not to start at all than to start something and do it badly. But when energy is endowed with wisdom, there is nothing hard to accomplish, because of the right way of undertaking it.

original: Tathā paññavā eva parāpakārādīnamadhivāsakajātiyo hoti, na duppañño. Paññāvirahitassa
analyzed: tathā paññavā eva para apakāra ādīnam adhivāsaka jātiyaḥ hoti na duppaññaḥ paññā virahitassa
translated: Likewise, only the wise man is able to endure the harm done by others, and so on, because he is not of a quarrelsome nature.

original: ca parehi upanītā apakārā khantiyā paṭipakkhameva anubrūhenti. Paññavato pana te🔽khantisampattiyā anubrūhanavasena assā thirabhāvāya saṃvattanti. Paññavā eva tīṇipi
analyzed: ca parehi upanītāḥ apakārāḥ khantiyā paṭipakkham eva paññavataḥ pana te  khanti sampattiyāḥ anubrūhana vasena assā thira bhāvāya saṃvattanti eva
translated: And when the harm done by others is endured by him, it only increases the perfection of his patience.🔽But for one devoid of wisdom, when he is harmed by others, his patience is not perfected, because it is not developed by the perfection of wisdom.

original: saccāni tesaṃ kāraṇāni paṭipakkhe ca yathābhūtaṃ jānitvā paresaṃ avisaṃvādako hoti.
analyzed: saccāni tesam kāraṇāni paṭipakkhe ca yathābhūtam jānitvā paresam avisaṃvādakaḥ hoti
translated: Only the wise man, knowing as they really are the three truths and their opposites, does not deceive others.

original: Tathā paññābalena attānamupatthambhetvā dhitisampadāya sabbapāramīsu acalasamādānādhiṭṭhāno
analyzed: tathā paññā balena attānam upatthambhetvā dhiti sampadāya sabba pāramīsu acala samādāna adhiṭṭhāno
translated: Likewise, only the wise man, having fortified himself with the strength of wisdom, is unshakably resolute in all the pāramīs through the perfection of resolution.

original: hoti. Paññavā eva ca piyamajjhattaverivibhāgamakatvā sabbattha hitūpasaṃhārakusalo
analyzed: hoti paññavā eva ca piya majjhatta veri vibhāgam a katvā sabbattha hitu upasaṃhāra kusalaḥ
translated: He is wise, and he is impartial, without making distinctions of dearness and hatefulness, and he is skillful in promoting the welfare of all.

original: hoti. Tathā paññāvasena lābhālābhādilokadhammasannipāte nibbikāratāya majjhatto hoti.
analyzed: hoti tathā paññā vasena lābha alābha ādi loka dhamma sannipāte nibbikāra tāya majjhatto hoti
translated: And likewise, through wisdom, he is impartial in the face of the worldly vicissitudes of gain and loss, etc., because he is indifferent to them.

original: Evaṃ sabbāsaṃ pāramīnaṃ paññāva pārisuddhihetūti paññāguṇā paccavekkhitabbā.
analyzed: evam sabbāsam pāramīnam paññā ava pārisuddhi hetū ti paññā guṇā paccavekkhitabbā
translated: Thus the excellence of wisdom should be reviewed as the cause for the purification of all the pāramīs.

original: Apica paññāya vinā na dassanasampatti, antarena ca diṭṭhisampadaṃ na sīlasampadā,
analyzed: apica paññāya vinā na dassana sampatti antarena ca diṭṭhi sampadam na sīla sampadā
translated: Moreover, without wisdom there is no perfection of insight; and without insight there is no perfection of virtue.

original: sīladiṭṭhisampadārahitassa ca na samādhisampadā, asamāhitena ca na sakkā attahitamattampi
analyzed: sīla diṭṭhi sampadā rahitassa ca na samādhi sampadā asamāhitena ca na sakkā atta hitam attampi
translated: And one who lacks the perfection of virtue and insight has no perfection of concentration. And without concentration it is impossible to accomplish even one’s own welfare,

original: sādhetuṃ, pageva ukkaṃsagataṃ parahitanti. “Nanu tayā parahitāya paṭipannena sakkaccaṃ
analyzed: sādhetum pagā iva ukkaṃsa gatam para hitanti nanu tayā para hitāya paṭipannena sakkaccam
translated: let alone the welfare of others. “Have you not set out to work for the welfare of others?

original: paññāpārisuddhiyā āyogo karaṇīyo”ti bodhisattena attā ovaditabbo. Paññānubhāvena
analyzed: paññāpārisuddhiyāḥ āyogo karaṇīyaḥ iti bodhisattena attā ovaditabbo paññā anubhāvena
translated: Then you should strive with all your effort to purify your wisdom.🔽For it is through the power of wisdom that the great being, having established the four kinds of direct knowledge,

original: hi mahāsatto caturadhiṭṭhānādhiṭṭhito catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi lokaṃ anuggaṇhanto satte
analyzed: hi mahāsatto catur adhiṭṭhāna dhiṭṭhito catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi lokam anuggaṇhantaḥ satte
translated: supports the world with the four means of gathering disciples.

original: niyyānamagge avatāreti, indriyāni ca nesaṃ paripāceti. Tathā paññābalena khandhāyatanādīsu
analyzed: niyyāna magge avatāreti indriyāni ca paripāceti tathā paññā balena khandha āyatana ādīsu
translated: Similarly, by means of the strength of wisdom, he penetrates the rise and fall of the aggregates, sense bases, etc.,

original: pavicayabahulo pavattinivattiyo yāthāvato parijānanto dānādayo guṇavisese nibbedhabhāgiyabhāvaṃ🔽nayanto bodhisattasikkhāya paripūrakārī hotīti evamādinā anekākāravokāre paññāguṇe
analyzed: pavatti nivattiyaḥ yāthāvataḥ parijānantaḥ dāna ādayaḥ guṇa visese nibbedha bhāgiya bhāvam  nayantaḥ bodhisatta sikkhāya paripūra kārī hoti iti evamādinā aneka ākāra vokāre paññā guṇe
translated: and by means of the path of seeing he leads them to the special qualities of generosity, etc., which are conducive to penetration.

original: vavatthapetvā paññāpāramī anubrūhetabbā.🔽Tathā dissamānapārānipi lokiyāni kammāni nihīnavīriyena pāpuṇitumasakkuṇeyyāni, agaṇitakhedena
analyzed: vavatthapetvā paññāpāramī anubrūhetabbā  tathā dissamāna pārāni api lokiyāni kammāni nihīna vīriyena pāpuṇitum asakkuṇeyyāni agaṇita khedena
translated: Thus he fulfills the training of a bodhisattva. Having defined the special qualities of wisdom in this and other ways, he should increase the perfection of wisdom.

original: pana āraddhavīriyena duradhigamaṃ nāma natthi. Nihīnavīriyo hi “saṃsāramahoghato
analyzed: pana āraddha vīriyena duradhigamam nāma natthi nihīna vīriyaḥ hi saṃsāra mahoghato
translated: Similarly, worldly actions, even though they are not beyond the range of the weak-willed, are not easily accomplished by them. But for one who has begun with indefatigable energy, there is nothing difficult to attain.

original: sabbasatte santāressāmī”ti ārabhitumeva na sakkuṇoti. Majjhimo pana ārabhitvāna antarāvosānamāpajjati.
analyzed: sabba satte santāressāmi iti ārabhitum eva na sakkuṇoti majjhimaḥ pana ārabhitvāna antara avosānam āpajjati
translated: For one of weak energy is unable even to begin, thinking, “I will rescue all beings from the great flood of saṃsāra.” But one of medium strength, though he begins, gives up halfway.

original: Ukkaṭṭhavīriyo pana attasukhanirapekkho ārabhitvā pāramadhigacchatīti vīriyasampatti paccavekkhitabbā.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha vīriyaḥ pana atta sukha nirapekkhaḥ ārabhitvā pāram adhigacchati iti vīriya sampatti paccavekkhitabbā
translated: But one of superior strength, disregarding his own welfare, begins and reaches the end. Thus he should review the perfection of energy.

original: Apica “yassa attano eva saṃsārapaṅkato samuddharaṇatthamārambho, tassāpi vīriyassa🔽sithilabhāvena manorathānaṃ matthakappatti na sakkā sambhāvetuṃ, pageva sadevakassa
analyzed: apica yassa attanaḥ eva saṃsāra paṅkato samuddharaṇa attham ārambhaḥ tassa api vīriyassa  sithila bhāvena manorathānam matthaka ppatti na sakkā sambhāvetum pagā iva sa devakassa
translated: Moreover, “Even if one were to make an effort to rescue oneself alone from the ocean of saṃsāra,🔽one could not hope to reach the end of one’s wishes if one’s energy were slack. How much less so if one’s aspiration is to rescue the world with its gods?

original: lokassa samuddharaṇatthaṃ katābhinīhārenā”ti ca “rāgādīnaṃ dosagaṇānaṃ mattamahānāgānamiva
analyzed: lokassa samuddharaṇa attham kata abhinīhārena ati ca rāga ādīnam dosa gaṇānam matta mahā nāgānam iva
translated: “Because of the difficulty of restraining the great hosts of defilements such as lust,

original: dunnivāraṇabhāvato, tannidānānañca kammasamādānānaṃ ukkhittāsikavadhakasadisabhāvato,
analyzed: dunnivāraṇa bhāvataḥ tad nidānānam ca kamma samādānānam ukkhitta asika vadhaka sadisa bhāvataḥ
translated: like great elephants, and because of the similarity of the kamma-formations that have them as their source to murderers with uplifted swords,🔽because of the ever-open door to the evil destinations that have them as their cause,

original: tannimittānañca duggatīnaṃ sabbadā vivaṭamukhabhāvato, tattha niyojakānañca pāpamittānaṃ🔽sadā sannihitabhāvato, tadovādakāritāya ca vasalassa puthujjanabhāvassa sati sambhave
analyzed: tad nimittānam ca duggatīnam sabbadā vivaṭa mukha bhāvataḥ tattha niyojakānam ca pāpa mittānam  sadā sannihita bhāvataḥ tadovāda kāritāya ca vasalassa puthujjana bhāvassa sati sambhave
translated: because of the ever-present nature of bad friends who impel one to them,🔽and because of the possibility of the existence of the ignoble ordinary man who acts as their advocate, it is proper to escape by oneself from the suffering of saṃsāra.

original: yuttaṃ sayameva saṃsāradukkhato nissaritu”nti ca “micchāvitakkā vīriyānubhāvena dūrī
analyzed: yuttam sayam eva saṃsāra dukkhataḥ nissaritun ti ca micchā vitakkā vīriya anubhāvena dūrī
translated: “Because of the power of energy, wrong thoughts are kept far away.

original: bhavantī”ti ca “yadi pana sambodhiṃ attādhīnena vīriyena sakkā samadhigantuṃ, kimettha
analyzed: bhavanti iti ca yadi pana sambodhim attā adhīnena vīriyena sakkā samadhigantum kim ettha
translated: “If the attainment of full enlightenment were possible by means of energy dependent on the self, then what would be the use of the other four factors of enlightenment?

original: dukkara”nti ca evamādinā nayena vīriyaguṇā paccavekkhitabbā.
analyzed: ca evamādinā nayena vīriya guṇā paccavekkhitabbā
translated: and so on.

original: Tathā “khanti nāmāyaṃ niravasesaguṇapaṭipakkhassa kodhassa vidhamanato guṇasampādane
analyzed: tathā khanti nāma ayam niravasesa guṇa paṭipakkhassa kodhassa vidhamanataḥ guṇa sampādane
translated: And he should review the special qualities of patience in this way: “Patience is a special quality because it clears away anger, which is the enemy of every kind of good quality.

original: sādhūnaṃ appaṭihatamāyudhaṃ, parābhibhavane samatthānamalaṅkāro, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ🔽balasampadā, kodhaggivinayanā udakadhārā, kalyāṇakittisaddassa sañjātideso, pāpapuggalānaṃ🔽vacīvisavūpasamakaro mantāgado, saṃvare ṭhitānaṃ paramā dhīrapakati, gambhīrāsayatāya
analyzed: sādhūnam appaṭihatam āyudham para abhibhavane samatthānam alaṅkāraḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇānam  bala sampadā kodhaggi vinayanā udaka dhārā kalyāṇa kitti saddassa sañjā atidesaḥ pāpa puggalānaṃ  saṃvare paramā
translated: It is a weapon that never fails for the good. It is an ornament that makes one fit to overcome others. It is a strength of ascetics and brahmins.🔽It is a stream of water for extinguishing the forest fire of anger. It is a place for the growth of the sound of good reports. It is a charm for averting the poison of bad men’s words. It is the ultimate in self-control for those who stand by their promises.

original: sāgaro, dosamahāsāgarassa velā, apāyadvārassa pidhānakavāṭaṃ devabrahmalokānaṃ ārohaṇasopānaṃ,
analyzed: sāgaraḥ dosa mahā sāgarassa velā apāya dvārassa pidhāna kavāṭam deva brahma lokānaṃ ārohaṇa sopānam
translated: It is an ocean because of its unfathomable depth. It is a sea wall for the great ocean of hate. It is a bolt for the door of the states of loss. It is a staircase for ascending to the heavenly and Brahmā worlds.

original: sabbaguṇānamadhivāsabhūmi, uttamā kāyavacīmanovisuddhī”ti manasi kātabbaṃ. Apica
analyzed: sabba guṇānam adhivāsa bhūmi uttamā kāya vacī manaḥ visuddhī iti manasi kātabbam apica
translated: It is a foundation for all good qualities. It is the highest purification of body, speech, and mind.”

original: “ete sattā khantisampattiyā abhāvato idhaloke tapanti, paraloke ca tapanīyadhammānuyogato”ti
analyzed: ete sattā khanti sampattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ idha loke tapanti para loke ca tapanīya dhamma anuyogato ti
translated: And he should also consider the matter in this way: “These beings are heated by the heat of anger, which is the cause of their burning in this world and the next.”

original: ca “yadipi parāpakāranimittaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjati, tassa pana dukkhassa khettabhūto
analyzed: ca yadi api para apakāra nimittam dukkham uppajjati tassa pana dukkhassa khetta bhūtaḥ
translated: “Even though suffering arises with the object of harming another, it is my very self that is the field for that suffering,

original: attabhāvo, bījabhūtañca kammaṃ mayāva abhisaṅkhata”nti ca “tassa ca dukkhassa āṇaṇyakaraṇameta”nti
analyzed: atta bhāvaḥ bīja bhūtam ca kammam ca tassa ca dukkhassa āṇaṇya karaṇam etat ti
translated: and it is my own kamma that is the seed,” “It is I who am responsible for that suffering,”

original: ca “apakārake asati kathaṃ mayhaṃ khantisampadā sambhavatī”ti ca “yadipāyaṃ etarahi
analyzed: ca apakārake asati katham khanti sampadā sambhavati iti ca etarahi
translated: “If there were no one to harm me, how could I achieve perfection in patience?” “If this person is harming me now, he has done me a favor in the past,”

original: apakārako, ayaṃ nāma pubbe anena mayhaṃ upakāro kato”ti ca “apakāro eva vā khantinimittatāya
analyzed: apakārakaḥ ayam nāma pubbe anena mayham upakāro kato ti ca apakāraḥ eva vā khanti nimitta tāya
translated: “Or even if he has not, his very harm is a favor to me, since it is the cause for my patience,”

original: upakāro”ti ca “sabbepime sattā mayhaṃ puttasadisā, puttakatāparādhesu ca ko kujjhissatī”ti🔽ca “yena kodhabhūtāvesena ayaṃ mayhaṃ aparajjhati, svāyaṃ kodhabhūtāveso mayā vinetabbo”ti
analyzed: upakāro ti ca sabbe pi ime sattā mayham putta sadisā putta kata aparādhesu ca kaḥ kujjhissati iti  ca yena kodha bhūta āvesena ayam mayham aparajjhati su ayam kodha bhūta āvesaḥ mayā vinetabbo ti
translated: “All these beings are like my children. Who would be angry at his children for their faults?”🔽“The one who is harming me is possessed by anger. I must tame that anger in him,”

original: ca “yena apakārena idaṃ mayhaṃ dukkhaṃ uppannaṃ, tassa ahampi nimitta”nti ca “yehi
analyzed: ca yena apakārena idam mayham dukkham uppannam tassa aham pi nimittam ti ca yehi
translated: “I am the cause for the suffering that has arisen in me because of his harm,” “I am the cause for his anger,”

original: dhammehi apakāro kato, yattha ca kato, sabbepi te tasmiṃyeva khaṇe niruddhā, kassidāni
analyzed: dhammehi apakāraḥ kataḥ yattha ca kataḥ sabbe pi te tasmiṃ yeva khaṇe niruddhā
translated: and the harm done is by states, and where it is done, all these states cease immediately they arise.

original: kena kopo kātabbo”ti ca “anattatāya sabbadhammānaṃ ko kassa aparajjhatī”ti ca paccavekkhantena
analyzed: kena kopaḥ kātabbo ti ca anatta tāya sabba dhammānam ko kassa aparajjhati iti ca paccavekkhantena
translated: So now by whom is it done and to whom is it done? ” and “Since all things are in the nature of not-self, who is there to offend against whom? ”

original: khantisampadā brūhetabbā.
analyzed: khanti sampadā
translated: and he should increase his perfection of patience.🔽But if anger due to the harm done should persist in his mind because of long acquaintance with it,

original: Yadi panassa dīgharattaṃ paricayena parāpakāranimittako kodho cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya,🔽tena iti paṭisañcikkhitabbaṃ “khanti nāmesā parāpakārassa paṭipakkhapaṭipattīnaṃ
analyzed: yadi pana assa dīgharattam paricayena para apakāra nimittakaḥ kodhaḥ cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya  tena iti paṭisañcikkhitabbam khanti nāma isā para apakārassa paṭipakkha paṭipattīnam
translated: he should review it thus: “Patience is the opposite of anger and the other states of hate.

original: paccupakārakāraṇa”nti ca “apakāro ca mayhaṃ dukkhuppādanena dukkhupanisāya saddhāya,
analyzed: paccupakāra kāraṇanti ca apakāro ca mayham dukkha uppādanena dukkha upanisāya saddhāya
translated: It is the counteragent for the states of hate. ” and “The harm-doer is a condition for my anger only when there is in me a tendency to anger due to lust for sensual desires,

original: sabbaloke anabhiratisaññāya ca paccayo”ti ca “indriyapakatiresā, yadidaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhavisayasamāyogo,🔽tattha aniṭṭhavisayasamāyogo mayhaṃ na siyāti taṃ kutettha labbhā”ti ca “kodhavasiko
analyzed: sabba loke an abhirati saññāya ca paccayaḥ ti ca indriya paka tiresā yat idam iṭṭha aniṭṭha visaya samāyogaḥ 🔽tattha aniṭṭha visaya samāyogaḥ mayham na siyāti tam kuta ittha ca kodha vasiko

translated: The “restraint by virtue” is the restraint of the Patimokkha. The “guarding of the sense doors” is the guarding of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body sense faculties. The “knowing the right amount in eating” is the knowledge of the right amount in eating. The “devotedness to wakefulness” is the devotedness to the first and last watches of the night.

original: saddhammā, cattāri jhānāni ca. Tesu sīlādīnaṃ catunnaṃ terasapi dhutaṅgadhammā, appicchatādayo🔽ca parikkhārā. Saddhammesu saddhāya buddhadhammasaṅghasīlacāgadevatupasamānussati
analyzed: saddhammā cattāri jhānāni ca tesu sīla ādīnam catunnam terasa api  ca parikkhārā saddhammesu saddhāya buddha dhamma saṅgha sīla cāga devatā upasama anussati
translated: The “seven good dhammas” are faith, shame, fear of wrongdoing, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding. The “four jhānas” are the first, second, third, and fourth jhānas. Of these, the thirteen ascetic practices are the requisites of the first four, virtue, etc.,🔽and so are the requisites of fewness of wishes, etc. The requisites of the seven good dhammas are the faith, shame, fear of wrongdoing, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding that are purified by equanimity.

original: lūkhapuggalaparivajjanā, siniddhapuggalasevanā, sampasādanīyadhammapaccavekkhaṇā,
analyzed: lūkha puggala parivajjanā siniddha puggala sevanā sampasādanīya dhamma paccavekkhaṇā
translated: The requisites of the four jhānas are the serenity, purity of mind, and unification of mind that are purified by equanimity. The requisites of the four paths are the faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding that are purified by equanimity.

original: tadadhimuttatā ca parikkhārā. Hirottappānaṃ akusalādīnavapaccavekkhaṇā, apāyādīnavapaccavekkhaṇā,🔽kusaladhammūpatthambhabhāvapaccavekkhaṇā, hirottapparahitapuggalaparivajjanā, hirottappasampannapuggalasevanā,
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ca parikkhārāḥ hirā uttappānam akusala ādīnava paccavekkhaṇā apāya ādīnava paccavekkhaṇā  kusala dhamma upatthambha bhāva paccavekkhaṇā hirottappa rahita puggala parivajjanā hirottappa sampanna puggala sevanā
translated: The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane paths are the same as those of the four fruits.🔽The requisites of the four jhānas are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four paths are the same as those of the four fruits. The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane paths are the same as those of the four fruits.

original: tadadhimuttatā ca. Bāhusaccassa pubbayogo, paripucchakabhāvo, saddhammābhiyogo, anavajjavijjāṭṭhānādiparicayo,
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ca bāhusaccassa pubba yogaḥ paripucchaka bhāvo saddhamma abhiyogaḥ anavajja vijjā ṭṭhāna ādi paricayo
translated: The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane paths are the same as those of the four fruits. The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane paths are the same as those of the four fruits. The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane paths are the same as those of the four fruits. The requisites of the four fruits are the same as those of the four paths. The requisites of the four supramundane

original: paripakkindriyatā, kilesadūrībhāvo, appassutapuggalaparivajjanā bahussutapuggalasevanā,
analyzed: paripakka indriya tā kilesa dūrībhāvaḥ appassuta puggala parivajjanā bahussuta puggala sevanā
translated: the maturity of the faculties, the state of being far from defilements, avoidance of people who are unlearned, cultivation of people who are learned,

original: tadadhimuttatā ca. Vīriyassa apāyabhayapaccavekkhaṇā, gamanavīthipaccavekkhaṇā, dhammamahattapaccavekkhaṇā,
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ca vīriyassa apāya bhaya paccavekkhaṇā gamana vīthi paccavekkhaṇā dhamma mahatta paccavekkhaṇā
translated: and being devoted to them. For energy: reviewing the danger in the states of loss, reviewing the path to be travelled, reviewing the greatness of the Dhamma,

original: thinamiddhavinodanā, kusītapuggalaparivajjanā, āraddhavīriyapuggalasevanā, sammappadhānapaccavekkhaṇā,
analyzed: thinamiddha vinodanā kusīta puggala parivajjanā āraddha vīriya puggala sevanā sammappadhāna paccavekkhaṇā
translated: banishing sloth and torpor, avoidance of people who are lazy, cultivation of people who are energetic, reviewing the right endeavours,

original: tadadhimuttatā ca. Satiyā satisampajaññaṃ, muṭṭhassatipuggalaparivajjanā upaṭṭhitassatipuggalasevanā,
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ca satiyā sati sampajaññam muṭṭhaḥ sati puggala parivajjanā upaṭṭhitaḥ sati puggala sevanā
translated: and being devoted to them. For mindfulness: mindfulness and full awareness, avoidance of people who are unmindful, cultivation of people who are mindful,

original: tadadhimuttatā ca. Paññāya paripucchakabhāvo, vatthuvisadakiriyā, indriyasamattapaṭipādanā,
analyzed: tad adhimutta tā ca paññāya paripucchaka bhāvaḥ vatthu visada kiriyā indriya samatta paṭipādanā
translated: and being devoted to them. For understanding: asking questions, making the basis clear, balancing the faculties,

original: duppaññapuggalaparivajjanā, paññavantapuggalasevanā, gambhīrañāṇacariyasuttantapaccavekkhaṇā,
analyzed: duppañña puggala parivajjanā paññavanta puggala sevanā gambhīra ñāṇa cariya suttanta paccavekkhaṇā
translated: avoidance of people who are unwise, cultivation of people who are wise, reviewing the discourses with profound meaning,

original: dhammamahattapaccavekkhaṇā, tadadhimuttatā ca. Catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ sīlādicatukkaṃ,
analyzed: dhamma mahatta paccavekkhaṇā tad adhimutta tā ca catunnam jhānānam sīla ādi catukkam
translated: reviewing the greatness of the Dhamma, and being devoted to them. For the four jhanas: the four things beginning with virtue,

original: aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu pubbabhāgabhāvanā, āvajjanādivasībhāvakaraṇañca parikkhārā.🔽Tattha sīlādīhi payogasuddhiyā sattānaṃ abhayadāne, āsayasuddhiyā āmisadāne, ubhayasuddhiyā
analyzed: aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu pubbabhāga bhāvanā āvajjana divasībhāva karaṇañca parikkhārā  tattha sīla ādīhi payoga suddhiyā sattānam abhaya dāne āsaya suddhiyā āmisa dāne ubhaya suddhiyā
translated: The meditation in the prior stage on the thirty-eight objects of contemplation and the bringing of the processes of adverting, etc., to the stage of predominance are the requisites of virtue, etc.🔽Herein, one who is capable of giving fearlessness to beings through the purification of his means, which is virtue, etc., and of giving material things through the purification of his end, which is the support, and of giving the True Idea through the purification of both his means and his end is capable of giving the True Object.

original: dhammadāne samatthohotītiādinā caraṇādīnaṃ dānādisambhārapaccayatā yathārahaṃ niddhāretabbā.🔽Ativitthārabhayena pana mayaṃ na vitthārayimha. Tathā sampatticakkādayopi dānādīnaṃ
analyzed: dhamma dāne caraṇa ādīnam dāna ādi sambhāra paccaya tā yathāraham niddhāretabbā  ati vitthāra bhayena pana mayam na vitthārayimha tathā
translated: So the requisites of the requisites of the perfections should be demonstrated in the appropriate places in the way beginning with the words “Through the purification of his means, which is virtue, etc.”🔽But we have not demonstrated them here for fear of over-extending this book.

original: paccayoti veditabbā.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ti veditabbā
translated: So too, the wheel of the aids to enlightenment, etc., should be understood as the requisites of the perfections.

original: Ko saṃkilesoti ettha –
analyzed: kaḥ saṃkilesaḥ ti ettha
translated: What is defilement?🔽The defilement of these is the state

original: Taṇhādīhi parāmaṭṭha-bhāvo tāsaṃ kilissanaṃ;
analyzed: taṇhā ādīhi parāmaṭṭha bhāvaḥ tāsam kilissanam
translated: Of being misapprehended by craving, etc.,🔽And also the misinterpretation

original: Sāmaññato visesena, yathārahaṃ vikappatā.
analyzed: sāmaññataḥ visesena yathāraham vikappatā
translated: Of them in the various ways.🔽For the defilement of the perfections is the state of being misapprehended by craving, conceit and views, etc., in general. But in particular:

original: Avisesena hi taṇhādīhi parāmaṭṭhabhāvo pāramīnaṃ saṃkileso. Visesena pana deyyadhammapaṭiggāhakavikappā
analyzed: avisesena hi taṇhā ādīhi parāmaṭṭha bhāvaḥ pāramīnam saṃkilesaḥ visesena pana deyya dhamma paṭiggāhaka vikappā
translated: The misapprehension of the object to be given and of the recipient🔽Is the defilement of the perfection of giving.🔽The misapprehension of creatures and of time is the defilement of the perfection of virtue.

original: dānapāramiyā saṃkileso. Sattakālavikappā sīlapāramiyā. Kāmabhavatadupasamesu abhiratianabhirativikappā
analyzed: dāna pāramiyā saṃkilesaḥ satta kāla vikappā sīla pāramiyā kāma bhava tad upasamesu abhirati anabhirati vikappā
translated: The misapprehension of sense desires, becoming, and the signless, and the misapprehension of equanimity are the defilements of the perfection of renunciation.

original: nekkhammapāramiyā. “Ahaṃ mamā”ti vikappā paññāpāramiyā. Līnuddhaccavikappā vīriyapāramiyā.
analyzed: nekkhamma pāramiyā aham mama ati vikappā paññāpāramiyā līn uddhacca vikappā vīriya pāramiyā
translated: and the perfection of renunciation. The misapprehension of “I” and “mine” is the perfection of understanding. The misapprehension of depression and agitation is the perfection of energy.

original: Attaparavikappā khantipāramiyā. Adiṭṭhādīsu diṭṭhādivikappā saccapāramiyā. Bodhisambhāratabbipakkhesu🔽dosaguṇavikappā adhiṭṭhānapāramiyā. Hitāhitavikappā mettāpāramiyā. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhavikappā
analyzed: khanti pāramiyā adiṭṭha ādīsu diṭṭha ādi vikappā sacca pāramiyā bodhi sambhāra tabbipakkhesu  dosa guṇa vikappāḥ adhiṭṭhāna pāramiyā hita ahita vikappāḥ mettā pāramiyā iṭṭha aniṭṭha vikappāḥ
translated: The misapprehension of self and others is the perfection of patience. The misapprehension of the seen, etc., as not seen, etc., is the perfection of truthfulness. The misapprehension of the requisites of enlightenment and their opposites

original: upekkhāpāramiyā saṃkilesoti veditabbo.
analyzed: upekkhā pāramiyā saṃkilesaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: as faulty and good respectively is the perfection of determination. The misapprehension of what is beneficial and not beneficial is the perfection of loving kindness. The misapprehension of the agreeable and disagreeable is the perfection of equanimity. This is how the defilements should be understood.

original: Kiṃ vodānanti –
analyzed: kim vā udānanti
translated: What is their cleansing?

original: Taṇhādīhi aghātatā, rahitatā vikappānaṃ;
analyzed: taṇhā ādīhi aghāta tā rahita tā vikappānam
translated: The non-affliction of the misapprehensions by craving, etc.,🔽And their absence should be known as the cleansing,

original: Vodānanti vijāniyā, sabbāsameva tāsampi.🔽Anupaghātā hi taṇhā māna diṭṭhi kodhu panāha makkha palāsa issāmacchariya māyā sāṭheyya🔽thambha sārambha mada pamādādīhi kilesehi deyyapaṭiggāhakavikappādirahitā ca dānādipāramiyo
analyzed: vodānanti vijāniyā sabbāsam eva tāsam pi  anupaghātā hi taṇhā māna diṭṭhi kodhu panāha makkha palāsa issā macchariya māyā sāṭheyya  thambha sa ārambha mada pamāda ādīhi kilesehi ca dāna ādi pāramiyaḥ
translated: In all cases, of the misapprehensions.

original: parisuddhā pabhassarā bhavantīti.
analyzed: parisuddhāḥ pabhassarāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: For the perfections of giving, etc., are purified and clear when they are not afflicted by craving, conceit, views, anger, hypocrisy, fraud, obstinacy, domineering, vanity, negligence, etc., and when they are not misapprehended as the bases for the conceit “I give,” etc., or as something to be desired or shunned.

original: Ko paṭipakkhoti –
analyzed: kaḥ paṭipakkhaḥ ti
translated: What is their opposition?

original: Akusalā kilesā ca, paṭipakkhā abhedato;
analyzed: akusalā kilesā ca paṭipakkhāḥ abhedato
translated: The unwholesome and the defilements are the opposition,🔽In general, to the wholesome;

original: Bhedato pana pubbepi, vuttā macchariyādayo.
analyzed: bhedataḥ pana pubbe api vuttāḥ macchariya ādayaḥ
translated: But in detail they are the greed, etc., already mentioned.

original: Avisesena hi sabbepi akusalā dhammā, sabbepi kilesā ca etāsaṃ paṭipakkhā. Visesena🔽pana pubbe vuttā macchariyādayoti veditabbā. Apica deyyapaṭiggāhakadānaphalesu alobhādosāmohaguṇayogato
analyzed: avisesena hi sabbe pi akusalāḥ dhammāḥ sabbe pi kilesāḥ ca etāsam paṭipakkhāḥ visesena  pana pubbe vuttā macchariya ādayaḥ ti veditabbāḥ apica deyya paṭiggāhaka dāna phalesu alobhā dosā moha guṇa yogataḥ
translated: For all unwholesome states and all defilements are, without distinction, their opposites. But in particular🔽they should be understood as the greed, etc., already mentioned.

original: lobhadosamohapaṭipakkhaṃ dānaṃ, kāyādidosattayavaṅkāpagamato lobhādipaṭipakkhaṃ sīlaṃ,
analyzed: lobha dosa moha paṭipakkham dānam kāya ādi dosa ttaya vaṅka apagamataḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkham sīlam
translated: Moreover, generosity is the opposite of greed, hate, and delusion, since it is associated with the special qualities of non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion, in the sense of giving, of refraining from harming, and of relinquishing, respectively, in regard to the gift, the recipient, and the act of giving.🔽Virtue is the opposite of greed, etc., since it is free from the three crookednesses of body, speech, and mind.

original: kāmasukhaparūpaghātaattakilamathaparivajjanato dosattayapaṭipakkhaṃ nekkhammaṃ, lobhādīnaṃ🔽andhīkaraṇato, ñāṇassa ca anandhīkaraṇato lobhādipaṭipakkhā paññā, alīnānuddhatañāyārambhavasena
analyzed: kāma sukha para upaghāta atta kilamatha parivajjanataḥ dosa ttaya paṭipakkham nekkhammam lobha ādīnam  andhīkaraṇataḥ ñāṇassa ca an andhīkaraṇataḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkhā paññā alīna anuddhata ñāya ārambha vasena
translated: Renunciation is the opposite of hate, etc., since it avoids sense desires, which are a source of suffering, and the suffering of oneself, others, and both, respectively.🔽Wisdom is the opposite of greed, etc., since it is the opposite of the blindness of greed, etc., and is the illumination of knowledge.🔽Energy is the opposite of greed, etc., since it is the opposite of the states of indolence, agitation, and lack of instigation, respectively.

original: lobhādipaṭipakkhaṃ vīriyaṃ, iṭṭhāniṭṭhasuññatānaṃ khamanato lobhādipaṭipakkhā khanti,
analyzed: lobha ādi paṭipakkham vīriyam iṭṭha aniṭṭha suññatānam khamanataḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkhā khanti
translated: Patience is the opposite of greed, etc., since it is the opposite of the states of attachment to sense desires, agitation, and lack of instigation, respectively.

original: satipi paresaṃ upakāre, apakāre ca yathābhūtappavattiyā lobhādipaṭipakkhaṃ saccaṃ,
analyzed: sati api paresam upakāre apakāre ca yathā bhūta ppavattiyā lobha ādi paṭipakkham saccam
translated: Truthfulness is the opposite of greed, etc., since it is the opposite of the states of attachment to sense desires, agitation, and lack of instigation, respectively.

original: lokadhamme abhibhuyya yathāsamādinnesu sambhāresu acalanato lobhādipaṭipakkhaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ,🔽nīvaraṇavivekato lobhādipaṭipakkhā mettā, iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu anunayapaṭighaviddhaṃsanato,
analyzed: loka dhamme abhibhuyya yathā samādinnesu sambhāresu acalanataḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkham adhiṭṭhānam  nīvaraṇa vivekataḥ lobha ādi paṭipakkhā mettā iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu anunaya paṭigha viddhaṃsanato
translated: And the resolution that is the opposite of greed, etc., should be regarded as resolution in the sense of unshakability in the undertaking of the duties as they arise, overcoming the states of worldly care.🔽And loving-kindness that is the opposite of greed, etc., should be regarded as loving-kindness in the sense of separation from the hindrances, and in the sense of non-aversion to what is unlovable.

original: samappavattito ca lobhādipaṭipakkhā upekkhāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: sama ppavattitaḥ ca lobha ādi paṭipakkhā upekkhā ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: And equanimity that is the opposite of greed, etc., should be regarded as equanimity in the sense of non-excess of preference and in the sense of non-excess of aversion.

original: Kā paṭipattīti –
analyzed: kā paṭipatti iti
translated: What is the practice?🔽The practice should be understood as the various kinds of help for beings

original: Dānākārādayo eva, uppāditā anekadhā;
analyzed: dāna ākāra ādayaḥ eva uppāditāḥ anekadhā
translated: By giving away what should be given, by refraining from what should not be done,

original: Paṭipattīti viññeyyā, pāramīpūraṇakkame.🔽Dānapāramiyā hi tāva sukhūpakaraṇasarīrajīvitapariccāgena, bhayāpanayanena, dhammopadesena🔽ca bahudhā sattānaṃ anuggahakaraṇaṃ paṭipatti. Tattha āmisadānaṃ abhayadānaṃ dhammadānanti
analyzed: paṭipatti iti viññeyyā pāramī pūraṇa kkame  dāna pāramiyā hi tāva sukhu upakaraṇa sarīra jīvita pariccāgena bhaya apanayanena dhamma upadesena  ca bahudhā sattānam anuggaha karaṇam paṭipatti tattha āmisa dānam abhaya dānam dhamma dānanti
translated: and by undertaking what should be done.

original: dātabbavatthuvasena tividhaṃ dānaṃ. Tesu bodhisattassa dātabbavatthu ajjhattikaṃ,
analyzed: dātabba vatthu vasena tividham dānam tesu bodhisattassa dātabba vatthu ajjhattikam
translated: For the perfection of giving, firstly, the practice is the various kinds of help for beings by giving away requisites, by saving from danger, and by sharing the Dhamma. Herein, giving is threefold, that is to say, giving of material things, giving of fearlessness, and giving of the Dhamma.

original: bāhiranti duvidhaṃ. Tattha bāhiraṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālā gandhaṃ vilepanaṃ
analyzed: bāhiranti duvidham tattha bāhiram annam pānam vattham yānam mālā gandham vilepanam
translated: It is twofold as internal and external. Herein, the external is food, drink, garments, vehicles, garlands, scents, unguents, flowers,78  etc.,

original: seyyā āvasathaṃ padīpeyyanti dasavidhaṃ. Annādīnaṃ khādanīyabhojanīyādivibhāgena
analyzed: āvasatham dasavidham anna ādīnam khādanīya bhojanīya ādi vibhāgena
translated: and a dwelling place, tenfold. And so on. And there are many kinds of food, etc., according to the division of what is to be eaten as food, etc.,

original: anekavidhañca. Tathā rūpārammaṇaṃ yāva dhammārammaṇanti ārammaṇato chabbidhaṃ. Rūpārammaṇādīnañca🔽nīlādivibhāgena anekavidhaṃ. Tathā maṇikanakarajatamuttāpavāḷādikhettavatthuārāmādi
analyzed: anekavidham ca tathā rūpa ārammaṇam yāva dhamma ārammaṇanti ārammaṇataḥ chabbidham rūpa ārammaṇa ādīnam ca  nīla ādi vibhāgena anekavidham tathā maṇi kanaka rajata muttāpa vāḷa ādi khetta vatthu ārāma ādi
translated: and according to the division of what is to be eaten as nutriment, etc. And likewise the object is sixfold according to the division of visible-data objects, etc.,

original: dāsīdāsagomahiṃsādinānāvidhavatthūpakaraṇavasena anekavidhaṃ.
analyzed: anekavidham
translated: and manifold according to the division of blue, etc., of visible-data objects, and so on. And likewise the field, site, park, etc., is manifold according to the division of gems, gold, silver, pearls, coral, etc., and according to the division of the various kinds of property such as female and male slaves, cattle, elephants, horses, etc.

original: Tattha mahāpuriso bāhiraṃ vatthuṃ dento “yo yena atthiko, taṃ tasseva deti. Dento🔽ca tassa atthiko”ti sayameva jānanto ayācitopi deti, pageva yācito. Muttacāgo deti,🔽no amuttacāgo. Pariyattaṃ deti, no apariyattaṃ. Sati deyyadhamme paccupakārasannissito
analyzed: tattha mahā purisaḥ bāhiram vatthum dentaḥ yaḥ yena atthikaḥ tam tassa iva deti dentaḥ  ca tassa atthikaḥ ti sayam eva jānantaḥ a yācitaḥ api deti pagā iva yācitaḥ mutta cāgaḥ deti  no amutta cāgaḥ pariyattam deti no a pariyattam sati deyya dhamme paccupakāra sannissito
translated: Herein, when the Great Man gives external things, he gives to each one what each one wants. And when he gives, he gives🔽knowing that the recipient wants what he is giving, and he does not wait to be asked, much less is he one who gives when asked. He gives freely,

original: na deti, asati deyyadhamme, pariyatte ca saṃvibhāgārahaṃ vibhajati. Na ca deti parūpaghātāvahaṃ
analyzed: na deti asati deyya dhamme pariyatte ca saṃvibhāga araham vibhajati na ca deti parūpa ghāta āvaham
translated: not ungraciously. He gives in good time, not at an inopportune time. He gives without attachment, not with attachment. He gives not for the sake of a return, not for the sake of use, not for the sake of experience, not for the sake of the support it gives to constancy, not for the sake of heaven, not for the sake of rulership, not for the sake of the status of Brahmā, not for the sake of becoming a deity, not for the sake of becoming a human, not for the sake of becoming a recluse, not for the sake of becoming a Buddha, but for the sake of giving itself, for the sake of merit itself, for the sake of the supreme benefit, for the sake of Nibbāna.

original: satthavisamajjādikaṃ, nāpi kīḷanakaṃ, yaṃ anatthupasaṃhitaṃ, pamādāvahañca, na ca
analyzed: sattha visamajja ādikam na api kīḷanakam yam anattha upasaṃhitam pamāda āvaham ca na ca
translated: nor does he give what is harmful, such as weapons, poisons, and intoxicants, or what is useless, such as toys, or what is dangerous, such as hunting birds and keeping fighting cocks,

original: gilānassa yācakassa pānabhojanādiasappāyaṃ, pamāṇarahitaṃ vā deti, pamāṇayuttaṃ pana sappāyameva deti.

original: Tathā yācito gahaṭṭhānaṃ gahaṭṭhānucchavikaṃ deti, pabbajitānaṃ pabbajitānucchavikaṃ
