original: deti. Mātāpitaro ñātisālohitā mittāmaccā puttadāradāsakammakarāti etesu kassaci pīḷaṃ
analyzed: deti mātā pitaraḥ ñāti sālohitāḥ mitta amaccā putta dāra dāsa kamma karāti etesu kassaci
translated: He gives without causing pain to anyone, to his mother and father, to his relatives and family, to his friends and companions, to his children, wife, and slaves, and to his workers.

original: ajanento deti, na ca uḷāraṃ deyyadhammaṃ paṭijānitvā lūkhaṃ deti, na ca lābhasakkārasilokasannissito
analyzed: a janentaḥ deti na ca uḷāram deyya dhammam paṭijānitvā lūkham deti na ca lābha sakkāra siloka sannissito
translated: He does not give a poor gift after promising a rich one. He does not give out of desire for gain, honor, and fame,

original: deti, na ca paccupakārasannissito deti, na ca phalapāṭikaṅkhī deti aññatra sammāsambodhiyā,
analyzed: deti na ca paccupakāra sannissito deti na ca phala pāṭikaṅkhī deti aññatra sammāsambodhiyā
translated: nor out of expectation of reward, except for the supreme enlightenment.

original: na ca yācito, deyyadhammaṃ vā jigucchanto deti, na ca asaññatānaṃ yācakānaṃ akkosakaparibhāsakānampi
analyzed: na ca yācitaḥ deyya dhammam vā jigucchantaḥ deti na ca asaññatānam yācakānam akkosaka paribhāsakānam pi
translated: He does not give with contempt for the gift, the receiver, or himself, or with contempt for those who do not give, or for those who do not receive.

original: yācakopi paccupaṭṭhito, taṃ acintetvā api attānaṃ dhāvitvā dento yācakaṃ sammāneti
analyzed: yācakaḥ api paccupaṭṭhitaḥ tam a cintetvā api attānam dhāvitvā dentaḥ yācakam sammāneti
translated: The giver who, without being asked, runs to give to the suppliant, thus rightly approaches the suppliant.

original: yathā taṃ akittipaṇḍito, na ca mahāpuriso attano puttadāradāsakammakaraporise yācito
analyzed: yathā tam akitti paṇḍitaḥ na ca mahā purisaḥ attano putta dāra dāsa kammakara porise yācito
translated: And the Great Man does not give his children, wife, slaves, servants, and workers when asked to do so,

original: te asaññāpite domanassappatte yācakānaṃ deti, sammadeva pana saññāpite somanassappatte🔽deti, dento ca yakkharakkhasapisācādīnaṃ vā manussānaṃ vā kurūrakammantānaṃ jānanto
analyzed: te a saññāpite domanassa ppatte yācakānam deti sammat eva pana saññāpite somanassa ppatte  deti dento ca yakkha rakkhasa pisāca ādīnam vā manussānam vā kurūra kammantānam jānanto
translated: but he gives them only when they themselves, without being asked, approach him with a desire to go forth, and he gives them gladly, not unwillingly.

original: na deti, tathā rajjampi tādisānaṃ na deti, ye lokassa ahitāya dukkhāya anatthāya
analyzed: na deti tathā rajjam pi tādisānam na deti ye lokassa ahitāya dukkhāya anatthāya
translated: And he does not give to yakkhas, rakkhasas, pisacas, etc., or to human beings who are addicted to evil deeds,

original: paṭipajjanti, ye pana dhammikā dhammena lokaṃ pālenti, tesaṃ rajjadānaṃ deti. Evaṃ
analyzed: paṭipajjanti ye pana dhammikāḥ dhammena lokam pālenti tesam rajja dānam deti evam
translated: but he gives to those who are righteous and rule the world righteously. Thus

original: tāva bāhiradāne paṭipatti veditabbā.
analyzed: tāva bāhira dāne paṭipatti veditabbā
translated: he gives the sovereignty. This is how the practice should be understood in the case of external giving.

original: Ajjhattikadānampi dvīhākārehi veditabbaṃ. Kathaṃ? Yathā nāma koci puriso ghāsacchādanahetu
analyzed: ajjhattika dānam pi dvīhākārehi veditabbam katham yathā nāma koci purisaḥ ghāsa chādana hetu
translated: Internal giving should be understood in two ways. How? As in the case of a man who, for the sake of food and clothing,

original: attānaṃ parassa nissajjati, vidheyyabhāvaṃ upagacchati dāsabyaṃ, evameva mahāpuriso
analyzed: attānam parassa nissajjati vidheyya bhāvam upagacchati dāsabyam evam eva mahā purisaḥ
translated: He surrenders himself to another, he becomes a slave, he submits to another’s will. So too the Great Man🔽wishing to fulfil his own perfection of giving,

original: sambodhihetu nirāmisacitto sattānaṃ anuttaraṃ hitasukhaṃ icchanto attano dānapāramiṃ
analyzed: sambodhi hetu sattānam anuttaram hita sukham icchantaḥ dāna pāramim
translated: desiring to bring about the unsurpassed welfare and happiness of beings by means of his desire for enlightenment,

original: paripūretukāmo attānaṃ parassa nissajjati, vidheyyabhāvaṃ upagacchati yathākāmakaraṇīyataṃ,
analyzed: paripūretu kāmaḥ attānam parassa nissajjati vidheyya bhāvam upagacchati yathākāma karaṇīya tam
translated: surrenders himself to others, he submits to another’s will, he becomes a slave to do the bidding of others,

original: karacaraṇanayanādiaṅgapaccaṅgaṃ tena tena atthikānaṃ akampito alīno anuppadeti, na
analyzed: kara caraṇa nayana ādi aṅga paccaṅgam tena tena atthikānam akampitaḥ alīnaḥ anuppadeti na
translated: he gives up his hands, feet, eyes, etc., without trembling, without wavering, without shrinking,

original: tattha sajjati, na saṅkocaṃ āpajjati yathā taṃ bāhiravatthusmiṃ. Tathā hi mahāpuriso
analyzed: tattha sajjati na saṅkocam āpajjati yathā tam bāhira vatthusmim tathā hi mahā purisaḥ
translated: without being attached to them, without being miserly with them, as he is with external goods. For the Great Man

original: dvīhākārehi bāhiravatthuṃ pariccajati yathāsukhaṃ paribhogāya vā yācakānaṃ, tesaṃ🔽manorathaṃ pūrento attano vasībhāvāya vā. Tattha sabbena sabbaṃ muttacāgo evamāha
analyzed: dvīhākārehi bāhira vatthum pariccajati yathāsukham paribhogāya vā yācakānam tesam  manoratham pūrentaḥ attanaḥ vasībhāvāya vā tattha sabbena sabbam mutta cāgaḥ evam āha
translated: surrenders external goods in two ways: either for the enjoyment of those who ask, fulfilling their wishes,

analyzed: nissaṅga bhāvena aham sambodhim pāpuṇissāmi iti evam ajjhattika vatthusmim pi veditabbam
translated: or for his own mastery, saying, “By means of non-attachment I shall attain enlightenment.” So too it should be understood in regard to internal goods.

original: Tattha yaṃ ajjhattikavatthu diyyamānaṃ yācakassa ekanteneva hitāya saṃvattati, taṃ🔽deti, na itaraṃ. Na ca mahāpuriso mārassa, mārakāyikānaṃ vā devatānaṃ vihiṃsādhippāyānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yam ajjhattika vatthu diyyamānam yācakassa ekantena iva hitāya saṃvattati tam  deti naḥ itaram na ca mahā purisaḥ mārassa māra kāyikānam vā devatānam vihiṃsā adhippāyānam
translated: Herein, he gives what is given to a suppliant that will only lead to his harm,

original: attano attabhāvaṃ, aṅgapaccaṅgāni vā jānamāno deti “mā tesaṃ anattho ahosī”ti. Yathā
analyzed: attanaḥ atta bhāvam aṅga paccaṅgāni vā jānamānaḥ deti mā tesam anatthaḥ ahosi iti yathā
translated: not what will lead to his welfare. And he does not give his own person or his limbs and appendages, knowing that they will be to the harm of the devas of Mara’s company who are bent on harming him.

original: ca mārakāyikānaṃ, evaṃ tehi anvāviṭṭhānampi na deti, nāpi ummattakānaṃ, itaresaṃ🔽pana yāciyamāno samanantarameva deti tādisāya yācanāya dullabhabhāvato, tādisassa
analyzed: ca māra kāyikānam evam tehi anvāviṭṭhānam api na deti na api ummattakānam itaresam  pana yāciyamānaḥ samanantaram eva deti tādisāya yācanāya dullabha bhāvato tādisassa
translated: And just as he does not give to those of Mara’s company, so too he does not give to those possessed by them, nor to lunatics,

original: ca dānassa dukkarabhāvato.
analyzed: ca dānassa dukkara bhāvato
translated: but he gives to others as soon as they ask, because such a request is difficult to make and such a gift difficult to give.

translated: The giving of the Dhamma is the teaching of the Dhamma without distortion by one whose mind is undefiled. analyzed: paripācanam tattha ayam nayo saṅkhepato tāva dāna kathā sīla kathā sagga kathā kāmānam

original: vipassanābhinivesesu yathārahaṃ abhinivesanamukhena vipassanānuyogo, tathā visuddhipaṭipadāya
analyzed: vipassanā abhinivesesu yathāraham abhinivesana mukhena vipassanā anuyogaḥ tathā visuddhi paṭipadāya
translated: The teaching of the Dhamma is a means of access to the Dispensation for those who have not yet gained entry to it, and it is a means of maturing those who have already gained entry to it.

original: sammattagahaṇaṃ, tisso vijjā, cha abhiññā, catasso paṭisambhidā, sāvakabodhīti etesaṃ🔽guṇasaṃkittanavasena yathārahaṃ tattha tattha patiṭṭhāpanā, pariyodapanā ca. Tathā
analyzed: sammatta gahaṇam tissaḥ vijjā cha abhiññā catasso paṭisambhidā sāvaka bodhi iti etesam  guṇa saṃkittana vasena yathāraham tattha tattha patiṭṭhāpanā pariyodapanā ca tathā
translated: The “guidance” is the establishment and purification of the following in the disciples, in accordance with their capacity: the three kinds of knowledge , the six kinds of direct knowledge , the four analytical knowledges , and the enlightenment of the disciples.🔽The “purification” is the establishment and purification of the disciples in the three stages of enlightenment, in accordance with their capacity, by means of the exposition of the qualities of the three kinds of enlightenment.

analyzed: paccekabodhiyam sammāsambodhiyam ca adhimutta cittānam yathāraham dāna ādi pāramīnam

original: sabhāvasarasalakkhaṇādisaṃkittanamukhena tīsupi avatthābhedesu tesaṃ buddhānaṃ mahānubhāvatāvibhāvanena
analyzed: sabhāva sarasa lakkhaṇa ādi saṃkittana mukhena tīsu pi avatthā bhedesu tesam buddhānam mahā anubhāva tā vibhāvanena
translated: and by means of the exposition of the great power of those Buddhas in the three stages of enlightenment.

original: yānadvaye patiṭṭhāpanā, pariyodapanā ca. Evaṃ mahāpuriso sattānaṃ dhammadānaṃ deti.
analyzed: yāna dvaye patiṭṭhāpanā pariyodapanā ca evam mahā puriso sattānam dhamma dānam deti
translated: Thus the Great Man gives the gift of the Dhamma to beings.

analyzed: tathā mahā purisaḥ āmisa dānam dentaḥ iminā aham dānena sattānam āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala paṭibhāna ādi sampattim ca

analyzed: ramaṇīyam agga phala sampattiñca annam deti tathā sattānam kāma kilesa pipāsa vūpasamāya
translated: and the attainment of the supreme fruit of nibbāna.” He gives drink for the purpose of removing the defilement of passion and the thirst of craving.

original: pānaṃ deti, tathā suvaṇṇavaṇṇatāya, hirottappālaṅkārassa ca nipphattiyā vatthāni

translated: for the sake of the attainment of psychic power and for the sake of the bliss of Nibbāna.🔽He gives perfumes, and likewise garlands and ointments,🔽for the sake of the attainment of the radiance of the Buddha-qualities.🔽He gives seats, and likewise beds,

original: gandhaṃ deti, tathā buddhaguṇasobhānipphattiyā mālāvilepanaṃ deti, tathā bodhimaṇḍāsananipphattiyā
analyzed: gandham deti tathā buddha guṇa sobhā nipphattiyā mālā vilepanam deti tathā bodhimaṇḍa āsana nipphattiyā
translated: for the sake of the attainment of the seat and the bed of the Bodhi-tree.🔽He gives dwellings,

original: āsanaṃ deti, tathāgataseyyanipphattiyā seyyaṃ deti, saraṇabhāvanipphattiyā āvasathaṃ
analyzed: āsanam deti tathāgata seyya nipphattiyā seyyam deti saraṇa bhāva nipphattiyā āvasatham
translated: for the sake of the attainment of the state of being a refuge.

original: deti, pañcacakkhupaṭilābhāya padīpeyyaṃ deti.
analyzed: deti pañca cakkhu paṭilābhāya padīpeyyam deti
translated: He gives lamps, for the sake of the attainment of the five eyes.🔽He gives material gifts, for the sake of the attainment of the radiance of the whole world.

original: Byāmappabhānipphattiyā rūpadānaṃ deti, brahmassaranipphattiyā saddadānaṃ deti, sabbalokassa
analyzed: byāma ppabhā nipphattiyā rūpa dānam deti brahmassara nipphattiyā sadda dānam deti sabba lokassa
translated: He gives the gift of sound, for the sake of the attainment of the divine ear.🔽He gives the gift of taste, for the sake of being dear to all the world.🔽He gives the gift of touch, for the sake of being the most delicate of the Buddhas.

original: piyabhāvāya rasadānaṃ deti, buddhasukhumālabhāvāya phoṭṭhabbadānaṃ deti, ajarāmaraṇabhāvāya
analyzed: piya bhāvāya rasa dānam deti buddha sukhu māla bhāvāya phoṭṭhabba dānam deti ajara amaraṇa bhāvāya
translated: He gives the gift of medicine, for the sake of being free from old age and death.🔽He gives the gift of servants, for the sake of being a master in the emancipation from the slavery of the defilements.

original: bhesajjadānaṃ deti, kilesadāsabyavimocanatthaṃ dāsānaṃ bhujissatādānaṃ deti, saddhammābhiratiyā
analyzed: bhesajja dānam deti kilesa dāsabya vimocana attham dāsānam bhujissa tā dānam deti saddhamma abhiratiyā
translated: He gives the gift of the Dhamma, for the sake of delight in the True Dhamma.

original: anavajjakhiḍḍāratihetudānaṃ deti, sabbepi satte ariyāya jātiyā attano puttabhāvūpanayanāya
analyzed: anavajja khiḍḍā rati hetu dānam deti sabbe pi satte ariyāya jātiyā attano putta bhāva upanayanāya
translated: He gives a gift of sons, making all beings his own sons by the noble birth of the Dhamma.🔽He gives a gift of wives, making all the world his own wives by his acceptance of them all.

original: puttadānaṃ deti, sakalassāpi lokassa patibhāvūpagamanāya dāradānaṃ deti, subhalakkhaṇasampattiyā🔽suvaṇṇamaṇimuttāpavāḷādidānaṃ, anubyañjanasampattiyā nānāvidhavibhūsanadānaṃ, saddhammakosādhigamāya
analyzed: putta dānam deti sakalassa api lokassa pati bhāva upagamanāya dāra dānam deti subha lakkhaṇa sampattiyā  suvaṇṇa maṇi muttā pavāḷa ādi dānam anubyañjana sampattiyāḥ nānāvidha vibhūsana dānam saddhamma kosa adhigamāya
translated: He gives a gift of jewels, gems, pearls, lapis lazuli, etc., for the sake of the perfection of the major and minor bodiiy marks.🔽He gives a gift of ornaments of various kinds for the sake of the perfection of the minor characteristics.🔽He gives a gift of his wealth for the sake of the acquisition of the treasure of the true Dhamma.

original: vittakosadānaṃ, dhammarājabhāvāya rajjadānaṃ, dānādisampattiyā ārāmuyyānādivanadānaṃ,
analyzed: vitta kosa dānam dhamma rāja bhāvāya rajja dānam dāna ādi sampattiyai ārāma uyyāna ādi vana dānam
translated: He gives a gift of his kingdom for the sake of kingship in the Dhamma. He gives a gift of parks, pleasure groves, etc., for the sake of the perfection of generosity, etc.🔽He gives a gift of his feet, marked with the auspicious signs, for the sake of walking to the foot of the Bodhi tree.

original: cakkaṅkitehi pādehi bodhimaṇḍūpasaṅkamanāya caraṇadānaṃ, caturoghanittharaṇe sattānaṃ🔽saddhammahatthadānatthaṃ hatthadānaṃ, saddhindriyādipaṭilābhāya kaṇṇanāsādidānaṃ,
analyzed: cakkaṅkitehi pādehi bodhi maṇḍūpa saṅkamanāya caraṇa dānam catur ogha nittharaṇe sattānam  saddhamma hattha dāna attham hattha dānam saddhi indriya ādi paṭilābhāya kaṇṇa nāsā ādi dānam
translated: He gives a gift of his hands for the sake of the hands of the true Dhamma for the crossing of beings over the four floods.🔽He gives a gift of his ears, nose, etc., for the sake of the acquisition of the faculties of faith, etc.

original: samantacakkhupaṭilābhāya cakkhudānaṃ, “dassanasavanānussaraṇapāricariyādīsu sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: samanta cakkhu paṭilābhāya cakkhu dānam dassana savana anussaraṇa pāricariya ādīsu sabbakālam
translated: He gives a gift of his eyes for the sake of the acquisition of the all-seeing eye, so that he may always be able to see, hear, remember, and attend to the Buddhas, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.

original: sabbasattānaṃ hitasukhāvaho sabbalokena ca upajīvitabbo me kāyo bhaveyyā”ti maṃsalohitādidānaṃ.
analyzed: sabba sattānam hita sukha āvahaḥ sabba lokena ca upajīvitabbaḥ me kāyaḥ bhaveyya iti maṃsa lohita ādi dānam
translated: “May my body be a source of benefit and happiness to all beings and may it be a means of livelihood for all the world.”

original: “Sabbalokuttamo bhaveyya”nti uttamaṅgadānaṃ deti.
analyzed: sabba lokuttamaḥ bhaveyyanti uttamaṅgadānam deti
translated: “May I be foremost in the whole world” — he gives the supreme gift, the gift of his own limbs.

original: Evaṃ dadanto ca na anesanāya deti, na paropaghātena, na bhayena, na lajjāya, na dakkhiṇeyyarosanena,
analyzed: evam dadanto ca na an esanāya deti na para upaghātena na bhayena na lajjāya na dakkhiṇeyya rosanena
translated: And when he gives in this way, he does not give what is unlovely by making a wrong livelihood, nor out of fear, nor out of shame, nor out of a sense of obligation to a donor,

original: na paṇīte sati lūkhaṃ, na attukkaṃsanena, na paravambhanena, na phalābhikaṅkhāya,
analyzed: na paṇīte sati lūkham na attukkaṃsanena na paravambhanena na phala abhikaṅkhāya
translated: nor does he give coarse things when fine ones are available, nor out of self-praise or the disparagement of others, nor in order to get a reward,

original: na yācakajigucchāya, na acittīkārena, atha kho sakkaccaṃ deti, sahatthena deti, kālena🔽deti, cittiṃ katvā deti, avibhāgena deti, tīsu kālesu somanassiko deti, tato eva
analyzed: na yācaka jigucchāya na acittīkārena atha kho sakkaccam deti sahatthena deti kālena  deti cittim katvā deti avibhāgena deti tīsu kālesu somanassikaḥ deti tatas eva
translated: nor out of disgust at the recipient, nor without attention, but rather he gives carefully, with his own hand, at the proper time,

original: ca datvā na pacchānutāpī hoti, na paṭiggāhakavasena mānāvamānaṃ karoti, paṭiggāhakānaṃ
analyzed: ca da tvā na pacchā anutāpī hoti na paṭiggāhaka vasena māna avamānam karoti paṭiggāhakānam
translated: with a mind that is joyful, not disdainful, and in the three periods of the day he is cheerful. And after giving, he has no regrets. He does not show contempt for the recipient by his manner of giving.

original: piyasamudācāro hoti vadaññū yācayogo saparivāradāyako. Annadānañhi dento “taṃ saparivāraṃ
analyzed: piya samudācāraḥ hoti vadaññū yāca yogo sa parivāra dāyakaḥ anna dānam hi dentaḥ tam sa parivāram
translated: He is friendly in his dealings with the recipient, generous, open-handed, and a giver of gifts. For when he gives food, he gives it together with its conditions, namely, with the earth element as physical nutriment,

original: katvā dassāmī”ti vatthādīhi saddhiṃ deti, tathā vatthadānaṃ dento “taṃ saparivāraṃ🔽katvā dassāmī”ti annādīhi saddhiṃ deti. Pānadānādīsupi eseva nayo, tathā rūpadānaṃ
analyzed: katvā dassāmi iti vattha ādīhi saddhim deti tathā vattha dānam dento tam sa parivāram  katvā dassāmi iti anna ādīhi saddhim deti pāna dāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ tathā rūpa dānam
translated: and he gives it together with the cloth, etc., so too, when giving a gift of cloth, he gives it together with food, etc., thinking, “I will give it with its accessories.”🔽The same method applies in the case of the gifts of drink, etc. So too, when giving a gift of visible forms,

original: dento itarārammaṇānipi tassa parivāraṃ katvā deti, evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: dentaḥ itara ārammaṇāni pi tassa parivāram katvā deti evam sesesu pi
translated: He gives it together with the cloth, etc., thinking, “I will give it with its accessories.” So too, when he gives a gift of cloth, thinking, “I will give it with its accessories,” he gives it together with food, etc. The same method applies in the case of the gifts of drink, etc. So too, when he gives a gift of visible forms, he gives the other objects of sense desire as their accessories. So too, in the case of the other objects of sense desire.

original: Tattha rūpadānaṃ nāma nīlapītalohitodātādivaṇṇādīsu pupphavatthadhātūsu aññataraṃ🔽labhitvā rūpavasena ābhujitvā “rūpadānaṃ dassāmi, rūpadānaṃ mayha”nti cintetvā tādise
analyzed: tattha rūpa dānam nāma nīla pīta lohita udāta ādi vaṇṇa ādīsu puppha vattha dhātūsu aññataram  labhitvā rūpa vasena ābhujitvā rūpa dānam dassāmi rūpa dānam cintetvā tādise
translated: Herein, a gift of visible forms is a visible form such as a flower, cloth, dye, etc., that is given after being acquired by one’s own labour or inherited from one’s father and mother, etc., or won by gambling, etc., or obtained by begging, etc.

original: dakkhiṇeyye dānaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti, etaṃ rūpadānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: dakkhiṇeyye dānam patiṭṭhāpeti etam rūpadānam nāma
translated: Having acquired it in one of these ways, he thinks, “I will give a gift of visible forms,” or “A gift of visible forms is mine,” and he establishes the giving of it as a gift of visible forms in a recipient who is worthy of an offering. This is called a gift of visible forms.

original: Saddadānaṃ pana bherīsaddādivasena veditabbaṃ. Tattha saddaṃ kandamūlāni viya uppāṭetvā,
analyzed: saddadānam pana bherī sadda ādi vasena veditabbam tattha saddam kanda mūlāni viya uppāṭetvā
translated: A gift of sounds is to be understood as a drum-sound, etc. Herein, it cannot be dug up like a root or bulb,

original: nīluppalahatthakaṃ viya ca hatthe ṭhapetvā dātuṃ na sakkoti, savatthukaṃ pana katvā
analyzed: nīluppala hatthakam viya ca hatthe ṭhapetvā dātum na sakkoti sa vatthukam pana katvā
translated: or placed in the hand like a blue lotus, and given. But it can be given by making it the subject of a deed of gift.

original: dadanto saddadānaṃ deti nāma, tasmā yadā “saddadānaṃ dassāmī”ti bherīmudiṅgādīsu
analyzed: dadantaḥ sat dadānam deti nāma tasmai yadā sat dadānam dassāmi iti bherī mudiṅga ādīsu
translated: Giving a gift of sound is giving a gift of sound called. Therefore when one makes an offering to the Three Gems with a musical instrument such as a drum or a tabor, thinking, “I will give a gift of sound,”

original: aññatarena tūriyena tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ upahāraṃ karoti, kāreti ca, “saddadānaṃ dassāmi,
analyzed: aññatarena tūriyena tiṇṇam rata nānam upahāram karoti kāreti ca saddadānam dassāmi
translated: and when one has it made, and when one has drums, etc., set up with the words, “I will give a gift of sound,

original: saddadānaṃ me”ti bherīādīni ṭhapāpeti, dhammakathikānaṃ pana saddabhesajjaṃ, telaphāṇitādīni
analyzed: sadda dānam mā iti bherī ādīni dhamma kathikānam pana sadda bhesajjam tela phāṇita ādīni
translated: a gift of sound is being given by me,” and when one gives medicine for the ears to preachers of the Dhamma, and oil, molasses, etc.,

original: ca deti, dhammassavanaṃ ghoseti, sarabhaññaṃ bhaṇati, dhammakathaṃ katheti, upanisinnakathaṃ,
analyzed: ca deti dhammassavanam ghoseti sarabhaññam bhaṇati dhamma katham katheti upanisinna katham
translated: and when one announces a preaching of the Dhamma, and when one recites a panegyric, and when one preaches the Dhamma, and when one holds a discussion while seated nearby,

original: anumodanakathañca karoti, kāreti ca, tadā saddadānaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: anumodana katham ca karoti ca tadā sat dadānam nāma hoti
translated: and when one does appreciative joy-rejoicing, and when one has it done, then there is what is called a gift of sound.

original: Tathā mūlagandhādīsu aññataraṃ rajanīyaṃ gandhavatthuṃ, pisitameva vā gandhaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: tathā mūla gandha ādīsu aññataram rajanīyam gandha vatthum pisitam eva vā gandham yam
translated: Likewise, when one has obtained any one of the various kinds of fragrant things such as root-scents, etc., or any kind of fragrant powder,

original: kiñci labhitvā gandhavasena ābhujitvā “gandhadānaṃ dassāmi, gandhadānaṃ mayha”nti
analyzed: kiñci labhitvā gandha vasena ābhujitvā gandha dānam dassāmi gandha dānam
translated: and after having mixed it with water, thinking, “I will give a gift of scent, a gift of scent is being given by me,”

original: buddharatanādīnaṃ pūjaṃ karoti, kāreti ca, gandhapūjanatthāya agarucandanādike gandhavatthuke
analyzed: buddha ratana ādīnam pūjam karoti ca gandha pūjana tthāya agaru candana ādike gandha vatthuke
translated: and when one makes an offering to the Buddha Gem, etc., and when one has it made, and when one has fragrant things such as aloes wood and sandalwood set aside for the purpose of offering scent,

original: pariccajati, idaṃ gandhadānaṃ.
analyzed: pariccajati idam gandha dānam
translated: He gives it away, this is the giving of scents.

original: Tathā mūlarasādīsu yaṃ kiñci rajanīyaṃ rasavatthuṃ labhitvā rasavasena ābhujitvā
analyzed: tathā mūla rasa ādīsu yam kiñci rajanīyam rasa vatthum labhitvā rasa vasena ābhujitvā
translated: Similarly, having obtained any kind of pleasant-tasting substance such as a root, etc., and having tasted it as a taste,

original: “rasadānaṃ dassāmi, rasadānaṃ mayha”nti dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ deti, rasavatthumeva vā aññaṃ
analyzed: rasa dānam dassāmi rasa dānam mayhanti dakkhiṇeyyānam deti rasa vatthum eva vā aññam
translated: he gives it to those worthy of offerings, saying: “I give a gift of taste, I give a gift of taste,” or he gives away the substance itself,

original: gavādikaṃ pariccajati, idaṃ rasadānaṃ.
analyzed: go ādikam pariccajati idam rasa dānam
translated: such as a root, etc., or an animal such as a cow, etc. This is the giving of tastes.

original: Tathā phoṭṭhabbadānaṃ mañcapīṭhādivasena, attharaṇapāvuraṇādivasena ca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā phoṭṭhabba dānam mañca pīṭha ādi vasena attharaṇa pāvuraṇa ādi vasena ca veditabbam
translated: Similarly, the giving of tactile objects should be understood as a bed, a seat, etc., and as a mattress, a pillow, etc.

original: Yadā hi mañcapīṭhabhisibibbohanādikaṃ, nivāsanapārupanādikaṃ vā sukhasamphassaṃ rajanīyaṃ🔽anavajjaṃ phoṭṭhabbavatthuṃ labhitvā phoṭṭhabbavasena ābhujitvā “phoṭṭhabbadānaṃ🔽dassāmi, phoṭṭhabbadānaṃ mayha”nti dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ deti. Yathāvuttaṃ phoṭṭhabbavatthuṃ
analyzed: yadā hi mañca pīṭha bhisi bibbohana ādikam nivāsana pārupana ādikam vā sukha samphassam rajanīyam  anavajjam phoṭṭhabba vatthum labhitvā phoṭṭhabba vasena ābhujitvā phoṭṭhabba dānam  dassāmi phoṭṭhabba dānam mayhanti dakkhiṇeyyānam deti yathāvuttam phoṭṭhabba vatthuṃ
translated: For when he has obtained a bed, a seat, a pillow, a mattress, etc., or a lower or upper garment, etc., which is pleasant to the touch,🔽agreeable, and blameless, and having touched it as a tactile object, he gives it to those worthy of offerings, saying: “I give a gift of tactile objects,

original: labhitvā pariccajati, etaṃ phoṭṭhabbadānaṃ.
analyzed: labhitvā pariccajati etam phoṭṭhabba dānam
translated: I give a gift of tactile objects,” or having obtained the kind of tactile object described, he gives it away. This is the giving of tactile objects.

original: Dhammadānaṃ pana dhammārammaṇassa adhippetattā ojāpānajīvitavasena veditabbaṃ. Ojādīsu🔽hi aññataraṃ rajanīyaṃ dhammavatthuṃ labhitvā dhammārammaṇavasena ābhujitvā “dhammadānaṃ🔽dassāmi, dhammadānaṃ mayha”nti sappinavanītādi ojadānaṃ deti, ambapānādiaṭṭhavidhaṃ
analyzed: dhamma dānam pana dhamma ārammaṇassa adhippeta ttā ojā pāna jīvita vasena veditabbam ojā ādīsu  hi aññataram rajanīyam dhamma vatthum labhitvā dhamma ārammaṇa vasena ābhujitvā dhamma dānam  dassāmi dhamma dānam sappi navanīta ādi oja dānam deti amba pāna ādi aṭṭhavidham
translated: But the gift of the Dhamma should be understood as consisting in the giving of nutriment, life, and so on, since it is intended for one whose object is the Dhamma.🔽For when someone obtains a suitable object of the Dhamma that is desirable, he gives nutriment, namely, ghee, fresh butter, oil, honey, and sugar, thinking, “I will give the gift of the Dhamma, the gift of the Dhamma is mine,” and he gives the eight kinds of drinking-liquor, namely, mango drink, etc., thinking, “I will give the gift of life.”

original: pānadānaṃ deti, jīvitadānanti ābhujitvā salākabhattapakkhikabhattādīni deti. Aphāsukabhāvena
analyzed: pāna dānam deti jīvita dānam ti ābhujitvā salāka bhatta pakkhika bhatta ādīni deti a phāsuka bhāvena
translated: And he gives the various kinds of food, such as rice, cakes, etc., thinking, “I will give the gift of life.”

original: abhibhūtānaṃ byādhikānaṃ vejjaṃ paṭṭhapeti, jālaṃ phālāpeti, kumīnaṃ viddhaṃsāpeti,
analyzed: abhibhūtānam byādhikānam vejjam paṭṭhapeti jālam phāla apeti kumīnam viddhaṃsa apeti
translated: He procures a doctor for those afflicted with disease who are overwhelmed by the suffering of illness; he has a net spread, he has a snare set, he destroys the young of animals, he destroys birds’ eggs,

original: sakuṇapañjaraṃ viddhaṃsāpeti, bandhanena baddhānaṃ sattānaṃ bandhanamokkhaṃ kāreti,🔽māghātabheriṃ carāpeti, aññānipi sattānaṃ jīvitaparittāṇatthaṃ evarūpāni kammāni
analyzed: sakuṇa pañjaram bandhanena baddhānam sattānam bandhana mokkham kāreti  māghāta bherim carāpeti aññāni pi sattānam jīvita parittāṇa ttham evarūpāni kammāni
translated: he releases living beings that have been caught in snares and nets, he sets free those living beings that have been seized by other living beings,

original: karoti, kārāpeti ca, idaṃ dhammadānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: karoti ca idam dhammadānam nāma
translated: he has a drum beaten for the proclamation: “In this town or village no living being is to be killed by anyone,” and he does such and such other deeds and has them done for the purpose of saving the lives of living beings. This is called the gift of the Dhamma.

original: Sabbampetaṃ yathāvuttadānasampadaṃ sakalalokahitasukhāya pariṇāmeti attano ca akuppāya🔽vimuttiyā aparikkhayassa chandassa aparikkhayassa vīriyassa aparikkhayassa samādhissa
analyzed: sabbam petam yathā vutta dāna sampadam sakala loka hita sukhāya pariṇāmeti attano ca akuppāya  vimuttiyāḥ a parikkhayassa chandassa a parikkhayassa vīriyassa a parikkhayassa samādhissa
translated: And he dedicates all this, the aforesaid perfection of giving, to the welfare and happiness of the whole world, and to his own unshakable deliverance.🔽He dedicates it to the inexhaustible desire for renunciation, to the inexhaustible energy, concentration, understanding,

original: aparikkhayassa paṭibhānassa aparikkhayassa jhānassa aparikkhayāya sammāsambodhiyā
analyzed: aparikkhayassa paṭibhānassa aparikkhayassa jhānassa aparikkhayāya sammāsambodhiyā
translated: and meditation, and to the supreme enlightenment.

original: pariṇāmeti, imañca dānapāramiṃ paṭipajjantena mahāsattena jīvite aniccasaññā paccupaṭṭhapetabbā.
analyzed: pariṇāmeti imam ca dāna pāramim paṭipajjantena mahāsattena jīvite anicca saññā paccupaṭṭhapetabbā
translated: And while he is practising this perfection of giving, the Great Man should establish the perception of impermanence in his life,

original: Tathā bhogesu, bahusādhāraṇatā ca nesaṃ manasi kātabbā, sattesu ca mahākaruṇā satataṃ
analyzed: tathā bhogesu bahu sādhāraṇa tā ca na īsam manasi kātabbā sattesu ca mahā karuṇā satatam
translated: and he should constantly and continuously generate great compassion for beings and keep in mind the common ownership of all beings with regard to his belongings.

original: samitaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetabbā. Evañhi bhogehi gahetabbasāraṃ gaṇhanto ādittato viya
analyzed: samitam paccupaṭṭhapetabbāḥ evam hi bhogehi gahetabba sāram gaṇhantaḥ ādittataḥ viya
translated: For when he takes the essence from his belongings in this way, he is like one who removes his property from a burning house and like one who takes himself out of a burning house, leaving nothing behind.

original: agārato sabbaṃ sāpateyyaṃ, attānañca bahi nīharanto na kiñci seseti, na katthaci🔽vibhāgaṃ karoti, aññadatthu nirapekkho nissajjati eva. Ayaṃ tāva dānapāramiyā paṭipattikkamo.
analyzed: agārataḥ sabbam sāpateyyam attānam ca bahi nīharantaḥ na kiñci seseti na katthaci 🔽vibhāgam karoti añña datthu nirapekkhaḥ nissajjati eva ayam tāva dāna pāramiyā paṭipatti kkamaḥ
translated: He makes no division anywhere, but gives up everything without reserve.

original: Sīlapāramiyā pana ayaṃ paṭipattikkamo – yasmā sabbaññusīlālaṅkārehi satte alaṅkaritukāmena
analyzed: sīla pāramiyā pana ayam paṭipatti kkamaḥ yasmā sabbaññu sīla alaṅkārehi satte alaṅkaritu kāmena
translated: The order of practice in the perfection of virtue is as follows. Since one who wishes to adorn beings with the adornment of the virtues of the Omniscient One

original: mahāpurisena ādito attano eva tāva sīlaṃ visodhetabbaṃ. Tattha catūhākārehi sīlaṃ
analyzed: mahāpurisena āditas attanaḥ eva tāva sīlam visodhetabbam tattha catūhākārehi sīlam
translated: must first purify his own virtue, there are four ways in which virtue is purified:

original: visujjhati ajjhāsayavisuddhito, samādānato, avītikkamanato, sati vītikkame puna pākaṭīkaraṇato🔽ca. Visuddhāsayatāya hi ekacco attādhipati hutvā pāpajigucchanasabhāvo ajjhattaṃ🔽hiridhammaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā suparisuddhasamācāro hoti, tathā parato samādāne sati
analyzed: visujjhati ajjhāsaya visuddhitaḥ samādānataḥ a vītikkamanataḥ sati vītikkame puna pākaṭīkaraṇato  ca visuddha āsaya tāya hi ekaccaḥ attā adhipati hutvā pāpa jigucchana sabhāvaḥ ajjhattam  hiri dhammam paccupaṭṭhapetvā su parisuddha samācāraḥ hoti tathā paratas samādāne sati
translated: by the purification of inclination, by undertaking, by non-transgression, and by confession when there has been a transgression.🔽For one who has a purified inclination is naturally disgusted with evil. He establishes the virtue of conscience within himself, and he becomes one whose conduct is well purified.

original: ekacco lokādhipati hutvā pāpato uttasanto ottappadhammaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā suparisuddhasamācāro🔽hoti, iti ubhayathāpi ete avītikkamanato sīle patiṭṭhahanti. Atha ca pana kadāci
analyzed: ekaccaḥ loka adhipati hutvā pāpataḥ uttasantaḥ ottappa dhammam paccupaṭṭhapetvā su parisuddha samācāro  hoti iti ubhayathā api ete a vītikkamanataḥ sīle patiṭṭhahanti atha ca pana kadāci
translated: Similarly, when he undertakes virtue in the presence of others,

original: satisammosena sīlassa khaṇḍādibhāvo siyā, tāyayeva yathāvuttāya hirottappasampattiyā
analyzed: sati sammosena sīlassa khaṇḍa ādi bhāvo siyā tāyayā iva yathā vuttāya hirottappa sampattiyā
translated: he becomes one whose conduct is well purified. Thus in both cases he establishes himself in virtue by non-transgression. But if there should be a breach of virtue through a lapse of mindfulness,🔽then by the very same possession of conscience and shame that was mentioned above,

original: khippameva naṃ vuṭṭhānādinā paṭipākatikaṃ karontīti.
analyzed: khippam eva nam vuṭṭhāna ādinā paṭipākatikam karonti iti
translated: and it is not long before it is restored to its former condition by means of the requisite expiation, etc.

original: Tayidaṃ sīlaṃ vārittaṃ cārittanti duvidhaṃ. Tatthāyaṃ bodhisattassa vārittasīle paṭipattikkamo
analyzed: tayā idam sīlam vārittam cārittanti duvidham tattha ayam bodhisattassa vāritta sīle paṭipatti kkamo
translated: This virtue is twofold as virtue consisting in restraint and virtue consisting in undertaking . Herein, this is the order of practice in the virtue of restraint for the bodhisattva:

original: – tena sabbasattesu tathā dayāpannacittena bhavitabbaṃ, yathā supinantenapi na āghāto🔽uppajjeyya, parūpakaraṇaviratatāya parasantako alagaddo viya na parāmasitabbo. Sace
analyzed: tena sabba sattesu tathā dayā āpanna cittena bhavitabbam yathā supinantena api na āghātaḥ  uppajjeyya para upakaraṇa virata tāya para santakaḥ alagaddaḥ viya na parāmasitabbaḥ sace
translated: he should be so full of pity for all beings that he would not arouse anger even if someone were to strike him with a blade of grass,🔽and he should not be covetous, like a man who has found a treasure, of the company of the wise, let alone of the society of fools.

original: pabbajito hoti, abrahmacariyatopi ārācārī hoti sattavidhamethunasaṃyogavirato, pageva
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ hoti a brahmacariyataḥ pi ārā cārī hoti sattavidha methuna saṃyoga virataḥ pagā iva
translated: If he is a monk, he is one who abstains from the seven kinds of sexual intercourse, not to speak of intercourse with another man’s wife.

original: paradāragamanato. Gahaṭṭho samāno paresaṃ dāresu sadā pāpakaṃ cittampi na uppādeti.🔽Kathento saccaṃ hitaṃ piyaṃ parimitameva ca kālena dhammiṃ kathaṃ bhāsitā hoti. Sabbattha
analyzed: para dāra gamanataḥ gahaṭṭhaḥ samāno paresam dāresu sadā pāpakam cittam pi na uppādeti  kathentaḥ saccam hitam piyam parimitam eva ca kālena dhammim katham bhāsitā hoti sabbattha
translated: If he is a layman, he does not arouse even a wicked thought of lust towards the wives of others.

original: anabhijjhālu, abyāpannacitto, aviparītadassano kammassakatāñāṇena ca samannāgato.
analyzed: an abhijjhālu a byāpanna cittaḥ a viparīta dassano kammassaka tā ñāṇena ca samannāgataḥ
translated: He speaks only such speech as is true, beneficial, and loving, and he speaks at the proper time. He speaks only such speech as is accompanied by the three characteristics . He is not covetous, not ill-tempered, and not full of wrong views. He possesses the knowledge of the way things are in the four noble truths.

original: Samaggatesu sammāpaṭipannesu niviṭṭhasaddho hoti niviṭṭhapemoti.
analyzed: samagga tesu sammāpaṭipannesu niviṭṭha saddhaḥ hoti niviṭṭha pemo ti
translated: He has firm faith and love for those who are united and who practice rightly.

original: Iti caturāpāyavaṭṭadukkhānaṃ pathabhūtehi akusalakammapathehi, akusaladhammehi ca
analyzed: iti caturā apāya vaṭṭa dukkhānam patha bhūtehi akusala kamma pathehi akusala dhammehi ca
translated: Thus, having abandoned the unwholesome courses of action and the unwholesome states that are the way to the four lower worlds,

original: oramitvā saggamokkhānaṃ pathabhūtesu kusalakammapathesu, kusaladhammesu ca patiṭṭhitassa
analyzed: oramitvā saggamokkhānam patha bhūtesu kusala kamma pathesu kusala dhammesu ca patiṭṭhitassa
translated: he is established in the wholesome courses of action and the wholesome states that are the way to heaven and liberation.

original: mahāpurisassa parisuddhāsayapayogato yathābhipatthitā sattānaṃ hitasukhūpasañhitā
analyzed: mahā purisassa parisuddha āsaya payogataḥ yathā abhipatthitā sattānam hita sukha upasañhitā
translated: The wishes of this Great Man, who has a pure intention and effort, for the welfare and happiness of beings,

original: manorathā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ abhinipphajjanti, pāramiyo paripūrenti. Evaṃbhūto hi ayaṃ.
analyzed: manorathā sīgham sīgham abhinipphajjanti pāramiyaḥ paripūrenti evaṃbhūtaḥ hi ayam
translated: are quickly fulfilled according to his desire, and he perfects the pāramīs.

original: Tattha hiṃsānivattiyā sabbasattānaṃ abhayadānaṃ deti, appakasireneva mettābhāvanaṃ🔽sampādeti, ekādasa mettānisaṃse adhigacchati, appābādho hoti appātaṅko, dīghāyuko
analyzed: tattha hiṃsā nivattiyā sabba sattānam abhaya dānam deti appa kasirena iva mettā bhāvanam  sampādeti ekādasa mettā nisaṃse adhigacchati appa ābādhaḥ hoti appa ātaṅkaḥ dīgha āyuko
translated: For by refraining from killing, he gives freedom from fear to all beings, and he easily accomplishes the development of loving-kindness.🔽He attains the eleven benefits of loving-kindness, and he becomes free from illness and affliction, long-lived,

original: sukhabahulo, lakkhaṇavisese pāpuṇāti, dosavāsanañca samucchindati. Tathā adinnādānanivattiyā
analyzed: sukha bahulaḥ lakkhaṇa visese pāpuṇāti dosa vāsanañca samucchindati tathā adinnādāna nivattiyā
translated: and endowed with much happiness. He acquires the special physical characteristics of a great man, and he cuts off the tendency to anger.🔽By refraining from taking what is not given, he gives to all beings the gift of material prosperity.

original: corādīhi asādhāraṇe bhoge adhigacchati, parehi anāsaṅkanīyo, piyo, manāpo, vissāsanīyo,
analyzed: cora ādīhi asādhāraṇe bhoge adhigacchati parehi anāsaṅkanīyaḥ piyaḥ manāpaḥ vissāsanīyaḥ
translated: He acquires wealth that is not shared by thieves, etc., and is not suspected by others, is dear and pleasing to them, and is trusted.🔽He is not attached to the enjoyments of existence, has the virtue of giving, and cuts off the tendency to greed.

original: bhavasampattīsu alaggacitto pariccāgasīlo, lobhavāsanañca samucchindati. Abrahmacariyanivattiyā
analyzed: bhava sampattīsu a lagga cittaḥ pariccāga sīlaḥ lobha vāsanañca samucchindati a brahmacariya nivattiyā
translated: By refraining from unchastity

original: alobho hoti santakāyacitto, sattānaṃ piyo hoti manāpo aparisaṅkanīyo, kalyāṇo cassa
analyzed: alobhaḥ hoti santa kāya citto sattānam piyaḥ hoti manāpaḥ a parisaṅkanīyaḥ kalyāṇaḥ cassa
translated: he is free from lust, is dear and pleasing to beings, is unsuspected, and his good

original: kittisaddo abbhuggacchati, alaggacitto hoti mātugāmesu aluddhāsayo, nekkhammabahulo,
analyzed: kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati a lagga cittaḥ hoti mātu gāmesu a luddha āsayaḥ nekkhamma bahulo
translated: renown spreads. He is not attached to women, is not greedy for them, and is full of renunciation.

original: lakkhaṇavisese adhigacchati, lobhavāsanañca samucchindati.🔽Musāvādanivattiyā sattānaṃ pamāṇabhūto hoti paccayiko theto ādeyyavacano devatānaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇa visese adhigacchati lobha vāsanañca samucchindati  musāvāda nivattiyā sattānam pamāṇa bhūtaḥ hoti paccayikaḥ theto ādeyya vacanaḥ devatānam
translated: He acquires special physical characteristics, and cuts off the tendency to greed.🔽By refraining from false speech

original: piyo manāpo surabhigandhamukho asaddhammārakkhitakāyavacīsamācāro, lakkhaṇavisese
analyzed: piyaḥ manāpaḥ surabhi gandha mukhaḥ asat dhamma ārakkhita kāya vacī samācāraḥ lakkhaṇa visese
translated: he becomes a measure for beings, a trustee, a refuge, and one whose words are accepted. He is dear and pleasing to the gods, has a fragrant mouth, and his bodily and verbal conduct are protected by the true Dhamma. He acquires special physical characteristics,🔽and cuts off the tendency to defilements. By refraining from malicious speech

original: adhigacchati, kilesavāsanañca samucchindati. Pesuññanivattiyā parūpakkamehi abhejjakāyo
analyzed: adhigacchati kilesa vāsanañca samucchindati pesuñña nivattiyā para upakkamehi abhejja kāyaḥ
translated: his body is unbreakable by enemies who hate him,

original: hoti abhejjaparivāro, saddhamme ca abhejjanakasaddho, daḷhamitto bhavantaraparicitānampi
analyzed: hoti abhejja parivāraḥ saddhamme ca abhejja naka saddhaḥ daḷha mittaḥ
translated: He has an unbreakable retinue, and he has unbreakable faith in the true Dhamma. He has firm friends, and he is dear to beings who have known him in other existences.

original: sattānaṃ ekantapiyo, asaṃkilesabahulo. Pharusavācānivattiyā sattānaṃ piyo hoti manāpo
analyzed: sattānam ekanta piyaḥ a saṃkilesa bahulaḥ pharusa vācā nivattiyā sattānam piyaḥ hoti manāpaḥ
translated: He is not defiled by much that is defiling. By refraining from harsh speech, he is dear and pleasing to beings.

original: sukhasīlo madhuravacano sambhāvanīyo, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato cassa saro nibbattati.
analyzed: sukha sīlaḥ madhura vacanaḥ sambhāvanīyaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgato cassa saraḥ nibbattati
translated: He is of pleasant disposition, sweet-voiced, and worthy of being greeted with joined palms. His voice is produced with the eight factors.

original: Samphappalāpanivattiyā sattānaṃ piyo hoti manāpo, garubhāvanīyo ca, ādeyyavacano
analyzed: samphappalāpa nivattiyā sattānam piyaḥ hoti manāpaḥ garu bhāvanīyaḥ ca ādeyya vacano
translated: By refraining from idle chatter, he is dear and pleasing to beings, and he is worthy of respect and his word is authoritative.

original: parimitālāpo, mahesakkho ca hoti mahānubhāvo, ṭhānuppattikena paṭibhānena pañhābyākaraṇakusalo,
analyzed: parimita ālāpaḥ mahesakkhaḥ ca hoti mahā anubhāvaḥ ṭhānuppattikena paṭibhānena pañha abyākaraṇa kusalaḥ
translated: He is a moderate speaker, and he is a great man of power. He is skilled in answering questions with a ready wit that arises through the attainment of absorption.

original: buddhabhūmiyañca ekāya eva vācāya anekabhāsānaṃ sattānaṃ anekesaṃ pañhānaṃ byākaraṇasamattho hoti.
analyzed: buddha bhūmiyam ca ekāya eva vācāya aneka bhāsānam sattānam anekesam pañhānam byākaraṇa samatthaḥ hoti
translated: And on the plane of Buddhahood, he is able to answer the many questions of beings who speak different languages with a single utterance.

original: Anabhijjhālutāya akicchalābhī hoti, uḷāresu ca bhogesu ruciṃ paṭilabhati, khattiyamahāsālādīnaṃ
analyzed: an abhijjhālu tāya a kiccha lābhī hoti uḷāresu ca bhogesu rucim paṭilabhati khattiya mahāsāla ādīnam
translated: By being free from covetousness, he obtains his desires without difficulty and he delights in great wealth. He is sought after by nobles, brahmins, and householders.

original: sammato hoti, paccatthikehi anabhibhavanīyo, indriyavekallaṃ na pāpuṇāti, appaṭipuggalo🔽ca hoti. Abyāpādena piyadassano hoti sattānaṃ sambhāvanīyo, parahitābhinanditāya
analyzed: sammataḥ hoti paccatthikehi an abhibhavanīyaḥ indriya vekallam na pāpuṇāti appaṭipuggalaḥ  ca hoti a byāpādena piya dassanaḥ hoti sattānam sambhāvanīyaḥ para hita abhinanditāya
translated: He is approved of and cannot be overcome by opponents, he does not come to have a deficiency of faculties, he is not a person who is difficult to correct.🔽By means of non-ill-will he is dear to beings, he is worthy of the respect of beings, and by rejoicing in the welfare of others

original: ca satte appakasireneva pasādeti, alūkhasabhāvo ca hoti mettāvihārī, mahesakkho ca
analyzed: ca satte appakasirena iva pasādeti a lūkha sabhāvaḥ ca hoti mettā vihārī mahesakkho ca
translated: he easily inspires confidence in beings. He is not one who is difficult to support, he who abides in loving-kindness is one of great wealth, he is one of great power

original: hoti mahānubhāvo. Micchādassanābhāvena kalyāṇe sahāye paṭilabhati, sīsacchedaṃ pāpuṇantopi
analyzed: hoti mahā anubhāvaḥ micchādassanā bhāvena kalyāṇe sahāye paṭilabhati sīsa chedam pāpuṇantaḥ api
translated: and great majesty. By means of the absence of wrong view he obtains good companions, even if he comes to have his head cut off

original: pāpakammaṃ na karoti, kammassakatādassanato akotūhalamaṅgaliko ca hoti, saddhamme
analyzed: pāpa kammam na karoti kammassaka tā dassanataḥ a kotūhala maṅgalikaḥ ca hoti saddhamme
translated: he does not do evil, and by seeing the ownership of one’s deeds he is not one who is superstitious about omens, and in the true Dhamma

original: cassa saddhā patiṭṭhitā hoti mūlajātā, saddahati ca tathāgatānaṃ bodhiṃ, samayantaresu
analyzed: cassa saddhā patiṭṭhitā hoti mūla jātā saddahati ca tathāgatānam bodhim samaya antaresu
translated: his faith is established, rooted and grounded, and he has faith in the Enlightened One’s enlightenment, he does not delight in the midst of assemblies

original: nābhiramati ukkāraṭṭhāne rājahaṃso viya, lakkhaṇattayavijānane kusalo hoti, ante
analyzed: na abhiramati ukkāra ṭṭhāne rājahaṃsaḥ viya lakkhaṇa ttaya vijānane kusalaḥ hoti ante
translated: like a royal goose in a place of shouting, he is skilled in discerning the three marks , and in the end

original: ca anāvaraṇañāṇalābhī, yāva ca bodhiṃ na pāpuṇāti, tāva tasmiṃ tasmiṃ sattanikāye
analyzed: ca anāvaraṇa ñāṇa lābhī yāva ca bodhim na pāpuṇāti tāva tasmin tasmin satta nikāye
translated: he attains to the knowledge of unobstructed insight. And as long as he has not attained to enlightenment, in whatever group of beings

original: ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭho hoti, uḷāruḷārasampattiyo pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭhaḥ hoti uḷāra uḷāra sampattiyaḥ pāpuṇāti
translated: He becomes the best of the best, and he attains the highest of the high attainments.

original: “Iti hidaṃ sīlaṃ nāma sabbasampattīnaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ, sabbabuddhaguṇānaṃ pabhavabhūmi,
analyzed: iti hi idam sīlam nāma sabba sampattīnam adhiṭṭhānam sabba buddha guṇānam pabhava bhūmi
translated: “Thus virtue is the foundation of all attainments, the source of all the Buddha’s qualities,

original: sabbabuddhakārakadhammānaṃ ādi caraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ mukhaṃ pamukha”nti bahumānaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: sabba buddha kāraka dhammānam ādi caraṇam kāraṇam mukham pamukham ti bahu mānam uppādetvā
translated: the beginning, the footing, the cause, the origin of all the qualities that lead to enlightenment. It is the face, the front, the forefront of all the qualities that lead to enlightenment.”

original: kāyavacīsaṃyame, indriyadamane, ājīvapārisuddhiyaṃ, paccayaparibhoge ca satisampajaññabalena🔽appamatto hoti, lābhasakkārasilokaṃ ukkhittāsikapaccatthikaṃ viya sallakkhetvā “kikīva
analyzed: kāya vacī saṃyame indriya damane ājīva pārisuddhiyam paccaya paribhoge ca sati sampajañña balena  appamattaḥ hoti lābha sakkāra silokam ukkhitta asika paccatthikam viya sallakkhetvā kikī iva
translated: He should be heedful in the restraint of body and speech, in the taming of the sense faculties, in purification of livelihood, and in the use of the requisites, by means of the power of mindfulness and clear comprehension.🔽He should be heedful in the observance of virtue, regarding gain, honour, and renown as a drawn sword, and regarding the five cords of sense desire as a pit of glowing embers, as a forest of thorns, and as a dream, as stated in the passage beginning “He dwells ardent and introspective, self-controlled and self-composed” .

original: aṇḍa”ntiādinā vuttanayena sakkaccaṃ sīlaṃ sampādetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva vārittasīle paṭipattikkamo.
analyzed: aṇḍa nti ādinā vutta nayena sakkaccam sīlam sampādetabbam ayam tāva vāritta sīle paṭipatti kkamo
translated: This, in brief, is the method of practice in virtue as restraint.

original: Cārittasīle pana paṭipatti evaṃ veditabbā – idha bodhisatto kalyāṇamittānaṃ garuṭṭhāniyānaṃ
analyzed: cāritta sīle pana paṭipatti evam veditabbā idha bodhisatto kalyāṇa mittānam garuṭṭhāniyānam
translated: The practice of virtue as embodied in the precepts of training should be understood as follows. Here the bodhisattva is one who pays respect to good friends, to teachers, to elders, to those of seniority,

original: abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikammaṃ kālena kālaṃ kattā hoti, tathā
analyzed: abhivādanam paccuṭṭhānam añjali kammam sāmīci kammam kālena kālam kattā hoti tathā
translated: and he is one who rises up from his seat to greet them, raises his joined palms in salutation, and is dutiful to them.

original: tesaṃ kālena kālaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ kattā hoti, gilānānaṃ kāyaveyyāvaṭikaṃ, vācāya pucchanañca
analyzed: tesam kālena kālam upaṭṭhānam kattā hoti gilānānam kāyaveyyā avaṭikam vācāya pucchanam ca
translated: and he is one who attends to them from time to time, and he is one who gives physical assistance to the sick, and he is one who asks about the sick,

original: kattā hoti, subhāsitapadāni sutvā sādhukāraṃ kattā hoti, guṇavantānaṃ guṇe vaṇṇetā,
analyzed: kattā hoti su bhāsita padāni sutvā sādhukāram kattā hoti guṇavantānam guṇe vaṇṇetā
translated: and he is one who applauds the words of those who speak well, and he is one who extols the virtues of those who have virtues,

original: paresaṃ apakāre khantā, upakāre anussaritā, puññāni anumoditā, attano puññāni sammāsambodhiyā
analyzed: paresam apakāre khantā upakāre anussaritā puññāni anumoditā attanaḥ puññāni sammāsambodhiyā
translated: and he is one who forgives the faults of others, and he is one who remembers benefits, and he is one who rejoices in the merits of others, and he is one who dedicates his own merits to the supreme enlightenment,

original: pariṇāmetā, sabbakālaṃ appamādavihārī kusalesu dhammesu, sati accaye accayato disvā
analyzed: sabbakālam appamāda vihārī kusalesu dhammesu sati accaye accayataḥ disvā
translated: and he is one who dwells in heedfulness at all times with regard to profitable things, and he is one who, if he has failed, shows it and confesses it,

original: tādisānaṃ sahadhammikānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ āvi kattā, uttariñca sammāpaṭipattiṃ sammadeva paripūretā.
analyzed: tādisānam sahadhammikānam yathābhūtam kattā uttariñca sammā paṭipattim sammat eva paripūretā
translated: and he is one who reveals to those who are of the same opinion as himself the true facts, and he is one who fulfils the right practice in the future.

original: Tathā attano anurūpāsu atthūpasaṃhitāsu sattānaṃ itikattabbatāpurekkhāro analaso
analyzed: tathā attanaḥ anurūpāsu attha upasaṃhitāsu sattānam itikattabba tā purekkhāraḥ analasaḥ
translated: And he is one who, in the matter of the duties to be done by others, is not lazy,

original: sahāyabhāvaṃ upagacchati. Uppannesu ca sattānaṃ byādhiādidukkhesu yathārahaṃ patikāravidhāyako,
analyzed: sahāya bhāvam upagacchati uppannesu ca sattānam byādhi ādi dukkhesu yathāraham patikāra vidhāyakaḥ
translated: but is one who takes up the role of a friend in the sense of being one who is not negligent in his consideration of what should be done for others, and he is one who provides the necessary remedy in the case of suffering that has arisen in others, such as sickness, and so on, in whatever way is appropriate,

original: ñātibhogādibyasanapatitesu sokapanodano, ullumpanasabhāvāvaṭṭhito hutvā niggahārahānaṃ🔽dhammeneva niggaṇhanako yāvadeva akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpanāya, paggahārahānaṃ
analyzed: ñāti bhoga ādi byasana patitesu soka panodanaḥ ullumpana sabhāva avaṭṭhitaḥ hutvā niggahāra hānam  dhammena iva niggaṇhanakaḥ yāvat eva akusalāḥ vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpanāya paggahāra hānam
translated: He is one who dispels the sorrow of those who have fallen into misfortune of relatives, property, etc., and who, standing as a support,

original: dhammeneva paggaṇhanako. Yāni purimakānaṃ mahābodhisattānaṃ uḷāratamāni paramadukkarāni
analyzed: dhammena iva paggaṇhanakaḥ yāni purimakānam mahā bodhisattānam uḷāratamāni parama dukkarāni
translated: is one who, by means of the Dhamma, disciplines those who should be disciplined, and who, by means of the Dhamma, encourages those who should be encouraged, in order to make them emerge from the unwholesome and to establish them in the wholesome.🔽Having heard of the most sublime, extremely difficult, inconceivable,

original: acinteyyānubhāvāni sattānaṃ ekantahitasukhāvahāni caritāni, yehi nesaṃ bodhisambhārā
analyzed: acinteyya anubhāvāni ekanta hita sukha āvahāni caritāni yehi bodhi sambhārā
translated: and beneficial practices of the great Bodhisattas of the past, by which their requisites for enlightenment

original: sammadeva paripākaṃ agamiṃsu, tāni sutvā anubbiggo anutrāso “tepi mahāpurisā manussā🔽eva, anukkamena pana sikkhāpāripūriyā bhāvitattā tādisāya uḷāratamāya ānubhāvasampattiyā
analyzed: sammat eva paripākam agamiṃsu tāni sutvā anubbiggaḥ anutrāsaḥ te pi mahā purisāḥ manussā  eva anukkamena pana sikkhā pāripūriyāḥ bhāvita ttā tādisāya uḷāratamāya ānubhāva sampattiyā
translated: were fully matured, he should not be frightened or terrified, thinking: “Those great men were also human beings.🔽But by gradually fulfilling the training, through development, they attained the most sublime and excellent success in the requisites for enlightenment. Therefore I too, by properly

original: bodhisambhāresu ukkaṃsapāramippattā ahesuṃ, tasmā mayāpi sīlādisikkhāsu sammadeva
analyzed: bodhi sambhāresu ukkaṃsa pārami pattāḥ ahesum tasmā mayā api sīla ādi sikkhāsu sammat eva
translated: practicing the training in virtue, etc.,

original: tathā paṭipajjitabbaṃ, yāya paṭipattiyā ahampi anukkamena sikkhaṃ paripūretvā ekantato
analyzed: tathā paṭipajjitabbam yāya paṭipattiyā aham pi anukkamena sikkham paripūretvā ekantato
translated: should follow the same course, by which I too, gradually fulfilling the training, will attain

original: padaṃ anupāpuṇissāmī”ti saddhāpurecārikaṃ vīriyaṃ avissajjanto sammadeva sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti.
analyzed: padam anupāpuṇissāmi iti saddhāpurecārikam vīriyam a vissajjanto sammad eva sīlesu paripūra kārī hoti
translated: and he is one who does not neglect the duties of a guest-house owner.

original: Tathā paṭicchannakalyāṇo hoti vivaṭāparādho, appiccho santuṭṭho pavivitto asaṃsaṭṭho
analyzed: tathā paṭicchanna kalyāṇaḥ hoti vivaṭa aparādhaḥ appicchaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ pavivittaḥ asaṃsaṭṭhaḥ
translated: He is one who conceals his virtues and reveals his faults, who is contented and easy to support, who dwells secluded and is not socializing,

original: dukkhasaho aviparītadassanajātiko anuddhato anunnaḷo acapalo amukharo avikiṇṇavāco
analyzed: dukkha sahaḥ a viparīta dassana jātikaḥ an uddhataḥ an unnaḷaḥ a capalaḥ a mukharaḥ a vikiṇṇa vācaḥ
translated: who endures patiently, who is not born to be reproved, who is not arrogant, not puffed up, not a cheat, not a swindler, not a deceiver of the world,

original: saṃvutindriyo santamānaso kuhanādimicchājīvavirahito ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu
analyzed: saṃvut indriyaḥ santa mānasaḥ kuhanā ādim icchājīva virahitaḥ ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇu mattesu
translated: who guards the doors of his sense faculties, who is content with any kind of resting place, who is not addicted to talk, who is not greedy for delicacies,🔽who is mindful and clearly comprehending, who is scrupulous and scrupulousness is born in him even over a mere trifle, who is afraid of wrongdoing and of the other world.

original: vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, āraddhavīriyo pahitatto kāye
analyzed: vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu āraddha vīriyo pahita tto kāye
translated: He is one who, having undertaken the training rules, trains in them, who is energetic in abandoning what is unwholesome and in acquiring the wholesome, who is firm, solid, and uncowed,

original: ca jīvite ca nirapekkho, appamattakampi kāye, jīvite vā apekkhaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati🔽vinodeti, pageva adhimattaṃ. Sabbepi dussīlyahetubhūte kodhupanāhādike kilesupakkilese
analyzed: ca jīvite ca nirapekkhaḥ appamattakam pi kāye jīvite vā apekkham na adhivāseti pajahati  vinode ti pageva adhimattam sabbe pi dussīlya hetu bhūte kodha upanāha ādike kilesu pakkilese
translated: who does not neglect the duties of hospitality, who is not greedy for sensual pleasures, who does not tolerate even the slightest trace of lust, hatred, or delusion,

original: pajahati vinodeti, appamattakena visesādhigamena aparituṭṭho hoti, na saṅkocaṃ āpajjati,
analyzed: pajahati vinodeti appamattakena visesa adhigamena a parituṭṭhaḥ hoti na saṅkocam āpajjati
translated: who is not satisfied merely with the acquisition of some little learning, who does not become conceited because of a little learning, who does not neglect the elder bhikkhus of long-standing ordination, who is not over-eager to speak,

original: uparūparivisesādhigamāya vāyamati.
analyzed: upari upari visesa adhigamāya vāyamati
translated: or he strives for the attainment of higher and higher distinctions.🔽In whatever way the Great Man does not allow the success he has gained to be shared in by loss or stagnation,

original: Yena yathāladdhā sampatti hānabhāgiyā vā ṭhitibhāgiyā vā na hoti, tathā mahāpuriso🔽andhānaṃ pariṇāyako hoti, maggaṃ ācikkhati, badhirānaṃ hatthamuddāya saññaṃ deti,
analyzed: yena yathāladdhā sampatti hāna bhāgiyā vā ṭhiti bhāgiyā vā na hoti tathā mahā purisaḥ  andhānam pariṇāyakaḥ hoti maggam ācikkhati badhirānam hattha muddāya saññam deti
translated: in that same way he is a guide for the blind, he points out the path, he gives a sign to the deaf,🔽he elucidates the meaning to those who are slow of wit, he gives a seat to those who need a seat, he gives a footstool to those who need a footstool, he gives a resting place to those who need a resting place, he gives a vehicle to those who need a vehicle, he gives a lamp to those who need a lamp.

original: atthamanuggāheti, tathā mūgānaṃ. Pīṭhasappikānaṃ pīṭhaṃ deti, vāheti vā. Assaddhānaṃ🔽saddhāpaṭilābhāya vāyamati, kusītānaṃ ussāhajananāya, muṭṭhassatīnaṃ satisamāyogāya.
analyzed: attham anuggāheti tathā mūgānam pīṭhasappikānam pīṭham deti vā aheti vā assaddhānam  saddhā paṭilābhāya vā āyamati kusītānam ussāha jananāya muṭṭha ssatīnam sati samāyogāya
translated: He strives for the acquisition of faith in those who are without faith, for the arousing of energy in the lazy, for the cultivation of mindfulness in the negligent,🔽for the attainment of concentration in those whose minds are scattered, and for the acquisition of wisdom in the unwise. He strives for the removal of lust in those obsessed by lust,

original: Vibbhantattānaṃ samādhisampadāya, duppaññānaṃ paññādhigamāya vāyamati. Kāmacchandapariyuṭṭhitānaṃ🔽kāmacchandapaṭivinodanāya vāyamati. Byāpādathinamiddhauddhaccakukkuccavicikicchāpariyuṭṭhitānaṃ
analyzed: vibbhanta ttānam samādhi sampadāya duppaññānam paññā adhigamāya vā āyamati kāmacchanda pariyuṭṭhitānam  kāmacchanda paṭivinodanāya vā āyamati byāpādathinam iddha auddhacca kukkucca vicikicchā pariyuṭṭhitānam
translated: for the removal of hatred in those obsessed by hatred, for the removal of delusion in those obsessed by delusion, for the removal of anger, contempt, hypocrisy, malice, envy, egotism, pride, arrogance, conceit, intoxication, violence, dishonesty, obduracy, overweening self-confidence, domineeringness, negligence, and for the removal of wrong thoughts in those obsessed by wrong thoughts.

original: vicikicchāvinodanāya vāyamati. Kāmavitakkādipakatānaṃ kāmavitakkādimicchāvitakkavinodanāya
analyzed: vicikicchā vinodanāya vā āyamati kāma vitakka ādi pakatānam kāma vitakka ādim icchā vitakka vinodanāya
translated: He strives for the removal of the thought of sensuality in those dominated by the thought of sensuality, for the removal of the thought of ill will in those dominated by the thought of ill will, for the removal of the thought of cruelty in those dominated by the thought of cruelty, for the removal of thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and cruelty in those dominated by these thoughts.

original: vāyamati. Pubbakārīnaṃ sattānaṃ kataññutaṃ nissāya pubbabhāsī piyavādī saṅgāhako
analyzed: vāyamati pubba kārīnam sattānam kataññutam nissāya pubba bhāsī piya vādī saṅgāhako
translated: He is a speaker of what is pleasant, a gatherer using the gratitude of beings who have done something for him in the past as a basis.

original: sadisena, adhikena vā paccupakāre sammānetā hoti.
analyzed: sadisena adhikena vā paccupakāre sammānetā hoti
translated: He is one who properly honours those who have helped him, whether they are his equals or superiors.

original: Āpadāsu sahāyakiccaṃ anutiṭṭhati, tesaṃ tesañca sattānaṃ pakatiṃ, sabhāvañca parijānitvā
analyzed: āpadāsu sahāya kiccam anutiṭṭhati tesam tesam ca sattānam pakatim sabhāvam ca parijānitvā
translated: He carries out the duties of a friend in times of trouble. Having understood the nature and disposition of beings,🔽he lives with those with whom he should live in the way he should live with them.

original: yehi yathā saṃvasitabbaṃ hoti, tehi tathā saṃvasati. Yesu ca yathā paṭipajjitabbaṃ
analyzed: yehi yathā saṃvasitabbam hoti tehi tathā saṃvasati yesu ca yathā paṭipajjitabbam
translated: And he acts towards those towards whom he should act in the way he should act towards them.

original: hoti, tesu tathā paṭipajjati. Tañca kho akusalato vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpanavasena,
analyzed: hoti tesu tathā paṭipajjati tat ca kho akusalataḥ vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpana vasena
translated: And he does this for the purpose of establishing them in virtue after extricating them from unwholesome ways,

original: na aññathā. Paracittānurakkhaṇā hi bodhisattānaṃ yāvadeva kusalābhivaḍḍhiyā. Tathā🔽hitajjhāsayenāpi paro na sāhasitabbo, na bhaṇḍitabbo, na maṅkubhāvamāpādetabbo, na
analyzed: na aññathā para citta anurakkhaṇā hi bodhisattānam yāvat eva kusala abhivaḍḍhiyā tathā  paraḥ na sāhasitabbaḥ na bhaṇḍitabbaḥ na maṅku bhāvam āpādetabbaḥ na
translated: not for any other reason. For the guarding of the minds of others is for the bodhisattva only to the extent that it increases their wholesome roots.🔽Even with a mind of good will, one should not overstep another, should not revile him, should not make him feel remorse,🔽should not cause him to be suspected, should not make him feel humiliated,🔽should not make him feel hurt, should not make him feel slighted,

original: parassa kukkuccaṃ uppādetabbaṃ, na niggahaṭṭhāne codetabbo, na nīcataraṃ paṭipannassa
analyzed: parassa kukkuccam uppādetabbam na niggaha ṭṭhāne codetabbaḥ na nīcataram paṭipannassa
translated: should not make him feel threatened, should not make him feel frightened, should not make him feel anxious.

original: attā uccatare ṭhapetabbo, na ca paresu sabbena sabbaṃ asevinā bhavitabbaṃ, na atisevinā,
analyzed: attā uccatare ṭhapetabbaḥ na ca paresu sabbena sabbam asevinā bhavitabbam na atisevinā
translated: He should place himself in a higher position than others, but he should not be one who associates with others in every way, nor one who does not associate with them.

original: na akālasevinā bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: na akāla sevinā bhavitabbam
translated: He should not be one who associates at the wrong time.

original: Yutte pana satte desakālānurūpaṃ sevati, na ca paresaṃ purato piyepi garahati, appiye🔽vā pasaṃsati, na adhiṭṭhāya vissāsī hoti, na dhammikaṃ upanimantanaṃ paṭikkhipati,
analyzed: yutte pana satte desa kāla anurūpam sevati na ca paresam puratas piye pi garahati appiye  vā pasaṃsati na adhiṭṭhāya vissāsī hoti na dhammikam upanimantanam paṭikkhipati
translated: But when he associates with suitable people at the right time and place, he does not praise those he likes in front of others nor disparage those he dislikes.🔽He does not become over-confident, nor does he refuse a proper invitation.

original: na paññattiṃ upagacchati, nādhikaṃ paṭiggaṇhāti, saddhāsampanne saddhānisaṃsakathāya
analyzed: na paññattim upagacchati na adhikam paṭiggaṇhāti saddhā sampanne saddhā nisaṃsa kathāya
translated: He does not accept a nomination, nor does he accept a gift that is excessive.

original: sampahaṃseti, sīlasutacāgapaññāsampanne paññānisaṃsakathāya sampahaṃseti. Sace pana
analyzed: sampahaṃseti sīla suta cāga paññā sampanne paññā nisaṃsa kathāya sampahaṃseti sace pana
translated: He encourages those endowed with faith by talking about the benefits of faith; he encourages those endowed with virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom by talking about the benefits of wisdom.

original: bodhisatto abhiññābalappatto hoti, pamādāpanne satte abhiññābalena yathārahaṃ nirayādike
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ abhiññā bala ppattaḥ hoti pamāda āpanne satte abhiññā balena yathāraham niraya ādike
translated: But if the Bodhisatta has attained the powers of supernormal knowledge, he can, by the power of his supernormal knowledge, show to those who are negligent the hells, etc.,

original: dassento saṃvejetvā assaddhādike saddhādīsu patiṭṭhāpeti, sāsane otāreti, saddhādiguṇasampanne
analyzed: dassentaḥ saṃvejetvā assaddha ādike saddhā ādīsu patiṭṭhāpeti sāsane otāreti saddhā ādi guṇa sampanne
translated: and can thus inspire them to make an effort. He establishes the faithless in faith, and so on up to: he establishes the unwise in wisdom. He introduces them to the Dispensation.

original: paripāceti. Evamassa mahāpurisassa cārittabhūto aparimāṇo puññābhisando kusalābhisando
analyzed: paripāca iti evam assa mahā purisassa cāritta bhūto aparimāṇaḥ puñña abhisando kusala abhisando
translated: he develops it. Thus, for this Great Man, the mass of merit, the mass of what is wholesome, based on conduct,

original: uparūpari abhivaḍḍhatīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica yā sā “kiṃ sīlaṃ, kenaṭṭhena sīla”ntiādinā pucchaṃ katvā “pāṇātipātādīhi viramantassa,🔽vattapaṭipattiṃ vā pūrentassa cetanādayo dhammā sīla”ntiādinā nayena nānappakārato🔽sīlassa vitthārakathā visuddhimagge vuttā, sā sabbāpi idha āharitvā vattabbā. Kevalañhi
analyzed: upari upari abhivaḍḍhati iti veditabbam  apica yā sā kim sīlam kenaṭṭhena sīla nti ādinā puccham katvā pāṇātipāta ādīhi viramantassa  vatta paṭipattim vā pūrentassa cetanā ādayaḥ dhammā sīlanti ādinā nayena nānā pakārato  sīlassa vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge vuttā sā sabbā api idha āharitvā vattabbā kevalañhi
translated: Thus the great man’s immeasurable accumulation of merit, his accumulation of what is wholesome, which is the basis for his conduct, should be understood to increase more and more.🔽Moreover, the detailed explanation of virtue, which was given in the Visuddhimagga in answer to the questions, “What is virtue? In what sense is it virtue? ” and so on, should be brought in here and expounded in full.

original: tattha sāvakabodhisattavasena sīlakathā āgatā, idha mahābodhisattavasena karuṇūpāyakosallapubbaṅgamaṃ
analyzed: tattha sāvaka bodhisatta vasena sīla kathā āgatā idha mahā bodhisatta vasena karuṇu upāya kosalla pubbaṅgamam
translated: For there virtue was expounded under the headings of disciples and paccekabuddhas, while here it should be expounded under the heading of great bodhisattvas, making compassion and skill in means the forerunner.

original: katvā vattabbāti ayameva viseso. Yato idaṃ sīlaṃ mahāpuriso yathā na attano duggatiyaṃ
analyzed: katvā vattabbā ti ayam eva visesaḥ yatas idam sīlam mahā purisaḥ yathā na attanaḥ duggatiyam
translated: This is the only difference. For this virtue of the great man is not for the sake of his own rebirth in a happy state,

original: parikilesavimuttiyā, sugatiyampi na rajjasampattiyā, na cakkavattī, na deva, na sakka,
analyzed: parikilesa vimuttiyā sugatiyam pi na rajja sampattiyam na cakkavattī na deva na sakka
translated: nor for the sake of the purification of the defilements and the attainment of liberation, nor for the sake of sovereignty in a world realm, nor for the sake of becoming a wheel-turning monarch, a world lord, Sakka,

original: na māra, na brahmasampattiyā pariṇāmeti, tathā na attano tevijjatāya, na chaḷabhiññatāya,
analyzed: na na brahma sampattiyā tathā na tevijja tāya na chaḷabhiñña tāya
translated: He does not dedicate it to the attainment of Māra or Brahmā, nor to his own attainment of the three knowledges or the six direct knowledges,

original: na catupaṭisambhidādhigamāya, na sāvakabodhiyā, na paccekabodhiyā pariṇāmeti, atha
analyzed: na catu paṭisambhidā adhigamāya na sāvaka bodhiyā na pacceka bodhiyā pariṇāmeti atha
translated: nor to the realization of the four discriminations, nor to the enlightenment of a disciple or a paccekabuddha, but

original: kho sabbaññubhāvena sabbasattānaṃ anuttarasīlālaṅkārasampādanatthameva pariṇāmetīti
analyzed: kho sabbaññu bhāvena sabba sattānam anuttara sīla alaṅkāra sampādana tham eva pariṇāmeti iti
translated: rather he dedicates it to the attainment of omniscience for the sake of adorning all beings with the unsurpassed ornament of virtue.

original: ayaṃ sīlapāramiyā paṭipattikkamo.🔽Tathā yasmā karuṇūpāyakosallapariggahitā ādīnavadassanapubbaṅgamā kāmehi ca bhavehi
analyzed: ayam sīla pāramiyā paṭipatti kkamaḥ  tathā yasmai karuṇu upāya kosalla pariggahitā ādīnava dassana pubbaṅgamā kāmehi ca bhavehi
translated: This is the method of practice in the perfection of virtue.🔽The perfection of renunciation is the wholesome thought that occurs by way of renunciation of sense pleasures and of existence, preceded by the seeing of danger in them, and accompanied by compassion and skillful means.

original: ca nikkhamanavasena pavattā kusalacittuppatti nekkhammapāramī, tasmā sakalasaṃkilesanivāsanaṭṭhānatāya,
analyzed: ca nikkhamana vasena pavattā kusala cittuppatti nekkhamma pāramī tasmā sakala saṃkilesa nivāsana ṭṭhāna tāya
translated: Therefore, since the household life is the abode of all defilements,

original: puttadārādīhi mahāsambādhatāya, kasivāṇijjādinānāvikammantādhiṭṭhānabyākulatāya ca
analyzed: putta dāra ādīhi mahā sambādha tāya kasi vāṇijja ādi nānā vikammanta adhiṭṭhāna byākula tāya ca
translated: and since it is crowded with wife, children, and so on, and is disturbed by the undertaking of various occupations such as farming and trading,

original: gharāvāsassa nekkhammasukhādīnaṃ anokāsataṃ, kāmānañca “satthadhārālaggamadhubindu
analyzed: ghara āvāsassa nekkhamma sukha ādīnam kāmānam ca sattha dhārā lagga madhu bindu
translated: it provides no opportunity for the happiness of renunciation, etc., and for the sense pleasures, which are like “a drop of honey on a razor’s edge,🔽a sweet grass-blade in a snake’s mouth,

original: viya ca kadalī viya ca avaleyhamānaparittassādavipulānatthānubandhā”ti ca vijjulatobhāsena
analyzed: ca kadalī ca ca ca
translated: and like a plantain tree, with its great mass of fruit that is worthless when stripped off.”🔽like a dance that can be grasped by a flash of lightning,🔽like a decoration for a madman that can be experienced by inverted perception,

original: gahetabbaṃ naccaṃ viya parittakālūpalabbhā, ummattakālaṅkāro viya viparītasaññāya
analyzed: gahetabbam naccam viya paritta kāla upalabbhā ummattaka alaṅkāraḥ viya viparīta saññāya
translated: like a face covered by a veil of leprosy,

original: anubhavitabbā, karīsāvacchādanamukhaṃ viya paṭikārabhūtā, udake temitaṅguliyā nisārudakapānaṃ
analyzed: anubhavitabbā karīsā avacchādana mukham viya paṭikāra bhūtā udake nisārudaka pānam
translated: like a drinking of water without essence by a finger dipped in water,🔽like a burning,🔽like food that is eaten with difficulty,

original: viya atittikarā, chātajjhattabhojanaṃ viya sābādhā, balisāmisaṃ viya byāsanupanipātakāraṇā
analyzed: viya a tittikarā chāta ajjhatta bhojanam viya sa ābādhā bali sa āmisam viya byāsan upanipāta kāraṇā
translated: like a bait that is the cause of the falling into a snare,

original: (byasanasannipātakāraṇā – dī. ni. ṭī. 1.7), aggisantāpo viya kālattayepi dukkhuppattihetubhūtā,
analyzed: byasana sannipāta kāraṇā aggi santāpaḥ viya kāla ttaye pi dukkha uppatti hetu bhūtā
translated: like the heat of a fire that is the cause of the arising of suffering in the three times,🔽like the smearing of a monkey that is the cause of bondage,

original: makkaṭālepo viya bandhananimittā, ghātakāvacchādanakimālayo viya anatthacchādanā,
analyzed: makkaṭa ālepaḥ viya bandhana nimittā anattha chādanā
translated: like a garland of flowers that is the covering of a murderer,🔽like a dwelling in a village with thieves that is a place of fear,

original: sapattagāmavāso viya bhayaṭṭhānabhūtā, paccatthikaposako viya kilesamārādīnaṃ āmisabhūtā,
analyzed: sa patta gāma vāsaḥ viya bhaya ṭṭhāna bhūtā paccatthi kaposakaḥ viya kilesa māra ādīnam āmisa bhūtā
translated: like a nurse for an enemy that is the material for the defilements and the like,

original: chaṇasampattiyo viya vipariṇāmadukkhā, koṭaraggi viya antodāhakā, purāṇakūpāvalambabīraṇamadhupiṇḍaṃ
analyzed: chaṇa sampattiyaḥ viya vipariṇāma dukkhā koṭara aggi viya antar dāhakā
translated: They are like the success of a dream, which ends in suffering; like a fire in a hollow, which burns from within; like a lump of honey on a plant growing over a deep abyss,

original: viya anekādīnavā, loṇūdakapānaṃ viya pipāsāhetubhūtā, surāmerayaṃ viya nīcajanasevitā,
analyzed: aneka ādīnavā loṇūdaka pānam viya pipāsā hetu bhūtā nīca jana sevitā
translated: which is full of many dangers; like drinking salt water, which only increases thirst; like liquor and spirits, which are used by low people;

original: appassādatāya aṭṭhikaṅkalūpamā”tiādinā ca nayena ādīnavaṃ sallakkhetvā tabbipariyāyena🔽nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ passantena nekkhammapavivekaupasamasukhādīsu ninnapoṇapabbhāracittena
analyzed: appassāda tāya aṭṭhi kaṅkalūpamā iti ādinā ca nayena ādīnavam sallakkhetvā tad vipariyāyena  nekkhamme ānisaṃsam passantena nekkhamma paviveka upasama sukha ādīsu ninna poṇa pabbhāra cittena
translated: and like a skeleton, which is repulsive.🔽Seeing the danger in this way, and seeing the benefits of renunciation in the opposite way,

original: nekkhammapāramiyaṃ paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: nekkhamma pāramiyam paṭipajjitabbam
translated: one should practice the perfection of renunciation with a mind that is inclined, inclined, and inclined towards renunciation, seclusion, peace, and happiness.

original: Yasmā pana nekkhammaṃ pabbajjāmūlakaṃ, tasmā pabbajjā tāva anuṭṭhātabbā. Pabbajjamanutiṭṭhantena🔽mahāsattena asati buddhuppāde kammavādīnaṃ kiriyavādīnaṃ tāpasaparibbājakānaṃ pabbajjā
analyzed: yasmā pana nekkhammam pabbajjā mūlakam tasmā pabbajjā tāva anuṭṭhātabbā pabbajjam anutiṭṭhantena  mahāsattena asati buddhuppāde kamma vādīnam kiriya vādīnam tāpasa paribbājakānam pabbajjā
translated: But since renunciation is rooted in going forth, one should first go forth. One who is going to go forth🔽should go forth in the dispensation of the Buddhas, if they have arisen; but if they have not arisen, then in the dispensation of the kamma-proclaimers, the kiriyavādins, the ascetics, and the wanderers.

original: anuṭṭhātabbā. Uppannesu pana sammāsambuddhesu tesaṃ sāsane eva pabbajitabbaṃ. Pabbajitvā
analyzed: anuṭṭhātabbāḥ uppannesu pana sammāsambuddhesu tesam sāsane eva pabbajitabbam pabbajitvā
translated: But having gone forth,

original: ca yathāvutte sīle patiṭṭhitena tassā eva sīlapāramiyā vodāpanatthaṃ dhutaguṇā samādātabbā.
analyzed: ca yathā vutte sīle patiṭṭhitena tassāḥ eva sīla pāramiyāḥ vodāpana ttham dhuta guṇā samādātabbā
translated: And when he has established himself in the virtue described above, he should undertake the ascetic practices in order to perfect that virtue.

original: Samādinnadhutadhammā hi mahāpurisā sammadeva te pariharantā appicchāsantuṭṭhasallekhapavivekaasaṃsaggavīriyārambhasubharatādiguṇasalilavikkhālitakilesamalatāya🔽anavajjasīlavataguṇaparisuddhasamācārā porāṇe ariyavaṃsattaye patiṭṭhitā catutthaṃ🔽bhāvanārāmatāsaṅkhātaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ gantuṃ cattārīsāya ārammaṇesu yathārahaṃ upacārappanābhedaṃ
analyzed: samādinna dhuta dhammā hi mahā purisā sammat eva te pariharantā appicchā santuṭṭha sat lekha paviveka a saṃsagga vīriya ārambha subhara tā ādi guṇa salila vikkhālita kilesa mala tāya  anavajja sīlavata guṇa parisuddha samācārā porāṇe ariya vaṃsattaye patiṭṭhitā catuttham  bhāvanā ārāma tā saṅkhātam ariya vaṃsam gantum cattārīsāya ārammaṇesu yathāraham upacāra ppanā bhedam
translated: For the great men who have undertaken the ascetic practices, by properly observing them, purify the stream of their character, which is like a pond, by the water of such special qualities as fewness of wishes, contentment, eradication of defilements, solitude, non-intercourse, and the arousing of energy.🔽And by the purity of their conduct, which is untarnished by the stain of defilements, they establish themselves in the ancient, noble tradition of the threefold training.🔽And then they enter upon and abide in the jhāna that is the fourth of the noble traditions called “ardour in cultivation,” and which is the basis for the perfection of the pāramīs.

original: jhānaṃ upasampajja viharanti. Evañhissa sammadeva nekkhammapāramī pāripūritā hoti.
analyzed: jhānam upasampajja viharanti evam hissa sammat eva nekkhamma pāramī pāripūritā hoti
translated: This is how they perfectly fulfil the perfection of renunciation.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne terasahi dhutadhammehi saddhiṃ dasa kasiṇāni dasāsubhāni dasānussatiyo
analyzed: imasmim pana ṭhāne terasahi dhuta dhammehi saddhim dasa kasiṇāni dasa asubhāni dasa anussatiyaḥ
translated: At this point, together with the thirteen ascetic practices, the ten kasiṇas, ten kinds of foulness, ten recollections,

original: cattāro brahmavihārā cattāro āruppā ekā saññā ekaṃ vavatthānanti cattārīsa samādhibhāvanākammaṭṭhānāni,
analyzed: cattāro brahmavihārā cattāro āruppāḥ ekā saññā ekam vavatthānanti cattārīsa samādhi bhāvanā kammaṭṭhānāni
translated: There are forty meditation subjects for the development of concentration: the ten kasiṇas, ten impurities, ten recollections, four divine abodes, four immaterial states, one perception, and one defining.

original: bhāvanāvidhānañca vitthārato vattabbāni, taṃ panetaṃ sabbaṃ yasmā visuddhimagge sabbākārato
analyzed: bhāvanā vidhānam ca vitthārataḥ vattabbāni tam pana etam sabbam yasmā visuddhi magge sabba ākārato
translated: The method of development should be given in detail. But all this has been given in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: vitthāretvā vuttaṃ, tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Kevalañhi tattha sāvakabodhisattassa
analyzed: vitthāretvā vuttam tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam kevalam hi tattha sāvaka bodhisattassa
translated: Therefore it should be understood according to the method given there. Only this is the difference: what was said there in terms of disciples and bodhisattvas,

original: vasena vuttaṃ, idha mahābodhisattassa vasena karuṇūpāyakosallapubbaṅgamaṃ katvā vattabbanti
