analyzed: vuttāḥ iminā hi padena karuṇāya gahitāya yehi dhammehi pāṇātipātā paṭivirati sampajjati
translated: For when pity is included by this word, then the possession of shame, loving-kindness, and pity by means of those ideas by means of which the abstention from killing breathing things comes about,🔽is shown by the three words in due succession.

original: tehi lajjāmettākaruṇāhi samaṅgibhāvo yathākkamaṃ padattayena dassito. Paradukkhāpanayanakāmatāpi
analyzed: tehi lajjā mettā karuṇāhi samaṅgi bhāvaḥ yathākkamam dassitaḥ para dukkha apanayana kāma tā api
translated: For the desire to remove the suffering of others is just the same as the desire for their welfare and benefit.

original: hi hitānukampanamevāti avassaṃ ayamattho sampaṭicchitabboti. Imāya pāḷiyā, saṃvaṇṇanāya
analyzed: hi hita anukampanam eva ati avassam ayam attho sampaṭicchitabbaḥ ti imāya pāḷiyā saṃvaṇṇanāya
translated: So the meaning should be accepted as this.

original: ca tassā viratiyā sattavasena apariyantataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: ca tassā viratiyā satta vasena apariyanta tam dasseti
translated: And by this text and by this commentary the author shows the inexhaustibility of that abstention in seven ways.

original: Viharatīti ettha vi-saddo vicchindanatthe, hara-saddo nayanatthe, nayanañca nāmetaṃ
analyzed: viharati iti ettha visaddaḥ vicchindana atthe hara saddaḥ nayana atthe nayanam ca nāma etam
translated: As to the word “dwells” , the prefix vi- has the meaning of “separating” , and the verbal root hr has the meaning of “taking” . And here “taking” is “causing to go” , “causing to go on” , “causing to continue” , “causing to maintain” .🔽So he said “It causes to go on, it causes to go, it causes to continue, it causes to maintain” .

original: idha pavattanaṃ, yāpanaṃ, pālanaṃ vāti āha “iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāletī”ti. Yapeti
analyzed: idha pavattanam yāpanam pālanam vā ati āha iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāleti iti yapeti
translated: And here “causes to go on” and “causes to go” are synonyms.

original: yāpetīti cettha pariyāyavacanaṃ. Tasmā yathāvuttappakāro hutvā ekasmiṃ iriyāpathe
analyzed: yāpeti iti ca itthā pariyāya vacanam tasmai yathā vutta ppakāraḥ hutvā ekasmin iriyāpathe
translated: So it is of the kind already stated, and it causes to go on in one posture,

original: uppannaṃ dukkhaṃ aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā harati pavatteti, attabhāvaṃ vā
analyzed: uppannam dukkham aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā harati pavattā iti atta bhāvam vā
translated: He removes and dispels arisen pain by changing posture, or he maintains his person, the meaning is that he supports it.

original: yāpeti pāletīti attho veditabbo. Iti vā hīti ettha hi-saddo vacanasiliṭṭhatāmatte🔽kassacipi tena jotitatthassa abhāvato. Tenāha “evaṃ vā bhikkhave”ti. Visuṃ kappanameva
analyzed: yāpeti pāleti iti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti vā hi iti ettha hi saddaḥ vacana siliṭṭha tā matte  kassaci pi tena jotita atthassa abhāvato tena āha evam vā bhikkhave iti visum kappanam eva
translated: The word “or” in the text is used in the sense of “and” because of the construction of the sentence.

original: attho vikappatthoti so anekabhinnesuyeva atthesu labbhati, anekabhedā ca atthā uparivakkhamānā🔽evāti vuttaṃ “upari adinnā…pe… apekkhitvā”ti. “Eva”ntiādi ganthagāravapariharaṇaṃ, nayadānaṃ vā.
analyzed: atthaḥ vikappa atthaḥ ti so aneka bhinnesu yeva atthesu labbhati aneka bhedāḥ ca atthāḥ upari vakkhamānāḥ  eva ati vuttam upari adinnāpe apekkhitvā ti eva ntiādi gantha gārava pariharaṇam naya dānam vā
translated: The meaning of “in one way” is “in a single way.” The meaning of “in various ways” is “in many ways.” It is found in many different meanings.🔽And the meanings, being of many kinds, are shown as above.

original: Idāni sampiṇḍanatthaṃ dassento “ayaṃ panetthā”tiādimāha. Tattha na hanatīti na hiṃsati.🔽Na ghātetīti na vadhati. Tatthāti pāṇātipāte. Samanuññoti santuṭṭho. Aho vata reti
analyzed: idāni sampiṇḍana attham dassentaḥ ayam pana itthā tiādim āha tattha na hanati iti na hiṃsati 🔽na ghāteti iti na vadhati tattha ati pāṇātipāte samanuñño ti santuṭṭhaḥ aho vata re ti
translated: “In one way” and so on are a way of avoiding the fault of over-elaboration in the text, or a way of giving guidance.

original: bhonto ekaṃsato acchariyāti attho. Ācārasīlamattakanti sādhujanācāramattakaṃ, matta-saddo🔽cettha visesanivattiattho, tena indriyasaṃvarādiguṇehipi lokiyaputhujjano tathāgatassa🔽vaṇṇaṃ vattuṃ na sakkotīti dasseti. Tathā hi indriyasaṃvarapaccayaparibhogasīlāni🔽idha na vibhattāni. Eva-saddo padapūraṇamattaṃ, matta-saddena vā yathāvuttatthassāvadhāraṇaṃ🔽karoti, eva-saddena ācārasīlameva vattuṃ sakkotīti sanniṭṭhānaṃ. Evamīdisesu. “Iti🔽vā hi bhikkhave puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyyā”ti vacanasāmatthiyeneva🔽taduttari guṇaṃ vattuṃ na sakkhissati. “Taṃ vo upari vakkhāmī”ti ca atthassāpajjanato
analyzed: bhonto ekaṃsataḥ acchariyā ti attho ācāra sīla mattakanti sādhu jana ācāra mattakam matta saddaḥ  ca ittha visesa nivatti atthaḥ tena indriya saṃvara ādi guṇehi pi lokiya puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa  vaṇṇam vattum na sakkoti iti dasseti tathā hi indriya saṃvara paccaya paribhoga sīlāni  na vibhattāni eva saddo pada pūraṇa mattam matta saddena vā yathāvutta tthassa avadhāraṇam  karoti eva saddena ācāra sīlam eva vattum sakkoti iti sanniṭṭhānam evamīdisesu iti  vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati vacana sāmatthiyena iva  tad uttari guṇam vattum na sakkhissati tam vaḥ upari vakkhāmi iti ca atthassa āpajjanato
translated: The meaning is: “You can only speak of his virtue as far as mere good conduct goes.” The word “mere”

original: tathāpannamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “upari asādhāraṇabhāva”ntiādi vuttaṃ. “Na kevalañcā”tiādinā
analyzed: tathā āpannam attham dassetum upari asādhāraṇa bhāva ntiādi vuttam na kevalam ca ati ādinā
translated: means “no more than.” Therefore he shows that the worldling is unable to speak of the Tathāgata’s virtue as far as the qualities of sense-restraint, etc., are concerned. For the virtues of sense-restraint and livelihood are not included here. The word “eva” is used merely to fill out the metre. Or else, the word “eva” emphasizes the meaning of the word “matta” . The meaning is: “He can only speak of his virtue as far as mere good conduct goes.” In the same way, in the passage: “Thus, bhikkhus, the worldling, speaking rightly, could say of the Tathāgata: ‘The recluse Gotama is one who speaks the Dhamma.’ But he could not say of him: ‘The recluse Gotama is one who speaks the good’” , the worldling will be unable to speak of the Tathāgata’s virtue as far as the qualities of sense-restraint, etc., are concerned. And because the meaning of the passage is established by the words of the sutta itself, the commentary explains the meaning of the passage as follows: “The Tathāgata’s virtue is not shared by ordinary people.” The words “not only” , etc.,

original: puggalavivecanena pana “puthujjano”ti idaṃ nidassanamattanti dassitaṃ. “Ito para”ntiādinā🔽ganthagāravaṃ pariharati. Pubbe vuttaṃ padaṃ pubbapadaṃ,na pubbapadaṃ tathā, na pubbaṃ
analyzed: puggala vivecanena pana puthujjanaḥ ti idam nidassanam attanti dassitam itas para nti ādinā  gantha gāravam pariharati pubbe vuttam padam pubba padam na pubba padam tathā na pubbam
translated: He avoids the weight of the text by “from here on” .

original: vā apubbaṃ, tameva padaṃ tathā.
analyzed: vā apubbam tam eva padam tathā
translated: The word previously stated is the prior term, not the prior term in the same way, not prior or not prior, that very term in the same way.

original: Saddantarayogena dhātūnamatthavisesavācakattā “ādāna”nti etassa gahaṇanti attho daṭṭhabbo,🔽tenāha “haraṇa”ntiādi. Parassāti attasantakato parabhūtassa santakassa, yo vā attato
analyzed: dhātūnam attha visesa vācaka ttā ādānam ti etassa gahaṇam ti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  tena āha haraṇa ntiādi parassa ati atta santakataḥ parabhūtassa santakassa yaḥ vā attataḥ
translated: Because the roots express a particular meaning by the combination of the words, the meaning of “ādāna” should be seen as “grasping,”

original: añño, so puggalo paro nāma, tassa idaṃ parantipi yujjati, “parasaṃharaṇa”ntipi pāṭho,
analyzed: aññaḥ so puggalo paraḥ nāma tassa idam para ipi yujjati para saṃharaṇa ipi pāṭhaḥ
translated: therefore he says “carrying away” and so on. “Of another” : of what belongs to another, of what belongs to another as distinct from oneself, or of a person who is different from oneself, that is called “another,” and this is proper as “of another.” The reading is also “parasaṃharaṇa,”

original: saṃ-saddo cettha dhanattho,parasantakaharaṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Theno vuccati coro,
analyzed: saṃsaddaḥ ca ittha dhanattha upara santaka haraṇan ti vuttam hoti thenaḥ vuccati coro
translated: and the word “saṃ” here has the meaning of “wealth,” thus it is said “carrying away what belongs to another.” A thief is called a “thena,”

original: tassa bhāvo theyyaṃ, corakammaṃ. Corikāti corassa kiriyā. Tadatthaṃ vivarati “tatthā”tiādinā.
analyzed: tassa bhāvaḥ theyyam cora kammam corikā ati corassa kiriyā tad attham vivarati tattha ati ādinā
translated: his state is “theft,” his action is “thieving.” “Roguery” is the action of a thief. He explains its meaning by “therein” and so on.

original: Tatthāti “ādinnādāna”nti pade. Parapariggahitameva ettha adinnaṃ, na pana dantapoṇasikkhāpade
analyzed: tattha ati ādinna ādānam ti pade para pariggahitam eva ettha adinnam na pana danta poṇa sikkhāpade
translated: Herein, “what is taken by force” is the words “what is taken by force.” What is meant is that here what is not given is only what is possessed by another, not what is not accepted, as in the case of the training precept about what is not given.

original: viya appaṭiggahitakaṃ attasantakanti adhippāyo. “Yattha paro”tiādi ubhayattha sambandho
analyzed: viya appaṭiggahitakam atta santakam ti adhippāyaḥ yattha parā uti ādi ubhayattha sambandho
translated: “Where another has a claim” and so on is the construction in both cases.

original: āvuttiyādinayena. Tasmā “taṃ parapariggahitaṃ nāma, tasmiṃ parapariggahite”ti ca
analyzed: āvuttiyā ādi nayena tasmā tam para pariggahitam nāma tasmim para pariggahita iti ca
translated: So it should be construed thus: “what is possessed by another is what another has a claim to; in what is possessed by another” .🔽He does as he likes: yathākāmakārī; the state of that is yathākāmakaritā.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Yathākāmaṃ karotīti yathākāmakārī, tassa bhāvo yathākāmakaritā, taṃ.
analyzed: yojetabbam yathākāmam karoti iti yathākāma kārī tassa bhāvaḥ yathākāma karitā tam
translated: The meaning is, he commits the act of liking it thus.

original: Tathārucikaraṇaṃ āpajjantoti attho. Sasantakattā adaṇḍāraho dhanadaṇḍarājadaṇḍavasena.
analyzed: tathā ruci karaṇam āpajjanto ti attho sasantakattā a daṇḍa ārahaḥ dhana daṇḍa rāja daṇḍa vasena
translated: Because it is not his own, he is not fit to be punished with a fine or with beating.🔽And he is not fit to be reproved with a censure or to be suspended, and so on.

original: Anupavajjo ca codanāsāraṇādivasena. Taṃ parapariggahitaṃ ādiyati etenāti tadādāyako,
analyzed: anupavajjaḥ ca codanā sāraṇā ādi vasena tam para pariggahitam ādiyati etena ati tad ādāyakaḥ
translated: He takes what is possessed by another with this, thus it is that which takes what is possessed by another;🔽the mere act of taking it is that which takes what is possessed by another;

original: sveva upakkamo, taṃ samuṭṭhāpetīti tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā. Theyyā eva cetanā
analyzed: su eva upakkamaḥ tam samuṭṭhāpeti iti tad ādāyaka opakkama samuṭṭhāpikā theyyā eva cetanā
translated: the intention to steal is the intention to steal.

original: theyyacetanā. Khuddakatāappagghatādivasena hīne. Mahantatāmahagghatādivasena paṇīte.
analyzed: theyya cetanā khuddaka tā appagghata ādi vasena hīne mahanta tā mahagghata ādi vasena paṇīte
translated: In what is inferior in quality and low in price, and so on; in what is superior in quality and high in price, and so on.

original: Kasmā? Vatthuhīnatāyāti gamyamānattā na vuttaṃ, hīne, hīnaguṇānaṃ santake ca cetanā🔽dubbalā, paṇīte, paṇītaguṇānaṃ santake ca balavatīti heṭṭhā vuttanayena tehi kāraṇehi🔽appasāvajjamahāsāvajjatā veditabbā. Ācariyā pana hīnapaṇītato khuddakamahante visuṃ
analyzed: kasmā vatthu hīna tāya ati gamyamāna ttā na vuttam hīne hīna guṇānam santake ca cetanā  dubbalā paṇīte paṇīta guṇānam santake ca balavatī iti heṭṭhā vutta nayena tehi kāraṇehi  appa sāvajja mahāsāvajja tā veditabbā ācariyā pana hīna paṇītato khuddaka mahante visum
translated: Why? Because it is understood, it is not stated. And the volition is weak in a small quantity of inferior things,🔽and strong in a large quantity of superior things. So the less blameworthiness and the greater blameworthiness should be understood in this way, according to the method stated above.

original: gahetvā “idhāpi khuddake parasantake appasāvajjaṃ, mahante mahāsāvajjaṃ. Kasmā? Payogamahantatāya.
analyzed: gahetvā idha api khuddake para santake appa sāvajjam mahante mahā sāvajjam kasmā payoga mahanta tāya
translated: But teachers, taking the small and the large separately from the inferior and the superior, say this: “Herein, the less blameworthy is in a small quantity belonging to another, and the more blameworthy is in a large quantity. Why? Because of the magnitude of the act.

original: Vatthuguṇānaṃ pana samabhāve sati kilesānamupakkamānañca mudutāya appasāvajjaṃ, tibbatāya
analyzed: vatthu guṇānam pana sama bhāve sati kilesānam upakkamānam ca mudu tāya appasāvajjam tibba tāya
translated: But when the object and the qualities are equal, and the defilement is slight, it is less blameworthy, and when it is excessive, it is more blameworthy.

original: mahāsāvajjanti ayampi nayo yojetabbo”ti vadanti.🔽Sāhatthikādayoti ettha parasantakassa sahatthā gahaṇaṃ sāhatthiko. Aññe āṇāpetvā
analyzed: ayam pi nayaḥ yojetabbo ti vadanti  sāhatthika ādayaḥ ti ettha para santakassa sahatthā gahaṇam sāhatthikaḥ aññe āṇāpetvā
translated: This method should be applied here too.”

original: gahaṇaṃ āṇattiko. Antosuṅkaghāte ṭhitena bahisuṅkaghātaṃ pātetvā gahaṇaṃ nissaggiyo.
analyzed: gahaṇam āṇattikaḥ antar suṅka ghāte ṭhitena bahi suṅka ghātam pātetvā gahaṇam nissaggiyaḥ
translated: “In the case of what is possessed by another,” etc.: what is possessed by another that is taken by oneself is “by one’s own hand.” What is possessed by another that is taken by ordering another is “by ordering.” What is possessed by another that is taken by throwing in a place where it is stored is “by throwing in.”

original: “Asukaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ yadā sakkosi, tadā avaharā”ti atthasādhakāvahāranipphādakena, āṇāpanena
analyzed: asukam bhaṇḍam yadā sakkosi tadā avaharāti attha sādhaka avahāra nipphādakena āṇāpanena
translated: “When you can, then steal such and such an article,” the instigation by one who is a means of accomplishing the purpose.

original: vā, yadā kadāci parasantakavināsakena sappitelakumbhiādīsu dukūlasāṭakacammakhaṇḍādipakkhipanādinā
analyzed: vā yadā kadāci para santaka vināsakena sappi tela kumbhi ādīsu dukūla sāṭaka camma khaṇḍa ādi pakkhipana ādinā
translated: Or the taking by one who is a means of destroying another’s property, such as by a pot of ghee or oil, etc., in which a piece of cloth, a garment, a piece of leather, etc., has been concealed.

original: vā gahaṇaṃ thāvaro. Mantaparijappanena gahaṇaṃ vijjāmayo. Vinā mantena, kāyavacīpayogehi
analyzed: vā gahaṇam thāvaraḥ manta parijappanena gahaṇam vijjā mayaḥ vinā mantena kāya vacī payogehi
translated: The taking by means of a spell is the spell-born. Without a spell, by means of bodily and verbal effort,

original: tādisaiddhiyogena parasantakassa ākaḍḍhanaṃ iddhimayo. Kāyavacīpayogesu hi santesuyeva
analyzed: tādisa eddhi yogena para santakassa ākaḍḍhanam iddhi mayaḥ kāya vacī payogesu hi
translated: the taking by means of such a union of psychic power as the drawing away of another’s property is the psychic-power-born. For the effort of taking by psychic power is only when there is bodily and verbal effort,

original: iddhimayo avaharaṇapayogo hoti, no asantesu. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “anāpatti bhikkhave,
analyzed: iddhi mayaḥ avaharaṇa payogaḥ hoti no asantesu tathā hi vuttam anāpatti bhikkhave
translated: not when there is not. For this is said: “There is no offence, bhikkhus,

original: iddhimassa iddhivisaye”ti, te ca kho payogā yathānurūpaṃ pavattāti sambandho. Tesaṃ
analyzed: iddhimassa iddhivisaya iti te ca kho payogāḥ yathānurūpam pavattā ati sambandho tesam
translated: in the case of one who has psychic power, in psychic-power-born action.” And the effort of taking by psychic power occurs in the way appropriate to each case.

original: pana payogānaṃ sabbesaṃ sabbattha avahāresu asambhavato “yathānurūpa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana payogānam sabbesam sabbattha avahāresu asambhavataḥ yathā anurūpan ti vuttam
translated: But since it is impossible for all these efforts to take by psychic power to occur in all cases of taking by psychic power, “in the way appropriate to each case” is said.

original: Sandhicchedādīni katvā adissamānena vā, kūṭamānakūṭakahāpaṇādīhi vañcanena vā, avaharaṇaṃ
analyzed: sandhi cheda ādīni katvā adissamānena vā kūṭa māna kūṭaka hāpaṇa ādīhi vañcanena vā avaharaṇam
translated: The taking by means of concealing oneself after cutting a hole in a wall, etc., or by means of cheating with false weights and measures, etc., is the craft-born.

original: theyyāvahāro. Pasayha balasā abhibhuyya santajjetvā, bhayaṃ dassetvā vā avaharaṇaṃ🔽pasayhāvahāro. Parabhaṇḍaṃ paṭicchādetvā avaharaṇaṃ paṭicchannāvahāro. Bhaṇḍokāsaparikappavasena
analyzed: theyya avahāraḥ pasayha balasāḥ abhibhuyya santajjetvā bhayam dassetvā vā avaharaṇam  pasayha avahāraḥ parabhaṇḍam paṭicchādetvā avaharaṇam paṭicchanna avahāraḥ bhaṇḍa ukāsa parikappa vasena
translated: Taking by force: taking by force, by violence, by overpowering, by overpowering and terrifying, by showing a weapon, by showing a threat.🔽Taking by stealth: taking by concealing one’s own real purpose, by concealing the goods, by concealing the place of concealment.🔽Taking by stratagem: taking by stratagem, by deception, by pretending to be mad, by pretending to be dumb, by pretending to be deaf, by pretending to be blind, by pretending to be poor.

original: parikappetvā avaharaṇaṃ parikappāvahāro. Kusaṃ saṅkāmetvā avaharaṇaṃ kusāvahāro.
analyzed: parikappetvā avaharaṇam parikappa avahāro kusam saṅkāmetvā avaharaṇam kusa avahāro
translated: Taking by means of a scale or measure: taking by means of a scale, by means of a measure, by means of a balance, by means of a field measure, by means of a basket measure, by means of a handful measure, by means of a thumb measure, by means of a finger measure, by means of a grain measure, by means of a finger-breadth measure, by means of a thread measure, by means of a rope measure, by means of a string measure.

original: Iti-saddena cettha ādiatthena, nidassananayena vā avasesā cattāro pañcakāpi gahitāti
analyzed: iti saddena ca ittha ādi atthena nidassana nayena vā avasesā cattāro pañcakā api gahitā ati
translated: The word “etc.” in the text should be understood to include the remaining four sets of five, either in the sense of “etc.” or by way of illustration.

original: veditabbaṃ. Pañcannañhi pañcakānaṃ samodhānabhūtā pañcavīsati avahārā sabbepi adinnādānameva,
analyzed: veditabbam pañcannam hi pañcakānam samodhāna bhūtā pañcavīsati avahārā sabbe pi adinnādānam eva
translated: For the twenty-five kinds of taking that are included in the five sets of five are all forms of theft.

original: aviññattiyā vā ariyāya viññattiyā vā dinnamevāti attho. “Dinnādāyī”ti idaṃ payogato
analyzed: a viññattiyā vā ariyāya viññattiyā vā dinnam eva ati atthaḥ dinna ādāyi iti idam payogato
translated: The meaning is: what is given by one who is not a noble one, or by one who is a noble one, but only after being asked.

original: parisuddhabhāvadassanaṃ. “Dinnapāṭikaṅkhī”ti idaṃ pana āsayatoti āha “cittenā”tiādi.
analyzed: parisuddha bhāva dassanam dinna pāṭikaṅkhī iti idam pana āsayato ti āha cittena atiādi
translated: “One who takes what is given” is one who sees the purity of his action. “One who expects to receive what is given” is one who sees the purity of his intention.

original: Athenenāti ettha -saddo na-saddassa kāriyo, a-saddo vā eko nipāto na-saddatthoti
analyzed: ettha saddaḥ na saddassa kāriyaḥ a saddaḥ vā ekaḥ nipātaḥ na sadda attho ti
translated: “Then not”: the word “then” is a substitute for the word “not.” The negative particle “a” is a single indeclinable word with the meaning of the word “not.”

original: dassetuṃ “na thenenā”ti vuttaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ dissamānavākyāvatthikavibhattiyantapaṭirūpakatākaraṇena🔽saddhiṃ samāsadassanametaṃ. Pakaraṇādhigate pana atthe viveciyamāne idha athenatoyeva
analyzed: dassetum na thenena ati vuttam pāḷiyam  saddhim samāsa dassanam etam pakaraṇa adhigate pana atthe viveciyamāne idha
translated: “Not by that” is said to show that. This is a way of showing the compound together with the declensional ending, which is a substitute for the sentence that is seen in the text.

original: sucibhūtatā adhigamīyati adinnādānādhikārattāti āha “athenattāyeva sucibhūtenā”ti
analyzed: suci bhūta tā adhigamīyati āha atha inattāya iva suci bhūtena iti
translated: But when the meaning that is known from the text is distinguished, here only the state of being pure by means of the state of being free from debt is understood because of the predominance of the topic of not taking what is not given. Therefore he said “by means of the state of being free from debt, being pure.”

original: tena hetālaṅkāravacanametanti dasseti. Āhito ahaṃmāno etthāti attā, attabhāvo. Bhagavato
analyzed: tena hetā alaṅkāra vacanam etat ti dasseti āhitaḥ ahaṃmānaḥ ettha ati attā atta bhāvaḥ bhagavato
translated: He shows that this is a reason ornament. The self is that in which the conceit “I am” is placed, the self-state. But in the Blessed One

original: pana so ruḷhiyā yathā taṃ nicchandarāgesu sattavohāro. Adati vā saṃsāradukkhanti
analyzed: pana saḥ ruḷhiyā yathā tam nicchanda rāgesu satta vohāraḥ adati vā saṃsāra dukkhanti
translated: it is as if it were a mere convention, like the terms “desire” and “anger” in the case of the seven-constituent being. Or it is the self because it is taken across the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: attā, tenāha “attabhāvenā”ti. Padattayepi itthambhūtalakkhaṇe karaṇavacananti ñāpetuṃ
analyzed: attā tena āha atta bhāvena ati padattaye pi ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe karaṇa vacanan ti
translated: Therefore he said “by means of the self-state.” In order to make known that in the three phrases the word “by means of” is in the instrumental case, which has the characteristic of showing a state of being thus,

original: “athenaṃ…pe… katvā”ti vuttaṃ. Athenena attanā athenattā hutvā sucibhūtena attanā
analyzed: athenaṃpe katvā iti vuttam athenena attanā athenattā hutvā suci bhūtena attanā
translated: “having made it” is said. Having made it, having become the state of being free from debt by means of the self,

original: sucibhūtattā hutvā viharatītipi attho.
analyzed: hutvā viharati iti pi attho
translated: having become the state of being pure by means of the self that is pure, he abides. This is the meaning.

original: Sesanti “pahāya paṭivirato”ti evamādikaṃ. Tañhi pubbe vuttanayaṃ. Kiñcāpi nayidha🔽sikkhāpadavohārena virati vuttā, ito aññesu pana suttapadesesu, vinayābhidhammesu🔽ca pavattavohārena viratiyo, cetanā ca adhisīlasikkhānamadhiṭṭhānabhāvato, tesamaññatarakoṭṭhāsabhāvato
analyzed: sesanti pahāya paṭivirataḥ ti evamādikam tat hi pubbe vutta nayam kiñca api  sikkhāpada vohārena virati vuttā itas aññesu pana sutta padesesu vinaya abhidhammesu  ca pavatta vohārena viratiyo cetanā ca adhi sīla sikkhānam adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato tesam aññatara koṭṭhāsa bhāvato
translated: The rest are stated as “abstaining from” . They are to be understood in the way already stated.🔽Although here the abstinence is not stated by the term “ training precept,” it is nevertheless called a “ training precept” because the volition of the abstinence is the undertaking of the training in the higher virtue and because it is a part of that training.

original: ca “sikkhāpada”ntveva vattabbāti āha “paṭhamasikkhāpade”ti. Kāmañcettha “lajjī dayāpanno”ti
analyzed: ca sikkhāpadam tu eva vattabbā ti āha paṭhama sikkhāpadā iti kāmam ca ittha lajjī dayā āpannaḥ ti
translated: And the volitions of the abstinences stated in other suttas, in the Vinaya and Abhidhamma, are also called “ training precepts” in the same way.

original: na vuttaṃ, adhikāravasena, pana atthato ca vuttamevāti veditabbaṃ. Yathā hi lajjādayo
analyzed: na vuttam adhikāra vasena pana atthataḥ ca vuttam eva ati veditabbam yathā hi lajjā ādayaḥ
translated: “ In the first training precept” : although here “ conscience and shame” are not stated, they should be understood as stated by implication, since they are mentioned in the heading.

original: pāṇātipātappahānassa visesapaccayo, evaṃ adinnādānappahānassāpīti. Esa nayo ito paresupi.
analyzed: pāṇātipāta ppahānassa visesa paccayaḥ evam adinnādāna ppahānassa api iti esa nayaḥ itas paresu pi
translated: For just as conscience and shame are a special condition for the abandoning of killing living beings, so too are they for the abandoning of taking what is not given. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Atha vā sucibhūtenāti hirottappādisamannāgamanaṃ, ahirikādīnañca pahānaṃ vuttamevāti
analyzed: atha vā suci bhūtena ati hirā uttappa ādi samannāgamanam ahirika ādīnam ca pahānam vuttam eva ati
translated: Or alternatively, “with a mind of conscience and shame” is said to imply the possession of conscience, shame, etc., and the abandoning of shamelessness, etc.

original: “lajjī dayāpanno”ti na vuttaṃ.
analyzed: lajjī dayā āpannaḥ ti na vuttam
translated: Therefore “conscience and shame” are not stated here.

original: Brahma-saddo idha seṭṭhavācako, abrahmānaṃ nihīnānaṃ, abrahmaṃ vā nihīnaṃ cariyaṃ
analyzed: brahma saddo idha seṭṭha vācakaḥ abrahmānam nihīnānam abrahmam vā nihīnam cariyaṃ
translated: The word brahma here signifies the best. The practice of those who are not brahmas, i.e. of those who are inferior, is unbrahmic.

original: vutti abrahmacariyaṃ, methunadhammo. Brahmaṃ seṭṭhaṃ ācāranti methunaviratiṃ. Na
analyzed: vutti abrahmacariyam methuna dhammo brahmam seṭṭham ācāranti methuna viratim na
translated: The practice of unbrahmic conduct is sexual intercourse. They practice the best, i.e. the abstention from sexual intercourse.

translated: He does not practice it, thus he is a non-practicer . He is devoid of that practice, is the meaning. Therefore it is said: “He is a farer from unbrahmic conduct.”

original: sadisānaṃ ubhinnaṃ ayaṃ methunoti atthaṃ dasseti “rāgapariyuṭṭhānavasenā”tiādinā.
analyzed: sadisānam ubhinnam ayam methunaḥ ti attham dasseti rāga pariyuṭṭhāna vasena ati ādinā
translated: Far from the practice called sexual intercourse is he who has it by reason of his abstention, thus he is a farer from far away . Or else: he practices the abstention from sexual intercourse, having become far from sexual intercourse, thus he is a farer from far away . This is also correct. He shows the meaning of sexual intercourse as follows: “By reason of the obsession of lust for couples” .🔽The Dhamma of the bad is unrighteousness . Therefore,

analyzed: asatam dhammo ācāro ti asat dhammo tasmai abheda vohārena gāma saddena iva gāma vāsino

analyzed: gahitā iti vuttam gāma vāsīnam ti gāme vasatam yujjati dūra cārī iti ca ittha
translated: it is said: “of the villagers.” The Dhamma of those who live in the village is also correct. “Farer” here,

analyzed: brahmacariyassa khaṇḍam pi chiddam pi sabalam pi kammāsam pi ayam vuccati brāhmaṇa a parisuddham  brahmacariyam carati saṃyuttaḥ methunena saṃyogena na parimuccati jātiyāḥ jarāya maraṇena

analyzed: saḥ tam assādeti tam nikāmeti tena ca vittim āpajjati idam api kho brāhmaṇa brahmacariyassa

original: khaṇḍampi chiddampi sabalampi kammāsampi. Ayaṃ vuccati brāhmaṇa, aparisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: khaṇḍam pi chiddam pi sabalam pi kammāsam pi ayam vuccati brāhmaṇa a parisuddham brahmacariyam

analyzed: dassitā ti daṭṭhabbā idha api asat dhamma sevana adhippāyena kāya dvāra ppavattā maggena magga paṭipatti samuṭṭhāpikā  cetanā abrahmacariyam pañca sikkhāpada kkame micchācāre pana agamanīya ṭṭhāna vītikkama cetanā

analyzed: yathā vuttā kāmesu micchā ācāro ti yojetabbam  tattha agamanīya ṭhānam nāma purisānam tāva māturakkhita ādayaḥ dasa dhanakkīta ādayaḥ
