original: rukkhagacchā jātā vaḍḍhitāti. Gāmoti samūho, so ca suddhaṭṭhakadhammarāsi, bījānaṃ,
analyzed: rukkhagacchā jātā vaḍḍhitā ati gāmo ti samūho so ca suddhaṭṭhaka dhammarāsi
translated: Trees, etc., are called a village because they are born and grow there. A village is a collection, and that is a mass of things consisting of earth, etc., and it is a village of the eight kinds of beings that have acquired their various names from the seeds,

original: bhūtānañca tathāladdhasamaññānaṃ aṭṭhadhammānaṃ gāmo, teyeva vā gāmoti tathā. Avayavavinimuttassa
analyzed: bhūtānam ca tathā laddha samaññānam aṭṭha dhammānam gāmo vā gāmo ti tathā avayava vinimuttassa
translated: or the village is just those eight kinds of beings. For there is no collection apart from the components.

original: hi samudāyassa abhāvato duvidhenāpi atthena teyeva tiṇarukkhalatādayo gayhanti.
analyzed: hi samudāyassa abhāvataḥ duvidhena api atthena te yeva tiṇa rukkha latā ādayaḥ gayhanti
translated: So it is because of the two meanings that the grass, trees, creepers, etc., are called “village.”

original: Apica bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā haritabhāvamāpannā rukkhagacchādayo devatā pariggayhanti,
analyzed: apica bhūmiyam patiṭṭhahitvā harita bhāvam āpannāḥ rukkhagaccha ādayaḥ devatā pariggayhanti
translated: Moreover, the gods claim ownership of the trees, etc., that have reached the green state after being planted in the earth.

original: tasmā bhūtānaṃ nivāsanaṭṭhānatāya gāmoti bhūtagāmotipi vadanti, te sarūpato dassetuṃ🔽“mūlabīja”ntiādimāha. Mūlameva bījaṃ mūlabījaṃ. Sesesupi ayaṃ nayo. Phaḷubījanti🔽pabbabījaṃ. Paccayantarasamavāye sadisaphaluppattiyā visesakāraṇabhāvato viruhanasamatthe
analyzed: tasmā bhūtānam nivāsana ṭṭhāna tāya gāmā iti bhūta gāmā tipi vadanti te sarūpataḥ dassetum  mūla bīja nti ādim āha mūlam eva bījam mūla bījam ayam phaḷu bīja nti  pabba bījam paccaya antara samavāye sadisa phala uppattiyā visesa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ viruhana samatthe
translated: Therefore they are called “the village of beings” because they are the dwelling place of beings.🔽In order to show them in their true nature he said: “root-seed,” etc. Root-seed is just the root as seed. The same method applies in the other cases. Fruit-seed is a seed in a fruit.🔽The word “seed” is used in the sense of “cause” for the purpose of establishing the fact that it is a cause for the production of a similar fruit by the presence of a condition, and it is used in the sense of “germinating” for the purpose of establishing the fact that it is capable of germinating a fruit that possesses sap.

original: sāraphale niruḷho bīja-saddo tadatthasiddhiyā mūlādīsupi kesuci pavattatīti mūlādito
analyzed: sāra phale niruḷhaḥ bīja saddo tad attha siddhiyā mūla ādīsu pi kesuci pavattati iti mūla āditaḥ
translated: Therefore it is applied to some roots, etc., as well.

original: nivattanatthaṃ ekena bīja-saddena visesetvā “bījabīja”nti vuttaṃ yathā “rūpaṃrūpaṃ,
analyzed: nivattana attham ekena bīja saddena visesetvā bīja bījam ti vuttam yathā rūpam rūpam
translated: In order to show the difference, he said “seed of a seed” with one word “bīja” in the sense of “seed of a seed” as “form of form,”🔽

original: dukkhadukkha”nti ca. Nīlatiṇarukkhādikassāti allatiṇassa ceva allarukkhādikassa ca.
analyzed: dukkha dukkhanti ca nīla tiṇa rukkha ādikassa ati alla tiṇassa ca iva alla rukkha ādikassa ca
translated: and so it is said with the word seed in order to exclude the seed of the seed, as “material form of material form,” “painful feeling of painful feeling.” “Grass, trees, etc.,” means grass, trees, etc., that are green.

original: Ādi-saddena osadhigacchalatādayo veditabbā. Samārambho idha vikopanaṃ, tañca chedanādiyevāti
analyzed: ādi saddena osadhi gaccha latā ādayaḥ veditabbā samārambhaḥ idha vikopanam tat ca chedana ādiyā iva ati
translated: By the word “etc.,” medicinal herbs, creepers, etc., should be understood. Here “initiation” is disturbance, and that is only cutting, etc.

original: vuttaṃ “chedanabhedanapacanādibhāvenā”ti. Nanu ca rukkhādayo cittarahitatāya na jīvā,
analyzed: vuttam chedana bhedana pacana ādi bhāvena ati nanu ca rukkha ādayaḥ citta rahitatāya na jīvā
translated: Therefore it is said “by the state of cutting, breaking, burning, etc.” But do not trees, etc., live, being devoid of consciousness?

original: cittarahitatā ca paripphandanābhāvato, chinne viruhanato, visadisajātikabhāvato,
analyzed: citta rahita tā ca paripphandana abhāvataḥ chinne viruhanataḥ visadisa jātika bhāvataḥ
translated: And their being devoid of consciousness should be understood because they do not move about, because they grow again when cut, because they are of a different kind,

original: catuyoniapariyāpannato ca veditabbā. Vuḍḍhi pana pavāḷasilālavaṇādīnampi vijjatīti
analyzed: catu yoni a pariyāpannato ca veditabbā vuḍḍhi pana pavāḷa silā lavaṇa ādīnam pi vijjati iti
translated: and because they are not included in the four planes of existence. But growth is found also in coral, stone, salt, etc.,

original: na tesaṃ jīvatābhāve kāraṇaṃ. Visayaggahaṇañca nesaṃ parikappanāmattaṃ supanaṃ viya
analyzed: na tesam jīva tā bhāve kāraṇam visaya ggahaṇam ca na īsam parikappanā mattam supanam viya
translated: and so they are not a reason for the non-existence of life. And their grasping of an object is mere supposition, like the dreaming of Cincī, etc.,

original: ciñcādīnaṃ, tathā kaṭukambilāsādinā dohaḷādayo. Tattha kasmā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā
analyzed: tathā kaṭu kambila sādinā dohaḷa ādayaḥ kasmai bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambhā
translated: and like the sour gruel, etc., from the sour fruit, etc. Herein, why are the initiation of the seed-essence and the initiation of the essence of the elements

original: paṭivirati icchitāti? Samaṇasāruppato, tannissitasattānukampanato ca. Tenevāha āḷavakānaṃ
analyzed: paṭivirati icchitā ati samaṇa sāruppato tad nissita satta anukampanato ca tena iva āha āḷavakānam
translated: and the abstention from them is what is meant? — Because of the resemblance to an ascetic and because of compassion for living beings dependent on them. Hence it was said:

original: rukkhacchedanādivatthūsu “jīvasaññino hi moghapurisā manussā rukkhasmi”ntiādi.
analyzed: rukkha chedana ādi vatthūsu jīva saññinaḥ hi mogha purisāḥ manussāḥ rukkhasmin tiādi
translated: and the abstention from it is desired? Because of the semblance of asceticism and because of the compassion for living beings that is based on that. Hence it is said in the case of the Āḷavakas’ cutting down of trees, etc., “Foolish men, human beings are full of consciousness in trees” .

original: Ekaṃ bhattaṃ ekabhattaṃ, tamassa atthi ekasmiṃ divase ekavārameva bhuñjanatoti ekabhattiko.
analyzed: ekam bhattam eka bhattam tamassa atthi ekasmin divase eka vāram eva bhuñjanato ti ekabhattikaḥ
translated: One meal is ekabhattaṃ. He has that, because he eats only once a day, thus he is an ekabhattika.

original: Tayidaṃ ekabhattaṃ kadā bhuñjitabbanti sandhāya vuttaṃ “pātarāsabhatta”ntiādi, dvīsu
analyzed: tayā idam ekabhattam kadā bhuñjitabban ti sandhāya vuttam pāta rāsa bhatta ntiādi dvīsu
translated: Now, when should that one meal be eaten? With reference to this it is said, “The morning meal, etc.” The intention is that the morning meal is referred to among the two meals.

original: bhattesu pātarāsabhattaṃ sandhāyāhāti adhippāyo. Pāto asitabbanti pātarāsaṃ. Sāyaṃ
analyzed: bhattesu pātarāsa bhattam sandhāya āha ati adhippāyaḥ pāto asitabbam ti pātarāsam sāyam
translated: The morning meal is pātarāsaṃ. The evening meal is sāyamāsaṃ. That same meal is so because of the time.

original: asitabbanti sāyamāsaṃ, tadeva bhattaṃ tathā. Eka-saddo cettha majjhanhikakālaparicchedabhāvena
analyzed: asitabbam ti sāyamāsam tat eva bhattam tathā eka saddo ca ittha majjhanhika kāla pariccheda bhāvena
translated: The word eka is used here in the sense of the time of midday,

original: payutto, na tadantogadhavārabhāvenāti dasseti “tasmā”tiādinā.
analyzed: payuttaḥ na tad anta gadha vāra bhāvena ati dasseti tasmā iti ādinā
translated: not in the sense of the beginning of the period of time, as is shown by the words “Therefore, etc.”

original: Rattiyā bhojanaṃ uttarapadalopato rattisaddena vuttaṃ, taddhitavasena vā tathāyevādhippāyasambhavato,
analyzed: rattiyāḥ bhojanam uttara pada lopataḥ ratti saddena vuttam taddhita vasena vā
translated: The word ratti is used for the night meal by the elision of the last syllable, or it is so used because the meaning is possible in the sense of a compound word.

original: tenāha “rattiyā”tiādi. Aruṇuggamanato paṭṭhāya yāva majjhanhikā ayaṃ buddhādīnaṃ
analyzed: tena āha rattiyā iti ādi aruṇuggamanataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva majjhanhikā ayam buddha ādīnam
translated: Hence he said “from dawn” and so on. From the time of sunrise until midday is the time for the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples.

original: ariyānaṃ āciṇṇasamāciṇṇo bhojanassa kālo nāma, tadañño vikālo. Tattha dutiyapadena
analyzed: ariyānam āciṇṇa samāciṇṇaḥ bhojanassa kālaḥ nāma tad aññaḥ vikālo tattha dutiya padena
translated: Hence he said “at dawn” and so on. The time for eating that is the usual time for Noble Ones beginning with the Enlightened One is from dawn until midday. Any other time is the wrong time. Herein, since eating at night is prohibited by the second line,

original: rattibhojanassa paṭikkhittattā aparanhova idha vikāloti pārisesanayena tatiyapadassa
analyzed: ratti bhojanassa paṭikkhitta ttā idha vikālo ti pārisesa nayena tatiya padassa
translated: it is the wrong time that is referred to by the third line. In order to illustrate the meaning of the third line by the method of exclusion,

original: atthaṃ dīpetuṃ “atikkante majjhanhike”tiādi vuttaṃ. Bhāvasādhano cettha bhojana-saddo🔽ajjhoharaṇatthavācakoti dīpeti “yāva sūriyatthaṅgamanā bhojana”nti iminā. Kassa pana
analyzed: attham dīpetum atikkante majjhanhika itiādi vuttam bhāva sādhanaḥ ca ittha bhojana saddo  dīpeti iminā kassa pana
translated: “When midday has passed” is said. Herein, the word “eating” is a verbal noun formed from the verb “to eat” (bhuñj).🔽This is what is shown by the words “eating until sunset.” But whose eating is it?

original: tadajjhoharaṇanti? Yāmakālikādīnamanuññātattā, vikālabhojanasaddassa ca yāvakālikajjhoharaṇeyeva
analyzed: tat ajjhoharaṇam ti yāmakālikā ādīnam anuññāta ttā vikāla bhojana saddassa ca
translated: Since the time for eating what is left over from a meal and so on is allowed, and since the word “wrong time” is established as referring only to the time for eating what is left over from a meal,

original: niruḷhattā “yāvakālikassā”ti viññāyati. Ayaṃ panettha aṭṭhakathāvaseso ācariyānaṃ
analyzed: niruḷha ttā yāvakālikassa iti viññāyati ayam pana ittha aṭṭhakathā avasesaḥ ācariyānam
translated: it is understood to refer to “one who is eating what is left over from a meal.” But this is the method of the teachers as given in the commentary:

original: nayo – bhuñjitabbaṭṭhena bhojanaṃ, yāgubhattādi sabbaṃ yāvakālikavatthu. Yathā ca
analyzed: nayaḥ bhuñjitabba ṭṭhena bhojanam yāgu bhatta ādi sabbam yāvakālika vatthu yathā ca
translated: “Eating” is what should be eaten. The things that are left over from a meal are all the things that are left over from a meal, such as rice gruel, cooked rice, and so on.

original: “rattūparato”ti ettha rattibhojanaṃ rattisaddena vuccati, evamettha bhojanajjhoharaṇaṃ🔽bhojanasaddena. Vikāle bhojanaṃ vikālabhojanaṃ, tato vikālabhojanā. Vikāle yāvakālikavatthussa
analyzed: ettha ratti bhojanam ratti saddena vuccati evam ettha bhojana ajjhoharaṇam  bhojana saddena vikāle bhojanam vikāla bhojanam tatas vikāla bhojanā vikāle yāvakālika vatthussa
translated: “Having eaten at the wrong time”: here, the food eaten at night is called “at night”; thus, here, the eating of food is called “at night” by the word “at night.” Eating at the wrong time is eating at the wrong time of day. From that, “having eaten at the wrong time.” At the wrong time, the object of the alms-food is called “at the wrong time.”🔽

original: ajjhoharaṇāti atthoti. Īdisā guṇavibhūti na buddhakāleyevāti āha “anomānadītīre”tiādi.🔽Ayaṃ pana pāḷiyaṃ anusandhikkamo – ekasmiṃ divase ekavārameva bhuñjanato “ekabhattiko”ti🔽vutte rattibhojanopi siyāti tannivāraṇatthaṃ “rattūparato”ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ sati sāyanhabhojīpi
analyzed: ajjhoharaṇā ti īdisā na āha anomā nadī tīra itiādi  ayam pana pāḷiyam anusandhi kkamaḥ ekasmin divase eka vāram eva bhuñjanataḥ ekabhattikaḥ iti  vutte rattibhojanaḥ api siyāti tad nivāraṇa attham vuttam evam sati sāyanhabhojī api
translated: “One who has gone to the far shore of the night”: here the night’s meal is called “the night” . Thus the taking of food is called “food” . Eating at the wrong time is “eating at the wrong time” . “One who has gone to the far shore of eating at the wrong time” is one who has gone to the far shore of eating at the wrong time. Eating at the wrong time is the taking of food at the wrong time. The meaning is: “one who does not do this.” Such a one does not have this kind of glory of qualities only in the Buddha era. Therefore the Exalted One said, “On the banks of the Anomā River,” and so on.

original: ekabhattiko siyāti tadāsaṅkānivattanatthaṃ “virato vikālabhojanā”ti vuttanti.
analyzed: eka bhattiko siyāti tad āsaṅkā nivattana attham virataḥ vikāla bhojanā ti vuttam ti
translated: But the sequence of the text is as follows: When it is said that he is “one who eats in one part of the day,” it is possible that he might eat at night. Therefore, in order to exclude that, it is said that he is “one who has gone to the far shore of the night.” But if that is so, then it is possible that he might eat in the evening. Therefore, in order to exclude that, it is said that he is “one who has gone to the far shore of eating at the wrong time.”

original: Saṅkhepato “sabbapāpassa akaraṇa”ntiādi nayappavattaṃ bhagavato sāsanaṃ sachandarāgappavattito
analyzed: saṅkhepato sabba pāpassa akaraṇa nti ādi naya pavattam bhagavataḥ sāsanam sa chanda rāga ppavattito
translated: In brief, the Dispensation of the Exalted One, which occurs in the way beginning, “Abandoning of all evil, ” is the opposite of the occurrence of lust and passion.

original: naccādīnaṃ dassanaṃ nānulometīti āha “sāsanassa ananulomattā”ti. Visucati sāsanaṃ
analyzed: nacca ādīnam dassanam na anulomā iti iti āha sāsanassa an anuloma ttā iti visucati sāsanam
translated: The seeing of dancing, etc., is not in conformity with the Dispensation, thus he says, “because it is not in conformity with the Dispensation.”🔽The Dispensation is purified

original: vijjhati ananulomikabhāvenāti visūkaṃ, paṭiviruddhanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tatra upamaṃ
analyzed: vijjhati ananulomika bhāvena ati visūkam paṭiviruddhanti vuttam hoti tatra upamam
translated: by the non-conformity of the unseemly. It is “unseemly” in the sense of being contrary, in the sense of being opposed. There he shows the simile

original: dasseti “paṭāṇībhūta”nti iminā, paṭāṇīsaṅkhātaṃ kīlaṃ viya bhūtanti attho. “Visūka”nti
analyzed: dasseti paṭāṇī bhūtanti iminā paṭāṇī saṅkhātam kīlam viya bhūtanti atthaḥ visūkam ti
translated: with the words “unseemly.” The meaning is: it is “unseemly” like a peg that is “unseemly.”🔽They also say that the meaning of “unseemly” is the meaning of “unseemliness.”

original: etassa paṭāṇībhūtanti atthamāhātipi vadanti. Attanā payojiyamānaṃ, parehi payojāpiyamānañca🔽naccaṃ naccabhāvasāmaññato pāḷiyaṃ ekeneva naccasaddena sāmaññaniddesanayena gahitaṃ,
analyzed: vadanti attanā payojiyamānam parehi  naccam nacca bhāva sāmaññato ekena iva nacca saddena sāmañña niddesa nayena gahitam
translated: Dancing is performed by oneself and by others.🔽It is included in the text with the single word “dancing” in the sense of a general statement because of the similarity of dancing to dancing.

original: ekasesanayena vā. Tathā gītavāditasaddehi gāyanagāyāpanavādanavādāpanānīti āha “naccananaccāpanādivasenā”ti.
analyzed: vā tathā gīta vādita saddehi gāyana gāyāpana vādana vādāpanāni iti āha nacca na naccāpana ādi vasena ati
translated: Or it is in the sense of a particular.🔽Likewise, singing, playing music, and seeing an unseemly sight are included in the text with the single words “singing,” “playing music,” and “unseemly sight” in the sense of a general statement.🔽Or they are in the sense of a particular.

original: Suddhahetutājotanavasena hi dvādhippāyikā ete saddā. Naccañca gītañca vāditañca visūkadassanañca
analyzed: suddha hetu tā jotana vasena hi dvi adhippāyikāḥ ete saddāḥ naccañca gītañca vāditañca visūka dassanañca
translated: For these words are intended to show the cause and the reason.

original: naccagītavāditavisūkadassanaṃ, samāhāravasenettha ekattaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana yathāpāṭhaṃ
analyzed: nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanam samāhāra vasena ittha ekattam aṭṭhakathāyam pana yathāpāṭham
translated: and seeing dancing, singing, instrumental music, and shows, are one in the sense of being a collection. But in the commentary the words “dancing and” are given in order to show the co-ordination compound,

original: vākyāvatthikantavacanena saha samuccayasamāsadassanatthaṃ “naccā cā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vākya avatthika anta vacanena saha samuccaya samāsa dassana attham naccā ca atiādi vuttam
translated: in accordance with the reading of the text.

original: Evaṃ sabbattha īdisesu. (Dassanavisaye mayūranaccādipaṭikkhipanena naccāpanavisayepi🔽paṭikkhipanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ) “naccādīni hī”tiādinā yathāvuttatthasamatthanaṃ. Dassanena🔽cettha savanampi saṅgahitaṃ virūpekasesanayena, yathāsakaṃ vā visayassa ālocanasabhāvatāya
analyzed: evam sabbattha īdisesu dassana visaye mayūra nacca ādi paṭikkhipanena nacca āpana visaye pi  paṭikkhipanam daṭṭhabbam nacca ādīni hi itiādinā yathā vutta ttha samatthanam dassanena  ca ittha savanam pi saṅgahitam virūpa eka sesa nayena yathāsakam vā visayassa ālocana sabhāva tāya
translated: So in all cases. And the prohibition of seeing the dancing of peacocks, etc., should be understood as the prohibition of seeing the dancing of men and women, etc.,

original: pañcannaṃ viññāṇānaṃ savanakiriyāyapi dassanasaṅkhepasambhavato “dassanā” icceva
analyzed: pañcannam viññāṇānam dassana saṅkhepa sambhavataḥ dassanāḥ icca eva
translated: with the words “Dancing, etc., are low” and so on. And here seeing includes hearing, by the method of the general and the particular, or else because the function of the five consciousnesses is the mere beholding of their respective objects.

original: vuttaṃ. Tenevāha “pañcahi viññāṇehi na kiñci dhammaṃ paṭijānāti aññatra atinipātamattā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam tena iva āha pañcahi viññāṇehi na kiñci dhammam paṭijānāti aññatra atinipāta mattā ati
translated: Therefore it is said, “He does not acknowledge any state as a state by means of the five consciousnesses, except for the mere occurrence of them” .

original: “Visūkabhūtā dassanā cā”ti etena avisūkabhūtassa pana gītassa savanaṃ kadāci vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: visūka bhūtā dassanā ca ati etena a visūka bhūtassa pana gītassa savanam kadāci vaṭṭati iti
translated: And by the words “Seeing, which is a show” it is shown that sometimes hearing of singing which is not a show is allowable for one who is not a showman.

original: dasseti. Tathā hi vuttaṃ paramatthajotikāya khuddakapāṭhaṭṭhakathāya “dhammūpasaṃhitampi🔽cettha gītaṃ na vaṭṭati, gītūpasaṃhito pana dhammo vaṭṭatī”ti katthaci pana na-kāravipariyāyena
analyzed: dasseti tathā hi vuttam paramatthajotikāya khuddakapāṭha aṭṭhakathāya dhamma upasaṃhitam pi  ca ittha gītam na vaṭṭati gītu upasaṃhito pana dhammo vaṭṭati iti katthaci pana nakāra vipariyāyena
translated: For it is said in the Khuddakapāṭha commentary, which is a light on the ultimate meaning, “Herein, singing that is mixed with secular matters is not allowed, but the Dhamma mixed with singing is allowed.” But in some places the negative is used in the opposite sense.

original: pāṭho dissati. Ubhayatthāpi ca gīto ce dhammānulomatthapaṭisaṃyuttopi na vaṭṭati,🔽dhammo ce gītasaddapaṭisaṃyuttopi vaṭṭatīti adhippāyo veditabbo. “Na bhikkhave, gītassarena
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ dissati ubhayattha api ca gītaḥ ce dhamma anuloma attha paṭisaṃyuttaḥ api na vaṭṭati  dhammaḥ ce gīta sadda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ api vaṭṭati iti adhippāyaḥ veditabbaḥ na bhikkhave gīta ssarena
translated: For it is said in the Khuddaka- pāṭha commentary, which is called the Paramatthajotikā, “Singing that is associated with the True Idea is not allowed, but the True Idea associated with singing is allowed.” But in some places the reading is found with the negative particle na, and in both cases the intention must be understood thus: if it is singing, it is not allowed even if it is associated with the True Idea in meaning,

original: dhammo gāyitabbo, yo gāyeyya, āpatti dukkaṭassā”ti hi desanāya eva paṭikkhepo, na🔽savanāya. Imassa ca sikkhāpadassa visuṃ paññāpanato viññāyati “gītassarena desitopi
analyzed: dhammaḥ gāyitabbaḥ yaḥ gāyeyya āpatti dukkaṭassa ati hi desanāya eva paṭikkhepaḥ na  savanāya imassa ca sikkhāpadassa visum paññāpanataḥ viññāyati gītassarena desitaḥ api
translated: but if it is the True Idea, it is allowed even if it is associated with the sound of singing. “ Bhikkhus, the True Idea should not be sung in a tune. Whoever should sing it in a tune, there is an offence of wrong-doing” . This is a prohibition of teaching, not of listening,

original: dhammo na gīto”ti. Yañca sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ sevitabbāsevitabbasaddaṃ niddharantena
analyzed: dhammaḥ na gītaḥ ti yat ca sakka pañha sutta vaṇṇanāyam sevitabba a sevitabba saddam niddharantena

And in the commentary to the Sakkapañhasutta, which is called the Sakkapañhasuttamātikā, it is said:🔽“The word sevitabba is to be analysed as follows: sevitabba = sevitabbattha sevitabbattha = sevitabbam ettha sevitabbam ettha = sevitabbam ettha

original: “yaṃ pana atthanissitaṃ dhammanissitaṃ kumbhadāsigītampi suṇantassa pasādo vā uppajjati,
analyzed: yam pana attha nissitam dhamma nissitam kumbha dāsi gītam pi suṇantassa pasādaḥ vā uppajjati
translated: “But if, while listening to a song that is meaningful and concerned with the Dhamma,🔽

analyzed: nibbidā vā saṇṭhāti evarūpaḥ saddo sevitabbo ti vuttam tam a samādāna sikkhāpadassa  sevitabba tā matta pariyāyena vuttam samādāna sikkhāpadassa hi evarūpam suṇantassa sikkhāpada saṃvaram
translated: “But when one hears a song sung by a pot-maker’s daughter, for instance, and one has confidence in it or one’s dispassion becomes established, then such a sound should be cultivated.” This is said in the sense of the mere cultivation of what is allowable in the case of the training precept about what is not to be committed.🔽For when one hears such a song, the restraint of the training precepts is broken in one who has undertaken them. It should be understood that this is because of the sound of the song.

original: bhijjati gītasaddabhāvatoti veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi vinayaṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ “gītanti
analyzed: bhijjati gīta sadda bhāvataḥ ti veditabbam tathā hi vinaya aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam gītan ti
translated: For this is said in the commentaries: “Song is

original: naṭādīnaṃ vā gītaṃ hotu, ariyānaṃ parinibbānakāle ratanattayaguṇūpasaṃhitaṃ sādhukīḷanagītaṃ🔽vā, asaṃyatabhikkhūnaṃ dhammabhāṇakagītaṃ vā, antamaso dantagītampi, yaṃ “gāyissāmā”ti
analyzed: naṭa ādīnam vā gītam hotu ariyānam parinibbāna kāle rata nattaya guṇa upasaṃhitam sādhu kīḷana gītam  vā asaṃyata bhikkhūnam dhamma bhāṇaka gītam vā antamasaḥ danta gītam pi yam gāyissāma ati
translated: the song of actors, and so on, or it is a good song that is connected with the special qualities of the Three Jewels at the time of the noble ones’ final extinction,

original: pubbabhāge okūjitaṃ karonti, sabbametaṃ gītaṃ nāmā”ti.
analyzed: pubba bhāge okūjitam karonti sabbam etam gītam nāma ati
translated: or it is the song of a bhikkhu who is not restrained, or a preacher of the Dhamma, or even a layman’s song. Any song that is sung in the first instance by making a preliminary humming sound with the words ‘We shall sing’—all this is called ‘song.’”

original: Kiñcāpi mālā-saddo loke baddhapupphavācako, sāsane pana ruḷhiyā abaddhapupphesupi
analyzed: kiñcā api mālā saddaḥ loke baddha puppha vācakaḥ sāsane pana abaddha pupphesu pi
translated: And although the word “garland” in the world is a term for a bound flower, in the Dispensation it is a term for unbound flowers too,

original: vaṭṭati, tasmā yaṃ kiñci pupphaṃ baddhamabaddhaṃ vā, taṃ sabbaṃ “mālā” tveva daṭṭhabbanti
analyzed: vaṭṭati tasmai yam kiñci puppham baddham a baddham vā tam sabbam mālā tu eva daṭṭhabbanti
translated: Any kind of flower, whether made up into a garland or not, is to be regarded as a “garland.”

original: āha “yaṃ kiñci puppha”nti. “Yaṃ kiñci gandha”nti cettha vāsacuṇṇadhūpādikaṃ vilepanato
analyzed: āha yam kiñci pupphanti yam kiñci gandhanti ca ittha vāsa cuṇṇa dhūpa ādikam vilepanato
translated: “Any kind of scent” is any kind of scent other than unguent, such as scented powder, incense, etc.

original: aññaṃ yaṃ kiñci gandhajātaṃ. Vuttatthaṃ viya hi vuccamānatthamantarenāpi saddo atthavisesavācako.
analyzed: aññam yam kiñci gandha jātam vuttattham viya hi vuccamāna ttham antarena api saddo attha visesa vācakaḥ
translated: For a word that expresses a particular meaning can also express another meaning, even though it is not its usual meaning.

original: Chavirāgakaraṇanti vilepanena chaviyā rañjanatthaṃ pisitvā paṭiyattaṃ yaṃ kiñci gandhacuṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: chavi rāga karaṇam ti vilepanena chaviyāḥ rañjana attham pisitvā paṭiyattam yam kiñci gandha cuṇṇam
translated: “Any kind of unguent” is any kind of scented powder prepared by grinding up scented substances such as sandalwood, etc., for the purpose of anointing the skin with it.🔽“Adornment” is the wearing of it. “Decoration” is the filling in of deficient parts.

original: Piḷandhanaṃ dhāraṇaṃ. Ūnaṭṭhānapūraṇaṃ maṇḍanaṃ. Gandhavasena, chavirāgavasena ca
analyzed: piḷandhanam dhāraṇam ūna ṭṭhāna pūraṇam maṇḍanam gandha vasena chavi rāga vasena ca
translated: “Ornamentation” is the acceptance of it by way of scent and by way of the colouring of the skin.

original: sādiyanaṃ vibhūsanaṃ. Tadevatthaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānena dīpeti “tattha piḷandhanto”tiādinā.
analyzed: vibhūsanam tadevattham puggala adhiṭṭhānena dīpeti tattha piḷandhanto tiādinā
translated: He illustrates the meaning of that by way of the person, saying “Herein, one who anoints himself.”

original: Tathā ceva majjhimaṭṭhakathāyampi vuttaṃ, paramatthajotikāyaṃ pana khuddakapāṭhaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: tathā ca iva majjhima ṭṭhakathāyam pi vuttam paramatthajotikāyam pana khuddakapāṭha ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: And so it is said in the Majjhima Commentary. But in the Khuddaka- pāṭha Commentary, which is a commentary on the ultimate meaning, it is said:

original: “mālādīsu dhāraṇādīni yathāsaṅkhyaṃ yojetabbānī”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ. Tatthāpi yojentena🔽yathāvuttanayeneva yojetabbāni. Kiṃ panetaṃ kāraṇanti āha “yāyā”tiādi. Yāya dussīlyacetanāya
analyzed: mālā ādīsu dhāraṇā ādīni yathāsaṅkhyam yojetabbāni iti ettakam eva vuttam tattha api  yathā vutta nayena iva yojetabbāni kim pana itam kāraṇan ti āha yāya atiādi yāya dussīlya cetanāya
translated: “Bearing, etc., should be construed with garlands, etc., respectively.” Only this much is said. And here too, when construing,🔽they should be construed in the way already stated. But why is this? “The reason is that” is the question.

original: karoti, sā idha kāraṇaṃ. “Tato paṭivirato”ti hi ubhayattha sambandhitabbaṃ, eteneva🔽“mālā…pe… vibhūsanānaṃ ṭhānaṃ, mālā…pe… vibhūsanāneva vā ṭhāna”nti samāsampi dasseti.
analyzed: karoti sā idha kāraṇam tatas paṭivirataḥ ti hi ubhayattha sambandhitabbam etena iva  mālāpe vibhūsanānam ṭhānam mālāpe vibhūsanānā iva vā ṭhānan ti samāsam pi dasseti
translated: The volition of unvirtuousness by means of which one does is the reason here. For “he refrains from that” should be construed in both cases. And by this he shows also the compound

original: Tadākārappavatto cetanādidhammoyeva hi dhāraṇādikiriyā. Tattha ca cetanāsampayuttadhammānaṃ🔽kāraṇaṃ sahajātādopakārakato, padhānato ca. “Cetayitvā kammaṃ karoti kāyena vācāya
analyzed: tad ākāra ppavatto cetanā ādi dhammo yā iva hi dhāraṇā ādi kiriyā tattha ca cetanā sampayutta dhammānam  kāraṇam padhānataḥ ca cetayitvā kammam karoti kāyena vācāya
translated: “garlands, etc., are the ground for wearing, etc., or for garlands, etc., only.” For the state of being a mere action of bearing, etc., is only a state of dhammas such as volition occurring in that mode. And here the reason for the dhammas associated with volition is

original: manasā”ti hi vuttaṃ. Dhāraṇādibhūtā eva ca cetanā ṭhānanti. Ṭhāna-saddo paccekaṃ
analyzed: manasā iti hi vuttam dhāraṇā ādi bhūtā eva ca cetanā ṭhānam ti ṭhāna saddo paccekam
translated: that they assist it by being conascent and so on and by being predominant. For it is said, “After willing, one does an action by body, speech, or mind” . And it is volition itself that is the ground for bearing, etc. The word “ground” should be construed

original: yojetabbo dvandapadato suyyamānattā.
analyzed: yojetabbaḥ dvanda padataḥ
translated: separately with each member of the compound, because it is a dvanda compound.

original: Uccāti uccasaddena akārantena samānatthaṃ ākārantaṃ ekaṃ saddantaraṃ accuggatavācakanti🔽āha “pamāṇātikkanta”nti. Seti etthāti sayanaṃ, mañcādi. Samaṇasārupparahitattā, gahaṭṭhehi
analyzed: ucca ati ucca saddena akāra antena samāna attham ākāra antam ekam saddantaram  āha pamāṇa atikkantanti sā iti ettha ati sayanam mañca ādi samaṇa sāruppa rahita ttā gahaṭṭhehi
translated: High: the word “high” is a synonym for the word “high-wide” which ends in -a, and it is a single sound. It is a word denoting what is lofty.🔽Therefore it is said, “beyond the right measure.” A bed is a couch, etc., because it is without the monk’s requisites, and

original: ca seṭṭhasammatattā akappiyapaccattharaṇaṃ “mahāsayana”nti idhādhippetanti dassetuṃ
analyzed: ca seṭṭha sammata ttā akappiya paccattharaṇam mahā sayananti idha adhippetanti dassetuṃ
translated: because it is considered the best by householders. The “high bed” referred to here is a bed with an unsuitable spread.

original: “akappiyattharaṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Nisīdanaṃ panettha sayaneneva saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: akappiya tharaṇam ti vuttam nisīdanam pana ittha sayanena iva saṅgahitan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: In order to show this, it is said, “with an unsuitable spread.” But the sitting mat should be understood to be included here with the bed.

original: Yasmā pana ādhāre paṭikkhitte tadādhārakiriyāpi paṭikkhittāva hoti, tasmā “uccāsayanamahāsayanā”
analyzed: yasmai pana ādhāre paṭikkhitte tad ādhāra kiriyā api paṭikkhittā ava hoti tasmai uccāsayana mahāsayanā
translated: But since the support is prohibited, the action of using it as a support is also prohibited. Therefore,

original: icceva vuttaṃ. Atthato pana tadupabhogabhūtanisajjānipajjanehi virati dassitāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: iccā iva vuttam atthataḥ pana tad upabhoga bhūta nisajjā nipajjanehi virati dassitā iti veditabbam
translated: only “high and luxurious beds” is said. But in the sense it should be understood that the avoidance of lying down and sitting on them is shown.

analyzed: atha vā uccāsayana mahāsayanā ti esa niddeso ekasesa nayena yathā nāma rūpa paccayā
translated: Or else, this is the demonstration: “high and luxurious beds” by the method of the remainder, just as “with name-and-form as condition,

analyzed: etasmim pi vikappe āsana pubbaka ttā sayana kiriyāya sayana ggahaṇena iva  āsanam pi gahitanti veditabbam kiriyā vācaka āsana sayana sadda lopataḥ uttara pada lopa niddeso ti pi
translated: In this exposition too, since the sitting is prior to the lying, the sitting should be understood to be included by the word “lying” because of the action.

original: vinayaṭīkāyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vinayaṭīkāyam vuttam
translated: And in the Vinaya Commentary it is said that the word “lying” is used for the sitting because of the elision of the word for the action and because of the elision of the second member of the compound.

original: Jātameva rūpamassa na vippakāranti jātarūpaṃ, satthuvaṇṇaṃ. Rañjīyati setavaṇṇatāya,
analyzed: jātam eva rūpam assa na vippakāranti jātarūpam satthu vaṇṇam rañjīyati seta vaṇṇa tāya
translated: “Jātarūpa” is gold, which is the colour of the Teacher’s body. It is “rañjana” because it delights the mind by its whiteness,🔽or because it delights beings here, like “nesaṃ padakkanta” .

original: rañjanti vā ettha sattāti rajataṃ yathā “nesaṃ padakkanta”nti. “Cattāro vīhayo guñjā,
analyzed: rañjanti vai ettha rajatam yathā cattāraḥ vīhayaḥ guñjā
translated: A “nīlakahāpaṇa” is twenty “māsa” coins, which are defined thus: “Four ‘vīhas’ are a ‘guñja’;

original: dve guñjā māsako bhave”ti vuttalakkhaṇena vīsatimāsako nīlakahāpaṇo vā dudradāmakādiko
analyzed: dve guñjāḥ māsakaḥ bhaveti vutta lakkhaṇena vīsati māsakaḥ nīla kahāpaṇaḥ vā dudra dāmaka ādikaḥ
translated: two ‘guñjas’ are a ‘māsa’” . Or it is a “kahāpaṇa” made according to the current practice in a particular country.

original: vā taṃtaṃdesavohārānurūpaṃ kato kahāpaṇo. Lohādīhi kato lohamāsakādiko. Ye vohāraṃ
analyzed: vā taṃ taṃ desa vohāra anurūpam kataḥ kahāpaṇaḥ loha ādīhi kataḥ loha māsaka ādikaḥ ye vohāram
translated: “Lohamāsa” , etc., are made of copper, etc. “Which are current” : this is said in order to exclude what is not current.

original: gacchantīti pariyādānavacanaṃ. Vohāranti ca kayavikkayavasena sabbohāraṃ. Aññehi
analyzed: gacchanti iti pariyādāna vacanam ca kaya vikkaya vasena sa bohāram aññehi
translated: “Current” is all kinds of currency by way of barter, etc.

original: gāhāpane, upanikkhittasādiyane ca paṭiggahaṇattho labbhatīti āha “na uggaṇhāpeti
analyzed: gāhāpane upanikkhitta sādiyane ca paṭiggahaṇa atthaḥ labbhati iti āha na uggaṇhāpa iti
translated: The meaning of “receiving” is applicable to taking from others and to consenting to what is deposited. Therefore it is said, “does not cause to be received” .

original: na upanikkhittaṃ sādiyatī”ti. Atha vā tividhaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ kāyena vācāya manasā.
analyzed: na upanikkhittam sādiyati iti atha vā tividham paṭiggahaṇam kāyena vācāya manasā
translated: Or alternatively, there are three kinds of acceptance: by body, by speech, and by mind.

original: Tattha kāyena paṭiggahaṇaṃ uggahaṇaṃ. Vācāya paṭiggahaṇaṃ uggahāpanaṃ. Manasā paṭiggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha kāyena paṭiggahaṇam uggahaṇam vācāya paṭiggahaṇam uggahāpanam manasā paṭiggahaṇam
translated: Herein, acceptance by body is taking up; acceptance by speech is taking up and making it one’s own; acceptance by mind is consenting to what is taken up and made one’s own.

original: sādiyanaṃ. Tividhampetaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesanayena vā gahetvā
analyzed: tividham petam paṭiggahaṇam sāmañña niddesena eka sesa nayena vā gahetvā
translated: And this threefold acceptance should be taken as stated in the Paṭisambhidā by the method of the general statement and the particular instance.

original: paṭiggahaṇāti vuttanti āha “neva naṃ uggaṇhātī”tiādi. Esa nayo āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇātiādīsupi.
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇā iti vuttanti āha na iva nam uggaṇhāti itiādi esa nayaḥ āmaka dhañña paṭiggahaṇa ati ādīsu pi
translated: So it is said: “He does not take it up” and so on. The same method applies in the case of “acceptance of raw grain” and so on.

original: Nīvārādiupadhaññassa sāliyādimūladhaññantogadhattā “sattavidhassāpī”ti vuttaṃ. Saṭṭhidinaparipāko sukadhaññaviseso sāli nāma salīyate sīlāghateti katvā. Dabbaguṇapakāse pana –
analyzed: nīvāra ādi upadhaññassa sattavidhassa api iti vuttam saṭṭhi dina paripāko suka dhañña viseso sāli nāma katvā dabba guṇa pakāse pana
translated: The word sāli is derived from the verbal root sal , to be firm , because it is firm in the granary. But in the Dabba Sutta it is said:

original: “Atha dhaññaṃ tidhā sāli-saṭṭhikavīhibhedato;🔽Sālayo hemantā tatra, saṭṭhikā gimhajā api;
analyzed: atha dhaññam tidhā sāli saṭṭhika vīhi bhedato  sa ālayaḥ tatra saṭṭhikāḥ gimha jāḥ api
translated: “Then grain is threefold: as rice, barley, and wheat.🔽Rice is of the winter season there, barley is of the summer season too,

original: Vīhayo tvāsaḷhākhyātā, vassakālasamubbha vā”ti. –
analyzed: vīhayaḥ vāti
translated: But wheat is called the sixth, or it arises in the rainy season.”

original: Vuttaṃ. Vahati, brūheti vā sattānaṃ jīvitanti vīhi, sassaṃ. Yuvitabbo missitabboti🔽yavo. So hi atilūkhatāya aññena missetvā paribhuñjīyati. Gudhati parivedhati palibuddhatīti
analyzed: vuttam vahati brūha iti vā sattānam jīvitanti vīhi sassam yuvitabbaḥ missitabbaḥ iti  yavo so hi ati lūkha tāya aññena missetvā paribhuñjīyati gudhati parivedhati palibuddhati iti
translated: ‘Vīhi’ is grain. It ‘carries’ or ‘brings’ beings to life. ‘Yava’ is barley. It should be ‘yowed’ or mixed with other grain.

original: godhūmo, yaṃ “milakkhabhojana”ntipi vadanti. Sobhanattā kamanīyabhāvaṃ gacchatīti🔽kaṅgu, atisukhumadhaññaviseso. Varīyati atilūkhatāya nivārīyati, khuddāpaṭivinayanato
analyzed: godhūmaḥ yam vadanti sobhanattā kamanīya bhāvam gacchati iti  kaṅgu ati sukhuma dhañña visesaḥ varīyati ati lūkha tāya nivārīyati khuddā paṭivinayanato
translated: ‘Godhūma’ is wheat. It ‘guards’ or ‘covers’ or ‘obstructs’ the belly. It is also called ‘foreign food’.🔽‘Kaṅgu’ is a kind of grain that is very fine and is much sought after because of its excellence. ‘Varaka’ is a kind of grain that is very small and is ‘warded off’ or rejected because of its smallness, or it is ‘warded off’ because it is rejected by the small people.

original: vā bhajīyatīti varako. Koraṃ rudhiraṃ dūsatīti kudrūsako, vaṇṇasaṅkamanena yo “govaḍḍhano”tipi
analyzed: vā bhajīyati iti varakaḥ koram rudhiram dūsati iti kudrūsakaḥ vaṇṇa saṅkamanena yaḥ go vaḍḍha na utipi
translated: ‘Kudrūsaka’ is a kind of grain that ‘stains’ or ‘defiles’ the blood. It is also called ‘cow-fattener’.

original: vuccati. Tāni sattapi sappabhedā nidhāne posane sādhuttena “dhaññānī”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: vuccati tāni satta pi sa pabhedā nidhāne posane sādhu ttena dhaññāni iti vuccanti
translated: These seven kinds of grain, together with their varieties, are called ‘grains’ because they are good for storing and nourishing.

original: “Na kevalañcā”tiādinā sampaṭicchanaṃ, parāmasanañca idha paṭiggahaṇasaddena vuttanti
analyzed: na kevalam ca ati ādinā sampaṭicchanam parāmasanañca idha paṭiggahaṇa saddena vuttan ti
translated: ‘And not only these’—he shows that the consenting to and the handling of the food are called ‘accepting’ here.

original: dasseti. Evamīdisesu. “Anujānāmi bhikkhave, vasāni bhesajjāni acchavasaṃ macchavasaṃ
analyzed: dassa iti evamīdisesu anujānāmi bhikkhave vasāni bhesajjāni acchavasam macchavasam
translated: ‘I allow you, monks, to use the following medicines: clarified butter, fresh butter,

original: susukāvasaṃ sūkaravasaṃ gadrabhavasa”nti vuttattā idaṃ pañcavidhampi bhesajjaṃ odissa
analyzed: susukā vasam sūkara vasam gadrabha vasanti vutta ttā idam pañcavidham pi bhesajjam odissa
translated: This fivefold medicine is called “permitted with reference to.”🔽But since it is said, “taken at the proper time,” the taking of it is allowed.

original: anuññātaṃ nāma. Tassa pana “kāle paṭiggahita”nti vuttattā paṭiggahaṇaṃ vaṭṭatīti🔽āha “aññatra odissa anuññātā”ti. Maṃsa-saddena macchānampi maṃsaṃ gahitaṃ evāti dassetuṃ🔽“āmakamaṃsamacchāna”nti vuttaṃ, tikoṭiparisuddhaṃ macchamaṃsaṃ anuññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: anuññātam nāma tassa pana kāle paṭiggahitanti vutta ttā paṭiggahaṇam vaṭṭati iti  āha aññatra odissa anuññātā iti maṃsa saddena macchānam pi maṃsam gahitam evā iti dassetuṃ  āmaka maṃsa macchānan ti vuttam ti koṭi parisuddham maccha maṃsam anuññātam a diṭṭham
translated: Therefore it is said, “Except when permitted with reference to.”🔽The word “flesh” includes fish as well. To show this,🔽it is said, “fresh fish and flesh.” Fish and flesh are permitted if they are pure in three respects: if they are not seen, heard, or suspected

original: asutaṃ, aparisaṅkitanti vā payogassa dassanato virūpekasesanayo dassito anenāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a sutam a parisaṅkitam ti vā payogassa dassanataḥ virūpa ika sesa nayaḥ dassitaḥ anena ati veditabbam
translated: to have been killed for one’s own sake. By showing the use of the word “flesh,” the method of the remainder after exclusion is shown.

original: Kāmaṃ lokiyā –
analyzed: kāmam lokiyā
translated: Although it is worldly,

original: “Aṭṭhavassā bhave gorī, dasavassā tu kaññakā;
analyzed: aṭṭha vassā bhave gorī dasa vassā tu kaññakā
translated: “A heifer is eight years old, a maiden is ten years old;

original: Sampatte dvādasavasse, kumārītibhidhīyate”ti. –
analyzed: sampatte dvādasa vasse kumārī iti abhidhīyate iti
translated: When she reaches twelve years, she is called a young woman.”

original: Vadanti. Idha pana purisantaragatāgatavasena itthikumārikābhedoti āha “itthīti purisantaragatā”tiādi.
analyzed: vadanti idha pana purisa antara gata āgata vasena itthi kumārikā bhedaḥ ti āha itthī iti purisa antara gata atiādi
translated: They say. But here the distinction is made according to whether or not she has had intercourse with a man. Therefore it is said, “A woman is one who has had intercourse with a man,” and so on.

original: Dāsidāsavasenevāti dāsidāsavohāravaseneva. Evaṃ vutteti tādisena kappiyavacanena
analyzed: dāsi dāsa vasena iva ati dāsi dāsa vohāra vasena iva evam vuttā iti tādisena kappiya vacanena
translated: As if they were male and female slaves: as if they were male and female slaves.🔽When this was said: when this was said by the Blessed One with such a proper expression.

original: vutte. Vinayaṭṭhakathāsu āgatavinicchayaṃ sandhāya “vinayavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. So kuṭikārasikkhāpadavaṇṇanādīsu gahetabbo.🔽Bījaṃ khipanti ettha, khittaṃ vā bījaṃ tāyatīti khettaṃ, kedāroti āha “yasmiṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vutte vinaya aṭṭhakathāsu āgata vinicchayam sandhāya vinaya vasena iti vuttam saḥ kuṭikāra sikkhāpada vaṇṇanā ādīsu gahetabbaḥ  bījam khipanti ettha khittam vā bījam tāyati iti khettam kedāro ti āha yasmim pubbaṇṇam
translated: “By the Monastic Law” is said referring to the decision given in the commentaries on the Monastic Law. It should be taken from the commentary on the training rule on huts.

original: ruhatī”ti. Aparaṇṇassa pubbe pavattamannaṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ na-kārassa ṇa-kāraṃ katvā, sāliādi.
analyzed: ruhati iti aparaṇṇassa pubbe pavattam annam pubbaṇṇam nakārassa ṇakāram katvā sāli ādi
translated: A field is so called because seeds are thrown there or because seeds thrown there grow. “A field is where the first crop grows,” he says. The first crop is a crop that occurs first, with the -nna- of pubbaṇṇa being changed to -a- . It is rice and so on.

original: Vasanti patiṭṭhahanti aparaṇṇāni etthāti vatthūti atthaṃ dasseti “vatthu nāmā”tiādinā.
analyzed: vasanti patiṭṭhahanti aparaṇṇāni ettha ati vatthu iti attham dasseti vatthu nāma atiādinā
translated: A site is so called because the second crop grows there and is established there. He shows the meaning of “site” with the words “A site is where the first crop grows.”

original: Pubbaṇṇassa aparaṃ pavattamannaṃ aparaṇṇaṃ vuttanayena. Evaṃ aṭṭhakathānayānurūpaṃ🔽atthaṃ dassetvā idāni “khettaṃ nāma yattha pubbaṇṇaṃ vā aparaṇṇaṃ vā jāyatī”ti vuttavinayapāḷinayānurūpampi
analyzed: pubbaṇṇassa aparam pavattam annam aparaṇṇam vutta nayena evam aṭṭhakathā naya anurūpam 🔽attham dassetvā idāni khettam nāma yattha pubbaṇṇam vā aparaṇṇam vā jāyati iti vutta vinaya pāḷi naya anurūpam pi
translated: The second crop is a crop that occurs second, with the -nna- of aparaṇṇa being changed to -a- . It is in the same way as the first crop.🔽Having thus shown the meaning in accordance with the method of the commentaries, he now shows the meaning in accordance with the method of the Monastic Law, which is stated in the rule as follows:

original: atthaṃ dassento “yattha vā”tiādimāha. Tadatthāyāti khettatthāya. Akatabhūmibhāgoti🔽aparisaṅkhato taduddesiko bhūmibhāgo. “Khettavatthu sīsenā”tiādinā nidassanamattametanti
analyzed: attham dassentaḥ yattha vā ti ādim āha tad atthāya ati khetta atthāya akata bhūmi bhāgā iti  aparisaṅkhataḥ tad uddesikaḥ bhūmibhāgaḥ khetta vatthu sīsena ati ādinā nidassanamattam etat ti
translated: Pointing out the meaning, he says, “Where … for the sake of … ” . For the sake of that: for the sake of the field. Unprepared ground:

original: dasseti. Ādi-saddena pokkharaṇīkūpādayo saṅgahitā.
analyzed: dassa iti ādi saddena pokkharaṇī kūpa ādayo saṅgahitā
translated: ground not prepared for that purpose. “The field site by the head” , etc., he shows that this is merely an illustration. By the word “etc.” , a lotus-pond, a well, etc., are included.

original: Dūtassa idaṃ, dūtena vā kātumarahatīti dūteyyaṃ. Paṇṇanti lekhasāsanaṃ. Sāsananti🔽mukhasāsanaṃ. Gharā gharanti aññasmā gharā aññaṃ gharaṃ. Khuddakagamananti dūteyyagamanato
analyzed: dūtassa idam dūtena vā kātum arahati iti dūteyyam paṇṇanti lekha sāsanam  mukha sāsanam gharā gharanti aññasmai gharā aññam gharam khuddaka gamananti dūteyya gamanataḥ
translated: It is a message to be sent by a messenger, or it is suitable to be done by a messenger, thus it is a message . A written message is a letter. An oral message is an

original: appataragamanaṃ, anaddhānagamanaṃ rassagamananti attho. Tadubhayesaṃ anuyuñjanaṃ
analyzed: appatara gamanam anaddhāna gamanam rassa gamanam ti attho tad ubhayesam anuyuñjanam
translated: order. From house to house: from one house to another. A short journey: a journey shorter than a journey on a message, a journey of less than a yojana, is what is meant. The pursuit of both of these is

original: anuyogoti āha “tadubhayakaraṇa”nti. Tasmāti tadubhayakaraṇasseva anuyogabhāvato.
analyzed: āha tad ubhaya karaṇam ti tasmā iti tad ubhaya karaṇassa iva anuyoga bhāvato
translated: pursuit of both. Thus he says “the doing of both” . Therefore: because the pursuit belongs only to the doing of both.

original: Kayanaṃ kayo, paramparā gahetvā attano dhanassa dānaṃ. Kī-saddañhi dabbavinimaye
analyzed: kayanam paramparā gahetvā attanaḥ dhanassa dānam dabba vinimaye
translated: A series of hands is a chain of hands. The giving of one’s own wealth after receiving it through a chain of hands.

original: paṭhanti vikkayanaṃ vikkayo, paṭhamameva attano dhanassa paresaṃ dānanti vadanti.🔽Sāratthadīpaniyādīsu pana “kaya”nti parabhaṇḍassa gahaṇaṃ. Vikkayanti attano bhaṇḍassa
analyzed: paṭhanti vikkayanam vikkayo paṭhamam eva attanaḥ dhanassa paresam dānanti vadanti  pana kayanti para bhaṇḍassa gahaṇam vikkayanti attanaḥ bhaṇḍassa
translated: They say that the first is the giving of one’s own property to others.🔽But in the Sārattha-dīpanī, etc., it is said that “kaya” is the taking of another’s goods, and “vikkaya” is the giving of one’s own goods

original: dāna”nti vuttaṃ. Tadeva “kayitañca hoti parabhaṇḍaṃ attano hatthagataṃ karontena,
analyzed: dānam ti vuttam tat eva kayitam ca hoti parabhaṇḍam attanaḥ hattha gatam karontena
translated: to others. And that agrees with the text of the Vinaya Commentary: “It is ‘kaya’ when one makes another’s goods one’s own,

original: vikkītañca attano bhaṇḍaṃ parahatthagataṃ karontenā”ti vinayaṭṭhakathāvacanena sameti.
analyzed: vikkītam ca attanaḥ bhaṇḍam para hattha gatam karontena ati vinaya ṭṭhakathā vacanena sameti
translated: and it is ‘vikkaya’ when one makes one’s own goods another’s.”

original: Vañcanaṃ māyākaraṇaṃ, paṭibhānakaraṇavasena upāyakusalatāya parasantakaggahaṇanti
analyzed: vañcanam māyā karaṇam paṭibhāna karaṇa vasena upāya kusala tāya para santaka ggahaṇam ti
translated: “Vañcanā” is the making of deception, the making of a trick, by skill in means, by the use of a substitute for another’s goods.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tulā nāma yāya tulīyati pamīyati, tāya kūṭaṃ “tulākūṭa”nti vuccati.
analyzed: vuttam hoti tulā nāma yāya tulīyati pamīyati tāya kūṭam tulākūṭanti vuccati
translated: “Tulā” is a balance by which one weighs and measures. The cheating with that is called “tulākūṭa.”

original: Taṃ pana karonto tulāya rūpaaṅgagahaṇākārapaṭicchannasaṇṭhānavasena karotīti catubbidhatā
analyzed: tam pana karontaḥ tulāya rūpa aṅga gahaṇa ākāra paṭicchanna saṇṭhāna vasena karoti iti catubbidha tā
translated: But one who does that does it by concealing the form of the balance-parts and the method of taking it, so it is said that there are four kinds.

original: vuttā. Attanā gahetabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ pacchābhāge, paresaṃ dātabbaṃ pubbabhāge katvā minentīti
analyzed: vuttāḥ attanā gahetabbam bhaṇḍam pacchābhāge paresam dātabbam pubbabhāge katvā minenti iti
translated: One who cheats by making the goods to be taken by oneself in the rear and those to be given to others in the front is called a “rear-cheater.”

original: āha “gaṇhanto pacchābhāge”tiādi. Akkamati nippīḷati, pubbabhāge akkamatīti sambandho.
analyzed: āha gaṇhantaḥ pacchābhāga itiādi akkamati nippīḷati pubbabhāge akkamati iti sambandho
translated: He says “The one who is weighing should stand behind” and so on. The meaning is: he steps on, he oppresses, he steps on in front.

original: Mūle rajjunti tulāya mūle yojitaṃ rajjuṃ. Tathā agge. Tanti ayacuṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: mūle rajjunti tulāya mūle yojitam rajjum tathā agge tanti aya cuṇṇam
translated: At the base of the scales: the rope attached at the base of the scales. So too at the top. T: a measure of copper.

original: Kanati dibbatīti kaṃso, suvaṇṇarajatādimayā bhojanapānapattā. Idha pana sovaṇṇamaye
analyzed: kanati dibbati iti kaṃso suvaṇṇa rajata ādi mayāḥ bhojana pāna pattāḥ idha pana sovaṇṇa maye
translated: A bronze vessel: a vessel for eating or drinking made of bronze, gold, silver, etc. Here, however, it is a golden vessel.

original: pānapatteti āha “suvaṇṇapātī”ti. Tāya vañcananti nikativasena vañcanaṃ. “Patirūpakaṃ
analyzed: āha suvaṇṇa pātī iti tāya vañcanam nti nikati vasena vañcanam pati rūpakam
translated: By that deception: by the deception of cheating by means of a false balance. “Having shown a false balance,

original: dassetvā parasantakagahaṇañhi nikati, paṭibhānakaraṇavasena pana upāyakusalatāya
analyzed: dassetvā para santaka gahaṇam hi nikati paṭibhāna karaṇa vasena pana upāya kusala tāya
translated: the taking of another’s property is cheating by means of a false balance. But by the skill in means of making a false balance, there is deception.

original: vañcana”nti nikativañcanaṃ bhedato kaṇhajātakaṭṭhakathādīsu vuttaṃ, idha pana tadubhayampi
analyzed: vañcanam ti nikati vañcanam bhedato kaṇha jāta kaṭṭhakathā ādīsu vuttam idha pana tat ubhayam pi
translated: This is the distinction between cheating and deception, as stated in the commentary to the Kaṇha-jātaka . Here, however, both are called “deception.”

original: “vañcana”micceva. “Katha”ntiādinā hi patirūpakaṃ dassetvā parasantakagahaṇameva vibhāveti.
analyzed: vañcanam icca eva kathan ti ādinā hi pati rūpakam dassetvā para santaka gahaṇam eva vibhāveti
translated: For by the words “How?” and so on, he distinguishes only the taking of another’s property by showing a false balance.

original: Samagghataranti tāsaṃ pātīnaṃ aññamaññaṃ samakaṃ agghavisesaṃ. Pāsāṇeti bhūtābhūtabhāvasañjānanake
analyzed: tāsam pātīnam aññam aññam samakam aggha visesam pāsāṇā iti bhūta abhūta bhāva sañjānanake
translated: The equal value: the equal value of those vessels one with another. A stone: a stone for testing the genuineness of gold.

original: pāsāṇe. Ghaṃsaneneva suvaṇṇabhāvasaññāpanaṃ siddhanti “ghaṃsitvā”tveva vuttaṃ.🔽Hadayanti nāḷiādiminanabhājanānaṃ abbhantaraṃ, tasmiṃ bhedo chiddakaraṇaṃ hadayabhedo. Tilādīnaṃ nāḷiādīhi minanakāle ussāpitā sikhāyeva sikhā, tassā bhedo hāpanaṃ sikhābhedo.
analyzed: pāsāṇe ghaṃsanena iva suvaṇṇa bhāva saññāpanam siddhan ti ghaṃsitvā tu eva vuttam  nāḷi ādi minana bhājanānam abbhantaram tasmin bhedaḥ chidda karaṇam hadaya bhedaḥ tila ādīnam nāḷi ādīhi minana kāle ussāpitā sikhāya iva sikhā tassāḥ bhedaḥ hāpanam sikhā bhedaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words “having broken” is established by the mere breaking, but it is said thus: “having broken” in order to show the state of being gold.🔽The “heart” is the inside of a bamboo tube, etc., and the “breaking of the heart” is the making of a hole in it. The “flame” is the flame that is produced when sesame seeds, etc., are threshed with bamboo tubes, etc.; the “breaking of the flame” is the extinguishing of it.

original: Rajjuyā bhedo visamakaraṇaṃ rajjubhedo. Tānīti sappitelādīni. Antobhājaneti paṭhamaṃ🔽nikkhittabhājane. Ussāpetvāti uggamāpetvā, uddhaṃ rāsiṃ katvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Chindantoti apanento.
analyzed: bhedaḥ visama karaṇam tāni iti sappita ilā ādīni antar bhājana iti  nikkhitta bhājane ussāpetvā iti uggamāpetvā uddham rāsim katvā iti vuttam hoti chindantaḥ iti apanentaḥ
translated: The “breaking of the rope” is the making of it uneven. “Those” means the bile, etc. “In the vessel” means in the vessel that was put down first.🔽“Having raised” means having lifted up; the meaning is, having made a heap on high. “Cutting” means removing.

original: Kattabbakammato uddhaṃ koṭanaṃ paṭihananaṃ ukkoṭanaṃ. Abhūtakārīnaṃ lañjaggahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: kattabba kammataḥ uddham koṭanam paṭihananam ukkoṭanam abhūta kārīnam lañja ggahaṇam
translated: The “shaking” is the shaking after the work has been done, the shaking for the purpose of showing.

original: na pana puna kammāya ukkoṭanamattanti āha “assāmike…pe… ggahaṇa”nti. Upāyehīti kāraṇapatirūpakehi.
analyzed: na pana puna kammāya ukkoṭana mattanti āha ggahaṇanti upāyehi iti kāraṇa patirūpakehi
translated: The meaning is, the seizing of the sign of those who do what is not true, but not the mere shaking for the purpose of work again. Therefore it is said: “The seizing of the sign of one who is not a partner … .” “By means of a pretext” means by means of a reason that is not the real one.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ vañcane. “Vatthu”nti avatvā “ekaṃ vatthu”nti vadanto aññānipi atthi🔽bahūnīti dasseti. Aññānipi hi sasavatthuādīni tattha tattha vuttāni. Miganti mahantaṃ🔽migaṃ. Tena hīti migaggahaṇe uyyojanaṃ, yena vā kāraṇena “migaṃ me dehī”ti āha, tena🔽kāraṇenāti attho. Hi-saddo nipātamattaṃ. Yogavasenāti vijjājappanādipayogavasena.
analyzed: tatra ati tasmim vañcane vatthunti a vatvā ekam vatthunti vadantaḥ aññāni pi atthi  bahūni iti dasseti aññāni api hi sa sa vatthu ādīni tattha tattha vuttāni miganti mahantam  migam tena hi iti miga ggahaṇe uyyojanam yena vā kāraṇena migam me dehi iti āha tena  kāraṇena ati atthaḥ hi saddaḥ nipātamattam yoga vasnā ati vijjā jappana ādi payoga vasena
translated: “There” means in that deception. By saying “one matter” instead of “matter” he shows that there are many others as well,🔽for there are other matters such as the matter of the cow, etc., mentioned here and there. “Deer” means a big deer. “For that reason” means for the reason of the sending out of the deer-catching party, or for the reason why he said “Give me a deer.”🔽The word “hi” is merely an indeclinable particle. “By means of a trick” means by means of the trick of magic spells, etc.

original: Māyāvasenāti mantajappanaṃ vinā abhūtassāpi bhūtākārasaññāpanāya cakkhumohanamāyāya🔽vasena. Yāya hi amaṇiādayopi maṇiādiākārena dissanti. Pāmaṅgo nāma kulācārayutto
analyzed: māyā vasena ati manta jappanam vinā abhūtassa api bhūta ākāra saññāpanāya cakkhu mohana māyāya  vasena hi a maṇi ādayaḥ api maṇi ādi ākārena dissanti pāmaṅgaḥ nāma kula ācāra yutto
translated: “Therein” : in that deception. By saying “one thing” instead of “a thing” he shows that there are many other things. For there are other things mentioned here and there, such as the “cow-matter” . “Deer” : a big deer. “For that reason” : the sending out for the purpose of catching the deer; or the reason for which he said “Give me a deer.” “For that reason” is the meaning. The word “hi” is merely a particle. “By means of magic” : by means of the magic of bewitching the eyes in order to make known the appearance of something non-existent without the use of spells and incantations. For by this means even non-gems and so on appear as if they were gems and so on. “Pāmaṅga” is a kind of ornament worn by families of a certain profession,

original: ābharaṇaviseso, yaṃ loke “yaññopavitta”nti vadanti. Vakkalittherāpadānepi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: ābharaṇa visesaḥ yam loke yaññā upavittanti vadanti vakkali tthera apadāne pi vuttam
translated: which in the world is called “yaññopavita” . It is also mentioned in the Vakkali Thera-apadana:🔽“See that young man, wearing a yellow robe,

original: “Passathetaṃ māṇavakaṃ, pītamaṭṭhanivāsanaṃ;
analyzed: passatha itam māṇavakam pītam aṭṭha nivāsanam
translated: with a golden ornament on his neck,

original: Hemayaññopavittaṅgaṃ, jananettamanohara”nti. ;
analyzed: hema yañña upavitta aṅgam
translated: pleasing to the eyes of the people.”

original: Tadaṭṭhakathāyampi “pītamaṭṭhanivāsananti siliṭṭhasuvaṇṇavaṇṇavatthe nivatthanti
analyzed: pītam aṭṭha nivāsanam ti siliṭṭha suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa vatthe nivatthanti
translated: In the commentary too it is said: “He was wearing yellow garments: he was wearing garments the colour of refined gold.

original: attho. Hemayaññopavittaṅganti suvaṇṇapāmaṅgalaggitagattanti attho”ti savanaṃ saṭhanaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ hema yañña upavittaṅganti suvaṇṇa pāmaṅga laggita gattanti atthaḥ iti savanam saṭhanam
translated: He was wearing a golden amulet box: he was wearing a golden amulet box with a flame-shaped ornament.”🔽The meaning of “cunning” is “deceitful.”🔽“Skillful” means “having the nature of a trick.”

original: sāvi, anujukatā, tenāha “kuṭilayogo”ti, jimhatāyogoti attho. “Etesaṃyevā”tiādinā
analyzed: sā avi anujuka tā tena āha kuṭila yogaḥ iti jimha tā yogaḥ iti attho etesam yeva iti ādinā
translated: “Of these only” shows that the words have the same reference.

original: tulyādhikaraṇataṃ dasseti. “Tasmā”tiādi laddhaguṇadassanaṃ. Ye pana catunnampi padānaṃ
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇa tam dasseti tasmā atiādi laddha guṇa dassanam ye pana catunnam pi padānam
translated: “Therefore” shows that the words have the same quality.

original: bhinnādhikaraṇataṃ vadanti, tesaṃ vādamāha “kecī”tiādinā. Tattha “kecī”ti sārasamāsakārakā
analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇatam vadanti tesam vādam āha keci iti ādinā tattha keci iti sārasa māsa kārakā
translated: But those who say that the words have different references, the author of the commentary refutes with the words “Some say.”

original: ācariyā, uttaravihāravāsino ca, tesaṃ taṃ na yuttaṃ vañcanena saṅgahitasseva puna🔽gahitattāti dasseti “taṃ panā”tiādinā.
analyzed: ācariyāḥ uttaravihāra vāsino ca tesam tam na yuttam vañcanena saṅgahitassa iva puna  gahita ttā iti dasseti tam pana iti ādinā
translated: Here “some” are the teachers who compose grammatical works and the residents of the Northern Monastery.🔽The author of the commentary shows that their view is not correct because it is a repetition of what is already included in the word “deceitful.”

original: Māraṇanti muṭṭhipahārakasātāḷanādīhi hiṃsanaṃ viheṭhanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na tu pāṇātipātaṃ.
analyzed: māraṇam ti muṭṭhi pahāraka sātāḷana ādīhi hiṃsanam viheṭhanam sandhāya vuttam na tu pāṇātipātam
translated: “Killing” is said with reference to the harming and injuring by means of fists, sticks, and so on, and not with reference to the taking of life.

original: Viheṭhanatthepi hi vadha-saddo dissati “attānaṃ vadhitvā vadhitvā rodeyyā”tiādīsu
analyzed: viheṭhana atthe pi hi vadha saddaḥ dissati attānam vadhitvā vadhitvā rodeyya ati ādīsu
translated: For the word “killing” is also found in the sense of tormenting, as in the passage: “Having killed himself, he would weep, having killed himself, he would weep” .🔽And the word “murder” should be regarded as used here in the sense of tormenting.

original: māraṇa-saddopi idha viheṭhaneyeva vattatīti daṭṭhabbo. Keci pana “pubbe pāṇātipātaṃ🔽pahāyā’tiādīsu sayaṃkāro, idha paraṃkāro”ti vadanti, taṃ na sakkā tathā vattuṃ “kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: māraṇa saddaḥ api idha viheṭhanā iya iva vattati iti daṭṭhabbaḥ keci pana pubbe pāṇātipātam  pahāya ati ādīsu vadanti tam na sakkā tathā vattum kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: But some say that in the passage beginning, “Having given up killing living beings” , the killing is done by oneself, while here the killing is done by another.

original: cetanā, cha payogā”ti ca vuttattā. Yathā hi appaṭiggāhabhāvasāmaññepi sati pabbajitehi🔽appaṭiggahitabbavatthuvisesabhāvasandassanatthaṃ itthikumāridāsidāsādayo vibhāgena🔽vuttā. Yathā ca parasantakassa haraṇabhāvato adinnādānabhāvasāmaññepi sati tulākūṭādayo
analyzed: cetanā cha payogā ti ca vutta ttā yathā hi a paṭiggāha bhāva sāmaññe pi sati pabbajitehi  a paṭiggahitabba vatthu visesa bhāva sandassana ttham itthi kumāri dāsi dāsa ādayaḥ vibhāgena  vuttāḥ yathā ca para santakassa haraṇa bhāvataḥ adinnādāna bhāva sāmaññe pi sati tulākūṭa ādayaḥ
translated: But that cannot be said, because it is said that volition is the instigation to action by body or speech, and that there are six kinds of instigation.🔽For just as, although there is a common characteristic of not being received in the case of all the things that are not to be received by those gone forth, the women, girls, slave women, slave men, etc., are nevertheless mentioned separately in order to show the particular things that should not be received by those gone forth;

original: adinnādānavisesabhāvasandassanatthaṃ vibhāgena vuttā, na evaṃ pāṇātipātapariyāyassa
analyzed: adinnādāna visesa bhāva sandassana attham vibhāgena vuttā na evam pāṇātipāta pariyāyassa
translated: and just as, although there is a common characteristic of being theft in the case of all the taking of what is not given, the false scales, etc., are nevertheless mentioned separately in order to show the particular kinds of theft;🔽so too, although there is a common characteristic of being a means of killing living beings in the case of all the means of killing, the particular means of killing are nevertheless mentioned separately in order to show the particular kinds of killing.

original: vadhassa puna gahaṇe payojanaṃ atthi tathāvibhajitabbassābhāvato, tasmā yathāvuttoyevattho sundarataroti.
analyzed: vadhassa puna gahaṇe payojanam atthi tathā vibhajitabbassa abhāvato tasmā sundarataraḥ iti
translated: There is a purpose in mentioning killing again, because it is not possible to divide it in the way the others are, so the meaning stated is more beautiful.

original: Viparāmosoti visesena samantato bhusaṃ mosāpanaṃ muyhanakaraṇaṃ, thenanaṃ vā. Theyyaṃ
analyzed: viparāmosā iti visesena samantataḥ bhusam mosāpanam muyhana karaṇam thenanam vā theyyam
translated: Misapprehending: misapprehending by a special all-round confusion, or deceiving, of what is seen, etc., is “misapprehending” .

original: corikā mosoti hi pariyāyo. So kāraṇavasena duvidhoti āha “himaviparāmoso”tiādi. Musantīti
analyzed: corikā mosoti hi pariyāyo saḥ kāraṇa vasena duvidhaḥ iti āha hima viparāmosa utiādi musanti iti
translated: For this is a synonym for “theft” , “robbery” , and “deception” . It is twofold as to kind, according to cause, and so he said “Misapprehending due to cold, etc.”

original: corenti, mosenti vā muyhanaṃ karonti, mosetvā tesaṃ santakaṃ gaṇhantīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: corenti mosenti vā muyhanam karonti mosetvā tesam santakam gaṇhanti iti vuttam hoti
translated: They steal, or they deceive, or they cause confusion, or they take what belongs to them after deceiving them.🔽And the misapprehending is the act of taking what is theirs.

original: Yanti ca tassā kiriyāya parāmasanaṃ. Maggappaṭipannaṃ jananti parapakkhepi adhikāro.
analyzed: yanti ca tassā kiriyāya parāmasanam magga paṭipannam jananti para pakkhe pi adhikāraḥ
translated: The people on the road is the province of the other side.

original: Ālopanaṃ vilumpanaṃ ālopo. Sahasā karaṇaṃ sahasākāro. Sahasā pavattitā sāhasikā, sāva kiriyā tathā.
analyzed: ālopanam vilumpanam ālopaḥ sahasā karaṇam sahasākāraḥ sahasā sāhasikā tathā
translated: Stealing is taking by force, and the act of doing it violently is “violence” . It is violent, thus it is “violent” . That act is so.

original: Ettāvatāti “pāṇātipātaṃ pahāyā”tiādinā “sahasākārā paṭivirato”ti pariyosānena etapparimāṇena
analyzed: ettāvatā ati pāṇa atipātam pahāya ati ādinā sahasākārā paṭiviratā ti pariyosānena etad parimāṇena
translated: To this extent: to this extent, namely, from “Having abandoned killing living beings” to the end with “refraining from violence.”

original: pāṭhena. Antarabhedaṃ aggahetvā pāḷiyaṃ yathārutamāgatavaseneva chabbīsatisikkhāpadasaṅgahametaṃ
analyzed: pāṭhena antara bhedam aggahetvā pāḷiyam yathārutam āgata vasena iva chabbīsati sikkhāpada saṅgaham etam
translated: By the text. Without taking the internal divisions, it is the collection of the sixty-two training precepts that has come down in the text as it is.

original: sīlaṃ yebhuyyena sikkhāpadānamavibhattattā cūḷasīlaṃ nāmāti attho. Desanāvasena hi
analyzed: sīlam yebhuyyena sikkhāpadānam avibhatta ttā cūḷasīlam nāma ati atthaḥ desanā vasena hi
translated: This virtue is called the “lesser virtue” because the training precepts are not analyzed in the main part.

original: idha cūḷamajjhimādibhāvo veditabbo, na dhammavasena. Tathā hi idhasaṅkhittena uddiṭṭhānaṃ🔽sikkhāpadānaṃ avibhattānaṃ vibhajanavasena majjhimasīladesanā pavattā, tenevāha “majjhimasīlaṃ
analyzed: idha cūḷa majjhima ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ na dhamma vasena tathā hi idha saṅkhittena  sikkhāpadānam avibhattānam vibhajana vasena majjhima sīla desanā pavattā tena iva āha majjhima sīlam
translated: For the lesser, medium, etc., should be understood here according to the teaching, not according to the Dhamma.

original: vitthārento”ti.Cūḷasīlavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: For thus, the medium virtue teaching occurs by way of the analysis of the training precepts that are not analyzed in the brief recitation here. Therefore it is said: “The medium virtue is taught in detail.” The explanation of the lesser virtue is finished.

original: Majjhimasīlavaṇṇanā🔽11. “Yathā vā paneke bhonto”tiādidesanāya sambandhamāha “idānī”tiādinā. Tatthāyamaṭṭhakathāmuttako
analyzed: majjhima sīla vaṇṇanā  yathā vā pana eke bhonto ti ādi desanāya sambandham āha idāni iti ādinā tattha ayam aṭṭhakathā muttako
translated: The medium virtue

original: nayo – yathāti opammatthe nipāto. Vāti vikappanatthe, tena imamatthaṃ vikappeti “ussāhaṃ
analyzed: nayaḥ yathā iti opamma atthe nipātaḥ vā ati vikappana tthe tena imam attham vikappeti ussāham
translated: The explanation of the medium virtue is begun with the words “Now as to the words ‘Just as some worshipers of shrines’ and so on.” Here is the method of explanation: “Just as” is a particle in the sense of a simile. “So” is in the sense of a comparison. Thus he compares this meaning: “Having made an effort

original: katvā mama vaṇṇaṃ vadamānopi puthujjano pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato”tiādinā
analyzed: katvā mama vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ api puthujjanaḥ pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ iti ādinā
translated: and he would say: “The worldling, having given up killing living things, abstains from killing living things,” and so on.🔽Or he would say: “The worldling, having given up killing living things, abstains from killing living things,” and so on, in the way of indirect indication.

original: parānuddesikanayena vā sabbathāpi ācārasīlamattameva vadeyya, na taduttariṃ. “Yathāpaneke
analyzed: para anuddesika nayena vā sabbathā api ācāra sīla mattam eva vadeyya na tad uttarim yathā apaneke
translated: Or he would say: “Just as some,

original: bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇabhāvaṃ paṭijānamānā, parehi ca tathā sambhāviyamānā tadanurūpapaṭipattiṃ
analyzed: bhontaḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇa bhāvam paṭijānamānā parehi ca tathā sambhāviyamānā tad anurūpa paṭipattim
translated: claiming to be ascetics and brahmins, and being regarded by others as such, do not succeed in the practice that accords with their claim,

original: ajānanato, asamatthanato ca na abhisambhuṇanti, na evamayaṃ. Ayaṃ pana samaṇo gotamo
analyzed: a jānanataḥ a samatthanataḥ ca na abhisambhuṇanti na evam ayam ayam pana samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ
translated: because of ignorance and lack of ability, so it is not with this ascetic Gotama.

original: sabbathāpi samaṇasāruppapaṭipattiṃ pūresiyevā”ti evaṃ aññuddesikanayena vā sabbathāpi🔽ācārasīlamattameva vadeyya, na taduttarinti. Panāti vacanālaṅkāre vikappanattheneva🔽upanyāsādiatthassa sijjhanato. Eketi aññe. “Ekacce”tipi vadanti. Bhontoti sādhūnaṃ
analyzed: sabbathā api samaṇa sāruppa paṭipattim pūresiya iva ati evam aññuddesika nayena vā sabbathā api  ācāra sīlam attam eva vadeyya na tad uttarin ti panāti vacana alaṅkāre vikappana atthena iva  upanyāsa ādi atthassa sijjhanato eke iti aññe ekacce itipi vadanti bhonto ti sādhūnam
translated: But this ascetic Gotama has fulfilled the practice that accords with the state of an ascetic in every way.”🔽Or he would say: “The worldling, having given up killing living things, abstains from killing living things,” and so on, in the way of indirect indication.

original: piyasamudāhāro. Sādhavo hi pare “bhonto”ti vā “devānaṃ piyā”ti vā “āyasmanto”ti vā
analyzed: sādhavaḥ hi pare bhonto iti vā devānam vā
translated: But he would say: “The worldling, having given up killing living things, abstains from killing living things,” and so on, in the way of indirect indication. But he would say: “The worldling, having given up killing living things, abstains from killing living things,” and so on, in the way of indirect indication. original: samālapanti. Samaṇabrāhmaṇāti yaṃ kiñci pabbajjaṃ upagatatāya samaṇā. Jātimattena ca brāhmaṇāti.
analyzed: samālapanti samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati yam kiñci pabbajjam upagata tāya samaṇāḥ jātimattena ca brāhmaṇāḥ ati
translated: They are conversing. Ascetics and brahmans: anyone who has gone forth is an ascetic. And anyone who is a brahmin by birth is a brahmin.

original: Saddhā nāma idha catubbidhesu ṭhānesūti āha “kammañcā”tiādi. Kammakammaphalasambandheneva
analyzed: saddhā nāma idha catubbidhesu ṭhānesu iti āha kammañca atiādi kamma kamma phala sambandhena iva
translated: Faith: in the four instances, it is said, “in kamma, etc.”

original: idhalokaparalokasaddahanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “ettha kammaṃ vipaccati, kammaphalañca anubhavitabba”nti.
analyzed: idhaloka paraloka saddahanam daṭṭhabbam ettha kammam vipaccati kamma phalam ca anubhavitabbanti
translated: One should see that it is the confidence that “Here kamma ripens and its fruit is experienced.”

original: Tadatthaṃ byatirekato ñāpeti “ayaṃ me”tiādinā. Paṭikarissatīti paccupakāraṃ karissati.
analyzed: tad attham byatirekataḥ ayam mā iti ādinā paṭikarissati iti paccupakāram karissati
translated: He shows the excess of that meaning by “This is mine,” etc. He will make amends: he will make reparation.

original: Tadeva samatthetuṃ “evaṃdinnāni hī”tiādimāha. Desanāsīsamattaṃ padhānaṃ katvā nidassanato.
analyzed: tat eva samatthetum evaṃdinnāni hi itiādim āha desanā sīsa mattam padhānam katvā nidassanato
translated: In order to establish that very fact, he says, “For thus given,” etc. The word “thus” is a mere figure of speech.

original: Tena catubbidhampi paccayaṃ nidassetīti vuttaṃ “atthato panā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena catubbidham pi paccayam nidasseti iti vuttam atthataḥ pana atiādi
translated: Therefore it is said, “But in meaning,” etc.

original: “Seyyathida”nti ayaṃ saddo “so katamo”ti atthe eko nipāto, nipātasamudāyo vā, tena
analyzed: seyyathidam ti ayam saddo so katamaḥ ti atthe ekaḥ nipātaḥ nipāta samudāyaḥ vā tena
translated: The word “such as” is a single indeclinable word or a group of indeclinables in the sense of “which.”

original: ca bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhapade saddakkamena appadhānabhūtopi bījagāmabhūtagāmo
analyzed: ca bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambha pade sadda kkamena appadhāna bhūtaḥ api bīja gāma bhūta gāmaḥ
translated: And although the word “such as” is not a basis for the act of appropriation, it is a basis for the act of beginning in the way that the words “seed,” “village,” and “field” are in the passage, “The seed is the nutriment derived from gross or fine food. The village and the field are this consciousness” .

original: vibhajjitabbaṭṭhāne padhānabhūto viya paṭiniddisīyati. Añño hi saddakkamo añño atthakkamoti
analyzed: vibhajjitabba ṭṭhāne padhāna bhūtaḥ viya aññaḥ hi sadda kkamaḥ aññaḥ attha kkamaḥ ti
translated: For the order of the words is different from the order of the meaning.🔽So he said, “What is that seed-essence and essence of life?”

original: āha “katamo so bījagāmabhūtagāmo”ti. Tasmiñhi vibhatte tabbisayasamārambhopi vibhattova
analyzed: āha katamaḥ saḥ bīja gāma bhūta gāmaḥ iti tasmin hi vibhatte tad bisaya samārambhaḥ api vibhattaḥ uva
translated: For when that is analysed, the reference to it is also analysed.

original: hoti. Imamatthañhi dassetuṃ “yassa samārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharantī”ti vuttaṃ. Teneva🔽ca pāḷiyaṃ “mūlabīja”ntiādinā so niddiṭṭhoti. Mūlameva bījaṃ mūlabījaṃ, mūlaṃ bījaṃ
analyzed: hoti imam attham hi dassetum yassa samārambham anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti vuttam tena iva  ca pāḷiyam mūla bīja nti ādinā saḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ iti mūlam eva bījam mūla bījam mūlam bījam
translated: For it is in order to show this meaning that it is said, “They live devoted to the pursuit of that” .🔽And that is why it is shown in the text by the words “root-seed” , etc.

original: etassātipi mūlabījanti idha dvidhā attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Ato na codetabbametaṃ
analyzed: mūla bījanti idha dvidhā atthaḥ sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ atas na codetabbam etam
translated: Herein, the meaning is twofold: root is the seed, root-seed; or root is the seed of that, root-seed.

original: “kasmā panettha bījagāmabhūtagāmaṃ pucchitvā bījagāmo eva vibhatto”ti. Tattha hi🔽paṭhamena atthena bījagāmo niddiṭṭho, dutiyena bhūtagāmo, duvidhopesa sāmaññaniddesena
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha bīja gāma bhūta gāmam pucchitvā bīja gāmaḥ eva vibhatto ti tattha hi  paṭhamena atthena bīja gāmaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ dutiyena bhūta gāmaḥ sāmañña niddesena
translated: So it should not be objected that “Why is it that, having asked about the seed-essence and essence of life, only the seed-essence is analysed?”🔽For in the first place the seed-essence is shown by the first meaning, and the essence of life by the second.

original: vā mūlabījañca mūlabījañca mūlabījanti ekasesanayena vā niddiṭṭhoti veditabbo, teneva
analyzed: vā mūla bījam ca mūla bījam ca mūla bījanti eka sesa nayena vā niddiṭṭhaḥ ti veditabbo tena iva
translated: And the two together are shown by the general indication “root-seed” , etc., or by the method of the single class in the double class “root-seed, root-seed” .

original: vakkhati “sabbañheta”ntiādiṃ. Atīva visati bhesajjapayogesūti ativisaṃ, ativisā vā,
analyzed: vakkhati atīva visati bhesajja payogesu iti ativisam ativisā vā
translated: He says “All this” and so on. It is a very strong poison, thus it is a strong poison . It is a poison that is strong, thus it is a strong poison .

original: yā “mahosadha”ntipi vuccati kacchakoti kāḷakacchako, yaṃ “pilakkho”tipi vadanti.🔽Kapitthanoti ambilaṅkuraphalo setarukkho. So hi kampati calatīti kapithano thanapaccayena,
analyzed: vuccati kacchako ti kāḷakacchakaḥ yam pilakkho tipi vadanti  kapitthano ti ambi laṅkura phalo seta rukkho so hi kampati calati iti kapithano thana paccayena
translated: It is called “great medicine” . The black aconite is the black aconite, which is also called “pillakku” .

original: kapīti vā makkaṭo, tassa thanasadisaṃ phalaṃ yassāti kapitthano. “Kapitthanoti pippalirukkho”ti
analyzed: kapi iti vā makkaṭo tassa thana sadisam phalam yassa ati kapitthano kapitthano ti pippali rukkho ti
translated: The citron is the sour fruit tree called “citron” . For it is shaken and moved , thus it is a citron . It is a tree that is like the shaking of a monkey , thus it is a citron . Or alternatively, it is a fruit that is like the shaking of a monkey , thus it is a citron .

original: hi visuddhimaggaṭīkāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Phaḷubījaṃ nāma pabbabījaṃ. Ajjakanti setapaṇṇāsaṃ.
analyzed: hi visuddhimagga ṭīkāyam vuttam phaḷubījam nāma pabba bījam ajjakanti seta paṇṇāsam
translated: For it is said in the Visuddhimagga Commentary : “The citron is the pepper tree” . The seed of the breadfruit is the breadfruit seed. The lime is the white-leaved lime .

original: Phaṇijjakanti samīraṇaṃ. Hiriveranti vāraṃ. Paccayantarasamavāye sadisaphaluppattiyā
analyzed: phaṇijjakanti samīraṇam hiriveranti vāram paccaya antara samavāye sadisa phala uppattiyā
translated: The ginger is the ginger . The water is the water . The condition is the condition . In the combination of conditions, the fruit that arises is similar .

original: visesakāraṇabhāvato viruhanasamatthe sāraphale niruḷho bījasaddoti dasseti “viruhanasamatthamevā”ti
analyzed: visesa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ viruhana samatthe sāra phale niruḷhaḥ bīja saddo ti dasseti viruhana samattham evā ti

translated: A seat made of wood, etc., is a bench. A bag for a water-strainer is a water-strainer bag. “For a single bhikkhu” and so on is the explanation of the meaning. translated: A seat made of wood, etc., is a bench. A bag for a water-strainer is a water-strainer bag. “For one bhikkhu” and so on is the explanation of the meaning. For the sake of the wilderness: for the purpose of going to the wilderness. For the sake of the feet being washed: for the purpose of protecting the feet that have been washed. A cloak is what is to be sewn together, what is to be joined. A pair of sandals is a cloak. The meaning is: a pair of sandals that are joined together. Should be given to another: the giving should be understood in the way already stated. A bed is mentioned merely by way of example. For all the sitting and lying things such as a bench, etc., should be taken. And in regard to them too one should proceed in the same way. “If there is an affliction of the skin, of the small or large intestines, etc.,” shows that perfumes are allowable only when there is a reason for using them. For it was said above, “When there is a reason, it is allowable in some cases even for one who has made an undertaking.”

analyzed: pattī pacchimam patta anīkam ti kaṇḍa viddha sikkhāpadassa pada bhājanam sandhāya tayā upe ādinā  nayena vuttassa ati āha tat ca kho dvādasa purisaḥ hatthī ti purisaḥ asso catu purisaḥ
