original: nāma dvīhi pantīti vīsatiyā padehi kīḷanajūtaṃ. Aṭṭhapadadasapadesūti aṭṭhapadadasapadaphalakesu.
analyzed: nāma dvīhi vīsatiyā padehi kīḷana jūtam aṭṭha pada dasa padesu iti aṭṭha pada dasa pada phalakesu
translated: The ‘ten-factored’ is gambling with twenty throws. ‘Eight-factored and ten-factored’ is the eight-factored and ten-factored throw.

original: Ākāseyeva kīḷananti “ayaṃ sārī asukapadaṃ mayā nītā, ayaṃ asukapada”nti kevalaṃ mukheneva
analyzed: ayam sārī asukapadam mayā nītā ayam kevalam mukhena iva
translated: ‘In mere talk’ is gambling with mere talk, saying ‘This piece has been brought by me to this place, this to that place’.

original: vadantānaṃ ākāseyeva jūtassa kīḷanaṃ. Nānāpathamaṇḍalanti anekavihitasārīmaggaparivaṭṭaṃ.
analyzed: vadantānam ākāseya iva jūtassa kīḷanam nānā patha maṇḍalanti aneka vihita sārī magga parivaṭṭam
translated: ‘With various courses’ is with many kinds of courses for the pieces.

original: Pariharitabbanti sāriyo pariharituṃ yuttakaṃ. Ito cito ca saranti parivattantīti
analyzed: pariharitabbanti sāriyaḥ pariharitum yuttakam itas ca itas ca saranti parivattanti iti
translated: ‘To be moved’ is suitable to be moved. ‘Pieces’ are so called because they move here and there, that is, they go round and round.

original: sāriyo, yena kenaci katāni akkhabījāni. Tatthāti tāsu sārīsu, tasmiṃ vā apanayanupanayane.
analyzed: sāriyaḥ yena kenacid katāni akkha bījāni tattha ati tāsu sārīsu tasmim vā apanayan upanayane
translated: They are dice made in any way. ‘There’ is in those pieces. ‘There’ is in that removal and bringing back.

original: Jūtakhaliketi jūtamaṇḍale. “Jūtaphalake”tipi adhunā pāṭho. Pāsakaṃ vuccati chasu
analyzed: jūta khalikā iti jūta maṇḍale adhunā pāṭhaḥ pāsakam vuccati chasu
translated: ‘In the gambling place’ is in the gambling arena. The reading now is ‘in the gambling board’. ‘Stake’ is said to be

original: passesu ekekaṃ yāva chakkaṃ dassetvā katakīḷanakaṃ, taṃ vaḍḍhetvā yathāladdhaṃ ekakādivasena
analyzed: passesu ekekam yāva chakkam dassetvā kata kīḷanakam tam vaḍḍhetvā yathāladdham ekaka ādi vasena
translated: and after showing one, two, three, four, five, and six in each direction, they play the game by increasing it.

original: sāriyo apanento, upanento ca kīḷanti, pasati aṭṭhapadādīsu bādhati, phusati cāti
analyzed: sāriyaḥ apanento upanento ca kīḷanti pasati aṭṭhapada ādīsu bādhati phusati ca ati
translated: They play by removing and adding one, two, etc., as they happen to get. The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square” is the “twenty-four-squares-and-lines” .

original: hi pāsako, catubbīsatividho akkho. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: hi pāsako catubbīsatividhaḥ akkho yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: The “thirty-two-square” is the “thirty-two-squares-and-lines” . The “sixty-four-square” is the “sixty-four-squares-and-lines” .

original: “Aṭṭhakaṃ mālikaṃ vuttaṃ, sāvaṭṭañca chakaṃ mataṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhakam mālikam vuttam sāvaṭṭam ca chakam matam
translated: The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square” is the “twenty-four-squares-and-lines” .

original: Catukkaṃ bahulaṃ ñeyyaṃ, dvi bindusantibhadrakaṃ;🔽Catuvīsati āyā ca, munindena pakāsitā”ti.🔽Tena kīḷanamidha pāsakakīḷanaṃ. Ghaṭanaṃ paharaṇaṃ, tena kīḷā ghaṭikāti āha “dīghadaṇḍakenā”tiādi.
analyzed: catuvīsati āyā ca munindena pakāsitā ati  tena pāsaka kīḷanam ghaṭanam paharaṇam tena kīḷā ghaṭikā iti āha dīghadaṇḍakena atiādi
translated: The “thirty-two-square” is the “thirty-two-squares-and-lines” . The “sixty-four-square” is the “sixty-four-squares-and-lines” .🔽The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square” is the “twenty-four-squares-and-lines” .🔽The “thirty-two-square” is the “thirty-two-squares-and-lines” . The “sixty-four-square” is the “sixty-four-squares-and-lines” .🔽The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square” is the “twenty-four-squares-and-lines” .

original: Ghaṭena kumbhena kīḷā ghaṭikāti eke. Mañjiṭṭhikāya vāti mañjiṭṭhisaṅkhātassa yojanavallirukkhassa
analyzed: ghaṭena kumbhena kīḷā ghaṭikā ati eke mañjiṭṭhikāya vāti mañjiṭṭhi saṅkhātassa yojana valli rukkhassa
translated: The “thirty-two-square” is the “thirty-two-squares-and-lines” . The “sixty-four-square” is the “sixty-four-squares-and-lines” .🔽The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square” is the “twenty-four-squares-and-lines” .

original: sāraṃ gahetvā pakkakasāvaṃ sandhāya vadati. Sitthodakena vāti [piṭṭhodakena vā (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)]
analyzed: sāram gahetvā pakka kasāvam sandhāya vadati sittha udakena vā ati piṭṭha udakena vā
translated: The “thirty-two-square” is the “thirty-two-squares-and-lines” . The “sixty-four-square” is the “sixty-four-squares-and-lines” .🔽The “eight-square” is the “eight-squares-and-lines” . The “twenty-four-square”

original: ca pakkamadhusitthodakaṃ. Salākahatthanti tālahīrādīnaṃ kalāpassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Bahūsu salākāsu visesarahitaṃ ekaṃ salākaṃ gahetvā tāsu pakkhipitvā puna taññeva
analyzed: ca pakka madhu sittha udakam salāka hattham ti tāla hīra ādīnam kalāpassa itam adhivacanam  bahūsu salākāsu visesa rahitam ekam salākam gahetvā tāsu pakkhipitvā puna taññeva
translated: and cooked honey, curd, and water. A stick in the hand: this is a term for a palm-leaf spray, etc.🔽Some say that it is a single stick without a notch taken from among many sticks with notches, and that they play with it by inserting it in the notches and then taking it out again.

original: uddharantā salākahatthena kīḷantīti keci. Guḷakīḷāti guḷaphalakīḷā, yena kenaci vā🔽kataguḷakīḷā. Paṇṇena vaṃsākārena katā nāḷikā paṇṇanāḷikā, tenevāha “taṃdhamantā”ti.
analyzed: uddharantā salāka hatthena kīḷanti iti keci guḷa kīḷā ati guḷa phala kīḷā yena kenaci vā  kata guḷa kīḷā paṇṇena vaṃsa ākārena katā nāḷikā paṇṇa nāḷikā tena iva āha tam dhamanta iti
translated: Playing with dice: playing with dice made of any kind of fruit.🔽A tube of leaves: a tube made of a strip of palm leaf, etc. Hence he says “with a toy” .🔽He shows that it is a small plough by “a small plough.”

original: Khuddake ka-paccayoti dasseti “khuddakanaṅgala”nti iminā. Hatthapādānaṃ mokkhena🔽mocanena cayati parivattati etāyāti mokkhacikā, tenāha “ākāse vā”tiādi. Paribbhamanattāyeva
analyzed: khuddake ka paccayaḥ ti dasseti khuddaka naṅgalam ti iminā hattha pādānam mokkhena  mocanena cayati parivattati etāya ati mokkhacikā tena āha ākāse vāti ādi
translated: A toy for the hands: it is called a “toy” because it is used for turning and revolving by means of the fingers and toes. Hence he says “in the air,” etc.

original: taṃ cakkaṃ nāmāti dassetuṃ “paribbhamanacakka”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam cakkam nāma ati dassetum paribbhamana cakkan ti vuttam
translated: He says “a revolving toy” in order to show that it is called a “wheel” because it revolves.

original: Paṇṇena katā nāḷi paṇṇanāḷi, iminā pattāḷhakapadadvayassa yathākkamaṃ pariyāyaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: paṇṇena katā nāḷi paṇṇa nāḷi iminā patta āḷhaka pada dvayassa yathākkamam pariyāyam dasseti
translated: A tube of leaves: a tube made of leaves. He shows the synonyms for the two terms “toy” and “wheel” in this way.

original: Tena katā pana kīḷā pattāḷhakāti vuttaṃ “tāyā”tiādi. Khuddako ratho rathako ka-saddassa
analyzed: tena katā pana kīḷā pattāḷhakā iti vuttam tāya atiādi khuddakaḥ rathaḥ rathakaḥ kasaddassa
translated: The game that he plays is called a ‘dice-game’ . The word ‘rathaka’ is a small chariot, because the word ‘ka’

original: khuddakatthavacanato. Esa nayo sesapadesupi. Ākāse vā yaṃ ñāpeti, tassa piṭṭhiyaṃ
analyzed: khudda kattha vacanataḥ esa nayaḥ sesa padesu pi ākāse vā yam ñāpeti tassa piṭṭhiyam
translated: means small. The same method applies in the other cases. ‘In the air’ means on the back of one who is informing .

original: vā yathā vā tathā vā akkharaṃ likhitvā “evamida”nti jānanena kīḷā akkharikā, pucchantassa
analyzed: vā yathā vā tathā vā akkharam likhitvā evam idam ti jānanena kīḷā akkharikā pucchantassa
translated: Or else, they say, it is a game of knowing by writing a letter in some way or another and knowing ‘It is like this’ . ‘In the mouth’ means taking a letter that has come into the mouth of one who is asking.

original: mukhāgataṃ akkharaṃ gahetvā naṭṭhamuttilābhādijānanakīḷātipi vadanti. Vajja-saddo
analyzed: mukha āgatam akkharam gahetvā vadanti vajja saddaḥ
translated: It is a game of knowing the gain of what is lost. The word ‘vajja’ means ‘fault’ .

original: aparādhatthoti āha “yathāvajjaṃ nāmā”tiādi. Vāditānurūpaṃ naccanaṃ, gāyanaṃ vā yathāvajjantipi
analyzed: āha yathāvajjam nāma atiādi vāditā anurūpam naccanam gāyanam vā yathāvat jantipi
translated: That is why he said ‘according as the fault is’ . They say that ‘according as the fault is’ is dancing or singing in accordance with the tune.

original: vadanti. “Evaṃ kate jayo bhavissati, evaṃ kate parājayo”ti jayaparājayaṃ purakkhatvā
analyzed: vadanti evam kate jayaḥ bhavissati evam kate parājayaḥ ti jaya parājayam purakkhatvā
translated: ‘If it is done like this, there will be victory; if it is done like that, there will be defeat’ .

original: payogakaraṇavasena parihārapathādīnampi jūtappamādaṭṭhānabhāvo veditabbo, paṅgacīrādīhi
analyzed: payoga karaṇa vasena parihāra patha ādīnam pi jūta ppamāda ṭṭhāna bhāvaḥ veditabbo paṅga cīra ādīhi
translated: The state of being a place of gambling and heedlessness should be understood in the way beginning with the ‘path of evasion’ by making an effort with victory and defeat placed in the lead.

original: ca vaṃsādīhi kattabbā kiccasiddhi, asiddhi cāti jayaparājayāvaho payogo vutto, yathāvajjanti
analyzed: ca vaṃsa ādīhi kattabbā payogaḥ vuttaḥ yathāvajjanti
translated: and the success or failure of the task to be done by means of the army, etc., is called the “application that brings victory and defeat,” according as it is said: “The application is the means by which the success or failure of the task to be done is known” .

original: ca kāṇādīhi sadisākāradassanehi jayaparājayavasena jūtakīḷikabhāvena vuttaṃ. Sabbepi
analyzed: ca kāṇa ādīhi sadisa ākāra dassanehi jaya parājaya vasena jūta kīḷika bhāvena vuttam sabbe pi
translated: and by means of dice, etc., the success or failure of the undertaking, that is, the winning or losing, is indicated. The word “gambling” is used in the sense of the playing of dice, which is called “gambling” because of the winning and losing that occurs through the showing of the same number of spots on two dice, etc. All these

original: hete jotenti pakāsenti etehi tappayogikā jayaparājayavasena, javanti ca gacchanti
analyzed: ete jotenti pakāsenti etehi tad payogikāḥ jaya parājaya vasena ca gacchanti
translated: are “gambling” in the sense of illuminating, manifesting, or because they are the means of illuminating, manifesting, winning, and losing.

original: jayaparājayaṃ etehīti vā atthena jūtasaddavacanīyataṃ nātivattanti.
analyzed: jaya parājayam vai atthena jūta sadda vacanīya tam na ativattanti
translated: Or they do not go beyond the meaning of the word “gambling” in the sense of going, proceeding, to winning and losing by means of these.

original: 15. Pamāṇātikkantāsananti “aṭṭhaṅgulapādakaṃ kāretabbaṃ sugataṅgulenā”ti vuttappamāṇato
analyzed: pamāṇa atikkanta āsanam ti aṭṭha aṅgula pādakam kāretabbam sugata ṅgulena ati vutta ppamāṇato
translated: “A seat of more than the right measure”: a seat that exceeds the right measure stated thus: “The legs should be eight standard fingerbreadths long” .

original: atikkantāsanaṃ. Kammavasena payojanato “anuyuttā viharantīti padaṃ apekkhitvā”ti
analyzed: atikkanta āsanam kamma vasena payojanataḥ anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti padam apekkhitvā iti
translated: “In the sense of the purpose of the action”: this is said with reference to the words “they live devoted to it.”

original: vuttaṃ. Vāḷarūpānīti āharimāni sīhabyagghādivāḷarūpāni. Vuttañhi bhikkhunivibhaṅge
analyzed: vuttam vāḷa rūpāni iti āharimāni sīha byaggha ādi vāḷa rūpāni vuttam hi bhikkhuni vibhaṅge
translated: “Animal figures”: these are the figures of lions, tigers, etc., that are brought in. For it is said in the Bhikkhunī Vibhaṅga:

original: “pallaṅko nāma āharimehi vāḷehi kato”ti “akappiyarūpākulo akappiyamañco pallaṅko”ti
analyzed: pallaṅkaḥ nāma akappiya rūpa ākulo akappiya mañco pallaṅkoti
translated: “A couch is one made with brought-in animal figures.” “A couch is a couch with unsuitable figures and unsuitable adornment.”

original: sārasamāse vuttaṃ. Dīghalomako mahākojavoti caturaṅgulādhikalomo kāḷavaṇṇo mahākojavo.
analyzed: sāra samāse vuttam dīghalomakaḥ mahākojavaḥ ti catur aṅgula adhika lomo kāḷavaṇṇo mahākojavaḥ
translated: It is said in the Sārasangaha: “The Long-haired has a big mane, four fingers in excess, black in colour, and a big mane.

original: Kuvuccati pathavī, tassaṃ javati sobhanavitthaṭavasenāti kojavo. “Caturaṅgulādhikāni
analyzed: pathavī catur aṅgula adhikāni
translated: It is called a kuva, because it runs on the ground, with a beautiful spread-out gait. ‘Its hairs are four fingers in excess,

translated: it is said,’ so they say it is circular below four fingers. The Single-haired and the Single-tuft are

analyzed: visesa dassanam etam tasmai yadi tāsu na pavisati vaṭṭati iti gahetabbam vāna vicittam ti
translated: a distinguishing description, therefore if it does not enter into those, it should be taken as circular. The Variegated is

analyzed: bhitti chada ādi ākārena vānena sibbanena vicitram miga loma pakatamattharaṇam
translated: variegated with a craft such as painting walls, etc. The Wool-spread is a spread made of the wool of the miga deer.

original: Setattharaṇoti dhavalattharaṇo. Sītatthikehi sevitabbattā setattharaṇo, “bahumudulomako”tipi
analyzed: setattharaṇo ti dhavalattharaṇaḥ sītatthikehi sevitabbattā setattharaṇaḥ bahu mudu lomakaḥ tipi
translated: The White-spread is a white spread. Because it is used in cold weather, it is called a white-spread, and they also say ‘with many soft hairs.’

original: vadanti. Ghanapupphakoti sabbathā pupphākārasampanno. “Uṇṇāmayattharaṇoti uṇṇāmayo
analyzed: vadanti ghana pupphako ti sabbathā puppha ākāra sampannaḥ uṇṇāmaya ttharaṇo ti uṇṇāmayaḥ
translated: The Flowery is endowed with the appearance of flowers all round. ‘The Wool-spread is made of wool,

original: lohitattharaṇo”ti sāratthadīpaniyaṃ vuttaṃ. Āmalakapattākārāhi pupphapantīhi yebhuyyato🔽katattā āmalakapattotipi vuccati.
analyzed: lohitattharaṇo ti sāratthadīpaniyam vuttam āmalaka patta ākārāhi puppha pantīhi yebhuyyataḥ  kata ttā āmalaka patto tipi vuccati
translated: It is called the “rose-apple-leaf bed” because it is mostly made of flower-clusters shaped like rose-apple leaves.

original: Tiṇṇaṃ tūlānanti rukkhatūlalatātūlapoṭakītūlasaṅkhātānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ tūlānaṃ. Uditaṃ dvīsu
analyzed: tiṇṇam tūlānan ti rukkha tūla latā tūla poṭakī tūla saṅkhātānam tiṇṇam tūlānam uditam dvīsu
translated: “Of three kinds of cotton wool”: of the three kinds of cotton wool called tree cotton wool, kapok, and silk-cotton tree wool.

original: lomaṃ dasā yassāti uddalomī i-kārassa akāraṃ, ta-kārassa lopaṃ, dvibhāvañca katvā.
analyzed: lomam yassa ati uddalomī ikārassa akāram takārassa lopam dvi bhāvam ca katvā
translated: “With hair on one side” (uddalomī): the i is changed to a, the ta is elided, and the u is reduplicated.

original: Ekasmiṃ ante lomaṃ dasā yassāti ekantalomī. Ubhayattha kecīti sārasamāsācariyā, uttaravihāravāsino
analyzed: ekasmin ante lomam dasā yassa ati ekantalomī ubhayattha keci iti uttaravihāra vāsinaḥ
translated: “With hair on one end” (ekantalomī): some teachers of the Sāraṇī say this, and so do the residents of the Northern Monastery.

original: ca. Tesaṃ vāde pana uditamekato uggataṃ lomamayaṃ pupphaṃ yassāti uddalomī vuttanayena.
analyzed: ca tesam vāde pana uditam ekatas uggatam loma mayam puppham yassa ati uddalomī vutta nayena
translated: But in their view the word uddalomī is formed according to the rule: “uddhaṃ ekato uggataṃ lomamayaṃ pupphaṃ yassa” .

analyzed: ubhatas antatas ekam sadisam loma mayam puppham yassa ati ekantalomī iti vacana atthaḥ vinaya ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: The word ekantalomī is formed according to the rule: “ubhato antato ekaṃ sadisaṃ lomamayaṃ pupphaṃ yassa” .🔽But in the Vinaya Commentary it is said:

original: pana “uddalomīti ekato uggatalomaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. ‘Uddhalomī’tipi pāṭho. Ekantalomīti
analyzed: pana uddalomī iti ekatas uggata lomam uṇṇāmayattharaṇam uddhalomī iti pi ekantalomī iti
translated: “Uddalomī: a bedspread with hair growing upwards. The reading is also uddhalomī. Ekantalomī:

original: ubhato uggatalomaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇa”nti vuttaṃ, nāmamattamesa viseso. Atthato pana
analyzed: ubhatas uggata lomam vuttam nāma mattamesa visesaḥ atthato pana
translated: and the other has hair that is raised on both sides and is a mat of rushes. ” This is the only difference in the name. But in the matter

original: aggahitāvaseso aṭṭhakathādvayepi natthīti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: aggahita avasesaḥ aṭṭhakathā dvaye pi na atthi iti daṭṭhabbo
translated: of the rest, which is not included, there is no difference in the two commentaries.

original: Koseyyañca kaṭṭissañca kaṭṭissāni virūpekasesavasena. Tehi pakatamattharaṇaṃ kaṭṭissaṃ.
analyzed: koseyyam ca kaṭṭissam ca kaṭṭissāni virūpa ekasesa vasena tehi pakatam attharaṇam kaṭṭissam
translated: The Koseyya and the Kaṭissa are distinguished by the difference of the warp and woof. The Kaṭissa is a mat of plain weave.

original: Etadevatthaṃ dassetuṃ “koseyyakaṭṭissamayapaccattharaṇa”nti vuttaṃ, koseyyasuttānamantarantaraṃ
analyzed: etat eva attham dassetum koseyya kaṭṭissamaya paccattharaṇam ti vuttam koseyya suttānam antarantaram
translated: In order to show the meaning of this, it is said, “a mat of Koseyya and Kaṭissa warp and woof.” The warp and woof of Koseyya is

original: suvaṇṇamayasuttāni pavesetvā vītamattharaṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Suvaṇṇasuttaṃ kira “kaṭṭissaṃ,🔽kassaṭa”nti ca vadanti. Teneva “koseyyakassaṭamaya”nti ācariyadhammapālattherena
analyzed: suvaṇṇa maya suttāni pavesetvā vītam attharaṇam ti vuttam hoti suvaṇṇa suttam kira kaṭṭissam  kassaṭanti ca vadanti tena iva ācariya dhammapāla ttherena
translated: said to be the warp and woof of gold thread, which is inserted between the warp and woof of Koseyya. The warp and woof of gold is said to be🔽“Kaṭissa,”🔽and “Kassaṭa.” Therefore it is said by the teacher Dhammapāla,

original: vuttaṃ. Kaṭṭissaṃ nāma vākavisesotipi vadanti. Ratanaparisibbitanti ratanehi saṃsibbitaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam kaṭṭissam nāma vāka visesaḥ ti pi vadanti ratana parisibbitanti ratanehi saṃsibbitam
translated: “Koseyya and Kassaṭa.” Some say that Kaṭissa is a kind of reed. Ratana-parisibbitam means covered with jewels.

analyzed: suvaṇṇa littanti keci ratana parisibbana rahitam vinaye iti vinaya ṭṭhakatham
translated: Some say that it is sprinkled with gold. Suddhakosayyam means without the covering of jewels. Vinaye means in the Vinaya Commentary,

original: vinayapariyāyaṃ vā sandhāya vuttaṃ. Idha hi suttantikapariyāye “ṭhapetvā tūlikaṃ
analyzed: vinaya pariyāyam vā sandhāya vuttam idha hi suttantika pariyāye ṭhapetvā tūlikam
translated: or it was said with reference to the Vinaya method. For in the method of the Suttanta books it is said: “Except for cotton down,

analyzed: sabbān eva gonaka ādīni ratana parisibbitāni vaṭṭanti iti vuttam vinaya pariyāyam pana

translated: it is allowable to use only pure silk, because it must be kept in a high place after being fumigated with incense. The rest is not allowable. This is the decision.

original: suttantikapariyāye pana ratanaparisibbanarahitāpi tūlikā na vaṭṭati, itarāni vaṭṭanti,

analyzed: sace pi tāni ratana parisibbitāni bhūmattharaṇa vasena yathānurūpam mañca pīṭha ādīsu  ca upanetum vaṭṭanti iti suttanta desanāya gaha ṭṭhānam pi vasena vutta ttā tesam saṅgaṇhana attham  ṭhapetvā āpe na vaṭṭanti iti vuttanti apare dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyanti katthaci pāṭhaḥ
translated: Even if they are sprinkled with perfume, they are allowable to be brought and used on the beds and chairs, etc., according to the circumstances, as floor coverings.🔽Others say that the words “except for cotton down” were said in order to include householders, because the teaching of the suttantas is given with reference to both monks and householders.🔽In some places the reading is “in the Dīgha-nikāya commentary.”

analyzed: porāṇa dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyanti atthaḥ nacca yogganti naccitum pahonakam karonti
translated: The meaning is “in the ancient Dīgha-nikāya commentary.” “Dancing” : that which is fit for dancing.

translated: “The double-line and single-line,🔽That is the Kuttaka dance, the best of dances,

translated: “ajinappaveṇī”ti, uparūpari ṭhapetvā sibbanavasena hi santatibhūtā “paveṇī”ti vuccati.

translated: Uttaraṃ uparibhāgaṃ chādetīti uttaracchado, vitānaṃ. Tampi lohitameva idhādhippetanti

analyzed: āha ratta vitānena ati yam vattati tam ettha sesaḥ saṃsibbita bhāvena
translated: He said, “With a canopy.” “What is used is with a border” means that the rest is included by the word “used” because it is connected with the canopy.

original: saddhiṃ vattatīti attho. Rattavitānesu ca kāsāvaṃ vaṭṭati, kusumbhādirattameva na
analyzed: saddhim vattati iti atthaḥ ratta vitānesu ca kāsāvam vaṭṭati kusumbha ādi rattam eva na
translated: And only the saffron-coloured is allowable for canopies; the red of safflower, etc., is not allowable.

analyzed: vaṭṭati tat ca kho sabba rattam eva yam pana nānā vaṇṇam vāna cittam vā lepa cittam vā
translated: And that is only all red. But what is many-coloured or has a pattern is allowable.

analyzed: tat vaṭṭati paccattharaṇassa iva padhāna ttā tad paṭibaddham seta vitānam pi na vaṭṭati iti
translated: Because only the spread is important, a white canopy connected with that is not allowable.

original: vuttaṃ. Ubhatoti ubhayattha mañcassa sīsabhāge, pādabhāge cāti attho. Etthāpi sauttaracchade🔽viya vinicchayo. Padumavaṇṇaṃ vāti nātirattaṃ sandhāyāha. Vicitraṃ vāti pana sabbathā
analyzed: vuttam ubhatas ti ubhayattha mañcassa sīsa bhāge pāda bhāge ca ati attho ettha api sa uttaracchade  viya vinicchayo paduma vaṇṇam vāti na ati rattam sandhāya āha vicitram vāti pana sabbathā
translated: “On both sides” means at the head of the bed and at the foot of the bed. Here too the decision is as in the case of “with a border.”

original: kappiyattā vuttaṃ, na pana ubhato upadhānesu akappiyattā. Na hi lohitaka-saddo citte🔽vaṭṭati. Paṭalikaggahaṇeneva cittakassāpi attharaṇassa saṅgahetabbappasaṅgato. Sace
analyzed: kappiya ttā vuttam na pana ubhatas upadhānesu a kappiya ttā na hi lohitaka saddaḥ citte 🔽vaṭṭati paṭalika ggahaṇena iva cittakassa api attharaṇassa saṅgahetabba ppasaṅgataḥ sace
translated: “The colour of a lotus” is said with reference to not too red. But “variegated” is said because it is allowable in every way, not because it is not allowable in the case of a spread on both sides. For the word “red” does not apply to a pattern.🔽And it is not proper to include a spread with a pattern by the mention of “striped.”

original: pamāṇayuttanti vuttamevatthaṃ byatirekato samatthetuṃ āha “mahāupadhānaṃ pana paṭikkhitta”nti.
analyzed: pamāṇa yuttam ti vuttam eva attham byatirekataḥ samatthetum āha mahā upadhānam pana
translated: The meaning of the words “to the right measure” has already been given. He gives a reason for the excess by saying “but a large pillow is prohibited.”

analyzed: mahā upadhānam ti ca pamāṇa atikkantam upadhānam sīsa pamāṇam eva hi tassa pamāṇam vuttam ca
translated: And “a large pillow” is a pillow that exceeds the right measure. The measure of it is the head, and it is said:

original: “anujānāmi bhikkhave, sīsappamāṇaṃ bibbohanaṃ kātu”nti sīsappamāṇañca nāma yassa🔽vitthārato tīsu kaṇṇesu dvinnaṃ kaṇṇānaṃ antaraṃ miniyamānaṃ vidatthi ceva caturaṅgulañca
analyzed: anujānāmi bhikkhave sīsa ppamāṇam bibbohanam kātunti sīsa ppamāṇam ca nāma yassa  vitthārato tīsu kaṇṇesu dvinnam kaṇṇānam antaram ca iva catur aṅgulam ca
translated: “Monks, I allow you to make a pillow the size of the head.”🔽And the size of the head is that which, when measured in three places—between the two ears and at the nape of the neck—is one cubit in width and four fingers in length.

original: hoti. Bibbohanassa majjhaṭṭhānaṃ tiriyato muṭṭhiratanaṃ hoti, dīghato pana diyaḍḍharatanaṃ
analyzed: hoti bibbohanassa majjha ṭṭhānam tiriyataḥ muṭṭhi ratanam hoti dīghataḥ pana diyaḍḍha ratanam
translated: The middle part of the pillow is one span in breadth and one and a half spans or two spans in length.

original: vā dviratanaṃ vā. Taṃ pana akappiyattāyeva paṭikkhittaṃ, na tu uccāsayanamahāsayanapariyāpannattā.
analyzed: vā dvi ratanam vā tam pana a kappiya ttāya iva paṭikkhittam na tu uccāsayana mahāsayana pariyāpanna ttā
translated: But it is prohibited because it is improper, not because it is included in the “high and luxurious” rule.🔽“Two”: the head pillow and the foot pillow.

original: Dvepīti sīsūpadhānaṃ, pādūpadhānañca. Paccattharaṇaṃ datvāti paccattharaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: dvepi iti sīsu upadhānam pādu upadhānam ca paccattharaṇam da tvā ati paccattharaṇam katvā
translated: “Having spread a coverlet”: having made a coverlet.

original: attharitvāti attho, idañca gilānameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tenāha senāsanakkhandhakavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: attharitvā ti attho idam ca gilānam eva sandhāya vuttam tena āha senāsana kkhandhaka vaṇṇanā ayam
translated: The meaning is: having spread out. And this is said with reference to the sick only. Hence it is said in the commentary on the chapter on resting places:

analyzed: a gilānassa api sīsu upadhānam ca pādu upadhānam ca ati dvayam eva vaṭṭati gilānassa bibbohanāni
translated: “Only two things are allowable for one who is not sick: a pillow for the head and a pillow for the feet. For one who is sick

original: santharitvā upari paccattharaṇaṃ katvā nipajjitumpi vaṭṭatī”ti vuttanayenevāti vinaye🔽bhagavatā vuttanayeneva. Kathaṃ pana vuttanti āha “vuttañheta”ntiādi. Yathā aṭṭhaṅgulapādakaṃ🔽hoti, evaṃ āsandiyā pādacchindanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Pallaṅkassa pana āharimāni vāḷarūpāni
analyzed: santharitvā upari paccattharaṇam katvā nipajjitum pi vaṭṭati iti vutta nayena iva ati vinaye  bhagavatā vutta nayena iva katham pana vuttam iti āha vuttam ha etad iti ādi yathā aṭṭhaṅgula pādakam  hoti evam āsandiyā pāda chindanam veditabbam pallaṅkassa pana āharimāni vāḷa rūpāni
translated: it is allowable to lie down after spreading out the bedding and putting a sheet over it.”🔽In the Vinaya🔽it is said by the Blessed One. But how is it said? He says, “It is said thus,” and so on. It should be understood that the legs of the couch are to be cut down so that they are eight fingerbreadths high.🔽But in the case of a chair, the legs are to be cut down so that they are four fingerbreadths high.

original: āharitvā puna appaṭibaddhatākāraṇampi bhedanameva. Vijaṭetvāti jaṭaṃ nibbedhetvā.🔽Bibbohanaṃ kātunti tāni vijaṭitatūlāni anto pakkhipitvā bibbohanaṃ kātuṃ.
analyzed: āharitvā puna appaṭibaddha tā kāraṇam pi bhedanam eva vijaṭetvā ati jaṭam nibbedhetvā  bibbohanam kātunti tāni vijaṭita tūlāni antar pakkhipitvā bibbohanam kātum
translated: The meaning of “having unwoven” is: having removed the weaving.🔽The meaning of “having made a pillow” is: having put the unwoven cotton inside, having made a pillow.

original: 16. “Mātukucchito nikkhantadārakāna”nti etena aṇḍajajalābujānameva gahaṇaṃ, mātukucchito
analyzed: mātukucchitaḥ etena aṇḍa ja jalābu jānam eva gahaṇam mātukucchitaḥ
translated: By the words “of children who have come out of the mother’s womb” only the egg-born and womb-born are included.

original: nikkhantattāti ca kāraṇaṃ dasseti, tenevāyamattho sijjhati “anekadivasāni antosayanahetu
analyzed: nikkhanta ttā iti ca kāraṇam dasseti tena iva ayam attho sijjhati aneka divasāni antosayana hetu
translated: and he shows the reason for this by the words “because of the long confinement in the womb,” and so this meaning is established: “For many days he was confined in the womb,

original: esa gandho”ti. Ucchādenti ubbaṭṭenti. Saṇṭhānasampādanatthanti susaṇṭhānatāsampādanatthaṃ.
analyzed: esa gandho ti ucchādenti ubbaṭṭenti saṇṭhāna sampādana tham ti su saṇṭhāna tā sampādana tham
translated: And he shows the reason for this by the words “because of the smell of the oil” . original: Parimaddantīti samantato maddanti.
analyzed: parimaddanti iti samantataḥ maddanti
translated: They “rubbed it all over” by rubbing it all round.

original: Tesaṃyeva dārakānanti puññavantānameva dārakānaṃ. Tesameva hi pakaraṇānurūpatāya
analyzed: tesam yeva dārakānanti puññavantānam eva dārakānam tesam eva hi pakaraṇa anurūpa tāya
translated: “Those very children” means only those children who are fortunate. For only they are mentioned in accordance with the context.

original: gahaṇaṃ. Mahāmallānanti mahataṃ bāhuyuddhakārakānaṃ. Ādāso nāma maṇḍanakapakatikānaṃ
analyzed: mahatam bāhuyuddha kārakānam ādāsaḥ nāma maṇḍanaka pakatikānam
translated: “Great wrestlers” means great fighters with the arms. “A mirror” is a particular kind of thing made of brass, copper, etc.,

original: manussānaṃ attano mukhachāyāpassanatthaṃ kaṃsalohādīhi kato bhaṇḍaviseso. Tādisaṃ
analyzed: manussānam attanaḥ mukha chāyā passana ttham kaṃsa loha ādīhi kataḥ bhaṇḍa visesaḥ tādisam
translated: by people who are skilled in ornamentation, for the purpose of looking at one’s own facial reflection.

original: sandhāya “yaṃ kiñci…pe… na vaṭṭatī”ti vuttaṃ. Alaṅkārañjanameva na bhesajjañjanaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya yam kiñcipe na vaṭṭati iti vuttam alaṅkāra añjanam eva na bhesajja añjanam
translated: “Any kind of ornament” is said with reference to such a thing. It is only the smearing of the face with ornaments that is prohibited, not the smearing of the face with medicine.🔽For the purpose of ornamentation is intended there, and that is the intended meaning there. In the world the word “garland”

original: Maṇḍanānuyogassa hi adhippetattā tamidhānadhippetaṃ. Loke mālā-saddo baddhamālāyameva
analyzed: maṇḍana anuyogassa hi adhippeta ttā tam idha an adhippetam loke mālā saddaḥ baddha mālāyam eva
translated: refers only to a bound garland.

original: “mālā mālyaṃ pupphadāme”ti vacanato. Sāsane pana suddhapupphesupi niruḷhoti āha “abaddhamālā🔽vā”ti. Kāḷapīḷakādīnanti kāḷavaṇṇapīḷakādīnaṃ. Mattikakakkanti osadhehi abhisaṅkhataṃ🔽yogamattikācuṇṇaṃ. Dentīti vilepenti. Caliteti vikārāpajjanavasena calanaṃ patte,🔽kupiteti attho. Tenāti sāsapakakkena. Doseti kāḷapīḷakādīnaṃ hetubhūte lohitadose.🔽Khāditeti apanayanavasena khādite. Sannisinneti tādise duṭṭhalohite parikkhīṇe. Mukhacuṇṇakenāti
analyzed: mālā mālyam puppha dāmā iti vacanataḥ sa āsane pana suddha pupphesu pi niruḷhaḥ iti āha abaddha mālā  vāti kāḷa pīḷaka ādīnam ti kāḷa vaṇṇa pīḷaka ādīnam osadhehi osadhehi  yogamattikā cuṇṇam denti iti vilepenti calitā iti vikāra āpajjana vasena calanam patte  kupitā iti tena ati sāsapa kakkena dose iti kāḷa pīḷaka ādīnam hetu bhūte lohita dose  khādita iti apanayana vasena khādite sannisinnā iti tādise duṭṭha lohite parikkhīṇe mukha cuṇṇakena ati
translated: “Garland” is a wreath of flowers. But in the Dispensation it is also fixed on pure flowers. Hence he said “without a garland” . “Black pimples, etc.”: black pimples, etc. “Medicinal clay”: medicinal clay mixed with herbs. “Smears”: applies. “Moves”: the meaning is that it moves in the bowl by way of causing a change, i.e. it becomes agitated. “By that”: by the salt-water. “Blisters”: blood-blisters that are the cause of black pimples, etc. “When it is eaten”: when it is eaten by way of removal. “When it is settled”: when such bad blood is exhausted. “With face-powder”:

original: mukhavilepanena. Cuṇṇentīti vilimpenti. Taṃ sabbanti mattikākakkasāsapatilahaliddikakkadānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: mukha vilepanena cuṇṇenti iti vilimpenti tam sabbanti mattikā kakka sāsapa tilaha liddi kakka dāna saṅkhātam
translated: “Garland” is a wreath or a chaplet. But in the Dispensation a garland is understood as a mere bunch of flowers, so he said “a garland that is not bound” . “Blackheads, etc.”: blackheads, pimples, etc. “Clay unguent”: clay powder mixed with herbs. “Smear”: rub in. “Move”: the meaning is, “agitate” by causing a change in the skin. “By that”: by the clay unguent. “Blemish”: the blood blemish that is the cause of blackheads, etc. “When it is eaten”: when it is eaten by being removed. “When it is settled”: when the bad blood of that kind is exhausted. “Face powder”: face ointment. “Powder”: smear. “All that”: the face powder called clay unguent, clay unguent powder, sesame powder, turmeric powder, and face ointment—

original: mukhacuṇṇaṃ, mukhavilepanañca na vaṭṭati. Atthānukkamasambhavato hi ayaṃ padadvayassa
analyzed: mukha cuṇṇam mukha vilepanam ca na vaṭṭati attha anukkama sambhavataḥ hi ayam pada dvayassa
translated: all that is not allowable. For this pair of terms is given in the order of their meaning.

original: vaṇṇanā. Mukhacuṇṇasaṅkhātaṃ mukhavilepananti vā padadvayassa tulyādhikaraṇavasena atthavibhāvanā.🔽Hatthabandhanti hatthe bandhitabbamābharaṇaṃ, taṃ pana saṅkhakapālādayoti āha “hatthe”tiādi.
analyzed: vaṇṇanā mukha cuṇṇa saṅkhātam mukha vilepanan ti vā pada dvayassa tulya adhikaraṇa vasena attha vibhāvanā  hatthabandhanti hatthe bandhitabbam ābharaṇam tam pana saṅkha kapāla ādayaḥ iti āha hattha itiādi
translated: The explanation of the two terms “face-powder” and “face-ointment” is by way of their having the same reference.🔽“Arm ornament” is an ornament to be worn on the arm. But that is a shell, a cup, etc., so he says “arm ornament” and so on.

original: Saṅkho eva kapālaṃ tathā. “Apare”tiādinā yathākkamaṃ “sikhābandha”ntiādi padānamatthaṃ
analyzed: eva kapālam tathā aparā iti ādinā yathākkamam
translated: A shell itself is a cup. “Other” and so on explain the terms “hair-ornament” and so on respectively.

original: saṃvaṇṇeti. Tattha sikhanti cūḷaṃ. Cīrakaṃ nāma yena cūḷāya thirakaraṇatthaṃ, sobhanatthañca
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇā iti tattha sikhanti cūḷam cīrakam nāma yena cūḷāya thira karaṇa ttham sobhana ttham ca
translated: Herein, “hair” is a lock of hair. “Leather” is what is used for stiffening and beautifying the lock of hair.

original: vijjhati. Muttāya, muttā eva vā latā muttālatā, muttāvaḷi. Daṇḍo nāma catuhatthoti
analyzed: vijjhati muttāya muttā eva vā latā muttālatā muttāvaḷi daṇḍaḥ nāma catu hatthaḥ ti
translated: “Pearl-string” is a string of pearls. “Stick” is said to be four cubits long.

original: vuttaṃ “catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ vā”ti. Alaṅkatadaṇḍakanti pana tato omakaṃ rathayaṭṭhiādikaṃ🔽sandhāyāha. Bhesajjanāḷikanti bhesajjatumbaṃ. Pattādiolambanaṃ vāmaṃseyeva aciṇṇanti
analyzed: vuttam catu hattha daṇḍam vāti alaṅkata daṇḍakan ti pana tatas omakam ratha yaṭṭhi ādikam 🔽sandhāya āha bhesajja nāḷikam iti bhesajja tumbam patta ādi olambanam
translated: “Or a stick four cubits long” is said. But “decorated stick” is said with reference to a toy stick, a toy whip, etc., which are less than that.🔽“Medicinal tube” is a medicine bag. Or a bag for carrying a water-strainer is a custom only in the left ear.

original: vuttaṃ “vāmapasse olaggita”nti. Kaṇṇikā nāma kūṭaṃ, tāya ca ratanena ca parikkhitto
analyzed: vuttam vāma passe olaggitan ti kaṇṇikā nāma kūṭam tāya ca ratanena ca parikkhittaḥ
translated: “On the left side” is said. A “fringe” is a border. It is surrounded by a jewel and a fringe.

original: koso yassa tathā. Pañcavaṇṇasuttasibbitanti nīlapītalohitodātamañjiṭṭhavasena pañcavaṇṇehi🔽suttehi sibbitaṃ tividhampi chattaṃ. Ratanamattāyāmaṃ caturaṅgulavitthatanti tesaṃ
analyzed: kosaḥ yassa tathā nīla pīta lohita udāta mañjiṭṭha vasena pañca vaṇṇehi  suttehi sibbitam tividham pi chattam ratana matta āyāmam catur aṅgula vitthatanti tesam
translated: A “jewel” is a jewel. “Made of five-colored thread” is made of five-colored thread, namely blue, yellow, red, white, and black.

original: paricayaniyāmena vā nalāṭe bandhituṃ pahonakappamāṇena vā vuttaṃ. “Kesantaparicchedaṃ
analyzed: paricaya niyāmena vā nalāṭe bandhitum pahona kappamāṇena vā vuttam kesanta paricchedam
translated: The three kinds of umbrellas are mentioned. “A jewel one cubit long and four fingers wide” is said according to the measure of their familiarity or the measure of being able to tie it on the forehead.

original: dassetvā”ti etena tadanajjhottharaṇavasena bandhanākāraṃ dasseti. Meghamukheti abbhantare.
analyzed: dassetvā iti etena tad an ajjhottharaṇa vasena bandhana ākāram dasseti megha mukha iti abbhantare
translated: “Having shown the boundary of the hair” shows the way of tying it by not going beyond it. “In the middle” is in the middle of the fringe.

original: “Maṇi”nti idaṃ siromaṇiṃ sandhāya vuttanti āha “cūḷāmaṇi”nti, cūḷāyaṃ maṇinti attho.🔽Camarassa ayaṃ cāmaro, sveva vālo, tena katā bījanī cāmaravālabījanī. Aññāsaṃ pana
analyzed: maṇin ti idam siromaṇim sandhāya vuttan ti āha cūḷāmaṇin ti cūḷāyam maṇin ti attho  camarassa ayam cāmaro su eva vālo tena katā bījanī cāmara vāla bījanī aññāsam pana
translated: “Jewel” is said with reference to a crest jewel. “Crest jewel” is the meaning.

original: makasabījanīvākamayabījanīusīramayabījanīmorapiñchamayabījanīnaṃ, vidhūpanatālavaṇṭānañca
analyzed: makasa bīja nīvāka maya bīja nī usīra maya bīja nī morapiñcha maya bījanīnam vidhūpana tāla vaṇṭānam ca
translated: This is the hide of a spotted deer. The hide itself is the hair. The fan made of that is a fan of spotted deer hair. But other fans are made of peacock feathers, made of bamboo, made of reeds, and made of palm leaves.

original: kappiyattā tassāyeva gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: kappiya ttā tassāya iva gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam
translated: It should be regarded as the taking of that itself because it is allowable.

original: 17. Duggatito, saṃsārato ca niyyāti etenāti niyyānaṃ, saggamaggo, mokkhamaggo ca.
analyzed: duggatitaḥ saṃsārataḥ ca niyyāti etena ati niyyānam sagga maggo mokkha maggo ca
translated: It is a going out because one goes out by it from the bad destinations and from the round of rebirths. It is the path to heaven and the path to liberation.

original: Taṃ niyyānamarahati, tasmiṃ vā niyyāne niyuttā, taṃ vā niyyānaṃ phalabhūtaṃ etissāti
analyzed: tam niyyānam arahati tasmin vā niyyāne niyuttā tam vā niyyānam phala bhūtam etissa ati
translated: It is fit for that going out, or it is occupied with that going out, or it goes to that going out which is the fruit,

original: niyyānikā, vacīduccaritakilesato niyyātīti vā niyyānikā ī-kārassa rassattaṃ, ya-kārassa
analyzed: niyyānikā vacīduccarita kilesataḥ niyyāti iti vā niyyānikā īkārassa rassattam yakārassa
translated: thus it is “conducive to going out” . Or alternatively, it is conducive to going out from the defilement of verbal misconduct,🔽by making the ī of niyyānika short and changing the ya to ka.🔽For the word aniyya is expressive of the meaning of the reduplicated aorist.

original: ca ka-kāraṃ katvā. Anīya-saddo hi bahulā katvatthābhidhāyako. Cetanāya saddhiṃ samphappalāpavirati
analyzed: ca kakāram katvā hi cetanāya saddhim
translated: Herein, the abstention from idle chatter together with the volition is intended.

original: idha adhippetā. Tappaṭipakkhato aniyyānikā, samphappalāpo, tassā bhāvo aniyyānikattaṃ,
analyzed: idha adhippetā tad paṭipakkhataḥ aniyyānikā samphappalāpaḥ tassāḥ bhāvaḥ aniyyānika ttam
translated: It is not conducive to going out because it is the opposite of that,🔽thus it is “not conducive to going out” .

original: tasmā aniyyānikattā. Tiracchānabhūtāti tirokaraṇabhūtā vibandhanabhūtā. Sopi nāmāti
analyzed: tasmai tiracchāna bhūtā ati tirokaraṇa bhūtā vibandhana bhūtā sā upi nāma ati
translated: The state of being an animal is the state of being a hindrance, a state of being an obstruction.🔽The word “even” here is in the sense of contempt.

original: ettha nāma-saddo garahāyaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānabhāveti aniccatāpaṭisaṃyuttattā catusaccakammaṭṭhānabhāve.
analyzed: ettha nāma saddo garahā ayam kammaṭṭhāna bhāve iti anicca tā paṭisaṃyutta ttā catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna bhāve
translated: In the sense of a meditation subject: because it is concerned with impermanence, it is a meditation subject dealing with the four noble truths.

original: Kāmassādavasenāti kāmasaṅkhātaassādavasena. Saha atthenāti sātthakaṃ, hitapaṭisaṃyuttanti
analyzed: kāma ssāda vasena ati kāma saṅkhāta assāda vasena saha atthena ati sa atthakam hita paṭisaṃyuttanti
translated: ‘In the sense of gratification in sensual desires’ means in the sense of gratification called ‘sensual desire’. ‘With meaning’ means ‘having meaning’, ‘connected with welfare’.

original: attho. Upāhanāti yānakathāsambandhaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Suṭṭhu nivesitabboti suniviṭṭho.
analyzed: atthaḥ upāhanā ti yāna kathā sambandham sandhāya vuttam suṭṭhu nivesitabbaḥ iti su niviṭṭhaḥ
translated: The meaning is this. ‘Footwear’ is said in the sense of the connection with the talk of vehicles. ‘Well-placed’ means well-arranged.

original: Tathā dunniviṭṭho. Gāma-saddena gāmavāsī janopi gahitoti āha “asukagāmavāsino”tiādi.🔽Sūrakathāti ettha sūra-saddo vīravācakoti dasseti “sūro ahosī”ti iminā. Visikhā nāma🔽maggasanniveso, idha pana visikhāgahaṇena tannivāsinopi gahitā “sabbo gāmo āgato”tiādīsu
analyzed: tathā dunniviṭṭhaḥ gāma saddena gāma vāsī janaḥ api gahitaḥ iti āha asuka gāma vāsinā itiādi  sūra kathā ti ettha sūra saddo vīra vācakaḥ ti dasseti sūraḥ ahosi iti iminā visikhā nāma  magga sannivesaḥ idha pana visikhā gahaṇena tad nivāsinaḥ api gahitā sabbaḥ gāmaḥ āgataḥ ti ādīsu
translated: ‘Ill-placed’ is likewise. The word ‘village’ includes the people who live in the village. Therefore he said: “The people who live in such and such a village” and so on.🔽‘Talk of heroes’ . Here the word ‘hero’ shows the meaning of ‘brave’. By this he shows: “He was a hero.” ‘A path’ is a place for the arrangement of a path. But here by the word ‘path’ the people who live there are included,

original: viya, tenevāha “saddhā pasannā”tiādi.🔽Kumbhassa ṭhānaṃ nāma udakaṭṭhānanti vuttaṃ “udakaṭṭhānakathā”ti. Udakatitthakathātipi
analyzed: tena iva āha saddhā pasannā atiādi  kumbhassa ṭhānam nāma udaka ṭhānanti vuttam udaka ṭṭhāna kathā ati udaka tittha kathā atipi
translated: as in such passages as: “The whole village has come.” Therefore he said: “The faithful and the confident” and so on.🔽‘A place for a water-pot’ is said to be a place for water. ‘Talk of a water-pot’ is also called

original: vuccati tattheva samavarodhato. Apica kumbhassa karaṇaṭṭhānaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānaṃ. Tadapadesena
analyzed: vuccati tattha eva samavarodhato api ca kumbhassa karaṇa ṭṭhānam kumbhaṭṭhānam tad apadesena
translated: a talk of a bathing place because of the restriction to that place. Furthermore, ‘a place for a water-pot’ is a place for making a water-pot. By that place

original: pana kumbhadāsiyo vuttāti dasseti “kumbhadāsikathā vā”ti iminā. Pubbe petā kālaṅkatāti
analyzed: pana kumbha dāsiyaḥ vuttā ati dasseti kumbha dāsi kathā vā ti iminā pubbe petā kālaṅkatā ti
translated: but the story of the slave girls is shown by the words “the story of the slave girls” .

original: pubbapetā. “Peto pareto kālaṅkato”ti hi pariyāyavacanaṃ. Heṭṭhā vuttanayamatidisituṃ
analyzed: pubba petā peto paretaḥ kālaṅkato ti hi pariyāya vacanam heṭṭhā vutta nayam atidisitum
translated: “The former dead” are the pubbapeta . For “dead,” “passed away,” and “deceased” are synonyms.🔽In order to illustrate the method stated above,

original: “tatthā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha atiādi vuttam
translated: “therein” is said.

original: Purimapacchimakathāhi vimuttāti idhāgatāhi purimāhi, pacchimāhi ca kathāhi vimuttā.
analyzed: purima pacchima kathāhi vimuttā ati idha āgatāhi purimāhi pacchimāhi ca kathāhi vimuttā
translated: “Free from the former and the latter talk” : free from the former and the latter talk that has come here.🔽“Of various natures” : he states the synonym of the word atta .

original: Nānāsabhāvāti atta-saddassa sabhāvapariyāyabhāvamāha. Asukena nāmāti pajāpatinā brahmunā,🔽issarena vā. Uppattiṭhitisambhārādivasena lokaṃ akkhāyati etāyāti lokakkhāyikā, sā🔽pana lokāyatasamaññe vitaṇḍasatthe nissitā sallāpakathāti dasseti “lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā”ti
analyzed: nānā sabhāvā ti atta saddassa sabhāva pariyāya bhāvam āha asukena nāma ati pajāpatinā brahmunā  issarena vā uppatti ṭhiti sambhāra ādi vasena lokam akkhāyati etāya ati lokakkhāyikā sā  pana lokāyata samaññe vitaṇḍa satthe nissitā sallāpa kathā ati dasseti lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā ati
translated: “By some” : by Pajapati Brahma,🔽or by the Lord.🔽“The talk of the world-expounding philosophers” : it is said that this is a talk of debate dependent on the world-view systems,🔽but he shows that it is a talk of mere chatter by the words “the talk of the world-view systems and of debate.”

original: iminā. Lokā bālajanā āyatanti ettha ussahanti vādassādenāti lokāyataṃ, loko vā hitaṃ
analyzed: iminā lokāḥ bāla janāḥ ettha ussahanti vāda ssādena ati lokāyatam lokaḥ vā hitam
translated: The world-view systems are so called because the foolish people here strive and exert themselves in them for the sake of the approval of their views.

original: na yatati na īhati tenāti lokāyataṃ. Tañhi ganthaṃ nissāya sattā puññakiriyāya cittampi
analyzed: na yatati na īhati tena ati lokāyatam tat hi gantham nissāya sattā puñña kiriyāya cittam pi
translated: It is called Lokāyata because it does not strive for or seek the world beyond. For by depending on that doctrine, beings do not even arouse a thought of merit.

original: na uppādenti. Aññamaññaviruddhaṃ, saggamokkhaviruddhaṃ vā kathaṃ tanonti etthāti
analyzed: na uppādenti aññamañña viruddham saggamokkha viruddham vā katham tanonti ettha ati
translated: It is called Vitanda because it is a discussion that is mutually contradictory or contradictory to heaven and liberation.

original: vitaṇḍo, viruddhena vā vādadaṇḍena tāḷenti ettha vādinoti vitaṇḍo, sabbattha niruttinayena padasiddhi.
analyzed: vitaṇḍaḥ viruddhena vā vāda daṇḍena tāḷenti ettha vādino ti vitaṇḍo sabbattha nirutti nayena
translated: Or it is called Vitanda because it is a discussion in which disputants strike each other with the rod of contradictory arguments.

original: Sāgaradevena khatoti ettha sāgararañño puttehi khatotipi vadanti. Vijjati pavedanahetubhūtā
analyzed: sāgaradevena khatoti ettha sāgararañño puttehi khatoti pi vadanti vijjati pavedana hetu bhūtā
translated: In the word “Sāgaradevena khato,” some say it is “khato” because of the sons of the king of the ocean.

original: muddhā yassāti samuddo dha-kārassa da-kāraṃ katvā, saha-saddo cettha vijjamānatthavācako
analyzed: muddhā yassa ati samuddaḥ dhakārassa dakāram katvā saha saddaḥ ca ittha vijjamāna attha vācakaḥ
translated: The word “samuddo” is formed by changing the “dha” to “da” in “muddhā,” which is the cause of the designation. The word “saha” here has the meaning of existence,

original: “salomakosapakkhako”tiādīsu viya. Bhavoti vuddhi bhavati vaḍḍhatīti katvā. Vibhavoti
analyzed: saloma kosapakkhako ti ādīsu viya bhava ūti bhavati vaḍḍhati iti katvā
translated: like in “salomakosapakkhako” and so on. “Bhava” means growth, in the sense of “it becomes, it increases.” “Vibhava”

original: hāni tabbirahato. Dvandato pubbe suyyamāno itisaddo paccekaṃ yojetabboti āha “iti
analyzed: hāni tad virahataḥ dvandataḥ pubbe suyyamānaḥ iti saddaḥ paccekam yojetabbaḥ iti āha iti
translated: means loss, in the sense of “it is removed from that.” The word “iti” should be connected separately before “dvandato,” therefore it is said “iti

original: bhavo iti abhavo”ti. Yaṃ vā taṃ vāti yaṃ kiñci, atha taṃ aniyamanti attho. Abhūtañhi
analyzed: iti yam vā tam vā ati yam kiñci atha tam aniyamanti attho abhūtam hi
translated: Or else, the word “or” is used in the sense of “whatever” and “non-existence” in the sense of “non-restriction.”🔽For the teachers explain that “non-restriction” means “without exception.”

original: aniyamatthaṃ saha vikappena yaṃtaṃ-saddehi dīpenti ācariyā. Apica bhavoti sassato.
analyzed: aniyama attham saha vikappena yam tam saddehi dīpenti ācariyāḥ api ca bhavaḥ ti sassataḥ
translated: “Existence” means “eternity,” and “non-existence” means “annihilation.”

original: Abhavoti ucchedo. Bhavoti vā kāmasukhaṃ. Abhavoti attakilamatho.
analyzed: ucchedaḥ bhavoti vā kāma sukham abhavoti
translated: Or else, “existence” means sensual pleasure, and “non-existence” means self-mortification.

original: Iti imāya chabbidhāya itibhavābhavakathāya saddhiṃ bāttiṃsa tiracchānakathā nāma
analyzed: iti imāya chat bidhāya iti bhava abhava kathāya saddhim bāttiṃsa tiracchānakathāḥ nāma
translated: Thus, together with the six kinds of talk about existence and non-existence, there are thirty-two kinds of animal talk.

original: honti. Atha vā pāḷiyaṃ sarūpato anāgatāpi araññapabbatanadīdīpakathā iti-saddena
analyzed: honti atha vā pāḷiyam sarūpataḥ anāgatā api arañña pabbata nadī dīpa kathā iti saddena
translated: Or else, although the talk about the forest, the mountains, the rivers, and the islands is not given in the text in its own form, it is included by the word “or”

original: saṅgahetvā battiṃsa tiracchānakathāti vuccanti. Pāḷiyañhi “iti vā”ti ettha iti-saddo🔽pakārattho, vā-saddo vikappanattho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti “evaṃpakāraṃ, ito aññaṃ vā tādisaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahetvā battiṃsa tiracchānakathā ati vuccanti pāḷiyam hi iti vā ti ettha iti saddo  pakāra atthaḥ vā saddaḥ vikappana atthaḥ idam vuttam hoti evaṃpakāram itas aññam vā tādisam
translated: and is called “animal talk.” For in the text the word “or”🔽has the meaning of “thus” and the word “or” has the meaning of “alternative.” The passage should be analyzed as follows: “They live engaged in this kind of talk, or in other similar kinds of talk that are pointless.”

original: niratthakakathaṃ anuyuttā viharantī”ti, ādiattho vā iti-saddo iti vā iti evarūpā
analyzed: niratthaka katham anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti ādi atthaḥ vā iti saddo iti vā iti evarūpā
translated: Or else, the word “or” has the meaning of “and so on.”

original: “naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato”tiādīsu viya, iti evamādiṃ aññampi tādisaṃ
analyzed: nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanā paṭivirataḥ ti ādīsu viya iti evamādim aññam pi tādisam
translated: “He abstains from shows, etc.,” and so on. So too in other cases.

original: kathamanuyuttā viharantīti attho.
analyzed: katham anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti attho
translated: What is the meaning? They live devoted to talk that is connected.🔽“Disagreeable” is “disagreeable to grasp at,” and “disagreeable to grasp” is “disagreeable to grasp at.”🔽“Argumentative” is “having argumentation,” and “argumentation” is “the grasping of what is disagreeable.”🔽“Quarrelsome” is “having quarrels,” and “quarrels” is “the grasping of what is disagreeable.”

original: 18. Viruddhassa gahaṇaṃ viggaho, so yesanti viggāhikā, tesaṃ tathā, viruddhaṃ vā
analyzed: viruddhassa gahaṇam viggahaḥ saḥ yesanti viggāhikā tesam tathā viruddham vā
translated: “Bellicose” is “having belligerence,” and “belligerence” is “the grasping of what is disagreeable.”🔽“Connected” is “not contradictory.”🔽“Relevant” is “having relevance.”🔽“Having relevance” is “having a reason.”🔽“Having a reason” is “having a cause.”🔽“Having a cause” is “having a ground.”

original: gaṇhāti etāyāti viggāhikā, sāyeva kathā tathā. Sārambhakathāti upārambhakathā. Sahitanti
analyzed: gaṇhāti etāya ati viggāhikā sā āyā iva kathā tathā sa ārambha kathā ati upārambha kathā
translated: “Having a ground” is “having a basis.”🔽“Having a basis” is “having a support.”🔽“Having a support” is “having a foundation.”🔽“Having a foundation” is “having a footing.”🔽“Having a footing” is “having a stand.”

original: pubbāparāviruddhaṃ. Tatoyeva siliṭṭhaṃ. Taṃ pana atthakāraṇayuttatāyāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: pubba apara aviruddham tatas yeva siliṭṭham tam pana attha kāraṇa yutta tāya iti dassetuṃ
translated: “Having a stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”🔽“Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”

original: “atthayuttaṃ kāraṇayuttanti attho”ti vuttaṃ. Nti vacanaṃ. Parivattitvā ṭhitaṃ sapattagato🔽asamattho yodho viya na kiñci jānāsi, kintu sayameva parājesīti adhippāyo. Vādo dosoti
analyzed: attha yuttam kāraṇa yuttanti attho ti vuttam vacanam parivattitvā ṭhitam sa patta gataḥ  asamatthaḥ yodhaḥ viya na kiñci jānāsi kintu sayam eva parājesi iti adhippāyaḥ vādaḥ doso ti
translated: “Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”🔽“Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”🔽“Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”

original: pariyāyavacanaṃ. Tathā cara vicarāti. Tattha tatthāti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ācariyakule.
analyzed: pariyāya vacanam tathā cara tattha tattha ati tasmin tasmin ācariya kule
translated: “Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”🔽“Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”🔽“Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”

original: Nibbedhehīti mayā ropitaṃ vādaṃ vissajjehi.
analyzed: nibbedhehi iti mayā ropitam vādam vissajjehi
translated: “Having a place to stand on” is “having a place to stand.”🔽“Having a place to stand” is “having a place to stand on.”

original: 19. Dūtassa kammaṃ dūteyyaṃ, tassa kathā tathā, tassaṃ. Idha, amutrāti upayogatthe🔽bhummavacanaṃ, tenāha “asukaṃ nāma ṭhāna”nti. Vitthārato vinicchayo vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: dūtassa kammam dūteyyam tassa kathā tathā tassaṃ idha amutra ati upayoga tthe  bhumma vacanam tena āha asukam nāma ṭhānam ti vitthārataḥ vinicchayaḥ vinaya ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: The act of a messenger is a message; the talk about it is likewise. Here and there: the locative case is used in the sense of utilization. Hence he said, “in such and such a place.” The detailed explanation is given in the Vinaya Commentary.

original: vuttoti saṅkhepato idha dassetuṃ “saṅkhepato panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gihisāsananti yathāvuttaviparītaṃ
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti saṅkhepataḥ idha dassetum saṅkhepataḥ pana ātiādi vuttam gihi sāsanam ti yathā vutta viparītam
translated: Since it is given there, it is said here in brief, “In brief, however,” etc. The word of the house-holder is the Dispensation as described above, the opposite of which is the Dispensation.

original: sāsanaṃ. Aññesanti gihīnaññeva.
analyzed: sāsanam aññesanti
translated: Others: only householders.

original: 20. Tividhenāti sāmantajappanairiyāpathasannissitapaccayapaṭisevanabhedato tividhena.
analyzed: tividhena ati sāmanta jappa nairiyāpatha sannissita paccaya paṭisevana bhedato tividhena
translated: Threefold: threefold by way of the division into muttering, deportment, and the utilization of requisites.

original: Vimhāpayantīti “ayamacchariyapuriso”ti attani paresaṃ vimhayaṃ sampahaṃsanaṃ acchariyaṃ
analyzed: vimhāpayanti iti ayam acchariya purisaḥ ti paresam vimhayam sampahaṃsanam acchariyam
translated: They cause wonder: they cause others to wonder about themselves, thinking, “This is a wonderful person,” and they cause them to rejoice.

original: uppādenti. Vipubbañhi mhi-saddaṃ sampahaṃsane vadanti saddavidū. Sampahaṃsanākāro
analyzed: uppādenti vipubbam hi mhi saddam sampahaṃsane vadanti sadda vidū sampahaṃsana ākāraḥ
translated: They cause wonder and they cause rejoicing. The word vipubbamhi is used in the sense of rejoicing by those who know the language.

original: ca acchariyaṃ. Lapantīti attānaṃ vā dāyakaṃ vā ukkhipitvā yathā so kiñci dadāti,
analyzed: ca acchariyam lapanti iti attānam vā dāyakam vā ukkhipitvā yathā saḥ kiñci dadāti
translated: The mode of rejoicing is also a wonder. They praise: they praise themselves or a donor, thinking, “Since he gives something,”

original: evaṃ ukkācetvā ukkhipanavasena dīpetvā kathenti. Nimittaṃ sīlametesanti nemittikāti🔽taddhitavasena tassīlattho yathā “paṃsukūliko”ti apica nimittena vadanti, nimittaṃ🔽vā karontīti nemittikā. Nimittanti ca paresaṃ paccayadānasaññuppādakaṃ kāyavacīkammaṃ🔽vuccati. Nippeso nippisanaṃ cuṇṇaṃ viya karaṇaṃ. Nippisantīti vā nippesā, nippesāyeva🔽nippesikā, nippisanaṃ vā nippeso, taṃ karontītipi nippesikā. Nippeso ca nāma bhaṭapuriso🔽viya lābhasakkāratthaṃ akkosanakhuṃsanuppaṇḍanaparapiṭṭhimaṃsikatā. Lābhena lābhanti🔽ito lābhena amutra lābhaṃ. Nijigīsanti magganti pariyesantīti pariyāyavacanaṃ. Kuhakādayo
analyzed: evam ukkācetvā ukkhipana vasena dīpetvā kathenti nimittam sīlam etesanti nemittikā ati  taddhita vasena yathā paṃsukūlikā iti apica nimittena vadanti nimittam  vā karonti iti nemittikāḥ nimittam ti ca paresam paccaya dāna saññā uppādakam kāya vacī kammam  vuccati nippesaḥ nippisanam cuṇṇam viya karaṇam nippisanti iti vā nippesā nippesāya iva  nippesikā nippisanam vā nippesaḥ tam karonti iti pi nippesikā nippesaḥ ca nāma bhaṭa puriso  viya lābha sakkāra attham akkosana khuṃsana uppaṇḍana parapiṭṭhi maṃsikatāḥ lābhena lābhanti  itas lābhena amutra lābham nijigīsanti magganti pariyesanti iti pariyāya vacanam kuhaka ādayaḥ
translated: They speak by way of hinting, by way of giving a sign, by way of a suggestion. They are called fortune-tellers because of their sign and their virtue.🔽The meaning of their virtue is derived by the method of adding the suffix “in” to the word for sign, just as in the case of the word “rag-robe” .🔽Moreover, they are fortune-tellers because they speak by means of a sign or because they make a sign.🔽And a sign is a bodily or verbal act that causes others to give requisites to oneself.🔽They are called schemers because they scheme, because they make a scheme, because they make a scheme like a powder, or because they make a scheme like a man.🔽And a schemer is a man who, for the sake of gain and honour, abuses, reviles, disparages, and flatters others.🔽They are called schemers because they scheme for gain by gain, that is, for gain in one place by means of gain in another place. They are called schemers because they seek, search for, and hunt for gain by means of gain.🔽The words “they seek” and so on are synonyms.🔽

original: Aṭṭhakathañcāti taṃtaṃpāḷisaṃvaṇṇanābhūtaṃ porāṇaṭṭhakathañca.
analyzed: aṭṭhakatham ca ati taṃ taṃ pāḷi saṃvaṇṇanā bhūtam porāṇa aṭṭhakatham ca
translated: And the commentaries: the ancient commentaries which are the commentaries on the various sections.

original: Majjhimasīlavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: majjhima sīla vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the middle length training is finished.

original: Mahāsīlavaṇṇanā🔽21. Aṅgāni ārabbha pavattattā aṅgasahacaritaṃ satthaṃ “aṅga”nti vuttaṃ uttarapadalopena
analyzed: mahāsīla vaṇṇanā  aṅgāni ārabbha pavatta ttā aṅga sahacaritam sattham aṅgam iti vuttam uttara pada lopena
translated: The exposition of the long training🔽The weapon that occurs in dependence on the limbs is called “limb” because of the loss of the second part of the word, or because it is associated with the limbs.

original: vā. Nimittanti etthāpi eseva nayo, tenāha “hatthapādādīsū”tiādi. Keci pana “aṅganti
analyzed: vā nimittanti ettha api esa iva nayo tena āha hattha pāda ādīsu itiādi keci pana aṅga nti
translated: The same method of explanation applies to “sign.” Therefore he says, “in the hand, foot, etc.”

original: aṅgavikāraṃ paresaṃ aṅgavikāradassanenāpi lābhālābhādivijānana”nti vadanti. Nimittasatthanti
analyzed: aṅga vikāram paresam aṅga vikāra dassanena api lābha a lābha ādi vijānananti vadanti nimitta sattham ti
translated: But some say that “limb” is a change in the limbs, and that one knows gain, loss, etc., by showing a change in one’s own limbs to others.

original: nimittena sañjānanappakāradīpakaṃ satthaṃ, taṃ vatthunā vibhāvetuṃ “paṇḍurājā”tiādimāha.🔽Paṇḍurājāti ca “dakkhiṇārāmādhipati” icceva vuttaṃ. Sīhaḷadīpe dakkhiṇārāmanāmakassa
analyzed: nimittena sañjānana ppakāra dīpakam sattham tam vatthunā vibhāvetum paṇḍurā jāti ādim āha  ca dakkhiṇārāma adhipati icca eva vuttam sīhaḷadīpe dakkhiṇārāma nāmakassa
translated: The weapon of the sign is the weapon that illuminates the mode of cognizing by means of the sign. In order to illustrate that by means of the text, he says “Paṇḍurāja,” etc.🔽And “Paṇḍurāja” is said to be “the lord of the Southern Monastery.”🔽They say that he was the builder of the Southern Monastery called Saṅghārāma in the island of Sri Lanka.

original: saṅghārāmassa kārakoti vadanti. “Dakkhiṇamadhurādhipatī”ti ca katthaci likhitaṃ,
analyzed: saṅgha ārāmassa kārako ti vadanti dakkhiṇa madhura adhipati iti ca katthaci likhitam
translated: And in some places it is written “Dakkhiṇamadhurādhipati.”

original: dakkhiṇamadhuranagarassa adhipatīti attho. Muttāyoti muttikā. Muṭṭhiyāti hatthamuddāya.
analyzed: dakkhiṇamadhura nagarassa adhipati iti attho muttāya iti muttikā muṭṭhiyā ati hattha muddāya
translated: The meaning is: the ruler of Dakkhiṇāgiri, the city of honey. ‘Pearls’ means pearls. ‘Fist’ means a raised hand.

original: Gharagolikāyāti sarabunā. So “muttā”ti saññānimittenāha, saṅkhyānimittena pana “tisso”ti.🔽“Mahantāna”nti etena appakaṃ nimittameva, mahantaṃ pana uppādoti nimittuppādānaṃ
analyzed: gharagolikāya iti sarabunā saḥ muttā iti saññā nimittena āha saṅkhyā nimittena pana tissā ti  etena appakam nimittam eva mahantam pana nimitta uppādānam
translated: ‘With a lump of sugar’ means with a lump of molasses. He said ‘pearls’ as a sign of the perception, but ‘three’ as a sign of the number.

original: visesaṃ dasseti. Uppatitanti uppatanaṃ. Subhāsubhaphalaṃ pakāsento uppajjati gacchatīti
analyzed: visesam dasseti uppatitam ti uppatanam subha asubha phalam pakāsentaḥ uppajjati gacchati iti
translated: ‘Great’—by this he shows the difference between the sign, which is small, and the appearance, which is great. ‘Arisen’ means arisen. Appearing as the fruit, whether good or bad, it arises, it goes,

original: uppādo, uppātopi, subhāsubhasūcikā bhūtavikati. So hi dhūmo viya aggissa kammaphalassa
analyzed: uppādaḥ uppātaḥ api subha asubha sūcikā bhūta vikati saḥ hi dhūmaḥ viya aggissa kamma phalassa
translated: therefore it is appearance. The appearance is a transformation of the elements that indicates good and bad. For it merely makes known the fruit of kamma, like the smoke of a fire,

original: pakāsanamattameva karoti, na tu tamuppādetīti. Idanti idaṃ nāma phalaṃ. Evanti iminā
analyzed: pakāsana mattam eva karoti na tu tam uppādeti iti idam ti idam nāma phalam evam iminā
translated: but it does not produce it. ‘This’ means this fruit. ‘Thus’ means in this way.

original: nāma ākārena. Ādisantīti niddisanti. Pubbaṇhasamayeti kālavasena. Idaṃ nāmāti vatthuvasena🔽vadati. Yo vasabhaṃ, kuñjaraṃ, pāsādaṃ, pabbataṃ vā āruḷhamattānaṃ supine passati,
analyzed: nāma ākārena ādisanti iti niddisanti pubbaṇha samaya iti kāla vasena idam nāma ati vatthu vasena 🔽vadati yaḥ vasabham kuñjaram pāsādam pabbatam vā āruḷha mattānam supine passati
translated: ‘Indicating’ means showing. ‘At dawn’ is by way of time. ‘This’ is said by way of the object.

original: tassa “idaṃ nāma phala”ntiādinā hi vatthukittanaṃ hoti. Supinakanti supinasatthaṃ.
analyzed: tassa idam nāma phalanti ādinā hi vatthu kittanam hoti supinakam ti supina sattham
translated: For this is the description of the object in terms of the fruit called “such and such.” “Dream” is dream-food.🔽In the former case, “limb” was said merely to show the excellence and deficiency of the limbs;

original: Aṅgasampattivipattidassanamattena pubbe “aṅga”nti vuttaṃ, idha pana mahānubhāvatādinipphādakalakkhaṇavisesadassanena🔽“lakkhaṇa”nti ayametesaṃ viseso, tenāha “iminā lakkhaṇenā”tiādi. Lakkhaṇanti hi aṅgapaccaṅgesu🔽dissamānākāravisesaṃ sattisirivacchagadāpāsādādikamadhippetaṃ taṃ taṃ phalaṃ lakkhīyati
analyzed: aṅga sampatti vipatti dassana mattena pubbe aṅganti vuttam idha pana mahā anubhāva tā ādi nipphādaka lakkhaṇa visesa dassanena  lakkhaṇam ti ayam etesam visesaḥ tena āha iminā lakkhaṇena atiādi lakkhaṇanti hi aṅga paccaṅgesu  dissamāna ākāra visesam satti siri vaccha gadā pāsāda ādikam adhippetam tam tam phalam lakkhīyati
translated: but here, by showing the special characteristics that produce the great power, etc.,🔽the difference is this: “by this characteristic” and so on. For the characteristic is the special appearance seen in the limbs and secondary limbs, such as the sword, the banner, the ox, the house, and so on, which is intended as the sign of this or that fruit.

original: anenāti katvā, satthaṃ pana tappakāsanato lakkhaṇaṃ. Āhateti purāṇe. Anāhateti nave.
analyzed: anena ati katvā sattham pana tad pakāsanato lakkhaṇam āhata iti purāṇe anāhata iti nave
translated: For it is by means of this that the fruit is characterized as “this” or “that.” But the sword is the characteristic because it is the cause of the display. “Old” means ancient; “new” means fresh.

original: Ahateti pana pāṭhe vuttavipariyāyena attho. Ito paṭṭhāyāti devarakkhasamanussādibhedena
analyzed: ahata iti pana pāṭhe vutta vipariyāyena atthaḥ itas paṭṭhāya ati devarakkhasa manussa ādi bhedena
translated: But in the reading “ahate” the meaning is the opposite of what is stated. “From now on” means from this or that place, such as the gods, the demons, or human beings, etc.,

original: yathāphalaṃ parikappitena vividhavatthabhāge ito vā etto vā sañchinne idaṃ nāma bhogādiphalaṃ
analyzed: yathāphalam parikappitena vividha vattha bhāge itas vā ettas vā sañchinne idam nāma bhoga ādi phalam
translated: having cut off the various kinds of objects that are apportioned according to the fruit, such as the enjoyment, etc.,

original: hoti. Evarūpena dārunāti palāsasiriphalādidārunā, tathā dabbiyā. Yadi dabbihomādīnipi
analyzed: evarūpena dārunā ati palāsa siriphalā ādi dārunā tathā dabbiyā yadi dabbi homa ādīni pi
translated: Such wood: wood such as palmyra, sirisa, and phala wood, and also such tinder.

original: aggihomāneva, atha kasmā visuṃ vuttānīti āha “evarūpāyā”tiādi. Dabbihomādīni homopakaraṇādivisesehi
analyzed: aggi homān eva atha kasmai visum vuttāni iti āha evarūpāya atiādi dabbi homa ādīni homa upakaraṇa ādi visesehi
translated: “Such as these”: such as palāsa-wood, siriphala-wood, etc., and such as the kindling. If the kindling-offering, etc., are also fire-offerings, why are they mentioned separately? He says “such as these” and so on. The kindling-offering, etc., are mentioned by way of the distinction of the requisites for the offering, etc.,

original: phalavisesadassanavasena vuttāni, aggihomaṃ pana vuttāvasesasādhanavasena vuttanti
analyzed: phala visesa dassana vasena vuttāni aggi homam pana vutta avasesa sādhana vasena vuttan ti
translated: showing the distinction in the fruit. But the fire-offering is mentioned by way of the fulfilment of the remainder of what was mentioned.

original: adhippāyo. Tenāha “dabbihomādīnī”tiādi.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ tena āha dabbi homa ādīni itiādi
translated: This is the intention. Therefore he says “kindling-offering, etc.” and so on.

original: Kuṇḍakoti taṇḍulakhaṇḍaṃ, tilassa idanti telaṃ, samāsataddhitapadāni pasiddhesu sāmaññabhūtānīti🔽visesakaraṇatthaṃ “tilatelādika”nti vuttaṃ. Pakkhipananti pakkhipanatthaṃ. “Pakkhipanavijja”ntipi
analyzed: taṇḍula khaṇḍam tilassa idam ti telam samāsa taddhita padāni sāmañña bhūtāni iti  visesa karaṇa attham tila tela ādikan ti vuttam pakkhipananti pakkhipana attham
translated: “A handful” is a handful of rice. “Sesamum oil” is oil from sesamum. The compound word samāsataddhita is well known and is a common term.🔽Therefore, in order to make a distinction, it is said “sesamum oil, etc.” “To be put in” means for the purpose of putting in. The reading “the art of putting in”

original: pāṭho, pakkhipanahetubhūtaṃ vijjanti attho. Dakkhiṇakkhakajaṇṇulohitādīhīti dakkhiṇakkhakalohitadakkhiṇajaṇṇulohitādīhi.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ pakkhipana hetu bhūtam vijjanti atthaḥ dakkhiṇa kkhaka jaṇṇu lohita ādīhi iti dakkhiṇa kkhaka lohita dakkhiṇa jaṇṇu lohita ādīhi
translated: is also found. The meaning is: the art that is the cause for putting in. “Blood from the right armpit, etc.” means blood from the right armpit, blood from the right shoulder, etc.

original: “Pubbe”tiādinā aṅgaaṅgavijjānaṃ visesadassanena punaruttabhāvamapaneti. Aṅgulaṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: pubba itiādinā aṅga aṅga vijjānam visesa dassanena punar utta bhāvam apaneti aṅgu laṭṭhim
translated: “Before” and so on: he removes the repetition by showing the difference between the science of the limbs and the science of the parts.

original: disvāti aṅgulibhūtaṃ, aṅguliyā vā jātaṃ aṭṭhiṃ passitvā, aṅgulicchavimattaṃ apassitvā🔽tadaṭṭhivipassanavaseneva byākarontīti vuttaṃ hoti. “Aṅgalaṭṭhinti sarīra”nti pana
analyzed: disvā ati aṅguli bhūtam aṅguliyā vā jātam aṭṭhim passitvā aṅguli chavi mattam a passitvā  tad aṭṭhi vipassana vasena iva byākaronti iti vuttam hoti aṅga laṭṭhin ti sarīranti pana
translated: Having seen a bone of the size of a digit: having seen a bone the size of a finger, or a bone produced in the finger, without seeing a piece of skin the size of a fingernail.

original: ācariyadhammapālattherena vuttaṃ, evaṃ sati aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ viruhanabhāvena laṭṭhisadisattā
analyzed: ācariya dhammapāla ttherena vuttam evam sati aṅga paccaṅgānam viruhana bhāvena laṭṭhi sadisa ttā
translated: What is meant is: by means of insight into that bone. But the Elder Acariya Dhammapāla says: “Aṅgalaṭṭhi = sarīra” . If that is so, then it is understood that the body itself is the aṅgalaṭṭhi because of its resemblance to a stick in the sense of its being the growth of limbs and secondary limbs.

original: sarīrameva aṅgalaṭṭhīti viññāyati. Kulaputtoti jātikulaputto, ācārakulaputto ca.
analyzed: sarīram eva aṅga laṭṭhī iti viññāyati kula putto ti jāti kula putto ācāra kula putto ca
translated: A clansman: a clansman by birth, and a clansman by conduct.

original: Disvāpīti ettha api-saddo adisvāpīti sampiṇḍanattho. Abbhino satthaṃ abbheyyaṃ. Māsurakkhena
analyzed: disvā api iti ettha api saddaḥ a disvā api iti sampiṇḍana tthaḥ sattham abbheyyam mā asu rakkhena
translated: Having seen: the word api in the text has the meaning of “and” in the sense of “including.”

original: kato gantho māsurakkho. Rājūhi paribhūttaṃ satthaṃ rājasatthaṃ. Sabbānipetāni khattavijjāpakaraṇāni.
analyzed: kataḥ ganthaḥ māsu rakkhaḥ rājūhi sattham rājasattham sabba anipetāni khatta vijjā pakaraṇāni
translated: A proclamation: a proclamation made by a king. A proclamation made by a guard: a proclamation made by a guard. A proclamation made by the king: a proclamation made by the kings. All these are the implements of the science of the stick.

original: Siva-saddo santiatthoti āha “santikaraṇavijjā”ti, upasaggūpasamanavijjāti attho.
analyzed: siva saddaḥ santi atthaḥ ti āha santi karaṇa vijjā ati upasaggu upasamana vijjā ati atthaḥ
translated: The word “siva” has the meaning of “peace” , thus he said “the knowledge of pacification” . The meaning is: the knowledge of the removal of the addition .

original: Sivā-saddameva rassaṃ katvā evamahāti sandhāya “siṅgālarutavijjā”ti vadanti, siṅgālānaṃ🔽rute subhāsubhasañjānanavijjāti attho. “Bhūtavejjamantoti bhūtavasīkaraṇamanto. Bhūrighareti
analyzed: sivā saddam eva rassam katvā sandhāya vadanti  rute subha asubha sañjānana vijjā ati atthaḥ bhūta vejja manto ti bhūta vasīkaraṇa mantaḥ bhūri gharā iti
translated: They say “the knowledge of the jackal’s howl” , thinking that the word “siva” is the same as the word “siva” . translated: that “hand-signal is the reckoning after placing the perception on the finger-joints.” “Reckoning” is said to be

original: acchiddakagaṇanā parisesañāyena, sā pana pādasikamilakkhakādayo viya “ekaṃ dve”tiādinā
analyzed: acchiddaka gaṇanā parisesa ñāyena sā pana ekam dve iti ādinā
translated: reckoning without omission by the method of counting the breaths, “one, two,” etc.,

original: navantavidhinā nirantaragaṇanāti veditabbā. Samūhanaṃ saṅkalanaṃ visuṃ uppādanaṃ
analyzed: nava anta vidhinā nirantara gaṇanā ati veditabbā samūhanam saṅkalanam visum uppādanam
translated: like the counting of steps, the counting of the finger-points, and so on. It should be understood as uninterrupted reckoning. “Grouping” is the collecting together, the producing separately,

original: apanayanaṃ paṭuppādanaṃ [saṭuppādanaṃ (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)] “saduppādana”ntipi paṭhanti,
analyzed: apanayanam paṭuppādanam saṭuppādanam aṭṭhakathāyam saduppādanam tipi paṭhanti
translated: the removing, the producing again. In the commentary “sad-uppādana” is read for “paṭuppādana.”

original: sammā uppādananti attho. Ādi-saddena vokalanabhāgahārādike saṅgaṇhāti. Tattha vokalanaṃ
analyzed: sammā uppādananti atthaḥ ādi saddena vokalana bhāgahāra ādike saṅgaṇhāti tattha vokalanam
translated: The meaning is: producing correctly. By the word “etc.” is included the vocalizing, the taking of shares, and so on. Herein, “vocalizing” is

original: visuṃ samūhakaraṇaṃ, vomissananti attho. Bhāgakaraṇaṃ bhāgo. Bhuñjanaṃ vibhajanaṃ
analyzed: visum samūha karaṇam vomissanam ti atthaḥ bhāga karaṇam bhāgaḥ bhuñjanam vibhajanam
translated: the making of a separate group. The meaning is: “I have missed.” “Taking of shares” is the taking of a share. “Eating” is the dividing up.

original: hāro. Sāti yathāvuttā piṇḍagaṇanā disvāti ettha diṭṭhamattena gaṇetvāti attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: hāraḥ sā ati yathā vuttā piṇḍa gaṇanā disvā iti ettha diṭṭha mattena gaṇetvā iti atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: is a necklace. ‘Having seen’ : the meaning of ‘having seen’ should be taken here as ‘having counted after seeing the enumeration stated thus’.

original: Paṭibhānakavīti ettha aṅguttarāgame vuttānanti seso, kavīnaṃ kabyakaraṇanti sambandho,
analyzed: paṭibhāna kavi iti ettha aṅguttara āgame vuttānam ti sesaḥ kavīnam sambandhaḥ
translated: ‘The poet of inspiration’ : the rest is stated in the Aṅguttara-nikāya. The connection is this: ‘the making of poetry by poets’.

original: etena kavīhi kataṃ, kavīnaṃ vā idaṃ kāveyyanti atthaṃ dasseti. “Attano cintāvasenā”tiādi🔽tesaṃ sabhāvadassanaṃ. Tathā hi vatthuṃ, anusandhiñca sayameva cirena cintetvā karaṇavasena🔽cintākavi veditabbo. Kiñci sutvā sutena asutaṃ anusandhetvā karaṇavasena sutakavi,
analyzed: etena kavīhi katam kavīnam vai idam kāveyyanti attham dasseti attanaḥ cintā vasena atiādi  tesam sabhāva dassanam tathā hi vatthum anusandhim ca sayam eva cirena cintetvā karaṇa vasena  cintā kavi veditabbaḥ kiñci sutvā sutena a sutam anusandhetvā karaṇa vasena suta kavi
translated: By this he shows the meaning: ‘made by poets or this is the poetry of poets’. ‘By his own thought’ and so on🔽is the showing of their individual natures. For thus:🔽the thought-poet should be understood as one who composes after thinking out for himself the subject-matter and the sequence of the thought over a long period of time. The heard-poet🔽is one who composes after connecting what he has not heard with what he has heard by hearing something.

original: kiñci atthaṃ upadhāretvā tassa saṅkhipanavitthāraṇādivasena atthakavi, yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: kiñci attham upadhāretvā tassa saṅkhipana vitthāraṇa ādi vasena attha kavi yam kiñci
translated: The meaning-poet is one who composes after determining a meaning and then abbreviating it, expanding it, and so on. The inspired-poet is one who composes

original: parena kataṃ kabbaṃ vā nāṭakaṃ vā disvā taṃsadisameva aññaṃ attano ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānena🔽karaṇavasena paṭibhānakavīti. Nti tamatthaṃ. Tappaṭibhāganti tena diṭṭhena sadisaṃ.
analyzed: parena katam kabbam vā nāṭakam vā disvā taṃsadisam eva aññam attanaḥ ṭhānuppattika paṭibhānena 🔽karaṇa vasena paṭibhānaka vīti nti tam attham tad paṭibhāgam ti tena diṭṭhena sadisam
translated: something like what he has seen in another’s poetry or drama by his own inspired ingenuity. ‘Nti’ is for ‘tam-atthaṃ’. ‘Tappaṭibhāgaṃ’ is like what he has seen.

original: “Kattabba”nti ettha visesanaṃ, “karissāmī”ti ettha vā bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ. Ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānavasenāti
analyzed: kattabbam ti ettha visesanam karissāmi iti ettha vā bhāva napuṃsakam ṭhāna uppattika paṭibhāna vasena ati
translated: “Will be done” is the distinguishing feature here, or “will be made” is the feminine form of the gerundive.🔽🔽By the method of spontaneous extemporaneous preaching.

original: kāraṇānurūpaṃ pavattanakañāṇavasena. Jīvikatthāyāti pakaraṇādhigatavaseneva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇa anurūpam pavattanaka ñāṇa vasena jīvika atthāya iti pakaraṇa adhigata vasena iva vuttam
translated: “To be done” is the distinguishing feature here, or “I will do” is the feminine noun formed from the verb. “By the method of extemporaneous speaking” means by the knowledge that occurs in conformity with the reason. “For the sake of livelihood” is said by way of the method of exposition.

original: Kavīnaṃ idanti kabyaṃ, yaṃ “gīta”nti vuccati.
analyzed: kavīnam kabyam yam vuccati
translated: Poetry is that which is called “song” and is called “kavīnaṃ idha” .

original: 26. Pariggahabhāvena dārikāya gaṇhanaṃ āvāhanaṃ. Tathā dānaṃ vivāhanaṃ. Idha pana
analyzed: pariggaha bhāvena dārikāya gaṇhanam āvāhanam tathā dānam vivāhanam
translated: The taking of a girl by way of possession is the “invitation” . Likewise the giving is the “marriage” . But here

original: tathākaraṇassa uttarapadalopena niddeso, hetugabbhavasena vā, tenāha “imassa dārakassā”tiādi.
analyzed: tathā karaṇassa uttara pada lopena niddesaḥ hetu gabbha vasena vā tena āha imassa dārakassa atiādi
translated: the description is by the elision of the second member of the compound in the sense of the cause of the action, thus he says “of this boy” and so on.

original: Itīti evaṃhontesu, evaṃbhāvato vā. Uṭṭhānanti khettādito uppannamāyaṃ. Iṇanti dhanavaḍḍhanatthaṃ🔽parassa dinnaṃ pariyudañcanaṃ. Pubbe paricchinnakāle asampattepi uddharitamiṇaṃ uṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: iti iti evaṃhontesu evaṃbhāvataḥ vā uṭṭhānam ti khetta āditaḥ uppanna māyam dhana vaḍḍhana attham  parassa dinnam pariyudañcanam pubbe paricchinna kāle a sampatte pi uddharita miṇam uṭṭhānam
translated: “Thus” means in this way, or in this state. “Work” is the income from the field and so on. “Debt” is the borrowing from another for the purpose of increasing wealth.🔽But some say that the debt is the income that is taken out before the time determined,

original: yathāparicchinnakāle pana sampatte iṇanti keci, tadayuttameva iṇagahaṇeneva sijjhanato.
analyzed: yathā a paricchinna kāle pana sampatte keci tat ayuttam eva iṇa gahaṇena iva
translated: but after the time determined it is the debt. But that is not correct, because it is established by the taking of the debt itself.

original: Paresaṃ dinnaṃ iṇaṃ vā dhananti sambandho. Thāvaranti ciraṭṭhitikaṃ. Desantare diguṇatiguṇādigahaṇavasena
analyzed: paresam dinnam iṇam vā dhananti sambandho thāvaranti cira ṭṭhitikam desa antare diguṇa tiguṇa ādi gahaṇa vasena
translated: “A pledge” is the object that is pledged, by way of taking double, triple, etc., the value of the object.

original: bhaṇḍappayojanaṃ payogo. Tattha vā aññattha vā yathākālaparicchedaṃ vaḍḍhigahaṇavasena🔽payojanaṃ uddhāro. “Bhaṇḍamūlarahitānaṃ vāṇijaṃ katvā ettakena udayena saha mūlaṃ
analyzed: bhaṇḍa payojanam payogo tattha vā aññattha vā yathā kāla paricchedam vaḍḍhi gahaṇa vasena  payojanam uddhāraḥ vāṇijam katvā ettakena udayena saha mūlam
translated: “A mortgage” is the object that is mortgaged, by way of taking interest according to the time period, either in that place or elsewhere.

original: dethā’ti dhanadānaṃ payogo, tāvakālikadānaṃ uddhāro”tipi vadanti. Ajja payojitaṃ🔽diguṇaṃ catuguṇaṃ hotīti yadi ajja payojitaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ, evaṃ aparajja diguṇaṃ, ajja
analyzed: dhana dānam vadanti payojitam  diguṇam catuguṇam hoti iti yadi ajja payojitam bhaṇḍam evam aparajja diguṇam ajja
