translated: For there too the teaching, which occurs in conformity with the disposition of the assembly seated there, reveals the impermanence, etc., of formations,🔽and it reveals the voidness of all dhammas by showing that they are not a self. That is why it is said: “Having given a reasoned talk from seats to the assembly of many thousands,” etc.🔽The expression of the Discipline: the expression of the Discipline is the expression of the Discipline. But the reading “vinayapaṇṇatti” is also allowable for “vinayapaññatti.”

original: ṇṇa-kāre kate vinayapaṇṇattintipi pāṭho. Bhūmantaranti dhammānaṃ avatthāvisesañca
analyzed: ṇṇakāre kate pāṭhaḥ dhammānam avatthā visesam ca
translated: The plane of existence: the plane of existence is the distinction of the state and the distinction of the place of dhammas.

original: ṭhānavisesañca. Bhavanti dhammā etthāti bhūmīti hi avatthāviseso, ṭhānañca vuccati.
analyzed: ṭhāna visesam ca bhavanti dhammā ettha ati bhūmi iti hi avatthā visesaḥ ṭhānam ca vuccati
translated: For the distinction of the state of dhammas is called the plane of existence, and the place is also called the plane of existence.

original: Tattha avatthāviseso satiādidhammānaṃ satipaṭṭhānindriyabalabojjhaṅgamaggaṅgādibhedo
analyzed: tattha avatthā visesaḥ sati ādi dhammānam sati paṭṭhānindriya bala bojjhaṅga maggaṅga ādi bhedaḥ
translated: Therein, the distinction of the state is the distinction of the dhammas such as mindfulness, etc., as foundations of mindfulness, faculties, powers, factors of enlightenment, factors of the path, etc.

original: “vaccho, dammo, balībaddo”ti ādayo viya. Ṭhānaviseso kāmāvacarādibhedo. Paccayākāra-saddassa
analyzed: vacchaḥ dammaḥ balībaddo ti ādayaḥ viya ṭhāna viseso kāmāvacara ādi bhedo paccaya ākāra saddassa
translated: “calf, bull, ox” and so on. The different kinds of state is the different kinds of sense-sphere existence, etc. The meaning of the word “mode”

original: attho heṭṭhā vuttoyeva. Samayantaranti diṭṭhivisesaṃ, nānāvihitā diṭṭhiyoti attho,🔽aññasamayaṃ vā, bāhirakasamayanti vuttaṃ hoti. Vinayapaññattiṃ patvā mahantaṃ gajjitaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yā iva samaya antaran ti diṭṭhi visesam nānā vihitāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ ti attho  añña samayam vā bāhiraka samayanti vuttam hoti vinaya paññattim patvā mahantam gajjitam
translated: has already been given below . “Another occasion” is a different view. The meaning is “the various kinds of views.”🔽Or “another occasion” can be taken as meaning “the occasion of the outsiders,” that is, the sectarians. The connection is this: “When it comes to the laying down of the rules of training, there is a great deal of rumbling and so on.”

original: hotītiādinā sambandho. Tasmāti yasmā gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ…pe… paṭisaṃyuttā, tasmā. Chejjagāminīti atekicchagāminī.
analyzed: hoti itiādinā tasmā ati yasmā paṭisaṃyuttā tasmā chejja gāminī iti atekiccha gāminī
translated: “Therefore”: because there is a great deal of rumbling and so on, and because there is a great deal of talk about the various kinds of views, and because there is a great deal of talk about the occasion of the outsiders, therefore. “Leads to schism”: leads to incurable schism.

original: Evaṃ otiṇṇe vatthusminti yathāvuttanayena lahukagarukādivasena tadanurūpe vatthumhi
analyzed: evam otiṇṇe vatthusmin ti yathā vutta nayena lahuka garuka ādi vasena tad anurūpe vatthumhi
translated: “When the matter has thus arisen”: when the matter has occurred in the way described above, according to its seriousness, and so on.

original: otarante. Yaṃ sikkhāpadapaññāpanaṃ nāma atthi, tatthāti sambandho. Thāmoti ñāṇasāmatthiyaṃ.
analyzed: otarante yam sikkhāpada paññāpanam nāma atthi tattha ati sambandho thāmaḥ ti ñāṇa sāmatthiyam
translated: “Therein”: the connection is with “the laying down of the rules of training.” “Strength”: the strength of knowledge.

original: Balanti akampanasaṅkhāto vīrabhāvo. Thāmo balanti vā sāmatthiyavacanameva paccavekkhaṇādesanāñāṇavasena
analyzed: balanti akampana saṅkhātaḥ vīra bhāvaḥ thāmaḥ balanti vā sāmatthiya vacanam eva paccavekkhaṇā desanā ñāṇa vasena
translated: “Power”: the quality of being unperturbed. “Strength” and “power” are terms for ability. By reviewing and teaching,

original: yojetabbaṃ. Paccavekkhaṇāñāṇapubbaṅgamañhi desanāñāṇaṃ. Esāti sikkhāpadapaññāpanameva
analyzed: yojetabbam paccavekkhaṇā ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam hi desanā ñāṇam esā ati sikkhāpada paññāpanam eva
translated: and should be construed thus. For the knowledge of teaching is preceded by the knowledge of reviewing.

original: vuccamānapadamapekkhitvā pulliṅgena niddisati, eso sikkhāpadapaññāpanasaṅkhāto visayo
analyzed: vuccamāna padam apekkhitvā pulliṅgena niddisati eso sikkhāpada paññāpana saṅkhātaḥ visayo
translated: He: he is shown in the feminine because the words “is being spoken” are being looked at. This is the sphere called the laying down of the training rule.🔽The meaning is that it is not the sphere of others.

original: aññesaṃ avisayoti attho. Itīti tathāvisayāvisayabhāvassa hetubhāvena paṭiniddesavacanaṃ,
analyzed: aññesam avisayaḥ ti atthaḥ iti iti tathā visaya avisaya bhāvassa hetu bhāvena paṭiniddesa vacanam
translated: Thus: this is said by way of a demonstrative pronoun in the sense of cause to show the state of being and not being the sphere of that.

original: nidassanattho vā iti-saddo, tena “idaṃ lahukaṃ, idaṃ garuka”ntiādinayaṃ niddisati.
analyzed: nidassana atthaḥ vā iti saddo tena idam lahukam idam garukam ti ādi nayam niddisati
translated: Or the word thus has the sense of showing, in which case it shows by the method “This is light, this is heavy,” and so on.

original: Evamaparatthāpi yathāsambhavaṃ.
analyzed: evam aparatthā api yathāsambhavam
translated: So too in the other instances as appropriate.

original: Yadipi kāyānupassanādivasena satipaṭṭhānādayo suttantapiṭake vibhattā, tathāpi suttantabhājanīyādivasena
analyzed: yadi api kāya anupassanā ādi vasena sati paṭṭhāna ādayo suttanta piṭake vibhattā tathā api suttanta bhājanīya ādi vasena
translated: Although the foundations of mindfulness, etc., are distributed in the Sutta Piṭaka by way of the survey of the body, and so on, nevertheless they are distributed in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka itself by way of the Abhidhamma method.

original: abhidhammeyeva te visesato vibhattāti āha “ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā…pe… abhidhammapiṭakaṃ
analyzed: abhidhamme iya iva te visesataḥ vibhattā ti āha ime cattāro abhidhamma piṭakam
translated: Therefore he said “having distributed the four foundations of mindfulness … the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.”

original: vibhajitvā”ti. Tattha satta phassāti sattaviññāṇadhātusampayogavasena vuttaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: vibhajitvā ti tattha satta phassā ti satta viññāṇa dhātu sampayoga vasena vuttam tathā
translated: Herein, seven contacts is said with reference to the seven consciousness elements. So too

original: “satta vedanā”tiādipi. Lokuttarā dhammā nāmāti ettha iti-saddo ādiattho, pakārattho🔽vā, tena vuttāvasesaṃ abhidhamme āgataṃ dhammānaṃ vibhajitabbākāraṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Catuvīsatisamantapaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: satta lokuttarāḥ dhammāḥ nāma ati ettha iti saddo ādi attho pakāra attho  vā tena vutta avasesam abhidhamme āgatam dhammānam vibhajitabba ākāram saṅgaṇhāti catuvīsati samanta paṭṭhānāni
translated: “Seven kinds of feeling,” and so on. As regards the words “called supramundane states,” the word “called” has the meaning of “beginning with” or the meaning of “including.”🔽It includes the remaining states mentioned in the Abhidhamma, which are to be distinguished among the states of consciousness.🔽The twenty-four kinds of “contemplation” are here called “contemplations” in the sense of “looking round” .

original: etthāti catuvīsatisamantapaṭṭhānanti bāhiratthasamāso. “Abhidhammapiṭaka”nti etassa🔽hi idaṃ visesanaṃ. Ettha ca paccayanayaṃ aggahetvā dhammavaseneva samantapaṭṭhānassa
analyzed: ettha ati catuvīsati samanta paṭṭhānan ti bāhirattha samāsaḥ abhidhamma piṭakan ti etassa  hi idam visesanam ettha ca paccaya nayam aggahetvā dhamma vasena iva samanta paṭṭhānassa
translated: The compound catuvīsatipaṭṭhānā is a bahubbīhi compound.🔽For this is a distinguishing mark of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.🔽And here the twenty-four kinds of contemplation are stated according to the method of states of consciousness, without taking into account the method of conditions.

original: catuvīsatividhatā vuttā. Yathāha –
analyzed: catuvīsatividha tā vuttā yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

original: “Tikañca paṭṭhānavaraṃ dukuttamaṃ,🔽Dukatikañceva tikadukañca;
analyzed: tikam ca paṭṭhāna varam duk uttamam  duka tikam ca iva tika dukam ca
translated: “The three and the supreme contemplation, the two and the three,🔽And the three and the two, and the two and the two,

original: Tikatikañceva dukadukañca,
analyzed: tika tikam ca iva duka dukam ca
translated: And the three and the three, and the two and the two—

original: Cha anulomamhi nayā sugambhīrā…pe…
analyzed: cha anulomam nayā sugambhīra āpe
translated: The six profound methods in direct order …

original: Cha paccanīyamhi…pe… anulomapaccanīyamhi…pe…
analyzed: cha paccanīya mhipe anuloma paccanīya mhipe
translated: The six in reverse order … the six in direct and reverse order …

original: Paccanīyānulomamhi nayā sugambhīrā”ti. [paṭṭhā. 1.1.41(ka), 44(kha), 48(ga), 52(gha)];
analyzed: paccanīya anulomamhi nayā su gambhīrā ati paṭṭhā
translated: The six profound methods in reverse and direct order” .

original: Evaṃ dhammavasena catuvīsatibhedesu tikapaṭṭhānādīsu ekekaṃ paccayanayena anulomādivasena
analyzed: evam dhamma vasena catuvīsati bhedesu tika paṭṭhāna ādīsu ekekam paccaya nayena anuloma ādi vasena
translated: So in the twenty-four kinds of tetrad distinguished according to the ideas, each of the three-rooted exercises beginning with the one on conditions is fourfold according to the direct-and-reverse order, etc.,

original: catubbidhaṃ hotīti channavutisamantapaṭṭhānāni. Tattha pana dhammānulome tikapaṭṭhāne
analyzed: catubbidham hoti iti channavuti samanta paṭṭhānāni tattha pana dhamma anulome tika paṭṭhāne
translated: and so there are thirty-six kinds of all-round exercises. Herein, in the three-rooted exercise on ideas according to the order of ideas,

original: kusalattike paṭiccavāre paccayānulome hetumūlake hetupaccayavasena ekūnapaññāsa pucchānayā🔽satta vissajjananayātiādinā dassiyamānā anantabhedā nayāti āha “anantanaya”nti.
analyzed: kusala ttike paṭicca vāre paccaya anulome hetu mūlake hetu paccaya vasena ekūnapaññāsa pucchā anayā  satta vissajjana nayā ati ādinā dassiyamānāḥ ananta bhedāḥ nayā iti āha ananta nayanti
translated: in the profitable triad, in the conditions chapter, in the reverse order of conditions, there are forty-nine questions by the method of questioning and seventy answers by the method of answering,🔽starting with the root cause in the conditions chapter, and so on. The method is shown as having an infinite number of divisions. So he said “infinite method.”

original: Navahākārehīti uppādādīhi navahi paccayākārehi. Taṃ sarūpato dassetuṃ “uppādo hutvā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha uppajjati etasmā phalanti uppādo, phaluppattiyā kāraṇabhāvo. Sati
analyzed: navahā ākārehi iti uppāda ādīhi navahi paccaya ākārehi tam sarūpataḥ dassetum uppādaḥ hutvā atiādi  vuttam tattha uppajjati etasmā phalanti uppādaḥ phala uppattiyā kāraṇa bhāvaḥ sati
translated: By the nine aspects: by the nine aspects of conditions beginning with arising. In order to show that in its true nature he said “Arising, having arisen” , etc.

original: ca avijjāya saṅkhārā uppajjanti, nāsati. Tasmā avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ uppādo hutvā paccayo
analyzed: ca avijjāya saṅkhārāḥ uppajjanti na asati tasmai avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ uppādaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ
translated: Herein, it arises from this, the fruit, thus it is arising ; it is a cause for the occurrence of the fruit. And when there is ignorance, formations arise, not when there is not. So ignorance is a condition for formations by being their arising.

original: hoti, tathā pavattati dharati etasmiṃ phalanti pavattaṃ. Nimīyati phalametasminti
analyzed: hoti tathā pavattati dharati etasmin phalanti pavattam nimīyati phalam etasmin iti
translated: It occurs, it is maintained, in this, the fruit, thus it is occurrence . It is clung to in this, the fruit, thus it is clinging .

original: nimittaṃ. (Nidadāti phalaṃ attano paccayuppannaṃ etenāti nidānaṃ.) (Etthantare aṭṭhakathāya🔽na sameti) āyūhati phalaṃ attano paccayuppannuppattiyā ghaṭeti etenāti āyūhanaṃ.
analyzed: nimittam nidadāti phalam attanaḥ paccaya uppannam etena ati nidānam etthantare aṭṭhakathāya  na sameti āyūhati phalam attanaḥ paccaya uppanna uppattiyā ghaṭeti etena ati āyūhanam
translated: and the sign. (The cause is the condition that places the fruit in itself, that is, that makes it arise. ) (The cause is not the same as the condition in the commentary. ) The condition is what brings about the fruit’s occurrence in itself, what causes it to arise.

original: Saṃyujjati phalaṃ attano paccayuppannena etasminti saṃyogo. Yattha sayaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: saṃyujjati phalam attanaḥ paccaya uppannena etasmin ti saṃyogaḥ yattha sayam uppajjati
translated: The support is that in which the fruit arises.

original: taṃ palibuddhati phalametenāti palibodho. Paccayantarasamavāye sati phalamudayati🔽etenāti samudayo. Hinoti kāraṇabhāvaṃ gacchatīti hetu. Avijjāya hi sati saṅkhārā
analyzed: tam phalam etena ati palibodho paccaya antara samavāye sati phalam udayati  etena ati samudayaḥ hinoti kāraṇa bhāvam gacchati iti hetu avijjāya hi sati saṅkhārāḥ
translated: The hindrance is what hinders the fruit by that. When the concurrence of other conditions exists, the fruit arises by that.

original: pavattanti, dharanti ca, te avijjāya sati attano phalaṃ (nidadanti) bhavādīsu khipanti,🔽āyūhanti attano phaluppattiyā ghaṭenti, attano phalena saṃyujjanti, yasmiṃ santāne
analyzed: pavattanti dharanti ca te avijjāya sati phalam nidadanti bhava ādīsu khipanti  āyūhanti attano phala uppattiyā ghaṭenti attano phalena saṃyujjanti yasmin santāne
translated: The origin is what causes the fruit to arise. The cause is what goes as the cause. For when there is ignorance, formations occur and are maintained. They place their fruit in the kinds of becoming, etc.,

original: sayaṃ uppannā taṃ palibuddhanti, paccayantarasamavāye udayanti uppajjanti, hinoti
analyzed: sayam uppannā tam palibuddhanti paccaya antara samavāye udayanti uppajjanti hinoti
translated: they bring it about, they cause it to arise, they are connected with their fruit, they hinder the continuity in which they arise themselves, and when the concurrence of other conditions exists, they cause it to arise.🔽They go as the cause.

original: ca saṅkhārānaṃ kāraṇabhāvaṃ gacchati, tasmā avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ pavattaṃ hutvā…pe…
analyzed: ca saṅkhārānam kāraṇa bhāvam gacchati tasmai avijjā saṅkhārānam pavattam hutvā ape
translated: and it becomes the cause of formations. So ignorance, having become the origin of formations, …

original: paccayo hutvā paccayo hoti. Evaṃ avijjāya saṅkhārānaṃ kāraṇabhāvūpagamanavisesā uppādādayo
analyzed: paccayaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti evam avijjāya saṅkhārānam kāraṇa bhāva upagamana visesāḥ uppāda ādayaḥ
translated: having become a condition, is a condition. So the distinction in ignorance’s becoming the cause of formations should be understood in terms of arising, etc.,

original: veditabbā. Saṅkhārādīnaṃ viññāṇādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Tamatthaṃ paṭisambhidāmaggapāḷiyā sādhentena “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tiṭṭhati🔽etenāti ṭhiti, paccayo, uppādo eva ṭhiti uppādaṭṭhiti. Evaṃ sesesupi. Yasmā pana
analyzed: veditabbā saṅkhāra ādīnam viññāṇa ādīsu pi esā iva nayo  tam attham paṭisambhidā magga pāḷiyā sādhentena yathā āha atiādi vuttam tattha tiṭṭhati  etena ati paccayaḥ uppādaḥ eva ṭhiti uppāda ṭṭhiti evam sesesu pi yasmā pana
translated: as follows. The same method applies to formations, etc., in relation to consciousness, and so on.

original: “āsavasamudayā avijjāsamudayo”ti vuttattā āsavāva avijjāya paccayo, tasmā vuttaṃ🔽“ubhopete dhammā “paccayasamuppannā”ti, avijjā ca saṅkhārā ca ubhopete dhammā paccayato
analyzed: āsava samudayā avijjā samudayo ti vutta ttā avijjāya paccayo tasmā vuttam  ubho upete dhammā paccaya samuppannā ati avijjā ca saṅkhārā ca ubho upete dhammā paccayato
translated: The meaning of this is confirmed by the text of the Paṭisambhidā Magga, which is quoted with the words “As it is said” . Herein, it stands by means of this, thus it is a stand ; a condition is a stand ; arising is a stand ; thus arising is a stand. So too with the rest. But since it is said that “with the arising of cankers there is the arising of ignorance” , cankers are the condition for ignorance. That is why it is said that

original: eva samuppannā, na vinā paccayenāti attho. Paccayapariggahe paññāti saṅkhārānaṃ,
analyzed: eva samuppannā na vinā paccayena ati atthaḥ paccaya pariggahe paññā ati saṅkhārānam
translated: “Both these states are conditionally arisen” . Both these states, namely, ignorance and formations, are arisen by way of condition, not without condition, is the meaning. Understanding of discerning conditions is in regard to formations,

original: avijjāya ca uppādādike paccayākāre paricchinditvā gahaṇavasena pavattā paññā. Dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇanti
analyzed: avijjāya ca uppāda ādike paccaya ākāre paricchinditvā gahaṇa vasena pavattā paññā dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇanti
translated: and the understanding that occurs by way of apprehending the mode of conditionality in the arising, etc., of ignorance.

original: paccayuppannadhammānaṃ paccayabhāvato dhammaṭṭhitisaṅkhāte paṭiccasamuppāde ñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya uppanna dhammānam paccaya bhāvataḥ dhamma ṭṭhiti saṅkhāte paṭiccasamuppāde ñāṇam
translated: Understanding of the stability of dhammas is the knowledge of dependent origination, called “the stability of dhammas,” in the arising of present dhammas through their conditions.

original: “Dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā”ti vacanato hi dvādasa paccayā eva paṭiccasamuppādo. Ayañca
analyzed: dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā ti vacanato hi dvādasa paccayāḥ eva paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ayam ca
translated: For it is said: “There are twelve dependent originations” . Thus the twelve conditions themselves are dependent origination.

original: nayo na paccuppanne eva, atha kho atītānāgatesupi, na ca avijjāya eva saṅkhāresu,
analyzed: nayaḥ na paccuppanne eva atha kho atīta anāgatesu pi na ca avijjāya eva saṅkhāresu
translated: And this method is not only applicable to present dhammas, but also to past and future dhammas, and not only to the conditionality of ignorance in relation to formations,

original: atha kho saṅkhārādīnaṃ viññāṇādīsupi labbhatīti paripuṇṇaṃ katvā paccayākārassa vibhattabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atha kho saṅkhāra ādīnam viññāṇa ādīsu pi labbhati iti paripuṇṇam katvā paccaya ākārassa vibhatta bhāvam
translated: but also to the conditionality of formations, etc., in relation to consciousness, etc. Thus, in order to show that the method of conditionality is applicable in its entirety,

original: dassetuṃ “atītampi addhāna”ntiādi pāḷimāhari. Paṭṭhāne pana dassitā hetādipaccayāevettha
analyzed: dassetum atītam pi addhā anantiādi pāḷim āhari paṭṭhāne pana dassitā hetu ādi paccayā eva ettha
translated: the text says: “In the past, too, this dependent origination was of this same conditionality” . But in the Paṭṭhāna the conditions such as root-cause, etc., are shown in the present only.

original: uppādādipaccayākārehi gahitāti tepi yathāsambhavaṃ nīharitvā yojetabbā. Ativitthārabhayena
analyzed: uppāda ādi paccaya ākārehi gahitā ati te pi yathāsambhavam nīharitvā yojetabbā ati vitthāra bhayena
translated: Therefore they should be extracted and applied as appropriate to the modes of conditionality in the arising, etc., of past and future dhammas.

original: pana na yojayimha, atthikehi ca visuddhimaggādito gahetabbā.
analyzed: pana na yojayimha atthikehi ca visuddhi magga āditaḥ gahetabbā
translated: But we have not applied them here for fear of being too prolix. Those who are interested should learn them from the Visuddhimagga and other works.

original: Tassa tassa dhammassāti saṅkhārādipaccayuppannadhammassa. Tathā tathā paccayabhāvenāti🔽uppādādihetādipaccayasattiyā. Kammakilesavipākavasena tīṇi vaṭṭāni yassāti tivaṭṭaṃ.
analyzed: tassa tassa dhammassa āti saṅkhāra ādi paccaya uppanna dhammassa tathā tathā paccaya bhāvena ati  uppāda ādi heta ādi paccaya sattiyā kamma kilesa vipāka vasena tīṇi vaṭṭāni yassa ati tivaṭṭam
translated: ‘Of this or that state’ means of the state that is a condition for formations, etc. ‘In this or that way as a condition’ means🔽by the presence of conditions for arising, etc., and for cause, etc. ‘With the three rounds’ means with the three rounds consisting of kamma, defilements, and becoming.🔽‘With the three times’ means with the three times of past, future, and present. ‘With the three links’ means with the three links of cause, fruit, fruit-cause, and cause-fruit.

original: Atītapaccuppannānāgatavasena tayo addhā kālā etassāti tiyaddhaṃ. Hetuphalaphalahetuhetuphalavasena🔽tayo sandhayo etassāti tisandhi. Saṅkhippanti ettha avijjādayo, viññāṇādayo cāti🔽saṅkhepā, hetu, vipāko ca. Atha vā hetu vipākoti saṅkhippantīti saṅkhepā. Avijjādayo,
analyzed: atīta paccuppanna anāgata vasena tayaḥ addhā kālāḥ etassa ati hetu phala phala hetu hetu phala vasena  tayo sandhayo etassa ati ti sandhi ettha avijjā ādayaḥ viññāṇa ādayaḥ ca ati  saṅkhepāḥ hetu vipāko ca atha vā hetu vipāko ti saṅkhippanti iti saṅkhepāḥ avijjā ādayo
translated: ‘With the four summaries’ means with the four summaries of past cause, etc. ‘With the four modes’ means with the four modes of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four aspects’ means with the four aspects of past cause, etc. ‘With the four kinds of knowledge’ means with the four kinds of knowledge of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four fruits’ means with the four fruits of past cause, etc. ‘With the four noble persons’ means with the four noble persons of past cause, etc.

original: viññāṇādayo ca koṭṭhāsapariyāyo vā saṅkhepasaddo. Atītahetusaṅkhepādivasena cattāro
analyzed: viññāṇa ādayo ca koṭṭhāsa pariyāyo vā saṅkhepa saddo atīta hetu saṅkhepa ādi vasena cattāro
translated: ‘With the four discriminations’ means with the four discriminations of past cause, etc. ‘With the four foundations of mindfulness’ means with the four foundations of mindfulness of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four right efforts’ means with the four right efforts of past cause, etc. ‘With the four bases for success’ means with the four bases for success of past cause, etc.

original: saṅkhepā yassāti catusaṅkhepaṃ. Sarūpato avuttāpi tasmiṃ tasmiṃ saṅkhepe ākirīyanti🔽avijjāsaṅkhārādiggahaṇehi pakāsīyantīti ākārā, atītahetuādīnaṃ pakārā. Te saṅkhepe
analyzed: saṅkhepāḥ yassa ati catu saṅkhepam sarūpataḥ a vuttā api tasmin tasmin saṅkhepe ākirīyanti 🔽avijjā saṅkhāra ādi gahaṇehi ākārāḥ atīta hetu ādīnam te saṅkhepe
translated: ‘With the four meditations’ means with the four meditations of past cause, etc. ‘With the four immaterial states’ means with the four immaterial states of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four noble truths’ means with the four noble truths of past cause, etc. ‘With the four paths’ means with the four paths of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four fruitions’ means with the four fruitions of past cause, etc. ‘With the four kinds of knowledge of penetration of minds’ means with the four kinds of knowledge of penetration of minds of past cause, etc.🔽‘With the four kinds of reviewing knowledge’ means with the four kinds of reviewing knowledge of past cause, etc. ‘With the four kinds of analytical knowledge’ means with the four kinds of analytical knowledge of past cause, etc.

original: pañca pañca katvā vīsati ākārā etassāti vīsatākāraṃ.🔽Khattiyādibhedena anekabhedabhinnāpi sassatavādino jātisatasahassānussaraṇādikassa
analyzed: pañca pañca katvā vīsati ākārā vīsati ākāram  khattiya ādi bhedena aneka bheda bhinnā api sassata vādinaḥ jāti sata sahassa anussaraṇa ādikassa
translated: and since there are twenty modes by taking five at a time, it is of twenty modes.

original: abhinivesahetuno vasena cattārova honti, na tato uddhaṃ, adho vāti sassatavādīnaṃ
analyzed: abhinivesa hetunaḥ vasena cattāraḥ iva honti na tatas uddham adhas vāti sassata vādīnam
translated: Although the eternalists are divided into many kinds by the divisions of khattiya, and so on, they are only four, not more, not less, because of the reason for their adherence, namely, the remembering of a hundred thousand births, and so on.

original: parimāṇaparicchedassa anaññavisayataṃ dassetuṃ “cattāro janā”tiādimāha. Esa nayo
analyzed: parimāṇa paricchedassa anañña visaya tam dassetum cattāraḥ jana ati ādim āha esa nayo
translated: To show that the measure of the eternalists’ views is not beyond that, he said, “four kinds of persons.”🔽The same method applies to the rest.

original: itaresupi. Tattha cattāro janāti cattāro janasamūhāti attho gahetabbo tesu ekekassāpi
analyzed: itaresu pi tattha cattāraḥ janāti cattāraḥ jana samūhā ti atthaḥ gahetabbo tesu ekekassa api
translated: Herein, the meaning of “four kinds of persons” should be taken as four groups of persons, since each of them is divided into many kinds.🔽“They” are the proponents of the sixty-two views.

original: anekappabhedato. Teti dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatavādino. Idaṃ nissāyāti idappaccayatāya sammā🔽aggahaṇaṃ. Tatthāpi ca hetuphalabhāvena sambandhānaṃ dhammānaṃ santatighanassa abheditattā
analyzed: aneka ppabhedato te ti dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigata vādinaḥ idam nissāya ati idappaccaya tāya sammā  aggahaṇam tattha api ca hetu phala bhāvena sambandhānam dhammānam santati ghanassa a bhedita ttā
translated: “Depending on this”: because of this condition.

original: paramatthato vijjamānampi bhedanibandhanaṃ nānattanayaṃ anupadhāretvā gahitaṃ ekattaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: paramatthataḥ vijjamānam api bheda nibandhanam nānat tanayam an upadhāretvā gahitam ekatta ggahaṇam
translated: Herein, the mode of perception of unity, which is found in the ultimate sense, is not apprehended by not attending to the mode of diversity, which is the basis for the distinction, because of the unbroken continuity of the connected dhammas by way of cause and effect.

original: nissāya. Idaṃ gaṇhantīti idaṃ sassataggahaṇaṃ abhinivissa voharanti, iminā nayena
analyzed: nissāya idam gaṇhanti iti idam sassata ggahaṇam abhinivissa voharanti iminā nayena
translated: “Taking support”: they speak taking support on this eternalist view.🔽In this way, the partial-eternalists, etc., should be explained according to the method stated above.

original: ekaccasassatavādādayopi yathāsambhavaṃ yojetvā vattabbā. Bhinditvāti “ātappamanvāyā”tiādinā
analyzed: ekacca sassata vāda ādayaḥ api yathāsambhavam yojetvā vattabbāḥ bhinditvā iti ātappam anvāya ati ādinā
translated: “Having analyzed”: having analyzed by the method of “through zeal and endeavour,” etc.,

original: vibhajitvā, “tayidaṃ bhikkhave tathāgato pajānātī”tiādinā vā vidhamitvā. Nijjaṭanti🔽anonaddhaṃ. Nigumbanti anāvuṭaṃ. Apica veḷuādīnaṃ heṭṭhupariyasaṃsibbanaṭṭhena jaṭā.
analyzed: vibhajitvā tayidam bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti iti ādinā vā vidhamitvā nijjaṭanti  anonaddham nigumbanti an āvuṭam apica veḷu ādīnam heṭṭhu pariya saṃsibbana ṭṭhena jaṭā
translated: or having divided by the method of “The Tathagata understands this, bhikkhus,” etc.🔽“Having unraveled the tangle, having untied the knot”: the tangle is unraveled by the method of “having unraveled the tangle of false views,” the knot by the method of “having untied the knot of false views.”

original: Kusādīnaṃ ovaraṇaṭṭhena gumbo. Tassadisatāya diṭṭhigatānaṃ byākulā pākaṭatā “jaṭā,
analyzed: kusa ādīnam ovaraṇa ṭṭhena gumbaḥ tad sadisa tāya diṭṭhi gatānam byākulā pākaṭa tā jaṭā
translated: The tangle is the entanglement of the bamboo, etc., above and below; the knot is the obstruction of the kusagras, etc.

original: gumbo”ti ca vuccati, diṭṭhijaṭāvijaṭanena, diṭṭhigumbavivaraṇena ca nijjaṭaṃ nigumbaṃ katvāti attho.
analyzed: gumbaḥ ti ca vuccati diṭṭhi jaṭā vijaṭanena diṭṭhi gumba vivaraṇena ca nijjaṭam nigumbam katvā iti attho
translated: The entanglement and obstruction of the views are like the tangle and knot. The meaning is that he has unraveled the tangle and untied the knot of views by the method of “having unraveled the tangle of false views,” etc., and by the method of “having untied the knot of false views,” etc.

original: “Tasmā”tiādinā buddhaguṇe ārabbha desanāya samuṭṭhitattā sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ uddisitvā desanākusalo bhagavā samayantaraṃ viggahaṇavasena sabbaññutaññāṇameva vissajjetīti dasseti.🔽29. Atthi pariyāyo santi-saddo, so ca saṃvijjantipariyāyo, saṃvijjamānatā ca ñāṇena
analyzed: tasmā iti ādinā buddha guṇe ārabbha desanāya samuṭṭhita ttā sabbaññu ta ññāṇam uddisitvā desanā kusalaḥ bhagavā samaya antaram viggahaṇa vasena sabbaññu ta ññāṇam eva vissajjeti iti dasseti  atthi pariyāyaḥ santi saddo so ca saṃvijjanti pariyāyo saṃvijjamāna tā ca ñāṇena
translated: “Therefore” : the Exalted One, skilled in teaching, shows that the knowledge of omniscience is the source of the teaching, and that he himself is the one who answers the question by way of the method of “interrogation and reply.”🔽The word “exists” has the meaning of “is found.” And that which is found is found by way of knowledge.

original: upalabbhamānatāti āha “santī”tiādi. Saṃvijjamānaparidīpanena pana “santī”ti iminā🔽padena tesaṃ diṭṭhigatikānaṃ vijjamānatāya avicchinnataṃ, tato ca nesaṃ micchāgāhato
analyzed: upalabbhamāna tā iti āha santi itiādi saṃvijjamāna paridīpanena pana santi iti iminā  padena tesam diṭṭhi gatikānam vijjamāna tāya a vicchinna tam tatas ca nesam micchā gāhato
translated: Therefore the Exalted One says: “Exists” means “is found.”🔽But by showing that which is found, the Exalted One, the King of the Dhamma, shows by the word “exists” that the views of the theorists are not interrupted, that they are found, and that they are not to be abandoned as wrong views.

original: sithilakaraṇavivecanehi attano desanāya kiccakāritaṃ, avitathatañca dīpeti dhammarājā.🔽Atthīti ca santipadena samānattho puthuvacanavisayo eko nipāto “atthi imasmiṃ kāye
analyzed: sithila karaṇa vivecanehi attanaḥ desanāya kicca kāritam avitatha tam ca dīpeti dhamma rājā  atthi iti ca santi padena samāna tthaḥ puthuvacana visayaḥ ekaḥ nipātaḥ atthi imasmin kāye
translated: And he shows that his own teaching is effective in the discernment of the loosening of the grip of wrong views.🔽The word “exists” is a particle that has the same meaning as the word “exists” and is used in a different way, as in the passage: “In this body there are head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin” .

original: kesā”tiādīsu viya. Ālapanavacananti buddhālapanavacanaṃ. Bhagavāyeva hi “bhikkhave,
analyzed: kesa ati ādīsu viya ālapana vacananti buddha ālapana vacanam bhagavāya iva hi bhikkhave
translated: The word “exists” is a word of address to the Buddha.

original: bhikkhavo”ti ca ālapati, na sāvakā. Sāvakā pana “āvuso, āyasmā”tiādisambandhaneneva.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti ca ālapati na sāvakā sāvakā pana āvuso āyasmā iti ādi sambandhanena iva
translated: and he addresses the bhikkhus as “bhikkhus,” not as “disciples.” But he addresses the disciples as “friend,” “venerable sir,” and so on, with the use of some connecting word.🔽When he says “some,” the meaning is “certain.” For the word “one” (eka), which denotes a number, is a definite singular

original: “Eke”ti vutte ekacceti attho eva saṅkhyāvācakassa eka-saddassa niyatekavacanattā,🔽na samitabahitapāpatāya samaṇabrāhmaṇāti āha “pabbajjūpagatabhāvenā”tiādi. Tathā
analyzed: eke iti vutte ekaccā iti atthaḥ eva saṅkhyā vācakassa eka saddassa niyata ikavacana ttā  na samita bahita pāpa tāya samaṇa brāhmaṇa iti āha pabbajju upagata bhāvena ati ādi tathā
translated: he says “by the fact of their having gone forth.”🔽whether they are so or not, he shows that they are intended here only by way of conventional usage.

original: vā hontu, aññathā vā, sammutimatteneva idhādhippetāti dasseti “lokenā”tiādinā. Sassatādivasena🔽pubbantaṃ kappentīti pubbantakappikā. Yasmā pana tesaṃ pubbantaṃ purimasiddhehi taṇhādiṭṭhikappehi🔽kappetvā āsevanabalavatāya, vicitravuttitāya ca vikappetvā aparabhāgasiddhehi abhinivesabhūtehi
analyzed: vā hontu aññathā vā sammutimattena iva idha adhippetā ati dasseti lokena ati ādinā sassata ādi vasena  pubbantam kappenti iti pubbantakappikāḥ yasmā pana tesam pubbantam purima siddhehi taṇhā diṭṭhi kappehi  kappetvā āsevana balava tāya vicitra vutti tāya ca vikappetvā aparabhāga siddhehi abhinivesa bhūtehi
translated: They are speculators about the past by speculating about the past in such ways as “The world is eternal” and so on.🔽But they speculate about the past by taking up and adhering to and misapprehending it through the grasping of craving and views, which are established in the future, after they have speculated about the past by means of the speculations of craving and views that are already established in the past, by making them habitual and strengthening them.

original: taṇhādiṭṭhigāhehi gaṇhanti abhinivisanti parāmasanti, tasmā vuttaṃ “pubbantaṃ kappetvā
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi gāhehi gaṇhanti abhinivisanti parāmasanti tasmā vuttam pubbantam kappetvā
translated: And they speculate about the future by taking up and adhering to and misapprehending it through the grasping of craving and views, which are established in the past, after they have speculated about the future by means of the speculations of craving and views that are already established in the future, by making them habitual and strengthening them. That is why it is said: “Having speculated about the past …

original: vikappetvā gaṇhantī”ti. Purimabhāgapacchimabhāgasiddhānaṃ vā taṇhāupādānānaṃ vasena
analyzed: vikappetvā gaṇhanti iti purima bhāga pacchima bhāga siddhānam vā taṇhā upādānānam vasena
translated: and they are the grasping of the prior and subsequent parts respectively.🔽Or alternatively, the grasping of the prior and subsequent parts should be understood as the taking up of craving and assuming respectively, which are established in the prior and subsequent parts. For craving is a condition for assuming,

original: yathākkamaṃ kappanagahaṇāni veditabbāni. Taṇhāpaccayā hi upādānaṃ sambhavati. Pahutapasaṃsānindātisayasaṃsagganiccayogādivisayesu
analyzed: yathākkamam kappana gahaṇāni veditabbāni taṇhā paccayā hi upādānam sambhavati pahuta pasaṃsā nindā atisaya saṃsagga nicca yoga ādi visayesu
translated: and the condition for the arising of craving is the occurrence of the five cords of sense desire.🔽Herein, the meaning of “the condition” is the meaning of “the occurrence” of the five cords of sense desire.

original: idha niccayogavasena vijjamānattho sambhavatīti vuttaṃ “pubbanta kappo vā”tiādi vuttañca –
analyzed: idha nicca yoga vasena vijjamāna atthaḥ sambhavati iti vuttam pubba anta kappaḥ vā itiādi vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:🔽“With the occurrence of praise,🔽And of blame in excess,

original: “Pahute ca pasaṃsāyaṃ, nindāyañcātisayane;
analyzed: ca nindāyan ca ati sayane
translated: And of association with the condition,

original: Niccayoge ca saṃsagge, hontime mantuādayo”ti.
analyzed: nicca yoge ca saṃsagge honti ime mantu ādayaḥ ti
translated: There are the mantras and so on.”

original: Koṭṭhāsesūti ettha koṭṭhāsādīsūti attho veditabbo ādi-saddalopena, nidassananayena🔽ca vuttattā. Padapūraṇasamīpaummaggādīsupi hi anta-saddo dissati. Tathā hi “iṅgha
analyzed: koṭṭhāsesu iti ettha koṭṭhāsa ādīsu uti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ādi sadda lopena nidassana nayena  ca vutta ttā pada pūraṇa samīpa ommagga ādīsu pi hi anta saddaḥ dissati tathā hi
translated: In the case of the words “in the sections,” the meaning of “in the sections and so on” should be understood, since the word “and so on” is omitted and the meaning is stated by the method of indication.🔽For the word “end” is found in the sense of “filling out the line” and in the sense of “near path” and so on.

original: tāva suttante vā gāthāyo vā abhidhammaṃ vā pariyāpuṇassu, suttante okāsaṃ kārāpetvā”tiādīsu
analyzed: tāva suttante vā gāthāyaḥ vā abhidhammam vā pariyāpuṇassu suttante okāsam kārāpetvā ati ādīsu
translated: For in the passage “Come now, first learn the discourses or the stanzas or the Abhidhamma, and having obtained an opportunity in the discourses” and so on,

original: ca padapūraṇe anta-saddo vattati, “gāmantasenāsana”ntiādīsu samīpe, “kāmasukhallikānuyogo
analyzed: ca pada pūraṇe anta saddo vattati samīpe kāma sukhallikā anuyogaḥ
translated: and the word ‘end’ is used to fill out the line, as in ‘a dwelling place near the village’ and so on, and in the sense of ‘near’ as in ‘the pursuit of gratification of sense desires is one end’

original: eko anto, atthīti kho kaccāna ayameko anto”tiādīsu ca ummaggeti.🔽Antapūroti mahāantaantaguṇehi pūro. “Sā haritantaṃ vā panthantaṃ vā”ti majjhimanikāye
analyzed: ekaḥ antaḥ atthi iti kho kaccāna ayam ekaḥ anto ti ādīsu ca ummagga iti  mahā anta anta guṇehi sā haritantam vā panthantam vāti majjhima nikāye
translated: and ‘There is, Kaccana, this one end, namely, this: “There is this” ’ and so on, it signifies ‘to heap up’.🔽‘Filled with ends’: filled with great ends and qualities. ‘She, having gone to the end of the green or the end of the path’ is a passage in the Mahāhatthipadopama Sutta

original: mahāhatthipadopamasuttantapāḷi. Tattha sāti tejodhātu. Haritantanti haritatiṇarukkhamariyādaṃ.🔽Panthantanti maggamariyādaṃ. Āgamma anāhārā nibbāyatīti seso. “Antamidaṃ bhikkhave,🔽jīvikānaṃ yadidaṃ piṇḍolya”nti piṇḍiyālopasuttantapāḷi. Tattha piṇḍaṃ ulati gavesatīti
analyzed: tattha sāti tejaḥ dhātu haritantanti harita tiṇa rukkha mariyādam  panthantanti magga mariyādam āgamma anāhārā nibbāyati iti sesaḥ antam idam bhikkhave  yat idam tattha piṇḍam ulati gavesati iti
translated: in the Majjhima Nikāya. Herein, ‘she’ is the fire element. ‘The end of the green’ is the boundary of the green grass and trees.🔽‘The end of the path’ is the boundary of the path. ‘Having gone to’ means having gone to the end of the path. ‘She is extinguished without feeding’ is the rest of it. ‘This, bhikkhus, is the end of the wanderers’ way of life, namely, alms-gathering’ is a passage in the Piṇḍiyālopa Sutta.

original: piṇḍolo, piṇḍācāriko, tassa bhāvo piṇḍolyaṃ, piṇḍacaraṇena jīvikatāti attho. Esevāti
analyzed: piṇḍolo piṇḍācāriko tassa bhāvaḥ piṇḍolyam piṇḍa caraṇena jīvika tā ati attho esā eva ati
translated: Herein, he wanders for alms, he seeks alms, thus he is an alms-goer , an alms-seeker; the state of that is alms-gathering , the meaning is that it is a living by going for alms. ‘This alone’

original: sabbapaccayasaṅkhayabhūto nibbānadhammo eva, tenāha “sabba…pe… vuccatī”ti. Etena
analyzed: sabba paccaya saṅkhaya bhūtaḥ nibbāna dhammaḥ eva tena āha sabbape vuccati iti etena
translated: is the state of extinction, which is the exhaustion of all conditions. Hence it is said that ‘all … is said to be’

original: sabbapaccayasaṅkhayanato asaṅkhataṃ nibbānaṃ saṅkhatabhūtassa vaṭṭadukkhassa parabhāgaṃ
analyzed: sabba paccaya saṅkhayanataḥ asaṅkhatam nibbānam saṅkhata bhūtassa vaṭṭa dukkhassa parabhāgam
translated: Nibbāna, which is unformed, is the other end of the formed, of the suffering of the round.

original: pariyosānabhūtaṃ, tasmā ettha parabhāgova attho yuttoti dasseti. Sakkāyoti sakkāyagāho.
analyzed: pariyosāna bhūtam tasmai ettha parabhāgaḥ uva atthaḥ yuttaḥ ti dasseti sakkāyaḥ ti sakkāya gāho
translated: It is the end of the round. Therefore he shows that the meaning of “other end” is appropriate here. “Personality view”: the assumption of a personality.

original: Kappoti leso. Kappakatenāti tiṇṇaṃ dubbaṇṇakaraṇānaṃ aññataradubbaṇṇakatena. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: kappo ti lesaḥ kappa katena ati tiṇṇam dubbaṇṇa karaṇānam aññatara dubbaṇṇa katena ādi saddena
translated: “A parrot”: a disease. “By a parrot-maker”: by one who makes it ugly by means of one of the three kinds of ugliness.

original: cettha kappa-saddo mahākappasamantabhāvakilesakāmavitakkakālapaññattisadisabhāvādīsupi
analyzed: ca ittha kappa saddaḥ mahā kappa samanta bhāva kilesa kāma vitakka kāla paññatti sadisa bhāva ādīsu pi
translated: The word “etc.” shows that the word kappa is also used in the sense of a great aeon, of all-roundness, of defilement, of sensual desire, of a thought unit, of a period of time, and so on.

original: vattatīti dasseti. Tathā hesa “cattārimāni bhikkhave, kappassa asaṅkhyeyyānī”tiādīsu
analyzed: vattati iti dasseti tathā ha isa cattārimāni bhikkhave kappassa asaṅkhyeyyāni iti ādīsu
translated: For in the passage, “Bhikkhus, there are four incalculables in the aeon” ,

original: mahākappe vattati, “kevalakappaṃ veḷuvanaṃ obhāsetvā”tiādīsu samantabhāve, “saṅkappo🔽kāmo rāgo kāmo saṅkapparāgo kāmo”tiādīsu kilesakāme, “takko vitakko saṅkappo”tiādīsu
analyzed: mahākappe vattati kevala kappam veḷuvanam obhāsetvā iti ādīsu samanta bhāve saṅkappaḥ  kāmaḥ rāgaḥ kāmaḥ saṅkappa rāgaḥ kāmaḥ iti ādīsu kilesa kāme takkaḥ vitakkaḥ saṅkappaḥ iti ādīsu
translated: it is used in the sense of a great aeon; in the passage, “Illuminating the whole of the Bamboo Grove” , in the sense of all-roundness; in the passage, “Thinking is sensual desire, sensual desire is thinking; thinking is lust, lust is thinking” ,🔽in the sense of sensual desire as defilement; in the passage, “Thinking, pondering, willing” , in the sense of a thought unit; in the passage, “I used to live quite secluded from sensual pleasures” ,

original: vitakke, “yena sudaṃ niccakappaṃ viharāmī”tiādīsu kāle, “iccāyasmā kappo”tiādīsu
analyzed: vitakke yena sudam nicca kappam viharāmi itiādīsu kāle icca ayasmai kappo tiādīsu
translated: in the sense of a period of time; in the passage, “Thus, venerable sir, the venerable Kappa” ,🔽in the sense of a name.

original: paññattiyaṃ, “satthukappena vata kira bho sāvakena saddhiṃ mantayamānā na jānimhā”tiādīsu sadisabhāveti.
analyzed: paññattiyam satthu kappena vata kira bho sāvakena saddhim mantayamānāḥ na jānimha ati ādīsu sadisa bhāva iti
translated: In the case of the designation, “We did not know that we were arguing with a disciple of the Teacher who is equal to the Teacher himself,” etc.

original: Taṇhādiṭṭhīsu pavattiṃ mahāniddesapāḷiyā sādhento “vuttampi ceta”ntiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhīsu pavattim mahāniddesa pāḷiyā sādhentaḥ vuttam pi cetan ti ādim āha tattha
translated: In the case of craving and views, he proves the occurrence of craving and views by the text of the Great Analysis.

original: uddānatoti saṅkhepato. “Tasmā”tiādi yathāvuttāya atthavaṇṇanāya guṇavacanaṃ. Taṇhādiṭṭhivasenāti🔽upanissayasahajātabhūtāya abhinandanasaṅkhātāya taṇhāya ceva sassatādiākārena abhinivisantassa
analyzed: uddānataḥ ti saṅkhepato tasmā atiādi yathā vuttāya attha vaṇṇanāya guṇa vacanam taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena ati  upanissaya sahajāta bhūtāya abhinandana saṅkhātāya taṇhāya ca iva sassata ādi ākārena abhinivisantassa
translated: “In brief” means in a condensed form. “Therefore” and so on are words of praise for the explanation of the meaning given above.🔽By the means of craving and views means by the means of craving called delighting and by the means of wrong grasping which is the taking of a false view such as eternalism, etc.

original: micchāgāhassa ca vasena. Pubbe nivutthadhammavisayāya kappanāya idha adhippetattā🔽atītakālavācakoyeva pubba-saddo, na pana “manopubbaṅgamā dhammā”tiādīsu viya padhānādivācako,
analyzed: micchāgāhassa ca vasena pubbe nivuttha dhamma visayāya kappanāya idha adhippeta ttā  atīta kāla vācakaḥ yā iva pubba saddaḥ na pana manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammā ti ādīsu viya padhāna ādi vācakaḥ
translated: Because the speculation which has as its domain the dhammas that have already arisen in the past is intended here.🔽Therefore the word “former” is only an expression for the past time, and not an expression for predominance, etc., as in the passage, “The dhammas have mind as their forerunner” (Dhp 1), etc.

original: rūpādikhandhavinimuttassa kappanavatthuno abhāvā anta-saddo ca koṭṭhāsavācako, na
analyzed: rūpa ādi khandha vinimuttassa kappana vatthunaḥ abhāvā anta saddo ca koṭṭhāsa vācakaḥ na
translated: Because there is no domain of speculation apart from the aggregates of matter, etc. The word “end” is an expression for a part, not an expression for the end of a continuum.

original: pana abbhantarādivācakoti dassetuṃ “atītaṃ khandhakoṭṭhāsa”nti vuttaṃ. Kappetvāti
analyzed: pana abbhantara ādi vācakaḥ ti dassetum atītam khandha koṭṭhāsam ti vuttam kappetvā ti
translated: But in order to show that it is a term for the internal, etc., it is said, “A part of the aggregates in the past.”🔽“Having reached” means

original: ca tasmiṃ pubbante taṇhāyanābhinivesanānaṃ samatthanaṃ pariniṭṭhāpanamāha. Ṭhitāti🔽tassā laddhiyā avijahanaṃ, pubbantameva anugatā diṭṭhi tesamatthīti yojanā. Atthitā,
analyzed: ca tasmin pubbante taṇhāyana abhinivesanānam samatthanam pariniṭṭhāpanam āha ṭhitā iti  tassā laddhiyā avijahanam pubbantam eva anugatā diṭṭhi tesam atthi iti yojanā atthi tā
translated: that the settling and finalizing of craving and insistence on that past are stated. “Standing” means🔽that the non-abandoning of that opinion is stated. The construction is: “They have the view that follows after the past only.”

original: anugatatā ca nāma punappunaṃ pavattiyāti dasseti “punappunaṃ uppajjanavasenā”ti iminā.
analyzed: anugata tā ca nāma punappunam pavattiyā ati dasseti punappunam uppajjana vasena ati iminā
translated: “Existence” and “following after” are shown by “by way of repeated arising.”🔽“They” and so on comment on the meaning of the passage beginning “with reference to the past.”

original: “Te eva”ntiādinā “pubbantaṃ ārabbhā”tiādipāḷiyā atthaṃ saṃvaṇṇeti. Tattha ārabbhāti
analyzed: te evam iti ādinā pubbantam ārabbha ati ādi pāḷiyā attham saṃvaṇṇā iti tattha ārabbha ati
translated: Therein, “with reference to” means

original: ālambitvā. Visayo hi tassā diṭṭhiyā pubbanto. Visayabhāvato hesa tassā āgamanaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: ālambitvā visayaḥ hi tassāḥ diṭṭhiyāḥ pubba antaḥ visaya bhāvataḥ ha esa tassāḥ āgamana ṭhānam
translated: having taken as object. For the past is the object of that view. And because of the state of being the object, it is the place of its coming,

original: ārammaṇapaccayo cāti vuttaṃ “āgamma paṭiccā”ti. Tadetaṃ aññesaṃ patiṭṭhāpanadassananti
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayo ca ati vuttam āgamma paṭicca iti tat etam aññesam patiṭṭhāpana dassanam ti
translated: and it is the condition by way of object. Therefore it is said, “having come, having taken as object.” This is shown in order to establish others.

original: āha “aññampi janaṃ diṭṭhigatitaṃ karontā”ti.
analyzed: āha aññam pi janam karontā iti
translated: Therefore it is said, “making others also fall into the view.”

original: Adhivacanapathānīti [adhivacanapaadāni (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)] ruḷhimattena paññattipathāni.
analyzed: adhivacana pathāni iti adhivacana paadāni aṭṭhakathāyam ruḷhimattena paññatti pathāni
translated: The “paths of terms” are the paths of the determinations by the method of derivation.

original: Dāsādīsu hi sirivaḍḍhakādisaddā viya vacanamattameva adhikāraṃ katvā pavattiyā tathā
analyzed: dāsa ādīsu hi sirivaḍḍhaka ādi saddāḥ viya vacana mattam eva adhikāram katvā pavattiyā tathā
translated: For in the case of “slave” and so on, the words “Sirivaḍḍha” and so on occur only as mere terms by the method of derivation,

original: paṇṇattiyeva adhivacanaṃ, sā ca vohārassa pathoti. Atha vā adhi-saddo uparibhāge,🔽vuccatīti vacanaṃ. Adhi uparibhāge vacanaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Upādāniyabhūtānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ
analyzed: paṇṇattiyā iva adhivacanam sā ca vohārassa patho ti atha vā adhi saddaḥ upari bhāge  vuccati iti vacanam adhi upari bhāge vacanam adhivacanam rūpa ādīnam
translated: and so the determination is a term in the sense of a path of usage. Or alternatively, the prefix adhi has the sense of “above,”🔽and vacana means “is said.” So adhivacana is “what is said above.” The determination of the things that are the bases for the determinations is made above the material form, etc., that are the bases for the determinations.

original: [upādābhūtarūpādīnaṃ ] upari paññāpiyamānā upādāpaññatti, tasmā paññattidīpakapathānīti
analyzed: upādā bhūta rūpa ādīnam upari paññāpiyamānā upādā paññatti tasmā paññatti dīpaka pathāni iti
translated: So the meaning should be regarded as “the paths that illuminate the determinations.”

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Paññattimattañhetaṃ vuccati, yadidaṃ “attā, loko”ti ca, na rūpavedanādayo🔽viya paramatthoti. Adhimutti-saddo cettha adhivacana-saddena samānattho “niruttipatho”tiādīsu
analyzed: attho daṭṭhabbo vuccati yat idam attā ca na rūpa vedanā ādayaḥ  viya paramattho ti adhimutti saddaḥ ca ittha adhivacana saddena samāna atthaḥ nirutti pathaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: For this is said to be a mere determination, namely, “self” and “world,” not an ultimate reality like material form, feeling, and so on.🔽And the prefix adhi here has the same meaning as the prefix adhi in the word adhivacana, as in the passages “path of language” ,🔽and “path of derivation” . The word utti has the sense of “saying” as a synonym for “vacana.”

original: viya uttisaddassa vacanapariyāyattā. “Bhūtaṃ attha”ntiādinā pana bhūtasabhāvato atirekaṃ.
analyzed: viya utti saddassa vacana pariyāyattā bhūtam attha nti ādinā pana bhūta sabhāvataḥ atirekam
translated: “True meaning” is a synonym for “ultimate reality.”

original: Tamatidhāvitvā vā muccantīti adhimuttiyo, tāsaṃ pathāni taddīpakattāti atthaṃ dasseti,🔽adhikaṃ vā sassatādikaṃ muccantīti adhimuttiyo. Adhikañhi sassatādiṃ, pakatiādiṃ,
analyzed: tam atidhāvitvā vā muccanti iti adhimuttiyaḥ tāsam pathāni tad dīpaka ttā ti attham dasseti  adhikam vā sassata ādikam muccanti iti adhimuttiyaḥ adhikam hi sassata ādim pakati ādim
translated: and so they are called “adhimuktis” because they are “freed” by running along them. He shows the meaning of “path” by the word “pathways” .🔽Or alternatively, they are called “adhimuktis” because they are “freed” from the excess of eternalism, etc.,🔽for the excess of eternalism, etc., is the natural state, etc.,

original: dabbādiṃ, jīvādiṃ, kāyādiñca abhūtaṃ atthaṃ sabhāvadhammesu ajjhāropetvā diṭṭhiyo pavattanti.🔽30. Abhivadantīti “idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti abhinivisitvā vadanti. “Ayameva🔽dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo”tiādinā abhibhavitvāpi vadanti. Abhivadanakiriyāya ajjāpi avicchedabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: dabba ādim jīva ādim kāya ādim ca abhūtam attham sa bhāva dhammesu ajjhāropetvā diṭṭhiyaḥ pavattanti  abhivadanti iti idam eva saccam mogham aññanti abhinivisitvā vadanti ayam eva  dhammaḥ na ayam dhammaḥ ti ādinā abhibhavitvā api vadanti abhivadana kiriyāya ajja api a viccheda bhāva dassana ttham
translated: They are called “adhimuktis” because they are released by running after that, or because they are released by running after the additional, i.e. eternalism, etc. For the views occur by superimposing on the dhammas their own-nature the non-existent meaning of “additional” as eternalism, etc., of “natural” as the self, etc., of “crushing” as the annihilation of beings, etc., of “living being” as the self, etc., and of “body” as the self, etc.🔽They are called “abhivadanti” because they speak, having resolved: “This alone is the truth, the rest is foolish.” They also speak, having overcome: “This alone is the Dhamma, this is not the Dhamma” , etc. The present tense is used in order to show that the action of speaking is still continuing even today. This is the commentary on the letter A.

original: vattamānavacanaṃ katanti ayamettha pāḷivaṇṇanā. Kathetukamyatāya hetubhūtāya pucchitvāti
analyzed: vattamāna vacanam ayam ettha pāḷivaṇṇanā kathā itu kamyatāya hetu bhūtāya pucchitvā iti
translated: The construction is: “having asked because of the desire to speak.”

original: sambandho. Micchā passatīti diṭṭhi, diṭṭhi eva diṭṭhigataṃ “muttagataṃ, saṅkhāragata”ntiādīsu
analyzed: sambandhaḥ micchā passati iti diṭṭhi diṭṭhi eva diṭṭhi gatam mutta gatam saṅkhāra gata nti ādīsu
translated: “He sees wrongly” is “diṭṭhi” . “Diṭṭhi” itself is “diṭṭhigatam” , as in the passages: “muttagatam, saṅkhāragatam” .

original: viya gata-saddassa tabbhāvavuttito, gantabbābhāvato vā diṭṭhiyā gatamattanti diṭṭhigataṃ.
analyzed: viya gata saddassa tad bhāva vuttitaḥ gantabba abhāvataḥ vā diṭṭhiyā gata mattanti diṭṭhi gatam
translated: because the word gata is used in the sense of “gone” or because of the absence of anything to be gone to, the view is “gone” only in the sense of a view.

original: Diṭṭhiyā gahaṇamattameva, natthaññaṃ avagantabbanti attho, diṭṭhipakāro vā diṭṭhigataṃ.🔽Lokiyā hi vidhayuttagatapakārasadde samānatthe icchanti. Ekasmiṃyeva khandhe “attā”ti
analyzed: diṭṭhiyāḥ gahaṇa mattam eva natthaññam avagantabbanti atthaḥ diṭṭhi pakāraḥ vā diṭṭhi gatam  lokiyāḥ hi vidha yutta gata pakāra sadde samāna atthe icchanti ekasmin yeva khandhe attā ati
translated: The meaning is: it is only a grasping by a view, there is nothing else to be understood. Or else, the mode of a view is a “gone” .🔽For they desire that the word “gone” should have the same meaning as “mode of a view” in the sense of “having a mode of a view” .🔽The designation is made by way of a distinction in the grasping of the one and the same aggregate as “self” and as “world.”

original: ca “loko”ti ca gahaṇavisesaṃ upādāya paññāpanaṃ hotīti āha “rūpādīsu aññataraṃ attāti🔽ca lokoti ca gahetvā”ti. Amaraṃ niccaṃ dhuvanti sassatavevacanāni, maraṇābhāvena
analyzed: ca loko ti ca gahaṇa visesam upādāya paññāpanam hoti iti āha rūpa ādīsu aññataram attā iti  ca ca ca gahetvā ati amaram niccam dhuvanti maraṇa abhāvena
translated: Therefore it is said: “having taken one of the forms, etc., as self and as the world.”🔽The words “the undying, the permanent, the eternal” are synonyms for the eternalist view. Or else, the undying is the absence of death;

original: vā amaraṃ. Uppādābhāvena sabbadāpi atthitāya niccaṃ. Thiraṭṭhena vikārābhāvena dhuvaṃ.
analyzed: vā amaram uppāda abhāvena sabbadā api atthitāya niccam thiraṭṭhena vikāra abhāvena dhuvam
translated: the permanent is the existence at all times by way of non-arising; the eternal is the unchangeable by way of stability.

original: “Yathāhā”tiādinā mahāniddesa paṭisambhidāmaggapāḷīhi yathāvuttamatthaṃ vibhāveti.
analyzed: yathā āha ati ādinā mahāniddesa paṭisambhidā magga pāḷīhi yathāvuttam attham vibhāveti
translated: By the words “as it is said,” etc., he analyzes the meaning stated above by the Mahāniddesa, the Paṭisambhidā, and the text of the Magga.

original: Tattha “rūpaṃ gahetvā”ti pāṭhasesena sambandho. Ayaṃ panattho – “rūpaṃ attato samanupassati.
analyzed: tattha rūpam gahetvā iti pāṭha sesena sambandhaḥ ayam pana atthaḥ rūpam attataḥ samanupassati
translated: Herein, the connection is by way of the reading “having taken form.” But the meaning is this: “He regards form as self.

original: Vedanaṃ, saññaṃ, saṅkhāre, viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti imissā pañcavidhāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā🔽vasena vutto, “rūpavantaṃ attāna”ntiādikāya pana pañcadasavidhāyapi tadavasesāya
analyzed: vedanam saññam saṅkhāre viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati iti imissā pañcavidhāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā  vasena vuttaḥ rūpavantam attā ananti ādikāya pana tad avasesāya
translated: “He regards feeling … perception … mental formations … consciousness as self.”

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā vasena cattāro khandhe “attā”ti gahetvā tadañño “loko”ti paññapentīti
analyzed: sakkāyadiṭṭhiyāḥ vasena cattāro khandhe attā ati gahetvā tad aññaḥ loko ti paññapenti iti
translated: And the meaning can also be taken as follows: “He regards the four aggregates as self and what is other than self as the world.”

original: ayampi attho labbhateva. Tathā ekaṃ khandhaṃ “attā”ti gahetvā añño attano upabhogabhūto
analyzed: ayam pi atthaḥ labbhateva tathā ekam khandham attā ati gahetvā aññaḥ attanaḥ upabhoga bhūto
translated: In the same way, he regards one of the aggregates as self and what is other than that as the world.

original: “loko”ti ca. Sasantatipatite khandhe “attā”ti gahetvā tadañño parasantatipatito “loko”ti
analyzed: ca sa santati patite khandhe attā ati gahetvā tad aññaḥ para santati patitaḥ
translated: And he regards the aggregates in his own continuity as self and what is other than that in the continuity of others as the world.

original: ca paññapetīti evampettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Etthāha – “sassato vādo etesa”nti kasmā
analyzed: ca paññapeti iti evam pi ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo ettha āha sassataḥ vādaḥ etesan ti kasmā
translated: Here it may be asked: Why is it said below that “they hold the doctrine of the eternity of self and the world”?

original: heṭṭhā vuttaṃ, nanu tesaṃ attā ca loko ca sassatoti adhippeto, na vādoti? Saccametaṃ,
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttam nanu tesam attā ca loko ca sassatoti adhippetaḥ na vādaḥ ti saccam etam
translated: Is not the self and the world intended by them as eternal, not the doctrine?🔽This is true, but the doctrine is called eternal because it is associated with the eternal self,

original: sassatasahacaritatāya pana vādopi sassatoti vutto yathā “kuntā pacarantī”ti, sassato
analyzed: sassata sahacarita tāya pana vādaḥ api sassato ti vuttaḥ yathā kuntā pacaranti iti sassato
translated: just as a person who is always angry is called “an angry man.”

original: iti vādo etesanti vā tattha iti-saddalopo daṭṭhabbo. Sassataṃ vadanti “idameva saccaṃ,
analyzed: iti vādaḥ etesan ti vā tattha iti sadda lopaḥ daṭṭhabbo sassatam vadanti idam eva saccam
translated: They speak thus, ‘This alone is the truth,’

original: moghamañña”nti abhinivissa voharantīti sassatavādā tipi yujjati.
analyzed: moghamaññanti abhinivissa voharanti iti sassata vādā tipi yujjati
translated: and they speak with the settled view that ‘the rest is futile.’

original: 31. Ātāpanabhāvenāti vibādhanassa bhāvena, vibādhanaṭṭhena vā. Pahānañcettha vibādhanaṃ.
analyzed: ātāpana bhāvena ati vibādhanassa bhāvena vibādhana ṭṭhena vā pahānam ca ittha vibādhanam
translated: ‘By the state of tormenting’: by the state of afflicting, or by the afflicting meaning. The abandoning here is the afflicting.🔽‘By the state of bearing up’: by the state of bearing up, but bearing up is

original: Padahanavasenāti samādahanavasena. Samādahanaṃ pana kosajjapakkhe patitumadatvā cittassa
analyzed: padahana vasena ati samādahana vasena samādahanam pana kosajja pakkhe cittassa
translated: the rousing of cognizance so that it does not fall into the side of indolence.

original: ussāhanaṃ. Yathā samādhi visesabhāgiyataṃ pāpuṇāti, evaṃ vīriyassa bahulīkaraṇaṃ🔽anuyogo. Iti padattayena vīriyameva vuttanti āha “evaṃ tippabhedaṃ vīriya”nti. Yathākkamañhiha
analyzed: ussāhanam yathā samādhi visesa bhāgiyatam pāpuṇāti evam vīriyassa bahulīkaraṇam  anuyogaḥ iti vīriyam eva vuttan ti āha evam tippabhedam vīriyanti yathākkaman hi ha
translated: The pursuit is the repeated practice of energy in such a way that it comes to have the special quality of concentration.🔽So it is energy that is spoken of by the three terms.🔽For the three terms here show respectively the keeping in being of serenity and insight, the keeping in being of energy, and the keeping in being of mindfulness and equanimity.

original: tīhi padehi upacārappanācittaparidamanavīriyāni dasseti. Na pamajjati etenāti appamādo,
analyzed: tīhi padehi upacāra ppanā citta paridamana vīriyāni dasseti na pamajjati etena ati appamādaḥ
translated: ‘He is not negligent’ : non-negligence is non-forgetting of the object by mindfulness.🔽But that is the four factors of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: satiyā avippavāso. So pana satipaṭṭhānā cattāro khandhā eva. Sammā upāyena manasi
analyzed: satiyā avippavāso so pana sati paṭṭhānā cattāro khandhāḥ eva sammā upāyena manasi
translated: ‘He is rightly in being’: he is in being rightly, by the right means, by the path.

original: karoti kammaṭṭhānametenāti sammāmanasikāro, so pana ñāṇameva, na ārammaṇavīthijavanapaṭipādakā,
analyzed: karoti kammaṭṭhānam etena ati sammāmanasikāro so pana ñāṇam eva na ārammaṇa vīthi javana paṭipādakā
translated: Right reflection is the means by which he does the meditation subject. But that is knowledge, not a forerunner of the cognitive series that has applied thought.

original: tenāha “atthato ñāṇa”nti. Pathamanasikāroti kāraṇamanasikāro. Tadevatthaṃ samattheti
analyzed: tena āha atthataḥ ñāṇam ti kāraṇa manasikāro tat evattham samatthā iti
translated: So it is said: “In the sense of knowledge” . The first reflection is the reflection as cause. He makes that the same means

original: “yasmiñhī”tiādinā. Tattha yasmiṃ manasikāreti kammaṭṭhānamanasikaraṇūpāyabhūte ñāṇasaṅkhāte🔽manasikāre. “Imasmiṃ ṭhāne”ti iminā saddantarasampayogādinā viya pakaraṇavasenāpi🔽saddo visesavisayoti dīpeti. Vīriyañcāti yathāvuttehi tīhi padehi vuttaṃ tippabhedaṃ🔽vīriyañca. Etthāti “ātappa…pe… manasikāramanvāyā”ti imasmiṃ pāṭhe, sīlavisuddhiyā
analyzed: yasmin hi iti ādinā yasmin manasikāre iti kammaṭṭhāna manasikaraṇa upāya bhūte ñāṇa saṅkhāte  manasikāre imasmin ṭhāne iti iminā pakaraṇa vasena api  saddaḥ visesa visayaḥ ti dīpeti vīriyam ca ati yathā vuttehi tīhi padehi vuttam ti pabhedam  vīriyam ca ettha ati ātappape manasikāram anvāyāti imasmin pāṭhe sīla visuddhiyā
translated: “In the case of” , etc. Herein, in the reflection is in the reflection called knowledge, which is the means for the undertaking of the meditation subject.🔽In this place: the word “in” shows that the word “case” has a particular meaning, like the words “together with” , “in combination with” , etc., and also like the word “in” in the expression “in the Canon” .

original: saddhiṃ catunnaṃ rūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ adhigamanapaṭipadā idha vattabbā, sā pana visuddhimagge
analyzed: saddhim catunnam rūpāvacara jhānānam adhigamana paṭipadā idha vattabbā sā pana visuddhi magge
translated: And energy: the energy of the three kinds stated by the three terms already mentioned. Herein: in this text, “diligence … reflection … and endeavour” , the way of practice for attaining the four fine-material jhānas together with purification of virtue should be stated. But that is stated in the Visuddhimagga

original: vitthārato vuttāti āha “saṅkhepattho”ti. Tathājātikanti tathāsabhāvaṃ, etena cuddasavidhehi
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vuttā iti āha saṅkhepa atthaḥ ti tathājātikam ti tathā sabhāvam etena cuddasavidhehi
translated: “The meaning of the brief statement” is the meaning of the brief statement. “Of such a kind” means of such a nature. By this he shows the fourteen kinds of

original: cittaparidamanehi rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānassa paguṇatāpādanena damitataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: citta paridamanehi rūpāvacara catuttha jjhānassa paguṇa tā āpādanena damita tam dasseti
translated: He said “the meaning of the brief form” because it is stated in brief. “Of such a kind” means of such a nature. By this he shows that it is tamed by the attainment of mastery over the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere by means of the fourteen kinds of mental development of that jhāna .

original: Cetaso samādhi cetosamādhi, so pana aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatarūpāvacaracatutthajjhānasseva
analyzed: cetasaḥ samādhi cetaḥ samādhi so pana aṭṭhaṅga samannāgata rūpāvacara catuttha jhānassa iva
translated: “Mental unification” is cetosamādhi . But that is the unification of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere endowed with eight factors.

original: samādhi. Yathā-saddo “yenā”ti atthe nipātoti āha “yena samādhinā”ti.
analyzed: yathā saddaḥ yena ati atthe nipāto ti āha yena samādhinā iti
translated: The word yathā is a particle in the sense of “by which” . That is why he said “by means of which unification.”

original: Vijambhanabhūtehi lokiyābhiññāsaṅkhātehi jhānānubhāvehi sampannoti jhānānubhāvasampanno.
analyzed: vijambhana bhūtehi lokiya abhiññā saṅkhātehi jhāna anubhāvehi sampannaḥ ti jhāna anubhāva sampannaḥ
translated: He is “endowed with the jhāna factors” because he possesses the jhāna’s potency, which is like its wings, consisting in the supramundane direct knowledges.

original: So diṭṭhigatiko evaṃ vadatīti vattamānavacanaṃ, tathāvadanassa avicchedabhāvena sabbakālikatādassanatthanti
analyzed: so diṭṭhigatikaḥ evam vadati iti vattamāna vacanam tathā vadanassa aviccheda bhāvena sabba kālika tā dassana ttham ti
translated: The present tense in the words “he speaks thus” should be understood as having the sense of the past tense in order to show that he spoke thus without interruption all the time.🔽For the words “when it has ripened” refer to a particular time that is not specified.

original: veditabbaṃ. Aniyamite hi kālavisese vippakatakālavacananti. Vanati yācati puttanti
analyzed: veditabbam a niyamite hi kāla visese vippakata kāla vacananti vanati yācati puttanti
translated: A barren woman is called “vañjhā” because she “vanati” , i.e. begs, for a child.

original: vañjhā jha-paccayaṃ, na-kārassa ca niggahitaṃ katvā, vadhati puttaṃ, phalaṃ vā hanatītipi
analyzed: vañjhā jha paccayam nakārassa ca niggahitam katvā vadhati puttam phalam vā hanati iti pi
translated: The prefix “ni” is prefixed to the verbal root “vañj” in the sense of prohibition, and the verbal root “ha” is prefixed by the negative particle “na” in the sense of killing. Thus the compound word “avaññatthaññaputtā” is formed.

original: vañjhā sapaccayaghya-kārassa jha-kāraṃ, niggahitāgamañca katvā. Sā viya kassaci phalassa
analyzed: vañjhā jhakāram katvā sā kassaci phalassa
translated: The letter jha is the barren of the one who has the function of jha, having made the letter jha and the vowel sign dependent. Like that, for some fruit

original: ajanenāti vañjho, tenāha “vañjhapasū”tiādi. Evaṃ padatthavatā iminā kīdisaṃ sāmatthiyatthaṃ🔽dassetīti antolīnacodanaṃ pariharituṃ “etenā”tiādimāha. Jhānalābhissa visesena jhānadhammā
analyzed: ajanena ati vañjhaḥ tena āha vañjha pasūti ādi evam padatthavatā iminā kīdisam sāmatthiyattham  dasseti iti antolīna codanam pariharitum etena ati ādim āha jhāna lābhissa visesena jhāna dhammā
translated: It is barren because it does not give birth. Therefore it is said: “barren cow” and so on. Thus, by the meaning of the word, this shows what kind of capability

original: āpāthamāgacchanti, tammukhena pana sesadhammāpīti imamatthaṃ sandhāya “jhānādīna”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Rūpādijanakabhāvanti rūpādīnaṃ janakasāmatthiyaṃ. Paṭikkhipatīti “nayime
analyzed: āpātham āgacchanti tad mukhena pana sesa dhammā api iti imam attham sandhāya  vuttam rūpa ādi janaka bhāvanti rūpa ādīnam janaka sāmatthiyam paṭikkhipati iti na yime
translated: In order to avoid the internal contradiction, he says “by this” and so on. For one who has attained jhāna, the dhammas of jhāna come within the range of experience especially, but other dhammas also come within the range of experience through that. With this meaning in mind, “jhāna and so on”

original: kiñci janentī”ti paṭikkhipati. Kasmāti ce? Sati hi janakabhāve rūpādidhammānaṃ viya,🔽sukhādidhammānaṃ viya ca paccayāyattavuttitāya uppādavantatā viññāyati, uppāde ca
analyzed: kiñci janenti iti paṭikkhipati kasmā iti ce sati hi janaka bhāve rūpa ādi dhammānam viya  sukha ādi dhammānam viya ca paccaya āyatta vutti tāya uppādavanta tā viññāyati uppāde ca
translated: Is said. The capability of producing form and so on means the capability of producing form and so on. He rejects means he rejects “these do not produce anything.” Why is it so? For if there is the state of producing, like the dhammas of form and so on,

original: sati avassaṃbhāvī nirodhoti anavakāsāva niccatā siyā, tasmā taṃ paṭikkhipatīti.
analyzed: sati avassaṃbhāvī nirodhaḥ ti anavakāsā ava nicca tā siyā tasmā tam paṭikkhipati iti
translated: Like the dhammas of pleasure and so on, it is known that they exist in dependence on conditions, and if they arise, their cessation is not uncertain, so permanence is not possible at all. Therefore he rejects that.

original: Ṭhitoti niccalaṃ patiṭṭhito, kūṭaṭṭha-saddoyeva vā loke accantaṃ nicce niruḷho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ iti niccalam patiṭṭhitaḥ vā loke accantam nicce niruḷhaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: “Standing” : standing firm, unmoving. Or else, the word “standing” is to be understood in the sense of “standing firm” , which is well-known in the world.

original: Tiṭṭhatīti ṭhāyī, esikā ca sā ṭhāyī cāti esikaṭṭhāyī, visesanaparanipāto cesa, tasmā
analyzed: tiṭṭhati iti ṭhāyī esikā ca sā ṭhāyī ca ati esika ṭṭhāyī visesana para nipāto tasmā
translated: “Standing firm” : ṭhāyī. “Standing firm like a pillar” : esikaṭṭhāyī. The word esikaṭṭhāyī is a compound word in which the second member is qualified by the first.

original: gambhīranemo niccalaṭṭhitiko indakhīlo viyāti attho, tenāha “yathā”tiādi. “Kūṭaṭṭho”ti🔽iminā cettha aniccatābhāvamāha. “Esikaṭṭhāyī ṭhito”ti iminā pana yathā esikā vātappahārādīhi
analyzed: gambhīra nemaḥ niccala ṭṭhitikaḥ inda khīlaḥ viya ati tena āha yathā itiādi  iminā ca ittha anicca tā bhāvam āha esika ṭṭhāyī ṭhitaḥ ti iminā pana yathā esikā vāta ppahāra ādīhi
translated: Therefore the meaning is: “like an indrakīla which is deep-rooted and unmoving.” Hence the commentary says: “Just as … a pillar.”

original: na calati, evaṃ na kenaci vikāramāpajjatīti vikārābhāvaṃ, vikāropi atthato vināsoyevāti
analyzed: na calati evam na kenacid vikāram āpajjati iti vikāra abhāvam vikāraḥ api atthataḥ
translated: By the words “standing firm like a pillar” , the absence of impermanence is stated here. But by the words “standing firm like a pillar” , it is stated that just as a pillar is not moved by the impact of the wind, etc., so it is not subject to any change. The absence of change is in fact the absence of destruction.

original: vuttaṃ “ubhayenāpi lokassa vināsābhāvaṃ dassetī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam ubhayena api lokassa vināsa abhāvam dasseti iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “By both it is shown that the world is not subject to destruction.”

original: Evamaṭṭhakathāvādaṃ dassetvā idāni kecivādaṃ dassetuṃ “keci panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Muñjatoti
analyzed: evam aṭṭhakathā vādam dassetvā idāni keci vādam dassetum keci pana atiādi vuttam muñjato ti
translated: Having thus shown the opinion of the Atthakathā, the author now says “Some, however,” in order to show the opinion of others. “From muñja grass” :

original: [muñje (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)] muñjatiṇato. Īsikāti kaḷīro. Yadidaṃ attasaṅkhātaṃ dhammajātaṃ
analyzed: muñje muñja tiṇataḥ īsikā ati kaḷīraḥ yat idam atta saṅkhātam dhamma jātam
translated: from muñja reeds. “Like a pillar” : like a post. “What is called self” : the dhammas called self.

original: jāyatīti vuccati, taṃ sattirūpavasena pubbe vijjamānameva byattirūpavasena nikkhamati,🔽abhibyattiṃ gacchatīti attho. “Vijjamānamevā”ti hi etena kāraṇe phalassa atthibhāvadassanena🔽byattirūpavasena abhibyattivādaṃ dasseti. Sāligabbhe saṃvijjamānaṃ sālisīsaṃ viya
analyzed: jāyati iti vuccati tam satti rūpa vasena pubbe vijjamānam eva byatti rūpa vasena nikkhamati  abhibyattim gacchati iti atthaḥ vijjamānam eva ati hi etena kāraṇe phalassa atthi bhāva dassanena  byatti rūpa vasena abhibyatti vādam dasseti sāli gabbhe saṃvijjamānam sāli sīsam viya
translated: It is said to be born. It is only what already exists in the form of the seed that comes out in the form of the sprout.

original: hi sattirūpaṃ, tadabhinikkhantaṃ viya byattirūpanti. Kathaṃ pana sattirūpavasena🔽vijjamānoyeva pubbe anabhibyatto byattirūpavasena abhibyattiṃ gacchatīti? Yathā andhakārena🔽paṭicchanno ghaṭo ālokena abhibyattiṃ gacchati, evamayampīti.🔽Idamettha vicāretabbaṃ – kiṃ karonto āloko ghaṭaṃ pakāsetīti vuccati, yadi ghaṭavisayaṃ🔽buddhiṃ karonto pakāseti, anuppannāya eva buddhiyā uppattidīpanato abhibyattivādo
analyzed: hi satti rūpam tat abhinikkhantam viya byatti rūpanti katham pana satti rūpa vasena 🔽vijjamānaḥ yā iva pubbe an abhibyattaḥ byatti rūpa vasena abhibyattim gacchati iti yathā andhakārena 🔽paṭicchannaḥ ghaṭaḥ ālokena abhibyattim gacchati evam ayam pi iti 🔽idam ettha vicāretabbam kim karontaḥ ālokaḥ ghaṭam pakāseti iti vuccati yadi ghaṭa visayam 🔽buddhim karontaḥ pakāseti anuppannāya eva buddhiyāḥ uppatti dīpanataḥ abhibyatti vādaḥ
