original: hāyati. Atha ghaṭavisayāya buddhiyā āvaraṇabhūtaṃ andhakāraṃ vidhamanto pakāseti,🔽evampi abhibyattivādo hāyateva. Sati hi ghaṭavisayāya buddhiyā kathaṃ andhakāro tassā🔽āvaraṇaṃ hotīti. Yathā ca ghaṭassa abhibyatti na yujjati, evaṃ diṭṭhigatikaparikappitassa
analyzed: atha ghaṭa visayāya buddhiyā āvaraṇa bhūtam andhakāram vidhamantaḥ pakāseti  evam pi abhibyatti vādaḥ sati hi ghaṭa visayāya buddhiyā katham andhakāraḥ tassā  āvaraṇam hoti iti yathā ca ghaṭassa abhibyatti na yujjati evam diṭṭhi gatika parikappitassa
translated: If, on the other hand, it is said that the light reveals by removing the darkness which is an obstruction to the cognition of the pot,🔽then the theory of manifestation is also untenable. For if there is a cognition of the pot, how can darkness be an obstruction to it?

original: attanopi abhibyatti na yujjatiyeva. Tatthāpi hi yadi indriyavisayādisannipātena anuppannā🔽eva buddhi uppannā, uppattivacaneneva abhibyattivādo hāyati abhibyattimattamatikkamma
analyzed: attanaḥ pi abhibyatti na tattha api hi yadi indriya visaya ādi sannipātena anuppannā  eva buddhi uppannā uppatti vacanena iva abhibyatti vādaḥ hāyati abhibyattimattam atikkamma
translated: And just as the manifestation of the pot is untenable, so too is the manifestation of the self imagined by the theorists. For in that case, if a cognition that did not exist previously were to arise through the concurrence of the faculties, the object, etc.,

original: anuppannāya eva buddhiyā uppattidīpanato. Tathā sassatavādopi teneva kāraṇena. Atha
analyzed: anuppannāya eva buddhiyāḥ uppatti dīpanataḥ tathā sassata vādaḥ api tena iva kāraṇena atha
translated: then the theory of manifestation is untenable because of the very statement of arising. For it shows the arising of a cognition that did not exist previously, going beyond mere manifestation. And the theory of eternalism is untenable for the same reason.

original: buddhippavattiyā āvaraṇabhūtassa andhakāraṭṭhāniyassa mohassa vidhamanena buddhi
analyzed: buddhi ppavattiyāḥ āvaraṇa bhūtassa andhakāra ṭṭhāniyassa mohassa vidhamanena buddhi
translated: But if it is said that the cognition arises through the removal of delusion, which is a hindrance to the occurrence of cognition and is of the nature of darkness,

original: uppannā. Evampi sati atthavisayāya buddhiyā kathaṃ moho tassā āvaraṇaṃ hotīti, hāyateva
analyzed: uppannā evam pi sati attha visayāya buddhiyā katham moho tassāḥ āvaraṇam hoti iti hāyatā iva
translated: then the theory of manifestation is untenable because of the very statement of arising. For if there is a cognition of an object, how can delusion be an obstruction to it?

original: abhibyattivādo, kiñca bhiyyo – bhedasabbhāvatopi abhibyattivādo hāyati. Na hi abhibyañjanakānaṃ🔽candimasūriyamaṇipadīpādīnaṃ bhedena abhibyañjitabbānaṃ ghaṭādīnaṃ bhedo hoti, hoti🔽ca visayabhedena buddhibhedo yathāvisayaṃ buddhiyā sambhavatoti bhiyyopi abhibyatti
analyzed: abhibyatti vādaḥ kiñca bhiyyas bheda sabbhāvataḥ pi abhibyatti vādaḥ hāyati na hi abhibyañjana kānam  candima sūriya maṇi padīpa ādīnam bhedena abhibyañjitabbānam ghaṭa ādīnam bhedaḥ hoti hoti  ca visaya bhedena buddhi bhedaḥ yathā visayam buddhiyā sambhavati iti
translated: and yet there is a difference in the cognition according to the difference in the object, because the cognition is possible according to the object. So manifestation is not tenable even in this way.🔽And here the theory of manifestation by way of existence is not tenable as a theory of manifestation. For the theory of manifestation, which is called the occurrence of the existent,🔽is not admitted as anything other than the occurrence, which is called manifestation, of the existent,

original: na yujjatiyeva, na cettha vijjamānatābhibyattivasena vuttikappanā yuttā vijjamānatābhibyattikiriyāsaṅkhātāya🔽vuttiyā vuttimato ca anaññathānujānanato. Anaññāyeva hi tathā vuttisaṅkhātā kiriyā
analyzed: na yujjatiyā iva na ca ittha vijjamāna tā abhibyatti vasena vutti kappanā yuttā vijjamāna tā abhibyatti kiriyā a saṅkhātāya  vuttiyāḥ vuttimataḥ ca anaññathā anujānanataḥ anaññāyā iva hi tathā vutti saṅkhātā kiriyā
translated: in the sense of the action of the object to be manifested. For the state of being manifested is just the action called manifestation,

original: tabbantavatthuto, yathā phassādīhi phusanādibhāvo, tasmā vuttimato anaññāya eva vijjamānatābhibyattisaṅkhātāya
analyzed: tad anta vatthutaḥ yathā phassa ādīhi phusana ādi bhāvaḥ tasmai vuttimataḥ anaññāya eva vijjamāna tā abhibyatti saṅkhātāya
translated: in the object to be manifested, like the state of being touched, etc., in the object to be touched, etc., by contact, etc. Therefore the theory of manifestation by some people, which is imagined by way of the occurrence of the existent, which is called manifestation,

original: vuttiyā parikappito kesañci abhibyattivādo na yutto evāti. Ye pana “īsikaṭṭhāyī ṭhito”ti
analyzed: vuttiyā parikappito kesañci abhibyatti vādo na yutto evā ati ye pana īsika ṭṭhāyī ṭhito ti
translated: as something other than the existent, is not tenable. But those who say, “He stands as if he were an icicle,”

original: paṭhitvā yathāvuttamatthamicchanti, te tadidaṃ kāraṇabhāvena gahetvā “te ca sattā
analyzed: paṭhitvā yathāvuttam attham icchanti te tat idam kāraṇa bhāvena gahetvā te ca sattā
translated: and they maintain that the meaning stated is the meaning of the sutta.🔽They take it as a reason and say:

original: sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjantī”ti padehi atthasambandhampi karonti, na
analyzed: sandhāvanti saṃsaranti cavanti upapajjanti iti padehi attha sambandham pi karonti na
translated: Those who maintain that the meaning stated is the one intended by the words of the text take the words “and those beings” as a reason and construe them with the words “transmigrate, pass on, and reappear,”

original: aṭṭhakathāyamiva asambandhanti dassento “yasmā cā”tiādimāha. Te ca sattā sandhāvantīti🔽ettha ye idha manussabhāvena avaṭṭhitā, teyeva devabhāvādiupagamanena ito aññattha
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā āyam iva asambandhanti dassentaḥ yasmā ca ati ādim āha te ca sattā sandhāvanti iti  ettha ye idha manussa bhāvena avaṭṭhitā te yeva deva bhāva ādi upagamanena itas aññattha
translated: showing that they are not unrelated to the latter as they are in the commentary.

original: gacchantīti attho. Aññathā katassa kammassa vināso, akatassa ca abbhāgamo āpajjeyyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: gacchanti iti atthaḥ aññathā katassa kammassa vināsaḥ akatassa ca abbhāgamaḥ āpajjeyya ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words “and those beings” is this: those who are established here in the human state go to another state by being reborn as a god, etc. The intention is that otherwise the kamma done would be lost and kamma not done would come to fruition.

original: Aparāparanti aparasmā bhavā aparaṃ bhavaṃ, aparamaparaṃ vā, punappunanti attho. “Cavantī”ti🔽padamulliṅgetvā “evaṃ saṅkhyaṃ gacchantī”ti atthaṃ vivarati, attano tathāgahitassa
analyzed: apara aparanti aparasmai bhavāḥ aparam bhavam aparam aparam vā punappunanti cavanti iti  padam ulliṅgetvā evam saṅkhyam gacchanti iti attham vivarati tathāgahitassa
translated: “From existence to existence”: from one existence to another existence, or from one to the other, is the meaning of “from existence to existence.”

original: niccasabhāvattā na cutūpapattiyo. Sabbabyāpitāya nāpi sandhāvanasaṃsaraṇāni, dhammānaṃyeva
analyzed: nicca sabhāva ttā na cutūpapattiyaḥ sabba byāpitāya na api sandhāvana saṃsaraṇāni
translated: The word “transmigrate” is a verbal noun formed from the verb “to go” . The meaning is that they go in this way. If they were not so regarded, they would not die and be reborn, because they would have a permanent nature. Nor would they transmigrate and pass on, because they would be all-pervading.

original: pana pavattivisesena evaṃ saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti evaṃ voharīyantīti adhippāyo. Etena🔽“avaṭṭhitasabhāvassa attano, dhammino ca dhammamattaṃ uppajjati ceva vinassati cā”ti🔽imaṃ vipariṇāmavādaṃ dasseti. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ imissaṃ sassatavādavicāraṇāyameva
analyzed: pana pavatti visesena evam saṅkhyam gacchanti evam voharīyanti iti adhippāyaḥ etena  avaṭṭhita sabhāvassa attanaḥ dhammino ca dhamma mattam uppajjati ca iva vinassati ca ati  imam vipariṇāma vādam dasseti yam pana ittha vattabbam tam imissam sassata vāda vicāraṇāyam eva
translated: but they are so reckoned and so spoken of according to the difference in their occurrence. This is the intention.🔽By this he shows the doctrine of change, namely, that “the self, which is not a fixed entity, and the states, which are a mere succession of states, arise and cease to be.” But what has to be said about this has been said in the treatment of the doctrine of eternalism.

original: “evaṃgatikā”ti padatthavibhāvane vakkhāma. Idāni aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ asambandhamattaṃ
analyzed: evaṃgatikā iti padattha vibhāvane vakkhāma idāni aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam asambandha mattam
translated: “Thus it goes” : we shall explain the meaning of this expression in the treatment of the doctrine of annihilationism.

original: dassetuṃ “aṭṭhakathāyaṃ panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sandhāvantītiādinā vacanena attano vādaṃ🔽bhindati vināseti sandhāvanādivacanasiddhāya aniccatāya pubbe attanā paṭiññātassa
analyzed: dassetum aṭṭhakathāyam pana atiādi vuttam sandhāvanti iti ādinā vacanena attanaḥ vādam  bhindati vināseti sandhāvana ādi vacana siddhāya anicca tāya pubbe attanā paṭiññātassa
translated: Now, in order to show the mere irrelevance of the statement in the commentary, it is said, “But in the commentary” , etc.🔽By the statement beginning with “wandering on” , he breaks up, destroys, his own doctrine,🔽because the doctrine of eternalism, which he himself has previously admitted, is contradicted by impermanence, which is established by the statement “wandering on” , etc. The meaning is that.

original: sassatavādassa viruddhabhāvatoti attho. “Diṭṭhigatikassā”tiādi tadatthasamatthanaṃ.
analyzed: sassata vādassa viruddha bhāvato ti atthaḥ diṭṭhigatikassa atiādi tad attha samatthanam
translated: “For one who holds a view” , etc., is the demonstration of that meaning.

original: Na nibaddhanti na thiraṃ. “Sandhāvantī”tiādivacanaṃ, sassatavādañca sandhāya “sundarampi
analyzed: na na thiram sandhāvanti iti ādi vacanam sandhāya sundaram pi
translated: “Not fixedly” : not firmly.

original: asundarampi hotiyevā”ti vuttaṃ. Sabbadā saranti pavattantīti sassatiyo ra-kārassa
analyzed: asundaram pi hotiyā iva ati vuttam sabbadā saranti pavattanti iti sassatiyoḥ rakārassa
translated: and it is not beautiful.”

original: sa-kāraṃ, dvibhāvañca katvā, pathavīsinerucandimasūriyā, sassatīhi samaṃ sadisaṃ🔽tathā, bhāvanapuṃsakavacanañcetaṃ. “Attā ca loko cā”ti hi kattuadhikāro. Sassatisamanti🔽vā liṅgabyattayena kattuniddeso. Sassatisamo attā ca loko ca atthi evāti attho, iti-saddo
analyzed: sakāram dvi bhāvam ca katvā pathavī sineru candima sūriyā sassatīhi samam sadisam  tathā attā ca lokaḥ ca ati hi kattu adhikāraḥ  vā liṅga byattayena kattu niddeso sassati samaḥ attā ca loko ca atthi eva ati atthaḥ iti saddo
translated: All the time, they flow on, thus they are eternalists (sassatiyo). The ra of sassati is made sa, and the dv is made v, thus it is like the earth, the Himalayas, the moon, the sun.🔽Eternalists are similar to them, thus it is said. And this is a neuter word formed by adding -a to the base. “The self and the world” is the nominative case. Eternalists are similar, thus

original: cettha padapūraṇamattaṃ. Eva-saddassa hi e-kāre pare iti-sadde i-kārassa va-kāramicchanti🔽saddavidū. Sassatisamanti sassataṃ thāvaraṃ niccakālantipi attho, sassatisama-saddassa
analyzed: ca ittha pada pūraṇam attam eva saddassa hi ekāre pare iti sadde ikārassa vakāram icchanti  sadda vidū sassati samanti sassatam thāvaram attho sassati sama saddassa
translated: it is said. Or the nominative case is indicated by the three genders. The meaning is: “The self and the world exist as eternalists are similar.” The word iti🔽here is merely to fill out the line. For those who know the language want the i of iti to be made va when e is after it.

original: sassatapadena samānatthataṃ sandhāya ṭīkāyaṃ vutto.
analyzed: sassata padena samānattha tam sandhāya ṭīkā āyam vuttaḥ
translated: Eternalists are similar, thus it is said. The meaning is: “Eternal, stable, permanent.” This is said in the subcommentary with reference to the fact that the word eternalists is similar in meaning to the word eternal.

original: Hetuṃ dassentoti yesaṃ “sassato”ti attānañca lokañca paññapeti, tesaṃ hetuṃ dassento
analyzed: hetum dassento ti yesam sassataḥ ti attānam ca lokañca paññapeti tesam hetum dassento
translated: Showing the reason: showing the reason for those who declare the self and the world to be eternal.

original: ayaṃ diṭṭhigatiko āhāti sambandho. Na hi attano diṭṭhiyā paccakkhakatamatthaṃ attanoyeva
analyzed: ayam diṭṭhi gatikaḥ āha ati sambandhaḥ na hi attanaḥ diṭṭhiyā attanaḥ yeva
translated: For one does not establish a meaning that is evident to oneself by means of one’s own view.

original: sādheti, attano pana paccakkhakatena atthena attano appaccakkhabhūtampi atthaṃ sādheti,
analyzed: sādheti attanaḥ pana paccakkha katena atthena attanaḥ appaccakkha bhūtam pi attham sādheti
translated: But one establishes a meaning that is not evident to oneself by means of a meaning that is evident to oneself.

original: attanā ca yathānicchitaṃ atthaṃ parepi viññāpeti, na anicchitaṃ, idaṃ pana hetudassanaṃ
analyzed: attanā ca yathā an icchitam attham pare pi viññāpeti na an icchitam idam pana hetu dassanam
translated: And one makes known to others a meaning that is desired by oneself, not one that is not desired. This is the presentation of the reason.

original: etesu anekesu jātisatasahassesu ekovāyaṃ me attā ca loko ca anussaraṇasambhavato.🔽Yo hi yamatthaṃ anubhavati, so eva taṃ anussarati, na añño. Na hi aññena anubhūtamatthaṃ
analyzed: etesu anekesu jāti sata sahassesu ekaḥ u vā ayam me attā ca loko ca anussaraṇa sambhavataḥ  yaḥ hi yam attham anubhavati saḥ eva tam anussarati na aññaḥ na hi aññena anubhūtam attham
translated: In these many hundreds of thousands of births, this is the only self and world that I remember.

original: añño anussarituṃ sakkoti yathā taṃ buddharakkhitena anubhūtaṃ dhammarakkhito. Yathā🔽cetāsu, evaṃ ito purimatarāsupi jātīsu, tasmā “sassato me attā ca loko ca, yathā
analyzed: aññaḥ anussaritum sakkoti yathā tam buddha rakkhitena anubhūtam dhamma rakkhitaḥ yathā  evam itas purimatarāsu pi jātīsu tasmā sassataḥ me attā ca loko ca yathā
translated: For it is only he who experiences a certain meaning who remembers it, not another. For another cannot remember a meaning experienced by another, as Dhammarakkhita could remember what was experienced by Buddharakkhita.🔽And just as in these , so also in the births prior to these. Therefore, “My self and the world are eternal,

original: ca me, evaṃ aññesampi sattānaṃ sassato attā ca loko cā”ti sassatavasena diṭṭhigahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ca me evam aññesam pi sattānam sassato attā ca loko ca ati sassata vasena diṭṭhi gahaṇam
translated: and just as they are for me, so they are for other beings too.” Thus he grasps the view in terms of eternalism.

original: pakkhandanto diṭṭhigatiko parepi tattha patiṭṭhapeti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “anekavihitāni🔽adhimuttipathāni abhivadanti, so evamāhā”ti vacanato parānugāhāpanavasena idha hetudassanaṃ🔽adhippetanti viññāyati. Etanti attano ca lokassa ca sassatabhāvaṃ. “Na kevala”ntiādi🔽atthato āpannadassanaṃ. Ṭhāna-saddo kāraṇe, tañca kho idha pubbenivāsānussatiyevāti
analyzed: pakkhandantaḥ diṭṭhigatiko pare pi tattha patiṭṭhapeti pāḷiyam pana aneka vihitāni  adhimutti pathāni abhivadanti saḥ evam āha ati vacanataḥ para anugāhāpana vasena idha hetu dassanam  adhippetanti viññāyati etanti attanaḥ ca lokassa ca sassata bhāvam na kevala ntiādi  atthataḥ āpanna dassanam ṭhāna saddaḥ kāraṇe tat ca kho idha pubbenivāsa anussatiyā iva ati
translated: and he himself, being a theorist, establishes others in that view. But it is evident that the word “because” here refers to the reason for his doing so, since the text says, “He says thus because he proclaims various speculative views.” The word “that” refers to the eternalism of himself and the world. The words “not only” show the meaning of the words “because” and “that.” The word “ground” means reason, and that is here the recollection of past lives.

original: āha “ida”ntiādi. Kāraṇañca nāmetaṃ tividhaṃ sampāpakaṃ nibbattakaṃ ñāpakanti. Tattha🔽ariyamaggo nibbānassa sampāpakakāraṇaṃ, bījaṃ aṅkurassa nibbattakakāraṇaṃ, paccayuppannatādayo🔽aniccatādīnaṃ ñāpakakāraṇaṃ, idhāpi ñāpakakāraṇameva adhippetaṃ. Ñāpako hi attho
analyzed: āha idam tiādi kāraṇam ca nāma etam tividham sampāpakam nibbattakam ñāpakam ti tattha  ariya maggaḥ nibbānassa sampāpaka kāraṇam bījam aṅkurassa nibbattaka kāraṇam paccaya uppanna tā ādayaḥ  anicca tā ādīnam ñāpaka kāraṇam idha api ñāpaka kāraṇam eva adhippetam ñāpakaḥ hi atthaḥ
translated: and he himself, being a theorist, establishes others in that view. But in the text it is said: “He says thus: ‘They declare various speculative views, and he says thus: ‘” . So it is evident that the word “cause” is used here in the sense of a reason for persuading others. The word “that” refers to the eternalism of self and world. The meaning of the words “not only” is stated in the words “not only the eternalist view” . The word “ground” is a reason. And here it is only the recollection of past lives that is intended. That is why it is said: “Herein, the word ‘ground’ is a reason. And the reason is of three kinds: maker, producer, and indicator” .

original: ñāpetabbatthavisayassa ñāṇassa hetubhāvato kāraṇaṃ. Tadāyattavuttitāya taṃ ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: ñāpetabba attha visayassa ñāṇassa hetu bhāvataḥ kāraṇam tad āyatta vutti tāya tam ñāṇam
translated: Herein, the noble path is the reason for the realization of Nibbāna, the seed is the reason for the production of the sprout, and the impermanence, etc., of formations is the reason for the knowledge of their impermanence, etc. Here the reason as indicator is intended. For the meaning of “indicator” is a reason in the sense of cause for the knowledge of the object to be indicated. The knowledge is called a reason because it exists in dependence on that.

original: tiṭṭhati etthāti ṭhānaṃ, vasati taṃ ñāṇamettha tiṭṭhatīti “vatthū”ti ca vuccati.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha ati ṭhānam vasati tam ñāṇam ettha tiṭṭhati iti ca vuccati
translated: and since it is the place where that knowledge stands, it is called a “standpoint” .

original: Tathā hi bhagavatā vatthu-saddena uddisitvāpi ṭhāna-saddena niddiṭṭhanti.🔽32-33. Dutiyatatiyavārānaṃ paṭhamavārato viseso natthi ṭhapetvā kālabhedanti āha🔽“upari vāradvayepi eseva nayo”ti. Tadetaṃ kālabhedaṃ yathāpāḷiṃ dassetuṃ “kevalañhī”tiādi
analyzed: tathā hi bhagavatā vatthu saddena uddisitvā api ṭhāna saddena niddiṭṭhanti  dutiya tatiya vārānam paṭhama vārataḥ viseso natthi ṭhapetvā kāla bhedan ti āha  upari vāra dvaye pi tat etam kāla bhedam yathāpāḷim dassetum kevalam hi itiādi
translated: For the Exalted One, after mentioning it by the word “standpoint,” explained it by the word “standpoint” .🔽There is no difference between the first and the second and third sections except in the length of time covered. Therefore it is said: “The same method applies to the two higher sections.”

original: vuttaṃ. Itarena dutiyatatiyavārā yāva dasasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappā, yāva cattālīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappā
analyzed: vuttam itarena dutiya tatiya vārāḥ yāva dasa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappāḥ yāva cattālīsa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappāḥ
translated: In order to show the length of time covered by the second and third sections according to the text, the following is said: “Only the time is different.” The intention is that the second and third sections are stated by way of recollection of the past up to ten and forty eons of world contraction and expansion, respectively.

original: ca anussaraṇavasena vuttāti adhippāyo. Yadevaṃ kasmā sassatavādo catudhā vibhatto,
analyzed: ca anussaraṇa vasena vuttā ati adhippāyaḥ yat evam kasmā sassata vādaḥ catudhā vibhatto
translated: If this is so, why is the eternalist view divided into four,

original: nanu tidhā kālabhedamakatvā adhiccasamuppattikavādo viya duvidheneva vibhajitabbo
analyzed: nanu tidhā kāla bhedam a katvā adhiccasamuppattika vādaḥ viya duvidhena iva vibhajitabbaḥ
translated: and not into two, like the view of fortuitous origination, without distinguishing the length of time?🔽In order to remove this doubt, the following is said: “Because of the dullness of the disciples.”

original: siyāti codanaṃ sodhetuṃ “mandapañño hī”tiādimāha. Mandapaññādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇalābhīnaṃ
analyzed: siyā iti codanam sodhetum manda paññaḥ hi itiādim āha manda paññā ādīnam tiṇṇam pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa lābhīnam
translated: The intention is that the three disciples of dull, middling, and sharp faculties, who have attained the knowledge of recollecting past lives,

original: vasena tidhā kālabhedaṃ katvā takkanena saha catudhā vibhattoti adhippāyo. Nanu ca
analyzed: vasena tidhā kāla bhedam katvā takkanena saha catudhā adhippāyaḥ nanu ca
translated: and then, by means of the three kinds of knowledge, he is divided into four by means of the three kinds of knowledge and the knowledge of the past.

original: anussavādivasena takkikānaṃ viya mandapaññādīnampi visesalābhīnaṃ hīnādivasena anekabhedasambhavato
analyzed: anussava ādi vasena takkikānam viya manda paññā ādīnam pi visesa lābhīnam hīna ādi vasena aneka bheda sambhavato
translated: But since there are also those of slow understanding, etc., who have attained distinction, and they are of many kinds according to the distinction of the inferior, etc.,

original: bahudhā bhedo siyā, atha kasmā sabbepi visesalābhino tayo eva rāsī katvā vuttāti?
analyzed: bahudhā bhedaḥ siyā atha kasmā sabbe pi visesa lābhino tayo eva rāsī katvā vuttā ati
translated: why are all those who have attained distinction stated in terms of only three kinds?

original: Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedena dassetukāmattā. Tīsu hi rāsīsu ye hīnamajjhimapaññā, te vuttaparicchedato
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha paricchedena tīsu hi rāsīsu ye hīna majjhima paññā te vutta paricchedato
translated: Because he wishes to show the maximum. For those of inferior and medium understanding among the three kinds of persons only remember what is stated,

original: ūnakameva anussaranti. Ye pana ukkaṭṭhapaññā, te vuttaparicchedaṃ atikkamitvā nānussarantīti🔽tattha tattha ukkaṭṭhaparicchedena dassetukāmato anekajātisatasahassadasacattārīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭānussaraṇavasena
analyzed: ūnakam eva anussaranti ye pana ukkaṭṭha paññā te vutta paricchedam atikkamitvā na anussaranti iti  tattha tattha ukkaṭṭha paricchedena dassetu kāmataḥ aneka jāti sata sahassa dasa cattārīsa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa anussaraṇa vasena
translated: but those of superior understanding remember more than is stated.🔽So he states them in terms of only three kinds, wishing to show the maximum in each case, by means of the remembering of one, two, and three asankheyyas and forty eons, respectively.

original: tayo eva rāsī katvā vuttāti. Na tato uddhanti yathāvuttakālattayato, cattārīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappato
analyzed: tayoḥ eva rāsī katvā vuttā ati na tatas uddhanti yathā vutta kāla ttayato cattārīsa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappato
translated: They do not go beyond that, that is, beyond the three kinds of knowledge stated.

original: vā uddhaṃ nānussarati, kasmā? Dubbalapaññattā. Tesañhi nāmarūpaparicchedavirahato
analyzed: vā uddham na anussarati kasmā dubbala paññattā tesam hi nāma rūpa pariccheda virahato
translated: Why does he not recollect the past? Because his wisdom is weak. For they are devoid of the discernment of mentality-materiality.

original: dubbalā paññā hotīti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ.🔽34. Tappakatiyattopi kattutthoyevāti āha “takkayatī”ti. Tappakatiyattattā eva hi
analyzed: dubbalā paññā hoti iti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam  tad pakati yattaḥ api kattutthaḥ yā iva ati āha takkayati iti tad pakati yattattā eva hi
translated: Why does he not review upwards? Because his understanding is weak. For it is said in the commentaries that their understanding is weak because they lack the discernment of mentality-materiality.

original: dutiyanayopi upapanno hoti. Tattha takkayatīti ūhayati, sassatādiākārena tasmiṃ tasmiṃ🔽ārammaṇe cittaṃ abhiniropayatīti attho. Takkoti ākoṭanalakkhaṇo, vinicchayalakkhaṇo
analyzed: dutiya nayaḥ api upapannaḥ hoti tattha takkayati iti ūhayati sassata ādi ākārena tasmim tasmim  ārammaṇe cittam abhiniropayati iti attho takkoti ākoṭana lakkhaṇo vinicchaya lakkhaṇo
translated: And the second method is also appropriate because of the delimitation of the extent by the question.🔽The meaning of the words is this. He speculates: he speculates about, he directs his mind to, he assumes the aspect of, eternalism, etc., in regard to this or that object.🔽The characteristic of speculation is that of striking, or it is the characteristic of investigation.

original: vā diṭṭhiṭṭhānabhūto vitakko. Tena tena pariyāyena takkanaṃ sandhāya “takketvā vitakketvā”ti
analyzed: vā diṭṭhi ṭṭhāna bhūtaḥ vitakkaḥ tena tena pariyāyena takkanam sandhāya takketvā vitakketvā iti
translated: It is a kind of applied thought that is a basis for views.🔽The words “after speculating, after pondering” refer to speculation in its various modes.

original: vuttaṃ vīmaṃsāya samannāgatoti atthavacanamattaṃ. Nibbacanaṃ pana takkipade viya
analyzed: vuttam vīmaṃsāya samannāgataḥ ti attha vacana mattam nibbacanam pana takki pade viya
translated: The words “possessed of investigation” are merely a statement of the meaning.🔽But the explanation should be given in two ways, as in the case of the word “speculator.”

original: dvidhā vattabbaṃ. Vīmaṃsā nāma vicāraṇā, sā ca duvidhā paññā ceva paññāpatirūpikā
analyzed: dvidhā vattabbam vīmaṃsā nāma vicāraṇā sā ca duvidhā paññā ca iva paññā patirūpikā
translated: Investigation is the act of investigating, and it is of two kinds: it is both understanding and that which is reflected by understanding.

original: ca. Idha pana paññāpatirūpikāva, sā catthato lobhasahagatacittuppādo, micchābhinivesasaṅkhāto
analyzed: ca idha pana sā catthatas lobha sahagata cittuppādaḥ micchā abhinivesa saṅkhāto
translated: Here, however, it is only the semblance of understanding. It is a state of consciousness accompanied by greed in the sense of wrong adherence,

original: vā ayonisomanasikāro. Pubbabhāge vā micchādassanabhūtaṃ diṭṭhivipphanditaṃ, tadetamatthattayaṃ🔽dassetuṃ “tulanā ruccanā khamanā”ti vuttaṃ. “Tulayitvā”tiādīsupi yathākkamaṃ “lobhasahagatacittuppādenā”tiādinā
analyzed: vā a yoniso manasikāraḥ pubbabhāge vā micchādassana bhūtam diṭṭhi vipphanditam tat etam atthattayam  dassetum tulanā ruccanā khamanā iti vuttam tulayitvā atiādīsu pi yathākkamam lobha sahagata cittuppādena atiādinā
translated: or it is wrong reflection in the form of wrong attention. Or it is the vacillation of views in the form of wrong view in the earlier stage. In order to show that this is the meaning of the three terms, “weighing,” “liking,” and “agreeing” are said.🔽And in the passages beginning “having weighed” , etc., the words “with a state of consciousness accompanied by greed,” etc., should be construed.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Samantato, punappunaṃ vā āhananaṃ pariyāhataṃ, taṃ pana vitakkassa ārammaṇaṃ🔽ūhanameva, bhāvanapuṃsakañcetaṃ padanti dasseti “tena tena pariyāyena takketvā”ti
analyzed: yojetabbam samantataḥ punappunam vā āhananam pariyāhatam tam pana vitakkassa ārammaṇam  ūhanam eva bhāva napuṃsakam ca itam dasseti tena tena pariyāyena takketvā ati
translated: Repeatedly striking or hitting all round is “repeated striking.” But that is only the object of applied thought. The word “way” shows that it is a male being in the course of development.🔽“By that way” shows that it is by the reason.

original: iminā. Pariyāyenāti ca kāraṇenāti attho. Vuttappakārāyāti tidhā vuttappabhedāya.
analyzed: iminā pariyāyena ati ca kāraṇena ati atthaḥ vutta ppakārāya ati tidhā vutta ppabhedāya
translated: “In the way stated” : in the threefold way stated.

original: Anuvicaritanti anupavattitaṃ, vīmaṃsānugatena vā vicārena anumajjitaṃ. Tadanugatadhammakiccampi
analyzed: anuvicaritam ti an upavattitam vīmaṃsā anugatena vā vicārena anumajjitam tad anugata dhamma kiccam pi
translated: “Has occurred” : has occurred in succession; or it has been pondered by the investigation-type applied thought that is associated with it.

original: hi padhānadhamme āropetvā tathā vuccati. Paṭibhāti dissatīti paṭibhānaṃ, yathāsamāhitākāravisesavibhāvako🔽diṭṭhigatasampayuttacittuppādo, tato jātanti paṭibhānaṃ, tathā paññāyanaṃ, sayaṃ
analyzed: hi padhāna dhamme āropetvā tathā vuccati paṭibhāti dissati iti paṭibhānam yathā samāhita ākāra visesa vibhāvakaḥ  diṭṭhi gata sampayutta cittuppādaḥ tatas jāta nti paṭibhānam tathā paññāyanam sayam
translated: it is a manifestation of the special mode of perception in one who is concentrated.

original: attano paṭibhānaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ, tenevāha “attano paṭibhānamattasañjāta”nti. Matta-saddena
analyzed: attano paṭibhānam sayaṃpaṭibhānam tena iva āha attano paṭibhāna matta sañjātanti matta saddena
translated: It is a “self-discernment” because it is a discernment of one’s own .🔽The word “only” excludes the attainment of distinction, etc.,

original: cettha visesādhigamādayo nivatteti. Anāmaṭṭhakālavacane vattamānavaseneva atthaniddeso
analyzed: ca ittha visesa adhigama ādayaḥ nivatteti anāmaṭṭha kāla vacane vattamāna vasena iva attha niddeso
translated: and the explanation of the meaning is given in the present tense in the sense of the time of the statement.

original: upapannoti āha “evaṃ vadatī”ti.
analyzed: upapannā iti āha evam vadati iti
translated: “He says thus” means “he speaks thus.”

original: Pāḷiyaṃ “takkī hoti vīmaṃsī”ti sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesena vā vuttaṃ takkībhedaṃ
analyzed: pāḷiyam takkī hoti vīmaṃsī iti sāmañña niddesena ekasesena vā vuttam takkī bhedam
translated: In the text, “he is a reasoner, an investigator,” the reasoner is stated by a general description or by a particular description.🔽In order to analyze the reasoner, he says, “Herein, the reasoner is fourfold.”

original: vibhajanto “tattha catubbidho”tiādimāha. Parehi puna savanaṃ anussuti, sā yassāyaṃ
analyzed: vibhajantaḥ tattha catubbidhā iti ādim āha parehi puna savanam sā yassa ayam
translated: The hearing of others is “report.” One who has that is “one who reports.”🔽One who remembers his former lives is “one who remembers his former lives.”

original: anussutiko. Purimaṃ anubhūtapubbaṃ jātiṃ saratīti jātissaro. Labbhateti lābho, yaṃ
analyzed: anussutikaḥ purimam anubhūta pubbam jātim sarati iti jātissaraḥ labbhate iti lābhaḥ yam
translated: “Gain” is what is obtained.

original: kiñci attanā paṭiladdhaṃ rūpādi, sukhādi ca, na pana jhānādiviseso, tenevāha pāḷiyaṃ🔽“so takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānuvicaritaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ evamāhā”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyampi🔽vuttaṃ “attano paṭibhānamattasañjāta”nti. Ācariyadhammapālattheropi vadati “matta-saddena🔽visesādhigamādayo nivattetī”ti so etassāti lābhī. Suddhena purimehi asammissena,🔽suddhaṃ vā takkanaṃ suddhatakko, so yassāyaṃ suddhatakkiko. Tena hīti uyyojanatthe
analyzed: kiñci attanā paṭiladdham rūpa ādi sukha ādi ca na pana jhāna ādi viseso tena iva āha pāḷiyam  saḥ takka pariyāhatam vīmaṃsā anuvicaritam sayaṃpaṭibhānam evam āha ati  vuttam attanaḥ paṭibhāna matta sañjātanti ācariya dhammapāla ttheraḥ api vadati matta saddena  visesa adhigama ādayaḥ nivatteti iti saḥ etassa ati lābhī suddhena purimehi asammissena  suddham vā takkanam suddha takko saḥ yassa ayam suddha takkiko tena hi iti uyyojana tthe
translated: and what he has himself acquired is visible form, etc., and pleasure, etc., but not the special states of jhāna, etc. That is why it is said in the text:

original: nipāto, tena tathā vessantararaññova bhagavati samāneti diṭṭhiggāhaṃ uyyojeti. Lābhitāyāti🔽rūpādisukhādilābhībhāvato. “Anāgatepi evaṃ bhavissatī”ti idaṃ lābhītakkino evampi🔽sambhavatīti sambhavadassanavasena idhādhippetaṃ takkanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Anāgataṃsatakkaneneva
analyzed: tena tathā vessantara raññā uva bhagavati samāne iti diṭṭhiggāham uyyojeti lābhi tāya ati 🔽rūpa ādi sukha ādi lābhībhāvataḥ anāgate pi evam bhavissati iti idam lābhītakkinaḥ evam pi 🔽sambhavati iti sambhava dassana vasena idha adhippetam takkanam sandhāya vuttam anāgataṃsa takkanena iva
translated: “He spoke thus after devising the assertion himself by his own unaided effort” . And in the commentary too it is said: “He had the idea after devising it himself by his own unaided effort” . And the teacher Dhammapāla says: “The word ‘himself’ excludes the acquisition of special states, etc.” . He who has that kind of acquisition is a gainer . Pure: unmixed with the former . Or else, pure reasoning is pure conjecture; he who has that is a pure conjecturer . By that : the particle tena is in the sense of purpose; by that he dismisses the view that the Blessed One is the same as the king Vessantara. By the gain : by the fact of his having acquired visible forms, etc., and pleasure, etc. “It will be so in the future” : this is a conjecture about gain that is possible in the future. It is said with reference to the kind of conjecture intended here, which is shown to be possible. By the conjecture about the future …

original: hi sassataggāhī bhavati. “Atītepi evaṃ ahosī”ti idaṃ pana anāgataṃsatakkanassa upanissayanidassanamattaṃ.
analyzed: hi bhavati atīte pi evam ahosi iti idam pana anāgata satakkanassa upanissaya nidassana mattam
translated: for he holds the view of eternalism. “And in the past it was like this” is merely the showing of the condition for the view of the ten-times-a-hundred-fold future.

original: So hi “yathā me idāni attā sukhī hoti, evaṃ atītepīti paṭhamaṃ atītaṃsānutakkanaṃ🔽upanissāya anāgatepi evaṃ bhavissatī”ti takkayanto diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. “Evaṃ sati idaṃ
analyzed: saḥ hi yathā me idāni attā sukhī hoti evam atīta ipi iti paṭhamam atītaṃsa anutakkanam  upanissāya anāgate pi evam bhavissati iti takkayantaḥ diṭṭhim gaṇhāti evam sati idam
translated: For he, having first considered the past thus: “As my self is happy now, so it was in the past,”🔽and having considered the future thus: “So it will be in the future,” takes up the view by surmising.

original: hotī”ti iminā aniccesu bhāvesu añño karoti, añño paṭisaṃvedetīti doso āpajjati, tathā🔽ca sati katassa vināso akatassa ca ajjhāgamo siyā. Niccesu pana bhāvesu añño karoti,🔽añño paṭisaṃvedetīti doso nāpajjati. Evañca sati katassa avināso, akatassa ca anajjhāgamo🔽siyāti takkikassa yuttigavesanākāraṃ dasseti.
analyzed: hoti iti iminā aniccesu bhāvesu aññaḥ karoti aññaḥ paṭisaṃvedeti iti dosaḥ āpajjati tathā  ca sati katassa vināsaḥ akatassa ca ajjhāgamaḥ siyā niccesu pana bhāvesu aññaḥ karoti  aññaḥ paṭisaṃvedeti iti doso na āpajjati evañca sati katassa avināsaḥ akatassa ca anajjhāgamo  siyā iti takkikassa yutti gavesanā ākāram dasseti
translated: By the words “If this is so, then this is the case” he shows the method of the logician’s search for reasons.

original: Takkamattenevāti suddhatakkaneneva. Matta-saddena hi āgamādīnaṃ, anussavādīnañca
analyzed: takka mattena iva ati suddha takkanena iva matta saddena hi āgama ādīnam anussava ādīnam ca
translated: “By mere surmising” : by mere surmising. For by the word “mere” the logician’s use of tradition, etc., and of hearsay, etc.,🔽is excluded.

original: abhāvaṃ dasseti. “Nanu ca visesalābhinopi sassatavādino visesādhigamahetu anekesu
analyzed: abhāvam dasseti nanu ca visesa lābhinaḥ api sassata vādinaḥ visesa adhigama hetu anekesu
translated: he shows the non-existence of the self. “But do not the eternalists, too, who have attained distinction, by reason of the attainment of distinction,

original: jātisatasahassesu, dasasu saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭesu, cattālīsāya ca saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭesu yathānubhūtaṃ
analyzed: jāti sata sahassesu dasasu saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭesu cattālīsāya ca saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭesu yathānubhūtam
translated: he shows that there is no such thing. “But do not the eternalists who have attained to distinction, by reason of the attainment of distinction, recollect their own continuity, which they have experienced in many hundreds of thousands of births, in the ten

original: attano santānaṃ, tappaṭibaddhañca dhammajātaṃ “attā, loko”ti ca anussaritvā tato🔽purimatarāsupi jātīsu tathābhūtassa atthitānuvitakkanamukhena anāgatepi evaṃ bhavissatīti🔽attano bhavissamānānutakkanaṃ, sabbesampi sattānaṃ tathābhāvānutakkanañca katvā sassatābhinivesino
analyzed: attano santānam tad paṭibaddham ca dhamma jātam attā loko ti ca anussaritvā tatas  purimatarāsu pi jātīsu tathābhūtassa atthita anuvitakkana mukhena anāgate pi evam bhavissati iti  attanaḥ bhavissamāna anutakkanam sabbesam pi sattānam tathābhāva anutakkanam ca katvā sassata abhinivesinaḥ
translated: disappearances and re-appearances of the world, and in the forty disappearances and re-appearances of the world, and the things connected with it, and, calling them ‘self’ and ‘world,’🔽by the method of thinking ‘I was in existence in the past in such and such a way,’ recollect their own future existence in the same way, and by thinking ‘All beings will be in existence in the same way in the future,’🔽recollect the existence of all beings in the same way, and become attached to eternalism?

original: jātā, evañca sati sabbopi sassatavādī anussutikajātissaralābhītakkikā viya attano🔽upaladdhavatthunimittena takkanena pavattavādattā takkīpakkheyeva tiṭṭheyya, tathā
analyzed: jātā evañca sati sabbaḥ api sassata vādī viya attanaḥ  upaladdha vatthu nimittena takkanena takkīpakkheyā iva tiṭṭheyya tathā
translated: And if that is so, then all eternalists would be included in the category of reasoners, like the reasoner Anussutika, who attained to distinction by reason of the sign of the object he had perceived,🔽and they would be included in the category of reasoners, and

original: ca sati visesabhedarahitattā ekovāyaṃ sassatavādo vavatthito bhaveyya, avassañca
analyzed: ca sati visesa bheda rahita ttā ekaḥ uva ayam sassata vādaḥ vavatthitaḥ bhaveyya
translated: if that were so, then this eternalist doctrine would be defined as being without any distinction or division, and it would be impossible🔽to distinguish it from the reasoner Anussutika’s doctrine.

original: vuttappakāraṃ takkanamicchitabbaṃ, aññathā visesalābhī sassatavādī ekaccasassatikapakkhaṃ,🔽adhiccasamuppannikapakkhaṃ vā bhajeyyāti? Na kho panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Visesalābhīnañhi
analyzed: vutta ppakāram takkanam icchitabbam aññathā visesa lābhī sassata vādī ekacca sassatika pakkham  adhiccasamuppannika pakkham vā bhajeyya ati na kho pana etam evam daṭṭhabbam visesa lābhīnam hi
translated: and he must wish for the kind of surmising described, otherwise he would be a theorist who has attained distinction and would side either with the sect of the eternalists who believe in a single abiding entity or with the sect of the accidentalists.

original: khandhasantānassa dīghadīghataraṃ dīghatamakālānussaraṇaṃ sassataggāhassa asādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ.🔽Tathā hi “anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi. analyzed: diṭṭhīsu pakappayitvā saccam musā ati dvaya dhammam āhūti takkī hoti vīmaṃsī iti ca  ādi ayonisaḥ manasikāraḥ api akusalānam sādhāraṇa kāraṇa ṭṭhena tena āha tassa evam ayonisaḥ  manasi karotaḥ channam diṭṭhīnam aññatarā diṭṭhi uppajjati atthi me attā ati vā assa

analyzed: vā desanā paratoghosaḥ
translated: Or the teaching is the sound from another.

original: “Khandhā hetū”tiādipāḷi tadatthavibhāvinī. Tattha janakaṭṭhena hetu, upatthambhakaṭṭhena🔽paccayo. Upādāyāti upādiyitvā, paṭiccāti attho. “Uppādāyā”tipi pāṭho, uppajjanāyāti🔽attho. Samuṭṭhāti etenāti samuṭṭhānaṃ, khandhādayo eva. Idha pana samuṭṭhānabhāvoyeva
analyzed: khandhāḥ hetu uti ādi pāḷi tad attha vibhāvinī tattha janaka ṭṭhena hetu upatthambhaka ṭṭhena  paccayaḥ upādāya ati upādiyitvā paṭicca ati atthaḥ uppādāya atipi pāṭhaḥ uppajjanāya ati  etena ati samuṭṭhānam khandha ādayaḥ eva idha pana
translated: The text beginning with “The aggregates are causes” is what distinguishes the meaning of that. Herein, a cause is in the sense of generator,🔽a condition is in the sense of supporter. “Depending on” : having depended on, is the meaning of “having taken as a support.” The reading “for the purpose of arising” is the meaning of “for the purpose of arising.”

original: samuṭṭhāna-saddena vutto bhāvalopattā, bhāvappadhānattā ca. Ādinnā sakasantāne. Pavattitā
analyzed: samuṭṭhāna saddena vuttaḥ bhāva lopattā bhāva ppadhāna ttā ca ādinnā saka santāne pavatti tā
translated: That by which there is a rising is a source. The aggregates, etc., are themselves the source. But here the state of being a source is expressed by the word “source” because of the elision of the state and because of the prominence of the state.🔽Having taken up in one’s own continuum, having caused to occur

original: saparasantānesu. Para-saddo abhiṇhatthoti vuttaṃ “punappuna”nti. Pariniṭṭhāpitāti
analyzed: sa para santānesu para saddaḥ abhiṇha atthaḥ ti vuttam punappunanti pariniṭṭhāpitā ti
translated: in the continua of others. The word “other” is said to have the meaning of “repeatedly.”

original: “idameva dassanaṃ saccaṃ, aññaṃ pana moghaṃ tucchaṃ musā”ti abhinivesassa pariyosānaṃ
analyzed: idam eva dassanam saccam aññam pana mogham tuccham musā ati abhinivesassa pariyosānam
translated: Having brought to the end of the insistence that “This view alone is the truth, the others are false, void, and lying.”

original: matthakaṃ pāpitāti attho. Ārammaṇavasenāti aṭṭhasu diṭṭhiṭṭhānesu khandhe sandhāyāha.
analyzed: matthakam pāpitā iti attho ārammaṇa vasena āti aṭṭhasu diṭṭhiṭṭhānesu khandhe sandhāya āha
translated: The meaning is: having brought to the head, to the culmination. “By way of object” : referring to the aggregates in the eight grounds for views.

original: Pavattanavasenāti avijjāphassasaññāvitakkāyonisomanasikāre. Āsevanavasenāti pāpamittaparatoghose.
analyzed: pavattana vasena ati avijjā phassa saññā vitakka yoni so manasikāre āsevana vasena ati pāpa mitta paratoghose
translated: By way of repetition: bad friends and hearing wrong teachings.

original: Yadipi sarūpatthavasena vevacanaṃ, saṅketatthavasena pana evaṃ vattabboti dassetuṃ
analyzed: yadi api sarūpa attha vasena vevacanam saṅketa attha vasena pana evam vattabbaḥ iti dassetuṃ
translated: Although the synonyms are given by way of their individual meanings, in order to show that they can also be given by way of their conventional meanings,

original: “evaṃvidhaparalokā”ti vuttaṃ. Yena kenaci hi visesaneneva vevacanaṃ sātthakaṃ siyā.
analyzed: evaṃvidha para lokā iti vuttam yena kenacid hi visesanena iva vevacanam sātthakam siyā
translated: “such a next world” is said. For a synonym can have a meaning in any way.

original: Paraloko ca kammavasena abhimukho sampareti gacchati pavattati etthāti abhisamparāyoti
analyzed: para loko ca kamma vasena abhimukho sampareti gacchati pavattati ettha ati abhisamparāyo ti
translated: And the next world is called “abhisamparāyika” because it comes face to face with one, goes to, occurs to one, by way of kamma.

original: vuccati. “Iti kho ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni anupubbena aggāya parentī”tiādīsu viya
analyzed: vuccati iti kho ānanda kusalāni sīlāni anupubbena aggāya parenti itiādīsu viya
translated: “Thus, Ānanda, wholesome habits lead gradually to the highest” .

original: hi curādigaṇavasena para-saddaṃ gatiyamicchanti saddavidū, ayamettha aṭṭhakathāto aparo nayo.
analyzed: hi curādi gaṇa vasena para saddam gatiyam icchanti sadda vidū ayam ettha aṭṭhakathātaḥ aparaḥ nayo
translated: Here, the grammarians desire the word “para” to be a destination in the sense of a group such as “curu” . This is another method here, apart from the commentary.

original: Evaṃgatikāti evaṃgamanā evaṃniṭṭhā, evamanuyuñjanena bhijjananassanapariyosānāti
analyzed: evaṃgatikā ati evaṃgamanā evaṃniṭṭhā evam anuyuñjanena bhijjana nassana pariyosānā ti
translated: “Such a destination”: such a going, such a destiny. The meaning is: by such a pursuit, it ends in breaking up and destruction.

original: attho. Gati-saddo cettha “yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavantī”tiādīsu
analyzed: atthaḥ gati saddo ca ittha yehi samannāgatassa mahā purisassa dvā iva gatiyaḥ bhavanti itiādīsu
translated: For the word “gati” is used in such passages as “For one who possesses these two things, there are two destinations” .

original: viya niṭṭhānattho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ime diṭṭhisaṅkhātā diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃ paramatthato
analyzed: viya niṭṭhāna attho idam vuttam hoti ime diṭṭhi saṅkhātāḥ diṭṭhi ṭhānāḥ evam paramatthato
translated: and the meaning of “end” is “termination.” What is meant is this. These standpoints of view called “views” are thus in the ultimate sense🔽grasped by being misapprehended as a self and as an eternal state that do not exist, and

original: asantaṃ attānaṃ, sassatabhāvañca tasmiṃ ajjhāropetvā gahitā, parāmaṭṭhā ca samānā🔽bālalapanāyeva hutvā yāva paṇḍitā na samanuyuñjanti, tāva gacchanti, pātubhavanti
analyzed: asantam attānam sassata bhāvañca tasmin ajjhāropetvā gahitā parāmaṭṭhā ca samānā  bāla lapanāya iva hutvā yāva paṇḍitāḥ na samanuyuñjanti tāva gacchanti pātubhavanti
translated: they are clung to as a result.🔽They go on being current and manifest as long as fools do not examine them.

original: ca, paṇḍitehi samanuyuñjiyamānā pana anavaṭṭhitavatthukā avimaddakkhamā sūriyuggamane🔽ussāvabindū viya, khajjopanakā viya ca bhijjanti, vinassanti cāti.
analyzed: ca paṇḍitehi samanuyuñjiyamānā pana anavaṭṭhita vatthukā a vimadda kkhamā sūri yuj gamane  ussāva bindū viya khajja upanakā viya ca bhijjanti vinassanti ca ati
translated: But when they are examined by the wise, they break up and vanish like a dewdrop touched by the sun’s rays or like salt thrown on a wet cow-pat.

original: Tatthāyaṃ anuyuñjane saṅkhepakathā – yadi hi parehi kappito attā loko vā sassato🔽siyā, tassa nibbikāratāya purimarūpāvijahanato kassaci visesādhānassa kātumasakkuṇeyyatāya
analyzed: tattha ayam anuyuñjane saṅkhepa kathā yadi hi parehi kappitaḥ attā lokaḥ vā sassataḥ  siyā tassa nibbikāra tāya purima rūpa a vijahanataḥ kassaci visesa ādhānassa kātum asakkuṇeyya tāya
translated: Here is a brief explanation of the examination: if the self or the world were eternal,🔽then, because of being unalterable, and because of not abandoning its former mode, it would be impossible to accomplish any distinction in it,

original: ahitato nivattanatthaṃ, hite ca paṭipajjanatthaṃ upadeso eva sassatavādino nippayojano
analyzed: ahitataḥ nivattana attham hite ca paṭipajjana attham upadesaḥ eva sassata vādinaḥ nippayojanaḥ
translated: and then it would be pointless for the eternalist to advise anyone to avoid what is unprofitable and to undertake what is profitable.

original: siyā, kathaṃ vā tena so upadeso pavattīyati vikārābhāvato. Evañca sati parikappitassa
analyzed: siyā katham vā tena saḥ upadeso pavattīyati vikāra abhāvataḥ evam ca sati parikappitassa
translated: Or how does that instruction proceed by him, since there is no change? And if that is so,🔽

original: attano ajaṭākāsassa viya dānādikiriyā, hiṃsādikiriyā ca na sambhavati, tathā sukhassa,
analyzed: attanaḥ ajaṭā kāsassa viya dāna ādi kiriyā hiṃsā ādi kiriyā ca na sambhavati tathā sukhassa
translated: Or how can that teaching be applied to him, since he is without change? And if that is so, then it is impossible for him to perform such actions as giving, etc., or such actions as killing, etc., just as it is impossible for his own unbraided hair.

original: dukkhassa ca anubhavananibandho eva sassatavādino na yujjati kammabaddhābhāvato.🔽Jātiādīnañca asambhavato vimokkho na bhaveyya, atha pana dhammamattaṃ tassa uppajjati
analyzed: dukkhassa ca anubhavana nibandhaḥ eva sassata vādinaḥ na yujjati kamma baddha abhāvato  jāti ādīnam ca asambhavataḥ vimokkhaḥ na bhaveyya atha pana dhamma mattam tassa uppajjati
translated: And it is not proper for the eternalist to be bound to the experiencing of pleasure and pain, because he is not bound by kamma.

original: ceva vinassati ca, yassa vasenāyaṃ kiriyādivohāroti vadeyya, evampi purimarūpāvijahanena
analyzed: ca iva vinassati ca yassa vasena ayam kiriyādivohāro ti vadeyya evam pi purima rūpa avijahanena
translated: And because birth, etc., are impossible for him, there would be no liberation. But if he says that it is only a state of his that arises and dissolves away, and that it is because of that that the terms “action,” etc., are used in regard to him,

original: avaṭṭhitassa attano dhammamattanti na sakkā sambhāvetuṃ, te vā panassa dhammā avatthābhūtā,🔽tasmā tassa uppannā aññe vā siyuṃ anaññe vā, yadi aññe, na tāhi avatthāhi tassa uppannāhipi
analyzed: avaṭṭhitassa attanaḥ dhammam attanti na sakkā sambhāvetum te vā panassa dhammā avatthā bhūtā  tasmā tassa uppannāḥ aññe vā siyuṃ anaññe vā yadi aññe na tāhi avatthāhi tassa uppannāhi pi
translated: then, since he does not abandon his previous form, it cannot be maintained that it is only a state of his self that arises and dissolves away. Or else, those states of his are not a basis for him.

original: koci viseso atthi, yāhi karoti paṭisaṃvedeti cavati uppajjati cāti icchitaṃ, evañca
analyzed: koci visesaḥ atthi yāhi karoti paṭisaṃvedeti cavati uppajjati ca ati icchitam evam ca
translated: Therefore, whether they are the same as or different from those that arose earlier, if they are different, there is no difference between those that arose earlier and those that are different, by means of which it is maintained that he acts, experiences, dies, and is reborn. And if they are the same,🔽then it is not proper to say that they arise and dissolve away.

original: dhammakappanāpi niratthakā siyā, tasmā tadavattho eva yathāvuttadoso, athānaññe,🔽uppādavināsavantīhi avatthāhi anaññassa attano tāsaṃ viya uppādavināsasabbhāvato
analyzed: dhamma kappanā api niratthakā siyā tasmā tad avatthaḥ eva yathā vutta dosaḥ atha anaññe  uppāda vināsavantīhi avatthāhi anaññassa attanaḥ tāsam viya uppāda vināsa sabbhāvato
translated: And the ascription of the state of being to the dhammas would be pointless. So the same fault stated in the way just shown would apply to the meaning of the state of being.🔽And how could there be any opportunity for the state of being to be permanent, since it is not different from the dhammas that arise and vanish, and it has the same nature of arising and vanishing as they have, like their arising and vanishing?

original: kuto bhaveyya niccatāvakāso, tāsampi vā attano viya niccatāpavatti, tasmā bandhavimokkhānaṃ
analyzed: kutas bhaveyya nicca tā avakāso tāsam pi vā attanaḥ viya nicca tā apavatti tasmā bandha vimokkhānam
translated: Or how could the state of being occur permanently, like the dhammas themselves? So the occurrence of bondage and deliverance is impossible.

original: asambhavo evāti na yujjatiyeva sassatavādo, na cettha koci vādī dhammānaṃ sassatabhāve🔽parisuddaṃ yuttiṃ vattuṃ samattho bhaveyya, yuttirahitañca vacanaṃ na paṇḍitānaṃ
analyzed: asambhavaḥ evā ati na sassata vādaḥ na ca ittha koci vādī dhammānam sassata bhāve  parisuddham yuttim vattum samatthaḥ bhaveyya yutti rahitam ca vacanam na paṇḍitānam
translated: Therefore the doctrine of eternalism is not tenable. And here no one is able to state a sound reason for the eternality of dhammas.🔽And a statement without a reason does not satisfy the minds of the wise.

original: cittaṃ ārādheti, tenāvocumha “yāva paṇḍitā na samanuyuñjanti, tāva gacchanti, pātubhavanti cā”ti.
analyzed: cittam ārādha iti tena avocumha yāva paṇḍitāḥ na samanuyuñjanti tāva gacchanti pātubhavanti ca ati
translated: That is why we said that they go on being believed as long as the wise do not examine them and they are not exposed.

original: Sakāraṇaṃ sagatikanti ettha saha-saddo vijjamānattho “salomako sapakkhako”tiādīsu
analyzed: sa kāraṇam sa gatikam ti ettha saha saddaḥ vijjamāna atthaḥ salomakaḥ sapakkhakaḥ ti ādīsu

analyzed: diṭṭhi gatassa samuccinita ttā tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti iti iminā ca kāraṇa gatīnam eva  pajānana bhāvena vutta ttā idam vuttam hoti tayidam bhikkhave kāraṇavantam gativantam
translated: Because the view-attitudes have been included in the reason-and-destination-ideas, and because the words “and the Tathagata understands” show that the Tathagata’s understanding is only of the reason-and-destination-ideas. analyzed: evaṃvidham ti sīlam ca iti ādinā evaṃvutta ppakāram pajānantaḥ api iti ettha pi saddena
translated: The meaning of the words “and the Tathagata understands” is commented on in the way beginning “From that

original: api-saddena vā “tañcā”ti vutta ca-saddassa sambhāvanatthabhāvaṃ dasseti, tena tato🔽diṭṭigatato uttaritaraṃ sārabhūtaṃ sīlādiguṇavisesampi tathāgato nābhinivisati, ko
analyzed: api saddena vā tat ca ati ca saddassa sambhāvanattha bhāvam dasseti tena tatas  diṭṭi gatataḥ uttaritaram sāra bhūtam sīla ādi guṇa visesam pi tathāgataḥ na abhinivisati ko
translated: Or else, by the word “api” he shows the sense of “ca” in “tañca” as being that of “sambhāvanā” . Thus,

original: pana vādo vaṭṭāmiseti sambhāveti. “Aha”nti diṭṭimānavasena parāmasanākāradassanaṃ.
analyzed: pana vādaḥ sambhāveti ahanti diṭṭi māna vasena parāmasana ākāra dassanam
translated: the Tathāgata does not adhere to the special qualities of virtue, etc., which are more excellent than the view-attitudes, how much less to the “filth of the round” . He “sambhāveti” . The word “ahaṃ” shows the mode of perception by way of the conceit of “I” and “mine” .

original: Pajānāmīti ettha iti-saddena pakāratthena, nidassanatthena vā. “Mama”nti taṇhāvasena
analyzed: pajānāmi iti ettha iti saddena pakāra atthena nidassana tthena vā mamanti taṇhā vasena
translated: “Pajānāmi” . Here, by the word “iti” in the sense of “pakāra” or in the sense of “nidassanā” , he shows the mode of perception by way of craving for “mama” .

original: parāmasanākāraṃ dasseti. Taṇhādiṭṭhimānaparāmāsavasenāti taṇhādiṭṭhimānasaṅkhātaparāmāsavasena.
analyzed: parāmasana ākāram dasseti taṇhā diṭṭhi māna parāmāsa vasena ati taṇhā diṭṭhi māna saṅkhāta parāmāsa vasena
translated: “Taṇhādiṭṭhimānasaṅkhātaparāmāsavasenā” means by way of the taints of perception called craving, conceit, and views.

original: Dhammasabhāvamatikkamitvā “ahaṃ mama”nti parato abhūtato āmasanaṃ parāmāso, taṇhādayo
analyzed: dhamma sabhāvam atikkamitvā aham paratas a bhūtatas āmasanam parāmāsaḥ taṇhā ādayo
translated: The “parāmāso” is the grasping of what is not as “I” and “mine” after transcending the real nature of dhammas. Craving, etc., are

original: eva. Na hi taṃ atthi, yaṃ khandhesu “aha”nti vā “mama”nti vā gahetabbaṃ siyā, aparāmasato
analyzed: eva na hi tam atthi yam khandhesu ahanti vā mamanti vā gahetabbam siyā a parāmasataḥ
translated: indeed the “parāmāso” . For there is nothing that can be grasped as “I” or “mine” in the aggregates.🔽The connection is this: “If he were to grasp, if he were to perceive, then his nibbāna would be known to the Tathāgata.”

original: aparāmasantassa assa tathāgatassa nibbuti viditāti sambandho. “Aparāmasato”ti cedaṃ
analyzed: a parāmasantassa assa tathāgatassa nibbuti viditā ati sambandhaḥ a parāmasato ti ca idam
translated: “Aparāmasato” means “if he were not to grasp.”

original: nibbutipavedanāya (nibbutivedanassa dī. ni. ṭī. 1.36) hetugabbhavisesanaṃ. “Viditā”ti
analyzed: nibbuti pa vedanāya nibbuti vedanassa hetu gabbha visesanam viditā ati
translated: and the Blessed One’s knowledge of the extinction element as the cause of the kind of conduct that is without clinging is the distinguishing of the cause of the feeling of extinction.

original: padamapekkhitvā kattari sāmivacanaṃ. Aparāmasato parāmāsarahitapaṭipattihetu assa
analyzed: padam apekkhitvā kattari sāmi vacanam a parāmasato parāmāsa rahita paṭipatti hetu assa
translated: The word “known” is the genitive in the sense of the possessor, taking the word “his” ;

original: tathāgatassa kattubhūtassa nibbuti asaṅkhatadhātu viditā, adhigatāti vā attho. “Aparāmasato”ti
analyzed: tathāgatassa kattu bhūtassa nibbuti asaṅkhata dhātu viditā adhigatā ati vā attho a parāmasato ti
translated: for the Blessed One, who is the possessor of the kind of conduct that is without clinging, the cause of which is the extinction element that is without clinging, has known, has realized, the extinction element that is the unformed .

original: hedaṃ hetumhi nissakkavacanaṃ.🔽“Aparāmāsapaccayā”ti paccattaññeva pavedanāya kāraṇadassanaṃ. Assāti kattāraṃ vatvāpi
analyzed: ha idam hetumhi nissakka vacanam  aparāmāsa paccayā ti paccattaññā iva pavedanāya kāraṇa dassanam assa ati kattāram vatvā api
translated: The word “without” is the locative in the sense of cause.🔽“With the non-clinging condition” is the showing of the reason for the feeling of extinction by himself.🔽Although the word “his” refers to the possessor,🔽the word “himself” is repeated in order to show the distinction of the possessor.

original: paccattaññevāti visesadassanatthaṃ puna kattuvacananti āha “sayameva attanāyevā”ti.🔽Sayaṃ, attanāti vā bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ. Nipātapadañhetaṃ. “Aparāmasato”ti vacanato parāmāsānameva
analyzed: paccattaññā eva āti visesa dassana attham puna kattu vacanan ti āha sayam eva attanāya iva ati  vā bhāva napuṃsakam vacanataḥ parāmāsānam eva
translated: “Himself” and “by himself” are neuter substantives.🔽The word “without” is a locative particle.

original: nibbuti idha desitā, taṃdesanāya eva tadaññesampi nibbutiyā sijjhanatoti dasseti
analyzed: nibbuti idha desitā tad desanāya eva tad aññesam pi nibbutiyā sijjhanato ti dasseti
translated: Since the word “without” is used, it is extinction that is taught here, and it is shown that the extinction of others is established by the teaching of that extinction.

original: “tesaṃ parāmāsakilesāna”nti iminā, parāmāsasaṅkhātānaṃ kilesānanti attho. Apica kāmaṃ
analyzed: tesam parāmāsa kilesānam ti iminā parāmāsa saṅkhātānam kilesānam ti atthaḥ api ca kāmam
translated: “Of those defilements called clinging”: the meaning is: of the defilements called clinging. Moreover,

original: “aparāmasato”ti vacanato parāmāsānameva nibbuti idha desitāti viññāyati, taṃdesanāya
analyzed: aparāmasato ti vacanato parāmāsānam eva nibbuti idha desitā ati viññāyati tad desanāya
translated: it is known that the quenching of the defilements called clinging is taught here because of the words “without clinging” . But

original: pana tadavasesānampi kilesānaṃ nibbuti desitā nāma bhavati pahānekaṭṭhatādibhāvato,
analyzed: pana tad avasesānam pi kilesānam nibbuti desitā nāma bhavati pahā aneka ṭṭha tā ādi bhāvato
translated: the teaching of the quenching of those other defilements is also a teaching of the quenching of those because of the identity of their abandonment, etc.,

original: tasmā tesampi nibbuti niddhāretvā dassetabbāti vuttaṃ “tesaṃ parāmāsakilesāna”nti,
analyzed: tasmā tesam pi nibbuti niddhāretvā dassetabbā ati vuttam tesam parāmāsa kilesānam ti
translated: therefore it is said “of those defilements called clinging” in order to show that their quenching should be inferred.

original: taṇhādiṭṭhimānasaṅkhātānaṃ parāmāsānaṃ, tadaññesañca kilesānanti attho. Gobalībaddanayo
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi māna saṅkhātānam parāmāsānam tad aññesam ca kilesānam ti atthaḥ gobalībaddanayo
translated: The meaning is: of the defilements called clinging, which are craving, views, and conceit, and of the other defilements. This is the method of interpretation.

original: hesa. Nibbutīti ca nibbāyanabhūtā asaṅkhatadhātu, tañca bhagavā bodhimūleyeva patto,
analyzed: ha isa nibbutī iti ca nibbāyana bhūtā asaṅkhata dhātu tat ca bhagavā bodhi mūleya iva patto
translated: “Quenching” is the unformed element, which is the state of being quenched. The Blessed One reached that at the root of the Bodhi tree,

original: tasmā sā paccattaññeva viditāti.
analyzed: tasmā sā paccattaññā iva viditā ati
translated: therefore it is “known to himself alone.”

original: Yathāpaṭipannenāti yena paṭipannena. Tappaṭipattiṃ dassetuṃ “tāsaṃyeva…pe… ādimāhā”ti
analyzed: yathā paṭipannena āti yena paṭipannena tad paṭipattim dassetum ādim āha ati
translated: “By the practice”: by the practice of the way. In order to show that practice of the way, he said “the beginning of which” , etc.

original: anusandhidassanaṃ. Kasmā pana vedanānaññeva kammaṭṭhānamācikkhatīti āha “yāsū”tiādi,
analyzed: anusandhi dassanam kasmā pana vedanā naññā iva kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhati iti āha yāsu itiādi
translated: But why does he teach only the meditation subject of feelings? He is asked this and so he says “In the case of which” ,

original: iminā desanāvilāsaṃ dasseti. Desanāvilāsappatto hi bhagavā desanākusalo khandhāyatanādivasena🔽anekavidhāsu catusaccadesanāsu sambhavantīsupi diṭṭhigatikā vedanāsu micchāpaṭipattiyā
analyzed: iminā desanā vilāsam dasseti desanā vilāsa ppattaḥ hi bhagavā desanā kusalaḥ khandha āyatana ādi vasena  anekavidhāsu catu sacca desanāsu sambhavantīsu pi diṭṭhi gatikāḥ vedanāsu micchā paṭipattiyā
translated: and so on. He shows the versatility of his teaching here. For the Blessed One is skilled in teaching, and he is versatile in teaching,🔽and he knows the many kinds of teaching that are possible in the four noble truths by means of the aggregates, bases, and elements, etc.,

original: diṭṭhigahanaṃ pakkhandāti dassanatthaṃ tathāpakkhandanamūlabhūtā vedanāyeva pariññābhūmibhāvena
analyzed: diṭṭhi gahanam pakkhandāti dassana attham tathā pakkhandana mūla bhūtā vedanāya iva pariññā bhūmi bhāvena
translated: and he extracts only feelings as the plane of full-understanding, making them the starting point for the penetration of the four noble truths, in order to show that those who have gone into the thicket of views by a wrong course of practice in regard to feelings, which are the root of the penetration,

original: uddharatīti. Idhāti imasmiṃ vāde. Evaṃ etthātipi. Kammaṭṭhānanti catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Ettha hi vedanāgahaṇena gahitā pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhasaccaṃ. Vedanānaṃ samudayaggahaṇena
analyzed: uddharati iti idha ati imasmin vāde evam ettha ati pi kammaṭṭhānam ti catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam  ettha hi vedanā gahaṇena gahitā pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkha saccam vedanānam samudaya ggahaṇena
translated: have gone into the thicket of views in this way. Here means in this argument. Or it is a demonstrative introducing what follows. Meditation subject : the four noble truth meditation subject.🔽For the five aggregates as objects of clinging are the truth of suffering when they are included by the inclusion of feelings.🔽The origin of ignorance, etc., is the truth of origin when it is included by the inclusion of the origin of feelings.

original: gahito avijjāsamudayo samudayasaccaṃ, atthaṅgamanissaraṇapariyāyehi nirodhasaccaṃ,
analyzed: gahitaḥ avijjā samudayaḥ samudaya saccam atthaṅgama nissaraṇa pariyāyehi nirodha saccam
translated: The cessation of ignorance, etc., is the truth of cessation when it is included by the inclusion of the cessation of feelings.

original: “yathābhūtaṃ viditvā”ti etena maggasaccanti evaṃ cattāri saccāni veditabbāni. “Yathābhūtaṃ🔽viditvā”ti idaṃ vibhajjabyākaraṇatthapadanti tadatthaṃ vibhajja dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Visesato hi “avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayo”tiādilakkhaṇānaṃ vasena samudayādīsu
analyzed: yathābhūtam viditvā iti etena magga saccanti evam cattāri saccāni veditabbāni yathābhūtam  viditvā iti idam vibhajja byākaraṇa attha padam ti tad attham vibhajja dassetum tattha atiādi  vuttam visesataḥ hi avijjā samudayā vedanā samudayaḥ ti ādi lakkhaṇānam vasena samudaya ādīsu
translated: “Having understood as they really are” : in this way the four Truths should be understood as the Path, etc.🔽“Having understood as they really are” : this is a term for an analytical answer. In order to show its meaning by analysis, “Herein” , etc., is said.🔽For it is in particular by way of the characteristics beginning with “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of feeling” that the arising, etc., of feeling should be understood.🔽

original: attho yathārahaṃ vibhajja dassetabbo. Avisesato pana vedanāya samudayādīni vipassanāpaññāya🔽ārammaṇapaṭivedhavasena, maggapaññāya asammohapaṭivedhavasena jānitvā paṭivijjhitvāti🔽attho. Paccayasamudayaṭṭhenāti “imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjatī”ti
analyzed: atthaḥ yathāraham vibhajja dassetabbo avisesato pana vedanāya samudaya ādīni vipassanā paññāya  ārammaṇa paṭivedha vasena magga paññāya asammoha paṭivedha vasena jānitvā paṭivijjhitvā ati  attho paccaya samudaya ṭṭhena ati imasmin sati idam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati iti
translated: “Having understood as they really are”: by this he shows that the four noble truths should be understood. “Having understood as they really are”: this is a term for an analytical answer. In order to show its meaning analytically, he said, “Herein,” etc. For the meaning of origination, etc., should be shown analytically according to the characteristics stated thus: “With the arising of ignorance, there is the arising of volitional formations” , etc. But in general the meaning should be understood thus: “Having known, having penetrated, the origination, etc., of feeling by means of insight knowledge and path knowledge respectively.”

original: vuttalakkhaṇena avijjādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ uppādena ceva maggena asamugghāṭena ca. Yāva
analyzed: vutta lakkhaṇena avijjā ādīnam paccayānam uppādena ca iva maggena asamugghāṭena ca yāva
translated: By the “arising of conditions”: by the arising of the conditions, ignorance, etc., and by their non-eradication by the path. “As long as” means “as far as.” “As far as the arising of conditions” means “as far as the arising of ignorance, etc.” “As far as the non-eradication of ignorance, etc., by the path” means “as far as the non-eradication of ignorance, etc., by the path.”

original: hi maggena na samugghāṭīyati, tāva paccayoti vuccati. Nibbattilakkhaṇanti uppādalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: hi maggena na samugghāṭīyati tāva paccayaḥ ti vuccati nibbatti lakkhaṇam ti uppāda lakkhaṇam
translated: for it is not yet eradicated by the path, it is still called a condition. As the characteristic of arising: as the characteristic of generation;

original: jātinti attho. Pañcannaṃ lakkhaṇānanti ettha ca catunnampi paccayānaṃ uppādalakkhaṇameva
analyzed: jātim ti attho pañcannam lakkhaṇānam ti ettha ca catunnam pi paccayānam uppāda lakkhaṇam eva
translated: the meaning is, as birth. As the characteristics of the five aggregates: here, without taking the characteristic of generation of the four conditions,

original: aggahetvā paccayalakkhaṇampi gahetabbaṃ samudayaṃ paṭicca tesaṃ yathārahaṃ upakārakattā.🔽Tathā ceva saṃvaṇṇitaṃ “maggena asamugghāṭena cā”ti. Paccayanirodhaṭṭhenāti “imasmiṃ🔽niruddhe idaṃ niruddhaṃ hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatī”ti vuttalakkhaṇena avijjādīnaṃ
analyzed: aggahetvā paccaya lakkhaṇam pi gahetabbam samudayam paṭicca tesam yathāraham upakāraka ttā  tathā ca iva saṃvaṇṇitam maggena a samugghāṭena ca ati paccaya nirodha ṭṭhena ati imasmin  niruddhe idam niruddham hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti vutta lakkhaṇena avijjā ādīnam
translated: the characteristic of condition should be taken too, since they are helpful to the aggregates in the appropriate way in dependence on their origination.🔽And that is commended thus: “Not eradicated by the path” . As the cessation of conditions: as the cessation of the conditions ignorance, etc.,🔽by the cessation of conditions and by their eradication by the path, according to the characteristic stated thus: “When this is absent, that is absent; from the cessation of this, that ceases” .

original: paccayānaṃ nirodhena ceva maggena samugghāṭena ca. Vipariṇāmalakkhaṇanti nirodhalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: paccayānam nirodhena ca iva maggena samugghāṭena ca vipariṇāma lakkhaṇan ti nirodha lakkhaṇam
translated: As the characteristic of change: as the characteristic of cessation;

original: bhaṅganti attho. Vayanti nirodhaṃ. Yanti yasmā paccayabhāvasaṅkhātahetuto. Vedanaṃ
analyzed: attho vayanti nirodham yanti yasmā paccaya bhāva saṅkhāta hetutaḥ vedanam
translated: the meaning is, as dissolution. As passing away: as cessation. As going: because of the cause called the state of condition. As feeling:

original: paṭiccāti purimuppannaṃ ārammaṇādipaccayabhūtaṃ vedanaṃ labhitvā. Sukhaṃ somanassanti
analyzed: paṭicca ati purima uppannam ārammaṇa ādi paccaya bhūtam vedanam labhitvā sukham somanassanti
translated: “With that as condition”: having obtained the feeling that has arisen earlier as a condition in the form of object-condition, etc. “Pleasure and joy”:

original: sukhañceva somanassañca. Ayanti purimavedanāya yathārahaṃ pacchimuppannānaṃ sukhasomanassānaṃ
analyzed: sukham ca iva somanassam ca ayanti purima vedanāya yathāraham pacchima uppannānam sukha somanassānam
translated: both pleasure and joy. “With that”: the pleasure and joy arisen later,

original: paccayabhāvo. Assādo nāma assāditabboti katvā.
analyzed: paccaya bhāvaḥ assādaḥ nāma assāditabbaḥ ti katvā
translated: according to the circumstances, have the condition of the earlier feeling. “Delight” is so called because it is to be delighted in.

original: Aparo nayo – yanti sukhaṃ, somanassañca. Ayanti ca napuṃsakaliṅgena niddiṭṭhaṃ sukhasomanassameva
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ yanti sukham somanassam ca ayanti ca napuṃsaka liṅgena niddiṭṭham sukha somanassam eva
translated: Another method: “With that” refers to pleasure and joy. “With that” is the neuter form of the same pleasure and joy that is referred to in the feminine form.

original: assādapadamapekkhitvā pulliṅgena niddisīyati, imasmiṃ pana vikappe sukhasomanassānaṃ🔽uppādoyeva tehi uppādavantehi niddiṭṭho, sattiyā, sattimato ca abhinnattā. Na hi
analyzed: assāda padam apekkhitvā pulliṅgena niddisīyati imasmin pana vikappe sukha somanassānam  uppādaḥ yā iva tehi uppādavantehi niddiṭṭhaḥ sattiyā sattimataḥ ca abhinnattā na hi
translated: The neuter form is used in consideration of the word “delight,” but in this method the arising of pleasure and joy is shown by those that arise with them,

original: sukhasomanassamantarena tesaṃ uppādo labbhati. Iti purimavedanaṃ paṭicca sukhasomanassuppādopi
analyzed: sukha somanassam antarena tesam uppādaḥ labbhati iti purima vedanam paṭicca sukha somanassa uppādaḥ api
translated: because the sword and the one who wields the sword are not different. For it is not possible to find the arising of pleasure and joy without them. Thus the arising of pleasure and joy with the earlier feeling as condition

original: purimavedanāya assādo nāma assādīyateti katvā. Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho – purimamuppannaṃ
analyzed: purima vedanāya assādaḥ nāma assādīyata iti katvā ayam ha ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ purimam uppannam
translated: is also called “delight” because it is delighted in by them. This is the condensed meaning here: The earlier feeling

original: vedanaṃ ārabbha somanassuppattiyaṃ yo purimavedanāya paccayabhāvasaṅkhāto assādetabbākāro,🔽somanassassa vā uppādasaṅkhāto tadassādanākāro, ayaṃ purimavedanāya assādoti. Kathaṃ
analyzed: vedanam ārabbha somanassa uppattiyam yaḥ purima vedanāya paccaya bhāva saṅkhāto assādetabba ākāro  somanassassa vā uppāda saṅkhāto tad assādana ākāraḥ ayam purima vedanāya assādaḥ ti katham
translated: The aspect of being able to be relished, called “conditionality,” in the arising of joy based on feeling,🔽and the aspect of relishing, called “arising of joy,” in the arising of joy based on feeling, is the gratification in the former feeling.

original: pana vedanaṃ ārabbha sukhaṃ uppajjati, nanu phoṭṭhabbārammaṇanti? Cetasikasukhasseva🔽ārabbha pavattiyamadhippetattā nāyaṃ doso. Ārabbha pavattiyañhi visesanameva somanassaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: pana vedanam ārabbha sukham uppajjati nanu phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇa nti cetasika sukhassa iva  ārabbha pavattiyam adhippeta ttā na ayam dosaḥ ārabbha pavattiyam hi visesanam eva somanassa ggahaṇam
translated: But how does pleasure arise based on feeling? Is it not based on the object of tactile consciousness? There is no fault in this, because it is said that it occurs based on mental pleasure.🔽For the mention of joy is only a distinction in the occurrence based on that.

original: somanassaṃ sukhanti yathā “rukkho sīsapā”ti aññapaccayavasena uppattiyaṃ pana kāyikasukhampi
analyzed: somanassam sukhanti yathā rukkho sīsapāti añña paccaya vasena uppattiyam pana kāyika sukham pi
translated: Joy is pleasure. Just as a tree is a sissara tree. But in the arising by way of other conditions, bodily pleasure is also gratification,

original: assādoyeva, yathālābhakathā vā esāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: assā doyā iva yathā lābha kathā vā esā ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: or this should be regarded as a statement of what is obtained.

original: “Yā vedanā aniccā”tiādinā sattimatā satti nidassitā. Tatrāyamattho – yā vedanā hutvā
analyzed: yā vedanā anicca ati ādinā sattimatā nidassitā tatra ayam atthaḥ yā vedanā hutvā
translated: The stableness of the stably perceiving one is shown by the words “Any feeling that is impermanent” and so forth. Herein, the meaning is this: Any feeling that is impermanent in the sense of non-existence,

original: abhāvaṭṭhena aniccā, udayabbayapaṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhā, jarāya, maraṇena cāti dvidhā
analyzed: abhāva ṭṭhena aniccāḥ udaya bbaya paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkhāḥ jarāya maraṇena ca ati dvidhā
translated: that is suffering in the sense of affliction by rise and fall, and that is void in the sense of non-existence of self by way of the two, aging and death,

original: vipariṇāmetabbaṭṭhena vipariṇāmadhammā. Tassā evaṃbhūtāya ayaṃ aniccadukkhavipariṇāmabhāvo
analyzed: vipariṇāmetabba ṭṭhena vipariṇāma dhammā tassai evaṃbhūtāya ayaṃ anicca dukkha vipariṇāma bhāvo
translated: and in the sense of being subject to change, they are subject to change.🔽This is the state of being impermanent, painful, and subject to change in feeling, which is of all kinds.🔽The state of being a danger is what is meant by danger.

original: vedanāya sabbāyapiādīnavoti. Ādīnaṃ paramakāruññaṃ vāti pavattati etasmāti hi ādīnavo.
analyzed: vedanāya sabbāya api ādīnavaḥ ti ādīnam parama kāruññam vāti pavattati etasmā ati hi ādīnavaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the state of being a very great misery is what is called danger, as a man of low birth is called a misery.🔽This is of that kind,

original: Apicaādīnaṃ ativiya kapaṇaṃ pavattanaṭṭhena kapaṇamanusso ādīnavo, ayampi evaṃsabhāvoti🔽tathā vuccati. Sattimatā hi satti abhinnā tadavinābhāvato.
analyzed: apica ādīnam ativiya kapaṇam pavattana ṭṭhena kapaṇa manussaḥ ādīnavaḥ ayam pi evaṃsabhāvaḥ ti  tathā vuccati sattimatā hi satti abhinnā tad avinābhāvataḥ
translated: and so it is said to be a danger. For a spear is not different from the spear-wound, since it is inseparable from it.

original: Ettha ca “aniccā”ti iminā saṅkhāradukkhatāvasena upekkhāvedanāya, sabbāsu vā vedanāsuādīnavamāha,
analyzed: ettha ca aniccā iti iminā saṅkhāra dukkha tā vasena upekkhā vedanāya sabbāsu vā vedanāsu ādīnavam āha
translated: And here, by the words “impermanent,” he stated the danger in feeling as the suffering due to formations, or the danger in all feelings,

original: “dukkhā”ti iminā dukkhadukkhatāvasenadukkhavedanāya, “vipariṇāmadhammā”ti iminā vipariṇāmadukkhatāvasena
analyzed: dukkhā ati iminā dukkha dukkha tā vasena dukkha vedanāya vipariṇāma dhammā ati iminā vipariṇāma dukkha tā vasena
translated: by the words “painful” he stated the danger in painful feeling as the suffering due to pain,

original: sukhavedanāya. Avisesena vā tīṇipi padāni tissannampi vedanānaṃ vasena yojetabbāni.
analyzed: sukha vedanāya avisesena vā tīṇi pi padāni tissannam pi vedanānam vasena yojetabbāni
translated: and by the words “subject to change” he stated the danger in pleasant feeling as the suffering due to change. Or all three terms can be taken as applicable without distinction to all three kinds of feeling.

original: Chandarāgavinayoti chandasaṅkhātarāgavinayanaṃ vināso. “Atthavasā liṅgavibhattivipariṇāmo”ti
analyzed: chanda rāga vinayo ti chanda saṅkhāta rāga vinayanam vināsaḥ attha vasā liṅga vibhatti vipariṇāmo ti
translated: “Destruction of will and lust” is the destruction of will and lust called “desire” .🔽“The change of the case endings and the change of the meaning” is said.🔽Therefore it should be construed as “the abandoning of will and lust” .

original: vacanato yaṃ chandarāgappahānanti yojetabbaṃ. Pariyāyavacanamevidaṃ padadvayaṃ. Yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: vacanataḥ yam chanda rāga ppahānam ti yojetabbam pariyāya vacanam eva idam pada dvayam yathābhūtam
translated: This is a mere synonym for the two terms.

original: viditvāti maggassa vuttattā magganibbānavasena vā yathākkamaṃ yojanāpi vaṭṭati. Vedanāyāti
analyzed: viditvā ti maggassa vutta ttā magga nibbāna vasena vā yathākkamam yojanā api vaṭṭati vedanāya ati
translated: “Having understood as they really are” : since the path is referred to, the interpretation can also be made according to the path and Nibbāna.🔽“In feeling” : this is a term of exclusion.🔽“The escape” is renunciation.

original: nissakkavacanaṃ. Nissaraṇanti nekkhammaṃ. Yāva hi vedanāpaṭibaddhaṃ chandarāgaṃ nappajahati,
analyzed: nissakka vacanam nissaraṇam ti nekkhammam yāva hi vedanā paṭibaddham chanda rāgam na ppajahati
translated: For as long as one does not abandon the will and lust bound up with feeling,

original: tāvāyaṃ puriso vedanāya allīnoyeva hoti. Yadā pana taṃ chandarāgaṃ pajahati, tadāyaṃ
analyzed: tāva ayam purisaḥ vedanāya hoti yadā pana tam chanda rāgam pajahati tadā ayam
translated: for that long one is still attached to feeling. But when one abandons that will and lust,

original: puriso vedanāya nissaṭo visaṃyutto hoti, tasmā chandarāgappahānaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ
analyzed: purisaḥ vedanāya nissaṭaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ hoti tasmā chanda rāga ppahānam vedanāya nissaraṇam
translated: then one has escaped from feeling, is disjoined from it. Therefore the abandoning of will and lust is said to be the escape from feeling.

original: vuttaṃ. Tabbacanena pana vedanāsahajātanissayārammaṇabhūtā rūpārūpadhammā gahitā
analyzed: vuttam tad bacanena pana vedanā sahajāta nissaya ārammaṇa bhūtāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ gahitā
translated: But by the word “feeling” material and immaterial states associated with feeling, as well as those that are its support and object, are included.

original: eva hontītipi pañcahi upādānakkhandhehi nissaraṇavacanaṃ siddhameva. Vedanāsīsena
analyzed: eva honti pañcahi upādānakkhandhehi nissaraṇa vacanam siddham eva vedanā sīsena
translated: For the teaching has come down in terms of feeling.🔽The reason for that has already been given.

original: hi desanā āgatā, tattha pana kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Lakkhaṇahāravasenāpi ayamattho
analyzed: hi desanā āgatā tattha pana kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva lakkhaṇa hāra vasena api ayam attho
translated: This meaning should also be illustrated by the method of characteristic.

original: vibhāvetabbo. Vuttañhi āyasmatā mahākaccānattherena –
analyzed: vibhāvetabbaḥ vuttam hi āyasmatā mahākaccāna therena
translated: For this is said by the venerable elder Mahā-Kaccāna:

original: “Vuttamhi ekadhamme, ye dhammā ekalakkhaṇā keci;
analyzed: vuttamhi eka dhamme ye dhammā eka lakkhaṇā keci
translated: “When one thing is stated, whatever things have one characteristic,

original: Vuttā bhavanti sabbo, so hāro lakkhaṇo nāmā”ti. ;
analyzed: vuttāḥ bhavanti sabbo so hāro lakkhaṇaḥ nāma ati
translated: All those are stated; this mode is called ‘By Characteristic.’ ”

original: Kāmupādānamūlakattā sesupādānānaṃ pahīne ca kāmupādāne upādānasesābhāvato “vigatachandarāgatāya
analyzed: kāma upādāna mūlaka ttā pahīne ca kāma upādāne upādāna sesa abhāvataḥ vigata chanda rāga tāya
