translated: And because the other kinds of clinging have sensual desire for their root, and when sensual desire is abandoned there are no other kinds of clinging left, he said “without clinging, free from clinging,”

original: anupādāno”ti vuttaṃ, etena “anupādāvimutto”ti etassatthaṃ saṅkhepena dasseti. Idaṃ
analyzed: anupādāno ti vuttam etena anupādāvimutto ti etassa attham saṅkhepena dasseti idam
translated: showing in brief the meaning of “unbound by clinging.”

original: vuttaṃ hoti – vigatachandarāgatāya anupādāno, anupādānattā ca anupādāvimuttoti. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti vigata chanda rāga tāya anupādānaḥ anupādāna ttā ca an upādā vimuttaḥ ti tam attham
translated: This is what he means: “Without clinging, free from clinging, because of non-clinging.”🔽To elaborate and explain the meaning of that, he said “In what is clung to,” etc.

original: vitthāretuṃ, samatthetuṃ vā “yasmi”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yasmiṃ upādāneti sesupādānamūlabhūte
analyzed: vitthāretum samatthetum vā yasmin tiādi vuttam tattha yasmin upādāne iti
translated: Herein, in what is clung to is in what has the other kinds of clinging for its root,

original: kāmupādāne. Tassāti kāmupādānassa. Anupādiyitvāti chandarāgavasena anādiyitvā, etena
analyzed: kāma upādāne tassa ati kāma upādānassa an upādiyitvā ati chanda rāga vasena an ādiyitvā etena
translated: in the case of sensual-desire clinging. ‘Of that’: of sensual-desire clinging. ‘Without clinging’: without taking it by way of desire and lust. By this

original: “anupādāvimutto”ti padassa ya-kāralopena samāsabhāvaṃ, byāsabhāvaṃ vā dasseti.🔽37. “Ime kho”tiādi yathāpuṭṭhassa dhammassa vissajjitabhāvena nigamanavacanaṃ, “pajānātī”ti🔽vuttapajānanameva ca ima-saddena niddiṭṭhanti dassetuṃ “ye te”tiādimāha. Ye te sabbaññutaññāṇadhamme…pe…
analyzed: an upādā vimuttaḥ ti padassa yakāra lopena samāsa bhāvam byāsa bhāvam vā dasseti  ime kho ti ādi yathā puṭṭhassa dhammassa vissajjita bhāvena nigamana vacanam pajānāti iti  vutta pajānanam eva ca ima saddena niddiṭṭhanti dassetum ye te iti ādim āha ye te sabbaññuta ññāṇa dhammepe
translated: he shows that the compound in the phrase ‘freed by non-clinging’ is either a genitive-tatpurusa compound or an appositional compound.🔽‘These are the ideas’ and so on is a concluding statement in the sense of the answering of the question as asked. And he said ‘ye te’ and so on in order to show that the understanding stated in the phrase ‘he understands’

original: apucchiṃ, yehi sabbaññutaññāṇadhammehi…pe… vadeyyuṃ, tañca…pe… pajānātīti evaṃ niddiṭṭhā
analyzed: a pucchim yehi sabbaññu taññāṇa dhamme hipe vadeyyum tat cape pajānāti iti evam niddiṭṭhā
translated: is indicated by the word ‘these’ . The construction is this: ‘These ideas that are the ideas of the knowledge of omniscience, which are deep, hard to see, hard to grasp, that surpass the world, that are to be felt only by the wise, which I have attained, which I have fully awakened to, and which I have rightly proclaimed to you, and which you understand thus,

original: ime sabbaññutaññāṇadhammā gambhīrā…pe… paṇḍitavedanīyā cāti veditabbāti yojanā. “Eva”ntiādi
analyzed: ime sabbaññuta ññāṇa dhammāḥ gambhīrāpe paṇḍita vedanīyā ca ati veditabbā ati yojanā eva ntiādi
translated: are the ideas that are the ideas of the knowledge of omniscience, which are deep, hard to see, hard to grasp, that surpass the world, that are to be felt only by the wise’ . ‘Thus’ and so on

original: piṇḍatthadassanaṃ. Tattha kiñcāpi “anupādāvimutto bhikkhave, tathāgato”ti iminā aggamaggaphaluppattiṃ
analyzed: piṇḍa attha dassanam tattha kiñcā api an upādā vimuttaḥ bhikkhave tathāgato ti iminā agga magga phala uppattim
translated: is the demonstration of the general meaning. Herein, although it is with the words ‘Bhikkhus, the Tathagata is freed by non-clinging’ that the attainment of the supreme path and fruition is stated,

original: dasseti, “vedanānaṃ, samudayañcā”tiādinā ca catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Tathāpi yassā🔽dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā imaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ sakāraṇaṃ sagatikaṃ pabhedato vibhajituṃ🔽samattho hoti, tassā padaṭṭhānena ceva saddhiṃ pubbabhāgapaṭipadāya uppattibhūmiyā
analyzed: dassa iti vedanānam samudayam ca ati ādinā ca catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam tathā api  dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā imam diṭṭhigatam sa kāraṇam sa gatikam pabhedataḥ vibhajitum  samatthaḥ hoti tassā padaṭṭhānena ca iva saddhim pubbabhāga paṭipadāya uppatti bhūmiyā
translated: and the fourfold meditation subject of the four noble truths beginning with “the origin of feelings” .

original: ca tadeva pākaṭataraṃ kattukāmo dhammarājā evaṃ dassetīti vuttaṃ “tadeva niyyātita”nti,
analyzed: ca tat eva pākaṭataram kattu kāmaḥ dhammarājā evam dasseti iti vuttam tat eva niyyātitan ti
translated: Nevertheless, the King of the Dhamma shows it thus, saying “That itself is declared,” because he is desirous of making that same Dhamma-element, by means of its footing and the arising-plane of the preliminary path, more evident, since by the thorough penetration of that element he is able to analyse this false view together with its cause and its destination.🔽“That itself is declared” means: “That itself is concluded, is finished,” is the meaning.

original: nigamitaṃ niṭṭhāpitanti attho. Antarāti pucchitavissajjitadhammadassanavacanānamantarā🔽diṭṭhiyo vibhattā tassa pajānanākāradassanavasenāti attho.
analyzed: nigamitam niṭṭhāpitanti atthaḥ antarā ti pucchita vissajjita dhamma dassana vacanānam antarā  diṭṭhiyaḥ vibhattā tassa pajānana ākāra dassana vasena ati attho
translated: “In between” means in between the words of the question and the words of the answer.🔽“The views are analysed” means: “The way in which he understands is shown,” is the meaning.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā.
translated: The explanation of the first section is ended.

original: Ekaccasassatavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekacca sassata vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the doctrine of partial-eternalism

original: 38. “Ekaccasassatikā”ti taddhitapadaṃ samāsapadena vibhāvetuṃ “ekaccasassatavādā”ti
analyzed: ekacca sassatikā iti taddhita padam samāsa padena vibhāvetum ekacca sassata vādā iti
translated: “Partial-eternalists” is a compound word formed by a taddhita affix. In order to show it by a compound word, it is said “partial-eternalists” .

original: vuttaṃ. Sattesu, saṅkhāresu ca ekaccaṃ sassatametassāti ekaccasassato, vādo, so etesanti🔽ekaccasassatikā taddhitavasena, samāsavasena pana ekaccasassato vādo etesanti ekaccasassatavādā.
analyzed: vuttam sattesu saṅkhāresu ca ekaccam sassatam etassa ati ekacca sassataḥ vādaḥ saḥ etesan ti  ekacca sassatikā taddhita vasena samāsa vasena pana ekacca sassataḥ vādaḥ etesanti ekacca sassata vādā
translated: This has been said. The view that some beings are eternal is the eternalist view. Those who have that view are eternalists.🔽The word “eternalist” is derived from the word “eternal” by adding the suffix “tva.” But in the compound “ekaccasassatikā” the word “eternalist” is derived by the method of “co-ordination.”🔽The same method applies to the word “annihilationist.”

original: Esa nayo ekaccaasassatikapadepi. Nanu ca “ekaccasassatikā”ti vutte tadaññesaṃ ekaccaasassatikabhāvasanniṭṭhānaṃ🔽siddhamevāti? Saccaṃ atthato, saddato pana asiddhameva tasmā saddato pākaṭataraṃ
analyzed: esa nayaḥ ekacca asassatika pade pi nanu ca ekacca sassatikā iti vutte tad aññesam ekacca asassatika bhāva sanniṭṭhānam  siddham eva ati saccam atthataḥ saddato pana asiddham eva tasmā saddato pākaṭataram
translated: But if the word “eternalist” is used, it is established that the rest are annihilationists.

original: katvā dassetuṃ tathā vuttaṃ. Na hi idha sāvasesaṃ katvā dhammaṃ deseti dhammassāmī.🔽“Issaro nicco, aññe sattā aniccā”ti evaṃpavattavādā sattekaccasassatikā seyyathāpi
analyzed: katvā dassetum tathā vuttam na hi idha sa avasesam katvā dhammam deseti dhamma sāmī  issaraḥ niccaḥ aññe sattāḥ aniccā ati evaṃpavatta vādā satta ikaccasassatikā sā iyyathā api
translated: It is true that it is established in meaning, but not in letter. Therefore, in order to show it in a way that is clear in letter, it is said in this way. For the Lord of the Dhamma does not teach the Dhamma by leaving out a part.🔽The eternalists who say that the Lord of the World is eternal and the other beings are not are like the eternalists who say that the Lord of the World is eternal.

original: issaravādā. Tathā “nicco brahmā, aññe aniccā”ti evaṃpavattavādāpi. “Paramāṇavo niccā,
analyzed: issara vādā tathā niccaḥ brahmā aññe aniccā ati evaṃpavatta vādā api paramāṇavaḥ niccā
translated: Likewise, the eternalists who say that Brahmā is eternal and the others are not.

original: dviaṇukādayo aniccā”ti (visisikadassane sattamaparicchede paṭhamakaṇḍe passitabbaṃ)
analyzed: dvi aṇuka ādayaḥ aniccā ati visisika dassane sattama paricchede paṭhama kaṇḍe passitabbam
translated: and the two-atom and so on are impermanent.” (See Vism-mht 712)🔽Those who hold the view that “formations are partly eternal” are like the Kāṇādis.

original: evaṃpavattavādā saṅkhārekaccasassatikā seyyathāpi kāṇādā. Tathā “cakkhādayo aniccā,
analyzed: evaṃpavatta vādā saṅkhāra ekacca sassatikā sā iyyathā api kāṇādā tathā cakkha ādayaḥ aniccā
translated: And so too are those who hold the view that “the eye, etc., are impermanent,

original: viññāṇaṃ nicca”nti (nyāyadassane, visesikadassane ca passitabbaṃ) evaṃpavattavādāpi.
analyzed: viññāṇam niccanti nyāya dassane visesika dassane ca passitabbam evaṃpavatta vādā api
translated: but consciousness is eternal.” (See Nyāyas° 1.1.1 and VisM III 1.)

original: Idhāti “ekaccasassatikā”ti imasmiṃ pade, imissā vā desanāya. Gahitāti vuttā, desitabbabhāvena
analyzed: idha āti ekacca sassatikā ati imasmin pade imissā vā desanāya gahitā ati vuttā desitabba bhāvena
translated: Here: in the case of the expression “partly eternalists.” In this teaching: they are called “included” because they are to be taught,

original: vā desanāñāṇena samādinnā tathā ceva desitattā. Tathā hi idha purimakā tayo vādā
analyzed: vā desanā ñāṇena samādinnā tathā ca iva desita tā tathā hi idha purimakā tayaḥ vādā
translated: or they are called “included” because they are taken up by the knowledge of the teaching and taught accordingly. For thus the first three views

original: sattavasena, catuttho saṅkhāravasena desito. “Saṅkhārekaccasassatikā”ti idaṃ pana
analyzed: satta vasena catutthaḥ saṅkhāra vasena desito saṅkhāra ekacca sassatikā ti idam pana
translated: are taught by way of the seven, and the fourth is taught by way of formations. But the expression “partly eternalists”

original: tehi sassatabhāvena gayhamānānaṃ dhammānaṃ yāthāvasabhāvadassanavasena vuttaṃ, na
analyzed: tehi sassata bhāvena gayhamānānam dhammānam yāthāvasa bhāva dassana vasena vuttam na
translated: is stated by way of showing the true nature of the states that are held to be eternal,

original: pana ekaccasassatikamatadassanavasena. Tassa hi sassatābhimataṃ asaṅkhatamevāti laddhi.
analyzed: pana ekacca sassatika mata dassana vasena tassa hi sassata abhimatam asaṅkhatam evā ti laddhi
translated: not by way of showing the view of partial-eternalism. For the latter holds that only the unformed is eternal.

original: Tenevāha pāḷiyaṃ “cittanti vā…pe… ṭhassatī”ti. Na hi yassa sabhāvassa paccayehi abhisaṅkhatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tena iva āha pāḷiyam cittam ti vāpe ṭhassati iti na hi yassa sabhāvassa paccayehi abhisaṅkhata bhāvam
translated: Hence it is said in the text: “Or ‘consciousness will be’ is said, or ‘consciousness will not be’ is said, or ‘consciousness will both be and not be’ is said, or ‘consciousness will neither be nor not be’ is said” .

original: paṭijānāti, tasseva niccadhuvādibhāvo anummattakena sakkā paṭijānituṃ, etena ca “uppādavayadhuvatāyuttā
analyzed: paṭijānāti tassa iva nicca dhuva ādi bhāvaḥ an ummattakena sakkā paṭijānitum etena ca uppāda vaya dhuva tā yuttā
translated: For it is not possible for one who admits that a given individual essence is brought into being by conditions to admit also that it is permanent, stable, eternal, and so on,🔽by mere reasoning. And by this it is shown that the doctrine of the sevenfold predicable, which is set forth thus:🔽“The individual essence may be permanent, or impermanent, or both, or neither,

original: sabhāvā siyā niccā, siyā aniccā, siyā na vattabbā”tiādinā pavattasattabhaṅgavādassa🔽ayuttatā vibhāvitā hoti.🔽Tatrāyaṃ ayuttatāvibhāvanā – yadi hi “yena sabhāvena yo dhammo atthīti vuccati, teneva
analyzed: sabhāvā siyā niccā siyā aniccā siyā na vattabbā ati ādinā pavatta sattabhaṅga vādassa  ayutta tā vibhāvitā hoti  tatra ayam ayutta tā vibhāvanā yadi hi yena sabhāvena yaḥ dhammo atthi iti vuccati tena iva
translated: and so on with the rest of the fourfold formula” , is unreasonable.🔽Here is the way in which it is shown to be unreasonable. If it were said that “the state of being of a given state of being is not” by means of that same state of being, then the doctrine of the sevenfold predicable would be a doctrine of the manifold.

original: sabhāvena so dhammo natthī”ti vucceyya, siyā anekantavādo. Atha aññena, na siyā anekantavādo.
analyzed: sabhāvena so dhammo natthi iti vucceyya siyā anekantavādo atha aññena na siyā anekantavādo
translated: But if it is by means of another, then the doctrine of the sevenfold predicable is not a doctrine of the manifold.

original: Na cettha desantarādisambandhabhāvo yutto vattuṃ tassa sabbalokasiddhattā, vivādābhāvato
analyzed: na ca ittha desantara ādi sambandha bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ vattum tassa sabba loka siddha ttā vivāda abhāvato
translated: And here it is not proper to say that there is a relation of the different localities, etc., because that is established for all the world, and because there is no dispute about it.

original: ca. Ye pana vadanti “yathā suvaṇṇaghaṭena makuṭe kate ghaṭabhāvo nassati, makuṭabhāvo
analyzed: ca ye pana vadanti yathā suvaṇṇa ghaṭena makuṭe kate ghaṭa bhāvaḥ nassati makuṭa bhāvaḥ
translated: But those who say that “when a golden bowl is made out of a golden chain, the state of being a chain is abandoned and the state of being a bowl arises, but the state of being gold does not abandon its own individual essence” ,

original: uppajjati, suvaṇṇabhāvo tiṭṭhatiyeva, evaṃ sabbasabhāvānaṃ koci dhammo nassati, koci
analyzed: uppajjati suvaṇṇa bhāvaḥ tiṭṭhati yeva evam sabba sabhāvānam koci dhammo nassati koci
translated: and the state of being gold remains. So no state of any phenomenon is destroyed,

original: dhammo uppajjati, sabhāvo eva tiṭṭhatī”ti. Te vattabbā “kiṃ taṃ suvaṇṇaṃ, yaṃ ghaṭe,
analyzed: dhammaḥ uppajjati sabhāvaḥ eva tiṭṭhati iti te vattabbā kim tat suvaṇṇam yam ghaṭe
translated: and no state arises. Only the state itself remains.” They should be told: “What is that gold which is present in the pot

original: makuṭe ca avaṭṭhitaṃ, yadi rūpādi, so saddo viya anicco. Atha rūpādisamūho sammutimattaṃ,
analyzed: makuṭe ca avaṭṭhitam yadi rūpa ādi saḥ saddaḥ viya aniccaḥ atha rūpa ādi samūhaḥ
translated: and in the crown? If it is visible form, etc., then it is impermanent like the sound. If it is a mere convention,

original: na tassa atthitā vā natthitā vā niccatā vā labbhatī”ti, tasmā anekantavādo na siyā.
analyzed: na tassa atthi tā vā natthi tā vā nicca tā vā labbhati iti tasmai anekantavādaḥ na siyā
translated: then it is not possible to say that it exists or does not exist or that it is permanent.” Therefore the doctrine of the many is not tenable.

original: Dhammānañca dhammino aññathānaññathā ca pavattiyaṃ doso vuttoyeva sassatavādavicāraṇāyaṃ.
analyzed: dhammānam ca dhamminaḥ aññathā anaññathā ca pavattiyam doso vuttaḥ yā iva sassata vāda vicāraṇāyam
translated: And the fault in the occurrence of phenomena and their essential nature in different ways has already been stated in the consideration of the doctrine of eternalism.

original: Tasmā so tattha vuttanayena veditabbo. Apica na niccāniccanavattabbarūpo attā, loko
analyzed: tasmā saḥ tattha vutta nayena veditabbaḥ apica na attā loko
translated: So that should be understood in the way stated there. Furthermore, the self and the world are not to be described as permanent, impermanent, or not so describable,

original: ca paramatthato vijjamānatāparijānanato yathā niccādīnaṃ aññataraṃ rūpaṃ, yathā vā
analyzed: ca paramatthataḥ vijjamāna tā parijānanataḥ yathā nicca ādīnam aññataram rūpam yathā vā
translated: because their existence in the ultimate sense is not known, just as the permanence, etc., of visible form, etc., is not known,

original: dīpādayo. Na hi rūpādīnaṃ udayabbayasabhāvānaṃ niccāniccanavattabbasabhāvatā sakkā
analyzed: dīpa ādayaḥ na hi rūpa ādīnam udaya bbaya sabhāvānam nicca anicca navatta bbasa bhāva tā sakkā
translated: or just as the light, etc., of the sun are not known. For it is not possible to say of visible form, etc., which have the nature of arising and passing away,🔽that they have the nature of permanence, impermanence, or not so describable.

original: viññātuṃ, jīvassa ca niccādīsu aññataraṃ rūpaṃ siyāti, evaṃ sattabhaṅgo viya sesabhaṅgānampi
analyzed: viññātum jīvassa ca nicca ādīsu aññataram rūpam siyāti evam satta bhaṅgaḥ viya sesa bhaṅgānam pi
translated: and the life-germ would be materiality, and so on.

original: asambhavoyevāti sattabhaṅgavādassa ayuttatā veditabbā.
analyzed: sattabhaṅga vādassa ayutta tā veditabbā
translated: So the impossibility of the other analyses should be understood in the same way.

original: Nanu ca “ekacce dhammā sassatā, ekacce asassatā”ti etasmiṃ vāde cakkhādīnaṃ asassatabhāvasanniṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca ekacce dhammā sassatā ekacce a sassata ati etasmin vāde cakkha ādīnam a sassata bhāva sanniṭṭhānam
translated: But is it not a fact that in the doctrine that some ideas are eternal and some are not eternal, the eye, etc., are established as non-eternal?

original: yathāsabhāvāvabodho eva, atha evaṃvādīnaṃ kathaṃ micchādassanaṃ siyāti, ko vā evamāha
analyzed: yathā a sabhāva avabodhaḥ eva atha evaṃvādīnam katham micchādassanam siyāti kaḥ vā evam āha
translated: And if that is so, how can it be a wrong view in those who hold that doctrine?

original: “cakkhādīnaṃ asassatabhāvasanniṭṭhānaṃ micchādassana”nti? Asassatesuyeva pana kesañci
analyzed: cakkha ādīnam asassata bhāva sanniṭṭhānam micchādassanam ti asassatesu yeva pana kesañci
translated: Or who says that the establishment of the eye, etc., as non-eternal is a wrong view?🔽But it can be taken that the establishment of some ideas as eternal, which are non-eternal, is a wrong view here.

original: dhammānaṃ sassatabhāvasanniṭṭhānaṃ idha micchādassananti gahetabbaṃ, tena pana ekavāde
analyzed: dhammānam sassata bhāva sanniṭṭhānam idha micchādassanan ti gahetabbam tena pana eka vāde
translated: And when that is put forward as a single doctrine,

original: pavattamānena cakkhādīnaṃ asassatabhāvāvabodho vidūsito saṃsaṭṭhabhāvato visasaṃsaṭṭho
analyzed: pavattamānena cakkha ādīnam asassata bhāva avabodhaḥ vidūsitaḥ saṃsaṭṭha bhāvataḥ visasaṃsaṭṭhaḥ
translated: the establishment of the eye, etc., as non-eternal is obscured by the confusion of the two, like a lump of sugar confused with poison,

original: viya sappipiṇḍo, tato ca tassa sakiccakaraṇāsamatthatāya sammādassanapakkhe ṭhapetabbataṃ
analyzed: viya sappi piṇḍo tatas ca tassa sa kicca karaṇa asamattha tāya sammādassana pakkhe ṭhapetabba tam
translated: and so it is not capable of doing its own work, and therefore it should be placed on the side of right view.

original: nārahatīti. Asassatabhāvena nicchitāpi vā cakkhuādayo samāropitajīvasabhāvā eva diṭṭhigatikehi
analyzed: na ārahati iti a sassata bhāvena vā cakkhu ādayo samāropita jīva sabhāvāḥ eva diṭṭhigatikehi
translated: Or, even though the eye, etc., are not eternal in the nature of things, still those who are on the way to a false view take them as having the nature of a soul that is superimposed on them.

original: gayhantīti tadavabodhassa micchādassanabhāvo na sakkā nivāretuṃ. Tenevāha pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: gayhanti iti tad avabodhassa micchādassana bhāvaḥ na sakkā nivāretum tena iva āha pāḷiyam
translated: So it cannot be denied that the understanding of them in this way is a wrong view. That is why it is said in the texts:

original: “cakkhuṃ itipi…pe… kāyo itipi ayaṃ attā”tiādi. Evañca katvā asaṅkhatāya, saṅkhatāya
analyzed: cakkhum kāyaḥ iti pi ayam attā ati ādi evañca katvā asaṅkhatāya saṅkhatāya
translated: “The eye, bhikkhus, is the self of one who knows, the self of one who sees … The mind is the self of one who knows, the self of one who sees” , and so on.

original: ca dhātuyā vasena yathākkamaṃ “ekacce dhammā sassatā, ekacce asassatā”ti evaṃpavatto
analyzed: ca dhātuyāḥ vasena yathākkamam ekacce dhammā sassatā ekacce a sassatā ati evaṃpavatto
translated: And if this is so, then the Vibhajjavāda, which occurs thus, “Some ideas are eternal, some are not eternal” ,🔽would be a doctrine of partial-eternalism according to the unformed and formed element respectively.

original: vibhajjavādopi ekaccasassatavādoyeva bhaveyyāti evampakārā codanā anavakāsā hoti
analyzed: vibhajja vādaḥ api bhaveyya ati evampakārā codanā anavakāsā hoti
translated: So this kind of objection is out of place,🔽because it is the right way to understand the nature of ideas.

original: aviparītadhammasabhāvapaṭipattibhāvato. Aviparītadhammasabhāvapaṭipattiyeva hesa
analyzed: aviparīta dhamma sabhāva paṭipatti bhāvataḥ aviparīta dhamma sabhāva paṭipattiyā iva ha esa
translated: For this is the right way to understand the nature of ideas,

original: vuttanayena asaṃsaṭṭhattā, anāropitajīvasabhāvattā ca.🔽Etthāha – purimasmimpisassatavāde asassatānaṃ dhammānaṃ “sassatā”ti gahaṇaṃ visesato
analyzed: vutta nayena asaṃsaṭṭha ttā anāropita jīva sabhāva ttā ca 🔽ettha āha purimasmim pi sassata vāde asassatānam dhammānam sassatā ati gahaṇam visesataḥ
translated: because it is unconfused and because it does not superimpose a soul-nature on what is without a soul.

original: micchādassanaṃ bhavati. Sassatānaṃ pana “sassatā”ti gāho na micchādassanaṃ yathāsabhāvaggāhabhāvato.
analyzed: micchā dassanam bhavati sassatānam pana gāhaḥ na micchā dassanam yathā sabhāva ggāha bhāvato
translated: But the holding of the eternalists’ view that “the self is percipient and continues to exist eternally” is not a wrong view, because it is a holding of what is in accordance with actuality.

original: Evañca sati imassa vādassa vādantaratā na vattabbā, idha viya purimepi ekaccesveva🔽dhammesu sassataggāhasambhavatoti, vattabbāyeva asassatesveva “kecideva dhammā sassatā,
analyzed: evañca sati imassa vādassa vādantara tā na vattabbā idha purime api ekaccesu eva  dhammesu sassata ggāha sambhavato ti vattabbāya iva a sassatesu eva kecid eva dhammā sassatā
translated: And if that is so, then this view cannot be said to be a subdivision of the eternalist view, because the holding of the eternalist view is possible in regard to some things in the first way and in regard to some in the second way.

original: keci asassatā”ti parikappanāvasena gahetabbadhammesu vibhāgappavattiyā imassa vādassa🔽dassitattā. Nanu ca ekadesassa samudāyantogadhattā ayaṃ sappadesasassataggāho purimasmiṃ
analyzed: keci parikappanā vasena gahetabba dhammesu vibhāga ppavattiyā imassa vādassa  dassita ttā nanu ca eka desassa ayam purimasmin
translated: But it must be said that this view is a subdivision of the eternalist view, because it is shown to be a subdivision of the eternalist view by the fact that it occurs by way of a distinction in the things that can be held as eternal, since it is possible to hold some things as eternal in the first way and some in the second way.

original: nippadesasassataggāhe samodhānaṃ gaccheyyātī? Tathāpi na sakkā vattuṃ vādī tabbisayavisesavasena
analyzed: samodhānam tathā api na sakkā vattum vādī tad visaya visesa vasena
translated: But is it not the case that this view, which is a holding of the eternalism of a part, should be included in the former view, which is a holding of the eternalism of the whole, since the former is a part of the latter?

original: vādadvayassa pavattattā. Aññe eva hi diṭṭhigatikā “sabbe dhammā sassatā”ti abhiniviṭṭhā,
analyzed: vāda dvayassa pavatta ttā aññe eva hi diṭṭhigatikā sabbe dhammā sassatā ati abhiniviṭṭhā
translated: Even so, it cannot be said that this is so, because the two views occur by way of a distinction in their respective spheres. For some eternalists are attached to the view that “all things are eternal,”🔽while others hold the view that “some things are eternal and some are not.”

original: aññe “ekacceva sassatā, ekacce asassatā”ti. Saṅkhārānaṃ anavasesapariyādānaṃ, ekadesapariggaho
analyzed: aññe ekacce iva sassatā ekacce a sassatā ti saṅkhārānam anavasesa pariyādānam eka desa pariggahaḥ
translated: and the others that some are eternal and some not. The complete exhaustion of formations and the grasping of a part🔽are quite impossible in the case of the two-pointed view. And what is more,

original: ca vādadvayassa paribyattoyeva. Kiñca bhiyyo – anekavidhasamussaye, ekavidhasamussaye
analyzed: ca vāda dvayassa kiñca bhiyyas anekavidha samussaye ekavidha samussaye
translated: in the case of the view of the many-pointed and the one-pointed,

original: ca khandhapabandhena abhinivesabhāvato tathā na sakkā vattuṃ. Catubbidhopi hi sassatavādī
analyzed: ca khandha pabandhena abhinivesa bhāvataḥ tathā na sakkā vattum catubbidhaḥ api hi sassata vādī
translated: it is impossible to say that in the same way because of the adherence to the continuity of aggregates. For the four kinds of eternalists

original: jātivisesavasena nānāvidharūpakāyasannissaye eva arūpadhammapuñje sassatābhinivesī🔽jāto abhiññāṇena, anussavādīhi ca rūpakāyabhedagahaṇato. Tathā ca vuttaṃ “tato cuto
analyzed: jāti visesa vasena nānāvidha rūpa kāya sannissaye eva arūpa dhamma puñje sassata abhinivesī  jātaḥ abhiññāṇena anussava ādīhi ca rūpa kāya bheda gahaṇato tathā ca vuttam tatas cutaḥ
translated: adhere to the eternity of the mass of immaterial dhammas that is dependent on the various kinds of material bodies according to the difference in their births.

original: amutra udapādi”nti, “cavanti upapajjantī”ti ca ādi. Visesalābhī pana ekaccasassatiko
analyzed: amutra udapādinti cavanti upapajjanti iti ca ādi visesa lābhī pana ekacca sassatikaḥ
translated: The one who has direct knowledge does so through direct knowledge, and the one who is a traditionalist does so through the apprehension of the dissolution of the material body. And it is said accordingly: “After passing away from here he arose there” , “They die and reappear” , and so on.

original: anupadhāritabhedasamussaye dhammapabandhe sassatākāragahaṇena abhinivesaṃ janesi
analyzed: an upadhārita bheda samussaye dhamma pabandhe sassata ākāra gahaṇena abhinivesam janesi
translated: But the one who is an eternalist in part, who has attained distinction, generates adherence by apprehending the aspect of eternity in the continuity of dhammas, which is undifferentiated in the sense of the nonapprehension of the difference in the aggregates.

original: ekabhavapariyāpannakhandhasantānavisayattā tadabhinivesassa. Tathā hi tīsupi vādesu
analyzed: eka bhava pariyāpanna khandha santāna visaya ttā tad abhinivesassa tathā hi tīsu pi vādesu
translated: For his adherence is confined to the continuity of aggregates included in a single becoming. For it is said in all three doctrines:

original: “taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussaratī”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ. Takkīnaṃ🔽pana ubhinnampi sassatekaccasassatavādīnaṃ sassatābhinivesaviseso rūpārūpadhammavisayatāya supākaṭoyevāti.
analyzed: tam pubbenivāsam anussarati tatas param na anussarati iti ettakam eva vuttam takkīnam  pana ubhinnam pi sassata ekacca sassata vā ādīnam sassata abhinivesa visesaḥ rūpa arūpa dhamma visaya tāya
translated: “He recollects his former lives up to that point, but not beyond that.”🔽But the difference in the insistence on eternalism of the eternalists, who are of two kinds, is quite clear, being based on material and immaterial states.

original: 39. Saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyīvivaṭṭavivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīsaṅkhātānaṃ tiṇṇampi asaṅkhyeyyakappānamatikkamena
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭa vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī saṅkhātānam tiṇṇam pi asaṅkhyeyya kappānam atikkamena
translated: The word “long” is used because of the lapse of time required for the three incalculable ages and a 100,000 aeons to elapse before the world contracts again after the world has expanded.

original: puna saṃvaṭṭanato, addhā-saddassa ca kālapariyāyattā evaṃ vuttanti āha “dīghassā”tiādi.🔽Atikkamma ayanaṃ pavattanaṃ accayo. Anekatthattā dhātūnaṃ, upasaggavasena ca atthavisesavācakattā🔽saṃ-saddena yutto vaṭṭa-saddo vināsavācīti vuttaṃ “vinassatī”ti, vatu-saddo vā gatiyameva.
analyzed: puna saṃvaṭṭanataḥ addhāsaddassa ca kāla pariyāyattā evam vuttan ti āha dīghassa atiādi  atikkamma ayanam pavattanam accayaḥ aneka attha ttā dhātūnam upasagga vasena ca attha visesa vācaka ttā  saṃsaddena yuttaḥ vaṭṭa saddaḥ vināsa vācī iti vuttam vinassati iti vatu saddaḥ vā gatiyam eva
translated: The word “addhā” is used because of the lapse of time.

original: Saṅkhayatthajotakena pana saṃ-saddena yuttattā tadatthasambandhanena vināsattho labbhatīti
analyzed: saṅkha yattha jotakena pana saṃsaddena yutta ttā tad attha sambandhanena vināsa tthaḥ labbhati iti
translated: The word “vaṭṭa” is used in the sense of “destruction” because of the prefix “sam” and because of the word’s meaning of “going” and because of the word’s meaning of “destruction” by the word “sam” which indicates the meaning of “exhaustion.”🔽The word “vaṭṭa” is used in the sense of “going” because of the word “sam” which indicates the meaning of “exhaustion.”

original: dasseti “vinassatī”ti iminā. Saṅkhayavasena vattatīti hi saddato attho, ta-kārassa🔽cettha ṭa-kārādeso. Vipattikaramahāmeghasamuppattitto hi paṭṭhāya yāva aṇusahagatopi
analyzed: dasseti vinassati iti iminā saṅkhaya vasena vattati iti hi saddataḥ attho takārassa  ca ittha ṭakāra ādesaḥ vipatti kara mahā megha samuppattittaḥ hi paṭṭhāya yāva aṇu sahagataḥ api
translated: He shows that it is destroyed by the word “perishes.” For the meaning of the word “perishes” is “it occurs by way of destruction.”🔽Here the letter ṭ is substituted for the letter ṭ. For from the time when the great cloud that causes the destruction of the world arises until the time when not even a single being remains in the Avīci hell, the world is said to be “contracted.”

original: saṅkhāro na hoti, tāva loko saṃvaṭṭatīti vuccati. Pāḷiyaṃ lokoti pathavīādibhājanaloko
analyzed: saṅkhāro na hoti tāva loko saṃvaṭṭati iti vuccati pāḷiyam loko ti pathavī ādi bhājana loko
translated: In the text, the world is intended to mean the world of the physical basis consisting of the earth, etc.,

original: adhippeto tadavasesassa bāhullato, tadeva sandhāya “yebhuyyenā”ti vuttanti dasseti
analyzed: adhippetaḥ tad avasesassa bāhullato tat eva sandhāya yebhuyyena ati vuttanti dasseti
translated: because of the abundance of that world. He shows that it is said “for the most part” with reference to that very world by the words “those beings who.”

original: “ye”tiādinā. Uparibrahmalokesūti ābhassarabhūmito uparibhūmīsu. Agginā kappavuṭṭhānañhi
analyzed: yā iti ādinā upari brahmalokesu iti ābhassara bhūmitaḥ upari bhūmīsu agginā kappa vuṭṭhānam hi
translated: In the upper Brahma worlds means in the upper planes beginning with the plane of the Ābhassara.🔽For the arising of the eon by fire is intended here. Therefore it is said in the text: “They become those who are headed for the Ābhassara world.”

original: idhādhippetaṃ, tenevāha pāḷiyaṃ “ābhassarasaṃvattanikā hontī”ti. Kasmā tadeva vuttanti
analyzed: idha adhippetam tena iva āha pāḷiyam ābhassara saṃvattanikāḥ honti iti kasmā tat eva vuttan ti
translated: Why is it said only of that?

original: ce? Tasseva bahulaṃ pavattanato. Ayañhi vāraniyamo –
analyzed: ce tassa iva bahulam pavattanataḥ ayam hi vāra niyamaḥ
translated: Because it occurs there most frequently. For this is the rule:🔽Seven times by water, seven times by fire,

original: “Sattasattagginā vārā, aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā;
analyzed: satta sattagginā vārāḥ aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā
translated: and in the eighth by wind.

original: Catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇā, eko vāyuvaro siyā”ti. (abhidhammatthavibhāvanīṭīkāya pañcamaparicchedavaṇṇanāyampi);🔽Āruppesu vāti ettha vikappanatthena vā-saddena saṃvaṭṭamānalokadhātūhi aññalokadhātūsu
analyzed: yadā puṇṇāḥ ekaḥ vāyu varaḥ siyāti abhidhammatthavibhāvanī ṭīkāya pañcama pariccheda vaṇṇanāyam pi  āruppesu vā ti ettha vikappana atthena vā saddena saṃvaṭṭamāna lokadhātūhi añña lokadhātūsu
translated: One aeon of wind is done” .🔽In the immaterial states: the word “or” is in the sense of alternative.

original: vāti vikappeti. Na hi sabbe apāyasattā tadā rūpārūpabhavesu uppajjantīti sakkā viññātuṃ
analyzed: vāti vikappeti na hi sabbe apāyasa ttā tadā rūpa arūpa bhavesu uppajjanti iti sakkā viññātum
translated: It is not possible to know that all beings in the unhappy destinies are reborn in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming,

original: apāyesu dīghatarāyukānaṃ manussalokūpapattiyā asambhavato, manussalokūpapattiñca🔽vinā tadā tesaṃ tatrūpapattiyā anupapattito. Niyatamicchādiṭṭhikopi hi saṃvaṭṭhamāne
analyzed: apāyesu dīghatara āyukānam manussa loka upapattiyāḥ asambhavataḥ manussa loka upapattiñca  vinā tadā tesam tatru upapattiyāḥ anupapattitaḥ niyatam icchādiṭṭhikaḥ api hi saṃvaṭṭhamāne
translated: because those with a long life span in the unhappy destinies cannot be reborn in the human world,🔽and without being reborn in the human world they cannot be reborn in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming.

original: kappe nirayato na muccati, piṭṭhicakkavāḷeyeva nibbattatīti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kappe nirayataḥ na muccati piṭṭhi cakkavāḷeyā iva nibbattati iti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam
translated: For it is said in the commentaries that one who is fixed in wrong view is not released from hell when the aeon is destroyed, but is reborn in the central world-sphere.

original: Satipi sabbasattānaṃ puññāpuññābhisaṅkhāramanasā nibbattabhāve bāhirapaccayehi vinā
analyzed: sati pi sabba sattānam puñña apuñña abhisaṅkhāra manasā nibbatta bhāve bāhira paccayehi vinā
translated: And although all beings are reborn by the mind’s aspiration for merit and for demerit,

original: manasāva nibbattattā rūpāvacarasattā eva “manomayā”ti vuccanti, na pana bāhirapaccayapaṭiyattā
analyzed: manasā ava nibbatta ttā rūpāvacara sattā eva manaḥ mayā ti vuccanti na pana bāhira paccaya paṭiyattā
translated: They are called “mind-made” because they are produced by mind only, and they are so only in the case of beings in the fine-material sphere, not in the case of others.

original: tadaññeti dassetuṃ “manena nibbattattā manomayā”ti āha. Yadevaṃ kāmāvacarasattānampi
analyzed: tad aññā iti dassetum manena nibbatta ttā manaḥ mayā iti āha yat evam kāmāvacara sattānam pi
translated: He said “produced by mind” in order to show that they are different from those.🔽But then it follows that the same applies to beings in the sense sphere too?

original: opapātikānaṃ manomayabhāvo āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati, adhicittabhūtena atisayamanasā
analyzed: opapātikānam manaḥ maya bhāvaḥ āpajjati iti na āpajjati adhicitta bhūtena atisaya manasā
translated: It does not, because the expression “mind-made” is used only of beings produced by a special kind of mind, that is, by a mind of the fine-material sphere.

original: nibbattasattesuyeva manomayavohāratoti dassentena jhāna-saddena visesetvā “jhānamanenā”ti
analyzed: nibbatta sattesu yeva manaḥ maya vohārato ti dassentena jhāna saddena visesetvā jhānam anena ati
translated: He therefore specified it by the word “meditation” thus: “By the mind of meditation.”

original: vuttaṃ. Evampi arūpāvacarasattānaṃ manomayabhāvo āpajjatīti? Na tattha bāhirapaccayehi
analyzed: vuttam evam pi arūpa avacara sattānam manaḥ maya bhāvaḥ āpajjati iti na tattha bāhira paccayehi
translated: But then it follows that the same applies to beings in the immaterial sphere too?

original: nibbattetabbatāsaṅkāya abhāvena manasā eva nibbattāti avadhāraṇāsambhavato. Niruḷhovāyaṃ
analyzed: nibbattetabba tā āsaṅkāya abhāvena manasā eva nibbattā ati avadhāraṇa asambhavataḥ niruḷhaḥ uva ayam
translated: It does not, because there is no possibility of the qualification “by mind only” there, since there is no question of their being produced by external conditions.

original: loke manomayavohāro rūpāvacarasattesu. Tathā hi annamayo pānamayo manomayo ānandamayo
analyzed: loke manaḥ maya vohāraḥ rūpāvacara sattesu tathā hi anna mayaḥ pāna mayaḥ manaḥ mayaḥ ānanda mayaḥ
translated: The expression “mind-made” is used in the world in this restricted sense of beings in the fine-material sphere.

original: viññāṇamayoti pañcadhā attānaṃ vedavādino parikappenti. Ucchedavādepi vakkhati “dibbo
analyzed: viññāṇa mayaḥ ti pañcadhā attānam veda vādino parikappenti uccheda vāde pi vakkhati dibbaḥ
translated: For the Vedāntins describe the self in five ways as “made of food,” “made of drink,” “made of mind,” “made of bliss,” and “made of consciousness” .🔽And in the doctrine of annihilationism it is said: “Divine, friends, is the self of one who is perfect, blissful, bright, incorporeal, and consisting of mind” .

original: rūpī manomayo”ti, te pana jhānānubhāvato pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhacarāti
analyzed: rūpī manaḥ mayaḥ ti te pana jhāna anubhāvato pīti bhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkha carā ti
translated: “They are material, mind-made” . But they are “fed on rapture” and “move in the firmament” because of the effulgence of the jhānas.

original: āha “pīti tesa”ntiādi, tesaṃ attanova pabhā atthīti attho. Sobhanā vā ṭhāyī sabhā🔽etesanti subhaṭṭhāyinotipi yujjati. Ukkaṃsenāti ābhassare sandhāya vuttaṃ. Parittābhāppamāṇābhā
analyzed: āha pi iti tesantiādi tesam attanā uva pabhā atthi iti attho sobhanā vā ṭhāyī sabhā  etesan ti subha ṭṭhāyinaḥ tipi yujjati ukkaṃsena ati ābhassare sandhāya vuttam paritta ābhā appamāṇa ābhā
translated: So it is said: “Rapture is theirs” , the meaning being that they have their own light. Or alternatively, the meaning is that they are “beautiful” and “steadfast” , and they are “in the firmament” .🔽“The highest” is said with reference to the Ābhassara gods. The Parittābha and Appamāṇābha gods live for two and four world-cycles respectively.

original: pana dve, cattāro ca kappe tiṭṭhanti. Aṭṭha kappeti catunnamasaṅkhyeyyakappānaṃ samudāyabhūte aṭṭha mahākappe.
analyzed: pana dve cattāro ca kappe tiṭṭhanti aṭṭha kappe iti catunnam asaṅkhyeyya kappānam samudāya bhūte aṭṭha mahākappe
translated: The “eight great world-cycles” are the eight great world-cycles that make up the four incalculable world-cycles.

original: 40. Vināsavācīyeva vaṭṭa-saddo paṭisedhajotakena upasaggena yuttattā saṇṭhāhanatthañāpakoti
analyzed: vināsa vācīyā iva vaṭṭa saddaḥ paṭisedha jotakena upasaggena yutta ttā saṇṭhā hana ttha ñāpakaḥ ti
translated: The word “cycle” is a word for destruction, and it is a word for accumulation because it is compounded with the prefix upa, which is a word for “near” .

original: āha “saṇṭhātī”ti, anekatthattā vā dhātūnaṃ nibbattati, vaḍḍhatīti vā attho. Sampattimahāmeghasamuppattito
analyzed: āha saṇṭhāti iti aneka attha ttā vā dhātūnam nibbattati vaḍḍhati iti vā attho sampatti mahā megha samuppattito
translated: So it is said: “It accumulates” . Or alternatively, the meaning is that it is “produced” or “increased” , because of the plurality of meanings of verbal roots.

original: hi paṭṭhāya pathavīsandhārakudakataṃsandhārakavāyuādīnaṃ samuppattivasena yāva candimasūriyānaṃ
analyzed: hi paṭṭhāya pathavī sandhāraka udaka taṃ sandhāraka vāyu ādīnam samuppatti vasena yāva candima sūriyānam
translated: For the “accumulation of the earth” begins with the arising of the great cloud of attainment and continues until the arising of the wind that destroys the world-sphere.🔽Then the “accumulation of the moon and sun” begins with the arising of the moon and sun and continues until the arising of the wind that destroys the world-sphere.

original: pātubhāvo, tāva loko vivaṭṭatīti vuccati. Pakatiyāti sabhāvena, tassa “suñña”nti🔽iminā sambandho. Tathāsuññatāya kāraṇamāha “nibbattasattānaṃ natthitāyā”ti. Purimataraṃ
analyzed: pātubhāvaḥ tāva lokaḥ vivaṭṭati iti vuccati pakatiyā ati sabhāvena tassa  iminā sambandhaḥ tathā asuññatāya kāraṇam āha nibbatta sattānam na atthitāya ati purimataram
translated: The world is said to be “revolving” as long as it is manifest. “By nature” means by its own-nature. The connection with “empty” is this:🔽because of the non-existence of beings who have been reborn there. The reason for its emptiness is stated: “because of the non-existence of beings who have been reborn there.”🔽

original: aññesaṃ sattānamanuppannattāti bhāvo, tena yathā ekaccāni vimānāni tattha nibbattasattānaṃ🔽chaḍḍitattā suññāni, na evamidanti dasseti.
analyzed: aññesam sattānam anuppanna ttā ati bhāvaḥ tena yathā ekaccāni vimānāni tattha nibbatta sattānam  chaḍḍita ttā suññāni na evam idanti dasseti
translated: The world is said to be “revolving” as long as it is becoming manifest. “By nature” means by its own-nature. The connection is with “empty” in the next clause. The reason for its emptiness is given: “because there are no beings who have been reborn there.” The meaning is: because no other beings have arisen there before. This shows that it is not empty because beings who have been reborn there have departed, as is the case with some of the divine mansions.

original: Aparo nayo – sakakammassa paṭhamaṃ karaṇaṃ pakati, tāya nibbattasattānanti sambandho,🔽tena yathā etassa attano kammabalena paṭhamaṃ nibbatti, na evaṃ aññesaṃ tassa purimataraṃ,
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ saka kammassa paṭhamam karaṇam pakati tāya nibbatta sattānam ti sambandhaḥ  tena yathā etassa attano kamma balena paṭhamam nibbatti na evam aññesam tassa purimataram
translated: Another interpretation: the first performance of one’s own kamma is the nature. The connection is with “beings who have been reborn there.”

original: samānakāle vā nibbatti atthi, tathā nibbattasattānaṃ natthitāya suññamidanti dasseti.
analyzed: samāna kāle vā nibbatti atthi tathā nibbatta sattānam na atthitāya suññam idan ti dasseti
translated: This shows that it is empty because there are no beings who have been reborn there by the power of their own kamma, as is the case with oneself, and because there are no beings who have been reborn there before one’s own time, or at the same time.

original: Brahmapārisajjabrahmapurohitamahābrahmāno idha brahmakāyikā, tesaṃ nivāsatāya bhūmipi
analyzed: brahma pārisajja brahmapurohita mahābrahmānaḥ brahmakāyikā tesam bhūmipi
translated: The Brahmakāyika gods are the assembly of Brahmas, the ministers of Brahma, and the Great Brahmas. The ground is empty because there are no beings who have been reborn there by the power of their own kamma, as is the case with oneself, and because there are no beings who have been reborn there before one’s own time, or at the same time.

original: “brahmakāyikā”ti vuttā, brahmakāyikabhūmīti pana pāṭhebrahmakāyikānaṃ sambandhinī
analyzed: brahmakāyikā ati vuttā brahmakāyika bhūmī iti pana pāṭhe brahmakāyikānam sambandhinī
translated: “Brahma’s retinue” is said, but in the reading “Brahma’s retinue plane” the meaning is: the plane related to Brahma’s retinue.

original: bhūmīti attho. Kattā sayaṃ kārako. Kāretā paresaṃ āṇāpako. Visuddhimagge pubbenivāsañāṇakathāyaṃ
analyzed: bhūmi iti attho kattā sayam kārako kāretā paresam āṇāpakaḥ visuddhi magge pubbenivāsa ñāṇa kathā ayam
translated: The maker is the one who makes by his own effort. The one who causes to make is the one who makes by the effort of others. In the Path of Purification, in the chapter on the knowledge of past lives,

original: vuttanayena, etena nibbattakkamaṃ kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānabhāve ca kāraṇaṃ dasseti.🔽Kammaṃ upanissayabhāvena paccayo etissāti kammapaccayā. Atha vā tattha nibbattasattānaṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena etena nibbatta kkamam kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhāna bhāve ca kāraṇam dasseti  kammam upanissaya bhāvena paccayaḥ etissa ati kamma paccayāḥ atha vā tattha nibbatta sattānam
translated: in the way stated there, he shows the reason for the state of being originated by kamma and by temperature as the maker and the one who causes to make.

original: vipaccanakakammassa sahakārīkārakabhāvato kammassa paccayāti kammapaccayā. Utu samuṭṭhānametissāti
analyzed: vipaccanaka kammassa sahakārīkāraka bhāvataḥ kammassa paccayā ati kamma paccayā utu samuṭṭhānam etissa ati
translated: Kamma is a condition by way of decisive support, thus it is a kamma condition. Or alternatively, because of the state of being a co-operating cause of the kamma that is ripening for the beings reborn there, kamma is a condition, thus it is a kamma condition. It is originated by temperature, thus it is temperature-originated.

original: utusamuṭṭhānā. “Kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānā”tipi samāsavasena pāṭho kammasahāyo paccayo,
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhānā kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhānā ti pi samāsa vasena pāṭhaḥ kamma sahāyaḥ paccayaḥ
translated: The reading “kamma condition and temperature-originated” is a compound. A condition that is a co-operating cause of kamma,

original: vuttanayena vā kammassa sahāyabhūto paccayoti kammapaccayo, so eva utu tathā, sova
analyzed: vutta nayena vā kammassa sahāya bhūto paccayo ti kammapaccayo so eva utu tathā saḥ uva
translated: or a condition that is a co-operating cause of kamma in the way stated, is a kamma condition. That same temperature is so, and that same temperature-originated is so.

original: samuṭṭhānametissāti kammapaccayautusamuānā. Ratanabhūmīti ukkaṃsagatapuññakammānubhāvato
analyzed: samuṭṭhānam etissa ti kamma paccaya otu samuānā ratana bhūmi iti ukkaṃsa gata puñña kamma anubhāvato
translated: The source is the tenfold source, namely, kamma, temperature, and nutriment.

original: ratanabhūtā bhūmi, na kevalaṃ bhūmiyeva, atha kho tapparivārāpīti āha “pakatī”tiādi.
analyzed: ratana bhūtā na kevalam tad parivārā api iti āha pakati itiādi
translated: The plane of the jewels: the plane is the plane of the Brahmakāyika gods, not only the plane but also the surrounding area.

original: Pakatinibbattaṭṭhāneti purimakappesu purimakānaṃ nibbattaṭṭhāne. Etthāti “brahmavimāna”nti
analyzed: pakati nibbatta ṭhāne ti purima kappesu purimakānam nibbatta ṭhāne ettha ati brahma vimānan ti
translated: The place of rebirth: in the places of rebirth of those who were reborn in the previous world systems.🔽Here: in the plane of the Brahmakāyika gods, which is called “the Brahma-palace.”

original: vuttāya brahmakāyikabhūmiyā. Sāmaññavisesavasena cetaṃ ādhāradvayaṃ. Kathaṃ paṇītāya
analyzed: vuttāya brahmakāyika bhūmiyā sāmañña visesa vasena ādhāra dvayam katham paṇītāya
translated: This is a twofold basis according to the general and the specific.

original: dutiyajjhānabhūmiyā ṭhitānaṃ hīnāya paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyā upapatti hotīti āha “atha🔽sattāna”ntiādi, nikantivasena paṭhamajjhānaṃ bhāvetvāti vuttaṃ hoti, pakatiyā sabhāvena
analyzed: dutiya jhāna bhūmiyā ṭhitānam hīnāya paṭhama jhāna bhūmiyā upapatti hoti iti āha atha
translated: How is it that those who are established in the excellent second jhāna plane are reborn in the inferior first jhāna plane?🔽Therefore it is said: “Then, with the disappearance of the second jhāna, etc.”🔽The meaning is: after developing the second jhāna by means of attachment.

original: nikanti taṇhā uppajjatīti sambandho. Vasitaṭṭhāneti vutthapubbaṭṭhāne. Tato otarantīti
analyzed: nikanti taṇhā uppajjati iti sambandhaḥ vasita ṭṭhāne ti vuttha pubba ṭṭhāne tatas otaranti iti
translated: The connection is: the natural, innate craving arises.🔽The place of residence: the place of residence that has been previously occupied.

original: upapattivasena dutiyajjhānabhūmito paṭhamajjhānabhūmiṃ apasakkanti, gacchantīti attho.
analyzed: upapatti vasena dutiya jhāna bhūmitaḥ paṭhama jhāna bhūmim apasakkanti gacchanti iti attho
translated: From there they descend: they go down from the second jhāna plane to the first jhāna plane by way of rebirth. The meaning is: they go.

original: Appāyuketi yaṃ uḷārapuññakammaṃ kataṃ, tassa upajjanārahavipākapabandhato appaparimāṇāyuke.
analyzed: appa āyukā iti yam uḷāra puñña kammam katam tassa upajjana araha vipāka pabandhataḥ appa parimāṇa āyuke
translated: ‘Short-lived’: they have a short span of life because the continuity of the result of the meritorious deeds they have done is slight.🔽‘In that divine world’: in that divine world, or the expression ‘in that divine world’ is a locative of support.

original: Tassa devalokassāti tasmiṃ devaloke, nissayavasena vā sambandhaniddeso. Āyuppamāṇenevāti
analyzed: tassa deva lokassa ati tasmin deva loke nissaya vasena vā sambandha niddesaḥ āyu pamāṇena iva āti
translated: ‘By the measure of their life-span’:🔽by the measure of their maximum life-span. ‘Limited’: small.

original: paramāyuppamāṇeneva. Parittanti appakaṃ. Antarāva cavantīti rājakoṭṭhāgāre pakkhittataṇḍulanāḷi
analyzed: parama āyu ppamāṇena iva parittanti appakam antarā ava cavanti iti rājakoṭṭhāgāre pakkhitta taṇḍula nāḷi
translated: ‘They die in the middle’: like rice in a granary that has been eaten by weevils from within,

original: viya puññakkhayā hutvā sakakammappamāṇena tassa devalokassa paramāyuantarā eva cavanti.
analyzed: viya puñña kkhayāḥ hutvā saka kamma ppamāṇena tassa deva lokassa parama āyu antarāḥ eva cavanti
translated: they die in the middle of the maximum life-span of that divine world through the exhaustion of their merit.

original: Kiṃ panetaṃ paramāyu nāma, kathaṃ vā taṃ paricchinnappamāṇanti? Vuccate – yo tesaṃ🔽tesaṃ sattānaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ bhavavisese vipākappabandhassa ṭhitikālaniyamo purimasiddhabhavapatthanūpanissayavasena
analyzed: kim pana itam parama āyu nāma katham vā tat paricchinna ppamāṇam ti vuccate yaḥ tesam  tesam sattānam tasmin tasmin bhava visese vipāka ppabandhassa ṭhiti kāla niyamo purima siddha bhava patthanūpa nissaya vasena
translated: ‘But what is this “maximum life-span,” and how is it determined?’🔽It is said: the maximum life-span is the fixed period of time for the continuity of the result of the kamma of a particular kind in a particular plane of existence.🔽It is determined by the aspiration for a particular kind of existence made in the past, and by the support of the kamma that is the cause of that existence.

original: sarīrāvayavavaṇṇasaṇṭhānappamāṇādivisesā viya taṃtaṃgatinikāyādīsu yebhuyyena niyataparicchedo
analyzed: sarīra avayava vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ppamāṇa ādi visesāḥ viya taṃ taṃ gati nikāya ādīsu yebhuyyena niyata paricchedaḥ
translated: It is determined in the various planes of existence, just as the size, color, shape, etc., of the various parts of the body are determined by the kamma of the individual.

original: hoti, gabbhaseyyakakāmāvacaradevarūpāvacarasattānaṃ sukkasoṇitādiutubhojanādiutuādipaccayuppannapaccayūpatthambhito
analyzed: hoti gabbhaseyyaka kāmāvacara devarūpāvacara sattānam sukka soṇita ādi utu bhojana ādi utu ādi paccaya uppanna paccaya upatthambhito
translated: and for beings in the womb, in the sensual-desire and fine-material-sphere heavens, and in the hells, it is due to the nutriment consisting of physical nutriment, etc., and the temperature of the season, etc., and the nutriment consisting of contact, etc., and the temperature of the season, etc., and the nutriment consisting of consciousness, etc., and the temperature of the season, etc., respectively.

original: ca, so āyuhetukattā kāraṇūpacārena āyu, ukkaṃsaparicchedavasena paramāyūti ca vuccati.
analyzed: ca saḥ āyu hetuka ttā kāraṇa upacārena āyu ukkaṃsa pariccheda vasena ca vuccati
translated: It is called “life” because it is the cause of life, and it is called “the maximum life span” because it is the limit of the duration of life.

original: Yathāsakaṃ khaṇamattāvaṭṭhāyīnampi hi attanā sahajātānaṃ rūpārūpadhammānaṃ ṭhapanākāravuttitāya
analyzed: yathāsakam khaṇa matta avaṭṭhāyīnam pi hi attanā sahajātānam rūpa arūpa dhammānam ṭhapana ākāra vutti tāya
translated: For although the material and immaterial phenomena that are conascent with it last only for a moment,

original: pavattakāni rūpārūpajīvitindriyāni na kevalaṃ nesaṃ khaṇaṭṭhitiyā eva kāraṇabhāvena
analyzed: pavattakāni rūpa arūpa jīvita indriyāni na kevalam khaṇa ṭṭhitiyāḥ eva kāraṇa bhāvena
translated: the material and immaterial faculties of life are not only the cause for their duration for that moment,

original: anupālakāni, atha kho yāva bhaṅgupacchedā [bhavaṅgupacchedā ] anupabandhassa avicchedahetubhāvenāpi.
analyzed: anupālakāni atha kho yāva bhaṅgu upacchedāḥ bhavaṅgu upacchedāḥ an upabandhassa a viccheda hetu bhāvena api
translated: but also the cause for the non-interruption of the continuity until the moment of death.

original: Tasmā cesa āyuhetukoyeva, taṃ pana devānaṃ, nerayikānañca yebhuyyena niyataparicchedaṃ,
analyzed: tasmā ca isaḥ tam pana devānam nerayikānam ca yebhuyyena niyata paricchedam
translated: Therefore it is called “life” because it is the cause of life. But for the gods and hell beings it is generally limited,

original: uttarakurukānaṃ pana ekantaniyataparicchedameva. Avasiṭṭhamanussapetatiracchānagatānaṃ
analyzed: uttarakurukānam pana ekanta niyata paricchedam eva avasiṭṭha manussa peta tiracchāna gatānam
translated: while for the Uttarakurus it is absolutely limited. For the rest of human beings, animals, and ghosts,

original: pana ciraṭṭhitisaṃvattanikakammabahule kāle taṃkammasahitasantānajanitasukkasoṇitapaccayānaṃ,
analyzed: pana cira ṭṭhiti saṃvattanika kamma bahule kāle tad kamma sahita santāna janita sukka soṇita paccayānam
translated: But in the case of those who have done much in the way of profitable action that leads to long lives, the duration of life is not definite because of the conditions consisting of the happiness and the blood produced in the course of the life-continuum generated by that profitable action,

original: tammūlakānañca candimasūriyasamavisamaparivattanādijanitautuāhārādisamavisamapaccayānaṃ🔽vasena cirācirakālatāya aniyataparicchedaṃ, tassa ca yathā purimasiddhabhavapatthanāvasena
analyzed: tad mūlakānam ca candima sūriya sama visama parivattana ādi janita otu āhāra ādi sama visama paccayānam  vasena cira acira kāla tāya aniyata paricchedam tassa ca yathā purima siddha bhava patthanā vasena
translated: and because of the conditions consisting of the temperature, nutriment, etc., that are favourable or unfavourable as a result of the sun and moon’s regular and irregular revolution, etc.,🔽and because the definition of the beginning is established by the aspiration for existence that is successful in accordance with the previous wish for a particular kind of existence,🔽and because the definition of the end is established by the aspiration for existence that occurs in dependence on the view and on report, etc.,🔽and because the measure of the duration of life is generally the same in the various kinds of rebirth-linking in the various kinds of becoming, generation, destiny, station of consciousness, and abode of beings,

analyzed: vattemi iti vasa vattī aham sadda yogataḥ hi sabbattha amha yogena vacana atthaḥ satta bhājana bhūtassa
translated: the meaning of the word “lord” is understood by the absence of the word “I.”🔽The connection is this: he is the creator of the world which is the vessel of the seven.

original: lokassa nimmātā cāti sambandho. “Pathavī”tiādi cettha bhājanalokavasena adhippāyakathanaṃ.
analyzed: lokassa nimmātā ca ati sambandho pathavī itiādi ca ittha bhājana loka vasena adhippāya kathanam
translated: “Earth,” etc., is said here with reference to the world of the vessel.

original: Sajitāti racitā, vibhajitā vā, tenāha “tvaṃ khattiyo nāmā”tiādi. Ciṇṇavasitāyāti
analyzed: sajitā ati racitā vibhajitā vā tena āha tvam khattiyaḥ nāma atiādi ciṇṇavasitāya iti
translated: Sajitā means made or divided up. Hence he said: “You are called a Khattiya” and so on. Ciṇṇavasitāyāti means having lived the life.

original: samāciṇṇapañcavidhavasibhāvato. Tatthāti bhūtabhabyesu. Antovatthimhīti antogabbhāsaye.
analyzed: tattha ati bhūta bhabyesu antovatthimhi iti
translated: Sajitā means contrived, or divided up. Hence he said: “You are called a noble, etc.” Ciṇṇavasitāyāti means in virtue of having practised the five kinds of control . Tattha means among those that have been and those that will be. Antovatthimhīti means in the womb.

original: Paṭhamacittakkhaṇeti paṭisandhicittakkhaṇe. Dutiyatoti paṭhamabhavaṅgacittakkhaṇato.
analyzed: paṭhama citta kkhaṇa iti paṭisandhi citta kkhaṇe dutiyataḥ ti paṭhama bhavaṅga citta kkhaṇato
translated: Paṭhamacittakkhaṇe means at the moment of rebirth-linking. Dutiyato means from the moment of the first life-continuum consciousness.

original: Paṭhamairiyāpatheti yena paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhāti, tasmiṃ iriyāpathe. Iti atītavasena,🔽bhūta-saddassa vattamānavasena ca bhabya-saddassa attho dassito. Ṭīkāyaṃ pana bhabya-saddattho
analyzed: paṭhama eriyāpatha iti yena paṭisandhim gaṇhāti tasmin iriyāpathe iti atīta vasena  bhūta saddassa vattamāna vasena ca bhabya saddassa atthaḥ dassito ṭīkā ayam pana bhabya sadda attho
translated: Paṭhamairiyāpatheti means in the posture by which he takes rebirth-linking. Thus the word bhūta is interpreted in the sense of the past,🔽and the word bhavyā in the sense of the present. But in the subcommentary the word bhavyā is interpreted

original: anāgatavasenāpi vutto. Ahesunti hi bhūtā. Bhavanti, bhavissanti cāti bhabyā tabbānīyā
analyzed: anāgata vasena api vuttaḥ ahesunti hi bhūtāḥ bhavanti bhavissanti ca ati bhabyā tabbānīyā
translated: in the sense of the future as well. For bhūtā means “they have been,” and bhavyā means “they will be,”

original: viya ṇyapaccayassa kattaripi pavattanato.
analyzed: viya ṇya paccayassa kattari pi pavattanataḥ
translated: like tabbānīyā , because the gerund suffix ṇya is used also in the sense of the agent.

original: “Issaro kattā nimmātā”ti vatvāpi puna “mayā ime sattā nimmitā”ti vacanaṃ kimatthiyanti
analyzed: issaraḥ kattā nimmātā ati vatvā api puna mayā ime sattā nimmitā ati vacanam kimatthiyanti
translated: “The lord is the maker, the creator,” but why does he say again: “By me these beings are created”?

original: āha “idāni kāraṇavasenā”tiādi [kāraṇato (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)] kāraṇavasena sādhetukāmatāya
analyzed: āha idāni kāraṇa vasena ati ādi kāraṇataḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam kāraṇa vasena sādhu hetu kāma tāya
translated: He says “Now, as to ‘by way of cause’ ” and so on. What is meant is that he makes his assertion because he wants to prove it by way of cause.

original: paṭiññākaraṇatthanti vuttaṃ hoti. Nanu cesa brahmā anavaṭṭhitadassanattā puthujjanassa
analyzed: paṭiññā karaṇa attham ti vuttam hoti nanu ca isa brahmā anavaṭṭhita dassana ttā puthujjanassa
translated: But surely this Brahmā, because of his not seeing the round of rebirths,

original: purimatarajātiparicitampi kammassakatāñāṇaṃ vissajjetvā vikubbaniddhivasena cittuppādamattapaṭibaddhena
analyzed: purimatara jāti paricitam pi kammassaka tā ñāṇam vissajjetvā vikubba niddhi vasena cittuppāda matta paṭibaddhena
translated: after giving up the knowledge of the ownership of kamma that he had acquired in his previous birth as a human being,

original: sattanimmānena vipallaṭṭho “mayā ime sattā nimmitā”tiādinā issarakuttadassanaṃ pakkhandamāno
analyzed: satta nimmānena vipallaṭṭhaḥ mayā ime sattāḥ nimmitāḥ ti ādinā issara kutta dassanam pakkhandamāno
translated: and after being misled by the mere arising of the thought of creating beings by his psychic power,

original: abhinivisanavasena patiṭṭhito, na pana patiṭṭhāpanavasena. Atha kasmā kāraṇavasena🔽sādhetukāmo paṭiññaṃ karotīti vuttanti? Na cevaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tesampi hi “evaṃ hotī”tiādinā
analyzed: abhinivisana vasena patiṭṭhitaḥ na pana patiṭṭhāpana vasena atha kasmā kāraṇa vasena  sādhetu kāmaḥ paṭiññam karoti iti vuttan ti na ca ivam daṭṭhabbam tesam pi hi evam hoti itiādinā
translated: he has fallen into the view of a creator and has settled down to it by way of misapprehension, not by way of establishing it.🔽But why is it said that he makes his assertion because he wants to prove it by way of cause?🔽It should not be so regarded. For it is said later on that “it occurs to him” and so on,

original: pacchā uppajjantānampi tathāabhinivesassa vakkhamānattā paresaṃ patiṭṭhāpanakkameneva
analyzed: pacchā uppajjantānam pi tathā abhinivesassa vakkhamāna ttā paresam patiṭṭhāpana kkamena iva
translated: and that “he settles down to it by way of misapprehension” .

original: tassa so abhiniveso jāto, na tu abhinivisanamattena, tasmā evaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tassa saḥ abhinivesaḥ jātaḥ na tu abhinivisana mattena tasmai evam vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and his insistence on it was born, not merely his insistence. That is why it is said in this way.

original: Tenevāha “taṃ kissa hetū”tiādi. Pāḷiyaṃ manaso paṇidhīti manaso patthanā, tathā cittuppattimattamevāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tena iva āha tam kissa hetu utiādi pāḷiyam manasaḥ paṇidhi iti manaso patthanā tathā citta uppattimattam eva ati vuttam hoti
translated: That is why he said, “And why? ” and so on. In the text, “a wish of the mind” is a desire of the mind. So it is said that it is merely the occurrence of a thought.

original: Itthabhāvanti idappakārabhāvaṃ. Yasmā pana so pakāro brahmattabhāvoyevidhādhippeto,
analyzed: itthabhāvanti idappakāra bhāvam yasmā pana saḥ pakāraḥ brahmatta bhāvaḥ yevidha adhippeto
translated: “The state of being a woman” is the state of being of this kind. But since this kind is intended as the state of being a Brahmā,

original: tasmā “brahmabhāva”nti vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ pakāro itthaṃ, tassa bhāvo itthattanti hi nibbacanaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā brahma bhāvanti vuttam ayam pakāraḥ ittham tassa bhāvaḥ itthattam ti hi nibbacanam
translated: it is said “the state of being a Brahmā.” The derivation is as follows: itthaṃ ayaṃ pakāro, tassa bhāvo itthattanti.

original: Kevalanti kammassakatāñāṇena asammissaṃ suddhaṃ. Maññanāmattenevāti diṭṭhimaññanāmatteneva,
analyzed: kevalanti kammassaka tā ñāṇena asammissam suddham maññanā mattena iva ati diṭṭhi maññanā mattena iva
translated: “Pure” : unmixed with the knowledge of the possibility of making it happen by one’s own action, it is pure. “Merely by the act of conceiving” : merely by the conceiving of views.

original: na adhimānavasena. Vaṅkachiddena vaṅkaāṇī viya onamitvā vaṅkaladdhikena vaṅkaladdhikā
analyzed: na adhimāna vasena vaṅka chiddena vaṅka āṇī viyas onamitvā vaṅka laddhikena vaṅka laddhikā
translated: not by the conceiving of conceit. Like a crooked arrow shot by a crooked archer,

original: onamitvā tasseva brahmuno pādamūlaṃ gacchanti, taṃpakkhakā bhavantīti attho. Nanu
analyzed: onamitvā tassa iva brahmunaḥ pāda mūlam gacchanti taṃpakkhakāḥ bhavanti iti atthaḥ nanu
translated: they go to the foot of that Brahmā’s footstool, they are on his side, is the meaning. But

original: ca devānaṃ upapattisamanantaraṃ “imāya nāma gatiyā cavitvā iminā nāma kammunā idhūpapannā”ti
analyzed: ca devānam upapatti samanantaram imāya nāma gatiyā cavitvā iminā nāma kammunā idhu upapannā ati
translated: and immediately after their rebirth among the gods they review thus, ‘Having passed away from that destination, I have reappeared here through this kind of kamma,’

original: paccavekkhaṇā hoti, atha kasmā tesaṃ evaṃ maññanā siyāti? Purimajātīsu kammassakatāñāṇe
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇā hoti atha kasmā tesam evam maññanā siyāti purima jātīsu kammassaka tā ñāṇe
translated: why should they have such a conceiving? It is only those whose habitual tendency is well established in the knowledge of the ownership of kamma in previous births

original: sammadeva niviṭṭhajjhāsayānameva tathāpaccavekkhaṇāya pavattito. Tādisānameva hi🔽tathāpaccavekkhaṇā sambhavati, sā ca kho yebhuyyavasena, ime pana purimāsupi jātīsu
analyzed: sammat eva niviṭṭha jjhāsa yānam eva tathā paccavekkhaṇāya pavattitaḥ tādisānam eva hi  tathā paccavekkhaṇā sambhavati sā ca kho yebhuyya vasena ime pana purimāsu pi jātīsu
translated: that the reviewing occurs in that way. For such a reviewing is possible only for those

original: issarakuttadiṭṭhivasena nibaddhābhinivesā evameva maññamānā ahesunti. Tathā hi pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: issara kutta diṭṭhi vasena nibaddha abhinivesāḥ evam eva maññamānāḥ ahesunti tathā hi pāḷiyam
translated: who are like that. And that is so only in the majority of cases. But these beings, who in their previous births were obsessed with the view that the world is created by an Overlord, etc., were conceiving even then in this way. For this is said in the texts:

original: vuttaṃ “iminā maya”ntiādi.🔽43. Īsati abhibhavatīti īso, mahanto īso maheso, suppatiṭṭhitamahesatāya parehi “maheso”
analyzed: vuttam iminā maya ntiādi  īsati abhibhavati iti īsaḥ mahantaḥ īsaḥ mahesaḥ su patiṭṭhita mahesatāya parehi mahesaḥ
translated: ‘By this I am this’ , etc.

original: iti akkhāyatīti mahesakkho, mahesakkhānaṃ atisayena mahesakkhoti mahesakkhataroti
analyzed: iti akkhāyati iti mahesakkhaḥ mahesakkhānam atisayena mahesakkhaḥ iti mahesakkhataraḥ ti
translated: He is a lord because he rules , and a great lord because he is a lord in a great way. He is called ‘the great lord’ because his lordship is well established. He is a great lordly person because he is a great lord. He is a greater lordly person because he is a great lordly person in a pre-eminent way.

original: vacanattho. So pana mahesakkhatarabhāvo ādhipateyyaparivārasampattiyā kāraṇabhūtāya
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ saḥ pana mahesakkhatara bhāvaḥ ādhipateyya parivāra sampattiyā kāraṇa bhūtāya
translated: The meaning of the words is this. But that state of being a great and powerful king is known to be due to the possession of the fortune of sovereignty and retinue, which is the cause.

original: viññāyatīti vuttaṃ “issariyaparivāravasena mahāyasataro”ti.
analyzed: viññāyati iti vuttam issariya parivāra vasena
translated: So it is said, “As a great and powerful king by reason of sovereignty and retinue.”

original: 44. Kiṃ panetaṃ kāraṇanti anuyogenāha “so tato”tiādi, tena “itthattaṃ āgacchatī”ti
analyzed: kim pana itam kāraṇam iti anuyogena āha saḥ tatas itiādi tena itthattam āgacchati iti
translated: But what is this cause? The question is answered by the words “From there he comes to this state of existence.”🔽So it is said, “He comes to this state of existence.”

original: vuttaṃ idhāgamanameva kāraṇanti dasseti. Idheva āgacchatīti imasmiṃ manussaloke eva
analyzed: vuttam idha āgamanam eva kāraṇanti dasseti idha iva āgacchati iti imasmin manussa loke eva
translated: He comes to this state of existence, to this human world, by rebirth-linking.

original: paṭisandhivasena āgacchati. Etanti “ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ bhikkhave, vijjatī”ti vacanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena āgacchati etat ti ṭhānam kho pana itam bhikkhave vijjati iti vacanam
translated: The words “It is possible” refer to the words “It is possible, bhikkhus, that a certain being.”

original: Pāḷiyaṃ yaṃ aññataro sattoti ettha yanti nipātamattaṃ, kāraṇatthe vā esa nipāto,
analyzed: pāḷiyam yam aññataraḥ satto ti ettha yanti nipāta mattam kāraṇa tthe vā esa nipāto
translated: In the text “a certain being” is merely a particle, or it is a demonstrative pronoun in the sense of cause,

original: hetumhi vā paccattaniddeso, yena ṭhānenāti attho, kiriyāparāmasanaṃ vā etaṃ. “Itthattaṃ
analyzed: hetumhi vā paccatta niddesaḥ yena ṭhānena ati attho kiriyā parāmasanam vā etam itthattam
translated: or it is a locative in the sense of ground, meaning “by what ground,” or it is a reference to a verbal root,

original: āgacchatī”ti ettha yadetaṃ itthattassa āgamanasaṅkhātaṃ ṭhānaṃ, tadetaṃ vijjatīti
analyzed: āgacchati iti ettha yat etam itthattassa āgamana saṅkhātam ṭhānam tat etam vijjati iti
translated: “He comes to this state of existence.” Here the state of existence is the ground for coming to this state of existence.🔽That state of existence is possible.

original: attho. Esa na so pabbajati, cetosamādhiṃ phusati, pubbenivāsaṃ anussatīti etesupi🔽padesu. “Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto”ti hi imāni padāni🔽“pabbajatī”tiādīhipi padehi paccekaṃ yojetabbāni. analyzed: atthaḥ esa na so pabbajati cetosamādhim phusati pubbenivāsam anussati iti etesu pi  padesu ṭhānam kho pana itam bhikkhave vijjati yam aññataraḥ satto ti hi imāni padāni  pabbajati iti ādīhi pi padehi paccekam yojetabbāni na gacchati iti agāram geham agārassa  hitam āgāriyam kasi gorakkha ādi kammam tam ettha natthi iti anāgāriyam pabbajjā tena āha  agārasma atiādi pasaddena visiṭṭhaḥ vaja saddaḥ upasaṅkamanā iti vuttam upagacchati iti  paranti pacchā atisayam vā aññam atthaḥ na sarati iti vuttā iya iva

The meaning of “he does not remember” is stated🔽by the words “he does not recollect.”
