original: idha sāmatthiyattho. Sadābhāvatoti sabbadā vijjamānattā. Jarāvasenāpīti ettha pi-saddena
analyzed: idha sāmatthiya tthaḥ sadābhāvato ti sabbadā vijjamāna ttā jarā vasena api iti ettha pi saddena
translated: Here the meaning of ‘is able’ is intended. ‘Because of its ever-presentness’: because it is always found. ‘Even by ageing’: the word ‘even’

original: maraṇavasenāpīti sampiṇḍeti.🔽45. Khiḍḍāpadosinoti kattuvasena padasiddhi, khiḍḍāpadosikāti pana sakatthavuttivasena,
analyzed: maraṇa vasena api iti sampiṇḍa iti  khiḍḍāpadosino ti kattu vasena khiḍḍāpadosikā ati pana sa kattha vutti vasena
translated: combines this with ‘by death’.🔽‘Given to play and jest’: the word is formed by the verbal noun method, but ‘given to play and jest’ is the meaning.

original: saddamanapekkhitvā pana atthameva dassetuṃ “khiḍḍāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Khiḍḍāpadosakā”ti
analyzed: saddam an apekkhitvā pana attham eva dassetum khiḍḍāya itiādi vuttam khiḍḍa apadosakā ti
translated: But in order to show the meaning without regard to the sound, ‘in play’ is said.🔽Or it may be said ‘given to play and jest’ and it is said thus with the addition of the i-sign.

original: vā vattabbe i-kārāgamavasena evaṃ vuttaṃ. Padussanaṃ vā padoso, khiḍḍāya padoso khiḍḍāpadoso,
analyzed: vā vattabbe ikāra āgama vasena evam vuttam padussanam vā padosaḥ khiḍḍāya padosaḥ khiḍḍāpadoso
translated: Or ‘play and jest’ is ‘play and jesting’.🔽They have that, thus they are ‘given to play and jest’.

original: so etesanti khiḍḍāpadosikā. “Padūsikātipi pāḷiṃ likhantī”ti aññanikāyikānaṃ pamādalekhataṃ
analyzed: pāḷim likhanti iti añña nikāyikānam
translated: ‘Some write the text as “padūsika” ’: he shows the careless writing of those of other schools.

original: dasseti. Mahāvihāravāsīnikāyikānañhi vācanāmaggavasena ayaṃ saṃvaṇṇanā pavattā. Apica
analyzed: dasseti mahāvihāravāsī nikāyikānam hi vācanā magga vasena ayam saṃvaṇṇanā pavattā apica
translated: For this commentary proceeds by the method of the recitation of those who live in the Mahāvihāra. Moreover,

original: tena potthakāruḷhakāle pamādalekhaṃ dasseti. Tampi hi padatthasodhanāya aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: tena potthaka āruḷha kāle pamāda lekham dasseti tam pi hi padattha sodhanāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: he shows careless writing at the time of copying the book. For this commentary🔽is composed for the purpose of establishing the meaning of the words.

original: sodhitaniyāmeneva gahetabbaṃ, tenāha “sā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthī”ti. Velaṃ atikkantaṃ🔽ativelaṃ, taṃ. Bhāvanapuṃsakañcetaṃ, tenāha “aticira”nti, āhārūpabhogakālaṃ atikkamitvāti
analyzed: sodhita niyāmena iva gahetabbam tena āha sā aṭṭhakathā ayam na atthi iti velam atikkantam  ativelam tam tena āha aticiranti āhāra upabhoga kālam atikkamitvā ati
translated: It should be taken only by the method of the commentary, which says, “It is not in the commentary.”🔽Over the time:🔽over the time for the development of the meditation subject. The word is neuter.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ratidhamma-saddo hassakhiḍḍā-saddehi paccekaṃ yojetabbo “hassakhiḍḍāsu
analyzed: vuttam hoti rati dhamma saddaḥ hassa khiḍḍā saddehi paccekam yojetabbaḥ hassa khiḍḍāsu
translated: The words “delight” and “fun” should be construed separately with the words “nature of delight” and “nature of fun.”

original: ratidhammo ramaṇasabhāvo”ti. Hasanaṃ hasso, keḷihasso. Kheḍanaṃ kīḷanaṃ khiḍḍā, kāyikavācasikakīḷā.
analyzed: rati dhammo ramaṇa sabhāvo ti hasanam hasso keḷi hasso kheḍanam kīḷanam khiḍḍā kāyika vācasika kīḷā
translated: Laughing is fun. Playing is fun.

original: Anuyogavasena taṃsamāpannāti dassento āha “hassaratidhammañcevā”tiādi. Kīḷā yesaṃ
analyzed: anuyoga vasena tat samāpannā iti dassentaḥ āha kīḷā yesam
translated: Showing that he has entered upon that by undertaking it, he said, “If he should enter upon and persist in delight and fun … ”🔽Those who have fun are merrymakers. Their fun is merrymaking.

original: te keḷino, tesaṃ hasso tathā. Kīḷāhassapayogena uppajjanakasukhañcettha keḷihassasukhaṃ.
analyzed: te keḷino tesam hasso tathā kīḷā hassa payogena uppajjanaka sukham ca ittha keḷi hassa sukham
translated: The pleasure that arises through the use of merrymaking and fun is the pleasure of merrymaking and fun.

original: Tadavasiṭṭhakīḷāpayogena uppajjanakaṃ kāyikavācasikakīḷāsukhaṃ.
analyzed: tad avasiṭṭha kīḍā apayogena uppad janakam kāyika vācasika kīḷā sukham
translated: The pleasure of playing is the pleasure of bodily and verbal play that arises through the use of play that remains after the use of merrymaking and fun.

original: “Te kirā”tiādi vitthāradassanaṃ. Kira-saddo hettha vitthārajotakoyeva, na tu anussavanāruciyādijotako
analyzed: te kira ati ādi vitthāra dassanam kira saddo ha ittha vitthāra jotakaḥ yā iva na tu anussavana aruci ādi jotakaḥ
translated: The words “they say” are a way of showing that the following is a detailed explanation. The word “they” indicates only a detailed explanation, not a report of what is well known or a lack of enthusiasm.

original: tathāyeva pāḷiyaṃ, aṭṭhakathāsu ca vuttattā. Sirivibhavenāti sarīrasobhaggādisiriyā,🔽parivārādisampattiyā ca. Nakkhattanti chaṇaṃ. Yebhuyyena hi nakkhattayogena katattā
analyzed: tathāyā iva pāḷiyam aṭṭhakathāsu ca vutta ttā siri vibhavena ati sarīra sobhagga ādi siriyā  parivāra ādi sampattiyā ca yebhuyyena hi nakkhatta yogena kata ttā
translated: and so it is said in the texts and in the commentaries. ‘With the glory of the stars’: with the glory of the beauty of the body, etc.,🔽and with the excellence of the retinue, etc. ‘Stars’: the constellations. For it is made

original: tathāyogo vā hotu, mā vā, nakkhattamicceva vuccati. Āhāranti ettha ko devānamāhāro,🔽kā ca tesamāhāravelāti? Sabbesampi kāmāvacaradevānaṃ sudhāhāro. Dvādasapāpadhammavigghātena
analyzed: tathā yogaḥ vā hotu mā vā nakkhattam icca iva vuccati ettha kaḥ devānam āhāro  kā ca tesam āhāra velā ati sabbesam pi kāmāvacara devānam sudhā āhāraḥ dvādasa pāpa dhamma vigghātena
translated: on the basis of the conjunction of the stars. Whether there is such a conjunction or not, it is called ‘the stars’. ‘What is the food of the gods here,🔽and what is their food and drink?’ The food of all the gods of the sense sphere is nectar.

original: hi sukhassa dhāraṇato devānaṃ bhojanaṃ “sudhā”ti vuccati. Sā pana setā saṅkhūpamā
analyzed: hi sukhassa dhāraṇataḥ devānam bhojanam sudhā iti vuccati sā pana sā itā saṅkhu upamā
translated: For the food of the gods is called ‘nectar’ because it sustains bliss by eliminating the twelve imperfections.🔽It is white, shaped like a water lily,

original: atulyadassanā suci sugandhā piyarūpā. Yaṃ sandhāya sudhābhojanajātake vuttaṃ –
analyzed: atulya dassanā suci sugandhā piya rūpā yam sandhāya sudhā bhojana jātake vuttam
translated: incomparable to see, pure, fragrant, and beautiful. It is with reference to this that it is said in the Sudhābhojana Jātaka:

original: “Saṅkhūpamaṃ seta’matulyadassanaṃ,
analyzed: saṅkhu upamam setam atulya dassanam
translated: ‘Shaped like a water lily, white, incomparable to see,

original: Suciṃ sugandhaṃ piyarūpa’mabbhutaṃ;
analyzed: sucim sugandham piya rūpam abbhutam
translated: Pure, fragrant, beautiful, and wonderful,

original: Adiṭṭhapubbaṃ mama jātu cakkhubhi,
analyzed: a diṭṭha pubbam mama jātu cakkhubhi
translated: Never before seen by my eyes—

original: Kā devatā pāṇisu kiṃ sudho’dahī”ti. ;
analyzed: kā devatā pāṇisu kim
translated: What god has placed nectar in my hands?’

original: “Bhuttā ca sā dvādasahanti pāpake,
analyzed: bhuttā ca sā dvādasa hanti pāpake
translated: ‘Having eaten it, the twelve imperfections are removed,

original: Khuddaṃ pipāsaṃ aratiṃ daraklamaṃ;
analyzed: khuddam pipāsam aratim dara klamam
translated: And hunger, thirst, discontent, and weariness,

original: Kodhūpanāhañca vivādapesuṇaṃ,
analyzed: kodhūpanāham ca vivāda pesuṇam
translated: Anger, resentment, and disputes, and cold and heat,

original: Sītuṇha tandiñca rasuttamaṃ ida”nti ca. ;🔽Sā ca heṭṭhimehi heṭṭhimehi uparimānaṃ uparimānaṃ paṇītatamā hoti, taṃ yathāsakaṃ
analyzed: sītuṇha tandiñca ras uttamam idanti ca  sā ca heṭṭhimehi heṭṭhimehi uparimānam uparimānam paṇītatamā hoti tam yathāsakam
translated: And sluggishness, this is the best of tastes.

original: parimitadivasavasena divase divase bhuñjanti. Keci pana vadanti “biḷārapadappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: parimita divasa vasena divase divase bhuñjanti keci pana vadanti biḷāra pada ppamāṇam
translated: And that is more and more refined in each lower one than in each higher one. They eat it day by day according to the number of days they have left to live. But some say that they eat a portion of ambrosia the size of a cat’s paw.

original: sudhāhāraṃ te bhuñjanti, so jivhāya ṭhapitamatto yāva kesagganakhaggā kāyaṃ pharati,
analyzed: sudhā āhāram te bhuñjanti saḥ jivhāya ṭhapita mattaḥ yāva kesagga nakhaggā kāyam pharati
translated: When it is placed on the tongue it spreads over the body as far as the tips of the hair and nails.

original: yathāsakaṃ gaṇitadivasavasena satta divase yāpanasamattho hotī”ti. Kecivāde panettha
analyzed: yathāsakam gaṇita divasa vasena satta divase yāpana samatthaḥ hoti iti keci vāde pana ittha
translated: It is sufficient to keep them alive for seven days according to the number of days they have left to live.

original: biḷārapada-saddo suvaṇṇasaṅkhātassa saṅkhyāvisesassa vācako. Pamāṇato pana udumbaraphalappamāṇaṃ,
analyzed: biḷārapada saddo suvaṇṇa saṅkhātassa saṅkhyā visesassa vācakaḥ pamāṇato pana udumbara phala ppamāṇam
translated: But in this statement the word “cat’s paw” is a designation for a particular number called “gold.” As to size, it is the size of a breadfruit seed.

original: yaṃ pāṇitalaṃ kabaḷaggahantipi vuccati. Vuttañhi madhukose –
analyzed: yam pāṇi talam vuccati vuttam hi madhu kose
translated: It is called a “handful” . For this is said in the Honeyball:

original: “Pāṇirakkho picu cāpi, suvaṇṇakamudumbaraṃ;
analyzed: ca api suvaṇṇakam udumbaram
translated: “The hand-protection, the spider, and the gold, the breadfruit,

original: Biḷārapadakaṃ pāṇi-talaṃ taṃ kabaḷaggaha”nti.
analyzed: biḷārapadakam pāṇi talam tam
translated: The cat’s paw, the hand-palm: that is the handful.”

original: “Nirantaraṃ khādantāpi pivantāpī”ti idaṃ parikappanāvasena vuttaṃ, na pana evaṃ niyamavasena
analyzed: nirantaram khādantā api pivantā api iti idam parikappanā vasena vuttam na pana evam niyama vasena
translated: “Even if they were to eat and drink uninterruptedly” is said by way of supposition, not by way of restriction.

original: tathā khādanapivanānamaniyamabhāvato. Kammajatejassa balavabhāvo uḷārapuññanibbattattā,
analyzed: tathā khādana pivanānam aniyama bhāvataḥ kamma ja tejassa balava bhāvaḥ uḷāra puñña nibbatta ttā
translated: Because there is no restriction in the way of eating and drinking in this way. The strength of the fire of kamma is due to the production of abundant merit,

original: uḷāragarusiniddhasudhāhārajīraṇato ca. Karajakāyassa mandabhāvo pana sukhumālabhāvato.
analyzed: ca karaja kāyassa manda bhāvaḥ pana sukhu māla bhāvato
translated: and to the digestion of the abundant heavy and solid nectar food. The weakness of the physical body, however, is due to its subtlety.

original: Teneva hi bhagavā indasālaguhāyaṃ pakatipathaviyaṃ patiātuṃ asakkontaṃ sakkaṃ devarājānaṃ🔽“oḷārikaṃ kāyaṃ adhiṭṭhehī”ti avoca. Manussānaṃ pana kammajatejassa mandabhāvo, karajakāyassa🔽balavabhāvo ca vuttaviparītena veditabbo. Karajakāyoti ettha ko vuccati sarīraṃ,
analyzed: tena iva hi bhagavā indasālaguhāyam pakatipathaviyam a sakkontam sakkam devarājānam  oḷārikam kāyam adhiṭṭhehi iti avoca manussānam pana kamma ja tejassa manda bhāvaḥ karaja kāyassa  balava bhāvo ca vutta viparītena veditabbo karaja kāyaḥ ti ettha kaḥ vuccati sarīram
translated: Therefore, the Blessed One said to Sakka, King of the Gods, who was unable to step on the earth in the Indasāla Cave,🔽“Make your body gross.” The weakness of the fire of kamma and the strength of the physical body of human beings should be understood in the opposite way.🔽In the phrase “physical body” , what is a body?

original: tattha pavatto. Rajo karajo, kiṃ taṃ? Sukkasoṇitaṃ. Tañhi “rāgo rajo na ca pana reṇu
analyzed: tattha pavatto rajaḥ karajaḥ kim tam sukkasoṇitam tat hi rāgaḥ rajaḥ na ca pana reṇu
translated: It is that which is found in the body. Dust is body-dust. What is that? Semen and blood. For that is called “passion” , “dust” , and “body-dust” .

original: vuccatī”ti evaṃ vuttarāgarajaphalattā sarīravācakena ka-saddena visesetvā kāraṇavohārena
analyzed: vuccati iti evam sarīra vācakena ka saddena visesetvā kāraṇa vohārena
translated: is said” , thus, because of being the fruit of the passion of lust, the word “kā” is distinguished by the word “kāya” , and by the word “kāraṇa” ,🔽

original: “karajo”ti vuccati. Tena sukkasoṇitasaṅkhātena karajena sambhūto kāyo karajakāyoti
analyzed: karajaḥ iti vuccati tena sukka soṇita saṅkhātena karajena sambhūto kāyo karaja kāyo ti
translated: and so on. So it is called “made of bone” by a figurative use of the word “bone” to denote a cause, specifying it by the word “body” as the fruit of the passion for sensual desires stated thus, “The body is the fruit of passion for sensual desires.”

original: ācariyā. Tathā hi kāyo mātāpettikasambhavoti vutto. Mahāassapūrasuttantaṭīkāyaṃ pana🔽“karīyati gabbhāsaye khipīyatīti karo, sambhavo, karato jātoti karajo, mātāpettikasambhavoti
analyzed: ācariyā tathā hi kāyaḥ mātā pettika sambhavaḥ ti vuttaḥ mahāassapūrasuttanta ṭīkāyam pana  karīyati gabbha āsaye khipīyati iti karo sambhavo karataḥ jāto ti kara jaḥ mātā pettika sambhavo ti
translated: So the body that is originated by that bone called “dry blood” is called “made of bone,” say the teachers. For the body is said to be originated by mother and father. But in the commentary to the Mahāassapura Sutta it is said:

original: attho. Mātuādīnaṃ saṇṭhāpanavasena karato hatthato jātoti karajoti apare. Ubhayathāpi
analyzed: attho mātu ādīnam saṇṭhāpana vasena karataḥ hatthataḥ jāto ti kara jaḥ iti apare ubhayathā api
translated: “It is made (kiriyati) and thrown (khipiyati) in the womb, thus it is a maker (karo); it is origination (sambhavo). It is made of (jāto) what is made, thus it is made of bone (karajo); the meaning is that it is originated by mother and father. Others say that it is made of (jāto) what is made (hattha) by the shaping of mother and so on, thus it is made of bone (karajo). In both cases

original: karajakāyanti catusantatirūpamāhā”ti vuttaṃ. Karoti putte nibbattetīti karo, sukkasoṇitaṃ,
analyzed: catu santati rūpam āha ati vuttam karoti putte nibbatteti iti sukka soṇitam
translated: it is the four-fold-derived-material-form body that is called ‘made of bone.’ ”

original: tena jāto karajotipi vadanti. Tathā asambhūtopi ca devādīnaṃ kāyo tabbohārena “karajakāyo”ti
analyzed: tena jātaḥ karaja iti pi vadanti tathā asambhūtaḥ api ca deva ādīnam kāyo tad bohārena karaja kāyo ti
translated: And they say: “It makes (karotī) a child to be born, thus it is a maker (karo); it is dry blood. It is born of that, thus it is made of bone (karajo). And although it is not originated in this way, still the body of deities and so on is called ‘made of bone’ by that figurative use.

original: vuccati yathā “pūtikāyo, jarasiṅgālo”ti. Tesanti manussānaṃ. Acchayāgu nāma pasannā
analyzed: vuccati yathā pūti kāyaḥ jarasiṅgālaḥ ti tesanti manussānam acchayāgu nāma pasannā
translated: “The body is foul, the old jackal” is said. “Their” means the human beings. “Congee” is clear

original: akasaṭā yāgu. Vatthunti karajakāyaṃ. Ekaṃ āhāravelanti ekadivasamattaṃ, kesañci matena pana sattāhaṃ.
analyzed: ekam āhāra velanti eka divasa mattam kesañci matena pana satta aham
translated: rice-gruel. “Cloth” is the physical body. “One meal” means for one day, but for some it means for seven days.

original: Evaṃ anvayato byatirekato ca dassetvā upamāvasenapi tamāvikaronto “yathā nāmā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: evam anvayataḥ byatirekataḥ ca dassetvā upamā vasena api tam āvikarontaḥ yathā nāma ati ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown it by the method of agreement and difference, he said “Just as, etc.,” in order to reveal it by the method of example.

original: Tattapāsāṇeti accuṇhapāsāṇe. Rattasetapadumato avasiṭṭhaṃ uppalaṃ. Akathāyanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ.
analyzed: tatta pāsāṇa iti accuṇha pāsāṇe ratta seta padumataḥ avasiṭṭham uppalam akathāyanti mahā aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: “A heated stone” is a hot stone. “The remaining lotus” is the red and white lotus. “Not in the commentary” is not in the Mahā-aṭṭhakathā.

original: Avisesenāti “devāna”nti avisesena, devānaṃ kammajatejo balavā hoti, karajaṃ mandanti
analyzed: avisesena ati devānam ti avisesena devānam kamma ja tejaḥ balavā hoti kara jam mandanti
translated: “Without distinction” means without distinction as to “gods,” for the heat of kamma-born fire is strong in gods, and kamma-born fire is weak.

original: vā kammajatejakarajakāyānaṃ balavamandatāsaṅkhāta kāraṇasāmaññena. Tadetañhi kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: vā kamma ja tejaka rajaka āyānam balava manda tā saṅkhāta kāraṇa sāmaññena tat etat hi kāraṇam
translated: Or, by the similarity of the reason called the strength and weakness of the heat of kamma-born fire and kamma-born body,

original: sabbesampi devānaṃ samānameva, tasmā sabbepi devā gahetabbāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kabaḷīkārabhūtaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam pi devānam samānam eva tasmā sabbe api devāḥ gahetabbā iti vuttam hoti kabaḷīkāra bhūtam
translated: for this reason is the same for all gods. Therefore it is said that all gods should be taken. “The food that is eaten” is the food that is eaten.

original: sudhāhāraṃ upanissāya jīvantīti kabaḷīkārāhārūpajīvino. Kecīti abhayagirivāsino.🔽“Khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva hete khiḍḍāpadosikāti vuttā”ti ayaṃ pāṭho “teyeva cavantīti
analyzed: sudhā āhāram upanissāya jīvanti iti kabaḷīkāra āhāra upajīvino keci iti abhayagiri vāsino  khiḍḍāpadussana mattena iva ha ete khiḍḍāpadosikā ati vuttā ati ayam pāṭhaḥ te eva cavanti iti
translated: They live by means of nutriment consisting of the pleasure of being eaten, thus they are “eaten by morsels.” “Some” means the residents of the Abhayagiri Monastery.

original: veditabbā”ti etassānantare paṭhitabbo tadanusandhikattā. Ayañhetthānusandhi – yadi🔽sabbepi evaṃ karontā kāmāvacaradevā caveyyuṃ, atha kasmā “khiḍḍāpadosikā”ti nāmavisesena🔽bhagavatā vuttāti? Vicāraṇāya evamāhāti, etena imamatthaṃ dasseti “sabbepi devā evaṃ
analyzed: veditabbā ti etassa anantare paṭhitabbaḥ tad anusandhika ttā ayan ha itthā anusandhi yadi  sabbe pi evam karontā kāmāvacara devā caveyyuṃ atha kasmā khiḍḍāpadosikā ati nāma visesena  bhagavatā vuttā iti vicāraṇāya evam āha ati etena imam attham dasseti sabbe pi devāḥ evam
translated: The reading “They are called ‘those destroyed by pleasure’ because they are destroyed by pleasure” should be read after the passage “They are called ‘those destroyed by pleasure’ because they are destroyed by pleasure” because it is a continuation of it. The continuation is this:🔽if all gods were to die in this way, then why were they mentioned by the Blessed One by the specific name “those destroyed by pleasure”?

original: cavantāpi khiḍḍāya padussanasabhāvamattaṃ pati nāmavisesena tathā vuttā”ti. Yadeke🔽vadeyyuṃ “kecivādapatiṭṭhāpakoyaṃ pāṭho”ti, tadayuttameva iti-saddantarikattā, ante
analyzed: cavantā api khiḍḍāya padussana sabhāva mattam pati nāma visesena tathā vuttā iti yat eke  vadeyyum ante
translated: The answer is that he said it in this way after considering the matter thus: “Although all gods die in this way, they are called ‘those destroyed by pleasure’ by the specific name because they are destroyed by pleasure in the form of play.”🔽If some should say: “This reading is not established,” that is not correct, because the word iti is included, and because it is not found at the end.

original: ca tassa avijjamānattā. Atthikehi pana tassa kecivādasamavarodhanaṃ ante itisaddo yojetabboti.
analyzed: ca tassa a vijjamāna ttā atthikehi pana tassa ante iti saddo yojetabbo ti
translated: But those who desire it should add the word iti at the end to exclude the statement of some.

original: 47-48. Manopadosinoti kattuvasena padasiddhi, manopadosikāti ca sakatthavuttivasena,🔽atthamattaṃ pana dassetuṃ “manenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Manopadosakā”ti vā vattabbe i-kārāgamavasena🔽evaṃ vuttaṃ. Manenāti issāpakatattā paduṭṭhena manasā. Aparo nayo – usūyanavasena
analyzed: manopadosinī iti kattu vasena manopadosikā ati ca sa kattha vutti vasena  attha mattam pana dassetum manena atiādi vuttam mana upadosakā iti vā vattabbe ikāra āgama vasena  evam vuttam manena ati issā pakata ttā paduṭṭhena manasā aparaḥ nayaḥ usūyana vasena
translated: The analysis of the words is by way of the verb “to hate” (padus-); the noun “hatred” (padosa) is formed by adding the nominal suffix -in to the past participle padusita.🔽To show the mere meaning, “by mind” is said. Or, it may be said that “hatred” is formed by the addition of the suffix -in to the past participle padusita, and that “hatred” is said to be “by mind” by the addition of the prefix manas-.🔽“By mind” means by a mind that is corrupted by envy. Another method:

original: manasā padoso manopadoso, vināsabhūto so etesamatthīti manopadosikāti. “Te aññamaññamhi
analyzed: manasā padosaḥ manas padosaḥ vināsa bhūto so etesam atthi iti manopadosikā ati te aññam aññamhi
translated: hatred by mind is manopadosa; they have that which is the cause of destruction, thus they are manopadosikā.

original: paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī”ti vacanato “ete
analyzed: paduṭṭha cittā kilanta kāyā kilanta cittā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti iti vacanataḥ ete
translated: “With their minds corrupted, their bodies and minds exhausted, those gods fall from that place.”

original: cātumahārājikā”ti āha. Manena padussanamatteneva hete manopadosikāti vuttā. “Tesu
analyzed: cātumahārājikā iti āha manena padussana mattena iva ha ete manopadosikā ati vuttā tesu
translated: Therefore, he says, “those Cātumahārājika gods.” They are called manopadosikā because they are corrupted by mind.🔽The elaboration beginning with “among them” is as follows.

original: kirā”tiādi vitthāro. Rathena vīthiṃ paṭipajjatīti upalakkhaṇamattaṃ aññehi aññatthāpi
analyzed: kirāti ādi vitthāraḥ rathena vīthim paṭipajjati iti upalakkhaṇa mattam aññehi aññattha api
translated: “He goes along the street in a chariot” is merely an illustration, because others go in other ways.

original: paṭipajjanasambhavato. Etanti attano sampattiṃ. Uddhumāto viyāti pītiyā karaṇabhūtāya
analyzed: paṭipajjana sambhavataḥ etat ti sampattim viyāti pītiyā karaṇa bhūtāya
translated: “That” refers to his own prosperity. “Like a bloated corpse” is by way of the joy that is the cause.

original: unnato viya. Bhijjamāno viyāti tāya bhijjanto viya, pītiyā vā kattubhūtāya bhañjito
analyzed: unnataḥ viya bhijjamānaḥ viyāti tāya bhijjantaḥ viya pītiyā vā kattu bhūtāya bhañjitaḥ
translated: Like a high-flown one. Like one being split: as if being split by that, or as if split by the joy which is the instrument of the splitting.

original: viya. Kuddhā nāma suvijānanā honti, tasmā kuddhabhāvamassa ñatvāti attho.🔽Akuddho rakkhatīti kuddhassa so kodho itarasmiṃ akujjhante anupādāno ceva ekavāramattaṃ
analyzed: viya kuddhāḥ nāma su vijānanāḥ honti tasmā kuddha bhāvam assa ñatvā ati attho  a kuddhaḥ rakkhati iti kuddhassa saḥ kodho itarasmin a kujjhante an upādānaḥ ca iva eka vāra mattam
translated: Those who are angry are easy to recognize, so the meaning is that he knows the state of his being angry.

original: uppattiyā anāsevano ca hutvā cāvetuṃ na sakkoti, udakantaṃ patvā aggi viya nibbāyati,🔽tasmā akuddho itaraṃ cavanato rakkhati. Ubhosu pana kuddhesu bhiyyo bhiyyo aññamaññamhi
analyzed: uppattiyāḥ anāsevano ca hutvā cāvetum na sakkoti udakantam patvā aggi viya nibbāyati  tasmai akuddhaḥ itaram cavanataḥ rakkhati ubhosu pana kuddhesu bhiyyas bhiyyas aññam aññamhi
translated: The unangry one protects: the anger of the angry one, when the other is not angry, is unable to kill him, being without a footing and not being nourished by the other’s anger, just as a fire goes out when it lacks fuel.

original: parivaḍḍhanavasena tikhiṇasamudācāro nissayadahanaraso kodho uppajjamāno hadayavatthuṃ
analyzed: parivaḍḍhana vasena tikhiṇa samudācāraḥ nissaya dahana rasaḥ kodhaḥ uppajjamānaḥ hadaya vatthum
translated: Therefore the unangry one protects the other from death. But when both are angry, anger arises in them with a more and more sharpened manifestation and with a more and more intense burning of the underlying tendency.

original: nidahanto accantasukhumālakarajakāyaṃ vināseti, tato sakalopi attabhāvo antaradhāyati,
analyzed: nidahantaḥ sakalaḥ api atta bhāvaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: When it arises, it destroys the heart-basis, which is extremely delicate, like a tender infant’s skin, and then the whole physical frame disappears.

original: tamatthaṃ dassetumāha “ubhosu panā”tiādi. Tathā cāha pāḷiyaṃ “te aññamaññamhi paduṭṭhacittā
analyzed: tam attham dassetum āha ubhosu pana atiādi tathā ca āha pāḷiyam te aññam aññamhi paduṭṭha cittā
translated: In order to illustrate this meaning, he said “But when both are angry” and so on. And in the text it is said: “They are hostile to each other in mind,

original: kilantakāyā kilantacittā te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī”ti. Ekassa kodho itarassa paccayo
analyzed: kilanta kāyā kilanta cittā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti iti ekassa kodho itarassa paccayo
translated: and their bodies and minds are exhausted, they fall from that place.”

original: hoti, tassapi kodho itarassa paccayo hotīti ettha kodhassa bhiyyo bhiyyo parivaḍḍhanāya🔽eva paccayabhāvo veditabbo, na cavanāya nissayadahanarasena attanoyeva kodhena hadayavatthuṃ
analyzed: hoti tassa api kodho itarassa paccayaḥ hoti iti ettha kodhassa bhiyyas bhiyyas parivaḍḍhanāya  eva paccaya bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ na cavanāya nissaya dahana rasena attanoyā iva kodhena hadaya vatthum
translated: The anger of one is a condition for the other’s anger, and the anger of the other is a condition for the first’s anger. Herein, the state of being a condition should be understood as the state of being a condition for the increase of anger,🔽not for falling away. For it is by his own anger that the being burns the heart-basis, as if by a fire of dry grass, and so falls away because of the extreme delicacy of the body of the fine-material sphere.

original: nidahantena accantasukhumālassa karajakāyassa cavanato. Kandantānaṃyeva orodhānanti🔽anādaratthe sāmivacanaṃ. Ayamettha dhammatāti ayaṃ tesaṃ karajakāyamandatāya, tathāuppajjanakassa
analyzed: nidahantena accantasukhumālassa karaja kāyassa cavanato  an ādara atthe sāmi vacanam ayam ettha dhamma tā ati ayam tesam karaja kāya manda tāya tathā uppajjanakassa
translated: “While they are crying out” :🔽the word “out” is a term for disrespect.🔽This is the rule here: the falling away in the case of these gods, who are delicate because of their fine-material bodies,

original: ca kodhassa balavatāya ṭhānaso cavanabhāvo etesu devesu rūpārūpadhammānaṃ dhammaniyāmo sabhāvoti attho.
analyzed: ca kodhassa balava tāya ṭhānaso cavana bhāvo etesu devesu rūpa arūpa dhammānam dhamma niyāmo sabhāvaḥ ti attho
translated: and the strength of the anger that arises in them, is the natural state, the rule, the way things are, of the mental phenomena of the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: 49-52. Cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passatīti virodhipaccayasannipāte vikārāpattidassanato,
analyzed: cakkha ādīnam bhedam passati iti virodhi paccaya sannipāte vikāra āpatti dassanato
translated: “He sees the dissolution of the eye, etc.”: because he sees the occurrence of change when the conditions opposed to them are present,

original: ante ca adassanūpagamanato vināsaṃ passati oḷārikattā rūpadhammabhedassa. Paccayaṃ
analyzed: ante ca a dassana upagamanataḥ vināsam passati oḷārika ttā rūpa dhamma bhedassa paccayam
translated: and he sees its destruction because of the grossness of the breakup of material dhammas.

original: datvāti anantarapaccayādivasena paccayasattiṃ datvā, paccayo hutvāti vuttaṃ hoti,
analyzed: da tvā iti anantara paccaya ādi vasena paccaya sattim da tvā paccayaḥ hutvā iti vuttam hoti
translated: ‘Having given conditions’: having given the conditionality of conditions by way of the condition of immediate-proximity, etc., he is a condition, is what is meant.

original: tasmā na passatīti sambandho, balavatarampi samānaṃ iminā kāraṇena na passatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tasmā na passati iti sambandhaḥ balavataram pi samānam iminā kāraṇena na passati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: ‘Therefore he does not see’: this is the construction. The intention is that it is because of this reason that he does not see it, though it is stronger.🔽And ‘stronger’ is said with reference to the lightness of the breakup of consciousness. For thus,

original: Balavataranti ca cittassa lahutarabhedaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tathā hi ekasmiṃ rūpe dharanteyeva🔽soḷasa cittāni bhijjanti. Cittassa bhedaṃ na passatīti ettha khaṇe khaṇe bhijjantampi🔽cittaṃ parassa anantarapaccayabhāveneva bhijjati, tasmā purimacittassa abhāvaṃ paṭicchādetvā
analyzed: ca cittassa lahutara bhedam sandhāya vuttam tathā hi ekasmin rūpe  soḷasa cittāni bhijjanti cittassa bhedam na passati iti ettha khaṇe khaṇe bhijjantam pi  cittam parassa anantara paccaya bhāvena iva bhijjati tasmā purima cittassa abhāvam paṭicchādetvā
translated: while one material dhamma persists, sixteen consciousnesses break up.🔽‘He does not see the breakup of consciousness’: here,🔽though consciousness breaks up moment by moment, it breaks up as the condition of immediate-proximity for the next consciousness. Therefore the aspect of existence, as if concealing the non-existence of the previous consciousness,

original: viya pacchimacittassa uppattito bhāvapakkho balavataro pākaṭova hoti, na abhāvapakkhoti
analyzed: viya pacchimacittassa uppattitaḥ bhāva pakkhaḥ balavataraḥ pākaṭaḥ va hoti na abhāva pakkhaḥ ti
translated: is more evident and stronger than the aspect of non-existence, because of the arising of the subsequent consciousness.

original: idaṃ kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “cittaṃ panā”tiādi vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayañcattho alābhacakkanidassanena
analyzed: idam kāraṇam dassetum cittam pana atiādi vuttanti daṭṭhabbam ayam ca atthaḥ alābha cakka nidassanena
translated: The words “but the mind” are said to show this reason. The meaning should be seen thus. And this meaning should be illustrated by the wheel of non-gain.

original: dīpetabbo. Yasmā pana takkīvādī nānattanayassa duravadhānatāya, ekattanayassa ca
analyzed: dīpetabbaḥ yasmā pana takkī vādī nānat tanayassa duravadhāna tāya ekatta nayassa ca
translated: But because the theorist, owing to the difficulty of discerning the mode of diversity and to his misapprehension of the mode of unity,

original: micchāgahitattā “yadevidaṃ viññāṇaṃ sabbadāpi evarūpena pavattati, ayaṃ me attā nicco”tiādinā
analyzed: micchā gahita ttā yadā eva idam viññāṇam sabbadā api evarūpena pavattati ayam me attā nicca uti ādinā
translated: generates the adherence “Whatever this consciousness is, it occurs always in this way, and this is my self, which is permanent,” etc.,

original: abhinivesaṃ janesi, tasmā tamatthaṃ “so taṃ apassanto”tiādinā saha upamāya vibhāveti.
analyzed: abhinivesam janesi tasmā tam attham saḥ tam a passantaḥ iti ādinā saha upamāya vibhāveti
translated: therefore the meaning is analyzed together with a simile in the words “not seeing that” , etc.

original: Antānantavādavaṇṇanā🔽53. Antānantasahacarito vādo antānanto yathā “kuntā pacarantī”ti, antānantasannissayo🔽vā yathā “mañcā ukkuṭṭhiṃ karontī”ti, so etesanti antānantikāti atthaṃ dassetuṃ “antānantavādā”ti
analyzed: anta ananta sahacaritaḥ vādaḥ anta anantaḥ yathā kuntā pacaranti iti anta ananta sannissayaḥ  vā yathā mañcāḥ ukkuṭṭhim karonti iti saḥ etesan ti anta anantikā ati attham dassetum anta ananta vādā ti
translated: The exposition of the views of finitude and infinity🔽The theorist’s view is associated with finitude and infinity, like the statement “The ants are marching” . Or it is dependent on finitude and infinity, like the statement “The beds are creaking” . To show the meaning of “the theorist’s view,” the words “the views of finitude and infinity” are said.

original: vuttaṃ. Vuttanayena antānantasahacarito, tannissayo vā, antānantesu vā pavatto vādo
analyzed: vuttam vutta nayena anta ananta sahacaritaḥ tad nissayaḥ vā anta anantesu vā pavattaḥ vādaḥ
translated: According to the method stated, the theorist’s view is associated with finitude and infinity, or it is dependent on them, or it occurs in regard to finitude and infinity.

original: etesanti antānantavādā. Idāni “antavā ayaṃ loko”tiādinā vakkhamānapāṭhānurūpaṃ atthaṃ🔽vibhajanto “antaṃ vā”tiādimāha. Amati gacchati bhāvo osānametthāti hi anto, mariyādā,🔽tappaṭisedhanena ananto. Anto ca ananto ca antānanto ca nevantanānanto ca antānanto
analyzed: anta ananta vādāḥ idāni antavā ayam lokaḥ iti ādinā vakkhamāna pāṭha anurūpam attham  vibhajantaḥ antam vā ati ādim āha amati gacchati bhāvaḥ hi antaḥ mariyādā  tad paṭisedhanena anantaḥ antaḥ ca anantaḥ ca anta anantaḥ ca nevantana anantaḥ ca anta anantaḥ
translated: “These” is the views of finitude and infinitude. Now, in order to analyze the meaning in accordance with the passage that will be stated thus, “The world is finite” and so on, he says, “The end, or the endless,” and so on.🔽The end is the limit, the end, the termination, the conclusion, the final point, the boundary, the end, the end-point, the end-limit, the end-extreme, the end-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-point, the end-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme-limit-extreme

original: tveva vutto sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesenavā “nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatana”ntiādīsu viya.
analyzed: tu eva vuttaḥ sāmañña niddesena ekasesena vā nāma rūpa paccayā
translated: “These” is the theorists of finitude and infinity. Now, in order to explain the meaning in accordance with the text to be stated thus, “The world is finite, etc.,” he says, “The finite, etc.” The finite is the end, the limit, because of the meaning “it goes ,” bhāvo gacchati, to the end, osānaṃ ettha . The infinite is the opposite of that, by the negation of the finite . The finite and the infinite are the finite and the infinite . The finite and the infinite is the finite and the infinite , stated by the method of agreement, as in the case of the statement, “With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold sense base” .

original: Catutthapadañhettha tatiyapadena samānatthanti antānantapadeneva yathāvuttanayadvayena🔽catudhā attho viññāyati. Kassa panāyaṃ antānantoti? Lokīyati saṃsāranissaraṇatthikehi🔽diṭṭhigatikehi avapassīyati, lokiyanti vā ettha tehi puññāpuññāni, tabbipāko cāti
analyzed: catuttha padam ha ittha tatiya padena anta ananta padena iva yathā vutta naya dvayena  catudhā atthaḥ viññāyati kassa pana ayam anta anantaḥ ti lokīyati saṃsāra nissaraṇa atthikehi  diṭṭhigatikehi avapassīyati lokiyanti vā ettha tehi puññāpuññāni tad vipākaḥ ca ati
translated: The fourth term has the same meaning as the third term. Therefore the meaning is understood in four ways by the finite and the infinite term itself, in the way stated.

original: “loko”ti saṅkhyaṃ gatassa attano. Tenāha pāḷiyaṃ “antānantaṃ lokassa paññapentī”ti.
analyzed: loka iti saṅkhyam gatassa tena āha pāḷiyam anta anantam lokassa paññapenti iti
translated: But whose is this finite and infinite ? It is the self that has come to be reckoned as “the world” , because of the meaning “it is gone ,” lokiyati , by the theorists of views who are seeking for escape from the round of rebirths. Or else, the meritorious and demeritorious kamma and its result are “gone in the world” , thus it is the self that has come to be reckoned as “the world” . Therefore it is said in the text, “They describe the world as finite and infinite” .

original: Ko paneso attāti? Jhānavisayabhūtaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ. Ayañhi diṭṭhigatiko paṭibhāganimittaṃ🔽cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ, apariyantaṃ vā vaḍḍhanavasena, tadanussavādivasena ca tattha🔽lokasaññī viharati, tathā ca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vakkhati “taṃ ‘loko’ti gahetvā”ti keci
analyzed: kaḥ pana isaḥ attā ati jhāna visaya bhūtam kasiṇa nimittam ayam hi diṭṭhi gatiko paṭibhāga nimittam  cakkavāḷa pariyantam apariyantam vā vaḍḍhana vasena tad anussava ādi vasena ca tattha  loka saññī viharati tathā ca aṭṭhakathā ayam vakkhati tam loko ti gahetvā ati keci
translated: But what is this self? It is the kasiṇa sign, which is the object of jhāna. For this theorist dwells perceiving the world as a visible sphere bounded by the horizon or unbounded, extending indefinitely, according to whether he develops the sign by “expansion” or by “extension” , and he dwells perceiving the world as a self by the mere fact that he is obsessed by the view of self. And the commentary says, “He takes that as ‘the world’ ” .

original: pana vadanti “jhānaṃ, taṃsampayuttadhammā ca idha attā, lokoti ca gahitā”ti, taṃ
analyzed: pana vadanti jhānam tad sampayutta dhammā ca idha attā loko ti ca gahitā ati taṃ
translated: But some say that jhāna and the states associated with it are here called “self” and “world” .

original: aṭṭhakathāya na sameti.🔽Etthāha – yuttaṃ tāva purimānaṃ tiṇṇampi vādīnaṃ antānantikattaṃ antañca anantañca🔽antānantañca ārabbha pavattavādattā, pacchimassa pana takkikassa tadubhayapaṭisedhanavasena
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāya na sameti  ettha āha yuttam tāva purimānam tiṇṇam pi vādīnam anta ānantikattam antam ca anantam ca  anta anantam ca ārabbha pavatta vādattā pacchimassa pana takkikassa tad ubhaya paṭisedhana vasena
translated: This is not in accordance with the commentary.

original: pavattavādattā kathaṃ antānantikattanti? Tadubhayapaṭisedhanavasena pavattavādattā
analyzed: pavatta vādattā katham tad ubhaya paṭisedhana vasena pavatta vādattā
translated: Here it may be asked: It is proper that the first three theories should be called “border theories” because they occur on the border between the mundane and the supramundane, and because they occur on the border between what is clung to and what is not clung to. But how can the last one be called a “border theory” because it occurs on the border between the mundane and the supramundane, since it occurs on the border between the two kinds of eternalism?🔽It is called a “border theory” because it occurs on the border between the two kinds of eternalism.

original: eva. Antānantapaṭisedhanavādopi hi so antānantavisayoyeva tamārabbha pavattattā.
analyzed: eva anta ananta paṭisedhana vādaḥ api hi saḥ anta ananta visayaḥ yā iva tam ārabbha pavatta tā
translated: For the theory that denies both is still concerned with the finite and the infinite, since it occurs in dependence on them.

original: Etadatthameva hi sandhāya aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “antaṃ vā antantaṃ vā antānantaṃ vā nevantānānantaṃ🔽vā ārabbha pavattavādā”ti vuttaṃ. Atha vā yathā tatiyavāde desapabhedavasena ekasseva🔽lokassa antavatā, anantavatā ca sambhavati, evamettha takkīvādepi kālapabhedavasena
analyzed: etad attham eva hi sandhāya aṭṭhakathā ayam antam vā anta antam vā anta anantam vā  vā ārabbha pavatta vādā iti vuttam atha vā yathā tatiya vāde desa pabheda vasena ekassa iva  lokassa antavatā anantavatā ca sambhavati evam ettha takkīvāde pi
translated: For it is with reference to this very meaning that it is said in the commentary: “The theories that occur in the world are theories about the finite, the infinite, both, and neither.

original: ekasseva tadubhayasambhavato aññamaññapaṭisedhena tadubhayaññeva vuccati, dvinnampi🔽ca paṭisedhānaṃ pariyudāsatā. Kathaṃ? Antavantapaṭisedhena hi anantavā vuccati, anantavantapaṭisedhena🔽ca antavā. Dvipaṭisedho hi pakatiyatthañāpako. Iti paṭisedhanavasena antānantasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: ekassa iva tad ubhaya sambhavataḥ aññamañña paṭisedhena vuccati dvinnam pi  ca paṭisedhānam pariyudāsa tā katham antavanta paṭisedhena hi anantavā vuccati anantavanta paṭisedhena  ca antavā dvi paṭisedhaḥ hi iti paṭisedhana vasena anta ananta saṅkhātassa
translated: Or alternatively, just as in the third theory the one world is finite and infinite in the sense of a difference of place, so too here in the theorist’s theory the one world is both in the sense of a difference of time. Therefore, by denying each of the two, only the two are mentioned, and the denial of both is implied.

original: ubhayassa vuttattā yuttoyeva tabbisayassa pacchimassāpi antānantikabhāvoti. Yadevaṃ
analyzed: ubhayassa vuttattā yuttaḥ yeva tad visayassa pacchimassa api anta ānantika bhāvaḥ ti yat evam
translated: How? For by the denial of finitude, infinity is mentioned, and by the denial of infinity, finitude is mentioned. For the denial of both makes known the natural meaning. So since both, called “finite” and “infinite,” are mentioned by the denial, the subject of the last theory is rightly finite and infinite.

original: so antānantikavādabhāvato tatiyavādasamavarodheyeva siyāti? Na, kālapabhedassa adhippetattā.
analyzed: saḥ anta anantika vāda bhāvataḥ siyāti na kāla pabhedassa adhippeta ttā
translated: No, because a difference in time is intended.

original: Desapabhedavasena hi antānantiko tatiyavādī viya pacchimopi takkiko kālapabhedavasena🔽antānantiko hoti. Kathaṃ? Yasmā ayaṃ lokasaññito attā ananto kadā ci sakkhidiṭṭhoti
analyzed: desapa bheda vasena hi anta anantikaḥ tatiya vādī pacchimaḥ api takkikaḥ kāla pa bheda vasena  anta ānantikaḥ hoti katham yasmai ayam loka saññitaḥ attā anantaḥ kadā ci sakkhidiṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: For the one who speculates is like the one who holds the third view of endless equivocation in that he does so by a difference in place.🔽But he is like the one who holds the view of endless equivocation in that he does so by a difference in time.🔽How? Because he is questioned by the great seers who have attained distinction thus: “This self, which is reputed in the world, is it endless or was it finite and became endless?”

original: adhigatavisesehi mahesīhi anusuyyati, tasmā nevantavā. Yasmā panāyaṃ antavā kadāci,
analyzed: adhigata visesehi mahesīhi tasmā na iva antavā yasmā pana ayam antavā kadācid
translated: And because he is questioned by the same seers thus: “Was it finite and became endless?”

original: sakkhidiṭṭhoti tehiyeva anusuyyati, tasmā nānantavāti. Ayaṃ takkiko avaḍḍhitabhāvapubbakattā
analyzed: sakkhi diṭṭhaḥ ti tehiyā iva tasmā na anantavā ati ayam takkikaḥ a vaḍḍhita bhāva pubbaka ttā
translated: Therefore he is one who speculates. Since the time of his non-increase is prior to the time of his increase,

original: paṭibhāganimittānaṃ vaḍḍhitabhāvassa ubhayathā labbhamānassa parikappitassa attano🔽appaccakkhakāritāya anussavādimatte ṭhatvā vaḍḍhitakālavasena “nevantavā”ti paṭikkhipati,
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimittānam vaḍḍhita bhāvassa ubhayathā labbhamānassa parikappitassa attano  appaccakkha kāritāya anussava ādi matte ṭhatvā vaḍḍhita kāla vasena paṭikkhipati
translated: and since the increase of the signs of the counterpart states is possible in both times, he, who is not a witness of the increase,🔽and who stands only on what is reported by hearsay, etc., denies the question of endlessness by the time of increase,

original: avaḍḍhitakālavasena pana “nānantavā”ti, na pana antatānantatānaṃ accantamabhāvena
analyzed: avaḍḍhita kāla vasena pana na pana accantama bhāvena
translated: and he denies the question of finiteness by the time of non-increase, but not because of the utter non-existence of finiteness and endlessness.

original: yathā taṃ “nevasaññānāsaññā”ti. Yathā cānussutikatakkino, evaṃ jātissaratakkiādīnampi
analyzed: yathā tam nevasaññā nāsaññā ti yathā ca anussutika takkino evam jātissara takki ādīnam pi
translated: And as in the case of the man who has had a purgative, so in the case of the man who has had a blood-letting, and so on.

original: vasena yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbaṃ.🔽Keci pana yadi panāyaṃ attā antavā, evaṃ sati dūradese upapajjanānussaraṇādikiccanibbatti
analyzed: vasena yathāsambhavam yojetabbam  keci pana yadi pana ayam attā antavā evam sati dūra dese upapajjana anussaraṇa ādi kicca nibbatti
translated: The four theories should be construed in the appropriate way with each of the terms beginning with “birth” .🔽But some say that if the self is finite, then it cannot be the basis for such activities as remembering what was done long ago, remembering what was done far away, and so on.

original: na siyā. Atha anantavā, evañca idha ṭhitasseva devalokanirayādīsu sukhadukkhānubhavanaṃ
analyzed: na siyā atha anantavā evañca idha ṭhitassa iva deva loka niraya ādīsu sukha dukkha anubhavanaṃ
translated: If it is infinite, then it would be the experiencer of pleasure and pain in the heavenly world and in hell, even while it remains here.

original: siyā. Sace pana antavā ceva anantavā ca, evampi tadubhayadosasamāyogo siyā. Tasmā
analyzed: siyā sace pana antavā ca iva anantavā ca evampi tad ubhaya dosa samāyogaḥ siyā tasmā
translated: And if it is both finite and infinite, then it would be subject to the faults of both alternatives.🔽Therefore it is not to be declared whether the self is finite or infinite.

original: “antavā, anantavā”ti ca abyākaraṇīyo attāti evaṃ takkanavasena catutthavādappavattiṃ
analyzed: antavā anantavā iti ca abyākaraṇīyaḥ attā ati evam takkana vasena catuttha vāda ppavattim
translated: Thus they explain the origin of the fourth theory as a consequence of speculation.

original: vaṇṇenti. Yadi panesa vuttanayena antānantiko bhaveyya, atha kasmā “ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā
analyzed: vaṇṇenti yadi pana esa vutta nayena anta ānantikaḥ bhaveyya atha kasmai ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: But if the self were finite in the way described, then why did the Blessed One reject the three theories of finitude,

original: evamāhaṃsu ‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo’ti, tesaṃ musā”tiādinā tassa purimavādattayapaṭikkhepo
analyzed: evam āhaṃsu antavā ayam loko parivaṭumaḥ ti tesam musā āti ādinā tassa purima vāda ttaya paṭikkhepo
translated: saying: “It is not the case, bhikkhus, that this world is finite and infinite” , and so on?

original: vuttoti? Purimavādattayassa tena yathādhippetappakāravilakkhaṇabhāvato. Teneva hi🔽kāraṇena tathā paṭikkhepo vutto, na pana tassa antānantikattābhāvena, na ca pariyantarahitadiṭṭhivācāhi🔽paṭikkhepena, avassañcetaṃ evameva ñātabbaṃ. Aññathā hesa amarāvikkhepapakkhaññeva
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti purima vāda ttayassa tena yathā adhippeta ppakāra vilakkhaṇa bhāvato tena iva hi  kāraṇena tathā paṭikkhepaḥ vuttaḥ na pana tassa anta ānantika tta abhāvena na ca pariyanta rahita diṭṭhi vācāhi  paṭikkhepena evam eva ñātabbam aññathā ha esa amarā vikkhepa pakkhaññā iva
translated: “Said”? —Because of the difference in the mode of expression of the first two theories.🔽For this very reason, the rejection is stated in this way, and not because of the absence of the finitist and infinitist theories, nor because of the rejection of the theories of the one who has no limit and of the one who has a limit.🔽But it is not necessary to understand it in this way. Otherwise, this fourth theory would be included in the theory of the endlessness of the world.

original: bhajeyya catutthavādo. Na hi antatāanantatātadubhayavinimutto attano pakāro atthi,
analyzed: bhajeyya catuttha vādaḥ na hi anta tā ananta tā tad ubhaya vinimuttaḥ attanaḥ pakāraḥ atthi
translated: For there is no mode of the self that is free from finitude and infinitude.

original: takkīvādī ca yuttimaggakoyeva. Kālabhedavasena ca ekasmimpi loke tadubhayaṃ no na🔽yujjatīti. Bhavatu tāva pacchimavādīdvayassa antānantikabhāvo yutto antānantānaṃ
analyzed: takkīvādī ca kāla bheda vasena ca ekasmin pi loke tat ubhayam no na  yujjati iti bhavatu tāva pacchimavādī dvayassa anta ānantika bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ
translated: And the theorist is one who follows the path of reason. And it is not impossible that both theories are true in the world, in terms of different times.

original: vasena ubhayavisayattā tesaṃ vādassa. Kathaṃ pana purimavādīdvayassa paccekaṃ antānantikabhāvo
analyzed: vasena ubhaya visaya ttā tesam vādassa katham pana purimavādī dvayassa paccekam anta ānantika bhāvo
translated: Let it be granted that the last two theories are rightly finitist and infinitist, because they have both finitude and infinitude as their domain. But how can the first two theories be rightly finitist and infinitist respectively, because they have each as their domain?

original: yutto siyā ekekavisayattā tesaṃ vādassāti? Vuccate – samudāye pavattamāna-saddassa
analyzed: yuttaḥ siyā eka eka visaya ttā tesam vādassa ati vuccate samudāye pavattamāna saddassa
translated: It is said: The word “world” is used in the sense of a collection.

original: avayavepi upacāravuttito. Samuditesu hi antānantavādīsu pavattamāno antānanti ka-saddo
analyzed: avayave pi upacāra vuttitaḥ samuditesu hi anta ananta vādīsu pavattamānaḥ anta ananti ka saddo
translated: and also in the parts by figurative use. For the word “end” occurs in the plural in the case of the theorists of the end and the infinite,

original: tattha niruḷhatāya tadavayavesupi paccekaṃ antānantikavādīsu pavattati yathā “arūpajjhānesu
analyzed: tattha niruḷha tāya tad avayavesu pi paccekam anta anantika vādīsu pavattati yathā arūpa jjhānesu
translated: and it occurs in the singular in the case of the theorists of the end and the infinite as parts of that, because it is established in that way, just as “the eight emancipations” occurs in the plural in the case of the eight emancipations,

original: paccekaṃ aṭṭhavimokkhapariyāyo”, yathā ca “loke sattāsayo”ti. Atha vā abhinivesato🔽purimakāle pavattavitakkavasena ayaṃ tattha vohāro kato. Tesañhi diṭṭhigatikānaṃ🔽tathārūpacetosamādhisamadhigamato pubbakāle “antavā nu kho ayaṃ loko, udāhu anantavā”ti
analyzed: paccekam aṭṭha vimokkha pariyāyaḥ yathā ca loke atha vā abhinivesato  purima kāle pavatta vitakka vasena ayam tattha vohāro kato tesam hi diṭṭhi gatikānam  tathārūpa cetaḥ samādhi samadhigamataḥ pubba kāle antavā nu kho ayam lokaḥ udāhu anantavā ti
translated: and “the sixty-two” occurs in the plural in the case of the sixty-two views. Or else this usage is made by way of the thinking that occurred in the past time of the adherence.🔽For in the case of those who have views,

original: ubhayākārāvalambino vitakkassa vasena niruḷho antānantikabhāvo pacchā visesalābhena
analyzed: ubhaya ākāra avalambinaḥ vitakkassa vasena niruḷhaḥ anta ānantika bhāvaḥ pacchā visesa lābhena
translated: the state of being a theorist of the end and the infinite is established by way of thinking that occurred in the past time before they had attained such and such a kind of mental concentration and meditative attainment, with the occurrence of thinking that had as its object both aspects, namely, “Is this world finite or infinite?”

original: tesu antānantavādesu ekasseva vādassa saṅgahe uppannepi purimasiddharuḷhiyā vohārīyati
analyzed: tesu anta ananta vādesu ekassa iva vādassa saṅgahe uppanne pi purima siddha ruḷhiyā vohārīyati
translated: And when the occurrence of the combination of only one of the theories, namely, that of the end or that of the infinite, has arisen by means of the gain of distinction in the case of those who have views,🔽the usage is made by the established state of being a theorist of the end or the infinite that occurred previously.

original: yathā “sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā”tiādīsu arahati sattapariyāyo, yathā ca bhavantaragatepi maṇḍūkādivohāroti.🔽54-60. Paṭibhāganimittavaḍḍhanāya heṭṭhā, upari, tiriyañca cakkavāḷapariyantagatāgatavasena
analyzed: yathā sabbe sattā maraṇa dhammā ti ādīsu arahati satta pariyāyaḥ yathā ca bhavantara gate pi maṇḍūka ādi vohāraḥ iti  paṭibhāga nimitta vaḍḍhanāya heṭṭhā upari tiriyan ca cakkavāḷa pariyanta gata āgata vasena
translated: As in the case of the statement, “All beings are subject to death,” the meaning of “being” is appropriate, and as in the case of the expression “tadpoles,” etc., when there is a change of existence.

original: antānantabhāvoti dassetuṃ “paṭibhāganimitta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Nti paṭibhāganimittaṃ.
analyzed: anta ananta bhāvaḥ ti dassetum paṭibhāga nimitta ntiādi vuttam nti paṭibhāga nimittam
translated: In order to show the finite and infinite in the sense of the extension of the counterpart sign, the text says, “The counterpart sign” and so on.🔽The counterpart sign is the sign that is similar to the kasiṇa.

original: Uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvāti etthāpi “cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā”ti adhikāravasena🔽yojetabbaṃ. Vuttanayenāti “takkayatīti takkī”tiādinā saddato, “catubbidho takkī”tiādinā🔽atthato ca sassatavāde vuttanayena. Diṭṭhapubbānusārenāti dassanabhūtena viññāṇena
analyzed: uddham adhas a vaḍḍhetvā tiriyam vaḍḍhetvā ati ettha api cakkavāḷa pariyantam katvā iti adhikāra vasena  yojetabbam vutta nayena ati takkayati iti takkī iti ādinā saddataḥ catubbidhaḥ takkī iti ādinā  atthato ca sassata vāde vutta nayena diṭṭha pubba anusārena ati dassana bhūtena viññāṇena
translated: Without extending it upwards or downwards, he extends it across, making it coincide with the horizon.🔽Here too, the words “making it coincide with the horizon” should be supplied.🔽In the way stated means in the way stated in the case of the eternalist view, both by way of the derivation of the word and by way of the meaning, and also by way of the meaning in the case of the annihilationist view.

original: upaladdhapubbassa antavantādino anussaraṇena, evañca katvā anussutitakkīsuddhatakkīnampi
analyzed: upaladdha pubbassa antavat ādinaḥ anussaraṇena evam ca katvā anussuti takkī suddha takkīnam pi
translated: By the recollection of what was seen before means by the recollection of what was previously apprehended by the consciousness that has the nature of seeing.

original: idha saṅgaho siddho hoti. Atha vā diṭṭhaggahaṇeneva “naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā”tiādīsu🔽viya sutādīnampi gahitabhāvo veditabbo. “Antavā”tiādinā icchitassa attano sabbadābhāvaparāmasanavaseneva🔽imesaṃ vādānaṃ pavattanato sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tathā hi vakkhati “satteva
analyzed: idha saṅgahaḥ siddhaḥ hoti atha vā diṭṭha ggahaṇena iva nacca gīta vādita visūka dassana ati ādīsu  viya suta ādīnam pi gahita bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ antavā ati ādinā icchitassa attano sabbadā bhāva parāmasana vasena iva  imesam vādānam pavattanato sassata diṭṭhi saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tathā hi vakkhati sattā iva
translated: Here the inclusion is established. Or else, by the word “seen” the other three kinds of objects of assertion, namely, heard, sensed, and cognized, are also included, just as in the passage “the seeing of dancing, singing, and music” .

original: ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo”ti.
analyzed: uccheda diṭṭhiyo sesā sassata diṭṭhiyo ti
translated: The inclusion of these theories under eternalism should be understood as the overestimation of one’s own self as existing in all modes of past and future time. For it is said: “The views of annihilation are two, the rest are eternalist views” .

original: Amarāvikkhepavādavaṇṇanā
translated: The theory of the non-abandonment of the life process

original: 61. Na maratīti “evamevā”ti sanniṭṭhānābhāvena na upacchijjati, anekantikāyeva hotīti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Pariyantarahitāti osānavigatā, aniṭṭhaṅgatāti attho. Vividhoti “evampi
analyzed: na marati iti evam eva ati sanniṭṭhāna abhāvena na upacchijjati anekantikāya iva hoti iti  vuttam hoti pariyanta rahitā ati osāna vigatā aniṭṭhaṅgatā ti attho vividhaḥ ti evam pi
translated: “He does not die” : he is not cut off, i.e., he does not cease to exist, but remains in a multiplicity of forms.

original: me no”tiādinā nānappakāro. Khepoti sakavādena paravādānaṃ khipanaṃ. Ko paneso amarāvikkhepoti?
analyzed: me no ti ādinā nānappakāro khepo ti saka vādena para vādānam khipanam kaḥ pana iso amara a vikkhepo ti
translated: “Without end” : without a final limit, i.e., without reaching a final goal. “Various” : of various kinds, i.e., “in this way, in that way, etc.” “Scattering” : the scattering of other theories by one’s own theory. But what is this “non-abandonment of the life process”?

original: Tathāpavatto diṭṭhippadhāno tādisāya vācāya samuṭṭhāpako cittuppādoyeva. Amarāya
analyzed: tathā pavattaḥ diṭṭhi ppadhāno tādisāya vācāya samuṭṭhāpako cittuppādaḥ yā iva amarāya
translated: It is the theory that occurs in this way, or it is the arising of consciousness that gives rise to such speech.

original: diṭṭhiyā, vācāya ca vikkhipanti, vividhamapanentīti vā amarāvikkhepino, teyeva “amarāvikkhepikā”tipi
analyzed: diṭṭhiyā vācāya ca vikkhipanti vividham apanenti iti vā amarā vikkhepino teyeva amarā vikkhepikā atipi
translated: They are “diverted” by view and by speech, or they divert in various ways, thus they are “diverted by the undiverted” . The same word is also appropriate as “diverted by the undiverted ones” .

original: yujjati. “Macchajāti” cceva avatvā “ekā”ti vadanto macchajātiviseso esoti dasseti.
analyzed: yujjati maccha jāti cca iva avatvā ekā ati vadantaḥ maccha jāti visesaḥ esā iti dasseti
translated: By saying “one” instead of “a kind of fish” he shows that there is a difference in the kind of fish.

original: Ito cito ca sandhāvati ekasmiṃ sabhāve anavaṭṭhānato. Yathā gāhaṃ na upagacchati,🔽tathā sandhāvanato, etena amarāya vikkhepo tathā, so viyāti amarāvikkhepoti atthamāha
analyzed: itas citas ca sandhāvati ekasmin sabhāve anavaṭṭhānataḥ yathā gāham na upagacchati  tathā sandhāvanataḥ etena amarāya vikkhepo tathā saḥ viyāti amara a vikkhepaḥ ti attham āha
translated: It runs hither and thither, not settling down on any one concept. It does not settle down in the way in which it runs hither and thither,🔽and this is the meaning of “diverted by the undiverted” .🔽“It is like a fish that is diverted by rising to the surface and diving beneath, etc.”

original: “sā ummujjananimujjanādivasenā”tiādinā vikkhepapadatthena upamitattā. Ayameva hi
analyzed: sā ummujjana nimujjana ādi vasena ati ādinā vikkhepa padatthena upamita ttā ayam eva hi
translated: This is the meaning: because it is likened to the act of diverting by the word “diverted.”

original: attho ācariyasāriputtattherenāpi sāratthadīpaniyaṃ vutto. Amarā viya vikkhepo amarāvikkhepoti🔽keci. Atha vā amarā viya vikkhipantīti amarāvikkhepino, teyeva amarāvikkhepikā.
analyzed: attho ācariya sāriputta therena api sāratthadīpaniyam vuttaḥ amarāḥ viya vikkhepaḥ amara a vikkhepaḥ ti  keci atha vā amarāḥ viya vikkhipanti iti amara avikkhepinaḥ te yeva amara avikkhepikā
translated: This is the meaning stated by the Elder Sāriputta, the teacher, in the Sāratthapakāsinī.🔽Some say that it is “diversion by the undiverted” because it is like the undiverted .

original: 62. Vikkhepavādino uttarimanussadhamme, abyākatadhamme ca (akusaladhammepi dī. ni.
analyzed: vikkhepa vādinaḥ uttari manussa dhamme abyākata dhamme ca akusala dhamme pi ni
translated: Or alternatively, they divert as if they were undiverted, thus they are “diverted by the undiverted” . They are the same as “diverted by the undiverted ones” .🔽The “diversionists” are those who divert the supermundane states and the indeterminate states .

original: ṭī. 1.62) sabhāvabhedavasena paṭivijjhituṃ ñāṇaṃ natthīti kusalākusalapadānaṃ kusalākusalakammapathavaseneva
analyzed: sa bhāva bheda vasena paṭivijjhitum ñāṇam na atthi iti kusala akusala padānam kusala akusala kammapatha vasena iva
translated: therefore the meaning of the terms “wholesome” and “unwholesome” is stated only by way of the wholesome and unwholesome courses of kamma.

original: attho vutto. Vighāto vihesā kāyikadukkhaṃ “vippaṭisāruppattiyā”ti domanassassa hetubhāvena
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ vighātaḥ vihesā kāyika dukkham vippaṭisāru ppattiyā ati domanassassa hetu bhāvena
translated: “Affliction” is affliction, bodily pain. “By the arising of displeasure” is stated as the cause of displeasure.

original: vacanato, tenāha “dukkhaṃ bhaveyyā”ti. Musāvādeti nimitte bhummavacanaṃ, nissakkatthe
analyzed: vacanataḥ tena āha dukkham bhaveyya ati musāvāde iti nimitte bhumma vacanam nissakka tthe
translated: Therefore it is said: “there would be suffering.” “False speech” is a locative expression in the sense of cause.

original: vā. Musāvādahetu, musāvādato vā ottappena ceva hiriyā cāti attho. Kīdisaṃ amarāvikkhepamāpajjatīti
analyzed: vā musāvāda hetu musāvādataḥ vā ottappena ca iva hiriyā ca ati attho kīdisam amarā vikkhepam āpajjati iti
translated: Or it is a locative in the sense of source. The meaning is: by shame and abashment, which are the cause of false speech, or which arise from false speech.🔽“What kind of distraction does he fall into?”

original: āha “apariyantavikkhepa”nti, tena amarāsadisavikkhepasaṅkhātaṃ dutiyanayaṃ nivatteti.
analyzed: āha apariyanta vikkhepan ti tena amara asadisa vikkhepa saṅkhātam dutiya nayam nivatteti
translated: He says: “infinite distraction,” thereby excluding the second method, which is called “distraction like the gods.”

original: Yathāvutte hi nayadvaye paṭhamanayavasenāyamattho dassito, dutiyanayavasena pana
analyzed: yathā vutte hi naya dvaye paṭhama naya vasena ayam atthaḥ dassitaḥ dutiya naya vasena pana
translated: For in the two methods stated thus, this meaning is shown by way of the first method, but by way of the second method,

original: amarāsadisavikkhepaṃ dassetuṃ “idaṃ kusalanti puṭṭho”tiādivacanaṃ vakkhati.
analyzed: amarā sadisa vikkhepam dassetum idam kusalam ti puṭṭhaḥ ti ādi vacanam vakkhati
translated: in order to show distraction like the gods, the statement “if he is asked: ‘Is this wholesome?’” is made.

original: “Evantipi me no”ti yaṃ tayā puṭṭhaṃ, taṃ evantipi me laddhi no hotīti attho. Evaṃ
analyzed: me no ti yam tayā puṭṭham tam evantipi me laddhi no hoti iti evam
translated: “I do not accept even that” : the meaning is that I do not accept even that which you have asked. Thus

original: sabbattha yathārahaṃ. Aniyamitavikkhepoti sassatādīsu ekasmimpi pakāre aṭṭhatvā vikkhepakaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: sabbattha yathāraham aniyamita vikkhepaḥ ti sassata ādīsu ekasmin pi pakāre vikkhepa karaṇam
translated: in all cases as appropriate. “Unrestricted equivocation” : without standing in any one of the positions such as eternalism, etc., the making of equivocation,

original: paravādinā yasmiṃ kismiñci pakāre pucchite tassa paṭikkhepavikkhepoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: paravādinā yasmin kismiñci pakāre pucchite tassa paṭikkhepa vikkhepo ti vuttam hoti
translated: the rejection of whatever position is asked about by the opponent.

original: Atha vā apariyantavikkhepadassanaṃyeva aṭṭhakathāyaṃ kataṃ “evantipi me noti aniyamitavikkhepo”tiādinā,
analyzed: atha vā apariyanta vikkhepa dassanam yeva aṭṭhakathā ayam katam me no ti aniyamita vikkhepa uti ādinā
translated: Or else, the showing of unrestricted equivocation has been made in the commentary by the words “I do not accept even that” and so on,🔽and by the words “asked whether it is wholesome or unwholesome” and so on.

original: “idaṃ kusalanti vā akusalanti vā puṭṭho”tiādinā ca. “Evantipi me no”tiādinā hi aniyametvā,🔽niyametvā ca sassatekaccasassatucchedatakkīvādānaṃ paṭisedhanena taṃ taṃ vādaṃ paṭikkhipateva
analyzed: idam kusalanti vā a kusalanti vā puṭṭha uti ādinā ca me na uti ādinā hi aniyametvā  niyametvā ca paṭisedhanena tam tam vādam paṭikkhipatā iva
translated: For by the words “I do not accept even that” and so on, without restriction,🔽and by the words “asked whether it is eternal or non-eternal” and so on, with restriction, he rejects this or that doctrine by the rejection of the doctrines of eternalism, partial eternalism, and annihilationism,

original: apariyantavikkhepavādattā. “Amarāvikkhepino”ti dassetvā attanā pana anavaṭṭhitavādattā
analyzed: apariyanta vikkhepa vādattā amara a vikkhepinaḥ ti dassetvā attanā pana anavaṭṭhita vādattā
translated: because of the unrestricted equivocation of his doctrine. Having shown that he is an “unrestricted equivocator,” he himself does not hold to any doctrine,

original: na kismiñci pakkhe avatiṭṭhatīti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “sayaṃ pana idaṃ…pe… na byākarotī”ti
analyzed: na kismiñci pakkhe avatiṭṭhati iti imam attham dassetum sayam pana na byākaroti iti
translated: “He does not stand in any position” : he does not say “it is this” or “it is not this” or “it is and it is not this” or “it neither is nor is not this.”

original: āha. Idāni kusalādīnaṃ abyākaraṇena tadeva anavaṭṭhānaṃ vibhāveti “idaṃ kusalanti🔽puṭṭho”tiādinā. Tenevāha “ekasmimpi pakkhe na tiṭṭhatī”ti. Kiṃ no noti te laddhīti
analyzed: āha idāni kusala ādīnam a byākaraṇena tat eva anavaṭṭhānam idam kusalanti  puṭṭha iti ādinā tena iva āha ekasmim pi pakkhe na tiṭṭhati iti kim no no ti te laddhi iti
translated: “He does not answer” : he does not answer by saying “it is wholesome” or “it is unwholesome” or “it is indeterminate.”🔽“He does not stand in any position” : he does not say “it is wholesome” or “it is unwholesome” or “it is indeterminate.”🔽“What is your opinion?” : what is your view?🔽“It is not so”: your view is not so.

original: neva na hotīti tava laddhi hoti kinti attho. No notipi me noti neva na hotītipi me laddhi no hoti.
analyzed: na iva na hoti iti tava laddhi hoti kinti atthaḥ no no tipi me noti na iva na hoti itipi me laddhi no hoti
translated: “It is not so”: my view is not so.🔽“He does not know”: he does not know by way of lust, etc., which are the domain of the wise.

original: 63. Attano paṇḍitabhāvavisayānaññeva rāgādīnaṃ vasena yojanaṃ kātuṃ “ajānantopī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: rāga ādīnam vasena yojanam kātum a jānantaḥ api iti ādim āha
translated: “Suddenly”: without reflection, quickly.

original: Sahasāti anupadhāretvā vegena. “Bhadramukhāti paṇḍitānaṃ samudāciṇṇamālapanaṃ, sundaramukhāti
analyzed: sahasā ati vegena bhadra mukhā ati samudāciṇṇam ālapanam sundara mukhā ati
translated: “Good sir”: this is a term of address for the wise; the meaning is “good-faced one.”🔽“There”: in that answer; the locative case is used for the instrumental.

original: attho. Tatthāti tasmiṃ byākaraṇe, nimitte cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Chandarāgapadānaṃ samānatthabhāvepi
analyzed: atthaḥ tattha ati tasmin byākaraṇe nimitte ca itam bhummam chanda rāga padānam samāna attha bhāve pi
translated: “Although the words ‘desire’ and ‘lust’ have the same meaning,” etc.

original: vikappanajotakena vā-saddena yogyattā gobalībaddādinayena bhinnatthatāva yuttāti
analyzed: vikappana jotakena vā saddena yogya ttā go balībadda ādi nayena yuttā ati
translated: Or else, because of the light of the word “also” , the meaning of “divided” is appropriate in the way beginning with “like a cow with a rope tied round its neck” .

original: āha “chando dubbalarāgo, rāgo balavarāgo”ti. Dosapaṭighesupi eseva nayo. Ettakampi🔽nāmāti ettha api-saddo sampiṇḍane vattati, nāma-saddo garahāyaṃ. Na kevalaṃ ito uttaritarameva,
analyzed: āha chandaḥ dubbala rāgaḥ rāgaḥ balavā rāgaḥ iti dosa paṭighesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettakam pi  nāma ati ettha api saddo sampiṇḍane vattati nāma saddo garahā ayam na kevalam itas uttaritaram eva
translated: So he says: “Desire is weak passion; passion is strong passion.” The same method applies in the case of “aversion” and “resentment.”🔽As to the words “I do not even know this much” , the word “even” is used in the sense of inclusion, and the word “know” in the sense of blame. It is not only more than this that I do not know,

original: atha kho ettakampi na jānāmi nāma, pageva taduttarijānaneti attho. Parehi katasakkārasamānavisayānaṃ
analyzed: atha kho ettakam pi na jānāmi nāma pagā iva tad uttari jānanā iti attho parehi kata sakkāra samāna visayānam
translated: but I do not even know this much, so how can I know what is beyond this?

original: pana rāgādīnaṃ vasena ayaṃ yojanā – kusalākusalaṃ yathābhūtaṃ apajānantopi yesamahaṃ
analyzed: rāga ādīnam vasena ayam yojanā kusala akusalam yathābhūtam apajānantaḥ api
translated: The application of the terms “passion” and so on is according to the object of the respect and honour done by others in this way: “Even though I do not know what is wholesome and what is unwholesome as it really is,

original: samavāyena kusalameva “kusala”nti, akusalameva “akusala”nti ca byākareyyaṃ, tesu🔽tathā byākaraṇahetu “aho vata re paṇḍito”ti sakkārasammānaṃ karontesu mama chando
analyzed: samavāyena kusalam eva kusalanti akusalam eva akusalanti ca byākareyyam tesu  tathā byākaraṇa hetu aho vata re paṇḍita uti sakkāra sammānam karontesu mama chando
translated: I would still explain what is wholesome as ‘wholesome’ and what is unwholesome as ‘unwholesome’ in accordance with the general agreement🔽of those who know. If they were to do me honour and respect, saying, ‘Oh, what a wise man!’

original: vā rāgo vā assāti. Dosapaṭighesupi vuttavipariyāyena yojetabbaṃ. “Taṃ mamassa upādānaṃ,
analyzed: vā rāgaḥ vā assa ati dosa paṭighesu pi vutta vipariyāyena yojetabbam tam mama assa upādānam
translated: because of my explanation in this way, I should have desire or passion for that. The same method applies in the case of “aversion” and “resentment” with the difference that the words should be construed in the opposite sense. “That would be a condition for my assuming” .

original: so mamassa vighāto”ti idaṃ abhidhammanayena yathālābhavacanaṃ yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbanti
analyzed: saḥ mama assa vighāto ti idam abhidhamma nayena yathālābha vacanam yathāsambhavam yojetabbanti
translated: This is the frustration for me.” This is the way of the Abhidhamma. It should be applied according to the way of the Suttas by taking the words as they are found and fitting them together as they are possible to be fitted.

original: āha “chandarāgadvaya”ntiādi. Taṇhādiṭṭhiyo eva hi “upādāna”nti abhidhamme vuttā idāni
analyzed: āha chanda rāga dvaya ntiādi taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ eva hi upādānanti abhidhamme vuttā idāni
translated: Therefore it is said: “The two, will and lust,” etc. For craving and views are called “clinging” in the Abhidhamma.

original: suttantanayena avisesayojanaṃ dasseti “ubhayampi vā”tiādinā. Suttante hi dosopi “upādāna”nti🔽vutto “kodhupādānavinibandhā vighātaṃ āpajjantī”tiādīsu “ubhayampī”ti ca atthato
analyzed: suttanta nayena avisesa yojanam dasseti ubhayam pi vā āti ādinā suttante hi dosaḥ api upādānam ti  vuttaḥ kodha upādāna vinibandhāḥ vighātam āpajjanti itiādīsu ubhayam pi iti ca atthataḥ
translated: Now, in order to show the way of the Suttas without distinction, he says: “Or both,” etc. For in the Suttas, hatred is also called “clinging” .🔽In the passage: “They fall into frustration bound by the clinging of anger,” etc. “Or both” is said in the sense of the two, not in the sense of the four, because the four terms express two meanings.

original: vuttaṃ, na saddato catunnampi saddānamatthadvayavācakattā. Daḷhaggahaṇanti amuñcanaggahaṇaṃ.🔽Paṭighopi hi ārammaṇaṃ na muñcati upanāhādivasena pavattanato, lobhasseva upādānabhāvena
analyzed: vuttam na catunnam pi saddānam attha dvaya vācaka ttā daḷha ggahaṇam ti amuñcana ggahaṇam  paṭighaḥ api hi ārammaṇam na muñcati upanāha ādi vasena pavattanataḥ lobhassa iva upādāna bhāvena
translated: “Firm grasping” is the grasping of not letting go.🔽For aversion also does not let go of the object, because it occurs by way of resentment, etc. This is said in order to show that aversion also has the nature of clinging, because the nature of clinging is evident only in greed.

original: pākaṭattā dosassāpi upādānabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ idaṃ vuttaṃ. Vihananaṃ vihiṃsanaṃ vibādhanaṃ.

translated: “Afflicting” is afflicting, afflicting, afflicting.

original: Rāgopi hi pariḷāhavasena sāraddhavuttitāya nissayaṃ vihanati. “Rāgo hī”tiādinā rāgadosānaṃ🔽upādānabhāve visesadassanamukhena tadatthasamatthanaṃ. analyzed: pucchāya vikkhepa karaṇa attham atthi paraḥ loko ti iti ce mama pucchasi iti pucchā ṭhapanam eva
translated: “If you ask me, ‘Is there a world beyond?’ I would reply, ‘There is a world beyond.’”

original: tena dassīyati, na attano dhammānavabodhāvabodhoti ayameva visesena “mando momūho”ti
analyzed: tena dassīyati na attanaḥ dhamma an avabodha avabodho ti ayam eva visesena mandaḥ momūhoti
translated: So he is called “dull” and “obtuse” in this way because of this difference.

original: vutto. Teneva hi tathāvādīnaṃ sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ ārabbha “ayañca imesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ🔽sabbabālo sabbamūḷho”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha “atthi paro loko”ti sassatadassanavasena,
analyzed: vuttaḥ tena iva hi tathāvādīnam sañcayam belaṭṭha puttam ārabbha ayam ca imesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam  sabba bālaḥ sabba mūḷhaḥ ti vuttam tattha atthi paraḥ loko ti sassata dassana vasena
translated: and so on. For it was said of Sañcaya Belaṭṭhaputta, who held that view, that he was “the most foolish and stupid of all these ascetics and Brahmins.”🔽Herein, “There is a world beyond” is a question asked from the standpoint of eternalism or from the standpoint of right view.

original: sammādiṭṭhivasena vā pucchā. Yadi hi diṭṭhigatiko sassatadassanavasena puccheyya,🔽yadi ca sammādiṭṭhiko sammādassanavasenāti dvidhāpi attho vaṭṭati. “Natthi paro loko”ti🔽natthikadassanavasena, sammādiṭṭhivasena vā, “atthi ca natthi ca paro loko”ti ucchedadassanavasena,
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi vasena vā pucchā yadi hi diṭṭhi gatiko sassata dassana vasena puccheyya  yadi ca sammādiṭṭhiko sammādassana vasena ati dvidhā api atthaḥ vaṭṭati natthi paraḥ loko ti  natthika dassana vasena sammādiṭṭhi vasena vā atthi ca natthi ca paraḥ loko ti uccheda dassana vasena
translated: For if the questioner is a theorist, then the meaning is from the standpoint of eternalism;🔽but if he is one of right view, then the meaning is from the standpoint of right view. “There is no world beyond” is a question asked from the standpoint of annihilationism or from the standpoint of right view.🔽“There is and is not a world beyond” is a question asked from the standpoint of the doctrine of the annihilation of the self or from the standpoint of right view.

original: sammādiṭṭhivasena vā, “nevatthi na natthi paro loko”ti vuttapakārattayapaṭikkhepe
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi vasena vā na iva atthi na natthi paraḥ loko ti vutta pakāra ttaya paṭikkhepe
translated: “There is no world beyond, there is not no world beyond” is a question asked by the denial of the three alternatives stated.

original: sati pakārantarassa asambhavato atthitānatthitāhi na vattabbākāro paro lokoti vikkhepaññeva
analyzed: sati pakāra antarassa asambhavataḥ atthita anatthitāhi na vattabba ākāraḥ paraḥ lokaḥ ti vikkhepaññā eva
translated: Since there is no other alternative, the meaning is that the world beyond is not to be spoken of as existent or non-existent.

original: purakkhārena, sammādiṭṭhivasena vā pucchā. Sesacatukkattayepi vuttanayānusārena attho🔽veditabbo. Puññasaṅkhārattiko viya hi kāyasaṅkhārattikena purimacatukkasaṅgahito🔽eva attho sesacatukkattayena sattaparāmāsapuññādisaphalatācodanānayena (attaparāmāsapuññādiphalatācodanānayena🔽dī. ni. ṭī. 1.65, 66) saṅgahito. Ettha hi tatiyacatukkena puññādikammasaphalatāya,
analyzed: purakkhārena sammādiṭṭhi vasena vā pucchā sesa catukka ttaye pi vutta naya anusārena attho  veditabbaḥ puñña saṅkhāra ttikaḥ viya hi kāya saṅkhāra ttikena purima catukka saṅgahitaḥ  eva attho sesa catukka ttayena satta parāmāsa puñña ādi sa phala tā codanā nayena atta parāmāsa puñña ādi phala tā codanā nayena  dī ni ṭī saṅgahitaḥ ettha hi tatiya catukkena puñña ādi kamma saphala tāya
translated: or by way of the foremost, or by way of right view. The meaning in the remaining four triads should be understood in the way already stated. For the meaning included in the first tetrad by the tetrad on bodily volitions is included in the remaining four triads by the method of urging on the seven kinds of fruitful clinging, etc., as fruitful,🔽(by the method of urging on the seven kinds of fruitless clinging, etc., as fruitless,🔽(see D.i,65,66). For here the third tetrad includes the fruitful by way of the fruit of the fruitful, etc., and the fruitless by way of the fruit of the fruitless, etc.

original: sesacatukkattayena ca sattaparāmāsatāya codanānayo vuttoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Amarāvikkhepiko pana sassatādīnaṃ attano aruccanatāya sabbattha “evantipi me no”tiādinā
analyzed: ca satta parāmāsa tāya codanā nayaḥ vuttaḥ iti daṭṭhabbam  pana sassata ādīnam attanaḥ aruccanatāya sabbattha me no ti ādinā
translated: or by way of right view. The meaning of the remaining three sets of four should be understood in the same way as the first set of four. For the meaning included in the first set of four by the proposition of the result of merit, etc., is included by the remaining three sets of four by the method of the proposition of the result of the merit, etc., of the seven misapprehensions, and by the method of the proposition of the result of the merit, etc., of self-misapprehension. For here the method of the proposition of the result of the merit, etc., is stated by the third set of four, and the method of the proposition of the seven misapprehensions is stated by the remaining three sets of four. This is how it should be regarded.

original: vikkhepaññeva karoti. Tattha “evantipi me no”tiādi tattha tattha pucchitākārapaṭisedhanavasena
analyzed: vikkhepaññā eva karoti tattha evam ti pi me na utiādi tattha tattha pucchita ākāra paṭisedhana vasena
translated: But the one who is confused about the immortal, because he does not like the eternal, etc., makes confusion everywhere by “I do not say ‘it is so’ ” , etc. Herein, “I do not say ‘it is so’ ” , etc., is the showing of the mode of confusion by the denial of the mode of questioning here and there.

original: vikkhepākāradassanaṃ. Kasmā pana vikkhepavādino paṭikkhepova sabbattha vutto. Nanu
analyzed: vikkhepa ākāra dassanam kasmā pana vikkhepa vādino paṭikkhepaḥ uva sabbattha vuttaḥ nanu
translated: But why is the denial of the one who is confused about the immortal stated everywhere?

original: vikkhepapakkhassa “evameva”nti anujānanampi vikkhepapakkhe avaṭṭhānato yuttarūpaṃ
analyzed: vikkhepa pakkhassa evam evanti anujānanam pi vikkhepa pakkhe avaṭṭhānataḥ yutta rūpam
translated: and the permission given in the phrase “So too, bhikkhus” is appropriate as a refusal to stand by the side of the proliferationists.

original: siyāti? Na, tatthāpi tassa sammūḷhattā, paṭikkhepavaseneva ca vikkhepavādassa pavattanato.
analyzed: siyā ti na tattha api tassa sammūḷha ttā paṭikkhepa vasena iva ca vikkhepa vādassa pavattanato
translated: “But is it not so?”—No, because he is confused even there, and because the proliferationists’ doctrine occurs only as a denial.

original: Tathā hi sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto raññā ajātasattunā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho
analyzed: tathā hi sañcayaḥ belaṭṭha puttaḥ raññā ajātasattunā sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ
