translated: For when Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta was asked by King Ajātasattu about the fruit of recluseship visible here and now,

original: paralokatthitādīnaṃ paṭisedhanamukheneva vikkhepaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: para loka tthita ādīnam paṭisedhana mukhena iva vikkhepam
translated: he gave a proliferation by way of a denial of the existence of another world, etc.,

original: Etthāha – nanu cāyaṃ sabbopi amarāvikkhepiko kusalādayo dhamme, paralokatthitādīni🔽ca yathābhūtaṃ anavabujjhamāno tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho pucchāya vikkhepanamattaṃ🔽āpajjati, atha tassa kathaṃ diṭṭhigatikabhāvo siyā. Na hi avattukāmassa viya pucchitatthamajānantassa
analyzed: ettha āha nanu ca ayam sabbaḥ api amara avikkhepikaḥ kusala ādayaḥ dhamme para loka tthita ādīni  ca yathābhūtam an avabujjhamāno tattha tattha pañham puṭṭhaḥ pucchāya vikkhepana mattam  āpajjati atha tassa katham diṭṭhigatika bhāvaḥ siyā na hi a vattu kāmassa viya pucchitattham a jānantassa
translated: Here it may be said: But does not this all-and-nothingist, not understanding the profitable, etc., and the existence of another world, etc., as they are,🔽when asked here and there a question, merely proliferate the question by evasive statements?🔽Then how can he be a theorist? For it is not proper to call one a theorist merely because he proliferates a question like one who does not want to say anything and does not know the answer to the question.

original: vikkhepakaraṇamattena diṭṭhigatikatā yuttāti? Vuccate – na heva kho pucchāya vikkhepakaraṇamattena
analyzed: vikkhepa karaṇa mattena diṭṭhigatika tā yuttā iti vuccate na ha iva kho pucchāya vikkhepa karaṇa mattena
translated: It may be replied: It is not merely by proliferating a question

original: tassa diṭṭhigatikatā, atha kho micchābhinivesavasena. Sassatābhinivesavasena hi micchābhiniviṭṭhoyeva
analyzed: tassa diṭṭhigatika tā atha kho micchā abhinivesa vasena sassata abhinivesa vasena hi micchā abhiniviṭṭhaḥ yeva
translated: and his view is due to his adherence to the wrong way of entry, that is, to his adherence to eternalism.

original: puggalo mandabuddhitāya kusalādidhamme, paralokatthitādīni ca yāthāvato appaṭibujjhamāno
analyzed: puggalaḥ manda buddhi tāya kusala ādi dhamme para loka tthita ādīni ca yāthāvataḥ a paṭibujjhamānaḥ
translated: For it is only a person who is misapprehended by adherence to eternalism who, because of his dullness, does not understand the profitable, etc., and the existence of the world beyond, etc., as they are in reality,

original: attanā aviññātassa atthassa paraṃ viññāpetumasakkuṇeyyatāya musāvādabhayena ca vikkhepamāpajjatīti.
analyzed: attanā a viññātassa atthassa param viññāpetum asakkuṇeyyatāya musāvāda bhayena ca vikkhepam āpajjati iti
translated: and who, because he is unable to make others understand what he himself does not understand, and because he is afraid of lying, resorts to equivocation.

original: Tathā hi vakkhati “yāsaṃ satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo”ti atha vā
analyzed: tathā hi vakkhati yāsam sattā iva uccheda diṭṭhiyo sesā sassata diṭṭhiyo ti atha vā
translated: For it is said: “Those who hold the annihilation view are of two kinds: the rest hold the eternalism view” .

original: puññapāpānaṃ, tabbipākānañca anavabodhena, asaddahanena ca tabbisayāya pucchāya vikkhepakaraṇameva
analyzed: puñña pāpānam tad vipākānam ca anavabodhena asaddahanena ca tad visayāya pucchāya vikkhepa karaṇam eva
translated: Or else, because of his failure to understand and to have faith in merit and demerit and their results, he resorts to equivocation in answering a question that refers to them,

original: sundaranti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā visuṃyevesā ekā diṭṭhi
analyzed: khantim rucim uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā ekā diṭṭhi
translated: and he adheres to it by arousing liking and approval for it as a fine thing. Then that view is a separate one arisen in him,

original: sattabhaṅgadiṭṭhi viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tathā ca vuttaṃ “pariyantarahitā diṭṭhigatikassa
analyzed: satta bhaṅga diṭṭhi viya iti daṭṭhabbam tathā ca vuttam pariyanta rahitā diṭṭhi gatikassa
translated: like the view of the annihilation of beings. And it is said: “The view of one who has entered a wrong path

original: diṭṭhi ceva vācā” cāti. Yaṃ panetaṃ vuttaṃ “imepi cattāro pubbe pavattadhammānusāreneva
analyzed: diṭṭhi ca iva vācā ca ati yam pana itam vuttam ime pi cattāro pubbe pavatta dhamma anusārena iva
translated: and view and speech.

original: diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā”ti, tadetassa amarāvikkhepavādassa
analyzed: diṭṭhiyā gahita ttā pubbanta kappikesu paviṭṭhā ti tat etassa amarā vikkhepa vādassa
translated: But it was said above that these four are included among the speculators about the past because they hold their view as a result of pursuing the past by the method of the fourfold logic.🔽This is said by way of their inclusion in eternalism.

original: sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgahavaseneva vuttaṃ. Kathaṃ panassa sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgahoti? Ucchedavasena
analyzed: sassata diṭṭhi saṅgaha vasena iva vuttam katham pana assa sassata diṭṭhi saṅgaho ti uccheda vasena
translated: But how is that? Because they do not insist on annihilationism.

original: anabhinivesanato. Natthi hi koci dhammānaṃ yathābhūtavedī vivādabahulattā lokassa.
analyzed: anabhinivesanataḥ natthi hi koci dhammānam yathā bhūta vedī vivāda bahula ttā lokassa
translated: For there is no one who knows things as they really are because of the abundance of disputes in the world.

original: “Evameva”nti pana saddantarena dhammanijjhānanā anādikālikā loke, tasmā sassatalesassa
analyzed: evam evanti pana sadda antarena dhamma nijjhānanā anādikālikā loke tasmā
translated: But the world has always had the habit of speculating about things by means of the word “thus” .

original: ettha labbhanato sassatadiṭṭhiyā etassa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Adhiccasamuppannavādavaṇṇanā🔽67. Adhicca yadicchakaṃ yaṃ kiñci kāraṇaṃ kassaci buddhipubbaṃ vinā samuppannoti
analyzed: ettha labbhanataḥ sassata diṭṭhiyāḥ etassa saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo  adhicca samuppanna vāda vaṇṇanā  adhicca yadicchakam yam kiñci kāraṇam kassaci buddhi pubbam vinā samuppanno ti
translated: So eternalism is found here, and that is why this view should be regarded as included in eternalism.🔽1. The doctrine of fortuitous origin

original: attalokasaññitānaṃ khandhānaṃ adhiccuppattiākārārammaṇadassanaṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ
analyzed: atta loka saññitānam khandhānam adhiccuppatti ākāra ārammaṇa dassanam adhicca samuppannam
translated: Fortuitous origin: fortuitous origin is the seeing of the occurrence of the aggregates called “self” and “world” without cause, without a cause that is prior to them, without a cause that is the same as they are.

original: tadākārasannissayeneva pavattito, tadākārasahacaritato ca yathā “mañcā ghosanti,
analyzed: tad ākāra sannissayena iva pavattitaḥ tad ākāra sahacaritataḥ ca yathā mañcāḥ ghosanti
translated: and it occurs and is associated with that mode of appearance, just as it is said that “the beds cry out” and “the stumps run about” when people are frightened by a ghost in a bed or by a stump in the dark.

original: kuntā pacarantī”ti, adhiccasamuppannadassanaṃ vā antapadalopena adhiccasamuppannaṃ
analyzed: kuntā pacaranti iti adhicca samuppanna dassanam vā anta pada lopena adhicca samuppannam
translated: Or the view of fortuitous origination is called “fortuitous” by ellipsis of the middle term,🔽just as “materiality is form” is said.

original: yathā “rūpabhavo rūpa”nti, imamatthaṃ sandhāya “adhiccasamuppanno”tiādi vuttaṃ. Akāraṇasamuppannanti
analyzed: yathā rūpa bhavaḥ imam attham sandhāya adhicca samuppannaḥ tiādi vuttam akāraṇa samuppannanti
translated: The meaning intended is this: “arisen by chance” means arisen without a cause,

original: kāraṇamantarena yadicchakaṃ samuppannaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇam antarena yad icchakam samuppannam
translated: as if by luck.

original: 68-73. Asaññasattāti ettha etaṃ asaññāvacananti attho. Desanāsīsanti desanāya jeṭṭhakaṃ
analyzed: asañña sattā ati ettha etam asaññā vacanam ti atthaḥ desanā sīsam ti desanāya jeṭṭhakam
translated: “Beings without consciousness”: the meaning is that this is a designation for the immaterial realm.🔽“The beginning of the teaching”: the foremost of the teaching,

original: padhānabhāvena gahitattā, tena saññaṃ dhuraṃ katvā bhagavatā ayaṃ desanā katā, na
analyzed: padhāna bhāvena gahita ttā tena saññam dhuram katvā bhagavatā ayam desanā katā na
translated: because it is taken as the chief thing. The Blessed One gave this teaching with perception as the burden,

original: pana tattha aññesaṃ arūpadhammānampi atthitāyāti dasseti, tenevāha “acittuppādā”tiādi.
analyzed: pana tattha aññesam arūpa dhammānam pi atthitāya ati dasseti tena iva āha acittuppāda itiādi
translated: but he does not show that other immaterial states are not present there. That is why he says “without the arising of consciousness,” etc.

original: Bhagavā hi yathā lokuttaradhammaṃ desento samādhiṃ, paññaṃ vā dhuraṃ katvā deseti,
analyzed: bhagavā hi yathā lokuttara dhammam desentaḥ samādhim paññam vā dhuram katvā deseti
translated: For just as the Blessed One gives the supramundane Dhamma as a teaching with concentration or understanding as the burden,

original: evaṃ lokiyadhammaṃ desento cittaṃ, saññaṃ vā. Tattha “yasmiṃ samaye lokuttaraṃ jhānaṃ🔽bhāveti, pañcaṅgiko sammāsamādhi pañcañāṇiko sammāsamādhi, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā🔽parikkhīṇā hontī”ti, tathā “yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hoti,
analyzed: evam lokiya dhammaṃ desento cittam saññam vā tattha yasmin samaye lokuttaram jhānam  bhāveti pañcaṅgiko sammāsamādhi pañcañāṇiko sammāsamādhi paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā  parikkhīṇāḥ honti iti tathā yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam cittam uppannam hoti
translated: So when he teaches mundane ideas, he teaches the mind or perception.

original: kiṃ citto tvaṃ bhikkhu manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, santi bhikkhave, sattā nānattakāyā🔽nānattasaññino, nevasaññānāsaññāyatana”nti ca evamādīni suttāni etassatthassa sādhakāni.
analyzed: kiṃcitto tvam bhikkhu manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammāḥ santi bhikkhave sattāḥ nānatta kāyāḥ  nānatta saññinaḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti ca evamādīni suttāni etassa atthassa sādhakāni
translated: Herein, the sutta passage beginning, “When he develops the supramundane jhāna, right concentration with five factors is concentration upon learning, and with five kinds of knowledge is concentration upon what is to be done, and when he sees with understanding, his taints are destroyed” , and that beginning, “When a profitable mind-element occurs in the sensual realm, bhikkhu, what is the mind then? ” , and that beginning, “Ideas have mind as their forerunner, mind as their chief, mind-made, with mind as their resort” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings with multiplicity of body and multiplicity of perception, namely, human beings, some gods, and some denizens of the nether world” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings with multiplicity of body and unity of perception, namely, the Gods of the Brahma-order generated by the first … second … third … fourth jhāna” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings with unity of body and multiplicity of perception, namely, the Gods of Streaming Radiance” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings with unity of body and unity of perception, namely, the Gods of Refulgent Glory” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings without perception, namely, the Gods Without Perception” , and that beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are beings without perception or with non-existence of perception, namely, the Gods of the Base of Neither Perception nor Non-Perception” , all help to prove this meaning.

original: Titthaṃ vuccati micchāladdhi tattheva bāhullena paribbhamanato taranti bālā etthāti🔽katvā, tadeva anappakānamanatthānaṃ titthiyānañca sañjātidesaṭṭhena, nivāsaṭṭhena
analyzed: tittham vuccati micchāladdhi tattha iva bāhullena paribbhamanataḥ taranti bālāḥ ettha ati  katvā tat eva anappakānam anatthānam titthiyānam ca sañjāti desa ṭṭhena nivāsa ṭṭhena
translated: A ford is a wrong crossing, it seems, because fools cross there in great numbers.🔽So it is a place for the non-beneficial, and it is a place for the various kinds of sectarians in the sense of being the place of their origin or in the sense of being the place where they live.🔽So the word titthāyatana is a place for the various kinds of sectarians.

original: vā āyatananti titthāyatanaṃ, tasmiṃ, aññatitthiyasamayeti attho. Titthiyā hi upapattivisese
analyzed: vā āyatanam ti titthāyatanam tasmim añña titthiya samaye ti attho titthiyāḥ hi upapatti visese
translated: The meaning is: with sectarians of other views. For the various kinds of sectarians are

original: vimuttisaññino, saññāvirāgāvirāgesu ādīnavānisaṃsadassāvino ca hutvā asaññasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: vimutti saññinaḥ saññā virāga avirāgesu ādīnava anisaṃsa dassāvinaḥ ca hutvā asañña samāpattim
translated: and they are visioners of danger in perception in the case of those who are not passionless and in the case of those who are passionless, and they are visioners of the escape in the case of those who are not passionless.

original: nibbattetvā akkhaṇabhūmiyaṃ upapajjanti, na sāsanikā, tena vuttaṃ “ekacco titthāyatane🔽pabbajitvā”ti. Vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvāti catutthe bhūtakasiṇe paṭhamādīni tīṇi
analyzed: nibbattetvā akkhaṇabhūmiyam upapajjanti na sāsanikā tena vuttam ekaccaḥ titthāyatane  pabbajitvā ti vāyokasiṇe parikammam katvā ati catutthe bhūtakasiṇe paṭhama ādīni tīṇi
translated: They attain the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness and are reborn in the plane of non-percipient beings. They are not of my Dispensation. That is why it is said, “some go forth among the sectarians” .🔽Having done the preliminary work on the air kasiṇa: having produced the first three jhānas in the fourth primary kasiṇa, that is to say, in the earth kasiṇa, and so on, and having obtained mastery in them, and then, after emerging from the third jhāna,

original: jhānāni nibbattetvā tatiyajjhāne ciṇṇavasī hutvā tato vuṭṭhāya catutthajjhānādhigamāya
analyzed: jhānāni nibbattetvā tatiya jhāne ciṇṇavasī hutvā tatas vuṭṭhāya catuttha jhāna adhigamāya
translated: having done the preliminary work for the attainment of the fourth jhāna,

original: parikammaṃ katvā, tenevāha “catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā”ti.🔽Kasmā panettha vāyokasiṇeyeva parikammaṃ vuttanti? Vuccate – yatheva hi rūpapaṭibhāgabhūtesu🔽kasiṇavisesesu rūpavibhāvanena rūpavirāgabhāvanāsaṅkhāto arūpasamāpattiviseso sacchikarīyati,
analyzed: parikammam katvā tena iva āha catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā iti  kasmā pana ittha vāyo kasiṇeya iva parikammam vuttanti vuccate yathā iva hi rūpa paṭibhāga bhūtesu  kasiṇa visesesu rūpa vibhāvanena rūpa virāga bhāvanā saṅkhātaḥ arūpa samāpatti viseso sacchikarīyati
translated: he produces the fourth jhāna. That is why it is said, “having produced the fourth jhāna” .🔽But why is the preliminary work said here only in the case of the air kasiṇa?🔽It can be said as follows. Just as, in the case of the different kasiṇas that are the counterpart of visible objects, the different immaterial states consisting in the development of the signless deliverance, that is to say, the immaterial states consisting in the surmounting of visible objects, are realized by means of the surmounting of the kasiṇa,

original: evaṃ aparibyattaviggahatāya arūpapaṭibhāgabhūte kasiṇavisese arūpavibhāvanena arūpavirāgabhāvanāsaṅkhāto
analyzed: evam a paribyatta viggaha tāya arūpa paṭibhāga bhūte kasiṇa visese arūpa vibhāvanena arūpa virāga bhāvanā saṅkhātaḥ
translated: so too, in the case of the different kasiṇas that are the counterpart of the immaterial states, the different immaterial states consisting in the development of the passionless deliverance, that is to say, the immaterial states consisting in the surmounting of the immaterial states, are realized by means of the surmounting of the kasiṇa.

original: rūpasamāpattiviseso adhigamīyati, tasmā ettha “saññā rogo saññā gaṇḍo”tiādinā, “dhi
analyzed: rūpa samāpatti visesaḥ tasmai ettha saññā rogaḥ saññā gaṇḍo ti ādinā dhi
translated: and the difference in the jhāna is discerned, therefore here in the passage beginning, “Perception is a disease, perception is a tumour” , “perception is a dart” ,

original: cittaṃ, dhibbate taṃ citta”ntiādinā ca nayena arūpapavattiyā ādīnavadassanena, tadabhāve
analyzed: cittam dhibbate tam cittam ti ādinā ca nayena arūpa pavattiyā ādīnava dassanena tad abhāve
translated: The difference in the attainment of the formless states is understood. So here the making of the formless states is by seeing the danger in the occurrence of the formless states in the way beginning, “Perception is a disease, perception is a tumour” , and in the way beginning, “Fie on this perception, fie on this cognizance” , and by deciding on the peace and excellence of the absence of them in the way beginning, “Non-perception is bliss” , “Non-perception is bliss” .

original: ca santapaṇītabhāvasanniṭṭhānena rūpasamāpattiyā abhisaṅkharaṇaṃ, rūpavirāgabhāvanā🔽pana saddhiṃ upacārena arūpasamāpattiyo visesena paṭhamāruppajjhānaṃ. Yadi evaṃ “paricchinnākāsakasiṇepī”ti
analyzed: ca santa paṇīta bhāva sanniṭṭhānena rūpa samāpattiyāḥ abhisaṅkharaṇam rūpa virāga bhāvanā  pana saddhim upacārena arūpa samāpattiyaḥ visesena paṭhama āruppa jhānam yadi evam paricchinna ākāsa kasiṇe pi iti
translated: The development of dispassion for materiality is the first immaterial jhāna with its accessories.🔽If that is so, then it should be said of the limited-space kasiṇa too,🔽since it has a likeness to the formless states.

original: vattabbaṃ. Tassāpi hi arūpapaṭibhāgatā labbhatīti? Vattabbamevetaṃ kesañci, avacanaṃ🔽pana pubbācariyehi aggahitabhāvena. Yathā hi rūpavirāgabhāvanā virajjanīyadhammabhāvamatte
analyzed: vattabbam tassa api hi arūpa paṭibhāga tā labbhati iti vattabbam eva etam kesañci avacanam  pana pubba ācariyehi agga hita bhāvena yathā hi rūpa virāga bhāvanā virajjanīya dhamma bhāva matte
translated: It should certainly be said, but some do not say it.🔽The reason why some do not say it is that it was not taken up by the former teachers.🔽For just as the development of dispassion for materiality is the first immaterial jhāna with its accessories, since it is completed by the mere state of dispassion that is the opposite of what is to be dispassionate towards,

original: parinibbindā (virajjanīyadhamma bhāvamattena parinipphannā dī. ni. ṭī. 1.6-73) virajjanīyadhammapaṭibhāgabhūte
analyzed: parinibbindā virajjanīya dhamma bhāva mattena parinipphannā virajjanīya dhamma paṭibhāga bhūte
translated: so too the limited-space kasiṇa is the first immaterial jhāna with its accessories, since it is completed by the mere state of dispassion that is the opposite of what is to be dispassionate towards.

original: ca visayavisese pātubhavati, evaṃ arūpavirāgabhāvanāpīti vuccamāne na koci virodho.
analyzed: ca visaya visese pātubhavati evam arūpa virāga bhāvanā api iti vuccamāne na koci virodhaḥ
translated: and the object is manifested in a particular way, so too there is no contradiction in saying that the development of the dispassion that leads to the immaterial states is a preliminary work to the fourth immaterial jhāna.

original: Titthiyeheva pana tassā samāpattiyā paṭipajjitabbatāya, tesañca visayapadesanimittasseva🔽tassa jhānassa paṭipattito taṃ kāraṇaṃ passantehi pubbācariyehi catuttheyeva bhūtakasiṇe
analyzed: titthiyehi iva pana tassā samāpattiyāḥ paṭipajjitabba tāya tesam ca visaya padesa nimittassa iva  tassa jhānassa paṭipattitaḥ tam kāraṇam passantehi pubba ācariyehi catutthe iya iva bhūta kasiṇe
translated: But because it is only the sectarians who practice for that attainment, and because the practice of that jhāna is only of the object’s sign consisting of a place,🔽the former teachers saw the reason for saying that the development of the dispassion that leads to the immaterial states is a preliminary work to the fourth, that is, the air kasiṇa,

original: arūpavirāgabhāvanāparikammaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kiñca bhiyyo – vaṇṇakasiṇesu viya
analyzed: arūpa virāga bhāvanā parikammam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam kiñca bhiyyas vaṇṇa kasiṇesu viya
translated: and it should be regarded thus. And what is more, in the first three earth kasiṇas, as in the colour kasiṇas,

original: purimabhūtakasiṇattayepi vaṇṇapaṭicchāyāva paṇṇattiārammaṇaṃ jhānassa lokavohārānurodheneva
analyzed: purima bhūta kasiṇattaye pi vaṇṇa paṭicchāyā ava paṇṇatti ārammaṇam jhānassa loka vohāra anurodhena iva
translated: the appearance of the colour is the concept- object of the jhāna, which occurs in conformity with the ordinary man’s way of looking at things.

original: pavattito, evañca katvā visuddhimagge pathavīkasiṇassa ādāsacandamaṇḍalūpamāvacanañca
analyzed: pavattitaḥ evam ca katvā visuddhi magge pathavī kasiṇassa ādāsa canda maṇḍala upamā vacanañca
translated: And it is in this way that the simile of the looking-glass moon in the Path of Purification is tenable.

original: samatthitaṃ hoti. Catutthe pana bhūtakasiṇe bhūtapaṭicchāyā eva jhānassa gocarabhāvaṃ
analyzed: samatthitam hoti catutthe pana bhūtakasiṇe bhūta paṭicchāyāḥ eva jhānassa gocara bhāvaṃ
translated: But in the fourth earth kasiṇa the appearance of the earth kasiṇa itself is the object of the jhāna.

original: gacchatīti tasseva arūpapaṭibhāgatā yuttā, tasmā vāyokasiṇeyeva parikammaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: gacchati iti tassa iva arūpa paṭibhāga tā yuttā tasmā vāyokasiṇeya iva parikammam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: “It goes” is appropriate only for the counterpart of the formless. Therefore it should be understood that the preliminary work is stated only in the air kasiṇa.

original: Kathaṃ passatīti āha “citte satī”tiādi. Santoti nibbuto, diṭṭhadhammanibbānametanti
analyzed: katham passati iti āha citte sati itiādi santaḥ ti nibbutaḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam etat ti
translated: “When there is consciousness” : he sees thus. “Tranquil” : extinguished. The meaning is, “Nibbāna here and now.”

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Kālaṃ katvāti maraṇaṃ katvā, yo vā manussaloke jīvanakālo upatthambhakapaccayehi🔽karīyati, taṃ karitvātipi attho. Asaññasattesu nibbattatīti asaññasattasaṅkhāte sattanikāye
analyzed: vuttam hoti kālam katvā ati maraṇam katvā yaḥ vā manussa loke jīvana kālaḥ upatthambhaka paccayehi  tam atipi atthaḥ asañña sattesu nibbattati iti asañña satta saṅkhāte satta nikāye
translated: “Having made time” : having made death. Or the meaning is, “having made the time of living in the human world, which is made by the supporting conditions that maintain life.”🔽“Is reborn among the non-percipient beings” : he is reborn only by way of a material rebirth-linking in the group of beings called “non-percipient beings” .

original: rūpapaṭisandhivaseneva upapajjati, aññesu vā cakkavāḷesu tassā bhūmiyā atthitāya
analyzed: rūpa paṭisandhi vasena iva upapajjati aññesu vā cakkavāḷesu tassā bhūmiyāḥ atthitāya
translated: Or, since that plane does not exist in other world systems, the meaning can be understood as “in the various kinds of existence here in this world system.”

original: anekavidhabhāvaṃ sandhāya puthuvacananiddesotipi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Idhevāti pañcavokārabhaveyeva.
analyzed: anekavidha bhāvam sandhāya daṭṭhabbam idhā iva ati
translated: “Here” : in the five-constituent existence.

original: Tatthāti asaññībhave. Yadi rūpakkhandhamattameva asaññībhave pātubhavati, kathaṃ
analyzed: tattha ati asaññībhave yadi rūpa kkhandha mattam eva asaññībhave pātubhavati katham
translated: “There” : in the non-percipient existence. If only the material aggregate becomes manifest in the non-percipient existence,

original: arūpasannissayena vinā tattha rūpaṃ pavattati, nanu siyā arūpasannissitāyeva rūpakkhandhassa
analyzed: arūpa sannissayena vinā tattha rūpam pavattati nanu siyā arūpa sannissitāya iva rūpa kkhandhassa
translated: And is it not possible for the materiality aggregate to arise supported by the immaterial only, since it is not seen to arise in that way in the five-constituent becoming here?

original: uppatti idheva pañcavokārabhave tathā uppattiyā adassanatoti? Nāyamanuyogo aññatthāpi
analyzed: uppatti idha iva pañcavokāra bhave tathā uppattiyāḥ adassanato ti na ayam anuyogaḥ aññattha api
translated: This is not a proper line of inquiry, since it is not found elsewhere either.

original: appaviṭṭho, kathaṃ pana rūpasannissayena vinā arūpadhātuyā arūpaṃ pavattatīti. Idampi
analyzed: appaviṭṭhaḥ katham pana rūpa sannissayena vinā arūpa dhātuyā arūpam pavattati iti idam pi
translated: But how does the immaterial come to be without support by materiality?🔽Because it is of the same kind as that. Why? Because it is not seen here.

original: hi tena samānajātiyameva. Kasmā? Idheva adassanato, kathañca kabaḷīkārāhārena vinā
analyzed: hi tena samāna jātiyam eva kasmai idha iva a dassanato kathañca kabaḷīkāra āhārena vinā
translated: And how does materiality come to be without support by nutritive essence?

original: rūpadhātuyā rūpaṃ pavattatīti. Idampi ca taṃsabhāvameva, kiṃ kāraṇā? Idha adassanatoyeva.
analyzed: rūpadhātuyā rūpam pavattati iti idam pi ca kim kāraṇā
translated: Because it is of the same kind as that. Why? Because it is not seen here.

original: Iti aññatthāpi tathā pavattidassanato, kimetena aññanidassanena idheva anuyogena.🔽Apica yathā yassa cittasantānassa nibbattikāraṇaṃ rūpe avigatataṇhaṃ, tassa saha
analyzed: iti aññattha api tathā pavatti dassanato kim etena añña nidassanena idha iva anuyogena  apica yathā yassa citta santānassa nibbatti kāraṇam rūpe avigata taṇham tassa saha
translated: So since it is seen to occur in the same way elsewhere too, what is the use of this line of inquiry here?🔽Besides, the materiality that occurs in the life-continuum of one whose craving for materiality is unabandoned arises together with materiality because of the cause of its arising.

original: rūpena sambhavato rūpaṃ nissāya pavatti rūpasāpekkhatāya kāraṇassa. Yassa pana nibbattikāraṇaṃ
analyzed: rūpena sambhavataḥ rūpam nissāya pavatti rūpa sāpekkha tāya kāraṇassa yassa pana nibbatti kāraṇam
translated: So it occurs supported by materiality because of the dependence of the cause. But the immaterial that occurs in the life-continuum of one whose craving for materiality is abandoned arises without materiality because of the cause of its arising.

original: rūpe vigatataṇhaṃ, tassa vinā rūpena pavatti rūpanirapekkhatāya kāraṇassa, evaṃ yassa
analyzed: rūpe vigata taṇham tassa vinā rūpena pavatti rūpa nirapekkha tāya kāraṇassa evam yassa
translated: When he is free from craving for material form, his occurrence is without regard for material form as cause,

original: rūpappabandhassa nibbattikāraṇaṃ arūpe vigatataṇhaṃ, tassa vinā arūpena pavatti arūpanirapekkhatāya🔽kāraṇassa, evaṃ bhāvanābalābhāvato pañcavokārabhave rūpārūpasambhavo viya, bhāvanābalena
analyzed: rūpa ppabandhassa nibbatti kāraṇam arūpe vigata taṇham tassa vinā arūpena pavatti arūpa nirapekkha tāya  kāraṇassa evam bhāvanā bala abhāvataḥ pañcavokāra bhave rūpa arūpa sambhavaḥ viya bhāvanā balena
translated: When he is free from craving for the immaterial, his occurrence is without regard for the immaterial as cause,

original: catuvokārabhave arūpasseva sambhavo viya ca. Asaññībhavepi bhāvanābalena rūpasseva🔽sambhavo daṭṭhabboti.
analyzed: catuvokāra bhave arūpassa iva sambhavaḥ ca asaññībhave pi bhāvanā balena rūpassa iva  sambhavaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ iti
translated: just as the occurrence of material form in the five-constituent becoming is due to the power of development, and just as the occurrence of the immaterial only is due to the power of development in the four-constituent becoming.🔽The occurrence of material form only due to the power of development should be regarded as in the non-percipient becoming too.

original: Kathaṃ pana tattha kevalo rūpappabandho paccuppannapaccayarahito cirakālaṃ pavattatīti
analyzed: katham pana tattha kevalaḥ rūpa ppabandhaḥ paccuppanna paccaya rahitaḥ cirakālam pavattati iti
translated: But how is it to be understood that the mere occurrence of the material continuum there goes on for a long time without the condition of the present?

original: paccetabbaṃ, kittakaṃ vā kālaṃ pavattatīti codanaṃ manasi katvā “yathā nāmā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: paccetabbam kittakam vā kālam pavattati iti codanam manasi katvā yathā nāma ati ādim āha
translated: Or how long does it go on? Anticipating such questions, he said, “Just as, in the first place,”

original: Tena na kevalaṃ idha ceva aññattha ca vutto āgamoyeva etadatthañāpane, atha kho ayaṃ
analyzed: tena na kevalam idha ca iva aññattha ca vuttaḥ āgamaḥ yā iva etad attha ñāpane atha kho ayam
translated: and so on. For the purpose of understanding this is not only the tradition stated here and elsewhere, but also

original: panettha yuttīti dasseti. Jiyāvegukkhittoti dhanujiyāya vegena khipito. Jhānavego
analyzed: pana ittha yuttī iti dasseti jiyā vegukkhittaḥ ti dhanu jiyāya vegena khipitaḥ jhāna vegaḥ
translated: He shows the right method here. “Shot by the force of the bow”: shot by the force of the bowstring. “The force of jhāna”

original: nāma jhānānubhāvo phaladāne samatthatā. Tattakameva kālanti ukkaṃsato pañca mahākappasatāni.
analyzed: nāma jhāna anubhāvaḥ phala dāne samattha tā tattakam eva kālanti ukkaṃsataḥ pañca mahā kappa satāni
translated: is the potency of jhāna, the ability to give a fruit. “The time it takes to do that”: at the most, five hundred great eons.

original: Tiṭṭhantīti yathānibbattairiyāpathameva cittakammarūpakasadisā hutvā tiṭṭhanti. Jhānavegeti
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti iti yathā nibbatta iriyāpatham eva citta kamma rūpaka sadisāḥ hutvā tiṭṭhanti jhāna vega iti
translated: “Lasts”: it lasts like a piece of work in wrought iron, in the same posture in which it was created. “By the force of jhāna”:

original: asaññasamāpattiparikkhitte catutthajjhānakammavege, pañcamajjhānakammavege vā. Antaradhāyatīti
analyzed: asañña samāpatti parikkhitte catuttha jjhāna kamma vege pañcama jhāna kamma vege vā antaradhāyati iti
translated: by the force of the jhāna-process that is delimited by the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, or by the force of the fifth jhāna-process. “It disappears”:

original: paccayanirodhena nirujjhati na pavattati. Idhāti kāmāvacarabhaveti attho aññattha🔽tesamanuppattito. Paṭisandhisaññāti paṭisandhicittuppādoyeva saññāsīsena vutto. Kathaṃ
analyzed: paccaya nirodhena nirujjhati na pavattati idha ati kāmāvacara bhave iti atthaḥ aññattha  tesam anuppattito paṭisandhi saññā ti paṭisandhi cittuppādaḥ yā iva saññā sīsena vutto katham
translated: it ceases with the cessation of its conditions; it does not continue. “Here”: in the sense sphere existence. Elsewhere

original: pana anekakappasatamatikkamena ciraniruddhato viññāṇato idha viññāṇamuppajjati. Na
analyzed: pana aneka kappa satama atikkamena cira niruddhataḥ viññāṇataḥ idha viññāṇam uppajjati na
translated: the arising of these is impossible. “Rebirth-linking perception”: the arising of rebirth-linking consciousness is called “perception” in the sense of a beginning. But how can consciousness arise here from consciousness that has ceased long ago, having passed over many eons?

original: hi niruddhe cakkhupasāde cakkhuviññāṇamuppajjamānaṃ diṭṭhanti? Nayidamekantato daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Niruddhampi hi cittaṃ samānajātikassa antarā anuppajjanato samanantarapaccayamattaṃ🔽hotiyeva, na bījaṃ. Bījaṃ pana kammameva, tasmā kammato bījabhūtato ārammaṇādīhi
analyzed: hi niruddhe cakkhu pasāde cakkhu viññāṇam uppajjamānam diṭṭhan ti na idam ekantataḥ daṭṭhabbam  niruddham pi hi cittam samāna jātikassa antarā an uppajjanataḥ samanantara paccaya mattam  na bījam bījam pana kammam eva tasmā kammataḥ bīja bhūtataḥ ārammaṇa ādīhi
translated: “When the eye-sensitivity has ceased, does eye-consciousness arise when it is seen?” This should not be regarded as a single case.🔽For when the consciousness has ceased, it is only the condition of being an immediately- antecedent condition that is present in the consciousness of the same kind that arises next without a break, but it is not a seed.

original: paccayehi asaññībhavato cutānaṃ kāmadhātuyā upapattiviññāṇaṃ hotiyeva, tenāha “idha
analyzed: paccayehi a saññībhavataḥ cutānam kāmadhātuyāḥ upapatti viññāṇam tena āha idha
translated: But the seed is only kamma, so the rebirth-linking consciousness arises in the sense sphere only from kamma that has been a seed, and it does so through the conditions of object, etc.,

original: paṭisandhisaññā uppajjatī”ti. Ettha ca yathā nāma utuniyāmena pupphaggahaṇe niyatakālānaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi saññā uppajjati iti ettha ca yathā nāma utu niyāmena puppha ggahaṇe niyata kālānam
translated: from those who have died in the non-percipient realm. That is why it is said, “Rebirth-linking perception arises here” .

original: rukkhānaṃ vidāraṇasaṅkhāte vekhe dinne vekhabalena aniyamatā hoti pupphaggahaṇassa,🔽evameva pañcavokārabhave avippayogena vattamānesu rūpārūpadhammesu rūpārūpavirāgabhāvanāsaṅkhāte
analyzed: rukkhānam vidāraṇa saṅkhāte vekhe dinne vekha balena aniyama tā hoti puppha ggahaṇassa  evam eva pañcavokāra bhave a vippayogena vattamānesu rūpa arūpa dhammesu rūpa arūpa virāga bhāvanā saṅkhāte
translated: And just as, when flowers are gathered according to the season, the trees that are cut down are not certain to flower again,🔽so too, when the development of the meditation subject consisting in the cutting down of the material and immaterial dhammas that occur in the five-constituent kind of becoming has been given,

original: vekhe dinne tassa samāpattivekhabalassa anurūpato arūpabhave, asaññabhave ca yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: vekhe dinne tassa samāpatti vekha balassa anurūpataḥ arūpa bhave asañña bhave ca yathākkamam
translated: the arising of the immaterial and non-percipient kinds of becoming is not certain, according to the strength of the development of the meditation subject consisting in the cutting down of the material and immaterial dhammas.

original: rūparahitā, arūparahitā ca khandhānaṃ pavatti hotīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Kasmā panettha puna saññuppādā ca pana “te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī”ti saññuppādo
analyzed: rūpa rahitā arūpa rahitā ca khandhānam pavatti hoti iti veditabbam  kasmā pana ittha puna saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti iti saññuppādo
translated: It should be understood that the occurrence of the aggregates is without materiality and without immateriality.🔽But why is the arising of perception stated here as the cause of their passing away thus: “And with the arising of perception, those devas pass away from that plane”?

original: tesaṃ cavanassa kāraṇabhāvena vutto, “saññuppādā”ti vacanaṃ vā kimatthadassananti🔽codanāya “yasmā panā”tiādimāha. Idha paṭisandhisaññuppādena tesaṃ cavanassa paññāyanato🔽ñāpakahetubhāvena vutto, “saññuppādā”ti vacanaṃ vā tesaṃ cavanassa paññāyanabhāvadassananti
analyzed: tesam cavanassa kāraṇa bhāvena vuttaḥ saññuppādā ti vacanam vā kim attha dassanam ti  codanāya yasmā pana ati ādim āha idha paṭisandhi saññā uppādena tesam cavanassa paññāyanato  ñāpaka hetu bhāvena vuttaḥ saññuppādā ti vacanam vā tesam cavanassa paññāyana bhāva dassanam ti
translated: Or why is the expression “with the arising of perception” used to show the passing away?🔽The answer to the question is given by the words “But it is said, etc.” Here the passing away is shown by the arising of rebirth-linking perception.🔽Or the expression “with the arising of perception” is used to show the passing away by showing the cause of their passing away.

original: adhippāyo. “Saññuppādā”ti hi etassa saññuppādena hetubhūtena cavanti, saññuppādā
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ saññuppādā ati hi etassa saññuppādena hetu bhūtena cavanti saññuppādā
translated: This is the intention. For the meaning of the expression “with the arising of perception” is this: they pass away with the arising of perception, or they are those devas with the arising of perception.🔽The word “for” in the text is to be construed with “passing away” . “For the sake of peace” : for the sake of Nibbāna.🔽But here, since the passing away of those devas is shown by the arising of rebirth-linking perception,

original: vā uppādasaññā te devāti sambandho. Santabhāvāyāti nibbānāya. Nanu cettha jātisatasahassadasasaṃvaṭṭādīnamatthake,🔽tadabbhantare vā pavattāya asaññūpapattiyā vasena lābhīadhiccasamuppannikavādopi
analyzed: vā uppāda saññā te deva ati sambandho santa bhāvāya ati nibbānāya nanu ca ittha jāti sata sahassa dasa saṃvaṭṭa ādīnam atthake 🔽tad abbhantare vā pavattāya asaññu upapattiyā vasena lābhī adhiccasamuppannika vādaḥ api
translated: is it not the case that the doctrine of fortuitous origination is implied?

original: lābhīsassatavādo viya anekabhedo sambhavatīti? Saccameva, anantarattā pana āsannāya
analyzed: viya aneka bhedaḥ sambhavati iti saccam eva anantara ttā pana āsannāya
translated: and it is possible that it has many divisions like the doctrine of the self-existent one? —It is true, but because of its nearness to the present,🔽

original: asaññūpapattiyā vasena lābhīadhiccasamuppannikavādo nayadassanavasena ekova dassitoti
analyzed: asaññūpapattiyāḥ vasena lābhī adhicca samuppannika vādaḥ naya dassana vasena ekaḥ eva dassitoti
translated: and it is possible that it has many divisions like the doctrine of the gainer? —It is true, but because of its nearness to the doctrine of the fortuitous origination of the self-idea, the doctrine of the gainer is shown as one only by the method of the appearance of the self-idea in the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgahato adhiccasamuppannikavādassa sassatavāde
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam atha vā sassata diṭṭhi saṅgahataḥ adhiccasamuppannika vādassa sassata vāde
translated: Or alternatively, the method of teaching in the doctrine of the gainer is included in the doctrine of eternalism because of its inclusion in the doctrine of eternalism.

original: āgato sabbopi desanānayo yathāsambhavaṃ adhiccasamuppannikavādepi gahetabboti imassa
analyzed: āgataḥ sabbaḥ api desanā nayaḥ yathāsambhavam adhiccasamuppannika vāde pi gahetabbaḥ iti imassa
translated: And all the methods of teaching in the doctrine of fortuitous origination are to be taken in the doctrine of fortuitous origination in the way appropriate to each,

original: visesassa dassanatthaṃ bhagavatā lābhīadhiccasamuppannikavādo avibhajitvā dassito,
analyzed: visesassa dassana attham bhagavatā lābhī adhicca samuppannika vādaḥ a vibhajitvā dassitaḥ
translated: so the doctrine of the gainer and the doctrine of fortuitous origination are shown by the Blessed One without being distinguished in order to point out this difference.

original: avassañcassa sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgaho icchitabbo saṃkilesapakkhe sattānamajjhāsayassa
analyzed: avassañcassa sassata diṭṭhi saṅgaho icchitabbo saṃkilesa pakkhe sattānamajjhāsayassa
translated: And it is to be understood that the doctrine of fortuitous origination is included in the doctrine of eternalism,

original: sassatucchedavaseneva duvidhattā, tesu ca ucchedappasaṅgābhāvato. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: duvidha ttā tesu ca uccheda ppasaṅga abhāvato tathā hi aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: because the tendency of beings in the defilement section is twofold, namely, as eternalism and annihilationism, and because it is not included in annihilationism.🔽For in the Commentary the word āsaya is explained as follows: “The view of eternalism and the view of annihilationism” .

original: āsaya-saddassa atthuddhāravasena vuttaṃ “sassatucchedadiṭṭhi cā”ti, tathā ca vakkhati
analyzed: āsaya saddassa attha uddhāra vasena vuttam ca ati tathā ca vakkhati
translated: And it is said:

original: “yāsaṃ satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo”ti.🔽Nanu ca adhiccasamuppannikavādassa sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgaho na yutto “ahañhi pubbe nāhosi”ntiādivasena🔽pavattanato apubbasattapātubhāvagāhakattā. Sassatadiṭṭhi pana attano, lokassa ca
analyzed: yāsam sattā iva uccheda diṭṭhiyo sesā sassata diṭṭhiyo ti  nanu ca adhiccasamuppannika vādassa sassata diṭṭhi saṅgahaḥ na yuttaḥ aham hi pubbe na ahosin ti ādi vasena  pavattanato apubba satta pātubhāva gāhaka ttā sassata diṭṭhi pana attanaḥ lokassa ca
translated: “The first seven are annihilationist views, the rest are eternalist views.”🔽But is it not improper to include the doctrine of fortuitous origination in the eternalist view, since it occurs thus: “I was not in the past, but later arose”

original: sadābhāvagāhinī “atthitveva sassatisama”nti pavattanatoti? No na yutto anāgatakoṭiadassanena🔽sassataggāhasamavarodhattā. Yadipi hi ayaṃ vādo “somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato”ti
analyzed: sadābhāva gāhinī atthitvā iva pavattanato ti no na yuttaḥ anāgata koṭi adassanena  yadi api hi ayam vādaḥ somhi etarahi a hutvā santatāya pariṇataḥ iti
translated: and it does not cause the manifestation of a being not existing previously? But the eternalist view is one that grasps the existence of the self and the world🔽as having always existed, since it occurs thus: “It was, and it was mine” .

original: attano, lokassa ca atītakoṭiparāmasanavasena pavatto, tathāpi vattamānakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: attanaḥ lokassa ca atīta koṭi parāmasana vasena pavatto tathā api vattamāna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: —It is not improper. For although this doctrine occurs in the form of a retrospective survey of the self and the world thus: “I was in the past, and I changed in such and such a way,”

original: na tesaṃ katthaci anāgate pariyantaṃ passati, visesena ca paccuppannānāgatakālesu
analyzed: na tesam katthaci anāgate pariyantam passati visesena ca paccuppanna anāgata kālesu
translated: nevertheless, it does not see any end to them in the future,

original: apariyantadassanapabhāvito sassatavādo, yathāha “sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassatī”ti
analyzed: sassata vādaḥ yathā āha sassati samam tathā iva ṭhassati iti
translated: and the eternalist view is reinforced by the non-perception of an end in the present and the future, as is said: “It will be, and it will be mine” .

original: yadevaṃ siyā imassa ca vādassa, sassatavādādīnañca pubbantakappikesu saṅgaho na yuttoyeva🔽anāgatakālaparāmasanavasena pavattattāti? Yutto eva samudāgamassa atītakoṭṭhāsikattā.
analyzed: yat evam siyā imassa ca vādassa sassata vāda ādīnam ca pubbanta kappikesu saṅgahaḥ na yuttaḥ yeva  anāgata kāla parāmasana vasena pavatta ttā ati yuttaḥ eva samudāgamassa atīta koṭṭhāsika ttā
translated: and it is not proper that this view and the views of the past-limit theorists should be included among the eternalists.🔽But it is proper, because the occurrence of the round is the past section.

original: Tathā hi nesaṃ samudāgamo atītaṃsapubbenivāsañāṇehi, tappatirūpakānussavādipabhāvitehi🔽ca takkanehi saṅgahitoti, tathā ceva saṃvaṇṇitaṃ. Atha vā sabbattha appaṭihatañāṇacārena
analyzed: tathā hi na isam samudāgamaḥ atīta aṃsa pubbenivāsa ñāṇehi tad patirūpaka anussava ādipa bhāvitehi  ca takkanehi saṅgahitaḥ ti tathā ca iva saṃvaṇṇitam atha vā sabbattha appaṭihata ñāṇa cārena
translated: For their occurrence of the round is included in the knowledge of past lives and in the surmises that are inspired by the reports of those who have such knowledge.

original: dhammassāminā niravasesato agatiṃ, gatiñca yathābhūtaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā
analyzed: dhammassāminā niravasesataḥ agatim gatim ca yathābhūtam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā
translated: And that is how it is commended. Or alternatively, the Blessed One, whose knowledge and whose vision are unobstructed as to all things, has himself realized and experienced the past and future of all these views by means of his own knowledge and vision,

original: paveditā etā diṭṭhiyo, tasmā yāvatikā diṭṭhiyo bhagavatā desitā, yathā ca desitā,
analyzed: paveditāḥ etāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ tasmai yāvatikāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ bhagavatā desitā yathā ca desitā
translated: and he has announced them. Therefore they should be accepted just as they are stated and as far as they are stated by the Blessed One,

original: tāvatikā tathā ceva sanniṭṭhānato sampaṭicchitabbā, na cettha yuttivicāraṇā kātabbā
analyzed: tāvatikā tathā ca iva sanniṭṭhānato sampaṭicchitabbā na ca ittha yutti vicāraṇā kātabbā
translated: and they should not be subjected to reasoning by the intellect.🔽For the Blessed One’s province is inconceivable. And it is said:

original: buddhavisayattā. Acinteyyo hi buddhānaṃ buddhavisayo, tathā ca vakkhati “tattha na
analyzed: buddha visaya ttā acinteyyaḥ hi buddhānam buddha visayaḥ tathā ca vakkhati tattha na
translated: “The province of Buddhas is inconceivable,

original: ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabba”nti.
analyzed: ekantena kāraṇam pariyesitabbanti
translated: and the reason must be sought out entirely.”

original: Dutiyabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second recitation section is finished.

original: Aparantakappikavādavaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the views of the Westerners

original: 74. “Aparanteñāṇaṃ, aparantānudiṭṭhino”tiādīsu viya aparanta –saddānaṃ yathākkamaṃ🔽anāgatakālakoṭṭhāsavācakataṃ sandhāyāha “anāgatakoṭṭhāsasaṅkhāta”nti. “Pubbantaṃ
analyzed: aparanta iñāṇam aparanta anudiṭṭhino ti ādīsu viya aparanta saddānam yathākkamam  anāgata kāla koṭṭhāsa vācaka tam sandhāya āha anāgata koṭṭhāsa saṅkhātam ti pubbantam
translated: In the passages beginning “Ignorance of the future, holding a view about the future” (see n. 1), the words “future” and “future life” are used

original: kappetvā”tiādīsu vuttanayena “aparantaṃ kappetvā”tiādīsupi attho veditabbo. Visesamattameva cettha vakkhāma.
analyzed: kappetvā atiādīsu vutta nayena apara antam kappetvā iti ādīsu pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ visesa mattam eva ca ittha vakkhāma
translated: in the sense of the future time period. “Having made the future into the past” should be understood in the way stated in the passage beginning “Having made the past into the present” . We shall point out only the difference.

original: Saññīvādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññī vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The view that one who possesses perception exists after death

original: 75. Āghātanā uddhanti uddhamāghātanaṃ, maraṇato uddhaṃ pavatto attāti attho. “Uddhamāghātana”nti🔽pavatto vādo uddhamāghātano sahacaraṇavasena, taddhitavasena ca, antalopaniddeso
analyzed: āghātanāḥ uddham ti uddham āghātanam maraṇataḥ uddham pavattaḥ attā ati atthaḥ uddham āghātanam ti  pavattaḥ vādaḥ sahacaraṇa vasena taddhita vasena ca anta lopa niddeso
translated: “Uddhamāghātana” is a compound meaning “what is above the killing,” i.e., “what occurs after death.” “Uddhamāghātana”🔽is a bahubbīhi compound in the sense of “what occurs together with” or “what occurs after” the killing. It is also a tatpurisa compound

original: vā esa. So etesanti uddhamāghātanikā. Evaṃ saddato nipphannaṃ atthato eva dassetuṃ
analyzed: vā esa saḥ etesan ti uddham āghātanikā evam saddataḥ nipphannam atthataḥ eva dassetuṃ
translated: in the sense of “what is above the killing.” Those who hold this view are called “uddhamāghātanikā.” In order to show the meaning of the

original: “uddhamāghātanā attānaṃ vadantī”ti vuttaṃ, āghātanā uddhaṃ uparibhūtaṃ attabhāvanti
analyzed: uddham āghātanāḥ attānam vadanti iti vuttam āghātanāḥ uddham uparibhūtam atta bhāvanti
translated: “They kill themselves by killing what is above” is said. The meaning is: “They kill what is above, what is above them, the selfhood.”

original: attho. Te hi diṭṭhigatikā “uddhaṃ maraṇato attā nibbikāro”ti vadanti. “So etesa”ntiādinā
analyzed: te hi diṭṭhi gatikāḥ uddham maraṇataḥ attā nibbikāro ti vadanti saḥ etesan tiādinā
translated: For those who have views say that “the self is unaffected by death, which is above.” “They are called ‘those who have the view that what is perishing is the self’ ”:

original: assatthiyatthaṃ dasseti yathā “buddhamassa atthīti buddho”ti. Ayaṃ aṭṭhakathāto aparo🔽nayo – saññīti pavatto vādo saññī sahacaraṇādinayena, saññī vādo etesanti saññīvādā
analyzed: dasseti yathā buddham assa atthi iti buddhaḥ ti ayam aṭṭhakathātaḥ aparaḥ  nayo saññī iti pavattaḥ vādo saññī sahacaraṇa ādi nayena saññī vādo etesanti saññīvādā
translated: he shows the meaning of the term “those who have the view that what is perishing is the self” in the way that “one who has the Buddha is called ‘a Buddhist.’ ” This is another method from the commentary.

original: samāsavasena. Saññīvādo eva vādo etesanti hi attho.🔽76-77. Rūpī attāti ettha kasiṇarūpaṃ “attā”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu rūpavinimuttena
analyzed: samāsa vasena saññīvādaḥ eva vādaḥ etesan ti hi attho  rūpī attā ati ettha kasiṇa rūpam attā iti kasmai vuttam nanu rūpa vinimuttena
translated: “Those who have the view that what is perishing is the self” is a compound in the sense of “having” , according to the method of sahacariya, etc., or else “those who have the view that what is perishing is the self” is a compound in the sense of “having” , according to the method of samāsava. For the meaning is: “They are those who have the view that what is perishing is the self.”

original: attanā bhavitabbaṃ “rūpamassa atthī”ti vutte saññāya viya rūpassāpi attaniyattā.
analyzed: attanā bhavitabbam rūpam assa atthi iti vutte saññāya viya rūpassa api attaniyattā
translated: “The self is possessed of form”: why is the kasiṇa-form called “self”? Should not the self be something other than form, since when it is said that “he has form” the form is subject to the self in the same way as perception is?

original: Na hi “saññī attā”ti ettha saññā eva attā, atha kho “saññā assa atthī”ti atthena
analyzed: na hi saññī attā ati ettha saññā eva attā atha kho saññā assa atthi iti atthena
translated: For in the passage “the self is possessed of perception” it is not perception itself that is the self, but rather the meaning is that “he has perception.”

original: attaniyāva, tathā ca vuttaṃ “tattha pavattasaññañcassa ‘saññā’ti gahetvā”ti? Na kho🔽panetamevaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “rūpamassa atthīti rūpī”ti, atha kho “ruppanasīlo rūpī”ti.
analyzed: tathā ca vuttam tattha pavatta saññaṃ cassa saññā iti gahetvā iti na kho  pana itam evam daṭṭhabbam rūpam assa atthi iti rūpī iti atha kho ruppana sīlaḥ rūpī iti
translated: and it is said, “having taken the perception occurring there as ‘perception’ ”?🔽But this should not be regarded thus, “He is possessed of form because he has form,” but rather “He is possessed of form because he is of the nature to form.”

original: Ruppanañcettha rūpasarikkhatāya kasiṇarūpassa vaḍḍhitāvaḍḍhitakālavasena visesāpatti.🔽Sā hi “natthī”ti na sakkā vattuṃ parittavipulatādivisesasabbhāvato. Yadevaṃ siyā
analyzed: ruppanam ca ittha rūpa sarikkhatāya kasiṇa rūpassa vaḍḍhita avaḍḍhita kāla vasena visesa āpatti  sā hi natthi iti na sakkā vattum paritta vipula tā ādi visesa sabbhāvataḥ yat evam siyā
translated: And here the “forming” is the assumption of different states by the kasiṇa materiality, according to whether it is extended or unextended, and so on.🔽For that cannot be said not to exist because it is of the same nature as the difference of smallness and largeness, and so on.

original: “ruppanasīlo rūpī”ti, atha imassa vādassa sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgaho na yujjati ruppanasīlassa
analyzed: ruppana sīlaḥ rūpī iti atha imassa vādassa sassata diṭṭhi saṅgahaḥ na yujjati ruppana sīlassa
translated: If it is of the nature to form in this way, then it is not proper to include this doctrine in eternalism because that which is of the nature to form is subject to destruction.

original: bhedasabbhāvatoti? Yujjateva kāyabhedato uddhaṃ parikappitassa attano nibbikāratāya
analyzed: bheda sabbhāvato ti yujjatā iva kāya bhedataḥ uddham parikappitassa attanaḥ nibbikāra tāya
translated: It is proper, because the self that is imagined to exist after the dissolution of the body is devoid of activity.

original: tena adhippetattā. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “arogo paraṃ maraṇā”ti. Atha vā “rūpamassa atthīti
analyzed: tena adhippeta ttā tathā hi vuttam arogo param atha vā rūpam assa atthi iti
translated: It is referred to by the word “he” because it is referred to by that word. For it is said, “after death he is healthy.”

original: rūpī”ti vuttepi na koci doso kappanāsiddhena bhedena abhedassāpi niddesadassanato
analyzed: rūpī iti vutte pi na koci doso kappanā siddhena bhedena abhedassa api niddesa dassanato
translated: Or, even if it is said, “He is possessed of form because he has form,” there is no fault, because the teaching of non-difference is shown by the impossibility of the difference of imagination.

original: yathā “silāputtakassa sarīra”nti.
analyzed: yathā silāputtakassa sarīranti
translated: as in the case of the expression “the body of the stone image.”

original: Apica avayavavasena avayavino tathāniddesanidassanato yathā “kāye kāyānupassī”ti,🔽ruppanaṃ vā rūpaṃ, rūpasabhāvo, tadassa atthīti rūpī, attā “rūpino dhammā”tiādīsu
analyzed: apica avayava vasena avayavino tathā niddesa nidassanataḥ yathā kāye kāya anupassī iti  ruppanam vā rūpam rūpa sabhāvaḥ tat assa atthi iti rūpī attā rūpinaḥ dhammā ti ādīsu
translated: Or else, just as in the case of the expression “contemplating the body in the body,” the word “body” is used to denote the parts of the body by way of the whole consisting of the parts,🔽so too here the word “form” is used to denote the individual essence of form, the nature of form, which exists in the self.🔽And when this is so, the statement “the self is possessed of form” is in accordance with reason, since the self has the individual essence of form,

original: viya, evañca katvā attano rūpasabhāvattā “rūpī attā”ti vacanaṃ ñāyāgatamevāti vuttaṃ🔽“kasiṇarūpaṃ attā”ti. “Gahetvā”ti etena cetassa sambandho. Tatthāti kasiṇarūpe. Assāti
analyzed: evam ca katvā attanaḥ rūpa sabhā vattā rūpī attā iti vacanam ñāya āgatam eva ati vuttam  kasiṇa rūpam attā ati gahetvā iti etena cetassa sambandhaḥ tattha ati kasiṇa rūpe assa ati
translated: just as in the case of the expressions “dhammas possessed of form” and so on.

original: parikappitassa attano, ājīvakādayo takkamattena paññapenti viyāti attho. Ājīvakā
analyzed: parikappitassa attanaḥ ājīvaka ādayo takka mattena paññapenti viya ati atthaḥ ājīvakā
translated: “The kasiṇa-form is the self” — by this he shows the connection of the self with the mind. “Therein” means in the kasiṇa-form. “The self” means the self as conceived. The meaning is that the Ājīvakas and others describe the self in this way by mere conjecture.

original: hi takkikāyeva, na lābhino. Niyatavāditāya hi kammaphalapaṭikkhepato natthi tesaṃ
analyzed: hi takkikāya iva na lābhinaḥ niyata vādi tāya hi kamma phala paṭikkhepato natthi tesam
translated: For the Ājīvakas are only logicians, not meditators. For, because of their doctrine of determinism, they deny the fruit of kamma, and therefore they do not attain the jhānas and higher knowledges.

original: jhānasamāpattilābho. Tathā hikaṇhābhijātiādīsu kāḷakādirūpaṃ “attā”ti ekacce ājīvakā
analyzed: jhāna samāpatti lābhaḥ tathā hi kaṇha abhijāti ādīsu kāḷaka ādi rūpam attā ati ekacce ājīvakā
translated: Thus some Ājīvakas admit that the dark-blue color, etc., in the case of a dark-blue birth, etc., is the self.

original: paṭijānanti. Purimanayena cettha lābhīnaṃ dasseti, pacchimanayena pana takkikaṃ.
analyzed: paṭijānanti purima nayena ca ittha lābhīnam dasseti pacchima nayena pana takkikam
translated: Here the first method shows the attainment of the Ājīvakas, the second the logical method.

original: Evamīdisesu. Roga-saddo bhaṅgapariyāyo bhaṅgassāpi rujjanabhāvato, evañca katvā aroga-saddassa🔽niccapariyāyatā upapannā hoti, tenāha “nicco”ti. Roga-saddo vā byādhipariyāyo. Arogoti
analyzed: evamīdisesu roga saddaḥ bhaṅga pariyāyaḥ bhaṅgassa api rujjana bhāvataḥ evam ca katvā aroga saddassa  nicca pariyāya tā upapannā hoti tena āha niccaḥ iti roga saddaḥ vā byādhi pariyāyaḥ arogaḥ ti
translated: In this way. The word ‘sickness’ is a synonym for ‘breaking up’ because of the breaking up of what is sick, and in this way the word ‘healthy’🔽is established as a synonym for ‘permanent’, thus he said “permanent”. Or the word ‘sickness’ is a synonym for ‘disease’. The word ‘healthy’ is a synonym for ‘not sick’,🔽🔽

original: pana rogarahitatāsīsena nibbikāratāya niccataṃ diṭṭhigatiko paṭijānātīti dassetuṃ🔽“nicco”ti vuttaṃ. Kasiṇugghāṭimākāsapaṭhamāruppaviññāṇanatthibhāvākiñcaññāyatanāni
analyzed: pana roga rahita tāsīsena nibbikāra tāya niccatam diṭṭhigatiko paṭijānāti iti dassetuṃ  niccaḥ ti vuttam kasiṇugghāṭima ākāsa paṭhama āruppa viññāṇa natthi bhāva ākiñcañña āyatanāni
translated: In this way. The word ‘disease’ is a synonym for ‘breaking up’, because breaking up is a kind of affliction. And in this way it is established that the word ‘healthy’ is a synonym for ‘permanent’. Therefore it is said ‘permanent’. Or the word ‘disease’ is a synonym for ‘sickness’. But the word ‘healthy’ is said to be ‘permanent’ in order to show that the theorist professes permanence by way of the absence of affliction, that is, by way of the absence of disease.

original: yathārahamarūpasamāpattinimittaṃ nāma. Nimbapaṇṇe tapparimāṇo tittakaraso viya sarīrapparimāṇo
analyzed: yathāraham arūpa samāpatti nimittam nāma nimba paṇṇe tad parimāṇaḥ tittaka rasaḥ viya sarīra parimāṇaḥ
translated: The base consisting of boundless space, the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and the consciousness that arises first in the fine-material sphere, which is the sign of the fine-material jhāna, are called ‘name’. Just as the juice of the bitter nimba leaf is of the same size as the leaf, so the immaterial self, which is material, is of the same size as the body.

original: arūpī attā sarīre tiṭṭhatīti takkamatteneva nigaṇṭhā “arūpī attā saññī”ti paññapentīti
analyzed: arūpī attā sarīre tiṭṭhati iti takka mattena iva nigaṇṭhāḥ arūpī attā saññī iti paññapenti iti
translated: The Niganthas profess the immaterial self that possesses perception by mere conjecture that ‘it stands in the body’.

original: āha “nigaṇṭhādayo viyā”ti.
analyzed: āha nigaṇṭha ādayaḥ viyāti
translated: Therefore it is said ‘like the Niganthas, etc.’

original: Tatiyā panāti “rūpī ca arūpī ca attā”ti laddhi. Missakagāhavasenāti rūpārūpasamāpattīnaṃ
analyzed: tatiyā pana ati rūpī ca arūpī ca attā ati laddhi missaka gāha vasena ati rūpa arūpa samāpattīnam
translated: The third view is that the self is both material and immaterial. By way of a mixed apprehension: the fine-material and immaterial jhānas are called ‘name-and-form’.

original: yathāvuttāni nimittāni ekajjhaṃ katvā ekova “attā”ti, tattha pavattasaññañcassa “saññā”ti🔽gahaṇavasena. Ayañhi diṭṭhigatiko rūpārūpasamāpattilābhī tāsaṃ nimittaṃ rūpabhāvena,🔽arūpabhāvena ca “attā”ti gahetvā “rūpī ca arūpī cā”ti abhinivesaṃ janesi athetavādino
analyzed: yathā vuttāni nimittāni ekajjham katvā ekaḥ iva attā ti tattha pavatta saññañcassa saññā ti  gahaṇa vasena ayam hi diṭṭhi gatikaḥ rūpa arūpa samāpatti lābhī tāsam nimittam rūpa bhāvena  arūpa bhāvena ca attā ati gahetvā rūpī ca arūpī ca ati abhinivesam janesi athetavādinaḥ
translated: Having combined the characteristics mentioned into one, he conceives the one “self” as “possessing form” and the perception occurring in regard to it as “perception.”🔽For this theorist who has attained the jhānas and the immaterial states conceives the characteristics of those states as “self” in the mode of materiality and immateriality,🔽like the proponents of the doctrine of “eternalism” who conceive the self as material and immaterial. Or else, he conceives the jhānas and immaterial states as a composite, and he conceives the self as “possessing form and being formless”

original: viya, takkamatteneva vā rūpārūpadhammānaṃ missakagahaṇavasena “rūpī ca arūpī ca attā”ti
analyzed: viya takka mattena iva vā rūpa arūpa dhammānam missaka gahaṇa vasena rūpī ca arūpī ca attā ati
translated: through mere reasoning, like the proponents of the doctrine of “eternalism.”

original: abhinivissa aṭṭhāsi. Catutthāti “neva arūpī ca nārūpī ca attā”ti laddhi. Takkagāhenevāti🔽saṅkhārasesasukhumabhāvappattadhammā viya accantasukhumabhāvappattiyā sakiccasādhanāsamatthatāya
analyzed: abhinivissa aṭṭhāsi catutthā ati na iva arūpī ca na arūpī ca attā ati laddhi takkagāhena iva ati  saṅkhāra sesa sukhuma bhāva patta dhammāḥ viya accanta sukhuma bhāva ppattiyā sa kicca sādhana asamattha tāya
translated: The fourth theorist conceives the self as “neither possessing form nor being formless” through mere reasoning.

original: khambhakucchi [thambhakuṭṭa ] hatthapādādisaṅghāto viya neva rūpī, rūpasabhāvānativattanato
analyzed: hattha pāda ādi saṅghātaḥ viya na iva rūpī rūpa sabhāva an ativattanato
translated: Through mere reasoning means that he conceives the self as “neither possessing form nor being formless” through mere reasoning that proceeds thus: “The self is not possessing form because it is incapable of performing its function of attaining the state of utter subtlety, like the dhammas that have attained the state of subtle residual formations;

original: na ca arūpīti evaṃ pavattatakkagāheneva.
analyzed: na ca arūpi iti evam pavatta takka gāhena iva
translated: and the self is not formless because it does not transcend the nature of materiality, like the aggregate of the trunk, belly, hands, feet, etc.”

original: Ayaṃ aṭṭhakathāmuttako nayo – nevarūpī nārūpīti ettha hi antānantikacatutthavāde
analyzed: ayam aṭṭhakathā muttakaḥ nayaḥ nevarūpī na arūpī iti ettha hi anta anantika catuttha vāde
translated: This is the method of the commentary: “Neither material nor immaterial” should be understood as the meaning of the two terms in the sense of mutual negation, as in the case of the fourth extreme of the eternalist.🔽And although the third and fourth views have the same meaning,

original: viya aññamaññapaṭikkhepavasena attho veditabbo. Satipi ca tatiyavādena imassa samānatthabhāve🔽tattha desakālabhedavasena viya idha kālavatthubhedavasena tatiyacatutthavādānaṃ🔽viseso daṭṭhabbo. Kālabhedavasena hi idha tatiyavādassa pavatti rūpārūpanimittānaṃ
analyzed: viya aññamañña paṭikkhepa vasena attho veditabbo sati pi ca tatiya vādena imassa samānattha bhāve  tattha desa kāla bheda vasena kāla vatthu bheda vasena tatiya catuttha vādānam  visesaḥ daṭṭhabbo kāla bheda vasena hi idha tatiya vādassa pavatti rūpa arūpa nimittānam
translated: the difference between the third and fourth views should be seen as being🔽due to the difference in the time and the basis in this case, as in the case of the difference in the time and the place in the previous case.

original: sahaanupaṭṭhānato. Catutthavādassa pana vatthubhedavasena pavatti rūpārūpadhammasamūhabhāvatoti.
analyzed: saha anupaṭṭhānato catuttha vādassa pana vatthu bheda vasena pavatti rūpa arūpa dhamma samūha bhāvato ti
translated: For the third view occurs in this case due to the difference in the time, since the material and immaterial signs do not appear together. But the fourth view occurs due to the difference in the basis, since the material and immaterial states are a collection.

original: Dutiyacatukkaṃ antānantikavāde vuttanayena veditabbaṃ sabbathā saddatthato samānatthattā.
analyzed: dutiya catukkam anta anantika vāde vutta nayena veditabbam sabbathā saddatthato samāna attha ttā
translated: The second tetrad should be understood in the same way as the first tetrad, according to the meaning of the terms, in all respects.

original: Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, tampi “amati gacchati bhāvo osānametthā”tiādinā amhehi vuttameva,
analyzed: yam pana ittha vattabbam tam pi gacchati bhāvaḥ osānam ettha ati ādinā amhehi vuttam eva
translated: But what should be said here has already been said by us in the passage beginning, “The state goes, but not the self; this is the end of it” .

original: kevalaṃ pana tattha pubbantakappanāvasena pavatto, idha aparantakappanāvasenāti ayaṃ
analyzed: kevalam pana tattha pubba anta kappanā vasena pavattaḥ idha apara anta kappanā vasena ati ayaṃ
translated: But the difference is obvious: the former is stated in terms of the past, the latter in terms of the future.

original: viseso pākaṭoyeva. Kāmañca nānattasaññī attāti ayampi vādo samāpannakavasena labbhati.
analyzed: visesaḥ pākaṭaḥ yā iva kāmañca nānatta saññī attā ati ayam pi vādaḥ samāpannaka vasena labbhati
translated: And the view “One perceives having made the self and the world multiple” is also found in the case of one who has attained jhāna.

original: Aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino diṭṭhigatikassa vasena saññābhedasambhavato. Tathāpi samāpattiyaṃ🔽ekarūpeneva saññāya upaṭṭhānato lābhīvasena ekattasaññitā sātisayaṃ yuttāti āha “samāpannakavasena
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ diṭṭhigatikassa vasena saññā bheda sambhavato tathā api  eka rūpena iva saññāyaḥ upaṭṭhānataḥ lābhī vasena ekatta saññitā sa atisayam yuttā iti āha samāpannaka vasena
translated: For it is possible that one who has attained the eight attainments and is a speculative theorist should have a multiple perception.🔽Nevertheless, since the perception occurs in the attainment as a single thing, it is more appropriate to speak of a single perception in terms of one who has attained jhāna.🔽So it is said, “One who has attained jhāna is said to have a single perception. ”

original: ekattasaññī”ti. Ekasamāpattilābhino eva vā vasena attho veditabbo. Satipi ca samāpattibhedato
analyzed: ekatta saññī iti eka samāpatti lābhinaḥ eva vā vasena atthaḥ veditabbo sati pi ca samāpatti bhedato
translated: Or the meaning can be understood in terms of one who has attained only one jhāna.🔽And although it is possible that there should be a multiple perception owing to the difference in the jhānas,

original: saññābhedasambhave bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇeyeva saññānānattassa oḷārikassa sambhavato
analyzed: saññā bheda sambhave bahiddhā saññā nānattassa oḷārikassa sambhavato
translated: the multiple perception of the gross kind is only in the case of external variety of object.

original: takkīvaseneva nānattasaññitaṃ dassetuṃ “asamāpannakavasena nānattasaññī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: takkī vasena iva nānatta saññitam dassetum asamāpannaka vasena nānatta saññī iti vuttam
translated: So in order to show the multiple perception in the sense of the theorist only, it is said, “One who has not attained jhāna is said to have a multiple perception. ”

original: Parittakasiṇavasenāti avaḍḍhitattā appakakasiṇavasena, kasiṇaggahaṇañcettha saññāya🔽visayadassanaṃ. Visayavasena hi saññāya parittatā, iminā ca satipi saññāvinimuttadhamme
analyzed: paritta kasiṇa vasena āti a vaḍḍhita ttā appaka kasiṇa vasena kasiṇa ggahaṇam ca ittha saññāya  visaya dassanam visaya vasena hi saññāya paritta tā iminā ca sati pi saññā vinimutta dhamme
translated: By means of a limited kasiṇa: by means of a kasiṇa that is limited because it is not extended. The word kasiṇa here refers to the object of perception.

original: “saññāyeva attā”ti vadatīti dasseti. Esa nayo vipulakasiṇavasenāti etthāpi. Evañca🔽katvā antānantikavāde ceva idha ca antānantacatukke paṭhamadutiyavādesu saddatthamattato
analyzed: saññāya iva attā ati vadati iti dassa iti esa nayaḥ vipula kasiṇa vasena ati ettha api evañca  katvā anta ānantika vāde ca iva idha ca anta ananta catukke paṭhama dutiya vādesu
translated: For it is by way of the object that perception is limited. And by this he shows that although the dhammas are free from perception, he still maintains that “perception is the self.” The same method applies to the phrase “by means of an extended kasiṇa.”

original: samānesupi sabhāvato tehi dvīhi vādehi imesaṃ dvinnaṃ vādānaṃ viseso siddho hoti,🔽aññathā vuttappakāresu vādesu satipi pubbantāparantakappanabhedamattena kehici visese
analyzed: samānesu pi sabhāvataḥ tehi dvīhi vādehi imesam dvinnam vādānam visesaḥ siddhaḥ hoti  aññathā vutta ppakāresu vādesu sati pi pubbanta aparanta kappana bheda mattena kehici visese
translated: Thus, although the first and second theories in the fourfold formula about the finite and infinite are the same in meaning, the difference between the two theories is established by their difference in content.

original: kehici avisesoyeva siyāti.
analyzed: kehici siyāti
translated: Otherwise, even though the theories are of the kind mentioned, there would be no difference between them, only a difference in the mere expression of the two theories in terms of the past and future.

original: Ayaṃ pana aṭṭhakathāmuttako nayo – “aṅguṭṭhappamāṇo attā, aṇumatto attā”tiādiladdhivasena
analyzed: ayam pana aṭṭhakathā muttakaḥ nayaḥ aṅguṭṭha ppamāṇaḥ attā aṇu mattaḥ attā iti ādi laddhi vasena
translated: The following method is given in the commentary: “By means of the attainment of the perception that ‘the self is the size of a thumb’ or ‘the self is the size of a mustard seed,’ etc.,

original: paritto ca so saññī cāti parittasaññī kāpilakāṇādapabhutayo [kapilakaṇādādayo ] viya.
analyzed: paritto ca so saññī ca ati paritta saññī kāpila kāṇāda pabhutayaḥ kapila kaṇāda ādayaḥ
translated: and he is limited and has perception, he is a limited-percipient one, like the followers of Kapila and Kaṇāda, etc.

original: Attano sabbagatabhāvapaṭijānanavasena appamāṇo ca so saññī cāti appamāṇasaññīti.
analyzed: attano sabbagata bhāva paṭijānana vasena appamāṇo ca so saññī ca ati appamāṇa saññī iti
translated: and he is immeasurable and has perception, he is an immeasurable-percipient one, by his claiming to be all-pervading.

original: Dibbacakkhuparibhaṇḍattā yathākammūpagañāṇassa dibbacakkhupabhāvajanitena yathākammūpagañāṇena
analyzed: dibba cakkhu paribhaṇḍa ttā yathākammūpaga ñāṇassa dibba cakkhu pabhāva janitena yathākammūpaga ñāṇena
translated: Because the knowledge of passing away according to action is a concomitant of the divine eye, it is called “divine eye” since it is generated by the divine eye.

original: dissamānāpi sattānaṃ sukhādisamaṅgitā dibbacakkhunāva diṭṭhā nāmāti āha “dibbena🔽cakkhunā”tiādi. Catukkanayaṃ, pañcakanayañca sandhāya tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiya”nti
analyzed: dissamānā api sattānam sukha ādi samaṅgi tā dibba cakkhunā eva diṭṭhā nāma ati āha dibbena  cakkhunā atiādi catukka nayam pañcaka nayam ca sandhāya tika catukka jjhāna bhūmiyanti
translated: And although it is seen by the knowledge of passing away according to action, it is called “seen with the divine eye” because it is seen by the divine eye.🔽The words “in the plane of the triple and quadruple jhānas” are said with reference to the fourfold and fivefold reckoning.

original: vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhigatikavisayāsu hi pañcavokārajhānabhūmīsu vehapphalabhūmiṃ ṭhapetvā🔽avasesā yathārahaṃ catukkanaye tikajjhānassa, pañcakanaye ca catukkajjhānassa vipākaṭṭhānattā
analyzed: vuttam diṭṭhigatika visayāsu hi pañcavokāra jhāna bhūmīsu vehapphala bhūmim ṭhapetvā  avasesāḥ yathāraham catukka naye tika jhānassa pañcaka naye ca catukka jhānassa vipāka ṭṭhāna ttā
translated: For the fivefold jhāna plane is the plane of the fivefold jhāna, and the fourfold jhāna plane is the plane of the fourfold jhāna.🔽The planes of the triple and quadruple jhānas are called “triple and quadruple jhānas” because they are the planes of the triple and quadruple jhānas respectively, in the fourfold and fivefold reckonings.

original: tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiyo nāma. Suddhāvāsā pana tesamavisayā. Nibbattamānanti uppajjamānaṃ.
analyzed: tika catukka jhāna bhūmiyaḥ nāma suddhāvāsāḥ pana tesama visayāḥ nibbattamānanti uppajjamānam
translated: But the Pure Abodes are not their planes.🔽“Is being born”: is arising.

original: Nanu ca “ekantasukhī attā”tiādinā pavattavādānaṃ aparantadiṭṭhibhāvato “nibbattamānaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca ekanta sukhī attā iti ādinā pavatta vādānam aparanta diṭṭhi bhāvataḥ nibbattamānam
translated: Are not the theories of the self stated in the passage “The self is absolutely happy” , etc., views about the future?

original: disvā”ti paccuppannavacanaṃ anupapannameva siyā. Anāgatavisayā hi ete vādāti? Upapannameva
analyzed: disvā ti paccuppanna vacanam anupapannam eva siyā anāgata visayāḥ hi ete vādāḥ ti upapannam eva
translated: But is it not improper to speak of seeing in the present what is being born in the future, since the views stated as “The self is absolutely happy” and so on are views about the future?🔽It is proper,

original: anāgatassa ekantasukhībhāvādikassa pakappanāya paccuppannanibbattidassanena adhippetattā.🔽Tenevāha “nibbattamānaṃ disvā ‘ekantasukhī’ti gaṇhātī”ti. Ettha ca tassaṃ tassaṃ
analyzed: anāgatassa ekanta sukhībhāva ādikassa pakappanāya paccuppanna nibbatti dassanena adhippeta ttā  tena iva āha nibbattamānam disvā ekanta sukhī iti gaṇhāti iti ettha ca tassam tassam
translated: because what is intended is the seeing of the present birth in order to infer the absolute happiness, etc., of the future.

original: bhūmiyaṃ bāhullena sukhādisahitadhammappavattidassanaṃ paṭicca tesaṃ “ekantasukhī”tiādigahaṇato
analyzed: bhūmiyam bāhullena sukha ādi sahita dhamma ppavatti dassanam paṭicca tesam ekanta sukhī ti ādi gahaṇato
translated: That is why it is said, “Seeing what is being born, he apprehends that it is absolutely happy.” And here the state should be regarded as stated in accordance with the way in which the seeing of the occurrence of states accompanied by happiness, etc., in a particular state is predominant.

original: tadanurūpāyeva bhūmi vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saddantarābhisambandhavasena viya hi atthapakaraṇādivasenapi
analyzed: tad anurūpāya iva bhūmi vuttā iti daṭṭhabbam sadda antara abhisambandha vasena viya hi attha pakaraṇa ādi vasena api
translated: For just as a meaning can be ascribed in accordance with the connection of the words, so too a meaning can be ascribed in accordance with the method of exposition of the texts.

original: atthaviseso labbhati. “Ekantasukhī”tiādīsu ca ekantabhāvo bahulaṃ pavattimattaṃ pati
analyzed: attha visesaḥ labbhati ekanta sukhī iti ādīsu ca ekanta bhāvaḥ bahulam pavattimattam pati
translated: And in the case of the words “absolutely happy,” etc., the state of absolute happiness is the mere occurrence of happiness in abundance.

original: payutto. Tathāpavattimattadassanena tesaṃ evaṃ gahaṇato. Atha vā hatthidassakaandhā🔽viya diṭṭhigatikā yaṃ yadeva passanti, taṃ tadeva abhinivissa voharanti. Vuttañhetaṃ🔽bhagavatā udāne “aññatitthiyā bhikkhave, paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā”tiādi, tasmā
analyzed: payuttaḥ tathā pavattimatta dassanena tesam evam gahaṇato atha vā hatthi dassaka andhā  viya diṭṭhigatikāḥ yam yat eva passanti tam tat eva abhinivissa voharanti vuttam ha etam  bhagavatā udāne añña titthiyāḥ bhikkhave paribbājakāḥ andhāḥ a cakkhukā ati ādi tasmā
translated: because they take them thus merely by seeing that they occur in that way. Or else, like the blind men in the parable of the elephant, they each take hold of what they have seen and make their report on that. For this is said by the Blessed One in the Udāna: “Monks, wanderers of other sects are blind and sightless” , and so on. Therefore🔽

original: alamettha yuttimagganāti. “Dibbena cakkhunā disvā”ti vuttamatthaṃ samatthetuṃ “visesato hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: alam ettha yutti magganā ati dibbena cakkhunā disvā iti vuttam attham samatthetum visesataḥ hi itiādi vuttam
translated: Because they take it thus, seeing only the mere occurrence of the ideas. Or just as the blind men in the Elephant-footprint Simile, who each took hold of one part of the elephant, so these theorists each take hold of one part of the ideas and make their assertions on the basis of that alone. For this is said by the Blessed One in the Udana: “Wanderers of other sects, bhikkhus, are blind and sightless” , and so on. So there is no need to pursue the matter further by way of reasoning. The words “and seeing with the divine eye” are stated to show the meaning of the words “seeing” and “knowing” in the phrase “having seen and known with the eye of a Buddha” . The words “in particular” are stated to show the difference between the divine eye and the Buddha eye.

original: Asaññīnevasaññīnāsaññīvādavaṇṇanā🔽78-83. Atha na koci viseso atthīti codanaṃ sodheti “kevalañhī”tiādinā. “Asaññī”ti🔽ca “nevasaññīnāsaññī”ti ca gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyoti sambandho. Kāraṇanti visesakāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: asaññī nevasaññī nāsaññī vāda vaṇṇanā  atha na koci visesaḥ atthi iti codanam sodheti kevalañ hi itiādinā asaññī iti  ca nevasaññī nāsaññī iti ca gaṇhantānam tāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ ti sambandho kāraṇam ti visesa kāraṇam
translated: The exposition of the doctrine of the non-percipient and of the doctrine of the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient

original: diṭṭhisamudāgamakāraṇaṃ vā. Satipi kiñci kāraṇapariyesanasambhave diṭṭhigatikavādānaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi samudāgama kāraṇam vā kiñci kāraṇa pariyesana sambhave diṭṭhigatika vādānam
translated: Now he answers the objection that there is no difference between the two doctrines by the words “but there is a difference.” The meaning is this: “but there is a difference in the way of taking the object.” The words “the doctrine of the non-percipient” and “the doctrine of the neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient” are connected with the words “the view of those who take it thus.” The words “the reason” refer to the special reason or the reason for the origin of the view.

original: anādariyabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabba”nti vuttaṃ. Kasmāti āha
analyzed: anādariya bhāvam dassetum na ekantena kāraṇam pariyesitabbanti vuttam kasmā iti āha
translated: “The reason is not to be sought after” is said in order to show the state of disrespect. Why?

original: “diṭṭhigatikassā”tiādi, etena pariyesanakkhamābhāvatoti apariyesitabbakāraṇaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: diṭṭhigatikassa atiādi etena pariyesana khama abhāvataḥ ti a pariyesitabba kāraṇam dasseti
translated: He says, “of one who has views,” etc. By this he shows the reason why it is not to be sought after, namely, because he is not willing to seek.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – asaññīvāde asaññībhave nibbattasattavasena pavatto paṭhamavādo,🔽“saññaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti ettha vuttanayena saññaṃyeva “attā”ti gahetvā tassa
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti asaññī vāde asaññībhave nibbatta satta vasena pavattaḥ paṭhama vādo  saññam attataḥ samanupassati iti ettha vutta nayena saññam yeva attā ati gahetvā tassa
translated: This is what is said: The first view occurs with reference to beings reborn in the state of non-percipient beings in the doctrine of the non-percipient.

original: kiñcanabhāvena ṭhitāya aññāya saññāya abhāvato “asaññī”ti pavatto dutiyavādo, tathā
analyzed: kiñcana bhāvena ṭhitāya aññāya saññāya abhāvataḥ asaññī iti pavattaḥ dutiya vādaḥ tathā
translated: The second view occurs with reference to one who has taken perception itself as the self in the manner stated in the passage, “one regards perception as the self” .

original: saññāya saha rūpadhamme, sabbe eva vā rūpārūpadhamme “attā”ti gahetvā pavatto tatiyavādo,
analyzed: saññāya saha rūpa dhamme sabbe eva vā rūpa arūpa dhamme attā ati gahetvā pavattaḥ tatiya vādaḥ
translated: The third view occurs with reference to one who has taken material phenomena together with perception, or all material and immaterial phenomena, as the self.

original: takkagāhavaseneva catutthavādo pavatto.
analyzed: takkagāha vasena iva catuttha vādaḥ pavatto
translated: The fourth view occurs with reference to one who has taken the self to be a material or immaterial phenomenon by way of mere conjecture.

original: Dutiyacatukkepi kasiṇarūpassa asañjānanasabhāvatāya asaññīti katvā antānantikavāde
analyzed: dutiya catukke pi kasiṇa rūpassa a sañjānana sabhāva tāya asaññī iti katvā anta ānantika vāde
translated: In the second tetrad, the view that occurs in the doctrine of the eternalists with reference to the kasiṇa materiality is called “non-percipient” because of the non-perceiving nature of the kasiṇa materiality.
