original: vuttanayena cattāro vikappā pavattā. Nevasaññīnāsaññīvāde pana nevasaññīnāsaññībhave🔽nibbattasattasseva cutipaṭisandhīsu, sabbattha vā paṭusaññākiccaṃ kātuṃ asamatthāya🔽sukhumāya saññāya atthibhāvapaṭijānanavasena paṭhamavādo, asaññīvāde vuttanayena
analyzed: vutta nayena cattāro vikappā pavattā nevasaññī nāsaññī vāde pana nevasaññī nāsaññī bhave  nibbatta sattassa iva cuti paṭisandhīsu sabbattha vā paṭu saññā kiccam kātum a samatthāya  sukhumāya saññāya atthi bhāva paṭijānana vasena paṭhama vādaḥ asaññī vāde vutta nayena
translated: And the four permutations occur in the way already stated.🔽But in the case of the doctrine of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, the first statement occurs in order to affirm the existence of a subtle perception that is incapable of performing the function of normal perception in the case of any being reborn in the plane of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: sukhumāya saññāya vasena, sañjānanasabhāvatāpaṭijānanavasena ca dutiyavādādayo pavattāti.🔽Evaṃ kenaci pakārena satipi kāraṇapariyesanasambhave diṭṭhigatikavādānaṃ pariyesanakkhamābhāvato
analyzed: sukhumāya saññāya vasena sañjānana sabhāva tā paṭijānana vasena ca dutiya vāda ādayaḥ  evam kenacid pakārena sati api kāraṇa pariyesana sambhave diṭṭhigatika vādānam pariyesana kkhama abhāvato
translated: or in the case of any being in any plane of existence, and the second and third statements occur in order to affirm the state of perceiving and the state of being in the way of a subtle perception, as in the case of the doctrine of non-perception.🔽So although there is a reason for investigating them in some way, the reason need not be sought with respect for them and with great interest because of the absence of any desire to investigate the doctrines of the theorists.

original: ādaraṃ katvā mahussāhena tesaṃ kāraṇaṃ na pariyesitabbanti. Etesaṃ pana saññīasaññīnevasaññīnāsaññīvādānaṃ🔽sassatadiṭṭhisaṅgaho “arogo paraṃ maraṇā”ti vacanato pākaṭoyeva.
analyzed: ādaram katvā mahussāhena tesam kāraṇam na pariyesitabbanti etesam pana saññī asaññī nevasaññī nāsaññī vādānam  arogo param vacanataḥ
translated: But the inclusion of these doctrines of the percipient, the non-percipient, and those who are neither percipient nor non-percipient under the eternalist view is evident from the words, “who are healthy and happy in another world” .

original: Ucchedavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uccheda vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of annihilation

original: 84. Avijjamānassa vināsāsambhavato atthibhāvahetuko ucchedoti dassetuṃ vijjamānavācakena
analyzed: avijjamānassa vināsa asambhavataḥ atthi bhāva hetukaḥ ucchedaḥ ti dassetum vijjamāna vācakena
translated: In order to show that annihilation is caused by the existence of what is, since what is not cannot be destroyed, he says, “What is”

original: santa-saddena “sato”ti pāḷiyaṃ vuttanti āha “vijjamānassā”ti. Vijjamānatāpayutto
analyzed: santa saddena sataḥ iti pāḷiyam vuttanti āha vijjamānassa iti vijjamāna tā payuttaḥ
translated: In order to show that annihilationism is based on the belief in existence because what is not found can be destroyed, the text says “sato” in the sutta with the word “santa,” which means “found.”

original: cesa diṭṭhigatikavādavisayo sattoyeva idha adhippetoti dassanatthaṃ pāḷiyaṃ “sattassā”ti🔽vuttaṃ, tena imamatthaṃ dasseti – yathā hetuphalabhāvena pavattamānānaṃ sabhāvadhammānaṃ🔽satipi ekasantānapariyāpannānaṃ bhinnasantatipatitehi visese hetuphalabhūtānaṃ paramatthato🔽bhinnasabhāvattā bhinnasantānapatitānaṃ viya accantaṃ bhedasanniṭṭhānena nānattanayassa
analyzed: diṭṭhigatika vāda visayo sattaḥ yā iva idha adhippeto ti dassana ttham pāḷiyam sattassa ati  vuttam tena imam attham dasseti yathā hetu phala bhāvena pavattamānānam sabhāva dhammānam  sati pi eka santāna pariyāpannānam bhinna santati patitehi visese hetu phala bhūtānam paramatthato  bhinna sabhāva tā bhinna santāna patitānam viya accantam bheda sanniṭṭhānena nānat tanayassa
translated: The text says “sattassa” in the sutta in order to show that the being who is the object of the views of the theorists is only a found being.🔽Therefore, it shows this meaning: Just as the wrong apprehension of the mode of difference, with the absolute certainty of difference, is the cause of the adherence to annihilationism, because of the difference of individual essences of the things that exist by way of cause and effect,

original: micchāgahaṇaṃ ucchedābhinivesassa kāraṇaṃ, evaṃ hetuphalabhūtānaṃ vijjamānepi sabhāvabhede
analyzed: micchā gahaṇam uccheda abhinivesassa kāraṇam evam vijjamāne api sa bhāva bhede
translated: even though they occur in a single continuum, like those that fall into different continua, in the same way, even though there is a difference of individual essences of the things that exist by way of cause and effect,

original: ekasantatipariyāpannatāya ekattanayena accantamabhedagahaṇampi kāraṇamevāti. Santānavasena
analyzed: eka santati pariyāpanna tāya kāraṇam eva ati santāna vasena
translated: The reason is also the apprehension of a complete unity, which is due to the fact that the aggregates are included in a single continuity.🔽For the aggregates that occur in a continuity are apprehended here as a single being because of the absence of any analysis of their compactness.

original: hi pavattamānesu khandhesu ghanavinibbhogābhāvena tesaṃ idha sattagāho, sattassa
analyzed: hi pavattamānesu khandhesu ghana vinibbhoga abhāvena tesam idha satta gāho sattassa
translated: And the annihilationist view is due to the apprehension of the existence of a being.

original: ca atthibhāvagāhahetuko ucchedavādo, anupubbanirodhavasena pana nirantaravināso idha
analyzed: ca atthi bhāva gāha hetuko uccheda vādaḥ anupubba nirodha vasena pana nirantara vināsaḥ idha
translated: But the annihilation referred to here is the uninterrupted destruction that occurs through successive cessation.🔽The annihilationist view arises because of the apprehension that “as long as this being is being annihilated, so long is it existent.”

original: “ucchedo”ti adhippeto yāvāyaṃ attā ucchijjamāno bhavati, tāvāyaṃ vijjatiyevāti gahaṇatoti
analyzed: ucchedaḥ ti adhippetaḥ yāvā ayam attā ucchijjamānaḥ bhavati tāvā ayam gahaṇato ti
translated: Hence “annihilation” is said.

original: āha “upaccheda”nti. U-saddo hi upa-saddapariyāyo, so ca upasaṅkamanattho, upasaṅkamanañcettha🔽anupubbamuppajjitvā aparāparaṃ nirodhavasena nirantaratā. Apica punānuppajjamānavasena
analyzed: āha upacchedam ti usaddaḥ hi upasadda pariyāyaḥ saḥ ca upasaṅkamana tthaḥ upasaṅkamanam ca ittha  anupubbam uppajjitvā apara aparam nirodha vasena nirantara tā api ca punar anuppajjamāna vasena
translated: For the prefix upa is synonymous with the prefix upa- , and it has the meaning of “approaching.” And the approaching here is the uninterruptedness that occurs through successive arising and cessation.🔽Moreover, the annihilation called “annihilation” is the destruction that occurs through successive arising.

original: nirudayavināsoyeva ucchedo nāma yathāvuttanayena gahaṇatoti āha “upaccheda”nti. U-saddo,
analyzed: ucchedaḥ nāma yathā vutta nayena gahaṇato ti āha upaccheda nti
translated: Hence “annihilation” is said. The prefix upa is synonymous with the prefix upa- , and it has the meaning of “approaching.” And the approaching here is the uninterruptedness that occurs through successive arising and cessation. Moreover, the annihilation called “annihilation” is the destruction that occurs through successive arising.

original: hi upa-saddo ca ettha uparibhāgattho. Niruddhato parabhāgo ca idha uparibhāgoti vuccati.🔽Nirantaravasena, nirudayavasena vā visesena nāso vināso, so pana maṃsacakkhupaññācakkhūnaṃ
analyzed: hi upasaddo ca ettha upari bhāga attho niruddhato para bhāgo ca idha upari bhāgaḥ ti vuccati  nirantara vasena nirudaya vasena vā visesena nāsaḥ vināsaḥ so pana maṃsa cakkhu paññā cakkhūnam
translated: for the prefix upa has the meaning of ‘above’ here. And the state above is called ‘the state above cessation’ here.

original: dassanapathātikkamanato adassanamevāti āha “adassana”nti. Adassane hi nāsa-saddo
analyzed: dassana patha atikkamanataḥ adassanam eva ti āha adassanam ti adassane hi
translated: The destruction, the passing away, is by way of distinction, either by way of uninterruptedness or by way of cessation. But that is non-seeing itself, because of the passing beyond the path of seeing, of the fleshly eye and the eye of wisdom. Therefore it was said: “non-seeing.” For the word “passing away” is well known in the world

original: loke niruḷho “dve cāpare vaṇṇavikāranāsā”tiādīsu (kāsikā 6-3-109 suttaṃ passitabbaṃ)🔽viya. Bhāvavigamanti sabhāvāpagamaṃ. Yathādhammaṃ bhavanaṃ bhāvoti hi atthena idha🔽bhāva-saddo sabhāvavācako. Yo pana nirantaraṃ nirudayavināsavasena ucchijjati, so
analyzed: loke niruḷhaḥ dve ca apare vaṇṇa vikāra nāsā ati ādīsu kāsikā suttam passitabbam  viya bhāva vigamanti sa bhāva apagamam yathādhammam bhavanam bhāvo ti hi atthena idha  bhāva saddo sabhāva vācakaḥ yaḥ pana nirantaram nirudaya vināsa vasena ucchijjati saḥ
translated: in the sense of non-seeing, as in such passages as “two other changes of colour, passing away” .🔽The passing away of the state is the passing away of the individual essence. For the word “state” here,

original: attano sabhāvena ṭhātumasakkuṇeyyatāya “bhāvāpagamo”ti vuccati. “Tatthā”tiādinā ucchedavādassa
analyzed: attano sabhāvena ṭhātum asakkuṇeyya tāya bhāvāpagamaḥ ti vuccati tattha ati ādinā uccheda vādassa
translated: in the sense of “the existing state according to the nature of things,” signifies the individual essence. But that which is destroyed by way of uninterruptedness or by way of cessation is said to be “the passing away of the state”

original: yathāpāṭhaṃ samudāgamaṃ nidassanamattena dasseti, tena vakkhati “tathā ca aññathā
analyzed: yathāpāṭham samudāgamam nidassana mattena dasseti tena vakkhati tathā ca aññathā
translated: because it is unable to remain by its own individual essence. “There” , etc., he shows by way of mere indication the way in which the doctrine of annihilation is arrived at according to the text. Therefore he says: “In that way, and in another way,

original: ca vikappetvāvā”ti. Tatthāti “sato sattassa ucchedaṃ vināsaṃ vibhavaṃ paññapentī”ti
analyzed: ca vikappetvā avāti tattha ati sataḥ sattassa ucchedam vināsam vibhavam paññapenti iti
translated: Herein, the words “asserting the annihilation, the destruction, the non-existence of an existing being” are the words in the text.

original: vacane. Lābhīti dibbacakkhuñāṇalābhī. Tadavasesalābhī ceva sabbaso alābhī ca idha
analyzed: vacane lābhī iti dibba cakkhu ñāṇa lābhī tad avasesa lābhī ca iva sabbaso alābhī ca idha
translated: “One who has obtained” is one who has obtained the knowledge of the divine eye. He is one who has obtained only a part of it and one who has obtained it entirely.

original: aparantakappikaṭṭhāne “alābhī” tveva vuccati.
analyzed: aparanta kappika ṭṭhāne alābhī tu eva vuccati
translated: Herein, the one who has obtained only a part of it is called “one who has not obtained” in the sense of not having obtained the entire divine eye.

original: Cutinti sekkhaputhujjanānampi cutimeva. Esa nayo cutimattamevāti etthāpi. Upapattiṃ
analyzed: cutim ti sekkha puthujjanānam pi cutim eva esa nayo cutimattam evā ti ettha api upapattim
translated: “Death” is the death of trainees and ordinary men. The same method applies to “merely death” .

original: apassantoti daṭṭhuṃ samatthepi sati anolokanavasena apassanto. Na upapātanti pubbayogābhāvena,
analyzed: apassantoti daṭṭhum samatthe pi sati anolokana vasena apassanto na pubba yoga abhāvena
translated: “Not seeing rebirth” : although he is able to see it, he does not see it by not looking at it. He does not see rebirth because he has not previously practised,

original: parikammākaraṇena vā upapattiṃ daṭṭhuṃ na sakkoti, evañca katvā nayadvaye viseso🔽pākaṭo hoti. Ko paralokaṃ jānāti, na jānātiyevāti natthikavādavasena ucchedaṃ gaṇhātīti
analyzed: parikamma akaraṇena vā upapattim daṭṭhum na sakkoti evam ca katvā naya dvaye viseso  pākaṭaḥ hoti kaḥ para lokam jānāti na natthika vāda vasena ucchedam gaṇhāti iti
translated: or because he has not performed the preliminary work. Thus the difference in the two methods becomes evident.🔽“Who knows whether there is or is not a world beyond? ” He takes annihilation in the sense of the doctrine of non-existence.

original: saha pāṭhasesena sambandho, natthikavādavasena mahāmūḷhabhāveneva “ito añño paraloko
analyzed: saha pāṭha sesena sambandhaḥ natthika vāda vasena mahā mūḷha bhāvena iva itas añño para loko
translated: The connection is made with the words “who knows” . In the sense of the doctrine of non-existence, he is extremely confused. “There is no world beyond this”

original: atthī”ti anavabodhanato imaṃ diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhātīti adhippāyo. “Ettakoyeva visayo, yvāyaṃ
analyzed: atthi iti anavabodhanataḥ imam diṭṭhim gaṇhāti iti adhippāyaḥ ettakaḥ yā iva visayaḥ yvā ayam
translated: “This is the extent of the world,

original: indriyagocaro”ti attano dhītuyā hatthaggaṇhanakarājā viya kāmasukhābhirattatāyapi🔽gaṇhātīti āha “kāmasukhagiddhatāya vā”ti. Vaṇṭato patitapaṇṇānaṃ vaṇṭena apaṭisandhikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: indriya gocarā ti  gaṇhāti iti āha vaṇṭataḥ patita paṇṇānam vaṇṭena a paṭisandhika bhāvam
translated: no further than the range of the senses” : like the king who seized his own daughter’s hand, he holds this view because of his delight in sensual pleasures.

original: sandhāya “na puna viruhantī”ti vuttaṃ. Evameva sattāti yathā paṇḍupalāso bandhanā
analyzed: sandhāya na puna viruhanti iti vuttam evam eva sattā ati yathā paṇḍu palāsaḥ bandhanā
translated: “They do not grow again” : he says this with reference to the fact that leaves fallen from the stalk do not take root again.

original: pavutto puna na paṭisandhīyati, evameva sabbepi sattā appaṭisandhikā maraṇapariyosānā🔽aponobbhavikā appaṭisandhikamaraṇameva nigacchantīti attho. Udakapubbuḷakūpamā hi
analyzed: pavuttaḥ puna na paṭisandhīyati evam eva sabbe pi sattāḥ appaṭisandhikāḥ maraṇa pariyosānāḥ  aponobbhavikāḥ appaṭisandhika maraṇam eva nigacchanti iti atthaḥ udaka pubbuḷaka upamāḥ hi
translated: “So it is with all beings” : just as a withered leaf, once it is released from its stalk, does not take root again, so it is with all beings. They are all without re-arising, ending in death.🔽The meaning is that they all come to a death that is without re-arising. For according to his doctrine, beings are like water bubbles, not arising again.

original: sattā puna anuppajjamānatoti tassa laddhi. Tathāti “lābhī anussaranto”tiādinā [arahato
analyzed: sattā puna an uppajjamānato ti tassa laddhi tathā ati lābhī anussaranto tiādinā arahataḥ
translated: “So” : in the way stated by the eight examples beginning with “one who attains and recollects.”

original: (aṭṭha)] nidassanavasena vuttappakārena. Aññathāti takkanassa anekappakārasambhavato
analyzed: aṭṭha nidassana vasena vutta ppakārena aññathā ti takkanassa aneka ppakāra sambhavato
translated: “Otherwise” : because of the many ways in which speculation can occur.

original: tato aññenapi pakārena. Lābhinopi cutito uddhaṃ upapātassa adassanamattaṃ pati takkaneneva
analyzed: tatas aññena api pakārena lābhinaḥ api cutitaḥ uddham upapātassa adassana mattam pati takkanena iva
translated: and then in another way. And even one who has attained jhāna, after death, by mere reasoning, sees no reappearance of what is reborn, and so on.

original: imā diṭṭhiyo uppajjantīti vuttaṃ “vikappetvāvā”ti. Tathā ca vikappetvāva uppannā
analyzed: imāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ uppajjanti iti vuttam vikappetvā avāti tathā ca vikappetvā ava uppannā
translated: So it is said, “after discriminating.” And after discriminating in this way,🔽and after discriminating in another way,

original: aññathā ca vikappetvāva uppannāti hi sambandho. Tattha “dve janā”tiādinā ucchedaggāhakappabhedadassanena
analyzed: aññathā ca vikappetvā ava uppannā ati hi sambandho tattha dve jana ati ādinā uccheda ggāha kappa bheda dassanena
translated: the views arise. So the construction is: after discriminating in this way and after discriminating in another way. Herein, by showing the mode of apprehension of annihilationism with the words “two kinds of persons,”

original: imamatthaṃ dasseti. Yathā amarāvikkhepikavādā ekantaalābhīvaseneva desitā, yathā
analyzed: imam attham dasseti yathā amarāvikkhepika vādāḥ ekanta alābhī vasena iva desitāḥ yathā
translated: he shows the meaning of this passage. For the view of endless equivocation is taught by a mode of apprehension that is one-sidedly affirmative,

original: ca uddhamāghātanikasaññīvāde catutthacatukke saññīvādā ekantalābhīvaseneva desitā,
analyzed: ca uddhama āghātanika saññīvāde catuttha catukke saññīvādāḥ ekanta lābhī vasena iva desitā
translated: and the view of the annihilation of the dead is taught by a mode of apprehension that is one-sidedly affirmative in the fourth tetrad of the “percipient” view of the dead.

original: nayime. Ime pana sassatekaccasassatavādādayo viya lābhīalābhīvaseneva desitāti. Yadevaṃ
analyzed: na yime ime pana sassata ekacca sassata vāda ādayaḥ viya lābhī alābhī vasena iva desitā ati yat evam
translated: But these views are not taught in this way. They are taught by a mode of apprehension that is both affirmative and negative, like the views of eternalism, partial-eternalism, and so on.🔽If this is so,

original: kasmā sassatavādādīsu viya lābhīvasena, takkīvasena ca paccekaṃ desanamakatvā sassatavādādidesanāhi
analyzed: kasmā sassata vāda ādīsu viya lābhī vasena takkī vasena ca paccekam desanam a katvā
translated: why is there no teaching of these views separately by a mode of apprehension that is affirmative and by a mode of apprehension that is negative, as there is in the case of the views of eternalism, etc.?

original: aññathā idha desanā katāti? Vuccate – desanāvilāsappattito. Desanāvilāsappattā hi
analyzed: aññathā idha desanā katā ati vuccate desanā vilāsa pattitaḥ desanā vilāsa ppattā hi
translated: It is said: because of the attainment of the beauty of teaching.🔽For the Enlightened Ones, the Blessed Ones, have attained the beauty of teaching,

original: buddhā bhagavanto, te veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ vividhenākārena dhammaṃ desenti, na
analyzed: buddhāḥ bhagavanto te veneyya ajjhāsayā anurūpam vividhena ākārena dhammam desenti na
translated: and they teach the Dhamma in various ways according to the dispositions of those who need training,

original: aññathā. Yadi hi idhāpi ca tathādesanāya nibandhanabhūto veneyyajjhāsayo bhaveyya,
analyzed: aññathā yadi hi idha api ca tathā desanāya nibandhana bhūtaḥ veneyya jhāsayaḥ bhaveyya
translated: not otherwise. If there were a disposition of those who need training to be bound to such a teaching here,

original: tathārūpameva bhagavā vadeyya, kathaṃ? “Idha bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo
analyzed: tathārūpam eva bhagavā vadeyya katham idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: the Blessed One would have said it thus. How so? “Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin🔽by means of ardour … Having thus made his mind concentrated …

original: vā ātappamanvāya…pe… yathā samāhite citte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti,🔽so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena arahato cuticittaṃ passati, puthūnaṃ
analyzed: vai ātappam anvāyape yathā samāhite citte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāma iti  so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena arahataḥ cuti cittam passati puthūnam
translated: directs it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: vā parasattānaṃ, na heva kho taduddhaṃ upapattiṃ. So evamāha ‘yato kho bho ayaṃ attā
analyzed: vā para sattānam na ha iva khalu tat uddham upapattim saḥ evam āha yatas khalu bho ayam attā
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees the passing away and reappearance of beings and understands how beings pass on according to their actions. He does not say thus: ‘That which is the self is the same as the world; after death I shall be permanent, everlasting, eternal, not subject to change.’🔽He says thus: ‘The self is one thing, and the world another;

original: rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhado ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti
analyzed: rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātā pettika sambhavo kāyassa bhadaḥ ucchijjati vinassati na hoti
translated: after death I shall be permanent, everlasting, eternal, not subject to change.’

original: paraṃ maraṇā’tiādinā” visesalābhino, takkino ca visuṃ katvā. Yasmā pana tathādesanāya🔽nibandhanabhūto veneyyajjhāsayo na idha bhavati, tasmā desanāvilāsena veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ
analyzed: param maraṇa ati ādinā visesa lābhino takkino ca visum katvā yasmai pana tathā desanāya  nibandhana bhūtaḥ veneyya jjhāsayaḥ naḥ idha bhavati tasmai desanā vilāsena veneyya jjhāsayā anurūpam
translated: and after death he is annihilated” .

original: sassatavādādidesanāhi aññathāyevāyaṃ desanā katāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: sassata vāda ādi desanāhi aññathāya iva ayam desanā katā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: But since the kind of inclination of disciples to be converted that is the basis for teaching in this way does not exist here, therefore this teaching should be regarded as given in a different way from the teaching of the eternalist doctrines, etc.,🔽in order to display the variety of teaching methods and to suit the variety of inclinations of those to be trained.

original: Atha vā sassatekaccasassatavādādīsu viya na idha takkīvādato visesalābhīvādo bhinnākāro,
analyzed: atha vā sassata ekacca sassata vāda ādīsu na idha takkīvādataḥ visesa lābhīvādaḥ bhinna ākāraḥ
translated: Or alternatively, just as the eternalist doctrines, etc., are not different in aspect from the theorist’s doctrine,🔽so too this doctrine of annihilation is not different in aspect from the theorist’s doctrine.

original: atha kho samānappakāratāya samānākāroyevāti imassa visesassa pakāsanatthaṃ ayamucchedavādo🔽bhagavatā purimavādehi visiṭṭhākārabhāvena desito. Sambhavati hi idha takkinopi anussavādivasena
analyzed: atha kho samāna ppakāra tāya samāna ākāraḥ yā iva ati imassa visesassa pakāsana attham ayam uccheda vādaḥ  bhagavatā purima vādehi visiṭṭha ākāra bhāvena desitaḥ sambhavati hi idha takkinaḥ api anussava ādi vasena
translated: But in order to point out this difference, this doctrine of annihilation🔽is taught by the Blessed One as having a different aspect from the previous doctrines. For it is possible that a theorist, like one who has attained, might be obsessed with the doctrine of annihilation by way of hearsay.

original: adhigamavato viya abhiniveso. Apica na imā diṭṭhiyo bhagavatā anāgate evaṃbhāvīvasena
analyzed: adhigamavataḥ viya abhinivesaḥ apica na imāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ bhagavatā anāgate evaṃbhāvī vasena
translated: Moreover, these views are not taught by the Blessed One as being such in the future,

original: desitā, nāpi evamete bhaveyyunti parikappanāvasena, atha kho yathā yathā diṭṭhigatikehi
analyzed: desitāḥ na api evam ete bhaveyyunti parikappanā vasena atha kho yathā yathā diṭṭhigatikehi
translated: nor are they taught by way of surmising that they might be so. But rather they are taught🔽in accordance with the way in which they are grasped by those who have fallen into views.

original: “idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña”nti maññitā, tathā tathāyeva ime diṭṭhigatā yathābhuccaṃ
analyzed: idam eva saccam mogham aññanti maññitā tathā tathāya iva ime diṭṭhi gatāḥ yathābhuccam
translated: “This alone is the truth, other ideas are foolish,”🔽and so on, in accordance with the way they are delimited by the knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇena paricchinditvā pakāsitā, yehi gambhīrādippakārā aputhujjanagocarā
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇena paricchinditvā pakāsitāḥ yehi gambhīra ādi ppakārāḥ a puthujjana gocarā
translated: They are the means by which the deep and so on, which are not the province of ordinary men,

original: buddhadhammā pakāsanti, yesañca parikittanena tathāgatā sammadeva thomitā honti.
analyzed: buddha dhammā pakāsanti yesam ca parikittanena tathāgatā sammat eva thomitāḥ honti
translated: are revealed as the Buddha’s ideas, and by the description of which the Perfect Ones are rightly extolled.

original: Aparo nayo – yathā ucchedavādīhi diṭṭhigatikehi uttaruttarabhavadassīhi aparabhavadassīnaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ yathā uccheda vādīhi diṭṭhigatikehi uttara uttara bhava dassīhi apara bhava dassīnam
translated: Another method: just as the annihilationists’ views are established by the annihilationists who see a further world in opposition to the annihilationists who do not see a further world,

original: tesaṃ vādapaṭisedhavasena sakasakavādā patiṭṭhāpitā, tathāyevāyaṃ desanā katāti purimadesanāhi
analyzed: tesam vāda paṭisedha vasena sakasaka vādā patiṭṭhāpitā tathāya iva ayam desanā katā ati purima desanā hi
translated: so this teaching is given in the same way. So the occurrence of this teaching

original: imissā desanāya pavattibhedo na codetabbo, evañca katvā arūpabhavabhedavasena ucchedavādo
analyzed: imissā desanāya pavatti bhedaḥ na codetabbaḥ evam ca katvā arūpa bhava bheda vasena uccheda vādaḥ
translated: should not be criticized as being different from the previous teachings. And when it is so treated, the annihilationist view, which the Exalted One said was of seven kinds,🔽is shown to be of more than seven kinds, as if it were divided according to the kinds of immaterial becoming.

original: catudhā vibhajitvā viya kāmarūpabhavabhedavasenāpi anekadhā vibhajitvāyeva vattabbo,
analyzed: catudhā vibhajitvā kāma rūpa bhava bheda vasena api anekadhā vibhajitvāya iva vattabbaḥ
translated: And it should be treated in the same way as if it were divided according to the kinds of sensual-sphere and fine-material-sphere becoming.

original: evaṃ sati bhagavatā vuttasattakato bahutarabhedo ucchedavādo āpajjatīti, atha vā
analyzed: evam sati bhagavatā vutta sattakataḥ bahutara bhedaḥ uccheda vādaḥ āpajjati iti atha vā
translated: If that is so, then the annihilationist view, which the Exalted One said was of seven kinds, is shown to be of more than seven kinds.

original: paccekaṃ kāmarūpabhavabhedavasena viya arūpabhavavasenāpi na vibhajitvā vattabbo,
analyzed: paccekam kāmarūpa bhava bheda vasena viya arūpa bhava vasena api na vibhajitvā vattabbo
translated: and it should not be said that it is not divided up into the formless-world becoming as it is into the sensual- and fine-material-world becomings.

original: evampi sati bhagavatā vuttasattakato appatarabhedova ucchedavādo āpajjatīti ca evaṃpakārāpi
analyzed: evam pi sati bhagavatā vutta sattakataḥ appatara bhedaḥ va uccheda vādaḥ āpajjati iti ca evaṃpakārā api
translated: And even if it were, the annihilationism that would be implied would be less than that stated by the Blessed One in the passage beginning ‘ There are, bhikkhus, some recluses and brahmins who are of this argument, this view’ .

original: codanā anavakāsā eva hoti. Diṭṭhigatikānañhi yathābhimataṃ desanā pavattāti.🔽85. Mātāpitūnaṃ etanti taṃsambandhanato etaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ santakanti attho. Sukkasoṇitanti🔽pitu sukkaṃ, mātu soṇitañca, ubhinnaṃ vā sukkasaṅkhātaṃ soṇitaṃ. Mātāpettiketi nimitte
analyzed: codanā anavakāsā eva hoti diṭṭhi gatikānam hi yathā abhimatam desanā pavattā ati  mātā pitūnam etat ti tad sambandhanataḥ etam mātā pitūnam santakam ti attho sukka soṇitanti  pitu sukkam mātu soṇitam ca ubhinnam vā sukka saṅkhātam soṇitam mātā apettikā iti nimitte
translated: And such an argument as this is impossible, since the teaching of the sectarians proceeds according to their own ideas.🔽‘This of their parents’: the meaning is that it is the property of those two, the mother and father, because it is related to them. ‘Semen and blood’: either the father’s semen and the mother’s blood or semen and blood called ‘ ovule ’ . ‘Mother and father’: this is a locative in the sense of cause. ‘Thus’: by means of these three words.

original: cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Itīti imehi tīhi padehi. “Rūpakāyavasenā”ti avatvā “rūpakāyasīsenā”ti
analyzed: bhummam iti iti imehi tīhi padehi rūpa kāya vasena ati avatvā rūpa kāya sīsena ati
translated: Without saying ‘ by means of the material body ’ he says ‘ by means of the material-body-sign ’,

original: vadanto arūpampi tesaṃ “attā”ti gahaṇaṃ ñāpeti. Iminā pakārena itthanti āha “evameke”ti.
analyzed: vadantaḥ arūpam pi tesam attā ati gahaṇam iminā pakārena itthat ti āha evam eka iti
translated: and thereby he makes it known that they apprehend the formless too as ‘ self ’. He said ‘ some ’ in order to show that it is not all of them that hold this view.

original: Evaṃ-saddo hettha idamattho, iminā pakārenāti attho. Eketi ekacce, aññe vā.
analyzed: evaṃsaddaḥ ha ittha idam atthaḥ iminā pakārena ati atthaḥ eke iti ekacce aññe vā
translated: The word ‘ thus ’ has the meaning of ‘ in this way ’ here; the meaning is ‘ by this method ’. ‘ Some ’ means some of them, or others.

original: 86. Manussānaṃ pubbe gahitattā, aññesañca asambhavato “kāmāvacaro”ti ettha chakāmāvacaradevapariyāpannoti attho. Kabaḷīkāro cettha yathāvuttasudhāhāro.
analyzed: manussānam pubbe gahita ttā aññesam ca asambhavataḥ kāmāvacaro ti ettha cha kāmāvacara deva pariyāpanno ti attho kabaḷīkāro ca ittha yathā vutta sudhā āhāro
translated: “Of the sense sphere” means of the six sense-sphere divine worlds, since they are already included among humans and are not possible elsewhere.🔽Here “material food” is the nectar mentioned above.

original: 87. Jhānamanena nibbattoti ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Mahāvayavo🔽aṅgo, tattha visuṃ pavatto paccaṅgo, sabbehi aṅgapaccaṅgehi yutto tathā. Tesanti🔽cakkhusotindriyānaṃ. Itaresanti ghānajivhākāyindriyānaṃ. Tesampi indriyānaṃ saṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: jhānam anena nibbatto ti ettha yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva mahā avayavaḥ  aṅgaḥ tattha visum pavatto paccaṅgaḥ sabbehi aṅga paccaṅgehi yutto tathā tesan ti  cakkhu sota indriyānam itaresanti ghāna jivhā kāya indriyānam tesam pi indriyānam saṇṭhānam
translated: What is to be said here about “born of jhāna” has already been said above.🔽A major part is a “limb.” A part that is a subdivision of that is a “sub-limb.” One who is endowed with all the limbs and sub-limbs is “such.”

original: purisavesavaseneva veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ “samānepi tattha ubhayaliṅgābhāve
analyzed: purisa vesa vasena iva veditabbam tathā hi aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam samāne pi tattha ubhaya liṅga abhāve
translated: The “eye and ear faculties” are the first two. The “other” faculties are the nose, tongue, and body faculties. The shape of these faculties should be understood according to the sex of the being.

original: purisasaṇṭhānāva tattha brahmāno, na itthisaṇṭhānā”ti.
analyzed: purisa saṇṭhānā ava tattha brahmānaḥ na itthi saṇṭhānā ti
translated: For it is said in the commentaries: “Although there is no difference in sex there, the Brahmas have the shape of males, not the shape of females.”🔽The word “base” here refers to the existence of the base of infinite space.

original: 88-92. Ākāsānañcāyatana-saddo idha bhaveyevāti āha “ākāsānañcāyatanabhava”nti. Etthāha
analyzed: ākāsa anañcāyatana saddo idha bhaveya iva ati āha ākāsa anañcāyatana bhavanti ettha āha
translated: Here it may be asked:

original: – yuttaṃ tāva purimesu tīsu vādesu “kāyassa bhedā”ti vattuṃ pañcavokārabhavapariyāpannaṃ
analyzed: yuttam tāva purimesu tīsu vādesu kāyassa bhedā ati vattum pañcavokāra bhava pariyāpannam
translated: It is proper to say “with the breakup of the body” in the first three doctrines,

original: attabhāvamārabbha pavattattā tesaṃ vādānaṃ, catuvokārabhavapariyāpannaṃ pana attabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atta bhāvam ārabbha pavatta ttā tesam vādānam catuvokāra bhava pariyāpannam pana atta bhāvam
translated: because they occur in reference to a self-hood included in the five-constituent existence. But in the last four doctrines, which occur in reference to a self-hood included in the four-constituent existence,🔽why is it said “with the breakup of the body”? For there is no body of the immaterial beings,

original: nissāya pavattesu catutthādīsu catūsu vādesu kasmā “kāyassa bhedā”ti vuttaṃ. Na hi🔽arūpīnaṃ kāyo vijjati. Yo bhedoti vucceyyāti? Saccametaṃ, rūpattabhāve pana pavattavohāreneva🔽diṭṭhigatiko arūpattabhāvepi kāyavohāraṃ āropetvā evamāha. Lokasmiñhi dissati aññatthabhūtopi
analyzed: nissāya pavattesu catuttha ādīsu catūsu vādesu kasmā kāyassa bhedā ti vuttam na hi  arūpīnam kāyaḥ vijjati yaḥ bhedaḥ iti vucceyya ati saccam etam rūpatta bhāve pana pavatta vohārena iva  diṭṭhigatikaḥ kāya vohāram āropetvā evam āha lokasmin hi dissati aññattha bhūtaḥ api
translated: which could be called “broken up.”

original: vohāro tadaññatthasamāropito yathā taṃ “sasavisāṇaṃ, khaṃ puppha”nti. Yathā ca diṭṭhigatikā
analyzed: vohāraḥ tad aññattha samāropitaḥ yathā tam sa sa visāṇam kham pupphanti yathā ca diṭṭhigatikā
translated: This is true, but the theorist, by the mere fact of his having a material self-hood, transfers the term “body” to the immaterial self-hood and says “with the breakup of the body.” For in the world, a term that has one meaning is seen to be transferred to something else, as in the expressions “the horn of a cow” and “the flower of the sky.” And just as the theorist formulates his doctrines,

original: diṭṭhiyo paññapenti, tathāyeva bhagavāpi desetīti. Apica nāmakāyabhāvato phassādidhammasamūhabhūte
analyzed: diṭṭhiyaḥ paññapenti tathāya iva bhagavā api deseti iti apica nāma kāya bhāvato phassa ādi dhamma samūha bhūte
translated: so the Exalted One teaches them. Moreover, the term “body” is used in the sense of a collection of phenomena such as contact, etc., which occur in a material self-hood.

original: arūpattabhāve kāyaniddeso daṭṭhabbo. Samūhaṭṭhenapi hi “kāyo”ti vuccati “hatthikāyo🔽assakāyo”tiādīsu viya. Ettha ca kāmāvacaradevattabhāvādiniravasesavibhavapatiṭṭhāpakānaṃ
analyzed: arūpatta bhāve kāya niddeso daṭṭhabbo samūha aṭṭhena api hi kāyo ti vuccati hatthi kāyo  assa kāyaḥ ti ādīsu viya ettha ca kāmāvacara devatta bhāva ādi niravasesa vibhava patiṭṭhāpakānam
translated: The description of the body should be understood as it is in the state of the formless-world deities. For the body is called a “mass” in such passages as “an elephant-body, a horse-body” .

original: dutiyādivādānaṃ aparantakappikabhāvo yutto hotu anāgataddhavisayattā tesaṃ vādānaṃ,
analyzed: dutiya ādi vādānam aparanta kappika bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ hotu anāgata ddha visaya ttā tesam vādānam
translated: And it is proper that the second and subsequent theories, which establish the non-perishing of the state of the sense-desire-world deities, etc., should be called “pertaining to the future,” since they have the future as their domain.

original: kathaṃ pana diṭṭhigatikassa paccakkhabhūtamanussattabhāvāpagamapatiṭṭhāpakassa paṭhamavādassa🔽aparantakappikabhāvo yujjeyya paccuppannaddhavisayattā tassa vādassa. Dutiyavādādīnañhi🔽purimapurimavādasaṅgahitasseva attano anāgate taduttaribhavūpapannassa samucchedabodhanato
analyzed: katham pana diṭṭhi gatikassa paccakkha bhūta manussatta bhāva apagama patiṭṭhāpakassa paṭhama vādassa  aparantakappika bhāvaḥ yujjeyya paccuppanna ddha visaya ttā tassa vādassa dutiya vāda ādīnam hi  purima purima vāda saṅgahitassa iva attanaḥ anāgate tad uttari bhava upapannassa samuccheda bodhanato
translated: But how can it be proper to call the first theory, which establishes the disappearance of the human state that is the opposite of the divine state, “pertaining to the future,” since it has the present as its domain?

original: yujjati aparantakappikatā, tathā ceva vuttaṃ “no ca kho bho ayaṃ attā ettāvatā sammā
analyzed: yujjati aparantakappika tā tathā ca iva vuttam no ca kho bho ayam attā ettāvatā sammā
translated: For the second and subsequent theories are called “pertaining to the future” because they teach the annihilation of the self that has arisen in a future existence higher than that of the first theory, which is included in the first theory. And this is how it is said: “But, good sirs, this self is not annihilated at that time,

original: samucchinno hotī”tiādi yaṃ pana tattha vuttaṃ “atthi kho bho añño attā”ti, taṃ manussattabhāvādiheṭṭhimattabhāvavisesāpekkhāya
analyzed: samucchinnaḥ hoti itiādi yat pana tattha vuttam atthi kho bho aññaḥ attā iti tam manussatta bhāva ādi heṭṭhimatta bhāva visesa apekkhāya
translated: But what is said there, “There is another self,” is said with reference to the distinction of the human self, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ, na sabbathā aññabhāvato. Paṭhamavādassa pana anāgate taduttaribhavūpapannassa
analyzed: vuttam na sabbathā añña bhāvato paṭhama vādassa pana anāgate tad uttari bhava upapannassa
translated: as the lowest kind of self, not as a self in all ways. But it is not right to say that the first theorist is an extra-systematic theorist because he does not know that his self is annihilated in the future,

original: attano samucchedabodhanābhāvato, “atthi kho bho añño attā”ti ettha aññabhāvena aggahaṇato
analyzed: attanaḥ samuccheda bodhana abhāvataḥ atthi kho bho aññaḥ attā iti ettha añña bhāvena aggahaṇato
translated: and because he does not apprehend a self in the sense of another in the passage, “There is another self.”

original: ca na yujjateva aparantakappikatāti? No na yujjati idhalokapariyāpannattepi paṭhamavādavisayassa🔽anāgatakālikasseva tena adhippetattā. Paṭhamavādināpi hi idhalokapariyāpannassa attano
analyzed: ca na yujjatā iva no na yujjati idha loka pariyāpanna tte pi paṭhama vāda visayassa  anāgata kālikassa iva tena adhippeta ttā paṭhamavādinā api hi idha loka pariyāpannassa attano
translated: —No, it is not wrong, because what is intended by the first theorist is only the future time, even though the domain of the first theorist is included in this world.

original: paraṃ maraṇā ucchedo anāgatakālavaseneva adhippeto, tasmā cassa aparantakappikatāya na koci virodhoti.
analyzed: param maraṇā ucchedaḥ anāgata kāla vasena iva adhippeto tasmā ca ssa aparantakappika tāya na koci virodho ti
translated: For the first theorist intends the annihilation of the self that is included in this world after death only in the future time. Therefore there is no contradiction in his being an extra-systematic theorist.

original: Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The theory of nibbana here and now

original: 93. Ñāṇena daṭṭhabboti diṭṭho, diṭṭho ca so sabhāvaṭṭhena dhammo cāti diṭṭhadhammo,
analyzed: ñāṇena daṭṭhabbo ti diṭṭhaḥ diṭṭho ca so sabhāvaṭṭhena dhammo ca ati diṭṭhadhammo
translated: “To be seen with knowledge” is seen. And that seen is a state in the ultimate sense, thus it is a state seen here and now.

original: dassanabhūtena ñāṇena upaladdhasabhāvoti attho. So pana akkhānamindriyānaṃ abhimukhībhūto
analyzed: dassana bhūtena ñāṇena upaladdha sabhāvaḥ ti attho so pana akkhānam indriyānam abhimukhībhūto
translated: The meaning is that it is apprehended with knowledge in the form of seeing. But that is the objective field of the faculties when it comes into focus.

original: visayoyevāti vuttaṃ “paccakkhadhammo vuccatī”ti. Tattha yo anindriyavisayo, sopi
analyzed: visayaḥ yā iva ati vuttam paccakkha dhammo vuccati iti tattha yaḥ anindriya visayo saḥ api
translated: So it is said to be “a state that is evident.” Herein, although it is not the objective field of the faculties,

original: supākaṭabhāvena indriyavisayo viya hotīti katvā tathā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, tenevāha
analyzed: su pākaṭa bhāvena indriya visayaḥ viya hoti iti katvā tathā vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam tena iva āha
translated: it is nevertheless treated as though it were, because it becomes evident, and it should be regarded as spoken of in this way for that reason. Hence it is said,

original: “tattha tattha paṭiladdhattabhāvassetaṃ adhivacana”nti, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ bhave yathākammaṃ
analyzed: tattha tattha adhivacananti tasmin tasmin bhave yathākammam
translated: “This is a term for the individual essence obtained in this or that becoming.” The word “name” is a term for the individual essence obtained in this or that becoming according to kamma.

original: paṭilabhitabbattabhāvassa vācakaṃ padaṃ, nāmanti vā attho. Nibbānañcettha dukkhavūpasamanameva,
analyzed: paṭilabhitabba tta bhāvassa vācakam padam nāman ti vā atthaḥ nibbānam ca ittha dukkha vūpasamanam eva
translated: Herein, nibbāna is the mere cessation of suffering,

original: na aggaphalaṃ, na ca asaṅkhatadhātu tesamavisayattāti āha “dukkhavūpasamana”nti.
analyzed: na agga phalam na ca asaṅkhata dhātu tesama visaya ttā ti āha dukkha vūpasamanam ti
translated: not the supreme fruit, nor the unformed element, because that is not their objective field. That is why he said “the cessation of suffering.”

original: Diṭṭhadhammanibbāne pavatto vādo etesanti diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādātipi yujjati.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma nibbāne pavattaḥ vādaḥ etesan ti diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādātipi yujjati
translated: And it is appropriate to say “the doctrine of nibbāna here and now” because the doctrine occurs in regard to nibbāna here and now.

original: 94. Kāmanīyattā kāmā ca te anekāvayavānaṃ samūhabhāvato sattānañca bandhanato guṇā🔽cāti kāmaguṇāti atthaṃ sandhāyāha “manāpiyarūpādīhī”tiādi. Yāva phoṭṭhabbārammaṇañcettha🔽ādi-saddena saṅgaṇhāti. Suṭṭhu appitoti sammā ṭhapito. Ṭhapanā cettha allīyanāti🔽āha “allīno”ti. Parito tattha tattha kāmaguṇesu yathāsakaṃ indriyāni cāreti gocaraṃ
analyzed: kāmanīya ttā kāmā ca te aneka avayavānam samūha bhāvataḥ sattānam ca bandhanataḥ guṇāḥ  ca ati kāmaguṇā ati attham sandhāya āha manāpiya rūpa ādīhi itiādi yāva phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam ca ittha  ādi saddena saṅgaṇhāti suṭṭhu appitaḥ ti sammā ṭhapitaḥ ṭhapanā ca ittha allīyanā ati  āha paritas tattha tattha kāma guṇesu yathāsakam indriyāni gocaram
translated: And they are “desirable” because of being desirable, and they are “pleasures” because of being a mass of many components and because of binding beings.🔽So they are “pleasures consisting of sensual desires” . Taking the meaning in this way, he said “Agreeable visible data, etc.,”🔽and he includes tangible data by the word “etc.”🔽“Well restrained” is well stopped. And here stopping is sticking.🔽So he said “stuck” .🔽He directs his faculties, each to its own objective field, here and there, among the various kinds of sensual desires.

original: gaṇhāpetīti atthaṃ dassetuṃ “tesū”tiādi vuttaṃ, tenāha “ito cito ca upanetī”ti. Pari-saddavisiṭṭho🔽vā idha cara-saddo kīḷāyanti vuttaṃ “palaḷatī”tiādi [laḷati (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)]. Palaḷatīti🔽hi pakārena laḷati, vilāsaṃ karotīti attho. “Ettha cā”tiādinā uttamakāmaguṇikānameva🔽diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapentīti dasseti. Mandhātumahārājavasavattīdevarājakāmaguṇā
analyzed: gaṇhāpeti iti attham dassetum tesu utiādi vuttam tena āha itas citas ca upaneti iti parisadda visiṭṭhaḥ 🔽vā idha cara saddo kīḷāyanti vuttam palaḷati itiādi laḷati aṭṭhakathāyam palaḷati iti 🔽hi pakārena laḷati vilāsam karoti iti ettha ca ati ādinā uttama kāma guṇikānam eva 🔽diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam paññapenti iti dasseti mandhātu mahārāja vasavattī devarāja kāmaguṇā

original: hi uttamatāya nidassitā, kasmāti āha “evarūpe”tiādi.
analyzed: hi uttamatāya nidassitā kasmā iti āha evarūpā itiādi
translated: for it is shown to be the highest. Why? He said “in such-and-such a way” and so on.

original: 95. Aññathābhāvāti kāraṇe nissakkavacanaṃ. Vuttanayenāti suttapadesu desitanayena,
analyzed: aññathābhāvā ti kāraṇe nissakka vacanam vutta nayena ati sutta padesu desita nayena
translated: “Otherwise” is a locative absolute. “In the way stated” is in the texts.🔽By this he shows the way in which sorrow, etc., arise.

original: etena sokādīnamuppajjanākāraṃ dasseti. Ñātibhogarogasīladiṭṭhibyasanehi phuṭṭhassa
analyzed: etena soka ādīnam uppajjana ākāram dasseti ñāti bhoga roga sīla diṭṭhi byasanehi phuṭṭhassa
translated: When the mind is affected by the loss of relatives, property, health, virtue, or view,

original: cetaso abbhantaraṃ nijjhāyanaṃ socanaṃ antonijjhāyanaṃ, tadeva lakkhaṇametassāti
analyzed: cetasaḥ abbhantaram nijjhāyanam socanam antar nijjhāyanam tat eva lakkhaṇam etassa ati
translated: the inward burning, the sorrow, is the inward burning of the mind. That is its characteristic.🔽It is characterized by inward burning.

original: antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇo. Tasmiṃ soke samuṭṭhānahetubhūte nissitaṃ tannissitaṃ. Bhusaṃ
analyzed: antar nijjhāyana lakkhaṇo tasmin soke samuṭṭhāna hetu bhūte nissitam tad nissitam bhusam
translated: It is dependent on sorrow, which is the cause of its arising. It is dependent on that.

original: vilapanaṃ lālappanaṃ, tannissitameva lālappanaṃ, tadeva lakkhaṇamassāti tannissitalālappanalakkhaṇo.
analyzed: vilapanam lālappanam tad nissitam eva lālappanam tat eva lakkhaṇam assa ati tad nissita lālappana lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: The outward expression of it is the outward expression of sorrow. It is dependent on that. It is characterized by the outward expression of sorrow.

original: Pasādasaṅkhāte kāye nissitassa dukkhasahagatakāyaviññāṇassa paṭipīḷanaṃ kāyapaṭipīḷanaṃ,
analyzed: pasāda saṅkhāte kāye nissitassa dukkha sahagata kāya viññāṇassa paṭipīḷanam kāya paṭipīḷanam
translated: The oppression of the painful bodily consciousness dependent on the body consisting in confidence is bodily oppression.

original: sasambhārakathanaṃ vā etaṃ yathā “dhanunā vijjhatī”ti tadupanissayassa vā aniṭṭharūpassa
analyzed: sa sambhāra kathanam vā etam yathā dhanunā vijjhati iti tad upanissayassa vā aniṭṭha rūpassa
translated: This is a description of it with its conditions, like the expression “He shoots with a bow.” Or it is the oppression of the body by the undesirable object that is its condition.

original: pacchā pavattanato “rūpakāyassa paṭipīḷana”ntipi vaṭṭati. Paṭighasampayuttassa manaso
analyzed: pacchā pavattanato rūpa kāyassa vaṭṭati paṭigha sampayuttassa manaso
translated: and it is also allowable to call it “the affliction of the material body” since it occurs after the latter.🔽It is the vexation of the mind associated with resistance.

original: vihesanaṃ manovighātaṃ. Tadeva lakkhaṇamassāti sabbattha yojetabbaṃ. Ñātibyasanādinā
analyzed: vihesanam manaḥ vighātam tat eva lakkhaṇam assa ati sabbattha yojetabbam ñāti byasana ādinā
translated: The characteristic of that is to be construed in each case.

original: phuṭṭhassa paridevanāyapi asakkuṇantassa antogatasokasamuṭṭhito bhuso āyāso upāyāso.
analyzed: phuṭṭhassa a sakkuṇantassa antar gata soka samuṭṭhitaḥ bhusaḥ āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ
translated: When a man is affected by the loss of relatives, etc., and is unable to lament, the great anguish that arises originating in grief is despair.

original: So pana cetaso appasannākāro evāti āha “visādalakkhaṇo”ti. Sādanaṃ pasādanaṃ sādo,
analyzed: so pana cetasaḥ appasanna ākāraḥ eva ati āha visāda lakkhaṇaḥ ti sādanam pasādanam sādaḥ
translated: But that is a state of mental disquiet, which is why he said “Its characteristic is disquiet.”🔽Satisfaction is the state of being satisfied, the state of being pleased.

original: pasannatā. Anupasaggopi hi saddo saupasaggo viya yathāvuttassa atthassa bodhako yathā
analyzed: pasanna tā anupasaggaḥ api hi saddaḥ saupasaggaḥ viya yathāvuttassa atthassa bodhakaḥ yathā
translated: For the word sāda is used with a prefix in the sense stated, just as the word go is used in the sense of a particular kind of animal with the prefix go-.

original: “gotrabhū”ti. Evaṃ sabbattha. Tato vigamanaṃ visādo, appasannabhāvo.
analyzed: gotrabhūti evam sabbattha tatas vigamanam visādaḥ appasanna bhāvo
translated: And the opposite of that is visāda, which is a state of disquiet, a state of being displeased.

original: 96. Vitakkanaṃ vitakkitaṃ, taṃ panatthato vitakkova, tathā vicāritanti etthāpi, tena
analyzed: vitakkanam vitakkitam tam pana atthataḥ vitakko uva tathā vicāritan ti ettha api tena
translated: Thinking is pondering. But that is in fact the same as thinking, and so too examining is in fact the same as examining.🔽That is why it is said, “Thinking is occurrence by way of absorption,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ “abhiniropanavasena pavatto vitakko”tiādi. Etenāti vitakkavicāre parāmasitvā
analyzed: vuttam abhiniropana vasena pavattaḥ vitakka uti ādi etena ati vitakka vicāre parāmasitvā
translated: By that: referring to thinking and examining,

original: karaṇaniddeso, hetuniddeso vā. Tenetamatthaṃ dīpeti “khobhakarasabhāvattā vitakkavicārānaṃ🔽taṃsahitampi jhānaṃ tehi sauppīḷanaṃ viya hotī”ti, tenāha “sakaṇṭakaṃ [bhakaṇḍakaṃ
analyzed: karaṇa niddesaḥ hetu niddesaḥ vā tena itam attham dīpeti khobhaka rasa bhāva ttā  tad sahitam pi jhānam tehi sauppīḍanam viya hoti iti tena āha sa kaṇṭakam bhakaṇḍakam
translated: By that he shows the meaning of this: “Because applied thought and sustained thought have the nature of agitation,🔽the jhāna is as though agitated by them, even though accompanied by them.” That is why he said: “It is as though it were accompanied by thorns.”

original: (aṭṭhakathāyaṃ)] viya khāyatī”ti. Oḷārikabhāvo hi vitakkavicārasaṅkhātena kaṇṭakena
analyzed: viya khāyati iti oḷārika bhāvaḥ hi vitakka vicāra saṅkhātena kaṇṭakena
translated: For the state of coarseness occurs with the thorns called applied thought and sustained thought.

original: saha pavattakathā. Kaṇṭakasahitabhāvo ca sauppīḷanatā eva, loke hi sakaṇṭakaṃ pharusakaṃ oḷārikanti vadanti.
analyzed: saha pavatta kathā kaṇṭaka sahita bhāvaḥ ca eva loke hi sa kaṇṭakam pharusakam oḷārikanti vadanti
translated: And the state of being accompanied by thorns is agitation itself, for in the world they say that what is accompanied by thorns is rough, coarse.

original: 97. Pītigataṃ pītiyeva “diṭṭhigata”ntiādīsu viya gata-saddassa tabbhāvavuttito. Ayañhi
analyzed: pīti gatam pītiyā iva diṭṭhi gatam ti ādīsu viya gata saddassa tad bhāva vuttitaḥ ayam hi
translated: “Rapt in happiness”: happiness itself is “rapt” in the sense of pervading, as in such passages as “Rapt in (or, in the way of) views” .

original: saṃvaṇṇakānaṃ pakati, yadidaṃ anatthakapadaṃ, tulyādhikaraṇapadañca ṭhapetvā atthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇakānam yat idam anatthaka padam tulya adhikaraṇa padam ca ṭhapetvā attha vaṇṇanā
translated: This is the commentators’ practice, namely, to comment on the meaning of a word by its synonym.

original: Tathā hi tattha tattha dissati. “Yopanāti yo yādiso, nibbānadhātūti nibbāyanamatta”nti
analyzed: tathā hi tattha tattha dissati yopanā ati yaḥ yādisaḥ nibbāna dhātu uti nibbāyana mattam ti
translated: For that is seen here and there, e.g. in the passage: “The ‘yoke’ is of such and such a kind; the ‘element of extinction’ is mere extinction” .

original: ca ādi. Yāya nimittabhūtāya ubbilāvanapītiyā uppannāya cittaṃ ubbilāvitaṃ nāma, sāyeva🔽ubbilāvitattaṃ bhāvavācakassa nimitte pavattanato. Iti pītiyā uppannāya eva cittassa
analyzed: ca ādi yāya nimitta bhūtāya ubbilāvana pītiyā uppannāya cittam ubbilāvitam nāma sāyā iva  bhāva vācakassa nimitte pavattanataḥ iti pītiyāḥ uppannāya eva cittassa
translated: and so on. The state of being uplifted is the state of being uplifted of consciousness when the happiness called “uplifting” has arisen.🔽That is called “uplifting” because it occurs in the sign of the state of being uplifted.🔽So it is said that the state of being uplifted of consciousness is due to the arising of happiness, since consciousness is uplifted when happiness arises.🔽The act of directing is the act of directing the mind onto the object.

original: ubbilāvanato tassa ubbilāvitabhāvo pītiyā kato nāmāti āha “ubbilabhāvakaraṇa”nti.
analyzed: ubbilāvanato tassa ubbilāvita bhāvaḥ pītiyā kataḥ nāma ati āha ubbila bhāva karaṇanti
translated: The act of adverting is the act of adverting the mind to the object.🔽The act of absorption is the act of absorbing the mind in the object.🔽The act of resolving is the act of resolving the mind on the object.🔽The act of exerting is the act of exerting the mind on the object.🔽The act of sustaining is the act of sustaining the mind on the object.🔽The act of guiding is the act of guiding the mind on the object.🔽The act of inclining is the act of inclining the mind towards the object.🔽The act of bending is the act of bending the mind towards the object.

original: 98. Ābhujanaṃ manasikaraṇaṃ ābhogo. Sammā anukkamena, punappunaṃ vā ārammaṇassa āhāro
analyzed: ābhujanam manasikaraṇam ābhogaḥ sammā anukkamena punappunam vā ārammaṇassa āhāro
translated: The act of swallowing is the act of swallowing the object with the mind.🔽The act of seizing is the act of seizing the object with the mind.🔽The act of focusing is the act of focusing the mind on the object.🔽The act of concentrating is the act of concentrating the mind on the object.

original: samannāhāro. Ayaṃ pana ṭīkāyaṃ vuttanayo – cittassa ābhuggabhāvo ārammaṇe abhinatabhāvo
analyzed: samannāhāraḥ ayam pana ṭīkā ayam vutta nayo cittassa ābhugga bhāvo ārammaṇe abhinata bhāvo
translated: The act of unifying is the act of unifying the mind on the object.🔽The act of exerting is the act of exerting the mind on the object.🔽The act of gladdening is the act of gladdening the mind on the object.🔽The act of encouraging is the act of encouraging the mind on the object.

original: ābhogo. Sukhena hi cittaṃ ārammaṇe abhinataṃ hoti, na dukkhena viya apanataṃ, nāpi🔽adukkhamasukhena viya anabhinataṃ, anapanatañcāti. Ettha ca “manuññabhojanādīsu khuppipāsādiabhibhūtassa
analyzed: ābhogaḥ sukhena hi cittam ārammaṇe abhinatam hoti na dukkhena viya apanatam na api 🔽adukkham asukhena viya an abhinatam an apanatam ca ati ettha ca manuñña bhojana ādīsu khuppipāsā ādi abhibhūtassa
translated: The act of establishing is the act of establishing the mind on the object.🔽The act of steadying is the act of steadying the mind on the object.🔽The act of quieting is the act of quieting the mind on the object.🔽The act of pacifying is the act of pacifying the mind on the object.🔽The act of concentrating is the act of concentrating the mind on the object.🔽The act of unifying is the act of unifying the mind on the object.🔽The act of making one-pointed is the act of making the mind one-pointed on the object.🔽The act of concentrating is the act of concentrating the mind on the object.🔽The act of unifying is the act of unifying the mind on the

original: viya kāmehi viveciyamānassa upādārammaṇapatthanāvisesato abhivaḍḍhati, manuññabhojanaṃ🔽bhuttāvino viya pana uḷārakāmarasassa yāvadatthaṃ nicitassa sahitassa bhuttakāmatāya
analyzed: kāmehi viveciyamānassa upādā ārammaṇa patthanā visesataḥ abhivaḍḍhati manuñña bhojanam  bhuttāvinaḥ viya pana uḷāra kāma rasassa yāvadattham nicitassa sahitassa bhutta kāma tāya
translated: But when one has stored up and collected sensual pleasures to his satisfaction and has indulged in them to his heart’s content, like a glutton who has eaten his fill,

original: kāmesu pātabyatā na hoti, visayānabhigiddhanato visayehi dummociyehi jalūkā viya
analyzed: kāmesu pātabya tā na hoti visaya an abhigiddha nataḥ visayehi dummociyehi jalūkā viya
translated: he is not greedy for sensual pleasures, just as the man who has eaten his fill is not greedy for food. He is freed from the sensual pleasures that are objects of craving, which are called “fetters” and “bonds” and are hard to abandon, just as a leech is freed from the object it clings to, which is called “its prey” and is hard to abandon.

original: sayameva muccatī”ti ca ayoniso ummujjitvā kāmaguṇasantappitatāya saṃsāradukkhavūpasamaṃ🔽byākāsi paṭhamavādī. Kāmādīnaṃ ādīnavadassitāya, paṭhamādijhānasukhassa santabhāvadassitāya
analyzed: sayam eva muccati iti ca ayonisaḥ ummujjitvā kāma guṇa santappita tāya saṃsāra dukkha vūpasamam  paṭhamavādī kāma ādīnam ādīnava dassitāya paṭhama ādi jhāna sukhassa santa bhāva dassitāya
translated: He is freed by himself, like a leech that frees itself. And he declares the cessation of the suffering of the round of rebirths by emerging from the sensual pleasures and emerging from the defilements by emerging from the five cords of sense desire, like a snake that emerges from its old skin.🔽The second speaker declares the cessation of the suffering of the round of rebirths by seeing the danger in sensual pleasures and by seeing the peacefulness of the pleasure of the first jhāna.🔽The third speaker declares it by seeing the danger in the first jhāna and by seeing the peacefulness of the pleasure of the second jhāna.🔽The fourth speaker declares it by seeing the danger in the second jhāna and by seeing the peacefulness of the pleasure of the third jhāna.

original: ca paṭhamādijhānasukhatittiyā saṃsāradukkhupacchedaṃ byākaṃsu dutiyādivādino. Idhāpi
analyzed: ca paṭhama ādi jhāna sukha tittiyā saṃsāra dukkha upacchedam dutiya ādi vādinaḥ idha api
translated: The fifth speaker declares it by seeing the danger in the third jhāna and by seeing the peacefulness of the pleasure of the fourth jhāna.

original: ucchedavādeva vuttappakāro vicāro yathāsambhavaṃ ānetvā vattabbo. Ayaṃ panettha viseso
analyzed: uccheda vādā iva vutta ppakāraḥ vicāraḥ yathāsambhavam ānetvā vattabbaḥ ayam pana ittha viseso
translated: Herein, the investigation should be undertaken in the way already stated under annihilationism. But this is the difference.

original: – ekasmimpi attabhāve pañca vādā labbhanti. Paṭhamavāde yadi kāmaguṇasamappito attā,
analyzed: ekasmim pi atta bhāve pañca vādāḥ labbhanti paṭhama vāde yadi kāma guṇa samappitaḥ attā
translated: Herein, in the first case, if the self is identified with the five cords of sense desire, then the self is annihilated with the annihilation of the body.

original: evaṃ so diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto. Dutiyādivādesu yadi paṭhamavādasaṅgahito soyeva
analyzed: evam saḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna ppattaḥ dutiya ādi vādesu yadi paṭhama vāda saṅgahitaḥ

original: attā paṭhamajjhānādisamaṅgī, evaṃ sati diṭṭhadhammanibbānappattoti. Teneva hi ucchedavāde🔽viya idha pāḷiyaṃ “añño attā”ti aññaggahaṇaṃ na kataṃ. Kathaṃ pana accantanibbānapaññāpakassa
analyzed: attā paṭhamajjhāna ādi samaṅgī evam sati diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna ppatto ti tena iva hi uccheda vāde  viya idha pāḷiyam aññaḥ attā ati añña ggahaṇam na katam katham pana accanta nibbāna paññāpakassa
translated: So he has attained extinction in this very life. If in the second and subsequent statements the self is the same as that included in the first statement, which is endowed with the first jhāna, etc., then it has attained extinction in this very life. For this reason the phrase ‘another self’ is not used here as it is in the annihilationist view.

original: attano diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādassa sassatadiṭṭhiyā saṅgaho, na ucchedadiṭṭhiyāti?🔽Taṃtaṃsukhavisesasamaṅgitāpaṭiladdhena bandhavimokkhena suddhassa attano sakarūpeneva
analyzed: attanaḥ diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādassa sassata diṭṭhiyā saṅgahaḥ na uccheda diṭṭhiyā ati  taṃ taṃ sukha visesa samaṅgi tā paṭiladdhena bandha vimokkhena suddhassa attano saka rūpena iva
translated: But how is the view that the self attains extinction in this very life, which proclaims absolute nibbāna, included in the eternalist view and not in the annihilationist view?

original: avaṭṭhānadīpanato. Tesañhi tathāpaṭiladdhena kammabandhavimokkhena suddho hutvā diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto🔽attā sakarūpeneva avaṭṭhāsīti laddhi. Tathā hi pāḷiyaṃ “ettāvatā kho bho ayaṃ attā
analyzed: avaṭṭhāna dīpanato tesam hi tathā paṭiladdhena kamma bandha vimokkhena suddhaḥ hutvā diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna ppatto 🔽attā saka rūpena iva avaṭṭhāsi iti laddhi tathā hi pāḷiyam ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā
translated: Because it shows that the self, which is pure and free from the bonds of kamma, remains in its own form by attaining a particular kind of bliss. For they hold the view that the self, which is pure and free from the bonds of kamma by attaining that particular kind of bliss, remains in its own form and attains extinction in this very life.🔽For this reason the text says: “At this point, Master Gotama, the self is well released from the bond that is ageing-and-death. It has understood the gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of forms … in the case of consciousness. It has abandoned craving, severed the fetter, and by completely breaking through conceit, it has made an end of suffering. At this point, Master Gotama, the self is well released from the bond that is ageing-and-death.”

original: paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ patto hotī”ti sassatabhāvañāpakacchāyāya eva tesaṃ vādadassanaṃ katanti.

original: “Ettāvatā”tiādinā pāḷiyatthasampiṇḍanaṃ. Tattha yāsanti yathāvuttānaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ aniyamaniddesavacanaṃ.

translated: then the view-speculator’s being is included in the past and future only.🔽So how can it be said that the two are not seen together?

original: cā”ti upari vadantena bhagavatā pubbantāparantehi visuṃ katvā vuttoyevāti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Aṭṭhakathāyampi “sabbepi te pubbantāparantakappike”ti etena sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesena

translated: “He might fall into the view that what is unprofitable is profitable.” But who are those who hold the view of the past and the future? They are those who, as eternalists,

original: 100-104. “Idānī”tiādinā appanāvacanadvayassa visesaṃ dasseti. Tattha ekajjhanti rāsikaraṇatthe

analyzed: apekkha ayam ayam pi pārājika uti ādīsu sampiṇḍane vā tena yathā vattha sutta ādīsu  paṭipakkha dhamma ppakāsana vasena yathānusandhi evam imasmim pi brahmajāla iti apekkhanam  sampiṇḍanam vā karoti tathā hi nicca sāra ādi paññāpakānam diṭṭhi gatānam vasena uṭṭhitā ayam
translated: and in the case of the “and so on” in “he is also one who is defeated” and so on, or in the case of the “and so on” in the “and the rest” in the “and so on” in “the offense entailing suspension and the rest,”🔽then just as in the case of the “and so on” in “cloth, a robe, and the rest,”🔽and in the case of the “and so on” in “a monk, a nun, and the rest,”🔽he should expect the same in the case of the “and so on” in “Brahma and the rest,”🔽or he should combine them. For in the case of the “and so on” in “Brahma and the rest,”🔽the “and so on” is stated in order to show the opposite qualities,🔽and in order to show the opposite qualities, the “and so on” is stated.

Mariyādavibhāgadassanatthanti diṭṭhigatikānaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhiparāmāsassa tathāgatānaṃ🔽jānanapassanena, sassatādimicchādassanassa ca sammādassanena saṅkarābhāva-vibhāgappakāsanatthaṃ.🔽Taṇhādiṭṭhiparāmāsoyeva tesaṃ, na tu tathāgatānamiva yathābhūtaṃ jānanapassanaṃ.
analyzed: desanā nicca sāra ādi suñña tā pakāsanena niṭṭhāpitā ati tena ati ādinā yathāvutta saṃvaṇṇanāya guṇam dasseti 🔽        🔽mariyāda vibhāga dassana ttham ti diṭṭhi gatikānam taṇhā diṭṭhi parāmāsassa tathāgatānam 🔽jānana passanena sassata ādim icchā dassanassa ca sammādassanena saṅkara abhāva vibhāga ppakāsana attham 🔽taṇhā diṭṭhi parāmāsaḥ yā iva tesam na tu tathāgatānam iva yathābhūtam jānana passanam
