original: Taṇhādiṭṭhivipphandanamevetaṃ micchādassanavedayitaṃ, na tu sotāpannassa sammādassanavedayitamiva🔽niccalanti ca hi imāya desanāya mariyādavibhāgaṃ dasseti. Tena vakkhati “yena diṭṭhiassādena…pe…
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi vipphandanam eva etam micchādassana vedayitam na tu sotāpannassa sammādassana vedayitam iva  niccalanti ca hi imāya desanāya mariyāda vibhāgam dasseti tena vakkhati yena
translated: This is the oscillation of craving and view, the feeling of wrong view, not the feeling of right view as in one who has entered the stream.

original: taṃ vedayita”nti, “diṭṭhisaṅkhātena ceva…pe… dassetī”ti ca. “Tadapī”ti vuttattā yena🔽somanassajātā paññapentīti attho labbhatīti dassetuṃ “yenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sāmatthiyato
analyzed: tam vedayitanti diṭṭhi saṅkhātena dasseti iti ca tat api iti vutta ttā yena  somanassa jātā paññapenti iti atthaḥ labbhati iti dassetum yena atiādi vuttam sāmatthiyato
translated: “Unwavering” : by this teaching he shows the distinction of the noble ones. Therefore he says, “By the satisfaction of view … he shows the feeling of that” and “By the satisfaction of view … he shows the feeling of that.”🔽Since the word “that” is used, the meaning that can be obtained is that they describe it as “that” by which they are gladdened. In order to show this, he says, “By which they are gladdened” and so on.

original: hi avagatatthassevettha ta-saddena parāmasanaṃ. Diṭṭhiassādenāti diṭṭhiyā paccayabhūtena
analyzed: hi avagata tthassa iva ittha ta saddena parāmasanam diṭṭhi assādena āti diṭṭhiyā paccaya bhūtena
translated: For the word “that” refers to the meaning that is understood by capability.

original: assādena. “Diṭṭhisukhenā”tiādi tasseva vevacanaṃ. Ajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: assādena diṭṭhi sukhena atiādi tassa iva vevacanam a jānantānam a passantānam tesam
translated: By the satisfaction of view: by the satisfaction that is a condition for view. “By the happiness of view” and so on are synonyms for that.

original: bhavantānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ tadapi vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ vedayitanti sambandho.
analyzed: bhavantānam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam tat api vedayitam taṇhā gatānam sambandho
translated: The connection is this: that feeling of theirs, of those ascetics and brahmins who are reborn, who do not know and do not see, is the feeling of those who have come under the sway of craving.

original: “Yathābhūtadhammānaṃ sabhāva”nti ca avisesena vuttaṃ. Na hi saṅkhatadhammasabhāvaṃ
analyzed: yathā bhūta dhammānam ca avisesena vuttam na hi saṅkhata dhamma sabhāvam
translated: “The individual essence of things as they really are” is said without distinction.

original: ajānanamattena micchā abhinivisanti. Sāmaññajotanā ca visese avatiṭṭhati. Tasmāyamettha🔽visesayojanā kātabbā – “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti idaṃ diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ evaṃgahitaṃ
analyzed: a jānana mattena micchāḥ abhinivisanti sāmañña jotanā ca visese avatiṭṭhati tasmā ayam ettha  visesa yojanā kātabbā sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati idam diṭṭhiṭṭhānam evaṃgahitam
translated: For it is not only by not knowing the individual essence of formed things that they misapprehend them.🔽And the illustration is given in terms of the distinction. So the distinction should be made here as follows:

original: evaṃparāmaṭṭhaṃ evaṃgatikaṃ hoti evaṃabhisamparāyanti yathābhūtamajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ
analyzed: evaṃparāmaṭṭham evaṃgatikam hoti evam abhisamparāyanti yathābhūtam a jānantānam a passantānam
translated: When this view-point, “The self and the world are eternal,” is thus apprehended, thus clung to, thus adhered to, thus misapprehended,🔽then those who do not know and see as it really is the gratification in the world, the danger, the escape in regard to the world,

original: atha vā yasmiṃ vedayite avītataṇhatāya evaṃdiṭṭhigataṃ upādīyati, taṃ vedayitaṃ samudayaatthaṅgamādito🔽yathābhūtamajānantānaṃ apassantānanti. Evaṃ visesayojanāya hi yathā anāvaraṇañāṇasamantacakkhūhi
analyzed: atha vā yasmin vedayite a vīta taṇhā tāya evaṃdiṭṭhigatam upādīyati tam vedayitam samudaya atthaṅgama āditaḥ  yathābhūtam a jānantānam a passantānam ti evam visesa yojanāya hi yathā anāvaraṇa ñāṇa samanta cakkhūhi
translated: or else, the feeling in which craving has become lodged, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation,🔽then, by not knowing and seeing as it really is, as it is in its individual essence,🔽as the Tathāgatas know and see it with the eye of the knowledge of omniscience and the eye of the knowledge of the way things are,

original: tathāgatānaṃ yathābhūtamettha jānanaṃ, passanañca hoti, na evaṃ diṭṭhigatikānaṃ,
analyzed: tathāgatānam yathābhūtam ettha jānanam passanam ca hoti na evam diṭṭhi gatikānam
translated: so it is not for those who have a view.

original: atha kho tesaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhiparāmāsoyevāti imamatthaṃ imāya desanāya dassetīti pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: atha kho tesam taṇhā diṭṭhi parāmāsaḥ yā iva ati imam attham imāya desanāya dasseti iti pākaṭam
translated: But the meaning of the sutta is that he shows by this teaching that the craving and the view are the same in being the outcome of delight in mere feeling.

original: hoti. Evampi cāyaṃ desanā mariyādavibhāgadassanatthaṃ jātā.
analyzed: hoti evam pi ca ayam desanā mariyāda vibhāga dassana attham jātā
translated: So this teaching has been given in order to show the distinction of the two kinds of persons.

original: Vedayitanti “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti diṭṭhipaññāpanavasena pavattaṃ diṭṭhissādasukhapariyāyena
analyzed: vedayitanti sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati diṭṭhi paññāpana vasena pavattam diṭṭhi ssāda sukha pariyāyena
translated: “Feeling” : the delight in the view that “the self and the world are eternal” is called “feeling” by way of the happiness of delight in the view.

original: vuttaṃ, tadapi anubhavanaṃ. Taṇhāgatānanti taṇhāya upagatānaṃ, pavattānaṃ vā tadeva
analyzed: vuttam tat api anubhavanam taṇhā gatānam ti taṇhāya upagatānam pavattānam vā tat eva
translated: That is also experience. “Those who have come under the sway of craving” : those who have come under the sway of craving, or who are engaged in it.

original: vuttinayena vivarati “kevalaṃ…pe… vedayita”nti. Tañca kho panetanti ca yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: vutti nayena vivarati tat ca kho pana itanti ca yathā vuttam
translated: He explains that very same thing by the method of expression, “mere feeling” .

original: vedayitameva paccāmasati, tenetaṃ dīpeti – “tadapi vedayitaṃ taṇhāgatānaṃ vedayitamevā”ti
analyzed: vedayitam eva paccā āmasati tena itam dīpeti tat api vedayitam vedayitam eva ati
translated: And that very feeling, which is said to be “mere feeling,” is the same as the feeling of those who have come under the sway of craving.

original: vacchinditvā “tadapi vedayitaṃ paritassitavipphanditamevā”ti puna sambandho kātabboti.
analyzed: avacchinditvā tat api vedayitam paritassita vipphanditam eva ati punar sambandhaḥ kātabbaḥ ti
translated: The connection should be made thus: “That feeling is also mere feeling, but it is agitated and disturbed.”

original: Tadapi tāva na sampāpuṇātīti heṭṭhimaparicchedena mariyādavibhāgaṃ dassetuṃ “na sotāpannassa
analyzed: tat api tāva na sampāpuṇāti iti heṭṭhima paricchedena mariyāda vibhāgam dassetum na sotāpannassa
translated: “That does not suffice” : in order to show the distinction of the two kinds of persons by the lower section, he says, “It is not the case that the stream-enterer

original: dassanamiva niccala”nti vuttaṃ. Dassananti ca sammādassanasukhaṃ, maggaphalasukhanti
analyzed: dassanam iva niccalanti vuttam dassanam ti ca sammādassana sukham magga phala sukham ti
translated: And “seeing” is the bliss of right seeing, the bliss of the path and fruit.🔽And how is this meaning got? From the force of the word eva.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Kuto cāyamattho labbhatīti eva-saddasāmatthiyato. “Paritassitavipphanditamevā”ti
analyzed: vuttam hoti kutas ca ayam attho labbhati iti eva sadda sāmatthiyataḥ paritassita vipphanditam evā ti
translated: For the meaning that is got is this: “It is only the trembling of the agitated one”

original: hi vuttena maggaphalasukhaṃ viya avipphanditaṃ hutvā ekarūpe avatiṭṭhati, atha kho🔽taṃ vaṭṭāmisabhūtaṃ diṭṭhitaṇhāsallānuviddhatāya sauppīḷattā vipphanditamevāti attho
analyzed: hi vuttena magga phala sukham viya a vipphanditam hutvā ekarūpe avatiṭṭhati atha kho  tam vaṭṭa āmisa bhūtam diṭṭhi taṇhā salla anuviddha tāya sauppīḷa ttā vipphanditam eva ati attho
translated: is said, and the meaning is that it stands still in one place, as it were, unmoving like the bliss of the path and fruit.🔽But then, because it is pierced by the arrow of craving for views, it is oppressed, and so the meaning that is got is that it is trembling.

original: āpanno hoti, tenevāha “paritassitenā”tiādi. Ayamettha aṭṭhakathāmuttako sasambandhanayo.
analyzed: āpannaḥ hoti tena iva āha paritassitena atiādi ayam ettha aṭṭhakathā muttako sa sambandha nayo
translated: This is the method of explanation with its connection taken from the commentary.

original: Evaṃ visesakāraṇato dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni vibhajitvā idāni avisesakāraṇato tāni
analyzed: evam visesa kāraṇataḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni vibhajitvā idāni avisesa kāraṇataḥ tāni
translated: Having thus analyzed the sixty-two views according to their specific causes, the Master now began the teaching in order to show those views

original: dassetuṃ “tatra bhikkhave”tiādikā desanā āraddhā. Sabbesañhi diṭṭhigatānaṃ vedanā,
analyzed: dassetum tatra bhikkhave iti ādikā desanā āraddhā sabbesam hi diṭṭhi gatānam vedanā
translated: according to their general cause, with the words “Therein, bhikkhus.”🔽For all views have feeling, ignorance, and craving as their undifferentiated cause.

original: avijjā, taṇhā ca avisiṭṭhakāraṇaṃ. Tattha tadapīti “sassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapentī”ti
analyzed: avijjā taṇhā ca a visiṭṭha kāraṇam tattha tat api iti sassatam attānam ca lokañca paññapenti iti
translated: Herein, that too is the same: “They describe a self and the world as eternal” .

original: ettha yadetaṃ “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti paññāpanahetubhūtaṃ sukhādibhedaṃ tividhampi🔽vedayitaṃ, tadapi yathākkamaṃ dukkhasallāniccato, avisesena samudayatthaṅgamassādādīnavanissaraṇato
analyzed: ettha yat etam sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati paññāpana hetu bhūtam sukha ādi bhedam tividham pi  vedayitam tat api yathākkamam dukkha salla aniccataḥ avisesena samudaya tthaṅgama ssāda ādīnava nissaraṇato
translated: Herein, the three kinds of feeling, which are the cause for the postulating of the self and the world as eternal, etc., as pleasure, etc., are respectively the source of the dart of pain, and, without distinction, they are the source of the escape from the gratification, etc., in the meaning of origin and of cessation.🔽

original: vā yathābhūtamajānantānaṃ apassantānaṃ hoti, tato eva ca sukhādipatthanāsambhavato,
analyzed: vā yathābhūtam a jānantānam a passantānam hoti tatas eva ca sukha ādi patthanā sambhavato
translated: Herein, the three kinds of feeling, namely, pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant, which are the cause for the postulating of the self and the world as eternal, etc., are, respectively, the source of suffering, and, without distinction, the source of the origin, the passing away, the satisfaction, the danger, and the escape in the case of those who do not know and see them as they are. And because of that, the desire for pleasure, etc., is possible.

original: taṇhāya ca upagatattā taṇhāgatānaṃ taṇhāparitassitena diṭṭhivipphanditameva diṭṭhicalanameva.
analyzed: taṇhāya ca upagata ttā taṇhā gatānam taṇhā paritassitena diṭṭhi vipphanditam eva diṭṭhi calanam eva
translated: And because they have come under the sway of craving, the vacillation of views due to the agitation of craving is itself the “flutter of views.”

original: “Asati attani ko vedanaṃ anubhavatī”ti kāyavacīdvāresu diṭṭhiyā copanappattimattameva,
analyzed: asati kaḥ vedanam anubhavati iti kāya vacī dvāresu diṭṭhiyā
translated: “If there is no self, who experiences the feeling?”—this is mere postulation of a view at the doors of body and speech.

original: na pana diṭṭhiyā paññapetabbo koci dhammo sassato atthīti adhippāyoti. Ekaccasassatādīsupi esa nayo.
analyzed: na pana diṭṭhiyā paññapetabbaḥ koci dhammo sassataḥ atthi iti adhippāyaḥ ti ekacca sassata ādīsu pi esa nayo
translated: But the intention is that there is no existent entity that can be postulated by a view as eternal. The same method applies to the case of the partial-eternalism, etc.

original: Phassapaccayavāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: phassa paccaya vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the conditionality of contact

original: 118. Paramparapaccayadassanatthanti yaṃ diṭṭhiyā mūlakāraṇaṃ, tassāpi kāraṇaṃ, puna
analyzed: parampara paccaya dassana ttham ti yam diṭṭhiyāḥ mūla kāraṇam tassa api kāraṇam puna
translated: The purpose of showing the successive conditions is this: the root cause of the view is the condition for that, and that is the condition for the view.

original: tassapi kāraṇanti evaṃ paccayaparamparadassanatthaṃ. Yena hi taṇhāparitassitena etāni
analyzed: tassa api kāraṇam ti evam paccaya parampara dassana attham yena hi taṇhā paritassitena etāni
translated: and the reason for that is the reason for that. Thus the teaching is given in order to show the succession of conditions. For it is by one who is agitated by craving that these views

original: diṭṭhigatāni pavattanti, tassa vedayitaṃ paccayo, vedayitassāpi phasso paccayoti
analyzed: diṭṭhigatāni pavattanti tassa vedayitam paccayaḥ vedayitassa api phassaḥ paccayaḥ ti
translated: are brought into play. The reason for that is feeling. The reason for feeling is contact.

original: evaṃ paccayaparamparavibhāvinī ayaṃ desanā. Kimatthiyaṃ pana paccayaparamparadassananti🔽ce? Atthantaraviññāpanatthaṃ. Tena hi yathā diṭṭhisaṅkhāto paññāpanadhammo, tappaccayadhammā
analyzed: evam paccaya parampara vibhāvinī ayam desanā kim atthiyam pana paccaya parampara dassanam ti  ce atthantara viññāpana ttham tena hi yathā diṭṭhi saṅkhātaḥ paññāpana dhammo tad paccaya dhammā
translated: Thus this teaching is a disclosure of the succession of conditions. But what is the purpose of showing the succession of conditions?

original: ca yathāsakaṃ paccayavaseneva uppajjanti, na paccayehi vinā, evaṃ paññapetabbadhammāpi
analyzed: ca yathāsakam paccaya vasena iva uppajjanti na paccayehi vinā evam paññapetabba dhammā api
translated: It is to show the difference in meaning. For the purpose of showing that the things that are taught as views, etc., and the things that are their conditions arise only by way of condition and not without conditions, and that the things that should be taught, such as material form, feeling, etc.,

original: rūpavedanādayo, na ettha koci sassato attā vā loko vāti evamatthantaraṃ viññāpitaṃ
analyzed: rūpa vedanā ādayaḥ na ettha koci sassataḥ attā vā lokaḥ vā ati evam atthantaram viññāpitam
translated: are not eternal or a self or the world, the difference in meaning is shown.

original: hoti. Taṇhādiṭṭhipariphanditaṃ tadapi vedayitaṃ diṭṭhikāraṇabhūtāya taṇhāya paccayabhūtaṃ
analyzed: hoti taṇhā diṭṭhi pariphanditam tat api vedayitam diṭṭhi kāraṇa bhūtāya taṇhāya paccaya bhūtam
translated: And that feeling that is agitated by craving and views is a condition for craving, which is the cause of the views, and it is a condition for contact, which is the condition for feeling.

original: phassapaccayā hotīti attho.
analyzed: phassa paccayā hoti iti attho
translated: This is the meaning.

original: 131. Tassa paccayassāti tassa phassasaṅkhātassa paccayassa. Diṭṭhivedayite diṭṭhiyā
analyzed: tassa paccayassa ati tassa phassa saṅkhātassa paccayassa diṭṭhi vedayite diṭṭhiyā
translated: ‘Of that condition’: of the condition called contact. ‘In feeling born of views’: in feeling which is a condition for views.

original: paccayabhūte vedayite, phassapadhānehi attano paccayehi nipphādetabbe. Sādhetabbe
analyzed: paccaya bhūte vedayite phassa padhānehi attanaḥ paccayehi nipphādetabbe sādhetabbe
translated: ‘To be effected, to be accomplished, by the bases of contact’: to be produced, to be brought about, by its own conditions, which are the bases of contact.

original: cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Balavabhāvadassanatthanti balavakāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Tathā hi
analyzed: ca itam bhummam balava bhāva dassana attham ti balava kāraṇa bhāva dassana attham tathā hi
translated: The locative ending has the sense of cause. ‘In order to show the powerfulness’: in order to show the state of being a powerful cause. For

original: vināpi cakkhādivatthūhi, sampayuttadhammehi ca kehici vedanā uppajjati, na pana kadācipi
analyzed: vinā api cakkha ādi vatthūhi sampayutta dhammehi ca kehici vedanā uppajjati na pana kadāci pi
translated: feeling arises even without the physical basis, the eye, etc., and without some of the associated states, but it never arises

original: phassena vinā, tasmā phasso vedanāya balavakāraṇaṃ. Na kevalaṃ vedanāya eva, atha
analyzed: phassena vinā phassaḥ vedanāya na kevalam vedanāya eva atha
translated: without contact. Therefore contact is a powerful cause for feeling. And not only for feeling, but also

original: kho sesasampayuttadhammānampi. Sannihitopi hi visayo sace cittuppādo phusanākāravirahito
analyzed: kho sesa sampayutta dhammānam pi sannihitaḥ api hi visayo sace cittuppādaḥ phusana ākāra virahitaḥ
translated: for the other associated states. For even though the object is present, if the arising of consciousness lacks the mode of activity called ‘contact’,

original: hoti, na tassa ārammaṇapaccayo bhavatīti phasso sabbesampi sampayuttadhammānaṃ visesapaccayo.
analyzed: hoti na tassa ārammaṇa paccayaḥ bhavati iti phassaḥ sabbesam pi sampayutta dhammānam visesa paccayaḥ
translated: it is not a condition by way of object for that consciousness. Therefore contact is a distinctive condition for all the associated states.

original: Tathā hi bhagavatā dhammasaṅgaṇīpakaraṇe cittuppādaṃ vibhajantena “phasso hotī”ti
analyzed: tathā hi bhagavatā dhammasaṅgaṇī pakaraṇe cittuppādam vibhajantena phassaḥ hoti iti
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One in the Dhammasangani when he analyses the arising of consciousness: ‘There is contact’ .

original: phassasseva paṭhamamuddharaṇaṃ kataṃ, vedanāya pana sātisayamadhiṭṭhānapaccayo eva.
analyzed: phassassa iva paṭhamam uddharaṇam katam vedanāya pana sa atisayam adhiṭṭhāna paccayo eva
translated: The first to be mentioned is contact, but feeling is the most important condition.

original: “Paṭisaṃvedissantī”ti vuttattā “tadapī”ti etthādhikāroti āha “taṃ vedayita”nti. Gamyamānatthassa
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedissanti iti vutta ttā tat api iti ettha adhikāraḥ iti āha tam vedayitanti gamyamāna atthassa
translated: “In the future” is the meaning of “tadapi,” he says. “That feeling” is the meaning of “tadapi.”

original: vā-saddassa payogaṃ pati kāmacārattā, lopattā, sesattāpi ca esa na payutto. Evamīdisesu. Hoti cettha –
analyzed: vā saddassa payogam kāmacāra ttā lopa ttā sesa ttā api ca esa na payuttaḥ evam īdisesu hoti ca ittha
translated: The word “vā” is used in the sense of “gamya” (what is to be gone to). It is not used in the sense of “lopa” (omission) and “sesa” (remainder).

original: “Gamyamānādhikārato, lopato sesato cāti;
analyzed: gamyamāna adhikārataḥ lopataḥ ca ati
translated: “In the future,” “by omission,” and “by remainder,”

original: Kāraṇehi catūhipi, na katthaci ravo yutto”ti.
analyzed: kāraṇehi na katthaci ravaḥ yuttaḥ ti
translated: For these four reasons, the word “vā” is not used anywhere.

original: “Yathā hī”tiādinā phassassa balavakāraṇatādassanena tadatthaṃ samattheti. Tattha patatoti patantassa. Thūṇāti upatthambhakadārussetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: yathā hi iti ādinā phassassa balava kāraṇa tā dassanena tad attham samatthā iti tattha patatoti patantassa thūṇā ati adhivacanam
translated: By showing the powerful cause of contact, he makes it possible by saying “Yathā hi,” etc. There, “patato” means “falling.” “Thūṇa” is a post.

original: Diṭṭhigatikādhiṭṭhānavaṭṭakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: diṭṭhigatika adhiṭṭhāna vaṭṭa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion on the round of views.

original: 144. Kiñcāpi imasmiṃ ṭhāne pāḷiyaṃ vedayitamanāgataṃ, heṭṭhā pana tīsupi vāresu adhikatattā,
analyzed: kiñca api imasmin ṭhāne pāḷiyam vedayitam anāgatam heṭṭhā pana tīsu pi vāresu
translated: Although in this section the future feeling is stated in the text, below in the three sections,

original: upari ca “phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedentī”ti vakkhamānattā vedayitamevettha padhānanti
analyzed: upari ca phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedenti iti vakkhamāna ttā vedayitam eva ittha padhānanti
translated: And since it will be said below, “They feel feeling by feeling,” feeling is the principal thing here.

original: āha “sabbadiṭṭhivedayitāni sampiṇḍetī”ti. “Yepi te”ti tattha tattha āgatassa ca pi-saddassa
analyzed: āha sabba diṭṭhi vedayitāni sampiṇḍeti iti ye pi te iti tattha tattha āgatassa ca pi saddassa
translated: So he said, “He combines all the views and feelings.” The word “and” in the passage “and those who are eternalists, etc.,”

original: atthaṃ sandhāya “sampiṇḍetī”ti vuttaṃ. Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā…pe… sabbepi
analyzed: attham sandhāya sampiṇḍeti iti vuttam ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇā sabbe api
translated: is stated to combine the meaning of the word “and” in the passage “and those who are eternalists, etc.,”

original: te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedentīti hi vedayitakiriyāvasena taṃtaṃdiṭṭhigatikānaṃ
analyzed: te chahi phassa āyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedenti iti hi vedayita kiriyā vasena taṃ taṃ diṭṭhi gatikānam
translated: since all those wanderers of various sects who are eternalists, etc., feel feeling by feeling through the six bases of contact.🔽Thus, since the various views of the wanderers of various sects are combined by way of the function of feeling, there is only a combination of feelings.

original: sampiṇḍitattā vedayitasampiṇḍanameva jātaṃ. Sabbampi hi vākyaṃ kiriyāpadhānanti.
analyzed: sampiṇḍita ttā vedayita sampiṇḍanam eva jātam sabbam pi hi vākyam kiriyā apadhānam ti
translated: For all the sentences are based on the function of action.

original: Upari phasse pakkhipanatthāyāti “chahi phassāyatanehī”ti vutte upari phasse pakkhipanatthaṃ,
analyzed: upari phasse pakkhipana atthāya ati chahi phassāyatanehi iti vutte upari phasse pakkhipana attham
translated: For the purpose of including contact above: when it is said “through the six bases of contact,” for the purpose of including contact above,

original: pakkhipanañcettha vedayitassa phassapaccayatādassanameva. “Chahi phassāyatanehi phussa
analyzed: pakkhipanam ca ittha vedayitassa phassa paccaya tā dassanam eva chahi phassa āyatanehi
translated: for the purpose of including contact above. And the inclusion here is only the showing that feeling has contact as its condition.

original: phussa paṭisaṃvedentī”ti iminā hi chahi ajjhattikāyatanehi chaḷārammaṇapaṭisaṃvedanaṃ
analyzed: phussa paṭisaṃvedenti iti iminā hi chahi ajjhattika āyatanehi chaṭṭha ārammaṇa paṭisaṃvedanam
translated: For by the words, “experiencing through the six internal bases,”

original: ekantato chaphassahetukamevāti dassitaṃ hoti, tena vuttaṃ “sabbe te”tiādi.
analyzed: ekantataḥ cha phassa hetukam evā ti dassitam hoti tena vuttam sabbe te itiādi
translated: it is shown that the experiencing of the six objects is entirely due to the six internal bases. Thus it is said, “All these are due to contact.”

original: Kambojoti evaṃnāmakaṃ raṭṭhaṃ. Tathā dakkhiṇāpatho. “Sañjātiṭṭhāne”ti iminā sañjāyanti
analyzed: kambojaḥ iti evaṃnāmakam raṭṭham tathā dakkhiṇāpatho sañjātiṭṭhānā iti iminā sañjāyanti
translated: “Kamboja” is the name of a country. So too, “the southern region.” By the words, “in the place of birth,”

original: etthāti adhikaraṇattho sañjāti-saddoti dasseti. Evaṃ samosaraṇa-saddo. Āyatana-saddopi
analyzed: ettha iti adhikaraṇa attho sañjāti saddo ti dasseti evam samosaraṇa saddaḥ āyatana saddaḥ api
translated: he shows that the word “birth” has the meaning of the place of birth. So too, the word “meeting place.” The word “base”

original: tadubhayatthe. Āyataneti samosaraṇabhūte catumahāpathe. Nanti mahānigrodharukkhaṃ.
analyzed: tad ubhayatthe āyatana iti samosaraṇa bhūte catu mahāpathe mahānigrodha rukkham
translated: also has both meanings. “In the base” means in the meeting place, the four-road crossing. “Nigrodha” is a great banyan tree.

original: Idañhi aṅguttarāgame pañcanipāte saddhānisaṃsasuttapadaṃ. Tattha ca seyyathāpi bhikkhave
analyzed: idam hi aṅguttara āgame pañcanipāte saddhānisaṃsa sutta padam tattha ca seyyathā api bhikkhave
translated: For this is a passage from the Sutta on the Benefits of Faith in the Anguttara Nikaya, the Book of Fives. And there it is said:🔽“Bhikkhus, just as a great banyan tree,

original: subhūmiyaṃ catumahāpathe mahānigrodho samantā pakkhīnaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ hotī”ti tanniddeso
analyzed: subhūmiyam catu mahāpathe mahānigrodho samantā pakkhīnam paṭisaraṇam hoti iti tad niddeso
translated: a meeting place for the birds, is a support for the birds,🔽so too, bhikkhus, wherever there is a condition called mindfulness,

original: vutto. Sati satiāyataneti satisaṅkhāte kāraṇe vijjamāne, tatra tatreva sakkhitabbataṃ
analyzed: vuttaḥ sati sati āyatane iti sati saṅkhāte kāraṇe vijjamāne tatra tatra iva sakkhitabba tam
translated: there is the support of concentration and wisdom.

original: pāpuṇātīti attho. Āyatanti ettha phalāni tadāyattavuttitāya pavattanti, āyabhūtaṃ
analyzed: pāpuṇāti iti atthaḥ ettha phalāni tad āyatta vutti tāya pavattanti āya bhūtam
translated: The meaning is: it reaches. In āyatana, the fruits occur dependent on that, or it extends its own fruit,

original: vā attano phalaṃ tanoti pavattetīti āyatanaṃ, kāraṇaṃ. Sammantīti upasammanti assāsaṃ
analyzed: vā attanaḥ phalam tanoti pavatteti iti āyatanam kāraṇam sammanti iti upasammanti assāsam
translated: thus it is an āyatana, a cause. Sammantīti upasammanti assāsaṃ janenti.

original: janenti. Āyatana-saddo aññesu viya na ettha atthantarāvabodhakoti āha “paṇṇattimatte”ti,🔽tathā tathā paññattimatteti attho. Rukkhagacchasamūhe paṇṇattimatte hi araññavohāro,
analyzed: janenti āyatana saddo aññesu viya na ettha attha antara avabodhako ti āha paṇṇattimattā iti  tathā tathā paññattimattā iti atthaḥ rukkha gaccha samūhe paṇṇattimatte hi arañña vohāro
translated: The word āyatana does not indicate a different meaning here as in other places, thus he says “in mere designation”🔽the meaning is: in mere designation as this or that. For in a mere designation of a tree, a forest, and a collection, there is the expression “forest,”

original: araññameva ca araññāyatananti. Atthattayepīti ettha pi-saddena ākaranivāsādhiṭṭhānatthe
analyzed: araññam eva ca araññāyatanan ti atthattaye pi iti ettha pi saddena ākara nivāsa adhiṭṭhāna tthe
translated: and the forest itself is the forest-āyatana. In atthattayepi, the word pi includes the meanings of mode, abode, and basis.

original: sampiṇḍeti. “Hiraññāyatanaṃ suvaṇṇāyatana”ntiādīsu hi ākare, “issarāyatanaṃ vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu🔽nivāse, “kammāyatanaṃ sippāyatana”ntiādīsu adhiṭṭhāne pavattati, nissayeti attho.
analyzed: sampiṇḍeti hiraññāyatanam suvaṇṇāyatana nti ādīsu hi ākare issara āyatanam vāsudevāyatana nti ādīsu  nivāse kamma āyatanam sippa āyatanam ti ādīsu adhiṭṭhāne pavattati nissaye ti attho
translated: For in such passages as “the āyatana of gold, the āyatana of silver,” the word occurs in the sense of mode; in such passages as “the āyatana of the overlord, the āyatana of Vāsudeva,”🔽in the sense of abode; and in such passages as “the āyatana of work, the āyatana of craft,” in the sense of basis. The meaning is: in a condition.

original: Āyatanti ettha ākaronti, nivasanti, adhiṭṭhahantīti yathākkamaṃ vacanattho. Cakkhādīsu
analyzed: āyatanti ettha ākaronti nivasanti adhiṭṭhahanti iti yathākkamam vacana atthaḥ cakkha ādīsu
translated: In āyatana, the meaning of the word is respectively: they extend, they abide, they are based.

original: ca phassādayo ākiṇṇā, tāni ca nesaṃ vāso, adhiṭṭhānañca nissayapaccayabhāvato. Tasmā
analyzed: ca phassa ādayaḥ ākiṇṇā tāni ca nesam vāsaḥ adhiṭṭhānam ca nissaya paccaya bhāvato tasmā
translated: and the contact, etc., are crowded in the eye, etc., and they are its abode and its foundation by way of the condition of support. Therefore

original: tadetampi atthattayamidha yujjatiyeva. Kathaṃ yujjatīti āha “cakkhādīsu hī”tiādi.
analyzed: tat etat pi katham yujjati iti āha cakkha ādīsu hi itiādi
translated: this triad of meaning is appropriate here. How is it appropriate? He says, “In the eye, etc., indeed,” and so on.

original: Phasso vedanā saññā cetanā cittanti ime phassapañcamakā dhammā upalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: phassaḥ vedanā saññā cetanā cittanti ime phassa pañcamakā dhammā upalakkhaṇa vasena
translated: The five things beginning with contact, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness, are stated by way of characteristic,

original: vuttā aññesampi taṃsampayuttadhammānaṃ āyatanabhāvato, padhānavasena vā. Tathā hi🔽cittuppādaṃ vibhajantena bhagavatā teyeva “phasso hoti, vedanā, saññā, cetanā, cittaṃ
analyzed: vuttā aññesam pi tad sampayutta dhammānam āyatana bhāvataḥ padhāna vasena vā tathā hi  cittuppādam vibhajantena bhagavatā teyeva phassaḥ hoti vedanā saññā cetanā cittam
translated: because they are the bases of the other associated things, or by way of predominance. Thus

original: hotī”ti paṭhamaṃ vibhattā. Sañjāyanti tannissayārammaṇabhāvena tattheva uppattito.
analyzed: hoti iti paṭhamam vibhattā sañjāyanti tad nissaya ārammaṇa bhāvena tattha eva uppattitaḥ
translated: when the Exalted One analyzed the arising of consciousness, he first analyzed those five things, saying, “There is contact, there is feeling, there is perception, there is volition, there is consciousness,”🔽because they arise there by way of being its support and object.

original: Samosaranti tattha tattha vatthudvārārammaṇabhāvena samosaraṇato. Tāni ca nesaṃ kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: samosaranti tattha tattha vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa bhāvena samosaraṇato tāni ca na īsam kāraṇam
translated: They come together there by way of the object, the door, and the basis. And they are its cause

original: tesamabhāve abhāvato. Ayaṃ pana yathāvutto sañjātidesādiattho ruḷhivaseneva tattha
analyzed: tesam abhāve abhāvataḥ ayam pana yathā vuttaḥ sañjāti desa ādi attho ruḷhi vasena iva tattha
translated: because it does not exist when they do not exist. But this meaning of arising, etc., as stated, is appropriate there by way of derivation🔽only.

original: tattha niruḷhatāya eva pavattattāti ācariyaānandattherena vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ pana padatthavivaraṇamukhena🔽pavatto attho – āyatanato, āyānaṃ tananato, āyatassa ca nayanato āyatanaṃ. Cakkhādīsu
analyzed: tattha niruḷha tāya eva pavatta tā ti ācariya ānandattherena vuttam ayam pana padattha vivaraṇa mukhena  pavattaḥ atthaḥ āyatanataḥ āyānam tananataḥ āyatassa ca nayanataḥ āyatanam cakkha ādīsu
translated: Herein, it is said by the Elder Ānanda that it is because of the occurrence of the eye, etc., as the outcome of the kamma-process.🔽But the meaning that occurs here by way of the explanation of the word-meaning is this: It is a sense-base because of the going out of the life-continuum, because of the spreading out of the life-continuum, and because of the leading of the life-continuum.

original: hi taṃtaṃdvārārammaṇā cittacetasikā dhammā sena sena anubhavanādikiccena āyatanti
analyzed: hi taṃ taṃ dvāra ārammaṇā citta cetasikā dhammā sena sena anubhavana ādi kiccena āyatanti
translated: For in the eye, etc., the states of consciousness and its concomitants, by the function of experiencing, etc., go out, arise, are active, strive, in regard to the respective doors and objects.

original: uṭṭhahanti ghaṭenti vāyamanti, āyabhūte ca dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārenti, āyatañca🔽saṃsāradukkhaṃ nayanti pavattentīti. Iti iminā nayenāti ettha ādiatthena iti saddena
analyzed: uṭṭhahanti ghaṭenti vā āyamanti āya bhūte ca dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārenti āyatam ca  saṃsāra dukkham nayanti pavattenti iti iti iminā nayena ati ettha ādi atthena iti saddena
translated: And they spread out, extend, the states that are the life-continuum. And they lead, cause to occur, the life-continuum, the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: “sotaṃ paṭiccā”tiādipāḷiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: sotam paṭicca ati ādi pāḷim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: So by this method: here the word “so” includes the text of the sutta beginning with the words “With the ear as condition” .

original: Tattha tiṇṇanti cakkhupasādarūpārammaṇacakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ visayindriyaviññāṇānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha tiṇṇam ti cakkhu pasāda rūpa ārammaṇa cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam tiṇṇam visayindriya viññāṇānam
translated: Herein, three: of the three, namely, the object, the sense-faculty, and the consciousness, of the eye, the visible-form object, and eye-consciousness, etc.

original: Tesaṃ samāgamanabhāvena gahetabbato “phasso saṅgatī”ti vutto. Tathā hi so “sannipātapaccupaṭṭhāno”ti
analyzed: tesam samāgamana bhāvena gahetabbataḥ phassaḥ saṅgatī iti vuttaḥ tathā hi so sannipāta paccupaṭṭhāno ti
translated: “Contact is the meeting” is said because it is to be apprehended by the state of meeting of those three. For that is described thus: “It has the characteristic of impingement” .

original: vuccati. Iminā nayena āropetvāti sambandho. Tena imamatthaṃ dasseti – yathā “cakkhuṃpaṭicca…pe…🔽phasso”ti etasmiṃ sutte vijjamānesupi saññādīsu sampayuttadhammesu vedanāya padhānakāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vuccati iminā nayena āropetvā iti sambandho tena imam attham dasseti yathā  phasso ti etasmin sutte vijjamānesu pi saññā ādīsu sampayutta dhammesu vedanāya padhāna kāraṇa bhāva dassana ttham
translated: Thus he shows this meaning: Just as in this sutta, “With eye as condition …

original: phassasīsena desanā katā, evamidhāpi “phassapaccayā vedanā”tiādinā phassaṃ ādiṃ katvā
analyzed: phassa sīsena desanā katā evam idha api phassa paccayā vedanā ati ādinā phassam ādim katvā
translated: contact …,” although such associated states as perception exist, the teaching is given in terms of contact as the beginning, for the purpose of showing that feeling is the principal cause,

original: aparantapaṭisandhānena paccayaparamparaṃ dassetuṃ “chahi phassāyatanehī”ti ca “phussa
analyzed: aparanta paṭisandhānena paccaya paramparam dassetum chahi phassa āyatanehi iti ca
translated: so too here, in order to show the succession of conditions beginning with contact, “with the six bases,” and “contact … contact,”🔽the teaching is given in terms of contact as the beginning, by way of the rebirth-linking at the end.

original: phussā”ti ca phassasīsena desanā katāti. Phassāyatanādīnīti ādi-saddena “phussa phussā”ti vacanaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: phussā ati ca phassa sīsena desanā katā ati phassa āyatana ādīni iti ādi saddena phussa phussa ati vacanam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The words “the six bases” and so on include the words “contact … contact.”

original: “Kiñcāpī”tiādinā saddamattato codanālesaṃ dassetvā “tathāpī”tiādinā atthato taṃ pariharati.
analyzed: kiñcā api itiādinā codana ālesam dassetvā tathā api itiādinā atthataḥ tam pariharati
translated: Having shown the opportunity for objection from the mere words in the passage beginning with “although,” he replies in meaning in the passage beginning with “nevertheless.”

original: Na āyatanāni phusanti rūpānamanārammaṇabhāvato. Phasso arūpadhammo visamāno ekadesena
analyzed: na āyatanāni phusanti rūpānam anārammaṇa bhāvataḥ phassaḥ arūpa dhammaḥ visamānaḥ eka desena
translated: The bases do not contact visible data, because they are not objects of the latter. Contact, being a mental datum, does not contact the bases, because it is not their object. Nor do the bases contact contact, because they are not its object. Nor does contact contact itself.

original: ārammaṇaṃ analliyamānopi phusanākārena pavatto phusanto viya hotīti āha “phassova
analyzed: ārammaṇam phusana ākārena pavattaḥ phusantaḥ viya hoti iti āha phassaḥ uva
translated: Though it does not actually touch the object, it occurs as if it touched it by the mode of touching, and so it is said that “contact touches that object.”

original: taṃ taṃ ārammaṇaṃ phusatī”ti. Teneva so “phusanalakkhaṇo, saṅghaṭṭanaraso”ti ca vuccati.
analyzed: tam tam ārammaṇam phusati iti tena iva so phusana lakkhaṇo saṅghaṭṭana rasaḥ ti ca vuccati
translated: That is why it is said to have the characteristic of touching, the function of impingement, and so on.

original: “Chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussā”ti aphusanakiccānipi nissitavohārena phusanakiccāni
analyzed: chahi phassāyatanehi nissita vohārena phusana kiccāni
translated: “With the six bases for contact as condition, contact” : though the functions of the six bases for contact are not touching, they are shown as if they were by the method of derivation.

original: katvā dassanameva phasse upanikkhipanaṃ nāma yathā “mañcā ghosantī”ti. Upanikkhipitvāti
analyzed: katvā dassanam eva phasse upanikkhipanam nāma yathā mañcāḥ ghosanti iti upanikkhipitvā ati
translated: The bringing of seeing into contact with contact is called “making it touch” in the way that one says, “The bed creaks.”🔽Having brought it into contact, having made it touch, having made it enter into contact by superimposing the function of touching on it, is the meaning.

original: hi phusanakiccāropanavasena phassasmiṃ pavesetvāti attho. Phassagatikāni katvā phassupacāraṃ
analyzed: hi phusana kicca āropana vasena phassasmim pavesetvā ati attho phassa gatikāni katvā phassa upacāram
translated: Having made it come under the heading of contact, having made it come under the heading of contact by superimposing the function of touching on it, is what is meant.

original: āropetvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Upacāro nāma vohāramattaṃ, na tena atthasiddhi ataṃsabhāvato.
analyzed: āropetvā iti vuttam hoti upacāraḥ nāma vohāra mattam na tena attha siddhi a taṃsa bhāvato
translated: The heading is mere usage; it does not establish the meaning by its own intrinsic nature.

original: Atthasijjhanako pana taṃsabhāvoyeva attho gahetabboti dassetuṃ “tasmā”tiādimāha. Yathāhu –🔽“Atthañhi nātho saraṇaṃ avoca,
analyzed: attha sijjhanakaḥ pana atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ iti dassetum tasmā iti ādim āha yathā āhu  atthan hi nātho saraṇam avoca
translated: But the meaning that establishes the meaning should be taken by its own intrinsic nature. In order to show this, he says “Therefore” and so on. As it is said:🔽“The Lord, the Great Sage, the Helper of the World,

original: Na byañjanaṃ lokahito mahesī”ti.
analyzed: na byañjanam loka hitaḥ mahā esi iti
translated: Has declared the meaning to be the refuge, not the letter.”

original: Attano paccayabhūtānaṃ channaṃ phassānaṃ vasena cakkhusamphassajā yāva manosamphassajāti saṅkhepato chabbidhaṃ sandhāya “chaphassāyatanasambhavā vedanā”ti vuttaṃ. Vitthārato pana –
analyzed: attanaḥ paccaya bhūtānam channam phassānam vasena cakkhu samphassa jā yāva manaḥ samphassa jā ti saṅkhepato chabbidham sandhāya cha phassa āyatana sambhavā vedanā iti vuttam vitthārato pana
translated: “Feeling born of contact with the six sense bases” is said in brief with reference to the six kinds of feeling born of contact with the six sense bases that are its conditions. But in detail it is

original: “Phassato chabbidhāpetā, upavicārabhedato;
analyzed: phassataḥ chabbidha apetāḥ upavicāra bhedataḥ
translated: “From contact, sixfold, then, from the seven stations of consciousness,

original: Tidhā nissitato dvīhi, tidhā kālena vaḍḍhitā”ti. –
analyzed: tidhā nissitataḥ dvīhi tidhā kālena vaḍḍhitā ati
translated: From the three rooted in craving, from the two, from the three by time increased.”

original: Aṭṭhasatapariyāye vuttanayena aṭṭhasatappabhedā. Mahāvihāravāsino cettha yathā viññāṇaṃ🔽nāmarūpaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, evaṃ phassaṃ, vedanañca paccayapaccayuppannampi sasantatipariyāpannaṃ🔽dīpento vipākameva icchanti, aññe pana yathā tathā vā paccayabhāvo sati na sakkā
analyzed: aṭṭhasata pariyāye vutta nayena aṭṭhasata ppabhedāḥ mahāvihāra vāsinaḥ ca ittha yathā viññāṇam  nāma rūpam saḷāyatanam evam phassam vedanam ca paccaya paccaya uppannam pi sa santati pariyāpannam  dīpentaḥ vipākam eva icchanti aññe pana yathā tathā vā paccaya bhāvo sati na sakkā
translated: It is of the eighty-eight kinds in the way stated in the Discourse on the Eighty-Eight. Herein, the residents of the Great Monastery maintain that, just as consciousness, mentality-materiality, and the sixfold base,🔽so contact and feeling, though conditionally arisen, are nevertheless only results of past kamma, and they are included in one’s own mental continuity.

original: vajjetunti sabbameva icchanti. Sāti yathāvuttappabhedā vedanā. Rūpataṇhādibhedāyāti
analyzed: vajjetunti sabbam eva icchanti sā ati yathāvutta ppabhedā vedanā rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedāya ati
translated: But others maintain that all of them are results of kamma in the way stated or otherwise, since it is not possible to deny the fact of their being conditions. And so they maintain that all of them are results of kamma. “Sati” is feeling of the kinds already stated. “Rūpataṇhādibhedāy” means “in order to abandon craving for materiality, etc.”

original: “seṭṭhiputto brāhmaṇaputto”ti pitunāmavasena viya ārammaṇanāmavasena vuttāya rūpataṇhā
analyzed: seṭṭhi putto brāhmaṇa putto ti pitu nāma vasena viya ārammaṇa nāma vasena vuttāya rūpa taṇhā
translated: “The craving for visible forms” is said by way of the name of the object, as “the son of a money-lender,” “the son of a brahmin,” is said by way of the name of the father.

original: yāva dhammataṇhāti saṅkhepato chabbidhāya. Vitthārato pana –
analyzed: yāva dhamma taṇhā ti saṅkhepato cha bidhāya vitthārato pana
translated: Craving for visible data, etc., is sixfold in brief, as craving for visible data, craving for sounds, craving for odour, craving for flavour, craving for tangible data, craving for mental data. In detail it is as follows:

original: “Rūpataṇhādikā kāma-taṇhādīhi tidhā puna;
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā ādikā tidhā puna
translated: “Craving for visible data, etc., is threefold by the three kinds of craving,

original: Santānato dvidhā kāla-bhedena guṇitā siyu”nti. –
analyzed: santānataḥ dvidhā kāla bhedena guṇitā
translated: And by continuity and time it is again twofold.”🔽So it is said to be of eight hundred and forty kinds.

original: Evaṃ vuttaaṭṭhasatappabhedāya. Upanissayakoṭiyāti upanissayasīsena. Kasmā panettha🔽upanissayapaccayova uddhaṭo, nanu sukhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā ca taṇhāya ārammaṇamattaārammaṇādhipatiārammaṇūpanissayapakatūpanissayavasena
analyzed: evam vutta aṭṭha sata ppabhedāya upanissaya koṭiyā ti upanissaya sīsena kasmā pana ittha  upanissaya paccayaḥ uva uddhaṭaḥ nanu sukhā vedanā adukkham asukhā ca taṇhāya ārammaṇa matta ārammaṇa adhipati ārammaṇa upanissaya pakatūpanissaya vasena
translated: As condition by way of decisive support: by way of the decisive-support condition.🔽But why is only the decisive-support condition mentioned here? Are not pleasant feeling and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling conditions for craving by way of object condition, object-predominance condition, object-decisive-support condition, and proximity-decisive-support condition,

original: catudhā paccayo, dukkhā ca ārammaṇamattapakatūpanissayavasena dvidhāti? Saccametaṃ,
analyzed: catudhā paccayaḥ dukkhā ca ārammaṇa matta pakatu upanissaya vasena dvidhā ati saccam etam
translated: and painful feeling by way of object condition and proximity-decisive-support condition? That is so,

original: upanissaye eva pana taṃ sabbampi antogadhanti evamuddhaṭo. Yuttaṃ tāva ārammaṇūpanissayassa
analyzed: upanissaye eva pana tam sabbam pi evam uddhaṭaḥ yuttam tāva ārammaṇa upanissayassa
translated: but all that is included in the decisive-support condition, and so it is mentioned thus. It is proper that the object-decisive-support condition should be mentioned,

original: upanissayasāmaññato upanissaye antogadhatā, kathaṃ pana ārammaṇamattaārammaṇādhipatīnaṃ
analyzed: upanissaya sāmaññato upanissaye antogadha tā katham pana ārammaṇa matta ārammaṇa adhipatīnam
translated: And the predominance of object is included in the decisive-support condition. But how is it that the object-predominance and the object-predominance-as-faculty are included in the decisive-support condition?

original: tattha antogadhabhāvo siyāti? Tesampi ārammaṇasāmaññato ārammaṇūpanissayena saṅgahitattā🔽ārammaṇūpanissayavasamodhānabhūteva upanissaye eva antogadhatā hoti. Etadatthameva🔽hi sandhāya “upanissayenā”ti avatvā “upanissayakoṭiyā”ti vuttaṃ. Siddhe hi satyārambho
analyzed: tattha antogadha bhāvo siyāti tesam pi ārammaṇa sāmaññato ārammaṇa upanissayena saṅgahita ttā  ārammaṇa upanissaya vasamodhāna bhūtā iva upanissaye eva antogadha tā hoti etad attham eva  hi sandhāya upanissayena ati avatvā upanissaya koṭiyā iti vuttam siddhe hi satya ārambhaḥ
translated: As to the proximity-cause, the object-predominance and the object-predominance-condition are included in the proximity-cause. But how is it that they are included in the proximity-cause? Because they are included in the proximity-cause by the proximity-cause of object, since they are similar as to object.🔽So they are included in the proximity-cause as if they were the proximity-cause of object. And it is with reference to this that it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “By the proximity-cause, by the proximity-cause-condition” ,

original: niyamāya vā hoti atthantaraviññāpanāya vāti. Evamīdisesu.
analyzed: niyamāya vā hoti atthantara viññāpanāya vā āti evamīdisesu
translated: not “by the proximity-cause-condition” , for the beginning of a statement is made for the purpose of a rule or for the purpose of conveying a different meaning.🔽So too in the case of the other kinds.

original: Catubbidhassāti kāmupādānaṃ yāva attavādupādānanti catubbidhassa. Nanu ca taṇhāva
analyzed: catubbidhassa ati kāma upādānam yāva attavāda upādānam ti catubbidhassa nanu ca
translated: As to the four kinds: as to the four kinds beginning with sense-desire as assuming and ending with the view of a self as assuming.🔽But surely craving is sense-desire as assuming. How can it be a condition for that?

original: kāmupādānaṃ, kathaṃ sāyeva tassa paccayo siyāti? Saccaṃ, purimataṇhāya pana upanissayapaccayena
analyzed: kāma upādānam katham sāya iva tassa paccayaḥ siyāti saccam purima taṇhāya pana upanissaya paccayena
translated: It is true, but it is the previous craving that is a condition for the subsequent craving by means of the proximity-cause-condition,

original: pacchimataṇhāya daḷhabhāvato purimāyeva taṇhā pacchimāya paccayo bhavati. Taṇhādaḷhattameva
analyzed: pacchima taṇhāya daḷha bhāvato purimāya iva taṇhā pacchimāya paccayaḥ bhavati taṇhā daḷha ttam eva
translated: since the latter is strong owing to the strength of the former craving. So it is the previous craving that is a condition for the subsequent craving.

original: hi “kāmupādānaṃ upāyāso upakaṭṭhā”tiādīsu viya upa-saddassa daḷhatthe pavattanato.
analyzed: hi kāma upādānam upāyāsaḥ upakaṭṭhā ti ādīsu viya upasaddassa daḷha atthe pavattanato
translated: for the prefix upa- occurs in the sense of “firmly” in such passages as “The clinging to sense pleasures is the firm basis for sorrow” .

original: Apica dubbalā taṇhā taṇhāyeva, balavatī taṇhā kāmupādānaṃ. Atha vā apattavisayapatthanā
analyzed: apica dubbalā taṇhā taṇhāya iva balavatī taṇhā kāma upādānam atha vā apatta visaya patthanā
translated: Moreover, craving is weak craving, and craving that is strong is clinging to sense pleasures. Or craving is a longing for an object not yet obtained,

original: taṇhā tamasi corānaṃ hatthapasāraṇaṃ viya, sampattavisayaggahaṇaṃ kāmupādānaṃ corānaṃ🔽hatthagatabhaṇḍaggahaṇaṃ viya. Appicchatāpaṭipakkhā taṇhā. Santuṭṭhitāpaṭipakkhaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā tamasi hattha pasāraṇam viya sampatta visaya ggahaṇam kāma upādānam  hattha gata bhaṇḍa ggahaṇam viya appiccha tā paṭipakkhā taṇhā santuṭṭhi tā paṭipakkham
translated: like the stretching out of a thief’s hand in the dark; clinging to sense pleasures is the grasping of an object already obtained,🔽like the thief’s seizing of the object in his hand. Craving is the opposite of fewness of wishes;

original: kāmupādānaṃ. Pariyesanadukkhamūlaṃ taṇhā, ārakkhadukkhamūlaṃ kāmupādānaṃ. Ayampi
analyzed: kāma upādānam pariyesana dukkha mūlam taṇhā ārakkha dukkha mūlam kāma upādānam ayam pi
translated: clinging to sense pleasures is the opposite of contentment. Craving is the root of the suffering of searching; clinging to sense pleasures is the root of the suffering of guarding.

original: tesaṃ viseso kecivādavasena ācariyadhammapālattherena dassito purimanayasseva visuddhimagge🔽sakavādabhāvena vuttattā.
analyzed: tesam visesaḥ keci vāda vasena ācariya dhammapāla ttherena dassitaḥ purima nayassa iva visuddhi magge  saka vāda bhāvena vutta ttā
translated: This is the difference between them. It was pointed out by the teacher Dhammapāla the Elder according to his own view. But in the Visuddhimagga it is given as his opponents’ view.

original: Asahajātassa upādānassa upanissayakoṭiyā, sahajātassa pana sahajātakoṭiyāti yathālābhamattho
analyzed: asahajātassa upādānassa upanissaya koṭiyā sahajātassa pana sahajāta koṭiyā ti yathālābham attho
translated: The meaning is according to circumstances: that of clinging associated with it by way of decisive support, and that of clinging associated with it by way of association.

original: gahetabbo. Tattha asahajātā anantaraniruddhā anantarasamanantaraanantarūpanissayanatthivigatāsevanapaccayehi
analyzed: tattha asahajātāḥ anantara niruddhāḥ anantara samanantara ananta rūpa nissaya natthi vigata āsevana paccayehi
translated: and it should be taken thus. Herein, the states associated with craving and the states that are its immediately following cessation are conditions for craving as non-concomitant states by means of the conditions consisting in mutuality, support, presence, dissociation, non-disappearance, and prenascence.

original: chadhā paccayo. Ārammaṇabhūtā pana ārammaṇamattaārammaṇādhipatiārammaṇūpanissayehi
analyzed: chadhā paccayaḥ ārammaṇa bhūtā pana ārammaṇa matta ārammaṇa adhipati ārammaṇa upanissayehi
translated: But those that are its object are conditions for it as object by means of the conditions consisting in object, predominance, and decisive-support.

original: tidhā, taṃ sabbampi vuttanayena upanissayeneva saṅgahetvā “upanissayakoṭiyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tidhā tam sabbam pi vutta nayena upanissayena iva saṅgahetvā upanissaya koṭiyā iti vuttam
translated: And all these are included in the decisive-support condition itself, which is why it is said, “as decisive-support” .

original: Yasmā ca taṇhāya rūpādīni assādetvā kāmesu pātabyataṃ āpajjati, tasmā taṇhā kāmupādānassa
analyzed: yasmā ca taṇhāya rūpa ādīni assādetvā kāmesu pātabyatam āpajjati tasmā taṇhā kāma upādānassa
translated: And since craving delights in visible data, etc., and so makes one addicted to sense desires, craving is a condition for sense-desire clinging as decisive-support.

original: upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo. Tathā rūpādibhede sammūḷho “natthi dinna”ntiādinā micchādassanaṃ,
analyzed: upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ tathā rūpa ādi bhede sammūḷhaḥ natthi micchādassanam
translated: Similarly, one who is confused about the kinds of visible data, etc., as to whether they are given or not, etc., holds the wrong view that there is no giving, etc.;

original: saṃsārato muccitukāmo asuddhimagge suddhimaggaparāmasanaṃ, khandhesu attattaniyagāhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: saṃsārataḥ muccitu kāmaḥ a suddhi magge suddhi magga parāmasanam khandhesu
translated: one who wants to be released from saṃsāra holds the view that misapprehends an impure path as the pure path; and one who misapprehends the aggregates as a self or as pertaining to a self holds personality view.

original: sakkāyadassanañca gaṇhāti. Tasmā itaresampi tiṇṇaṃ taṇhā upanissayakoṭiyā paccayoti
analyzed: sakkāya dassanam ca gaṇhāti tasmai itaresam pi tiṇṇam taṇhā upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ ti
translated: So craving is a condition for the other three kinds of clinging as decisive-support.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sahajātā pana sahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttaatthiavigatahetuvasena🔽sattadhā sahajātānaṃ paccayo. Tampi sabbaṃ sahajātapaccayeneva saṅgahetvā “sahajātakoṭiyā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Bhavassāti kammabhavassa ceva upapattibhavassa ca. Tattha cetanādisaṅkhātaṃ sabbaṃ🔽bhavagāmikammaṃ kammabhavo. Kāmabhavādinavavidho upapattibhavo. Tesu upapattibhavassa
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sahajātā pana sahajāta aññamañña nissaya sampayutta atthi avigata hetu vasena  sattadhā sahajātānam paccayo tat pi sabbam sahajāta paccayena iva saṅgahetvā sahajāta koṭiyā iti vuttam  bhavassa ati kamma bhavassa ca iva upapatti bhavassa ca tattha cetanā ādi saṅkhātam sabbam  bhava gāmi kammam kamma bhavaḥ kāma bhava ādi navavidhaḥ upapatti bhavo tesu upapatti bhavassa
translated: But the conascent are a condition for conascent states in seven ways as conascence, mutuality, support, association, presence, non-disappearance, and root.🔽And all that is included in the condition being stated as conascence condition.🔽“In the becoming” is in kamma-process becoming and rebirth-process becoming. Herein, all kamma that leads to becoming, called “cetanā” , etc.,🔽is kamma-process becoming. The nine-fold rebirth-process becoming is rebirth-process becoming.🔽Herein, the kamma-process becoming is a condition for the rebirth-process becoming in the way beginning “Kamma is a condition as kamma-condition for the kamma-originated kinds of materiality” .🔽

original: catubbidhampi upādānaṃ upapattibhavahetubhūtassa kammabhavassa kāraṇabhāvato, tassa🔽ca sahāyabhāvūpagamanato pakatūpanissayavasena paccayo. Kammārammaṇakaraṇakāle pana🔽kammasahajātamupādānaṃ upapattibhavassa ārammaṇavasena paccayo. Kammabhavassa pana
analyzed: catubbidham pi upādānam upapatti bhava hetu bhūtassa kamma bhavassa kāraṇa bhāvato tassa  ca sahāya bhāva upagamanataḥ pakata upanissaya vasena paccayaḥ kamma ārammaṇa karaṇa kāle pana  kamma sahajātam upādānam upapatti bhavassa ārammaṇa vasena paccayaḥ kamma bhavassa pana
translated: but it is to be understood as the condition by way of the condition being conascent and the conditioned being conascent, etc.,
